{'sentences': [u'Nebraska /n\u0259\u02c8br\xe6sk\u0259/ is a state that lies in both the Great Plains and the Midwestern United States.', u'The state is bordered by South Dakota to the north, Iowa to the east and Missouri to the southeast, both across the Missouri River, Kansas to the south, Colorado to the southwest and Wyoming to the west.', u'Its area is just over 77,220 sq mi (200,000 km2) with almost 1.9 million people.', u'Its state capital is Lincoln.', u'Its largest city is Omaha, which is on the Missouri River.', u'Indigenous peoples including Omaha, Missouria, Ponca, Pawnee, Otoe, and various branches of the Lakota (Sioux) tribes lived in the region of present-day Nebraska for thousands of years before European exploration.', u'The state is crossed by many historic trails and was explored by the Lewis and Clark Expedition.', u'Nebraska was admitted as the 37th state of the United States in 1867.', u'It is the only state in the United States whose legislature is unicameral and officially nonpartisan.', u'Nebraska is composed of two major land regions: the Dissected Till Plains and the Great Plains.', u'The Dissected Till Plains is a region of gently rolling hills; the states largest cities, Omaha and Lincoln, are in this region.', u'The Great Plains occupy most of western Nebraska, characterized by treeless prairie, suitable for cattle-grazing.', u'The state has a large agriculture sector and is a major producer of beef, pork, corn, and soybeans.', u'Two major climatic zones are represented in Nebraska: the eastern half of the state has a humid continental climate (K\xf6ppen climate classification Dfa), and the western half, a semi-arid climate (Koppen BSk).', u'The entire state has wide variations between winter and summer temperatures, and violent thunderstorms and tornadoes happen primarily during the spring and summer, though they can also occur in the autumn.', u'== Etymology ==\nNebraska\'s name is derived from transliteration of the archaic Otoe words \xd1\xed Br\xe1sge, pronounced [\u0272\u0129b\u027eas\ua71ck\u025b] (contemporary Otoe \xd1\xed Br\xe1hge), or the Omaha N\xed Bth\xe1ska, pronounced [n\u0129b\u026b\u1d9eas\ua71cka], meaning "flat water", after the Platte River that flows through the state.', u'== History ==\n\nIndigenous peoples lived in the region of present-day Nebraska for thousands of years before European exploration.', u'The historic tribes in the state included the Omaha, Missouria, Ponca, Pawnee, Otoe, and various branches of the Lakota (Sioux), some of which migrated from eastern areas into this region.', u'When European exploration, trade, and settlement began, both Spain and France sought to control the region.', u'In the 1690s, Spain established trade connections with the Apaches, whose territory then included western Nebraska.', u'By 1703, France had developed a regular trade with the native peoples along the Missouri River in Nebraska, and by 1719 had signed treaties with several of these peoples.', u'After war broke out between the two countries, Spain dispatched an armed expedition to Nebraska under Lieutenant General Pedro de Villasur in 1720.', u'The party was attacked and destroyed near present-day Columbus by a large force of Pawnees and Otoes, both allied to the French.', u'The massacre of the Villasur expedition effectively put an end to Spanish exploration of Nebraska for the remainder of the 18th century.', u"In 1762, during the Seven Years' War, France ceded the Louisiana territory to Spain.", u"France's withdrawal from the area left Britain and Spain competing for dominance along the Mississippi; by 1773, the British were trading with the native peoples of Nebraska.", u'In response, Spain dispatched two trading expeditions up the Missouri in 1794 and 1795; the second, under James Mackay, established the first European settlement in Nebraska near the mouth of the Platte.', u"Later that year, Mackay's party built a trading post, dubbed Fort Carlos IV (Fort Charles), near present-day Homer.", u'In 1819, the United States established Fort Atkinson as the first US Army post west of the Missouri River, just east of present-day Fort Calhoun.', u'The army abandoned the fort in 1827 as migration moved further west.', u'European-American settlement did not begin in any numbers until after 1848 and the California Gold Rush.', u'On May 30, 1854, the US Congress created the Kansas and the Nebraska territories, divided by the Parallel 40\xb0 North, under the Kansas\u2013Nebraska Act.', u'The Nebraska Territory included parts of the current states of Colorado, North Dakota, South Dakota, Wyoming, and Montana.', u'The territorial capital of Nebraska was Omaha.', u'In the 1860s, after the US government forced many of the Native American tribes to cede their lands and settle on reservations, it opened large tracts of land to agricultural development by Europeans and Americans.', u'Under the Homestead Act, thousands of settlers migrated into Nebraska to claim free land granted by the federal government.', u'Because so few trees grew on the prairies, many of the first farming settlers built their homes of sod, as had the Native Americans such as the Omaha.', u'The first wave of settlement gave the territory a sufficient population to apply for statehood.', u'Nebraska became the 37th state on March 1, 1867, and the capital was moved from Omaha to the center at Lancaster, later renamed Lincoln after the recently assassinated President of the United States, Abraham Lincoln.', u'The battle of Massacre Canyon on August 5, 1873, was the last major battle between the Pawnee and the Sioux.', u'During the 1870s to the 1880s, Nebraska experienced a large growth in population.', u'Several factors contributed to attracting new residents.', u'The first was that the vast prairie land was perfect for cattle grazing.', u'This helped settlers to learn the unfamiliar geography of the area.', u'The second factor was the invention of several farming technologies.', u'Agricultural inventions such as barbed wire, wind mills, and the steel plow, combined with good weather, enabled settlers to make use of Nebraska as prime farming land.', u"By the 1880s, Nebraska's population had soared to more than 450,000 people.", u'The Arbor Day holiday was founded in Nebraska City by territorial governor J.', u'Sterling Morton.', u'The National Arbor Day Foundation is still headquartered in Nebraska City, with some offices in Lincoln.', u'In the late nineteenth century, many African Americans migrated from the South to Nebraska as part of the Great Migration, primarily to Omaha which offered working class jobs in meatpacking, the railroads and other industries.', u'Omaha has a long history of civil rights activism.', u'Blacks encountered discrimination from other Americans in Omaha and especially from recent European immigrants, ethnic whites who were competing for the same jobs.', u'In 1912, African Americans founded the Omaha chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to work for improved conditions in the city and state.', u'Since the 1960s, Native American activism in the state has increased, both through open protest, activities to build alliances with state and local governments, and in the slower, more extensive work of building tribal institutions and infrastructure.', u'Native Americans in federally recognized tribes have pressed for self-determination, sovereignty and recognition.', u'They have created community schools to preserve their cultures, as well as tribal colleges and universities.', u'Tribal politicians have also collaborated with state and county officials on regional issues.', u'== Geography ==\n\nThe state is bordered by South Dakota to the north; Iowa to the east and Missouri to the southeast, across the Missouri River; Kansas to the south; Colorado to the southwest; and Wyoming to the west.', u'The state has 93 counties; it occupies the central portion of the Frontier Strip.', u"Nebraska is split into two time zones, with the state's eastern half observing Central Time and the western half observing Mountain Time.", u'Three rivers cross the state from west to east.', u"The Platte River, formed by the confluence of the North Platte and the South Platte, runs through the state's central portion, the Niobrara River flows through the northern part, and the Republican River runs across the southern part.", u'Nebraska is composed of two major land regions: the Dissected Till Plains and the Great Plains.', u'The easternmost portion of the state was scoured by Ice Age glaciers; the Dissected Till Plains were left after the glaciers retreated.', u'The Dissected Till Plains is a region of gently rolling hills; Omaha and Lincoln are in this region.', u'The Great Plains occupy most of western Nebraska.', u'The Great Plains region consists of several across Nebraska, with hot summers and generally cold winters.', u'Average annual precipitation decreases east to west from about 31.5 inches (800 mm) in the southeast corner of the state to about 13.8 inches (350 mm) in the Panhandle.', u'Humidity also decreases significantly from east to west.', u'Snowfall across the state is fairly even, with most of Nebraska receiving between 25 and 35 inches progressive income tax.', u'The portion of income from $0 to $2,400 is taxed at 2.56%; from $2,400 to $17,500, at 3.57%; from $17,500 to $27,000, at 5.12%; and income over $27,000, at 6.84%.', u'The standard deduction for a single taxpayer is $5,700; the personal exemption is $118.', u'Nebraska has a state sales and use tax of 5.5%.', u'In addition to the state tax, some Nebraska cities assess a city sales and use tax, in 0.5% increments, up to a maximum of 1.5%.', u'One county in Nebraska, Dakota County, levies an additional 0.5% county sales tax.', u'Food and ingredients that are generally for home preparation and consumption are not taxable.', u'All real property within the state of Nebraska is taxable unless specifically exempted by statute.', u'Since 1992, only depreciable personal operations in the state are: Amtrak; BNSF Railway; Canadian Pacific Railway; and Iowa Interstate Railroad.', u'=== Roads and highways ===\n\nInterstate Highways through the State of Nebraska     The U.S.', u"Routes in Nebraska                 \n\n\n== Law and government ==\nNebraska's government operates under the framework of the Nebraska Constitution, adopted in 1875, and is divided into three branches: executive, legislative, and judicial.", u'=== Executive branch ===\n\nThe head of the executive branch is Governor Pete Ricketts.', u'Other elected officials in the executive branch are Lieutenant Governor Mike Foley, Attorney General Doug Peterson, Secretary of State John A. Gale, State Treasurer Don Stenberg, and State Auditor Charlie Janssen.', u'All elected officials in the executive branch serve four-year terms.', u'=== Legislative branch ===\n\nNebraska is the only state in the United States with a unicameral legislature.', u'Although this house is officially known simply as the "Legislature", and more commonly called the "Unicameral", its members call themselves "senators".', u"Nebraska's Legislature is also the only state legislature in the United States that is officially nonpartisan.", u'The senators are elected with no party affiliation next to their names on the ballot, and the speaker and committee chairs are chosen at large, so that members of any party can be chosen for these positions.', u"The Nebraska Legislature can also override a governor's veto with a three-fifths majority, in contrast to the two-thirds majority required in some other states.", u'The Legislature meets in the third Nebraska State Capitol building, built between 1922 and 1932.', u'It was designed by Bertram G. Goodhue.', u"Built from Indiana limestone, the capitol's base is a cross within a square.", u'A 400-foot domed tower rises from this base.', u'The Sower, a 19-foot bronze statue representing agriculture, crowns the building.', u'When Nebraska became a state in 1867, its legislature consisted of two houses: a House of Representatives and a Senate.', u'For years, US Senator George Norris and other Nebraskans encouraged the idea of a unicameral legislature, and demanded the issue be decided in a referendum.', u'Norris argued:\n\nThe constitutions of our various states are built upon the idea that there is but one class.', u'If this be true, there is no sense or reason in having the same thing done twice, especially if it is to be done by two bodies of men elected in the same way and having the same jurisdiction.', u'Unicameral supporters also argued that a bicameral legislature had a significant undemocratic feature in the committees that reconciled House and Senate legislation.', u'Votes in these committees were secretive, and would sometimes add provisions to bills that neither house had approved.', u"Nebraska's unicameral legislature today has rules that bills can contain only one subject, and must be given at least five days of consideration.", u'In 1934, due in part to the budgetary pressure of the Great Depression, Nebraska citizens ran a state initiative to vote on a constitutional amendment creating a unicameral legislature, which was approved.', u'In effect, the House of Representatives (the lower house) was abolished; today\'s Nebraska state legislators are commonly referred to as "Senators".', u'=== Judicial branch ===\n\nThe judicial system in Nebraska is unified, with the Nebraska Supreme Court having administrative authority over all Nebraska courts.', u'Nebraska uses the Missouri Plan for the selection of judges at all levels.', u'The lowest courts in Nebraska are the county courts, above that are twelve district courts (containing one or more counties).', u"The Court of Appeals hears appeals from the district courts, juvenile courts, and workers' compensation courts.", u'The Nebraska Supreme Court is the final court of appeal.', u"=== Federal government representation ===\n\nNebraska's U.S. senators are Deb Fischer and Ben Sasse, both Republicans; Fischer, elected in 2012, is the senior.", u'Nebraska has three representatives in the House of Representatives: Jeff Fortenberry (R) of the 1st district; Brad Ashford (D) of the 2nd district; and Adrian Smith (R) of the 3rd district.', u"Nebraska is one of two states (with Maine) that allow for a split in the state's allocation of electoral votes in presidential elections.", u"Under a 1991 law, two of Nebraska's five votes are awarded to the winner of the statewide popular vote, while the other three go to the highest vote-getter in each of the state's three congressional districts.", u'=== Politics ===\n\nFor most of its history, Nebraska has been a solidly Republican state.', u'Republicans have carried the state in all but one presidential election since 1940: the 1964 landslide election of Lyndon B. Johnson.', u"In the 2004 presidential election, George W. Bush won the state's five electoral votes by a margin of 33 percentage points (making Nebraska's the fourth-strongest Republican vote among states) with 65.9% of the overall vote; only Thurston County, which is majority-Native American, voted for his Democratic challenger John Kerry.", u'In 2008, the state split its electoral votes for the first time: Republican John McCain won the popular vote in Nebraska as a whole and two of its three congressional districts; the second district, which includes the city of Omaha, went for Democrat Barack Obama.', u'Despite the current Republican domination of Nebraska politics, the state has a long tradition of electing centrist members of both parties to state and federal office; examples include George Norris (who served few years in the Senate as an independent), J. James Exon, and Bob Kerrey.', u'Voters have tilted to the right in recent years with the election of conservative Mike Johanns to the U.S. Senate and the 2006 re-election of Ben Nelson, who was considered the most conservative Democrat in the Senate until his retirement in 2013, when he was replaced by conservative Republican Deb Fischer.', u'Former President Gerald Ford was born in Nebraska, but moved away shortly after birth.', u'Illinois native William Jennings Bryan represented Nebraska in Congress, served as U.S. Secretary of State under President Woodrow Wilson, and unsuccessfully ran for President three times.', u"== Education ==\n\n\n=== Colleges and universities ===\n\n\n== Sports ==\n\n\n=== Professional sports ===\nNebraska Stampede - Women's Football Alliance\nLincoln Saltdogs \u2013 American Association (independent minor league baseball)\nNebraska Danger \u2013 Indoor Football League\nOmaha Beef \u2013 Indoor Football League\nOmaha Storm Chasers \u2013 Pacific Coast League (AAA minor league baseball; affiliate of the Kansas City Royals)\nOmaha Vipers \u2013 Major Indoor Soccer League (folded)\n\n\n=== Junior-level sports ===\nUnited States Hockey League\nLincoln Stars\nOmaha Lancers\nTri-City Storm\n\n\n=== College sports ===\n\n\n==== NCAA Division I sports ====\nThe College World Series has been held in Omaha since 1950.", u'It was held at Rosenblatt Stadium from 1950 through 2010, and at TD Ameritrade Park Omaha since 2011.', u'The following are National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I college sports programs in Nebraska.', u'==== NCAA Division II sports ====\nNebraska has several colleges playing at the NCAA Division II level.', u'==== NAIA sports ====\n\n\n== See also ==\n\nOutline of Nebraska \u2013 organized list of topics about Nebraska\nIndex of Nebraska-related articles\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== Bibliography ==\n\n\n=== Surveys ===\n\n\n=== Scholarly special studies ===\n\n\n== External links ==\n\nNebraska state government\nNebraska Division of Travel and Tourism\nEnergy Profile for Nebraska\nUSGS real-time, geographic, and other scientific resources of Nebraska\nNebraska State Facts from USDA\nNebraska Frequently Asked Questions\nNebraska State Publications Online\nNebraska city-data\nNebraska at DMOZ\nnebraskastudies.org \u2013 History of Nebraska from Nebraska Department of Education, Nebraska State Historical Society, and NET\nNebraska State Databases \u2013 Annotated list of searchable databases produced by Nebraska state agencies and compiled by the Government Documents Roundtable of the American Library Association.', u'Geographic data related to Nebraska at OpenStreetMap'], 'year': '1867-03-01', 'title': 'Nebraska becomes 37th state'}
{'sentences': [u'Adolf Hitler (German: [\u02c8ad\u0254lf \u02c8h\u026atl\u0250]; 20 April 1889 \u2013 30 April 1945) was a German politician who was the leader of the Nazi Party (Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei; NSDAP), Chancellor of Germany from 1933 to 1945, and F\xfchrer ("leader") of Nazi Germany from 1934 to 1945.', u'As dictator of the German Reich, he initiated World War II in Europe with the invasion of Poland in September 1939 and was a central figure of the Holocaust.', u'Hitler was born in Austria, then part of Austria-Hungary, and raised near Linz.', u'He moved to Germany in 1913 and was decorated during his service in the German Army in World War I.', u"He joined the German Workers' Party, the precursor of the NSDAP, in 1919 and became leader of the NSDAP in 1921.", u'In 1923, he attempted a coup in Munich to seize power.', u'The failed coup resulted in Hitler\'s imprisonment, during which time he dictated the first volume of his autobiography and political manifesto Mein Kampf ("My Struggle").', u'After his release in 1924, Hitler gained popular support by attacking the Treaty of Versailles and promoting Pan-Germanism, anti-Semitism, and anti-communism with charismatic oratory and Nazi propaganda.', u'Hitler frequently denounced international capitalism and communism as being part of a Jewish conspiracy.', u"By 1933, the Nazi Party was the largest elected party in the German Reichstag, which led to Hitler's appointment as Chancellor on 30 January 1933.", u'Following fresh elections won by his coalition, the Reichstag passed the Enabling Act, which began the process of transforming the Weimar Republic into Nazi Germany, a one-party dictatorship based on the totalitarian and autocratic ideology of National Socialism.', u'Hitler aimed to eliminate Jews from Germany and establish a New Order to counter what he saw as the injustice of the post-World War I international order dominated by Britain and France.', u'His first six years in power resulted in rapid economic recovery from the Great Depression, the effective abandonment of restrictions imposed on Germany after World War I, and the annexation of territories that were home to millions of ethnic Germans\u2014actions which gave him significant popular support.', u'Hitler sought Lebensraum ("living space") for the German people in Eastern Europe.', u'His aggressive foreign policy is considered to be the primary cause of the outbreak of World War II in Europe.', u'He directed large-scale rearmament and on 1 September 1939 invaded Poland, resulting in British and French declarations of war on Germany.', u'In June 1941, Hitler ordered an invasion of the Soviet Union.', u'By the end of 1941 German forces and the European Axis powers occupied most of Europe and North Africa.', u'Failure to defeat the Soviets and the entry of the United States into the war forced Germany onto the defensive and it suffered a series of escalating defeats.', u'In the final days of the war, during the Battle of Berlin in 1945, Hitler married his long-time lover, Eva Braun.', u'On 30 April 1945, less than two days later, the two killed themselves to avoid capture by the Red Army, and their corpses were burned.', u'Under Hitler\'s leadership and racially motivated ideology, the Nazi regime was responsible for the genocide of at least 5.5 million Jews and millions of other victims whom he and his followers deemed Untermenschen ("sub-humans") and socially undesirable.', u'Hitler and the Nazi regime were also responsible for the killing of an estimated 19.3 million civilians and prisoners of war.', u'In addition, 29 million soldiers and civilians died as a result of military action in the European Theatre of World War II.', u'The number of civilians killed during the Second World War was unprecedented in warfare, and constitutes the deadliest conflict in human history.', u"== Early years ==\n\n\n=== Ancestry ===\nHitler's father Alois Hitler, Sr. (1837\u20131903) was the illegitimate child of Maria Anna Schicklgruber.", u"The baptismal register did not show the name of his father, and Alois initially bore his mother's surname Schicklgruber.", u"In 1842, Johann Georg Hiedler married Alois's mother Maria Anna.", u"Alois was brought up in the family of Hiedler's brother, Johann Nepomuk Hiedler.", u'In 1876, Alois was legitimated and the baptismal register changed by a priest to register Johann Georg Hiedler as Alois\'s father (recorded as "Georg Hitler").', u'Alois then assumed the surname "Hitler", also spelled as Hiedler, H\xfcttler, or Huettler.', u'The Hitler surname is probably based on "one who lives in a hut" (German H\xfctte for "hut").', u"Nazi official Hans Frank suggested that Alois's mother had been employed as a housekeeper for a Jewish family in Graz, and that the family's 19-year-old son Leopold Frankenberger had fathered Alois.", u"No Frankenberger was registered in Graz during that period, and no record has been produced of Leopold Frankenberger's existence, so historians dismiss the claim that Alois's father was Jewish.", u'=== Childhood and education ===\n\nAdolf Hitler was born on 20 April 1889 in Braunau am Inn, a town in Austria-Hungary (in present-day Austria), close to the border with the German Empire.', u'He was one of six children born to Alois Hitler and Klara P\xf6lzl (1860\u20131907).', u"Three of Hitler's siblings\u2014Gustav, Ida, and Otto\u2014died in infancy.", u'When Hitler was three, the family moved to Passau, Germany.', u'There he acquired the distinctive lower Bavarian dialect, rather than Austrian German, which marked his speech throughout his life.', u'The family returned to Austria and settled in Leonding in 1894, and in June 1895 Alois retired to Hafeld, near Lambach, where he farmed and kept bees.', u'Hitler attended Volksschule (a state-owned school) in nearby Fischlham.', u"The move to Hafeld coincided with the onset of intense father-son conflicts caused by Hitler's refusal to conform to the strict discipline of his school.", u"Alois Hitler's farming efforts at Hafeld ended in failure, and in 1897 the family moved to Lambach.", u'The eight-year-old Hitler took singing lessons, sang in the church choir, and even considered becoming a priest.', u'In 1898 the family returned permanently to Leonding.', u'The death of his younger brother Edmund, who died from measles in 1900, deeply affected Hitler.', u'He changed from a confident, outgoing, conscientious student to a morose, detached boy who constantly fought with his father and teachers.', u'Alois had made a successful career in the customs bureau and wanted his son to follow in his footsteps.', u'Hitler later dramatised an episode from this period when his father took him to visit a customs office, depicting it as an event that gave rise to an unforgiving antagonism between father and son, who were both strong-willed.', u"Ignoring his son's desire to attend a classical high school and become an artist, Alois sent Hitler to the Realschule in Linz in September 1900.", u'Hitler rebelled against this decision, and in Mein Kampf stated that he intentionally did poorly in school, hoping that once his father saw "what little progress I was making at the technical school he would let me devote myself to my dream".', u'Like many Austrian Germans, Hitler began to develop German nationalist ideas from a young age.', u'He expressed loyalty only to Germany, despising the declining Habsburg Monarchy and its rule over an ethnically variegated empire.', u'Hitler and his friends used the greeting "Heil", and sang the "Deutschlandlied" instead of the Austrian Imperial anthem.', u"After Alois's sudden death on 3 January 1903, Hitler's performance at school deteriorated and his mother allowed him to leave.", u'He enrolled at the Realschule in Steyr in September 1904, where his behaviour and performance improved.', u'In 1905, after passing a repeat of the final exam, Hitler left the school without any ambitions for further education or clear plans for a career.', u"=== Early adulthood in Vienna and Munich ===\n\nFrom 1905, Hitler lived a bohemian life in Vienna, financed by orphan's benefits and support from his mother.", u"He worked as a casual labourer and eventually as a painter, selling watercolours of Vienna's sights.", u'The Academy of Fine Arts Vienna rejected him in 1907 and again in 1908, citing "unfitness for painting".', u'The director recommended that Hitler study architecture, which was also an interest, but he lacked academic credentials as he had not finished secondary school.', u'On 21 December 1907, his mother died of breast cancer at the age of 47.', u"Hitler ran out of money and was forced to live in homeless shelters and men's hostels.", u'At the time Hitler lived there, Vienna was a hotbed of religious prejudice and racism.', u'Fears of being overrun by immigrants from the East were widespread, and the populist mayor Karl Lueger exploited the rhetoric of virulent anti-Semitism for political effect.', u'German nationalism had a widespread following in the Mariahilf district, where Hitler lived.', u'German nationalist Georg Ritter von Sch\xf6nerer, who advocated Pan-Germanism, anti-Semitism, anti-Slavism, and anti-Catholicism, was one influence on Hitler.', u'Hitler read local newspapers such as the Deutsches Volksblatt that fanned prejudice and played on Christian fears of being swamped by an influx of eastern Jews.', u'Hitler also read newspapers that published the main thoughts of philosophers and theoreticians such as Darwin, Nietzsche, Le Bon and Schopenhauer.', u'Hostile to what he saw as "Catholic Germanophobia", he developed an admiration for Martin Luther.', u"The origin and first expression of Hitler's anti-Semitism remain a matter of debate.", u'Hitler states in Mein Kampf that he first became an anti-Semite in Vienna.', u'His close friend, August Kubizek, claimed that Hitler was a "confirmed anti-Semite" before he left Linz.', u'Several sources provide strong evidence that Hitler had Jewish friends in his hostel and in other places in Vienna.', u'Historian Richard J. Evans states that "historians now generally agree that his notorious, murderous anti-Semitism emerged well after Germany\'s defeat [in World War I], as a product of the paranoid "stab-in-the-back" explanation for the catastrophe".', u"Hitler received the final part of his father's estate in May 1913 and moved to Munich.", u'Historians believe he left Vienna to evade conscription into the Austro-Hungarian Army.', u'Hitler later claimed that he did not wish to serve Austria-Hungary because of the mixture of races in its armed forces.', u'After he was deemed unfit for service\u2014he failed his physical exam in Salzburg on 5 February 1914\u2014he returned to Munich.', u'=== World War I ===\n\nIn 1914, at the outbreak of World War I, Hitler was living in Munich and voluntarily enlisted in the Bavarian Army.', u'According to a 1924 report by the Bavarian authorities, allowing Hitler to serve was almost certainly an administrative error, since as an Austrian citizen, he should have been returned to Austria.', u'Posted to the Bavarian Reserve Infantry Regiment 16 (1st Company of the List Regiment), he served as a dispatch runner on the Western Front in France and Belgium, spending nearly half his time at the regimental headquarters in Fournes-en-Weppes, well behind the front lines.', u'He was present at the First Battle of Ypres, the Battle of the Somme, the Battle of Arras, and the Battle of Passchendaele, and was wounded at the Somme.', u'He was decorated for bravery, receiving the Iron Cross, Second Class, in 1914.', u"On a recommendation by Lieutenant Hugo Gutmann, Hitler's Jewish superior, he received the Iron Cross, First Class on 4 August 1918, a decoration rarely awarded to one of Hitler's Gefreiter rank.", u'He received the Black Wound Badge on 18 May 1918.', u'During his service at headquarters, Hitler pursued his artwork, drawing cartoons and instructions for an army newspaper.', u"During the Battle of the Somme in October 1916, he was wounded in the left thigh when a shell exploded in the dispatch runners' dugout.", u'Hitler spent almost two months in hospital at Beelitz, returning to his regiment on 5 March 1917.', u'On 15 October 1918, he was temporarily blinded in a mustard gas attack and was hospitalised in Pasewalk.', u"While there, Hitler learnt of Germany's defeat, and\u2014by his own account\u2014upon receiving this news, he suffered a second bout of blindness.", u'Hitler described the war as "the greatest of all experiences", and was praised by his commanding officers for his bravery.', u"His wartime experience reinforced his German patriotism and he was shocked by Germany's capitulation in November 1918.", u'His bitterness over the collapse of the war effort began to shape his ideology.', u'Like other German nationalists, he believed the Dolchsto\xdflegende (stab-in-the-back myth), which claimed that the German army, "undefeated in the field", had been "stabbed in the back" on the home front by civilian leaders and Marxists, later dubbed the "November criminals".', u'The Treaty of Versailles stipulated that Germany must relinquish several of its territories and demilitarise the Rhineland.', u'The treaty imposed economic sanctions and levied heavy reparations on the country.', u'Many Germans saw the treaty as an unjust humiliation\u2014they especially objected to Article 231, which they interpreted as declaring Germany responsible for the war.', u'The Versailles Treaty and the economic, social, and political conditions in Germany after the war were later exploited by Hitler for political gain.', u'== Entry into politics ==\n\nAfter World War I, Hitler returned to Munich.', u'With no formal education or career prospects, he remained in the army.', u"In July 1919 he was appointed Verbindungsmann (intelligence agent) of an Aufkl\xe4rungskommando (reconnaissance commando) of the Reichswehr, assigned to influence other soldiers and to infiltrate the German Workers' Party (DAP).", u"While monitoring the activities of the DAP, Hitler was attracted to the founder Anton Drexler's anti-Semitic, nationalist, anti-capitalist, and anti-Marxist ideas.", u'Drexler favoured a strong active government, a non-Jewish version of socialism, and solidarity among all members of society.', u"Impressed with Hitler's oratorical skills, Drexler invited him to join the DAP.", u'Hitler accepted on 12 September 1919, becoming party member 555 (the party began counting membership at 500 to give the impression they were a much larger party).', u"At the DAP, Hitler met Dietrich Eckart, one of the party's founders and a member of the occult Thule Society.", u"Eckart became Hitler's mentor, exchanging ideas with him and introducing him to a wide range of Munich society.", u'To increase its appeal, the DAP changed its name to the Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei (National Socialist German Workers Party; NSDAP).', u"Hitler designed the party's banner of a swastika in a white circle on a red background.", u'Hitler was discharged from the army on 31 March 1920 and began working full-time for the NSDAP.', u'The party headquarters was in Munich, a hotbed of anti-government German nationalists determined to crush Marxism and undermine the Weimar Republic.', u'In February 1921\u2014already highly effective at speaking to large audiences\u2014he spoke to a crowd of over 6,000.', u'To publicise the meeting, two truckloads of party supporters drove around Munich waving swastika flags and distributing leaflets.', u'Hitler soon gained notoriety for his rowdy polemic speeches against the Treaty of Versailles, rival politicians, and especially against Marxists and Jews.', u'In June 1921, while Hitler and Eckart were on a fundraising trip to Berlin, a mutiny broke out within the NSDAP in Munich.', u'Members of its executive committee wanted to merge with the rival German Socialist Party (DSP).', u'Hitler returned to Munich on 11 July and angrily tendered his resignation.', u'The committee members realised that the resignation of their leading public figure and speaker would mean the end of the party.', u'Hitler announced he would rejoin on the condition that he would replace Drexler as party chairman, and that the party headquarters would remain in Munich.', u'The committee agreed, and he rejoined the party on 26 July as member 3,680.', u'Hitler continued to face some opposition within the NSDAP: Opponents of Hitler in the leadership had Hermann Esser expelled from the party, and they printed 3,000 copies of a pamphlet attacking Hitler as a traitor to the party.', u'In the following days, Hitler spoke to several packed houses and defended himself and Esser, to thunderous applause.', u'His strategy proved successful, and at a special party congress on 29 July, he was granted absolute powers as party chairman, replacing Drexler, by a vote of 533 to 1.', u"Hitler's vitriolic beer hall speeches began attracting regular audiences.", u"He became adept at using populist themes, including the use of scapegoats, who were blamed for his listeners' economic hardships.", u'Hitler used personal magnetism and an understanding of crowd psychology to his advantage while engaged in public speaking.', u'Historians have noted the hypnotic effect of his rhetoric on large audiences, and of his eyes in small groups.', u'Alfons Heck, a former member of the Hitler Youth, later recalled:\n\nWe erupted into a frenzy of nationalistic pride that bordered on hysteria.', u'For minutes on end, we shouted at the top of our lungs, with tears streaming down our faces: Sieg Heil, Sieg Heil, Sieg Heil!', u'From that moment on, I belonged to Adolf Hitler body and soul.', u'Some visitors who met Hitler privately noted that his appearance and demeanour failed to make a lasting impression.', u'Early followers included Rudolf Hess, former air force ace Hermann G\xf6ring, and army captain Ernst R\xf6hm.', u'R\xf6hm became head of the Nazis\' paramilitary organisation, the Sturmabteilung (SA, "Stormtroopers"), which protected meetings and attacked political opponents.', u"A critical influence on Hitler's thinking during this period was the Aufbau Vereinigung, a conspiratorial group of White Russian exiles and early National Socialists.", u'The group, financed with funds channelled from wealthy industrialists, introduced Hitler to the idea of a Jewish conspiracy, linking international finance with Bolshevism.', u'=== Beer Hall Putsch ===\n\nIn 1923 Hitler enlisted the help of World War I General Erich Ludendorff for an attempted coup known as the "Beer Hall Putsch".', u'The NSDAP used Italian Fascism as a model for their appearance and policies.', u'Hitler wanted to emulate Benito Mussolini\'s "March on Rome" of 1922 by staging his own coup in Bavaria, to be followed by a challenge to the government in Berlin.', u"Hitler and Ludendorff sought the support of Staatskommissar (state commissioner) Gustav Ritter von Kahr, Bavaria's de facto ruler.", u'However, Kahr, along with Police Chief Hans Ritter von Seisser and Reichswehr General Otto von Lossow, wanted to install a nationalist dictatorship without Hitler.', u'On 8 November 1923 Hitler and the SA stormed a public meeting of 3,000 people organised by Kahr in the B\xfcrgerbr\xe4ukeller, a beer hall in Munich.', u"Interrupting Kahr's speech, he announced that the national revolution had begun and declared the formation of a new government with Ludendorff.", u'Retiring to a back room, Hitler, with handgun drawn, demanded and got the support of Kahr, Seisser, and Lossow.', u"Hitler's forces initially succeeded in occupying the local Reichswehr and police headquarters, but Kahr and his cohorts quickly withdrew their support.", u'Neither the army nor the state police joined forces with Hitler.', u'The next day, Hitler and his followers marched from the beer hall to the Bavarian War Ministry to overthrow the Bavarian government, but police dispersed them.', u'Sixteen NSDAP members and four police officers were killed in the failed coup.', u'Hitler fled to the home of Ernst Hanfstaengl and by some accounts contemplated suicide.', u'He was depressed but calm when arrested on 11 November 1923 for high treason.', u"His trial before the special People's Court in Munich began in February 1924, and Alfred Rosenberg became temporary leader of the NSDAP.", u"On 1 April, Hitler was sentenced to five years' imprisonment at Landsberg Prison.", u'There, he received friendly treatment from the guards, and he was allowed mail from supporters and regular visits by party comrades.', u"Pardoned by the Bavarian Supreme Court, he was released from jail on 20 December 1924, against the state prosecutor's objections.", u'Including time on remand, Hitler served just over one year in prison.', u'While at Landsberg, Hitler dictated most of the first volume of Mein Kampf (My Struggle; originally entitled Four and a Half Years of Struggle against Lies, Stupidity, and Cowardice) to his deputy, Rudolf Hess.', u'The book, dedicated to Thule Society member Dietrich Eckart, was an autobiography and exposition of his ideology.', u"The book laid out Hitler's plans for transforming German society into one based on race.", u'Some passages implied genocide.', u'Published in two volumes in 1925 and 1926, it sold 228,000 copies between 1925 and 1932.', u"One million copies were sold in 1933, Hitler's first year in office.", u'Shortly before Hitler was eligible for parole, the Bavarian government attempted to have him deported back to Austria.', u'The Austrian federal chancellor rejected the request on the specious grounds that his service in the German Army made his Austrian citizenship void.', u'In response, Hitler formally renounced his Austrian citizenship on 7 April 1925.', u"=== Rebuilding the NSDAP ===\nAt the time of Hitler's release from prison, politics in Germany had become less combative and the economy had improved, limiting Hitler's opportunities for political agitation.", u'As a result of the failed Beer Hall Putsch, the NSDAP and its affiliated organisations were banned in Bavaria.', u'In a meeting with Prime Minister of Bavaria Heinrich Held on 4 January 1925, Hitler agreed to respect the authority of the state and promised that he would seek political power only through the democratic process.', u'The meeting paved the way for the ban on the NSDAP to be lifted on 16 February.', u'Hitler was barred from public speaking by the Bavarian authorities, a ban that remained in place until 1927.', u'To advance his political ambitions in spite of the ban, Hitler appointed Gregor Strasser, Otto Strasser, and Joseph Goebbels to organise and grow the NSDAP in northern Germany.', u"A superb organiser, Gregor Strasser steered a more independent political course, emphasising the socialist elements of the party's programme.", u'The stock market in the United States crashed on 24 October 1929.', u'The impact in Germany was dire: millions were thrown out of work and several major banks collapsed.', u'Hitler and the NSDAP prepared to take advantage of the emergency to gain support for their party.', u'They promised to repudiate the Versailles Treaty, strengthen the economy, and provide jobs.', u'== Rise to power ==\n\n\n=== Br\xfcning administration ===\nThe Great Depression provided a political opportunity for Hitler.', u'Germans were ambivalent about the parliamentary republic, which faced challenges from right- and left-wing extremists.', u'The moderate political parties were increasingly unable to stem the tide of extremism, and the German referendum of 1929 helped to elevate Nazi ideology.', u'The elections of September 1930 resulted in the break-up of a grand coalition and its replacement with a minority cabinet.', u'Its leader, chancellor Heinrich Br\xfcning of the Centre Party, governed through emergency decrees from President Paul von Hindenburg.', u'Governance by decree became the new norm and paved the way for authoritarian forms of government.', u'The NSDAP rose from obscurity to win 18.3 per cent of the vote and 107 parliamentary seats in the 1930 election, becoming the second-largest party in parliament.', u'Hitler made a prominent appearance at the trial of two Reichswehr officers, Lieutenants Richard Scheringer and Hans Ludin, in late 1930.', u'Both were charged with membership in the NSDAP, at that time illegal for Reichswehr personnel.', u'The prosecution argued that the NSDAP was an extremist party, prompting defence lawyer Hans Frank to call on Hitler to testify.', u'On 25 September 1930, Hitler testified that his party would pursue political power solely through democratic elections, which won him many supporters in the officer corps.', u"Br\xfcning's austerity measures brought little economic improvement and were extremely unpopular.", u'Hitler exploited this by targeting his political messages specifically at people who had been affected by the inflation of the 1920s and the Depression, such as farmers, war veterans, and the middle class.', u'Although Hitler had terminated his Austrian citizenship in 1925, he did not acquire German citizenship for almost seven years.', u'This meant he was stateless, unable to run for public office, and still faced the risk of deportation.', u"On 25 February 1932, the interior minister of Brunswick, Dietrich Klagges, who was a member of the NSDAP, appointed Hitler as administrator for the state's delegation to the Reichsrat in Berlin, making Hitler a citizen of Brunswick, and thus of Germany.", u'In 1932, Hitler ran against Hindenburg in the presidential elections.', u"A 27 January 1932 speech to the Industry Club in D\xfcsseldorf won him support from many of Germany's most powerful industrialists.", u'Hindenburg had support from various nationalist, monarchist, Catholic, and republican parties, and some Social Democrats.', u'Hitler used the campaign slogan "Hitler \xfcber Deutschland" ("Hitler over Germany"), a reference to his political ambitions and his campaigning by aircraft.', u'He was one of the first politicians to use aircraft travel for political purposes, and utilised it effectively.', u'Hitler came in second in both rounds of the election, garnering more than 35 per cent of the vote in the final election.', u'Although he lost to Hindenburg, this election established Hitler as a strong force in German politics.', u'=== Appointment as chancellor ===\nThe absence of an effective government prompted two influential politicians, Franz von Papen and Alfred Hugenberg, along with several other industrialists and businessmen, to write a letter to Hindenburg.', u'The signers urged Hindenburg to appoint Hitler as leader of a government "independent from parliamentary parties", which could turn into a movement that would "enrapture millions of people".', u'Hindenburg reluctantly agreed to appoint Hitler as chancellor after two further parliamentary elections\u2014in July and November 1932\u2014had not resulted in the formation of a majority government.', u"Hitler headed a short-lived coalition government formed by the NSDAP and Hugenberg's party, the German National People's Party (DNVP).", u"On 30 January 1933, the new cabinet was sworn in during a brief ceremony in Hindenburg's office.", u'The NSDAP gained three posts: Hitler was named chancellor, Wilhelm Frick Minister of the Interior, and Hermann G\xf6ring Minister of the Interior for Prussia.', u'Hitler had insisted on the ministerial positions as a way to gain control over the police in much of Germany.', u"=== Reichstag fire and March elections ===\nAs chancellor, Hitler worked against attempts by the NSDAP's opponents to build a majority government.", u'Because of the political stalemate, he asked Hindenburg to again dissolve the Reichstag, and elections were scheduled for early March.', u'On 27 February 1933, the Reichstag building was set on fire.', u'G\xf6ring blamed a communist plot, because Dutch communist Marinus van der Lubbe was found in incriminating circumstances inside the burning building.', u'According to the British historian Sir Ian Kershaw, the consensus of nearly all historians is that van der Lubbe actually set the fire.', u'Others, including William L. Shirer and Alan Bullock, are of the opinion that the NSDAP itself was responsible.', u"At Hitler's urging, Hindenburg responded with the Reichstag Fire Decree of 28 February, which suspended basic rights and allowed detention without trial.", u'The decree was permitted under Article 48 of the Weimar Constitution, which gave the president the power to take emergency measures to protect public safety and order.', u'Activities of the German Communist Party (KPD) were suppressed, and some 4,000 communist party members were arrested.', u'In addition to political campaigning, the NSDAP engaged in paramilitary violence and the spread of anti-communist propaganda in the days preceding the election.', u"On election day, 6 March 1933, the NSDAP's share of the vote increased to 43.9 per cent, and the party acquired the largest number of seats in parliament.", u"Hitler's party failed to secure an absolute majority, necessitating another coalition with the DNVP.", u'=== Day of Potsdam and the Enabling Act ===\n\nOn 21 March 1933, the new Reichstag was constituted with an opening ceremony at the Garrison Church in Potsdam.', u'This "Day of Potsdam" was held to demonstrate unity between the Nazi movement and the old Prussian elite and military.', u'Hitler appeared in a morning coat and humbly greeted Hindenburg.', u"To achieve full political control despite not having an absolute majority in parliament, Hitler's government brought the Erm\xe4chtigungsgesetz (Enabling Act) to a vote in the newly elected Reichstag.", u'The Act\u2014officially titled the Gesetz zur Behebung der Not von Volk und Reich ("Law to Remedy the Distress of People and Reich")\u2014gave Hitler\'s cabinet the power to enact laws without the consent of the Reichstag for four years.', u'These laws could (with certain exceptions) deviate from the constitution.', u'Since it would affect the constitution, the Enabling Act required a two-thirds majority to pass.', u'Leaving nothing to chance, the Nazis used the provisions of the Reichstag Fire Decree to arrest all 81 Communist deputies (in spite of their virulent campaign against the party, the Nazis had allowed the KPD to contest the election) and prevent several Social Democrats from attending.', u'On 23 March 1933, the Reichstag assembled at the Kroll Opera House under turbulent circumstances.', u'Ranks of SA men served as guards inside the building, while large groups outside opposing the proposed legislation shouted slogans and threats towards the arriving members of parliament.', u'The position of the Centre Party, the third largest party in the Reichstag, was decisive.', u'After Hitler verbally promised party leader Ludwig Kaas that Hindenburg would retain his power of veto, Kaas announced the Centre Party would support the Enabling Act.', u'The Act passed by a vote of 441\u201384, with all parties except the Social Democrats voting in favour.', u"The Enabling Act, along with the Reichstag Fire Decree, transformed Hitler's government into a de facto legal dictatorship.", u'=== Dictatorship ===\n\nAt the risk of appearing to talk nonsense I tell you that the National Socialist movement will go on for 1,000 years!', u"... Don't forget how people laughed at me 15 years ago when I declared that one day I would govern Germany.", u'They laugh now, just as foolishly, when I declare that I shall remain in power!', u'Having achieved full control over the legislative and executive branches of government, Hitler and his allies began to suppress the remaining opposition.', u'The Social Democratic Party was banned and its assets seized.', u'While many trade union delegates were in Berlin for May Day activities, SA stormtroopers demolished union offices around the country.', u'On 2 May 1933 all trade unions were forced to dissolve and their leaders were arrested.', u'Some were sent to concentration camps.', u'The German Labour Front was formed as an umbrella organisation to represent all workers, administrators, and company owners, thus reflecting the concept of national socialism in the spirit of Hitler\'s Volksgemeinschaft ("people\'s community").', u'By the end of June, the other parties had been intimidated into disbanding.', u"This included the Nazis' nominal coalition partner, the DNVP; with the SA's help, Hitler forced its leader, Hugenberg, to resign on 29 June.", u'On 14 July 1933, the NSDAP was declared the only legal political party in Germany.', u'The demands of the SA for more political and military power caused anxiety among military, industrial, and political leaders.', u'In response, Hitler purged the entire SA leadership in the Night of the Long Knives, which took place from 30 June to 2 July 1934.', u"Hitler targeted Ernst R\xf6hm and other SA leaders who, along with a number of Hitler's political adversaries (such as Gregor Strasser and former chancellor Kurt von Schleicher), were rounded up, arrested, and shot.", u'While the international community and some Germans were shocked by the murders, many in Germany believed Hitler was restoring order.', u'On 2 August 1934, Hindenburg died.', u'The previous day, the cabinet had enacted the "Law Concerning the Highest State Office of the Reich".', u"This law stated that upon Hindenburg's death, the office of president would be abolished and its powers merged with those of the chancellor.", u'Hitler thus became head of state as well as head of government, and was formally named as F\xfchrer und Reichskanzler (leader and chancellor).', u'With this action, Hitler eliminated the last legal remedy by which he could be removed from office.', u'As head of state, Hitler became supreme commander of the armed forces.', u'The traditional loyalty oath of servicemen was altered to affirm loyalty to Hitler personally, by name, rather than to the office of supreme commander or the state.', u'On 19 August, the merger of the presidency with the chancellorship was approved by 90 per cent of the electorate voting in a plebiscite.', u'In early 1938, Hitler used blackmail to consolidate his hold over the military by instigating the Blomberg\u2013Fritsch Affair.', u"Hitler forced his War Minister, Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg, to resign by using a police dossier that showed that Blomberg's new wife had a record for prostitution.", u'Army commander Colonel-General Werner von Fritsch was removed after the Schutzstaffel (SS) produced allegations that he had engaged in a homosexual relationship.', u"Both men had fallen into disfavour because they objected to Hitler's demand to make the Wehrmacht ready for war as early as 1938.", u"Hitler assumed Blomberg's title of Commander-in-Chief, thus taking personal command of the armed forces.", u'He replaced the Ministry of War with the Oberkommando der Wehrmacht (Armed Forces High Command: OKW), headed by General Wilhelm Keitel.', u'On the same day, sixteen generals were stripped of their commands and 44 more were transferred; all were suspected of not being sufficiently pro-Nazi.', u'By early February 1938, twelve more generals had been removed.', u'Hitler took care to give his dictatorship the appearance of legality.', u'Many of his decrees were explicitly based on the Reichstag Fire Decree and hence on Article 48 of the Weimar Constitution.', u'The Reichstag renewed the Enabling Act twice, each time for a four-year period.', u'While elections to the Reichstag were still held (in 1933, 1936, and 1938), voters were presented with a single list of Nazis and pro-Nazi "guests" which carried with well over 90 percent of the vote.', u"These elections were held in far-from-secret conditions; the Nazis threatened severe reprisals against anyone who didn't vote or dared to vote no.", u'== Nazi Germany ==\n\n\n=== Economy and culture ===\n\nIn August 1934, Hitler appointed Reichsbank President Hjalmar Schacht as Minister of Economics, and in the following year, as Plenipotentiary for War Economy in charge of preparing the economy for war.', u'Reconstruction and rearmament were financed through Mefo bills, printing money, and seizing the assets of people arrested as enemies of the State, including Jews.', u'Unemployment fell from six million in 1932 to one million in 1936.', u'Hitler oversaw one of the largest infrastructure improvement campaigns in German history, leading to the construction of dams, autobahns, railroads, and other civil works.', u'Wages were slightly lower in the mid to late 1930s compared with wages during the Weimar Republic, while the cost of living increased by 25 per cent.', u'The average work week increased during the shift to a war economy; by 1939, the average German was working between 47 and 50 hours a week.', u"Hitler's government sponsored architecture on an immense scale.", u"Albert Speer, instrumental in implementing Hitler's classicist reinterpretation of German culture, was placed in charge of the proposed architectural renovations of Berlin.", u'Despite a threatened multi-nation boycott, Germany hosted the 1936 Olympic Games.', u'Hitler officiated at the opening ceremonies and attended events at both the Winter Games in Garmisch-Partenkirchen and the Summer Games in Berlin.', u'=== Rearmament and new alliances ===\n\nIn a meeting with German military leaders on 3 February 1933, Hitler spoke of "conquest for Lebensraum in the East and its ruthless Germanisation" as his ultimate foreign policy objectives.', u"In March, Prince Bernhard Wilhelm von B\xfclow, secretary at the Ausw\xe4rtiges Amt (Foreign Office), issued a statement of major foreign policy aims: Anschluss with Austria, the restoration of Germany's national borders of 1914, rejection of military restrictions under the Treaty of Versailles, the return of the former German colonies in Africa, and a German zone of influence in Eastern Europe.", u"Hitler found B\xfclow's goals to be too modest.", u'In speeches during this period, he stressed the peaceful goals of his policies and a willingness to work within international agreements.', u'At the first meeting of his cabinet in 1933, Hitler prioritised military spending over unemployment relief.', u'Germany withdrew from the League of Nations and the World Disarmament Conference in October 1933.', u'In January 1935, over 90 per cent of the people of the Saarland, then under League of Nations administration, voted to unite with Germany.', u'That March, Hitler announced an expansion of the Wehrmacht to 600,000 members\u2014six times the number permitted by the Versailles Treaty\u2014including development of an air force (Luftwaffe) and an increase in the size of the navy (Kriegsmarine).', u'Britain, France, Italy, and the League of Nations condemned these violations of the Treaty, but did nothing to stop it.', u'The Anglo-German Naval Agreement (AGNA) of 18 June allowed German tonnage to increase to 35 per cent of that of the British navy.', u'Hitler called the signing of the AGNA "the happiest day of his life", believing that the agreement marked the beginning of the Anglo-German alliance he had predicted in Mein Kampf.', u'France and Italy were not consulted before the signing, directly undermining the League of Nations and setting the Treaty of Versailles on the path towards irrelevance.', u'Germany reoccupied the demilitarised zone in the Rhineland in March 1936, in violation of the Versailles Treaty.', u'Hitler also sent troops to Spain to support General Franco during the Spanish Civil War after receiving an appeal for help in July 1936.', u'At the same time, Hitler continued his efforts to create an Anglo-German alliance.', u'In August 1936, in response to a growing economic crisis caused by his rearmament efforts, Hitler ordered G\xf6ring to implement a Four Year Plan to prepare Germany for war within the next four years.', u'The plan envisaged an all-out struggle between "Judeo-Bolshevism" and German national socialism, which in Hitler\'s view required a committed effort of rearmament regardless of the economic costs.', u"Count Galeazzo Ciano, foreign minister of Mussolini's government, declared an axis between Germany and Italy, and on 25 November, Germany signed the Anti-Comintern Pact with Japan.", u'Britain, China, Italy, and Poland were also invited to join the Anti-Comintern Pact, but only Italy signed in 1937.', u'Hitler abandoned his plan of an Anglo-German alliance, blaming "inadequate" British leadership.', u'At a meeting in the Reich Chancellery with his foreign ministers and military chiefs that November, Hitler restated his intention of acquiring Lebensraum for the German people.', u'He ordered preparations for war in the East, to begin as early as 1938 and no later than 1943.', u'In the event of his death, the conference minutes, recorded as the Hossbach Memorandum, were to be regarded as his "political testament".', u'He felt that a severe decline in living standards in Germany as a result of the economic crisis could only be stopped by military aggression aimed at seizing Austria and Czechoslovakia.', u'Hitler urged quick action before Britain and France gained a permanent lead in the arms race.', u'In early 1938, in the wake of the Blomberg\u2013Fritsch Affair, Hitler asserted control of the military-foreign policy apparatus, dismissing Neurath as foreign minister and appointing himself Oberster Befehlshaber der Wehrmacht (supreme commander of the armed forces).', u'From early 1938 onwards, Hitler was carrying out a foreign policy ultimately aimed at war.', u'== World War II ==\n\n\n=== Early diplomatic successes ===\n\n\n==== Alliance with Japan ====\n\nIn February 1938, on the advice of his newly appointed foreign minister, the strongly pro-Japanese Joachim von Ribbentrop, Hitler ended the Sino-German alliance with the Republic of China to instead enter into an alliance with the more modern and powerful Japan.', u'Hitler announced German recognition of Manchukuo, the Japanese-occupied state in Manchuria, and renounced German claims to their former colonies in the Pacific held by Japan.', u'Hitler ordered an end to arms shipments to China and recalled all German officers working with the Chinese Army.', u'In retaliation, Chinese General Chiang Kai-shek cancelled all Sino-German economic agreements, depriving the Germans of many Chinese raw materials.', u'==== Austria and Czechoslovakia ====\nOn 12 March 1938, Hitler announced the unification of Austria with Nazi Germany in the Anschluss.', u'Hitler then turned his attention to the ethnic German population of the Sudetenland region of Czechoslovakia.', u'On 28\u201329 March 1938, Hitler held a series of secret meetings in Berlin with Konrad Henlein of the Sudeten Heimfront (Home Front), the largest of the ethnic German parties of the Sudetenland.', u'The men agreed that Henlein would demand increased autonomy for Sudeten Germans from the Czechoslovakian government, thus providing a pretext for German military action against Czechoslovakia.', u'In April 1938 Henlein told the foreign minister of Hungary that "whatever the Czech government might offer, he would always raise still higher demands ... he wanted to sabotage an understanding by any means because this was the only method to blow up Czechoslovakia quickly".', u'In private, Hitler considered the Sudeten issue unimportant; his real intention was a war of conquest against Czechoslovakia.', u'In April Hitler ordered the OKW to prepare for Fall Gr\xfcn (Case Green), the code name for an invasion of Czechoslovakia.', u'As a result of intense French and British diplomatic pressure, on 5 September Czechoslovakian President Edvard Bene\u0161 unveiled the "Fourth Plan" for constitutional reorganisation of his country, which agreed to most of Henlein\'s demands for Sudeten autonomy.', u"Henlein's Heimfront responded to Bene\u0161' offer by instigating a series of violent clashes with the Czechoslovakian police that led to the declaration of martial law in certain Sudeten districts.", u"Germany was dependent on imported oil; a confrontation with Britain over the Czechoslovakian dispute could curtail Germany's oil supplies.", u'This forced Hitler to call off Fall Gr\xfcn, originally planned for 1 October 1938.', u'On 29 September Hitler, Neville Chamberlain, \xc9douard Daladier, and Mussolini attended a one-day conference in Munich that led to the Munich Agreement, which handed over the Sudetenland districts to Germany.', u'Chamberlain was satisfied with the Munich conference, calling the outcome "peace for our time", while Hitler was angered about the missed opportunity for war in 1938; he expressed his disappointment in a speech on 9 October in Saarbr\xfccken.', u"In Hitler's view, the British-brokered peace, although favourable to the ostensible German demands, was a diplomatic defeat which spurred his intent of limiting British power to pave the way for the eastern expansion of Germany.", u"As a result of the summit, Hitler was selected Time magazine's Man of the Year for 1938.", u'In late 1938 and early 1939, the continuing economic crisis caused by rearmament forced Hitler to make major defence cuts.', u'In his "Export or die" speech of 30 January 1939, he called for an economic offensive to increase German foreign exchange holdings to pay for raw materials such as high-grade iron needed for military weapons.', u'On 15 March 1939, in violation of the Munich accord and possibly as a result of the deepening economic crisis requiring additional assets, Hitler ordered the Wehrmacht to invade Prague, and from Prague Castle he proclaimed Bohemia and Moravia a German protectorate.', u"=== Start of World War II ===\nIn private discussions in 1939, Hitler declared Britain the main enemy to be defeated and that Poland's obliteration was a necessary prelude for that goal.", u"The eastern flank would be secured and land would be added to Germany's Lebensraum.", u'Offended by the British "guarantee" on 31 March 1939 of Polish independence, he said, "I shall brew them a devil\'s drink".', u'In a speech in Wilhelmshaven for the launch of the battleship Tirpitz on 1 April, he threatened to denounce the Anglo-German Naval Agreement if the British continued to guarantee Polish independence, which he perceived as an "encirclement" policy.', u"Poland was to either become a German satellite state or be neutralised to secure the Reich's eastern flank and to prevent a possible British blockade.", u'Hitler initially favoured the idea of a satellite state, but upon its rejection by the Polish government, he decided to invade and made this the main foreign policy goal of 1939.', u'On 3 April, Hitler ordered the military to prepare for Fall Weiss ("Case White"), the plan for invading Poland on 25 August.', u'In a Reichstag speech on 28 April, he renounced both the Anglo-German Naval Agreement and the German\u2013Polish Non-Aggression Pact.', u"Historians such as William Carr, Gerhard Weinberg, and Kershaw have argued that one reason for Hitler's rush to war was his fear of an early death.", u'Hitler was concerned that a military attack against Poland could result in a premature war with Britain.', u"Hitler's foreign minister and former Ambassador to London, Joachim von Ribbentrop, assured him that neither Britain nor France would honour their commitments to Poland.", u'Accordingly, on 22 August 1939 Hitler ordered a military mobilisation against Poland.', u'This plan required tacit Soviet support, and the non-aggression pact (the Molotov\u2013Ribbentrop Pact) between Germany and the Soviet Union, led by Joseph Stalin, included a secret agreement to partition Poland between the two countries.', u"Contrary to Ribbentrop's prediction that Britain would sever Anglo-Polish ties, Britain and Poland signed the Anglo-Polish alliance on 25 August 1939.", u'This, along with news from Italy that Mussolini would not honour the Pact of Steel, prompted Hitler to postpone the attack on Poland from 25 August to 1 September.', u'Hitler unsuccessfully tried to manoeuvre the British into neutrality by offering them a non-aggression guarantee on 25 August; he then instructed Ribbentrop to present a last-minute peace plan with an impossibly short time limit in an effort to blame the imminent war on British and Polish inaction.', u'On 1 September 1939, Germany invaded western Poland under the pretext of having been denied claims to the Free City of Danzig and the right to extraterritorial roads across the Polish Corridor, which Germany had ceded under the Versailles Treaty.', u'In response, Britain and France declared war on Germany on 3 September, surprising Hitler and prompting him to angrily ask Ribbentrop, "Now what?"', u'France and Britain did not act on their declarations immediately, and on 17 September, Soviet forces invaded eastern Poland.', u'The fall of Poland was followed by what contemporary journalists dubbed the "Phoney War" or Sitzkrieg ("sitting war").', u'Hitler instructed the two newly appointed Gauleiters of north-western Poland, Albert Forster of Reichsgau Danzig-West Prussia and Arthur Greiser of Reichsgau Wartheland, to Germanise their areas, with "no questions asked" about how this was accomplished.', u"Whereas Polish citizens in Forster's area merely had to sign forms stating that they had German blood, Greiser carried out a brutal ethnic cleansing campaign on the Polish population in his purview.", u'Greiser complained that Forster was allowing thousands of Poles to be accepted as "racial" Germans and thus endangered German "racial purity".', u'Hitler refrained from getting involved.', u'This inaction has been advanced as an example of the theory of "working towards the F\xfchrer": Hitler issued vague instructions and expected his subordinates to work out policies on their own.', u'Another dispute pitched one side represented by Himmler and Greiser, who championed ethnic cleansing in Poland, against another represented by G\xf6ring and Hans Frank, governor-general of the General Government territory of occupied Poland, who called for turning Poland into the "granary" of the Reich.', u'On 12 February 1940, the dispute was initially settled in favour of the G\xf6ring\u2013Frank view, which ended the economically disruptive mass expulsions.', u'On 15 May 1940, Himmler issued a memo entitled "Some Thoughts on the Treatment of Alien Population in the East", calling for the expulsion of the entire Jewish population of Europe into Africa and reducing the Polish population to a "leaderless class of labourers".', u'Hitler called Himmler\'s memo "good and correct", and, ignoring G\xf6ring and Frank, implemented the Himmler\u2013Greiser policy in Poland.', u"Hitler began a military build-up on Germany's western border, and in April 1940, German forces invaded Denmark and Norway.", u'On 9 April, Hitler proclaimed the birth of the Greater Germanic Reich, his vision of a united empire of the Germanic nations of Europe, where the Dutch, Flemish, and Scandinavians were joined into a "racially pure" polity under German leadership.', u'In May 1940, Germany attacked France, and conquered Luxembourg, the Netherlands, and Belgium.', u'These victories prompted Mussolini to have Italy join forces with Hitler on 10 June.', u'France and Germany signed an armistice on 22 June.', u"Kershaw notes that Hitler's popularity within Germany \u2013 and German support for the war \u2013 reached its peak when he returned to Berlin on 6 July from his tour of Paris.", u'Following the unexpected swift victory, Hitler promoted twelve generals to the rank of field marshal during the 1940 Field Marshal Ceremony.', u'Britain, whose troops were forced to evacuate France by sea from Dunkirk, continued to fight alongside other British dominions in the Battle of the Atlantic.', u'Hitler made peace overtures to the new British leader, Winston Churchill, and upon their rejection he ordered a series of aerial attacks on Royal Air Force airbases and radar stations in south-east England.', u'The German Luftwaffe failed to defeat the Royal Air Force in what became known as the Battle of Britain.', u'By the end of October, Hitler realised that air superiority for the invasion of Britain (in Operation Sea Lion) could not be achieved, and he ordered nightly air raids on British cities, including London, Plymouth, and Coventry.', u'On 27 September 1940, the Tripartite Pact was signed in Berlin by Sabur\u014d Kurusu of Imperial Japan, Hitler, and Italian foreign minister Ciano, and later expanded to include Hungary, Romania, and Bulgaria, thus yielding the Axis powers.', u"Hitler's attempt to integrate the Soviet Union into the anti-British bloc failed after inconclusive talks between Hitler and Molotov in Berlin in November, and he ordered preparations for the invasion of the Soviet Union.", u'In early 1941, German forces were deployed to North Africa, the Balkans, and the Middle East.', u'In February, German forces arrived in Libya to bolster the Italian presence.', u'In April, Hitler launched the invasion of Yugoslavia, quickly followed by the invasion of Greece.', u'In May, German forces were sent to support Iraqi rebel forces fighting against the British and to invade Crete.', u'=== Path to defeat ===\nOn 22 June 1941, contravening the Hitler\u2013Stalin Non-Aggression Pact of 1939, 4\u20135 million Axis troops attacked the Soviet Union.', u'This offensive (codenamed Operation Barbarossa) was intended to destroy the Soviet Union and seize its natural resources for subsequent aggression against the Western powers.', u'The invasion conquered a huge area, including the Baltic republics, Belarus, and West Ukraine.', u'By early August, Axis troops had advanced 500 km (310 mi) and won the Battle of Smolensk.', u'Hitler ordered Army Group Centre to temporarily halt its advance to Moscow and divert its Panzer groups to aid in the encirclement of Leningrad and Kiev.', u'His generals disagreed with this change, having advanced within 400 km (250 mi) of Moscow, and his decision caused a crisis among the military leadership.', u'The pause provided the Red Army with an opportunity to mobilise fresh reserves; historian Russel Stolfi considers it to be one of the major factors that caused the failure of the Moscow offensive, which was resumed in October 1941 and ended disastrously in December.', u'On 7 December 1941, Japan attacked the American fleet based at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii.', u'Four days later, Hitler declared war against the United States.', u'On 18 December 1941, Himmler asked Hitler, "What to do with the Jews of Russia?', u'", to which Hitler replied, "als Partisanen auszurotten" ("exterminate them as partisans").', u'Israeli historian Yehuda Bauer has commented that the remark is probably as close as historians will ever get to a definitive order from Hitler for the genocide carried out during the Holocaust.', u"In late 1942, German forces were defeated in the second battle of El Alamein, thwarting Hitler's plans to seize the Suez Canal and the Middle East.", u'Overconfident in his own military expertise following the earlier victories in 1940, Hitler became distrustful of his Army High Command and began to interfere in military and tactical planning, with damaging consequences.', u"In December 1942 and January 1943, Hitler's repeated refusal to allow their withdrawal at the Battle of Stalingrad led to the almost total destruction of the 6th Army.", u'Over 200,000 Axis soldiers were killed and 235,000 were taken prisoner.', u'Thereafter came a decisive strategic defeat at the Battle of Kursk.', u"Hitler's military judgement became increasingly erratic, and Germany's military and economic position deteriorated, as did Hitler's health.", u'Following the allied invasion of Sicily in 1943, Mussolini was removed from power by Victor Emmanuel III after a vote of no confidence of the Grand Council.', u'Marshal Pietro Badoglio, placed in charge of the government, soon surrendered to the Allies.', u"Throughout 1943 and 1944, the Soviet Union steadily forced Hitler's armies into retreat along the Eastern Front.", u'On 6 June 1944, the Western Allied armies landed in northern France in one of the largest amphibious operations in history, Operation Overlord.', u"Many German officers concluded that defeat was inevitable and that continuing under Hitler's leadership would result in the complete destruction of the country.", u'Between 1939 and 1945, there were many plans to assassinate Hitler, some of which proceeded to significant degrees.', u'The most well known came from within Germany and was at least partly driven by the increasing prospect of a German defeat in the war.', u"In July 1944, in the 20 July plot, part of Operation Valkyrie, Claus von Stauffenberg planted a bomb in one of Hitler's headquarters, the Wolf's Lair at Rastenburg.", u'Hitler narrowly survived because staff officer Heinz Brandt moved the briefcase containing the bomb behind a leg of the heavy conference table, which deflected much of the blast.', u'Later, Hitler ordered savage reprisals resulting in the execution of more than 4,900 people.', u'=== Defeat and death ===\n\nBy late 1944, both the Red Army and the Western Allies were advancing into Germany.', u'Recognising the strength and determination of the Red Army, Hitler decided to use his remaining mobile reserves against the American and British troops, which he perceived as far weaker.', u'On 16 December, he launched the Ardennes Offensive to incite disunity among the Western Allies and perhaps convince them to join his fight against the Soviets.', u'The offensive failed after some temporary successes.', u'With much of Germany in ruins in January 1945, Hitler spoke on the radio: "However grave as the crisis may be at this moment, it will, despite everything, be mastered by our unalterable will."', u"Hitler's hope to negotiate peace with the United States and Britain was encouraged by the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt on 12 April 1945, but contrary to his expectations, this caused no rift among the Allies.", u"Acting on his view that Germany's military failures meant it had forfeited its right to survive as a nation, Hitler ordered the destruction of all German industrial infrastructure before it could fall into Allied hands.", u'Minister for Armaments Albert Speer was entrusted with executing this scorched earth policy, but he secretly disobeyed the order.', u"On 20 April, his 56th birthday, Hitler made his last trip from the F\xfchrerbunker (F\xfchrer's shelter) to the surface.", u'In the ruined garden of the Reich Chancellery, he awarded Iron Crosses to boy soldiers of the Hitler Youth, who were now fighting the Red Army at the front near Berlin.', u"By 21 April, Georgy Zhukov's 1st Belorussian Front had broken through the defences of General Gotthard Heinrici's Army Group Vistula during the Battle of the Seelow Heights and advanced to the outskirts of Berlin.", u'In denial about the dire situation, Hitler placed his hopes on the undermanned and under-equipped Armeeabteilung Steiner (Army Detachment Steiner), commanded by Waffen SS General Felix Steiner.', u'Hitler ordered Steiner to attack the northern flank of the salient, while the German Ninth Army was ordered to attack northward in a pincer attack.', u"During a military conference on 22 April, Hitler asked about Steiner's offensive.", u'He was told that the attack had not been launched and that the Soviets had entered Berlin.', u'Hitler asked everyone except Wilhelm Keitel, Alfred Jodl, Hans Krebs, and Wilhelm Burgdorf to leave the room, then launched into a tirade against the treachery and incompetence of his commanders, culminating in his declaration\u2014for the first time\u2014that "everything was lost".', u'He announced that he would stay in Berlin until the end and then shoot himself.', u'By 23 April the Red Army had surrounded Berlin, and Goebbels made a proclamation urging its citizens to defend the city.', u'That same day, G\xf6ring sent a telegram from Berchtesgaden, arguing that since Hitler was isolated in Berlin, G\xf6ring should assume leadership of Germany.', u'G\xf6ring set a deadline, after which he would consider Hitler incapacitated.', u'Hitler responded by having G\xf6ring arrested, and in his last will and testament, written on 29 April, he removed G\xf6ring from all government positions.', u'On 28 April Hitler discovered that Himmler, who had left Berlin on 20 April, was trying to negotiate a surrender to the Western Allies.', u"He ordered Himmler's arrest and had Hermann Fegelein (Himmler's SS representative at Hitler's HQ in Berlin) shot.", u'After midnight on 29 April, Hitler married Eva Braun in a small civil ceremony in the F\xfchrerbunker.', u'After a wedding breakfast with his new wife, Hitler dictated his will to his secretary Traudl Junge.', u'The event was witnessed and documents signed by Krebs, Burgdorf, Goebbels, and Bormann.', u'Later that afternoon, Hitler was informed of the execution of Mussolini, which presumably increased his determination to avoid capture.', u'On 30 April 1945, when Soviet troops were within a block
