{'sentences': [u'The sailing ship Andrew Jackson, a 1,679-registered-ton medium clipper, was built by the firm of Irons & Grinnell in Mystic, Connecticut in 1855.', u'The vessel was designed for the shipping firm of J.H.', u'Brower & Co. to carry cargo intended for sale to participants in the California Gold Rush.', u"== Construction ==\nThe ship's dimensions were: length 220 feet (67 m), beam 41 ft., 2 in., and draft 22 ft., 3 in.", u'The vessel was described as "a very handsome, well-designed ship.', u'She was heavily sparred and carried double topsails, skysails, and royal studdingsails."', u'== Voyages ==\nAndrew Jackson made seven passages from New York to San Francisco, with an average time of 106\u200a1\u20443 days.', u'These times compare well with the passages of extreme clippers such as Flying Cloud and Flying Fish, which averaged 105\u200a5\u20447 days and 103\u200a1\u20443 days respectively, and the vessel was advertised as "The Fastest Ship in the World."', u'== Record passage to San Francisco ==\nAndrew Jackson is best known for her 1859\u20131860 run around Cape Horn from New York City to San Francisco, which the vessel performed in 89 days and 4 hours.', u'The run began at noon on Christmas Day, 1859, and ended at 4 p.m. on 23 March 1860 at the Farallon Islands.', u'This was one of only three 89-day runs performed by square-rigged ships driving from New York City to California.', u'The other two runs were both posted by Flying Cloud.', u"Flying Cloud's fastest New York-to-California run had taken 89 days and 8 hours; Andrew Jackson's run was, by four hours, widely acclaimed in the newspapers as the fastest in history.", u"Andrew Jackson's run, as calculated above, was from New York City to the Farallon Islands, the pilot boat entry point to the harbor of San Francisco.", u'Andrew Jackson did not get a pilot boat in a timely manner and did not actually tie up at a San Francisco wharf until the next day.', u'Some clipper ship authorities, including Howe and Matthews, assert that Andrew Jackson did not actually set the record described above.', u'They concede, however, that this medium clipper, perhaps not naturally as fast as Flying Cloud, achieved a remarkable passage as the result of a combination of hard driving by the captain and favorable winds.', u'=== Andrew Jackson vs.', u'Flying Cloud ===\nHowever, after careful scrutiny of the logbooks, one author, Carl C. Cutler, concludes that a case can be made for either Flying Cloud or Andrew Jackson holding the record.', u'Some will consider the passage from pilot-to-pilot as the appropriate indicator of fastest sailing performance around Cape Horn.', u"Flying Cloud holds the record time for a passage anchor-to-anchor from New York to San Francisco, of 89 days 8 hours, while Andrew Jackson's completed passage anchor-to-anchor may have been as long as 89 days 20 hours.", u'== Loss ==\nAndrew Jackson was lost on December 4, 1868, after going ashore on a reef in the Gaspar Strait.', u"== Legacy ==\nAndrew Jackson's 1859\u20131860 run was to be one of the final sailing-ship records posted by an American clipper ship.", u'During the 1860s, the progress of colonialism led to the creation of a network of coaling stations worldwide to serve fast steamships with a reliable supply of fuel, and the market for clipper-ship freight collapsed.', u'== Images ==\nPainting of clipper ship Andrew Jackson, Mystic Seaport Museum\n\n\n== See also ==\nList of clipper ships\n\n\n== References =='], 'year': '1860-03-24', 'title': 'Clipper Andrew Jackson arrives in SF - 89 days out of NY'}
{'sentences': [u'A patent (/\u02c8p\xe6t\u0259nt/ or /\u02c8pe\u026at\u0259nt/) is a set of exclusive rights granted by a sovereign state to an inventor or assignee for a limited period of time in exchange for detailed public disclosure of an invention.', u'An invention is a solution to a specific technological problem and is a product or a process.', u'Patents are a form of intellectual property.', u'The procedure for granting patents, requirements placed on the patentee, and the extent of the exclusive rights vary widely between countries according to national laws and international agreements.', u'Typically, however, a granted patent application must include one or more claims that define the invention.', u'A patent may include many claims, each of which defines a specific property right.', u'These claims must meet relevant patentability requirements, such as novelty, usefulness, and non-obviousness.', u'The exclusive right granted to a patentee in most countries is the right to prevent others, or at least to try to prevent others, from commercially making, using, selling, importing, or distributing a patented invention without permission.', u"Under the World Trade Organization's (WTO) Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights, patents should be available in WTO member states for any invention, in all fields of technology, and the term of protection available should be a minimum of twenty years.", u'Nevertheless, there are variations on what is patentable subject matter from country to country.', u'== Definition ==\nThe word patent originates from the Latin patere, which means "to lay open" (i.e., to make available for public inspection).', u'More directly, it is a shortened version of the term letters patent, which was a royal decree granting exclusive rights to a person, predating the modern patent system.', u'Similar grants included land patents, which were land grants by early state governments in the USA, and printing patents, a precursor of modern copyright.', u'In modern usage, the term patent usually refers to the right granted to anyone who invents any new, useful, and non-obvious process, machine, article of manufacture, or composition of matter.', u"Some other types of intellectual property rights are also called patents in some jurisdictions: industrial design rights are called design patents in the US, plant breeders' rights are sometimes called plant patents, and utility models and Gebrauchsmuster are sometimes called petty patents or innovation patents.", u'The additional qualification utility patent is sometimes used (primarily in the US) to distinguish the primary meaning from these other types of patents.', u'Particular species of patents for inventions include biological patents, business method patents, chemical patents and software patents.', u'== History ==\n\nAlthough there is some evidence that some form of patent rights was recognized in Ancient Greece in the Greek city of Sybaris, the first statutory patent system is generally regarded to be the Venetian Patent Statute of 1450.', u'Patents were systematically granted in Venice as of 1450, where they issued a decree by which new and inventive devices had to be communicated to the Republic in order to obtain legal protection against potential infringers.', u'The period of protection was 10 years.', u'These were mostly in the field of glass making.', u'As Venetians emigrated, they sought similar patent protection in their new homes.', u'This led to the diffusion of patent systems to other countries.', u'The English patent system evolved from its early medieval origins into the first modern patent system that recognised intellectual property in order to stimulate invention; this was the crucial legal foundation upon which the Industrial Revolution could emerge and flourish.', u'By the 16th century, the English Crown would habitually abuse the granting of letters patent for monopolies.', u'After public outcry, King James I of England (VI of Scotland) was forced to revoke all existing monopolies and declare that they were only to be used for "projects of new invention".', u"This was incorporated into the Statute of Monopolies (1624) in which Parliament restricted the Crown's power explicitly so that the King could only issue letters patent to the inventors or introducers of original inventions for a fixed number of years.", u'The Statute became the foundation for later developments in patent law in England and elsewhere.', u'Important developments in patent law emerged during the 18th century through a slow process of judicial interpretation of the law.', u'During the reign of Queen Anne, patent applications were required to supply a complete specification of the principles of operation of the invention for public access.', u'Legal battles around the 1796 patent taken out by James Watt for his steam engine, established the principles that patents could be issued for improvements of an already existing machine and that ideas or principles without specific practical application could also legally be patented.', u'Influenced by the philosophy of John Locke, the granting of patents began to be viewed as a form of intellectual property right, rather than simply the obtaining of economic privilege.', u'The English legal system became the foundation for patent law in countries with a common law heritage, including the United States, New Zealand and Australia.', u"In the Thirteen Colonies, inventors could obtain patents through petition to a given colony's legislature.", u'In 1641, Samuel Winslow was granted the first patent in North America by the Massachusetts General Court for a new process for making salt.', u'The modern French patent system was created during the Revolution in 1791.', u"Patents were granted without examination since inventor's right was considered as a natural one.", u'Patent costs were very high (from 500 to 1,500 francs).', u'Importation patents protected new devices coming from foreign countries.', u'The patent law was revised in 1844 - patent cost was lowered and importation patents were abolished.', u'The first Patent Act of the U.S. Congress was passed on April 10, 1790, titled "An Act to promote the progress of useful Arts".', u'The first patent was granted on July 31, 1790 to Samuel Hopkins for a method of producing potash (potassium carbonate).', u'== Law ==\n\n\n=== Effects ===\nA patent does not give a right to make or use or sell an invention.', u'Rather, a patent provides, from a legal standpoint, the right to exclude others from making, using, selling, offering for sale, or importing the patented invention for the term of the patent, which is usually 20 years from the filing date subject to the payment of maintenance fees.', u'From an economic and practical standpoint however, a patent is better and perhaps more precisely regarded as conferring upon its proprietor "a right to try to exclude by asserting the patent in court", for many granted patents turn out to be invalid once their proprietors attempt to assert them in court.', u'A patent is a limited property right the government gives inventors in exchange for their agreement to share details of their inventions with the public.', u'Like any other property right, it may be sold, licensed, mortgaged, assigned or transferred, given away, or simply abandoned.', u'A patent, being an exclusionary right, does not necessarily give the patent owner the right to exploit the invention subject to the patent.', u"For example, many inventions are improvements of prior inventions that may still be covered by someone else's patent.", u'If an inventor obtains a patent on improvements to an existing invention which is still under patent, they can only legally use the improved invention if the patent holder of the original invention gives permission, which they may refuse.', u'Some countries have "working provisions" that require the invention be exploited in the jurisdiction it covers.', u'Consequences of not working an invention vary from one country to another, ranging from revocation of the patent rights to the awarding of a compulsory license awarded by the courts to a party wishing to exploit a patented invention.', u'The patentee has the opportunity to challenge the revocation or license, but is usually required to provide evidence that the reasonable requirements of the public have been met by the working of invention.', u'=== Challenges ===\n In most jurisdictions, there are ways for third parties to challenge the validity of an allowed or issued patent at the national patent office; these are called opposition proceedings.', u'It is also possible to challenge the validity of a patent in court.', u'In either case, the challenging party tries to prove that the patent should never have been granted.', u'There are several grounds for challenges: the claimed subject matter is not patentable subject matter at all; the claimed subject matter was actually not new, or was obvious to experts in the field, at the time the application was filed; or that the some kind of fraud was committed during prosecution with regard to listing of inventors, representations about when discoveries were made, etc.', u'Patents can be found to be invalid in whole or in part for any of these reasons.', u'=== Infringement ===\n\nPatent infringement occurs when a third party, without authorization from the patentee, makes, uses, or sells a patented invention.', u'Patents, however, are enforced on a nation by nation basis.', u'The making of an item in China, for example, that would infringe a U.S. patent, would not constitute infringement under US patent law unless the item were imported into the US.', u'=== Enforcement ===\nPatents can generally only be enforced through civil lawsuits (for example, for a U.S. patent, by an action for patent infringement in a United States federal court), although some countries (such as France and Austria) have criminal penalties for wanton infringement.', u'Typically, the patent owner seeks monetary compensation for past infringement, and seeks an injunction that prohibits the defendant from engaging in future acts of infringement.', u'To prove infringement, the patent owner must establish that the accused infringer practises all the requirements of at least one of the claims of the patent.', u'(In many jurisdictions the scope of the patent may not be limited to what is literally stated in the claims, for example due to the doctrine of equivalents).', u'An accused infringer has the right to challenge the validity of the patent allegedly being infringed in a countersuit.', u'A patent can be found invalid on grounds described in the relevant patent laws, which vary between countries.', u'Often, the grounds are a subset of requirements for patentability in the relevant country.', u'Although an infringer is generally free to rely on any available ground of invalidity (such as a prior publication, for example), some countries have sanctions to prevent the same validity questions being relitigated.', u'An example is the UK Certificate of contested validity.', u'Patent licensing agreements are contracts in which the patent owner (the licensor) agrees to grant the licensee the right to make, use, sell, and/or import the claimed invention, usually in return for a royalty or other compensation.', u'It is common for companies engaged in complex technical fields to enter into multiple license agreements associated with the production of a single product.', u"Moreover, it is equally common for competitors in such fields to license patents to each other under cross-licensing agreements in order to share the benefits of using each other's patented inventions.", u'=== Ownership ===\nIn most countries, both natural persons and corporate entities may apply for a patent.', u'In the United States, however, only the inventor(s) may apply for a patent although it may be assigned to a corporate entity subsequently and inventors may be required to assign inventions to their employers under an employment contract.', u"In most European countries, ownership of an invention may pass from the inventor to their employer by rule of law if the invention was made in the course of the inventor's normal or specifically assigned employment duties, where an invention might reasonably be expected to result from carrying out those duties, or if the inventor had a special obligation to further the interests of the employer's company.", u'The inventors, their successors or their assignees become the proprietors of the patent when and if it is granted.', u'If a patent is granted to more than one proprietor, the laws of the country in question and any agreement between the proprietors may affect the extent to which each proprietor can exploit the patent.', u'For example, in some countries, each proprietor may freely license or assign their rights in the patent to another person while the law in other countries prohibits such actions without the permission of the other proprietor(s).', u'The ability to assign ownership rights increases the liquidity of a patent as property.', u'Inventors can obtain patents and then sell them to third parties.', u'The third parties then own the patents and have the same rights to prevent others from exploiting the claimed inventions, as if they had originally made the inventions themselves.', u'=== Governing laws ===\n\nThe grant and enforcement of patents are governed by national laws, and also by international treaties, where those treaties have been given effect in national laws.', u'Patents are granted by national or regional patent offices.', u'A given patent is therefore only useful for protecting an invention in the country in which that patent is granted.', u'In other words, patent law is territorial in nature.', u'When a patent application is published, the invention disclosed in the application becomes prior art and enters the public domain (if not protected by other patents) in countries where a patent applicant does not seek protection, the application thus generally becoming prior art against anyone (including the applicant) who might seek patent protection for the invention in those countries.', u"Commonly, a nation forms a patent office with responsibility for operating that nation's patent system, within the relevant patent laws.", u'The patent office generally has responsibility for the grant of patents, with infringement being the remit of national courts.', u'The authority for patent statutes in different countries varies.', u'In the UK, substantive patent law is contained in the Patents Act 1977 as amended.', u'In the United States, the Constitution empowers Congress to make laws to "promote the Progress of Science and useful Arts..." The laws Congress passed are codified in Title 35 of the United States Code and created the United States Patent and Trademark Office.', u'There is a trend towards global harmonization of patent laws, with the World Trade Organization (WTO) being particularly active in this area.', u'The TRIPs Agreement has been largely successful in providing a forum for nations to agree on an aligned set of patent laws.', u'Conformity with the TRIPs agreement is a requirement of admission to the WTO and so compliance is seen by many nations as important.', u'This has also led to many developing nations, which may historically have developed different laws to aid their development, enforcing patents laws in line with global practice.', u'In addition, there are international treaty procedures, such as the procedures under the European Patent Convention (EPC) [constituting the European Patent Organisation (EPOrg)], that centralize some portion of the filing and examination procedure.', u'Similar arrangements exist among the member states of ARIPO and OAPI, the analogous treaties among African countries, and the nine CIS member states that have formed the Eurasian Patent Organization.', u'A key international convention relating to patents is the Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property, initially signed in 1883.', u'The Paris Convention sets out a range of basic rules relating to patents, and although the convention does not have direct legal effect in all national jurisdictions, the principles of the convention are incorporated into all notable current patent systems.', u'The most significant aspect of the convention is the provision of the right to claim priority: filing an application in any one member state of the Paris Convention preserves the right for one year to file in any other member state, and receive the benefit of the original filing date.', u'Another key treaty is the Patent Cooperation Treaty (PCT), administered by WIPO and covering more than 140 countries.', u'The Patent Cooperation Treaty provides a unified procedure for filing patent applications to protect inventions in each of its contracting states.', u'A patent application filed under the PCT is called an international application, or PCT application.', u'=== Application and prosecution ===\n\nA patent is requested by filing a written application at the relevant patent office.', u'The person or company filing the application is referred to as "the applicant".', u'The applicant may be the inventor or its assignee.', u'The application contains a description of how to make and use the invention that must provide sufficient detail for a person skilled in the art (i.e., the relevant area of technology) to make and use the invention.', u'In some countries there are requirements for providing specific information such as the usefulness of the invention, the best mode of performing the invention known to the inventor, or the technical problem or problems solved by the invention.', u'Drawings illustrating the invention may also be provided.', u'The application also includes one or more claims that define what a patent covers or the "scope of protection".', u'After filing, an application is often referred to as "patent pending".', u'While this term does not confer legal protection, and a patent cannot be enforced until granted, it serves to provide warning to potential infringers that if the patent is issued, they may be liable for damages.', u'Once filed, a patent application is "prosecuted".', u'A patent examiner reviews the patent application to determine if it meets the patentability requirements of that country.', u'If the application does not comply, objections are communicated to the applicant or their patent agent or attorney through an Office action, to which the applicant may respond.', u'The number of Office actions and responses that may occur vary from country to country, but eventually a final rejection is sent by the patent office, or the patent application is granted, which after the payment of additional fees, leads to an issued, enforceable patent.', u'In some jurisdictions, there are opportunities for third parties to bring an opposition proceeding between grant and issuance, or post-issuance.', u'Once granted the patent is subject in most countries to renewal fees to keep the patent in force.', u'These fees are generally payable on a yearly basis.', u'Some countries or regional patent offices (e.g.', u'the European Patent Office) also require annual renewal fees to be paid for a patent application before it is granted.', u'==== Costs ====\nThe costs of preparing and filing a patent application, prosecuting it until grant and maintaining the patent vary from one jurisdiction to another, and may also be dependent upon the type and complexity of the invention, and on the type of patent.', u'The European Patent Office estimated in 2005 that the average cost of obtaining a European patent (via a Euro-direct application, i.e.', u'not based on a PCT application) and maintaining the patent for a 10-year term was around \u20ac32,000.', u'Since the London Agreement entered into force on May 1, 2008, this estimation is however no longer up-to-date, since fewer translations are required.', u'In the United States, in 2000 the cost of obtaining a patent (patent prosecution) was estimated to be from $10,000 to $30,000 per patent.', u'When patent litigation is involved (which in year 1999 happened in about 1,600 cases compared to 153,000 patents issued in the same year), costs increase significantly: although 95% of patent litigation cases are settled out of court, those that reach the courts have legal costs on the order of a million dollars per case, not including associated business costs.', u'=== Alternatives to applying for a patent ===\nA defensive publication is the act of publishing a detailed description of a new invention without patenting it, so as to establish prior art and public identification as the creator/originator of an invention, although a defensive publication can also be anonymous.', u'A defensive publication prevents others from later being able to patent the invention.', u'A trade secret is information that is intentionally kept confidential and that provides a competitive advantage to its possessor.', u'Trade secrets are protected by nondisclosure agreements and employment law, each of which prevents information leaks such as breaches of confidentiality and corporate espionage.', u'Compared to patents, the advantages of trade secrets are that the value of a trade secret continues until it is made public, whereas a patent is only in force for a specified time, after which others may freely copy the invention; does not require payment of fees to governmental agencies or filing paperwork; has an immediate effect; and does not require any disclosure of information to the public.', u'The key disadvantage of a trade secret is its vulnerability to reverse engineering.', u'== Benefits ==\nPrimary incentives embodied in the patent system include incentives to invent in the first place; to disclose the invention once made; to invest the sums necessary to experiment, produce and market the invention; and to design around and improve upon earlier patents.', u'Patents provide incentives for economically efficient research and development (R&D).', u'A study conducted annually by the IPTS shows that the 2,000 largest global companies invested more than 430 billion euros in 2008 in their R&D departments.', u'If the investments can be considered as inputs of R&D, real products and patents are the outputs.', u'Based on these groups, a project named Corporate Invention Board, had measured and analyzed the patent portfolios to produce an original picture of their technological profiles.', u'Supporters of patents argue that without patent protection, R&D spending would be significantly less or eliminated altogether, limiting the possibility of technological advances or breakthroughs.', u'Corporations would be much more conservative about the R&D investments they made, as third parties would be free to exploit any developments.', u'This second justification is closely related to the basic ideas underlying traditional property rights.', u'Specifically, "[t]he patent internalizes the externality by giving the [inventor] a property right over its invention."', u'A 2008 study by Yi Quan of Kellogg School of Management showed that countries instituting patent protection on pharmecuticals did not necessarily have an increase in domestic pharmaceutical innovation.', u'Only countries with "higher levels of economic development, educational attainment, and economic freedom" showed an increase.', u'There also appeared to be an optimal level of patent protection that increased domestic innovation.', u'In accordance with the original definition of the term "patent", patents are intended to facilitate and encourage disclosure of innovations into the public domain for the common good.', u'Thus patenting can be viewed as contributing to open hardware after an embargo period (usually of 20 years).', u'If inventors did not have the legal protection of patents, in many cases, they might prefer or tend to keep their inventions secret (e.g.', u'keep trade secrets).', u'Awarding patents generally makes the details of new technology publicly available, for exploitation by anyone after the patent expires, or for further improvement by other inventors.', u"Furthermore, when a patent's term has expired, the public record ensures that the patentee's invention is not lost to humanity.", u'In many industries (especially those with high fixed costs and either low marginal costs or low reverse engineering costs \u2014 computer processors, and pharmaceuticals for example), once an invention exists, the cost of commercialization (testing, tooling up a factory, developing a market, etc.)', u'is far more than the initial conception cost.', u'(For example, the internal rule of thumb at several computer companies in the 1980s was that post-R&D costs were 7-to-1.)', u'One effect of modern patent usage is that a small-time inventor, who can afford both the patenting process and the defense of the patent, can use the exclusive right status to become a licensor.', u'This allows the inventor to accumulate capital from licensing the invention and may allow innovation to occur because he or she may choose not to manage a manufacturing buildup for the invention.', u"Thus the inventor's time and energy can be spent on pure innovation, allowing others to concentrate on manufacturability.", u'Another effect of modern patent usage is to both enable and incentivize competitors to design around (or to "invent around" according to R S Praveen Raj) the patented invention.', u'This may promote healthy competition among manufacturers, resulting in gradual improvements of the technology base.', u'This may help augment national economies and confer better living standards to the citizens.', u'The 1970 Indian Patent Act allowed the Indian pharmaceutical industry to develop local technological capabilities in this industry.', u'This act coincided with the transformation of India from a bulk importer of pharmaceutical drugs to a leading exporter.', u'The rapid evolution of Indian pharmaceutical industry since the mid-1970s highlights the fact that the design of the patent act was instrumental in building local capabilities even in a developing country like India.', u'== Criticism ==\n\nLegal scholars, economists, activists, policymakers, industries, and trade organizations have held differing views on patents and engaged in contentious debates on the subject.', u'Critical perspectives emerged in the nineteenth century that were especially based on the principles of free trade.', u'Contemporary criticisms have echoed those arguments, claiming that patents block innovation and waste resources (e.g.', u'with patent-related overheads) that could otherwise be used productively to improve technology.', u'These and other research findings that patents decreased innovation because of the following mechanisms:\nLow quality, already known or obvious patents hamper innovation and commercialization.', u'Blocking the use of fundamental knowledge with patents creates a "tragedy of the anticommons, where future innovations can not take place outside of a single firm in an entire field.', u'Patents weaken the public domain and innovation that comes from it.', u'Patent thickets, or an "an overlapping set of patent rights", in particular slow innovation.', u'Broad patents prevent companies from commercializing products and hurt innovation.', u'In the worst case, such broad patents are held by non-practicing entities (patent trolls), which do not contribute to innovation.', u'Enforcement by patent trolls of poor quality patents  has led to criticism of the patent office as well as the system itself.', u'For example, in 2011, United States business entities incurred $29 billion in direct costs because of patent trolls.', u'Lawsuits brought by "patent assertion companies" made up 61% of all patent cases in 2012, according to the Santa Clara University School of Law.', u'Patents apply a "one size fits all" model to industries with differing needs, that is especially unproductive for the software industry.', u'Rent seeking by owners of pharmaceutical patents have also been a particular focus of criticism, as the high prices they enable puts life-saving drugs out of reach of many people.', u'Boldrin and Levine conclude "Our preferred policy solution is to abolish patents entirely and to find other legislative instruments, less open to lobbying and rent seeking, to foster innovation when there is clear evidence that laissez-faire undersupplies it."', u'Abolishing patents may be politically challenging in some countries, however, as the primary economic theories supporting patent law hold that inventors and innovators need patents to recoup the costs associated with research, inventing, and commercializing; this reasoning is weakened if the new technologies decrease these costs.', u'A 2016 paper argued for substantial weakening of patents because current technologies (e.g.', u'3-D printing, cloud computing, synthetic biology, etc.)', u'have reduced the cost of innovation.', u'Debates over the usefulness of patents for their primary objective are part of a larger discourse on intellectual property protection, which also reflects differing perspectives on copyright.', u'=== Anti-patent initiatives ===\nThe Patent Busting Project is an Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) initiative challenging patents that the organization claims are illegitimate and suppress innovation or limit online expression.', u'The initiative launched in 2004 and involves two phases: documenting the damage caused by these patents, and submitting challenges to the United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO).', u'Patent critic, Joseph E. Stiglitz has proposed Prizes as an alternative to patents in order to further advance solutions to global problems such as AIDS.', u'In 2012, Stack Exchange launched Ask Patents, a forum for crowdsourcing prior art to invalidate patents.', u'Several authors have argued for developing defensive prior art to prevent patenting based on obviousness using lists  or algorithms.', u'For example, a Professor of Law at the University of North Carolina, has demonstrated a method to protect DNA research., which could can apply to other technology.', u'Chin wrote an algorithm to generate 11 million "obvious" nucleotide sequences to count as prior art and his algorithmic approach has already proven effective at anticipating prior art against oligonucleotide composition claims filed since his publication of the list and has been cited by the U.S. patent office a number of times.', u'More recently, Joshua Pearce developed an open-source algorithm for identifying prior art for 3-D printing materials to make such materials obvious by patent standards.', u'As the 3-D printing community is already grappling with legal issues, this development was hotly debated in the technical press.', u'Chin made the same algorithem-based obvious argument in DNA probes.', u'Google and other technology companies founded the LOT Network in 2014 to combat patent assertion entities by cross-licensing patents, thereby preventing legal action by such entities.', u'== See also ==\nList of people associated with patent law\nOutline of patents\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== External links ==\nDirectory of Intellectual Property Offices, maintained by World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO)\nUseful links, maintained by the European Patent Office\nOECD Patent statistics\nHenderson, David R. (2002).', u'"Patents".', u'Concise Encyclopedia of Economics (1st ed.).', u'Library of Economics and Liberty.', u'OCLC 317650570, 50016270, 163149563'], 'year': '1845-03-26', 'title': 'Patent awarded for adhesive medicated plaster - precusor of bandaid'}

{'sentences': [u'A veteran (from Latin vetus, meaning "old") is a person who has had long service or experience in a particular occupation or field.', u'This page refers to military veterans, i.e., a person who has served or is serving in the armed forces.', u'Those veterans that have had direct exposure to acts of military conflict may also be referred to as war veterans (although not all military conflicts, or areas in which armed combat takes place, are necessarily referred to as wars).', u'== Public attitude towards veterans ==\n\nMilitary veterans often receive special treatment in their respective countries due to the sacrifices they made during wars.', u'Different countries handle this differently: some openly support veterans through government programs, while others ignore them.', u'Veterans are also subject to illnesses directly related to their military service such as posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).', u'War veterans are generally treated with great respect and honour for their contribution to the world and country by their own nationals.', u'Conversely there are often negative feelings towards the veterans of foreign nations held long after the war is over; for example towards the German Nazi soldiers, yet they are no less veterans of war than those of the winning side.', u'There are exceptions.', u'Veterans of unpopular or lost conflicts may be discriminated against.', u'Veterans of short or small conflicts are often forgotten when the country fought bigger conflicts.', u'In some countries with strong anti-military traditions (e.g., Germany after 1945), veterans are neither honoured in any special way by the general public, nor have their dedicated Veterans Day, although events are sometimes orchestrated by minority groups.', u'Many countries have longstanding traditions, ceremonies, and holidays to honour their veterans.', u'In the UK "Remembrance Day" is held on November the 11th and is focused mostly on the veterans who died in service to the monarch and country.', u'A red or white poppy is worn on the lapel (for remembrance or for peace, respectively) in the weeks up to the date, and wreaths and flowers laid at memorials been an actual war.', u"== Veterans' experiences around the world ==\n\n\n=== Britain ===\n\nBritain, with its historic distrust of standing armies, did little for its veterans before the 19th century.", u'It did set up two small hospitals for them in the 1680s.', u'In London and other cities the streets teemed with disabled or disfigured veterans begging for alms.', u'The First World War focused national attention on veterans, especially those who had been partly or wholly disabled.', u"The King's National Roll Scheme (KNRS) was an employment program for disabled veterans of the First World War.", u'Kowalsky says it was practical, innovative, and ahead of its time and was the most important piece of legislation enacted for disabled veterans in interwar Britain.', u'In addition to direct aid, it stimulate a national discussion regarding the need for employment programs for disabled veterans and the responsibility of the state, setting up a future demand for more benefits.', u'In the 21st century Britain has one of the highest densities of veterans in a major country, with 13 million in 2000, or 219 per 1000 population.', u'=== The Congo ===\n\nSome veterans from the especially one who has served in combat.', u'The National Guard and Reserve is included.', u'It is especially applied to those who served for an entire career, usually of 20 years or more, but may be applied for someone who has only served one tour of duty.', u'A common misconception is that only those who have served in combat or those who have retired from active duty can be called military veterans.', u'==== Veterans\' benefits in the United States ====\nPresident Abraham Lincoln, in his second inaugural address, in 1865 towards the end of the American Civil War, famously called for good treatment of veterans: "to care for him who shall have borne the battle, and for his widow, and his orphan".', u"The American Civil War produced veterans' organizations, such as the Grand Army of marching on Washington, DC, to get a claimed bonus now that Congress had promised them decades in the future.', u"Each state of the United States sets specific criteria for state-specific veterans' veteran experience after OEF and OIF ====\nMany veterans of Operation Enduring Freedom and Operation Iraqi Freedom have had to face challenges unique to warfare in the 21st century.', u'One significant difference between OEF and OIF and previous wars is a greater dependence on reservists and repeat deployments.', u'Up to 80% of troops deployed at the beginning of OEF were part of the National Guard and Reserve and about 40% of currently serving military members have been deployed more than once.', u'This has meant that many deployed troops, not being as \u201c steeped in military culture \u201d have had more difficult transitions into military life, and for many the increased redeployment rate has meant more transitions, more uncertainty, longer terms, and shorter dwell times, all of which contribute to greater stress.', u'Due to medical advances, warfare in the 21st century tends to yield more survivors with severe injuries which soldiers in previous wars would have died from.', u'This means that, though fewer service members die, more return from war with injuries more serious, and in turn more emotionally devastating, than ever before.', u'Among these injuries is service can be profound and lasting, and some veterans have found it difficult to adjust to normal life again.', u'Figures from 2009 showed that twice as many veterans were in prison than there were increase in referrals from doctors.', u'=== Suicide ===\n\nAn article in the London Metro on 28 January 2010 was titled "Veterans prone to suicide" and cited a report by the Mental Health Foundation rate among veterans is 300% the national average.', u'They account for 30% of the suicides in the US annually.', u'Support services were found to be patchy from area to area.', u'=== Posttraumatic Stress Disorder ===\n\nPosttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a condition that affects a significant number of veterans.', u'Studies involving veterans with combat-related PTSD indicate that between 4-17% of United States veterans have been diagnosed with PTSD.', u'There United Kingdom counterparts however, have significantly lower number of just 3-6%.', u'New treatment programs are emerging to assist veterans suffering from post-combat mental health problems such as depression and PTSD.', u'Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), is becoming an important method for the treatment of mental health issues among veterans, and is currently considered the standard of care for depression and PTSD by the United States Department of Defense.', u'CBT is a psychotherapeutic approach that aims to change the patterns of thinking or behavior that responsible for patient\u2019s negative emotions and in doing so change the way they feel.', u'It has been proven to be an effective treatment for PTSD among war veterans.', u'Recently, online programs that pair CBT with therapist interaction have also proven effective in treating mental health problems among veterans.', u'Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) is also an effective and noninvasive, drug-free treatment for PTSD, although it has not been tested against specific military traumatic exposure for efficacy.', u'Veterans under the age of 25 are at higher risk for PTSD than veterans older than 25.', u'Younger veterans with severe PTSD are at higher risk for metabolic syndrome and suicide.', u'=== Other disorders ===\nVeterans are at higher risk than the general population for several disorders, especially younger veterans (those younger than 25).', u'Younger veterans are at increased risk for drug use disorders, alcohol abuse disorders, and mental illnesses in general.', u'=== Help for veterans ===\n\nNecessity has resulted in a number of sources of help being made available for veterans.', u'Many of these are independent, charitable organisations, and in some countries the aftercare and rehabilitation services provided by Governments have been inadequate.', u'This may be because they do not wish to give attention to the negative effects of military service and the difficulties of readjustment to civilian life for it may have an adverse impact upon recruitment for their armed {'sentences': [u'The United States Mint produces circulating coinage for the United States to conduct its trade and commerce, as well as controlling the movement of bullion.', u'It does not produce paper money.', u'The Mint was created in Philadelphia in 1792, and soon joined by other centres, whose coins were identified by their own mint marks.', u'There are currently four active coin-producing mints: Philadelphia, Denver, San Francisco, and West Point.', u'== History ==\n\nThe Mint was created by Congress with the Coinage Act of 1792, and originally placed within the Department of State.', u'Per the terms of the Coinage Act, the first Mint building was in Philadelphia, then the capital of the United States; it was the first building of the Republic raised under the Constitution.', u"Today, the Mint's headquarters (a non-coin-producing facility) are in Washington D.C..", u'It operates mint facilities in Philadelphia, Denver, San Francisco, and West Point, New York and a bullion depository at Fort Knox, Kentucky.', u'Official Mints (Branches) were once also located in Carson City, Nevada, Charlotte, North Carolina, Dahlonega, Georgia, New Orleans, Louisiana, Washington, D.C.; and even in Manila, in the Philippines.', u'Originally part of the State Department, the Mint was made an independent agency in 1799.', u"It converted precious metals into standard coin for anyone's account with no seigniorage charge beyond the refining costs.", u'Under the Coinage Act of 1873, the Mint became part of the Department of the Treasury.', u'It was placed under the auspices of the Treasurer of the United States in 1981.', u"Legal tender coins of today are minted solely for the Treasury's account.", u'The first Director of the United States Mint was renowned scientist David Rittenhouse from 1792 to 1795.', u'The position was held most recently by Edmund C. Moy until his resignation effective January 9, 2011.', u'(The position is currently vacant, the Mint being run by the Principal Deputy Director, Rhett Jeppson, who was appointed in January 2015).', u'Henry Voigt was the first Superintendent and Chief Coiner, and is credited with some of the first U.S. coin designs.', u'Another important position at the Mint is that of Chief Engraver, which has been held by such men as Frank Gasparro, William Barber, Charles E. Barber, James B. Longacre, and Christian Gobrecht.', u'The Mint has operated several branch facilities throughout the United States since the Philadelphia Mint opened in 1792, in a building known as "Ye Olde Mint".', u'With the opening of branch mints came the need for mint marks, an identifying feature on the coin to show its facility of origin.', u'The first of these branch mints were the Charlotte, North Carolina (1838\u20131861), Dahlonega, Georgia (1838\u20131861), and New Orleans, Louisiana (1838\u20131909) branches.', u'Both the Charlotte (C mint mark) and Dahlonega (D mint mark) Mints were opened to facilitate the conversion of local gold deposits into coinage, and minted only gold coins.', u'The Civil War closed both these facilities permanently.', u'The New Orleans Mint (O mint mark) closed at the beginning of the Civil War (1861) and did not re-open until the end of Reconstruction in 1879.', u'During its two stints as a minting facility, it produced both gold and silver coinage in eleven different denominations, though only ten denominations were ever minted there at one time (in 1851 silver three-cent pieces, half dimes, dimes, quarters, half dollars, and gold dollars, Quarter Eagles, half eagles, eagles, and double eagles).', u'A new branch facility was opened in Carson City, Nevada, in 1870; it operated until 1893, with a three-year hiatus from 1886 to 1888.', u'Like the Charlotte and Dahlonega branches, the Carson City Mint (CC mint mark) was opened to take advantage of local precious metal deposits, in this case, a large vein of silver.', u'Though gold coins were also produced there, no base metal coins were.', u"In 1911 the Mint had a female acting director, Margaret Kelly, at that point the highest paid woman on the government's payroll.", u'She stated that women were paid equally within the bureau.', u'A branch of the U.S. mint (Manila Mint) was established in 1920 in Manila in the Philippines, which was then a U.S. colony.', u'To date, the Manila Mint is the only U.S. mint established outside the continental U.S. and was responsible for producing coins for the colony (one, five, ten, twenty and fifty centavo denominations).', u'This branch was in production from 1920 to 1922, and then again from 1925 through 1941.', u'Coins struck by this mint bear either the M mintmark (for Manila) or none at all, similar to the Philadelphia mint at the time.', u'A branch mint in The Dalles, Oregon, was commissioned in 1864.', u'Construction was halted in 1870, and the facility never produced any coins, although the building still stands.', u'== Current facilities ==\nThere are four active coin-producing mints: Philadelphia, Denver, San Francisco, and West Point.', u"=== Philadelphia ===\n\nThe Mint's largest facility is the Philadelphia Mint.", u'The current facility at Philadelphia, which opened in 1969, is the fourth Philadelphia Mint.', u'The first was built in 1792, when Philadelphia was still the U.S. capital, and began operation in 1793.', u'Until 1980, coins minted at Philadelphia bore no mint mark, with the exceptions of the Susan B. Anthony dollar and the wartime Jefferson nickel.', u'In 1980, the P mint mark was added to all U.S. coinage except the cent.', u'Until 1968, the Philadelphia Mint was responsible for nearly all official proof coinage.', u'Philadelphia is also the site of master die production for U.S. coinage, and the engraving and design departments of the Mint are also located there.', u'=== Denver ===\n\nThe Denver branch began life in 1863 as the local assay office, just five years after gold was discovered in the area.', u'By the turn of the century, the office was bringing in over $5 million in annual gold and silver deposits, and in 1906, the Mint opened its new Denver branch.', u'Denver uses a D mint mark and strikes coinage only for circulation, although it did strike, along with three other mints, the $10 gold 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Commemorative.', u'It also produces its own working dies, as well as working dies for the other mints.', u'Although the Denver and Dahlonega mints used the same mint mark D, they were never in operation at the same time, so this is not a source of ambiguity.', u'=== San Francisco ===\n\nThe San Francisco branch, opened in 1854 to serve the goldfields of the California Gold Rush, uses an S mint mark.', u'It quickly outgrew its first building and moved into a new facility in 1874.', u'This building, one of the few that survived the great earthquake and fire of 1906, served until 1937, when the present facility was opened.', u'It was closed in 1955, then reopened a decade later during the coin shortage of the mid-60s.', u'In 1968, it took over most proof-coinage production from Philadelphia, and since 1975, it has been used solely for proof coinage, with the exception of the Anthony dollar and a portion of the mintage of cents in the early 1980s.', u'(These cents are indistinguishable from those minted at Philadelphia.)', u'=== West Point ===\nThe West Point branch is the newest mint facility, gaining official status as a branch mint in 1988.', u'Its predecessor, the West Point Bullion Depository, was opened in 1937, and cents were produced there from 1973 to 1986.', u'Along with these, which were identical to those produced at Philadelphia, West Point has struck a great deal of commemorative and proof coinage bearing the W mint mark.', u'In 1996, West Point produced clad dimes, but for collectors, not for circulation.', u"The West Point facility is still used for storage of part of the United States' gold bullion reserves, and West Point is now the United States' production facility for gold, silver and platinum American Eagle coins.", u'=== Fort Knox ===\nWhile not a coin production facility, the U.S. Bullion Depository at Fort Knox, Kentucky, is another facility of the Mint.', u"Its primary purpose is for storage of the United States and other countries' gold and silver bullion reserves.", u'== Functions ==\nThe Mint manages extensive commercial marketing programs.', u'The product line includes special coin sets for collectors, national medals, American Eagle gold, silver and platinum bullion coins, and commemorative coins marking national events such as the Bicentennial of the Constitution.', u"The Mint's functions include:\nProducing domestic, bullion and foreign coins;\nManufacturing and selling national commemorative medals;\nDesigning and producing the congressional gold medals;\nDesigning, producing, and marketing special coinage;\nSafeguarding and controlling the movement of bullion;\nDisbursing gold and silver for authorized purposes;\nDistributing coins from the various mints to Federal Reserve Banks.", u'Note that the Mint is not responsible for the production of paper money; that is the responsibility of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing.', u'In 2000, the Mint was responsible for the production of 28 billion coins.', u'See United States Mint coin production for annual production values of each coin.', u'The United States Mint Police, a federal law enforcement agency, is responsible for protection of Mint facilities, employees and reserves.', u"== Mintmarks ==\n\nWith the exception of a brief period in 1838 and 1839, all coins minted at U.S. branch mints prior to 1909 displayed that branch's mintmark on their reverse.", u'Larger denominations of gold and silver coins were labeled with the Dahlonega, Charlotte, and New Orleans mintmarks (D, C, and O, respectively) on the obverse (just above the dates) in those two years.', u'Carson City, which served as a U.S. branch mint from 1870 to 1893, produced coins with a CC mintmark.', u'The Manila Mint (the only overseas U.S. mint, which produced U.S. Territorial and U.S. Commonwealth coinage) used the M mintmark from 1920\u20131941.', u'Between 1965 and 1967, as the Mint labored to replace the silver coinage with base metal coins, mintmarks were temporarily dispensed with (including on the penny and nickel) in order to discourage the hoarding of coins by numismatists.', u'Mintmarks were moved to the obverse of the nickel, dime, quarter, and half dollar in 1968, and have appeared on the obverse of the dollar coin since its re-introduction in 1971.', u"Penny: Unlike all other coins, which had their mintmarks on the reverse until 1964, the Lincoln cent has always had its mintmark on the obverse below the date to the right of Lincoln's bust since its 1909 introduction.", u"Nickel: The mintmark was located near the rim of the obverse side, clockwise from the date from 1968 to 2005, to the right of Thomas Jefferson's bust.", u'The redesigned obverse of the nickel which appeared starting in 2006 has its mintmark below the date on the lower right.', u'Many earlier nickels from 1938 to 1964 are still in circulation, and their mintmarks can be found on the reverse to the right of Monticello, with the exception of the 1942\u20131945 war nickels cited elsewhere in this article.', u"Dime: The mintmark is above the date on the obverse side to the right of Franklin Delano Roosevelt's bust.", u"Quarter dollar: The mintmark is to the right of George Washington's bust.", u"Half dollar: The mintmark is below the center of John F. Kennedy's bust, above the date.", u"Eisenhower Dollar (1971\u20131978): The mintmark is below the center of Dwight D. Eisenhower's bust, above the date.", u"Susan B. Anthony dollar (1979\u20131981, 1999): The mintmark is found to the left of Susan B. Anthony's bust.", u'Sacagawea dollar (2000\u20132016): For coins minted from 2000 to 2008, the mintmark is just below the date.', u'For coins minted from 2009 to 2016, the date, mintmark and E pluribus unum were moved to the rim of the coin.', u'Presidential dollar (2007\u20132016): The mintmark and date are found on the rim of the coin.', u'Due to a shortage of nickel during World War II, the composition of the five-cent coin was changed to include silver.', u'To mark this change, nickels minted in Philadelphia (which had featured no mintmarks until then) displayed a P in the field above the dome of Monticello.', u'Nickels from San Francisco were minted in the same fashion, and Denver nickels reflected the change in 1943.', u'This new mintmark location continued until 1946, when the nickel returned to its pre-war composition.', u'The P mintmark, discontinued after the war, reappeared in 1979 on the Anthony dollar.', u'By 1982, it had appeared on every other regular-issue coin except the cent, which still bears no P mintmark.', u"The circulating cents struck in the 1980s at San Francisco (except proofs) and West Point also bear no mintmark, as their facilities were used to supplement Philadelphia's production.", u'Given the limited numbers produced at each facility, they might have been hoarded as collectibles.', u'== See also ==\nAmerican Arts Commemorative Series medallion\nBureau of Engraving and Printing\nCoins of the United States dollar\nEarly United States commemorative coins\nModern United States commemorative coins\nUnited States commemorative coin\nUnited States Mint coin sets\nList of Federal Reserve branches\n\n\n== References ==\nNotes\n\n\n== External links ==\nU.S. Mint website\nU.S. Mint in the Federal Register'], 'year': '1862-04-21', 'title': 'Congress establishes US Mint in Denver - Colorado.'}
{'sentences': [u"A supernova is an astronomical event that occurs during the last stellar evolutionary stages of a massive star's life, whose dramatic and catastrophic destruction is marked by one final titanic explosion.", u"For a short time, this causes the sudden appearance of a 'new' bright star, before slowly fading from sight over several weeks or months.", u'Only three Milky Way naked-eye supernova events have been observed during the last thousand years, though many have been telescopically seen in other galaxies.', u"The most recent directly observed supernova in the Milky Way was Kepler's Supernova in 1604, but remnants of two more recent supernovae have been found retrospectively.", u'Statistical observations of supernovae in other galaxies suggest they should occur on average about three times every century in the Milky Way, and that any galactic supernova would almost certainly be observable in modern astronomical equipment.', u'Supernovae are more energetic than novae.', u'In Latin, nova means "new", referring astronomically to what appears to be a temporary new bright star.', u'Adding the prefix "super-" distinguishes supernovae from ordinary novae, which are far less luminous.', u'The word supernova was coined by Walter Baade and Fritz Zwicky in 1931.', u'It is pronounced /\u02ccsu\u02d0p\u0259rno\u028av\u0259/ with the plural supernovae /\u02ccsu\u02d0p\u0259rno\u028avi\u02d0/ or supernovas (abbreviated SN, plural SNe after "supernovae").', u'During maximum brightness, the total equivalent radiant energies produced by supernovae may briefly outshine an entire output of a typical galaxy and emit energies equal to that created over the lifetime of any solar-like star.', u'Such extreme catastrophes may also expel much, if not all, of its stellar material away from the star, at velocities up to 7007300000000000000\u266030,000 km/s or 10% of the speed of light.', u'This drives an expanding and fast-moving shock wave into the surrounding interstellar medium, and in turn, sweeping up an expanding shell of gas and dust, which is observed as a supernova remnant.', u'Supernovae create, fuse and eject the bulk of the chemical elements produced by nucleosynthesis.', u'Supernovae play a significant role in enriching the interstellar medium with the heavier atomic mass chemical elements.', u'Furthermore, the expanding shock waves from supernova explosions can trigger the formation of new stars.', u'Supernova remnants are expected to accelerate a large fraction of galactic primary cosmic rays, but direct evidence for cosmic ray production was found only in a few of them so far.', u'They are also potentially strong galactic sources of gravitational waves.', u"Theoretical studies of many supernovae indicate that most are triggered by one of two basic mechanisms: the sudden re-ignition of nuclear fusion in a degenerate star or the sudden gravitational collapse of a massive star's core.", u'In the first instance, a degenerate white dwarf may accumulate sufficient material from a binary companion, either through accretion or via a merger, to raise its core temperature enough to trigger runaway nuclear fusion, completely disrupting the star.', u'In the second case, the core of a massive star may undergo sudden gravitational collapse, releasing gravitational potential energy as a supernova.', u'While some observed supernovae are more complex than these two simplified theories, the astrophysical collapse mechanics have been established and accepted by most astronomers for some time.', u'Due to the wide range of astrophysical consequences of these events, astronomers now deem supernovae research, across the fields of stellar and galactic evolution, as an especially important area for investigation.', u'== Etymology ==\nIn Latin, Nova means "new", referring astronomically to what appears to be a temporary new bright star.', u'Adding the prefix "super-" distinguishes supernovae from ordinary novae, which are far less luminous.', u'The word supernova was coined by Walter Baade and Fritz Zwicky in 1931.', u'It is pronounced /\u02ccsu\u02d0p\u0259rno\u028av\u0259/ with the plural supernovae /\u02ccsu\u02d0p\u0259rno\u028avi\u02d0/ or supernovas (abbreviated SN, plural SNe after "supernovae").', u'== Observation history ==\n\nThe earliest recorded supernova, SN 185, was viewed by Chinese astronomers in 185 AD, with the brightest recorded supernova being SN 1006, which occurred in 1006 AD and was described in detail by Chinese and Islamic astronomers.', u'The widely observed supernova SN 1054 produced the Crab Nebula.', u'Supernovae SN 1572 and SN 1604, the latest to be observed with the naked eye in the Milky Way galaxy, had notable effects on the development of astronomy in Europe because they were used to argue against the Aristotelian idea that the universe beyond the Moon and planets was static and unchanging.', u'Johannes Kepler began observing SN 1604 at its peak on October 17, 1604, and continued to make estimates of its brightness until it faded from naked eye view a year later.', u'It was the second supernova to be observed in a generation (after SN 1572 seen by Tycho Brahe in Cassiopeia).', u'Before the development of the telescope, there have only been five supernovae seen in the last millennium.', u"In the perspective of how long a star's lifetime is, its death is very brief.", u"In fact, a star's death may only last a few months.", u'Due to this, a typical human will only experience this rarity, on average, once in their lifetime.', u'This is a microscopic fraction in comparison to the 100 billion stars that compose a galaxy.', u'However, since the use of modern equipment, particularly in this millennium, professional and amateur astronomers have been finding several hundreds of supernovae each year.', u'The field of supernova discovery has extended to other galaxies, starting with SN 1885A in the Andromeda galaxy.', u'American astronomers Rudolph Minkowski and Fritz Zwicky developed the modern supernova classification scheme beginning in 1941.', u'In the 1960s, astronomers found that the maximum intensities of supernova explosions could be used as standard candles, hence indicators of astronomical distances.', u'Some of the most distant supernovae recently observed appeared dimmer than expected.', u'This supports the view that the expansion of the universe is accelerating.', u'Techniques were developed for reconstructing supernova explosions that have no written records of being
