{'sentences': [u'Kurt Josef Waldheim (German pronunciation: [\u02c8k\u028a\u0250\u032ft \u02c8valdha\u026am]; 21 December 1918 \u2013 14 June 2007) was an Austrian diplomat and politician.', u'Waldheim was the fourth Secretary-General of the United Nations from 1972 to 1981, and the ninth President of Austria from 1986 to 1992.', u'While he was running for president in Austria in 1985, the revelation of his service in Salonica as an intelligence officer in the Wehrmacht during World War II raised international controversy.', u'== Early life and education ==\nWaldheim was born in Sankt Andr\xe4-W\xf6rdern, a village near Vienna, on 21 December 1918.', u'His father was a Roman Catholic school inspector of Czech origin named Watzlawick (original Czech spelling V\xe1clav\xedk) who changed his name that year as the Habsburg monarchy collapsed.', u'Waldheim served in the Austrian Army (1936\u201337) and attended the Vienna Consular Academy, where he graduated in 1939.', u"Waldheim's father was active in the Christian Social Party.", u'Waldheim himself was politically unaffiliated during these years at the Academy.', u"Three weeks after the German annexation of Austria in 1938, Waldheim applied for membership in the National Socialist German Students' League (NSDStB), a division of the Nazi Party.", u'Shortly thereafter he became a registered member of the mounted corps of the SA.', u'On 19 August 1944, he married Elisabeth Ritschel in Vienna; their first daughter, Lieselotte, was born the following year.', u'A son, Gerhard, and another daughter, Christa, followed.', u'== Military service in World War II ==\nIn early 1941, Waldheim was drafted into the Wehrmacht and posted to the Eastern Front where he served as a squad leader.', u'In December of that year, he was wounded but he returned to service in 1942.', u'His service in the Wehrmacht from 1942 to 1945 was the subject of international review in 1985 and 1986.', u'In his 1985 autobiography, he stated that he was discharged from further service at the front and, for the remainder of the war, finished his law degree at the University of Vienna, in addition to marrying in 1944.', u'After publication, documents and witnesses came to light that revealed Waldheim\u2019s military service continued until 1945, during which time he rose to the rank of Oberleutnant.', u"=== Service in Yugoslavia and Greece ===\nWaldheim's functions within the staff of German Army Group E from 1942 until 1945, as determined by the International Commission of Historians, were:\nInterpreter and liaison officer with the 5th Alpine Division (Italy) in April/May 1942, then,\nO2 officer (communications) with Kampfgruppe West in Bosnia in June/August 1942,\nInterpreter with the liaison staff attached to the Italian 9th Army in Tirana in early summer 1942,\nO1 officer in the German liaison staff with the Italian 11th Army and in the staff of the Army Group South in Greece in July/October 1943, and\nO3 officer on the staff of Army Group E in Arksali, Kosovska Mitrovica and Sarajevo from October 1943 to January/February 1945.", u'By 1943, Waldheim was serving in the capacity of an aide-de-camp in Army Group E which was headed by General Alexander L\xf6hr.', u'In 1986, Waldheim said that he had served only as an interpreter and a clerk and had no knowledge either of reprisals against local Serb civilians or of massacres in neighboring provinces of Yugoslavia.', u'He said that he had known about some of the things that had happened, and had been horrified, but could not see what else he could have done.', u"Much historical interest has centered on Waldheim's role in Operation Kozara in 1942.", u"According to one post-war investigator, prisoners were routinely shot within only a few hundred meters (yards) of Waldheim's office, and just 35 kilometres (22 mi) away at the Jasenovac concentration camp.", u'Waldheim later stated that "he did not know about the murder of civilians there".', u'Waldheim\'s name appears on the Wehrmacht\'s "honor list" of those responsible for the militarily successful operation.', u'The Nazi puppet state, the Independent State of Croatia, awarded Waldheim the Medal of the Crown of King Zvonimir in silver with an oak branches cluster.', u'Decades later, during the lobbying for his election as U.N. Secretary General, Yugoslav President Josip Broz Tito, who had led anti-German forces during the war, awarded Waldheim one of the highest Yugoslav orders.', u"Waldheim denied that he knew war crimes were taking place in Bosnia at the height of the battles between the Nazis and Tito's partisans in 1943.", u'According to Eli Rosenbaum, in 1944, Waldheim reviewed and approved a packet of anti-Semitic propaganda leaflets to be dropped behind Soviet lines, one of which ended: "Enough of the Jewish war, kill the Jews, come over."', u'=== Surrender ===\nIn 1945, Waldheim surrendered to British forces in Carinthia, at which point he said he had fled his command post within Army Group E, where he was serving with General L\xf6hr, who was seeking a special deal with the British.', u'== Diplomatic career ==\nWaldheim joined the Austrian diplomatic service in 1945, after finishing his studies in law at the University of Vienna.', u'He served as First Secretary of the Legation in Paris from 1948, and in the Ministry for Foreign Affairs in Vienna from 1951 to 1956.', u'In 1956 he was made Ambassador to Canada, returning to the Ministry in 1960, after which he became the Permanent Representative of Austria to the United Nations in 1964.', u"For two years beginning in 1968, he was the Federal Minister for Foreign Affairs in Austria serving for the Austrian People's Party, before going back as Permanent Representative to the U.N. in 1970.", u'Shortly afterwards, he ran and was defeated in the 1971 Austrian presidential elections.', u"=== United Nations Secretary-General ===\n\nAfter being defeated in his home country's presidential election, he was appointed to succeed U Thant as United Nations Secretary-General the same year.", u'As Secretary-General, Waldheim opened and addressed a number of major international conferences convened under United Nations auspices.', u'These included the third session of the U.N. Conference on Trade and Development (Santiago, April 1972), the U.N. Conference on the Human Environment (Stockholm, June 1972), the third UN Conference on the Law of the Sea (Caracas, June 1974), the Third World Population Conference (Bucharest, August 1974) and the World Food Conference (Rome, November 1974).', u'However, his diplomatic efforts particularly in the Middle East were overshadowed by the diplomacy of then U.S. Secretary of State, Henry Kissinger.', u'On 11 September 1972, Ugandan dictator Idi Amin sent a telegram to Waldheim, copies of which went to Yasser Arafat and Golda Meir.', u'In the telegram, Amin "applauded the massacre of the Israeli Olympic athletes in Munich and said Germany was the most appropriate locale for this because it was where Hitler burned more than six million Jews."', u'Amin also called "to expel Israel from the United Nations and to send all the Israelis to Britain, which bore the guilt for creating the Jewish state."', u'Amidst international protest, "the UN spokesman said [in his daily press conference] it was not the secretary-general\'s practice to comment on telegrams sent him by heads of government.', u'He added that the secretary-general condemned any form of racial discrimination and genocide."', u'After Operation Entebbe on 7 July 1976 \u2014 where Israeli commandos freed more than 100 Israeli and Jewish passengers held captive in Entebbe Airport (Uganda\'s main airport) by Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine and German Revolutionary Cells fighters protected by forces of Ugandan dictator Idi Amin, and where all the hijackers, three hostages and 45 Ugandan soldiers were killed \u2014 Waldheim described the raid as a "serious violation of the national sovereignty of a United Nations member state".', u'Waldheim was appointed again in 1976 despite some opposition.', u'Waldheim and then-U.S. President Jimmy Carter both prepared written statements for inclusion on the Voyager Golden Records, now in deep space.', u'He was the first Secretary-General to visit North Korea, in 1979.', u'In 1980, Waldheim flew to Iran in an attempt to negotiate the release of the American hostages held in Tehran, but Ayatollah Khomeini refused to see him.', u"While in Tehran, it was announced that an attempt on Waldheim's life had been foiled.", u'Near the end of his tenure as Secretary-General, Waldheim and Paul McCartney organized a series of concerts for the People of Kampuchea to help Cambodia recover from the damage done by Pol Pot.', u"China vetoed Waldheim's candidature, and he was succeeded by Javier P\xe9rez de Cu\xe9llar of Peru.", u'== Presidency of Austria ==\n\n\n=== Election and Waldheim Affair ===\nWaldheim had unsuccessfully sought election as President of Austria in 1971, but his second attempt on 8 June 1986 proved successful.', u'During his campaign for the presidency in 1985, the events started that marked the beginning of what became known internationally as the "Waldheim affair".', u"Before the presidential elections, investigative journalist Alfred Worm revealed in the Austrian weekly news magazine Profil that there had been several omissions about Waldheim's life between 1938 and 1945 in his recently published autobiography.", u'A short time later, the World Jewish Congress alleged that Waldheim had lied about his service as an officer in the mounted corps of the SA, and his time as an ordnance officer for Army Group E in Saloniki, Greece, from 1942 to 1943 based on files from the United Nations War Crimes Commission.', u'Waldheim called the allegations "pure lies and malicious acts".', u'Nevertheless, he admitted that he had known about German reprisals against partisans: "Yes, I knew.', u'I was horrified.', u'But what could I do?', u'I had either to continue to serve or be executed."', u'He said that he had never fired a shot or even seen a partisan.', u'His former immediate superior at the time stated that Waldheim had "remained confined to a desk".', u'Former Austrian chancellor Bruno Kreisky, of Jewish origin, denounced the actions of the World Jewish Congress as an "extraordinary infamy", adding that Austrians would not "allow the Jews abroad to ... tell us who should be our President."', u"Part of the reason for the controversy was Austria's refusal to address its national role in the Holocaust.", u'(Many leading Nazis, including Adolf Hitler, were Austrians, and Austria became part of the Third Reich.)', u'Austria refused to pay compensation to Nazi victims, and from 1970 onwards refused to investigate Austrian citizens who were senior Nazis.', u'Stolen Jewish art remained public property until after the Waldheim affair.', u'Because the revelations leading to the Waldheim affair came shortly before the presidential election, there has been speculation about the background of the affair.', u'Declassified CIA documents show that the CIA had been aware of his wartime past since 1945.', u"Information about Waldheim's wartime past was also previously published by a pro-German Austrian newspaper, Salzburger Volksblatt, during the 1971 presidential election campaign, including the claim of an SS membership, but the matter was supposedly regarded as unimportant or even advantageous for the candidate at that time.", u'It has been asserted that his wartime past and the discrepancies in his autobiography, In the Eye of the Storm, must have been well-known to both superpowers before he was elected UN Secretary General, and there were rumours that the KGB had blackmailed him during his UN time (for example here and here).', u'In 1994, former Mossad officer Victor Ostrovsky claimed in his book The Other Side of Deception that Mossad doctored the file of the then UN Secretary General to implicate him in Nazi crimes.', u'These allegedly false documents were subsequently "discovered" by Benjamin Netanyahu in the UN file and triggered the "Waldheim Affair".', u"Ostrovsky says it was motivated by Waldheim's criticism of Israel's war in Lebanon.", u'Controversy surrounds Ostrovsky because many of his revelations have not been sourced or otherwise confirmed, leading several critics to say that most of his work (including TOSOD) is fictional.', u"Ostrovsky's service in Mossad was confirmed when the Israeli government unsuccessfully attempted to stop publication of the book.", u"=== The International Committee of Historians and allegations of Nazi war crimes ===\nIn view of the ongoing international controversy, the Austrian government decided to appoint an international committee of historians to examine Waldheim's life between 1938 and 1945.", u'Their report found no evidence of any personal involvement in those crimes.', u'Although Waldheim had stated that he was unaware of any crimes taking place, the committee cited evidence that Waldheim must have known about war crimes.', u'In response to Waldheim\'s denial that he knew about war crimes, Simon Wiesenthal stated that Waldheim was stationed 5 miles (8.0 km) from Salonika while, over the course of several weeks, the Jewish community, which formed one-third of the population there, was sent to Auschwitz:\n\nI could only reply what the committee of historians likewise made clear in its report: "I cannot believe you."', u'Wiesenthal stated the committee found no evidence that Waldheim took part in any war crimes but was guilty of lying about his military record.', u'The International Committee in February 1988 concluded that he could not stop what was going on in Yugoslavia and Greece even if he knew:\n\nIn favour of Waldheim is, that he only had very minor possibilities to act against the injustices happening.', u'Actions against these, depending on which level the resistance occurred, were of very different importance.', u'For a young member of the staff, who did not have any military authority on the army group level, the practical possibilities for resistance were very limited and with a high probability would not have led to any actual results.', u'Resistance would have been limited to a formal protest or on the refusal to serve any longer in the army, which would have seemed to be a courageous act, however would have not led to any practical achievement.', u'=== Foreign visits ===\nThroughout his term as President (1986\u20131992), Kurt Waldheim and his wife Elisabeth were officially deemed personae non gratae by the United States.', u'== Later years and death ==\n\nAfter his term ended in 1992, Waldheim did not seek re-election.', u'The same year, he was made an honorary member of K.H.V.', u'Welfia Klosterneuburg, a Roman Catholic student fraternity a part of the Austrian Cartellverband.', u'In 1994, Pope John Paul II awarded Waldheim a knighthood in the Order of Pius IX and his wife a papal honor.', u'He died on 14 June 2007, from heart failure.', u'On 23 June, his funeral was held at St. Stephen\'s Cathedral, Vienna, and he was buried at the Presidential Vault in the Zentralfriedhof ("central cemetery").', u'In his speech at the Cathedral, Federal President Heinz Fischer called Waldheim "a great Austrian" who had been wrongfully accused of having committed war crimes.', u'Fischer also praised Waldheim for his efforts to solve international crises and for his contributions to world peace.', u"At Waldheim's own request, no foreign heads of states or governments were invited to attend his funeral the day after he died, Waldheim admitted making "mistakes" ("but these were certainly not those of a follower let alone an accomplice of a criminal regime") and asked his critics for forgiveness.', ice hockey film entitled Hockey, The Lighter Side, former New York Rangers goaltender John Davidson is explaining his fictional goaltender school, and as hockey highlights play, he exclaims, "You\'ll have more shots taken at you than Kurt Waldheim."', u'In episode 3, series 2 of The Million Pound Radio Show, Andy Hamilton announces next week\'s special guest as Waldheim, "although he\'ll deny [his appearance on the show] in 40 years time."', u'During the filming of Schindler\'s List, comedian Robin Williams cheered director Steven Spielberg with a spoof telemarketing call from "the Waldheimers Association, a society devoted to helping raise money to help older Germans who had forgotten everything before 1945."', u'In an episode of The New Statesman, aired in 1989, Alan B\'Stard (Rik Mayall) attempts to blackmail an aged former Nazi officer, who complains that, "it\'s not fair; I\'m living here in the tripe capital of Europe, while Kurt Waldheim is President of Austria \u2014 and he was beneath me!"', u"American poet Srikanth Reddy's 2011 book Voyager presents a collection of poems and fragments created by erasing large sections of Waldheim's memoir In the Eye of the Storm.", u'Graphic novel and film Persepolis (comics) by Marjane Satrapi reference the election in Austria.', u'In the 2015 fiction novel The Lady From Zagreb by Philip Kerr, the protagonist, Captain Bernie Gunther, encounters a young Intelligence Officer, Lieutenant Kurt Waldheim while on a mission in Yugoslavia in 1942.', u"In the 2015 film Woman in Gold, Hubertus Czernin shows Maria Altmann an issue of Profil uncovering Waldheim's Nazi past.", u'== Further reading ==\nBassett, Richard (1988).', u'Waldheim and Austria, Penguin Books.', u'ISBN 978-0-14-013019-5\nHerzstein, Robert Edwin (1988).', {'sentences': [u'The Soviet Union (Russian: \u0421\u043e\u0432\u0435\u0301\u0442\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0439 \u0421\u043e\u044e\u0301\u0437, tr.', u"Sovetskiy Soyuz; IPA: [s\u0250'v\u02b2etsk\u02b2\u026aj s\u0250\u02c8j\u0289s]), officially the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (Russian: \u0421\u043e\u044e\u0301\u0437 \u0421\u043e\u0432\u0435\u0301\u0442\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0445 \u0421\u043e\u0446\u0438\u0430\u043b\u0438\u0441\u0442\u0438\u0301\u0447\u0435\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0445 \u0420\u0435\u0441\u043f\u0443\u0301\u0431\u043b\u0438\u043a, tr.", u'Soyuz Sovetskikh Sotsialisticheskikh Respublik; IPA: [s\u0250\u02c8jus s\u0250\u02c8v\u02b2\u025btsk\u02b2\u026ax s\u0259ts\u0268\u0259l\u02b2\u026as\u02c8t\u02b2it\u0255\u026ask\u02b2\u026ax r\u02b2\u026a\u02c8spubl\u02b2\u026ak]), abbreviated to USSR (Russian: \u0421\u0421\u0421\u0420, tr.', u'SSSR), was a socialist state on the Eurasian continent that existed from 1922 to 1991.', u'A union of multiple subnational Soviet republics, its government and economy were highly centralized.', u'The Soviet Union was a one-party federation, governed by the Communist Party with Moscow as its capital.', u'The Soviet Union had its roots in the October Revolution of 1917, when the Bolsheviks, led by Vladimir Lenin, overthrew the provisional government that had replaced the Tsar.', u'They established the Russian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic (renamed Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic in 1936), beginning a civil war between the revolutionary "Reds" and the counter-revolutionary "Whites."', u'The Red Army entered several territories of the former Russian Empire and helped local Communists take power through soviets, which nominally acted on behalf of workers and peasants.', u'In 1922, the Communists were victorious, forming the Soviet Union with the unification of the Russian, Transcaucasian, Ukrainian, and Byelorussian republics.', u"Following Lenin's death in 1924, a troika and a brief power struggle, Joseph Stalin came to power in the mid-1920s.", u'Stalin suppressed all political opposition to his rule, committed the state ideology to Marxism\u2013Leninism (which he created), and initiated a centrally planned command economy.', u'As a result, the country underwent a period of rapid industrialization and collectivization which laid the foundation for its victory in World War II and post-war dominance of Eastern Europe.', u'Stalin also fomented political paranoia, and conducted the Great Purge to remove opponents of his from the Communist Party through the mass arbitrary arrest of many people (military leaders, Communist Party members, and ordinary citizens alike) who were then sent to correctional labor camps or sentenced to death.', u'Shortly before World War II, Stalin signed the non-aggression pact with Nazi Germany, after which the two countries invaded Poland in September 1939.', u'In June 1941 the Germans invaded, opening the largest and bloodiest theater of war in history.', u'Soviet war casualties accounted for the highest proportion of the conflict in the cost of acquiring the upper hand over Axis forces at intense battles such as Stalingrad.', u'Soviet forces eventually captured Berlin in 1945.', u'The territory overtaken by the Red Army became satellite states of the Eastern Bloc.', u'The Cold War emerged by 1947 as the Soviet bloc confronted the Western states that united in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in 1949.', u'Following Stalin\'s death in 1953, a period of political and economic liberalization, known as "de-Stalinization" and "Khrushchev\'s Thaw", occurred under the leadership of Nikita Khrushchev.', u'The country developed rapidly, as millions of peasants were moved into industrialized cities.', u'The USSR took an early lead in the Space Race with the first ever satellite and the first human spaceflight.', u'In the 1970s, there was a brief d\xe9tente of relations with the United States, but tensions resumed when the Soviet Union deployed troops in Afghanistan in 1979.', u'The war drained economic resources and was matched by an escalation of American military aid to Mujahideen fighters.', u'In the mid-1980s, the last Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, sought to further reform and liberalize the economy through his policies of glasnost and perestroika.', u'The goal was to preserve the Communist Party while reversing economic stagnation.', u'The Cold War ended during his tenure, and in 1989 Soviet satellite countries in Eastern Europe overthrew their respective communist regimes.', u'This led to the rise of strong nationalist and separatist movements inside the USSR as well.', u'Central authorities initiated a referendum\u2014boycotted by the Baltic republics, Armenia, Georgia, and Moldova\u2014which resulted in the majority of participating citizens voting in favor of preserving the Union as a renewed federation.', u"In August 1991, a coup d'\xe9tat was attempted by Communist Party hardliners.", u'It failed, with Russian President Boris Yeltsin playing a high-profile role in facing down the coup, resulting in the banning of the Communist Party.', u'On 25 December 1991, Gorbachev resigned and the remaining twelve constituent republics emerged from the dissolution of the Soviet Union as independent post-Soviet states.', u"The Russian Federation (formerly the Russian SFSR) assumed the Soviet Union's rights and obligations and has emerged as the recognized primary legal successor of the Soviet Union.", u'== Name ==\n\nThe word \u201cSoviet\u201d is derived from a Russian word meaning council, assembly, advice, harmony, concord, and all ultimately deriving from the Proto-Slavic verbal stem of *v\u011bt-iti "to inform", related to Slavic "v\u011bst" ("news"), English "wise", the root in "ad-vis-or" (which came to English through French), or the Dutch "weten" (to know; cf.', u'"wetenschap" = science).', u'The word "sovietnik" means councillor.', u'A number of organizations in Russian history were called "council" (Russian: \u0441\u043e\u0432\u0435\u0301\u0442).', u'For example, in the Russian Empire, the State Council, which functioned from 1810 to 1917, was referred to as a Council of Ministers after the revolt of 1905.', u'From the beginning, the Soviet Union was the called the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics from its founding, although all the republics began as Socialist Soviet and did not change to the other order until 1936.', u'In addition, in the national languages of several republics the word "Council/Conciliar" in the respective language was only quite late changed to an adaptation of the Russian "Soviet" - and never in others, e.g., Ukraine.', u'The names of the Soviet Union are as follows in several languages of its 15 constituent republics:\nRussian: \u0421\u043e\u044e\u0437 \u0421\u043e\u0432\u0435\u0442\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0445
