Nostradamus dies in Salon'}
{'sentences': [u'John Couch Adams FRS (5 June 1819 \u2013 21 January 1892) was a British mathematician and astronomer.', u'Adams was born in Laneast, near Launceston, Cornwall, and died in Cambridge.', u'The Cornish name Couch is pronounced "cooch".', u'His most famous achievement was predicting the existence and position of Neptune, using only mathematics.', u"The calculations were made to explain discrepancies with Uranus's orbit and the laws of Kepler and Newton.", u'At the same time, but unknown to each other, the same calculations were made by Urbain Le Verrier.', u"Le Verrier would send his coordinates to Berlin Observatory astronomer Johann Gottfried Galle, who confirmed the existence of the planet on 23 September 1846, finding it within 1\xb0 of Le Verrier's predicted location (there was, and to some extent still is, some controversy over the apportionment of credit for the discovery; see Discovery of Neptune).", u'He was Lowndean Professor in the University of Cambridge from 1859 until his death.', u'He won the Gold Medal of the Royal Astronomical Society in 1866.', u'In 1884, he attended the International Meridian Conference as a delegate for Britain.', u'A crater on the Moon is jointly named after him, Walter Sydney Adams and Charles Hitchcock Adams.', u"Neptune's outermost known ring and the asteroid 1996 Adams are also named after him.", u'The Adams Prize, presented by the University of Cambridge, commemorates his prediction of the position of Neptune.', u'His personal library is held at Cambridge University Library.', u'== Early life ==\n\nAdams was born at Lidcot, a farm at Laneast, near Launceston, Cornwall, the eldest of seven children.', u'His parents were Thomas Adams (1788\u20131859), a poor tenant farmer, and his wife, Tabitha Knill Grylls (1796\u20131866).', u"The family were devout Wesleyans who enjoyed music and among John's brothers, Thomas became a missionary, George a farmer, and William Grylls Adams, professor of natural philosophy and astronomy at King's College London.", u"Tabitha was a farmer's daughter but had received a rudimentary education from John Couch, her uncle, whose small library she had inherited.", u'John was intrigued by the astronomy books from an early age.', u'John attended the Laneast village school where he acquired some Greek and algebra.', u"From there, he went, at the age of twelve, to Devonport, where his mother's cousin, the Rev.", u'John Couch Grylls, kept a private school.', u"There he learned classics but was largely self-taught in mathematics, studying in the Library of Devonport Mechanics' Institute and reading Rees's Cyclop\xe6dia and Samuel Vince's Fluxions.", u"He observed Halley's comet in 1835 from Landulph and the following year started to make his own astronomical calculations, predictions and observations, engaging in private tutoring to finance his activities.", u'In 1836, his mother inherited a small estate at Badharlick and his promise as a mathematician induced his parents to send him to the University of Cambridge.', u"In October 1839 he entered as a sizar at St John's College, graduating B.A.", u"in 1843 as senior wrangler and first Smith's prizeman of his year.", u"== Discovery of Neptune ==\n\nIn 1821, Alexis Bouvard had published astronomical tables of the orbit of Uranus, making predictions of future positions based on Newton's laws of motion and gravitation.", u'Subsequent observations revealed substantial deviations from the tables, leading Bouvard to hypothesize some perturbing body.', u'Adams learnt of the irregularities while still an undergraduate and became convinced of the "perturbation" theory.', u"Adams believed, in the face of anything that had been attempted before, that he could use the observed data on Uranus, and utilising nothing more than Newton's law of gravitation, deduce the mass, position and orbit of the perturbing body.", u'On 3 July 1841, he noted his intention to work on the problem.', u'After his final examinations in 1843, Adams was elected fellow of his college and spent the summer vacation in Cornwall calculating the first of six iterations.', u'While he worked on the problem back in Cambridge, he tutored undergraduates, sending money home to educate his brothers, and even taught his bedmaker to read.', u'Apparently, Adams communicated his work to James Challis, director of the Cambridge Observatory, in mid-September 1845 but there is some controversy as to how.', u'On 21 October 1845, Adams, returning from a Cornwall vacation, without appointment, twice called on Astronomer Royal George Biddell Airy in Greenwich.', u'Failing to find him at home, Adams reputedly left a manuscript of his solution, again without the detailed calculations.', u'Airy responded with a letter to Adams asking for some clarification.', u'It appears that Adams did not regard the question as "trivial", as is often alleged, but he failed to complete a response.', u"Various theories have been discussed as to Adams's failure to reply, such as his general nervousness, procrastination and disorganisation.", u'Meanwhile, Urbain Le Verrier, on 10 November 1845, presented to the Acad\xe9mie des sciences in Paris a memoir on Uranus, showing that the pre-existing theory failed to account for its motion.', u"On reading Le Verrier's memoir, Airy was struck by the coincidence and initiated a desperate race for English priority in discovery of the planet.", u'The search was begun by a laborious method on 29 July.', u'Only after the discovery of Neptune on 23 September 1846 had been announced in Paris did it become apparent that Neptune had been observed on 8 and 12 August but because Challis lacked an up-to-date star-map it was not recognized as a planet.', u'A keen controversy arose in France and England as to the merits of the two astronomers.', u'As the facts became known, there was wide recognition that the two astronomers had independently solved the problem of Uranus, and each was ascribed equal importance.', u'However, there have been subsequent assertions that "The Brits Stole Neptune" and that Adams\'s British contemporaries retrospectively ascribed him more credit than he was due.', u"But it is also notable (and not included in some of the foregoing discussion references) that Adams himself publicly acknowledged Le Verrier's priority and credit (not forgetting to mention the role of Galle) in the paper that he gave 'On the Perturbations of Uranus' to the Royal Astronomical Society in November 1846:-\n\nI mention these dates merely to show that my results were arrived at independently, and previously to the publication of those of M. Le Verrier, and not with the intention of interfering with his just claims to the honours of the discovery ; for there is no doubt that his researches were first published to the world, and led to the actual discovery of the planet by Dr. Galle, so that the facts stated above cannot detract, in the slightest degree, from the credit due to M. Le Verrier.", u'Adams held no bitterness towards Challis or Airy and acknowledged his own failure to convince the astronomical world:\n\nI could not expect however that practical astronomers, who were already fully occupied with important labours, would feel as much confidence in the results of my investigations, as I myself did.', u"== Adams' style of working ==\nHis lay fellowship at St John's College came to an end in 1852, and the existing statutes did not permit his re-election.", u'However, Pembroke College, which possessed greater freedom, elected him in the following year to a lay fellowship which he held for the rest of his life.', u'Despite the fame of his work on Neptune, Adams also did much important work on gravitational astronomy and terrestrial magnetism.', u'He was particularly adept at fine numerical calculations, often making substantial revisions to the contributions of his predecessors.', u'However, he was "extraordinarily uncompetitive, reluctant to publish imperfect work to stimulate debate or claim priority, averse to correspondence about it, and forgetful in practical matters".', u'It has been suggested that these are symptoms of Asperger syndrome which would also be consistent with the "repetitive behaviours and restricted interests" necessary to perform the Neptune calculations, in addition to his difficulties in personal interaction with Challis and Airy.', u"In 1852, he published new and accurate tables of the moon's parallax, which superseded Johann Karl Burckhardt's, and supplied corrections to the theories of Marie-Charles Damoiseau, Giovanni Antonio Amedeo Plana, and Philippe Gustave Doulcet.", u'He had hoped that this work would leverage him into the vacant post as superintendent of HM Nautical Almanac Office but John Russell Hind was preferred, Adams lacking the necessary ability as an organiser and administrator.', u"== Lunar theory \u2014 Secular acceleration of the Moon ==\nSince ancient times, the Moon's mean rate of motion relative to the stars had been treated as a constant rate, but in 1695, Edmond Halley had suggested that this mean rate was gradually increasing.", u'Later, during the eighteenth century, Richard Dunthorne estimated the rate as +10" (arcseconds/century2) in terms of the resulting difference in lunar longitude, an effect that became known as the secular acceleration of the Moon.', u"Pierre-Simon Laplace had given an explanation in 1787 in terms of changes in the eccentricity of the Earth's orbit.", u'He considered only the radial gravitational force on the Moon, from the Sun and Earth but obtained close agreement with the historical record of observations.', u"In 1820, at the insistence of the Acad\xe9mie des sciences, Damoiseau, Plana and Francesco Carlini revisited Laplace's work, investigating quadratic and higher-order perturbing terms, and obtained similar results, again addressing only a radial, and neglecting tangential, gravitational force on the Moon.", u'Hansen obtained similar results in 1842 and 1847.', u'In 1853, Adams published a paper showing that, while tangential terms vanish in the first-order theory of Laplace, they become substantial when quadratic terms are admitted.', u'Small terms integrated in time come to have large effects and Adams concluded that Plana had overestimated the secular acceleration by approximately 1.66" per century.', u"At first, Le Verrier rejected Adams's results.", u"In 1856, Plana admitted Adams's conclusions, claiming to have revised his own analysis and arrived at the same results.", u"However, he soon recanted, publishing a third result different both from Adams's and Plana's own earlier work.", u"Delaunay in 1859 calculated the fourth-order term and duplicated Adams's result leading Adams to publish his own calculations for the fifth, sixth and seventh-order terms.", u'Adams now calculated that only 5.7" of the observed 11" was accounted for by gravitational effects.', u'Later that year, Philippe Gustave Doulcet, Comte de Pont\xe9coulant published a claim that the tangential force could have no effect though Peter Andreas Hansen, who seems to have cast himself in the role of arbitrator, declared that the burden of proof rested on Pont\xe9coulant, while lamenting the need to discover a further effect to account for the balance.', u'Much of the controversy centred around the convergence of the power series expansion used and, in 1860, Adams duplicated his results without using a power series.', u"Sir John Lubbock also duplicated Adams's results and Plana finally concurred.", u"Adams's view was ultimately accepted and further developed, winning him the Gold Medal of the Royal Astronomical Society in 1866.", u'The unexplained drift is now known to be due to tidal acceleration.', u'In 1858 Adams became professor of mathematics at the University of St Andrews, but lectured only for a session, before returning to Cambridge for the Lowndean professorship of astronomy and geometry.', u'Two years later he succeeded Challis as director of the Cambridge Observatory, a post Adams held until his death.', u'== The Leonids ==\n\nThe great meteor shower of November 1866 turned his attention to the Leonids, whose probable path and period had already been discussed and predicted by Hubert Anson Newton in 1864.', u"Newton had asserted that the longitude of the ascending node, that marked where the shower would occur, was increasing and the problem of explaining this variation attracted some of Europe's leading astronomers.", u'Using a powerful and elaborate analysis, Adams ascertained that this cluster of meteors, which belongs to the solar system, traverses an elongated ellipse in 33.25 years, and is subject to definite perturbations from the larger planets, Jupiter, Saturn and Uranus.', u'These results were published in 1867.', u"Some experts consider this Adams's most substantial achievement.", u'His "definitive orbit" for the Leonids coincided with that of the comet 55P/Tempel-Tuttle and therefore suggested the, later widely accepted, close relationship between comets and meteors.', u'== Later career ==\n\nTen years later, George William Hill described a novel and elegant method for attacking the problem of lunar motion.', u"Adams briefly announced his own unpublished work in the same field, which, following a parallel course had confirmed and supplemented Hill's.", u"Over a period of forty years, he periodically addressed the determination of the constants in Carl Friedrich Gauss's theory of terrestrial magnetism.", u'Again, the calculations involved great labour, and were not published during his lifetime.', u'They were edited by his brother, William Grylls Adams, and appear in the second volume of the collected Scientific Papers.', u'Numerical computation of this kind might almost be described as his pastime.', u'He calculated the Euler\u2013Mascheroni constant, perhaps somewhat eccentrically, to 236 decimal places and evaluated the Bernoulli numbers up to the 62nd.', u"Adams had boundless admiration for Newton and his writings and many of his papers bear the cast of Newton's thought.", u"In 1872, Isaac Newton Wallop, 5th Earl of Portsmouth donated his private collection of Newton's papers to Cambridge University.", u'Adams and G. G. Stokes took on the task or arranging the material, publishing a catalogue in 1888.', u'The post of Astronomer Royal was offered him in 1881, but he preferred to pursue his teaching and research in Cambridge.', u'He was British delegate to the International Meridian Conference at Washington in 1884, when he also attended the meetings of the British Association at Montreal and of the American Association at Philadelphia.', u"== Honours ==\n1847 He is reputed to have been offered a knighthood on Queen Victoria's 1847 Cambridge visit but to have declined, either out of modesty, or fear of the financial consequences of such social distinction;\n1847 Foreign Honorary Member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences;\n1848 Copley medal of the Royal Society;\n1848 Adams Prize, founded by the members of St John's College, to be given biennially for the best treatise on a mathematical subject;\n1849 Elected Fellow of the Royal Society of London and Honorary Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh\n1851 and 1874 President of the Royal Astronomical Society (1851\u20131853 and 1874\u20131876).", u'== Family and death ==\nAfter a long illness, Adams died at Cambridge on 21 January 1892 and was buried near his home in St Giles Cemetery, now the Parish of the Ascension Burial Ground in Cambridge.', u'In 1863 he had married Miss Eliza Bruce (1827\u20131919), of Dublin, who survived him, and is buried with him.', u'His wealth at death was \xa332,434 (\xa32.6 million at 2003 prices).', u"== Memorials ==\nMemorial in Westminster Abbey with a portrait medallion, by Albert Bruce-Joy;\nA bust, by Joy in the hall of St John's College, Cambridge;\nAnother youthful bust belongs to the Royal Astronomical Society;\nPortraits by:\nHubert von Herkomer in Pembroke College;\nPaul Raphael Montord in the combination room of St John's;\n\nA memorial tablet, with an inscription by Archbishop Benson, in Truro Cathedral;\nPassmore Edwards erected a public institute in his honour at Launceston, near his birthplace.", u'Adams Nunatak, a nunatak on Neptune Glacier in Alexander Island in Antarctica, is named after him\n\n\n== Bibliography ==\n This article incorporates text from a {'sentences': [u'An aquarium (plural: aquariums or aquaria) is a vivarium of any size having at least one transparent side in which water-dwelling plants or animals are kept and displayed.', u'Fishkeepers use aquaria to keep fish, invertebrates, amphibians, aquatic reptiles such as turtles, and aquatic plants.', u'The term, coined by English naturalist Philip Henry Gosse, combines the Latin root aqua, meaning water, with the suffix -arium, meaning "a place for relating to".', u'The aquarium principle was fully developed in 1850 by the chemist Robert Warington, who explained that plants added to water in a container would give off enough oxygen to support animals, so long as their numbers do not grow too large.', u'The aquarium craze was launched in early Victorian England by Gosse, who created and stocked the first public aquarium at the London Zoo in 1853, and published the first manual, The Aquarium: An Unveiling of the Wonders of the Deep Sea in 1854.', u'An aquarist owns fish or maintains an aquarium, typically constructed of glass or high-strength acrylic.', u'Cuboid aquaria are also known as fish tanks or simply tanks, while bowl-shaped aquaria are also known as fish bowls.', u'Size can range from a small glass bowl to immense public aquaria.', u"Specialized equipment maintains appropriate water quality and other characteristics suitable for the aquarium's residents.", u'== History and popularization ==\n\n\n=== Antiquity ===\nIn the Roman Empire, the first fish to be brought indoors was the sea barbel, which was kept under guest beds in small tanks made of marble.', u'Introduction of glass panes around the year 50 AD allowed Romans to replace one wall of marble tanks, improving their view of the fish.', u'In 1369, the Hongwu Emperor of China established a porcelain company that produced large porcelain tubs for maintaining goldfish; over time, people produced tubs that approached the shape of modern fish bowls.', u'Leonhard Baldner, who wrote Vogel-, Fisch- und Tierbuch (Bird, Fish, and Animal Book) in 1666, maintained weather loaches and newts.', u'=== Nineteenth century ===\n\nIn 1832, Jeanne Villepreux-Power, a pioneering French marine biologist, became the first person to create aquaria for experimenting with aquatic organisms.', u'In 1836, soon after his invention of the Wardian case, Dr. Nathaniel Bagshaw Ward proposed to use his tanks for tropical animals.', u'In 1841 he did so, though only with aquatic plants and toy fish.', u'However, he soon housed real animals.', u'In 1838, F\xe9lix Dujardin noted owning a saltwater aquarium, though he did not use the term.', u'In 1846, Anne Thynne maintained stony corals and seaweed for almost three years, and was credited as the creator of the first balanced marine aquarium in London.', u'English chemist Robert Warington experimented with a 13-gallon container, which contained goldfish, eelgrass, and snails, creating one of the first stable aquaria.', u'The aquarium principle was fully developed by Warington, explaining that plants added to water in a container would give off enough oxygen to support animals, so long as their numbers do not grow too large.', u"He published his findings in 1850 in the Chemical Society's journal.", u'The keeping of fish in an aquarium became a popular hobby and spread quickly.', u'In the United Kingdom, it became popular after ornate aquaria in cast-iron frames were featured at the Great Exhibition of 1851.', u'In 1853, the aquarium craze was launched in England by Philip Henry Gosse who created and stocked the first public aquarium in the London Zoo which came to be known as the Fish House.', u'Gosse coined the word "aquarium", opting for this term (instead of "aquatic vivarium" or "aqua-vivarium") in 1854 in his book The Aquarium: An Unveiling of the Wonders of the Deep Sea.', u'In this book, Gosse primarily discussed saltwater aquaria.', u'In the 1850s, the aquarium became a fad in the United Kingdom.', u'Tank designs and techniques for maintaining water quality were developed by Warington, later cooperating with Gosse until his critical review of the tank water composition.', u'Edward Edwards developed these glass-fronted aquaria in his 1858 patent for a "dark-water-chamber slope-back tank", with water slowly circulating to a reservoir beneath.', u'Germans soon rivaled the British in their interest.', u'In 1854, an anonymous author had two articles published about the saltwater aquaria of the United Kingdom: Die Gartenlaube (The Garden House) entitled Der Ocean auf dem Tische (The Ocean on the Table).', u'However, in 1856, Der See im Glase (The Lake in a Glass) was published, discussing freshwater aquaria, which were much easier to maintain in landlocked areas.', u'In 1862 William Alford Lloyd, then bankrupt because of the craze in England being over, moved to Grindel Dammthor, Hamburg, to supervise the installation of the circulating system and tanks at the Hamburg Aquarium.', u'During the 1870s, some of the first aquarist societies were appearing in Germany.', u'The United States soon followed.', u"Published in 1858, Henry D. Butler's The Family Aquarium was one of the first books written in the United States solely about the aquarium.", u'According to the July issue of The North American Review of the same year, William Stimson may have owned some of the first functional aquaria, and had as many as seven or eight.', u'The first aquarist society in the United States was founded in New York City in 1893, followed by others.', u"The New York Aquarium Journal, first published in October 1876, is considered to be the world's first aquarium magazine.", u'In the Victorian era in the United Kingdom, a common design for the home aquarium was a glass front with the other sides made of wood (made watertight with a pitch coating).', u'The bottom would be made of slate and heated from below.', u'More advanced systems soon began to be introduced, along with tanks of glass in metal frames.', u'During the latter half of the 19th century, a variety of aquarium designs were explored, such as hanging the aquarium on a wall, mounting it as part of a window, or even combining it with a birdcage.', u'=== Twentieth century ===\n\nAround 1908, the first mechanical aquarium air pump was invented, powered by running water, instead of electricity.', u'The introduction of the air pump into the hobby is considered by several historians of the hobby to be a pivotal moment in its development.', u'Aquaria became more widely popular as houses had an electricity supply after World War I.', u'Electricity allowed artificial lighting, as well as aeration, filtration, and heating of the water.', u'Initially, amateur aquarists kept native fish (with the exception of goldfish); the availability of exotic species from overseas further increased the popularity of the aquarium.', u'Jugs made from a variety of materials were used to import fish from overseas, with a bicycle foot pump for aeration.', u'Plastic shipping bags were introduced in the 1950s, making it easier to ship fish.', u'The eventual availability of air freight allowed fish to be successfully imported from distant regions.', u'In the 1960s, metal frames made marine aquaria almost impossible due to corrosion, but the development of tar and silicone sealant allowed the first all-glass aquaria made by Martin Horowitz in Los Angeles, CA.', u'The frames remained, however, though purely for aesthetic reasons.', u'In the United States, as of 1996, aquarium keeping is the second-most popular hobby after stamp collecting.', u'In 1999, an estimated 9.6 million US households owned an aquarium.', u'Figures from the 2005/2006 APPMA National Pet Owners Survey report that Americans own approximately 139 million freshwater fish and 9.6 million saltwater fish.', u'Estimates of the numbers of fish kept in aquaria in Germany suggest at least 36 million.', u'The hobby has the strongest following in Europe, Asia, and North America.', u'In the United States, 40% of aquarists maintain two or more tanks.', u'== Design ==\n\n\n=== Materials ===\nMost aquaria consist of glass panes bonded together by 100% silicone sealant, with plastic frames attached to the upper and lower edges for decoration.', u'The glass aquarium is standard for sizes up to about 1,000 litres (260 US gal; 220 imp gal).', u'However, glass as a material is brittle and has very little give before fracturing, though generally the sealant fails first.', u'Aquaria are made in a variety of shapes, such as cuboid, hexagonal, angled to fit in a corner (L-shaped), and bow-front (the front side curves outwards).', u'Fish bowls are generally either made of plastic or glass, and are either spherical or some other round configuration in shape.', u'The very first modern aquarium made of glass was developed in the 19th century by Robert Warrington.', u'During the Victorian age, glass aquariums commonly had slate or steel bottoms, which allowed them to be heated underneath by an open-flame heat source.', u'These aquariums had the glass panels attached with metal frames and sealed with putty.', u'Metal-framed aquariums were still available until the mid-1960s, when the modern, silicone-sealed style replaced them.', u'Acrylic aquariums first became available to the public in the 1970s.', u'Laminated glass is sometimes used, which combines the advantages of both glass and acrylic.', u'Glass aquaria have been a popular choice for many home and hobbyist aquarists for many years.', u'Once silicone sealant became strong enough to ensure a long-term water-tight seal, it eliminated the need for a structural frame.', u'In addition to lower cost, glass aquaria are more scratch resistant than acrylic.', u'Although the price is one of the main considerations for aquarists when deciding which of these two types of aquaria to purchase, for very large tanks, the price difference tends to disappear.', u'Acrylic aquaria are now the primary competitor with glass.', u'Prior to the invention of UV stabilization, early acrylic aquaria discolored over time with exposure to light; this is no longer the case.', u'Acrylic is generally stronger than glass, weighs less, and provides a certain amount of temperature insulation.', u'In colder climates or environments, it is easier to achieve and maintain a tropical temperature and requires less capacity from an aquarium heater.', u'Acrylic-soluble cements are used to directly fuse acrylic together.', u'Acrylic allows for the formation of unusual shapes, such as the hexagonal tank.', u'Compared to glass, acrylics are easier to scratch; but unlike glass, it is possible to polish out scratches in acrylic.', u'Large aquaria might instead use stronger materials such as fiberglass-reinforced plastics.', u'However, this material is not transparent.', u'Reinforced concrete is used for aquaria where weight and space are not factors.', u'Concrete must be coated with a waterproof layer to prevent the water from breaking down the concrete, as well as preventing contamination of the water by the concrete.', u'=== Styles ===\n\nObjects used for aquariums include: coffee tables, sinks, gumball machines and even toilets.', u'Another such example is the MacQuarium, an aquarium made from the shell of an Apple Macintosh computer.', u'In recent years, elaborate custom-designed home aquariums costing hundreds of thousands of dollars have become status symbols\u2014according to The New York Times, "among people of means, a dazzling aquarium is one of the last surefire ways to impress their peers."', u'==== Kreisel ====\n\nA kreisel tank ("kreisel" being German for "spinning top" or "gyroscope") is an aquarium shaped like a horizontal cylinder that is designed to hold delicate animals such as jellyfish and newborn seahorses.', u'These aquariums provide slow, circular water flow with a bare minimum of interior hardware to prevent the inhabitants from becoming injured by pumps or the tank itself.', u'The tank has no sharp angles around its sides and keeps the housed animals away from plumbing.', u'Water moving into the tank gives a gentle flow that keeps the inhabitants suspended.', u'Water leaves the tank through a screen which prevents animals from being drawn into the pump intake or overflow line.', u'There are several types of kreisel tanks.', u'In a true kreisel, a circular tank has a circular, submerged lid.', u'Pseudokreisels are "U" or semicircle shaped, usually without a lid.', u'Stretch kreisels are a "double gyre" kreisel design, where the tank length is at least twice the height.', u'Using two downwelling inlets on both sides of the tank lets gravity create two gyres in the tank.', u'A single downwelling inlet may be used in the middle as well.', u'The top of a stretch kreisel may be open or closed with a lid.', u'There may also be screens about midway down the sides of the tank, or at the top on the sides.', u'It is possible to combine these designs; a circular shaped tank is used without a lid or cover, and the surface of the water acts as the continuation of circular flow.', u'It is now possible to start a jellyfish aquarium at home as easily as a regular fish tank.', u'==== Biotope ====\nAnother popular setup is the biotope aquarium.', u'A biotope aquarium is a recreation of a specific natural environment.', u'Some of the most popular biotopes are the freshwater habitats of the Amazon and Rio Negro rivers, the African rift lake environments of Lake Malawi and Lake Tanganyika, and saltwater coral reefs of Australia, the Red Sea, and the Caribbean.', u'The fish, plants, substrate, rocks, wood, coral, and any other component of the display should completely match that of the local natural environment.', u'It can be a challenge to recreate such environments, and most "true" biotopes will only have a few (if not only one) species of fish and invertebrates.', u'Finally, an emerging concept for the home is that of a wall mounted aquarium, some of which are displayed at the Living Art Marine Center.', u'=== Aquarium size and volume ===\n\nAn aquarium can range from a small glass bowl containing less than 1 litre (2.1 US pt) of water to immense public aquaria that house entire ecosystems such as kelp forests.', u'Relatively large home aquaria resist rapid fluctuations of temperature and pH, allowing for greater system stability.', u'Beginner aquarists are advised to consider larger tanks to begin with, as controlling water parameters in smaller tanks can prove difficult.', u'Unfiltered bowl-shaped aquaria are now widely regarded as unsuitable for most fish.', u'Advanced alternatives are now available.', u'In order to keep water conditions at suitable levels, aquariums should contain at least two forms of filtration: biological and mechanical.', u'Chemical filtration should also be considered under some circumstances for optimum water quality.', u'Chemical filtration is frequently achieved via activated carbon, to filter medications, tannins, and/or other known impurities from the water.', u'Reef aquaria under 100 litres (26 US gal; 22 imp gal) have a special place in the aquarium hobby; these aquaria, termed nano reefs (when used in reefkeeping), have a small water volume, under 40 litres (11 US gal; 9 imp gal).', u'Practical limitations, most notably the weight of water (1 kilogram per litre (8.345 lb/U.S.', u'gal; 10.022 lb/imp gal)) and internal water pressure (requiring thick glass siding) of a large aquarium, restrict most home aquaria to a maximum of around 1 cubic metre in volume (1000 L, weighing 1,000 kg or 2,200 lb).', u'Some aquarists, however, have constructed aquaria of many thousands of litres.', u'Public aquariums designed for exhibition of large species or environments can be dramatically larger than any home aquarium.', u'The Georgia Aquarium, for example, features an individual aquarium of 6,300,000 US gallons (24,000 m3).', u'==== Nano aquariums ====\nA new trend is to have very small aquariums, termed mini aquariums (less than 150 litres or 40 gallons) or nano aquariums (less than 75 litres or 20 gallons).', u'These can be either freshwater or saltwater, and are intended to display a tiny but self-contained ecosystem.', u"== Components ==\n\nThe typical hobbyist aquarium includes a filtration system, an artificial lighting system, and a heater or chiller depending on the aquarium's inhabitants.", u'Many aquaria incorporate a hood, containing the lights, to decrease evaporation and prevent fish from leaving the aquarium (and anything else from entering the aquarium).', u'Combined biological and mechanical aquarium filtration systems are common.', u'These either convert ammonia to nitrate (removing nitrogen at the expense of aquatic plants), or to sometimes remove phosphate.', u'Filter media can house microbes that mediate nitrification.', u'Filtration systems are sometimes the most complex component of home aquaria.', u'Aquarium heaters combine a heating element with a thermostat, allowing the aquarist to regulate water temperature at a level above that of the surrounding air, whereas coolers and chillers (refrigeration devices) are for use anywhere, such as cold water aquaria, where the ambient room temperature is above the desired tank temperature.', u'Thermometers used include glass alcohol thermometers, adhesive external plastic strip thermometers, and battery-powered LCD thermometers.', u'In addition, some aquarists use air pumps attached to airstones or water pumps to increase water circulation and supply adequate gas exchange at the water surface.', u'Wave-making devices have also been constructed to provide wave action.', u"An aquarium's physical characteristics form another aspect of aquarium design.", u"Size, lighting conditions, density of floating and rooted plants, placement of bog-wood, creation of caves or overhangs, type of substrate, and other factors (including an aquarium's positioning within a room) can all affect the behavior and survival of tank inhabitants.", u'An aquarium can be placed on an aquarium stand.', u'Because of the weight of the aquarium, a stand must be strong as well as level.', u'A tank that is not level may distort, leak, or crack.', u'These are often built with cabinets to allow storage, available in many styles to match room decor.', u'Simple metal tank stands are also available.', u'Most aquaria should be placed on polystyrene to cushion any irregularities on the underlying surface or the bottom of the tank itself that may cause cracks.', u'However, some tanks have an underframe making this unnecessary.', u'== Aquarium maintenance ==\n\nLarge volumes of water enable more stability in a tank by diluting effects from death or contamination events that push an aquarium away from equilibrium.', u'The bigger the tank, the easier such a systemic shock is to absorb, because the effects of that event are diluted.', u'For example, the death of the only fish in a 11-litre (3 US gal; 2 imp gal) tank causes dramatic changes in the system, while the death of that same fish in a 400-litre (110 US gal; 88 imp gal) tank with many other fish in it represents only a minor change.', u'For this reason, hobbyists often favor larger tanks, as they require less attention.', u'Several nutrient cycles are important in the aquarium.', u'Dissolved oxygen enters the system at the surface water-air interface.', u'Similarly, carbon dioxide escapes the system into the air.', u'The phosphate cycle is an important, although often overlooked, nutrient cycle.', u'Sulfur, iron, and micronutrients also cycle through the system, entering as food and exiting as waste.', u'Appropriate handling of the nitrogen cycle, along with supplying an adequately balanced food supply and considered biological loading, is enough to keep these other nutrient cycles in approximate equilibrium.', u'An aquarium must be maintained regularly to ensure that the fish are kept healthy.', u'Daily maintenance consists of checking the fish for signs of stress and disease.', u'Also, aquarists must make sure that the water has a good quality and it is not cloudy or foamy and the temperature of the water is appropriate for the particular species of fish that live in the aquarium.', u'Typical weekly maintenance includes changing around 10-20% of the water while cleaning the gravel, or other substrate if the aquarium has one.', u'A good habit is to remove the water being replaced by "vacuuming" the gravel with suitable implements, as this will eliminate uneaten foods and other residues that settle on the substrate.', u'In many areas tap water is not considered to be safe for fish to live in because it contains chemicals that harm the fish.', u'Tap water from those areas must be treated with a suitable water conditioner, such as a product which removes chlorine and chloramine and neutralises any heavy metals present.', u'The water conditions must be checked both in the tank and in the replacement water, to make sure they are suitable for the species of fish kept.', u'=== Water conditions ===\nThe solute content of water is perhaps the most important aspect of water conditions, as total dissolved solids and other constituents dramatically impact basic water chemistry, and therefore how organisms interact with their environment.', u'Salt content, or salinity, is the most basic measure of water conditions.', u'An aquarium may have freshwater (salinity below 500 parts per million), simulating a lake or river environment; brackish water (a salt level of 500 to 30,000 PPM), simulating environments lying between fresh and salt, such as estuaries; and salt water or seawater (a salt level of 30,000 to 40,000 PPM), simulating an ocean environment.', u'Rarely, higher salt concentrations are maintained in specialized tanks for raising brine organisms.', u'Saltwater is typically alkaline, while the pH (alkalinity or acidicity) of fresh water varies more.', u'Hardness measures overall dissolved mineral content; hard or soft water may be preferred.', u'Hard water is usually alkaline, while soft water is usually neutral to acidic.', u'Dissolved organic content and dissolved gases content are also important factors.', u'Home aquarists typically use tap water supplied through their local water supply network to fill their tanks.', u'Straight tap water cannot be used in localities that pipe chlorinated water.', u'In the past, it was possible to "condition" the water by simply letting the water stand for a day or two, which allows the chlorine time to dissipate.', u'However, chloramine is now used more often and does not leave the water as readily.', u'Additives formulated to remove chlorine or chloramine are often all that is needed to make the water ready for aquarium use.', u'Brackish or saltwater aquaria require the addition of a commercially available mixture of salts and other minerals.', u"Some aquarists modify water's alkalinity, hardness, or dissolved content of organics and gases, before adding it to their aquaria.", u'This can be accomplished by additives, such as sodium bicarbonate, to raise pH.', u'Some aquarists filter or purify their water through deionization or reverse osmosis prior to using it.', u'In contrast, public aquaria with large water needs often locate themselves near a natural water source (such as a river, lake, or ocean) to reduce the level of treatment.', u'Some hobbyists use an algae scrubber to filter the water naturally.', u'Water temperature determines the two most basic aquarium classifications: tropical versus cold water.', u'Most fish and plant species tolerate only a limited temperature range; tropical aquaria, with an average temperature of about 25 \xb0C (77 \xb0F), are much more common.', u'Cold water aquaria are for fish that are better suited to a cooler environment.', u'More important than the range is consistency; most organisms are not accustomed to sudden changes in temperatures, which can cause shock and lead to disease.', u'Water temperature can be regulated with a thermostat and heater (or cooler).', u'Water movement can also be important in simulating a natural ecosystem.', u"Aquarists may prefer anything from still water up to swift currents, depending on the aquarium's inhabitants.", u'Water movement can be controlled via aeration from air pumps, powerheads, and careful design of internal water flow (such as location of filtration system points of inflow and outflow).', u"=== Nitrogen cycle ===\n\nOf primary concern to the aquarist is management of the waste produced by an aquarium's inhabitants.", u'Fish, invertebrates, fungi, and some bacteria excrete nitrogen waste in the form of ammonia (which converts to ammonium, in acidic water) and must then either pass through the nitrogen cycle or be removed by passing through zeolite.', u'Ammonia is also produced through the decomposition of plant and animal matter, including fecal matter and other detritus.', u'Nitrogen waste products become toxic to fish and other aquarium inhabitants at high concentrations.', u'In the wild, the vast amount of water surrounding the fish dilutes ammonia and other waste materials.', u'When fish are put into an aquarium, waste can quickly reach toxic concentrations in the enclosed environment unless the tank is cycled to remove waste.', u'==== The process ====\nA well-balanced tank contains organisms that are able to metabolize the waste products of other aquarium residents.', u'This process is known in the aquarium hobby as the nitrogen cycle.', u'Bacteria known as nitrifiers (genus Nitrosomonas) metabolize nitrogen waste.', u'Nitrifying bacteria capture ammonia from the water and metabolize it to produce nitrite.', u'Nitrite is toxic to fish in high concentrations.', u'Another type of bacteria (genus Nitrospira) converts nitrite into nitrate, a less toxic substance.', u'(Nitrobacter bacteria were previously believed to fill this role.', u'While biologically they could theoretically fill the same niche as Nitrospira, it has recently been found that Nitrobacter are not present in detectable levels in established aquaria, while Nitrospira are plentiful.)', u'However, commercial products sold as kits to "jump start" the nitrogen cycle often still contain Nitrobacter.', u'In addition to bacteria, aquatic plants also eliminate nitrogen waste by metabolizing ammonia and nitrate.', u'When plants metabolize nitrogen compounds, they remove nitrogen from the water by using it to build biomass that decays more slowly than ammonia-driven plankton already dissolved in the water.', u'==== Maintaining the nitrogen cycle ====\n\nWhat hobbyists call the nitrogen cycle is only a portion of the complete cycle: nitrogen must be added to the system (usually through food provided to the tank inhabitants), and nitrates accumulate in the water at the end of the process, or become bound in the biomass of plants.', u'The aquarium keeper must remove water once nitrate concentrations grow, or remove plants which have grown from the nitrates.', u'Hobbyist aquaria often do not have sufficient bacteria populations to adequately denitrify waste.', u'This problem is most often addressed through two filtration solutions: Activated carbon filters absorb nitrogen compounds and other toxins, while biological filters provide a medium designed to enhance bacterial colonization.', u'Activated carbon and other substances, such as ammonia absorbing resins, stop working when their pores fill, so these components have to be replaced regularly.', u'New aquaria often have problems associated with the nitrogen cycle due to insufficient beneficial bacteria.', u'Therefore, fresh water has to be matured before stocking them with fish.', u'There are three basic approaches to this: the "fishless cycle", the "silent cycle" and "slow growth".', u'In a fishless cycle, small amounts of ammonia are added to an unpopulated tank to feed the bacteria.', u'During this process, ammonia, nitrite, and nitrate levels are tested to monitor progress.', u'The "silent" cycle is basically nothing more than densely stocking the aquarium with fast-growing aquatic plants and relying on them to consume the nitrogen, allowing the necessary bacterial populations time to develop.', u'According to anecdotal reports, the plants can consume nitrogenous waste so efficiently that ammonia and nitrite level spikes seen in more traditional cycling methods are greatly reduced or disappear.', u'"Slow growth" entails slowly increasing the population of fish over a period of 6 to 8 weeks, giving bacteria colonies time to grow and stabilize with the increase in fish waste.', u'This method is usually done with a small starter population of hardier fish which can survive the ammonia and nitrite spikes, whether they are intended to be permanent residents or to be traded out later for the desired occupants.', u'The largest bacterial populations are found in the filter, where is high water flow and plentiful surface available for their growth, so effective and efficient filtration is vital.', u'Sometimes, a vigorous cleaning of the filter is enough to seriously disturb the biological balance of an aquarium.', u'Therefore, it is recommended to rinse mechanical filters in an outside bucket of aquarium water to dislodge organic materials that contribute to nitrate problems, while preserving bacteria populations.', u'Another safe practice consists of cleaning only half of the filter media during each service, or using two filters, only one of which is cleaned at a time.', u'=== Biological load ===\n\nThe biological load, or bioload, is a measure of the burden placed on the aquarium ecosystem by its inhabitants.', u'High biological loading presents a more complicated tank ecology, which in turn means that equilibrium is easier to upset.', u'Several fundamental constraints on biological loading depend on aquarium size.', u"The water's surface area limits oxygen intake.", u'The bacteria population depends on the physical space they have available to colonize.', u'Physically, only a limited size and number of plants and animals can fit into an aquarium while still providing room for movement.', u'Biologically, biological loading refers to the rate of biological decay in proportion to tank volume.', u'Adding plants to an aquarium will sometimes help greatly with taking up fish waste as plant nutrients.', u'Although an aquarium can be overloaded with fish, an excess of plants is unlikely to cause harm.', u'Decaying plant material, such as decaying plant leaves, can add these nutrients back into the aquarium if not promptly removed.', u"The bioload is processed by the aquarium's biofilter filtration system.", u'==== Calculating capacity ====\nLimiting factors include the oxygen availability and filtration processing.', u'Aquarists have rules of thumb to estimate the number of fish that can be kept in an aquarium.', u'The examples below are for small freshwater fish; larger freshwater fishes and most marine fishes need much more generous allowances.', u'3 cm of adult fish length per 4 litres of water (i.e., a 6 cm-long fish would need about 8 litres of water).', u'1 cm of adult fish length per 30 square centimetres of surface area.', u'1 inch of adult fish length per US gallon of water.', u'1 inch of adult fish length per 12 square inches of surface area.', u'Experienced aquarists warn against applying these rules too strictly because they do not consider other important issues such as growth rate, activity level, social behaviour, filtration capacity, total biomass of plant life, and so on.', u'It is better to apply the overall mass and size of a fish per gallon of water, than simply the length.', u'This is because fish of different sizes produce quite differing amounts of waste.', u'Establishing maximum capacity is often a matter of slowly adding fish and monitoring water quality over time, following a trial and error approach.', u'==== Other factors affecting capacity ====\nOne variable is differences between fish.', u'Smaller fish consume more oxygen per gram of body weight than larger fish.', u'Labyrinth fish can breathe atmospheric oxygen and do not need as much surface area (however, some of these fish are territorial, and do not appreciate crowding).', u'Barbs also require more surface area than tetras of comparable size.', u'Oxygen exchange at the surface is an important constraint, and thus the surface area of the aquarium matters.', u'Some aquarists claim that a deeper aquarium holds no more fish than a shallower aquarium with the same surface area.', u'The capacity can be improved by surface movement and water circulation such as through aeration, which not only improves oxygen exchange, but also waste decomposition rates.', u'Waste density is another variable.', u'Decomposition in solution consumes oxygen.', u'Oxygen dissolves less readily in warmer water; this is a double-edged sword since warmer temperatures make fish more active, so they consume more oxygen.', u'In addition to bioload/chemical considerations, aquarists also consider the mutual compatibility of the fish.', u'For instance, predatory fish are usually not kept with small, passive species, and territorial fish are often unsuitable tankmates for shoaling species.', u'Furthermore, fish tend to fare better if given tanks conducive to their size.', u'That is, large fish need large tanks and small fish can do well in smaller tanks.', u'Lastly, the tank can become overcrowded without being overstocked.', u'In other words, the aquarium can be suitable with regard to filtration capacity, oxygen load, and water, yet still be so crowded that the inhabitants are uncomfortable.', u'For planted freshwater aquariums, it is also important to maintain a balance between the duration and quality of light, the amount of plants, CO2 and nutrients.', u'For a given amount of light, if there is insufficient number of plants or insufficient CO2 to support the growth of those plants, so as to consume all the nutrients in the tank, the result would be algae growth.', u'While there are fishes and invertebrates that could be introduced in the tank to clean up this algae, the ideal solution would be to find the optimal balance between the above-mentioned factors.', u'Supplemental CO2 can be provided, whose quantity has to be carefully regulated, as too much CO2 may harm the fishes,\n\n\n== Aquarium classifications ==\n\nFrom the outdoor ponds and glass jars of antiquity, modern aquaria have evolved into a wide range of specialized systems.', u'Individual aquaria can vary in size from a small bowl large enough for only a single small fish, to the huge public aquaria that can simulate entire marine ecosystems.', u'One way to classify aquaria is by salinity.', u'Freshwater aquaria are the most popular due to their lower cost.', u'More expensive and complex equipment is required to set up and maintain marine aquaria.', u'Marine aquaria frequently feature a diverse range of invertebrates in addition to species of fish.', u'Brackish water aquaria combine elements of both marine and freshwater fishkeeping.', u'Fish kept in brackish water aquaria generally come from habitats with varying salinity, such as mangrove swamps and estuaries.', u'Subtypes exist within these types, such as the reef aquarium, a typically smaller marine aquarium that houses coral.', u'Another classification is by temperature range.', u'Many aquarists choose a tropical aquarium because tropical fish tend to be more colorful.', u'However, the coldwater aquarium is also popular, which is mainly restricted to goldfish, but can include fish from temperate areas worldwide and native fish keeping.', u'Aquaria may be grouped by their species selection.', u'The community tank is the most common today, where several non-aggressive species live peacefully.', u'In these aquaria, the fish, invertebrates, and plants probably do not originate from the same geographic region, but tolerate similar water conditions.', u'Aggressive tanks, in contrast, house a limited number of species that can be aggressive toward other fish, or are able to withstand aggression well.', u'Most marine tanks and tanks housing cichlids have to take the aggressiveness of the desired species into account when stocking.', u"Specimen tanks usually only house one fish species, along with plants, perhaps ones found in the fishes' natural environment and decorations simulating a natural ecosystem.", u'This type is useful for fish that cannot coexist with other fish, such as the electric eel, as an extreme example.', u'Some tanks of this sort are used simply to house adults for breeding.', u'Ecotype, ecotope, or biotope aquaria is another type based on species selection.', u'In it, an aquarist attempts to simulate a specific natural ecosystem, assembling fish, invertebrate species, plants, decorations and water conditions all found in that ecosystem.', u'These biotope aquaria are the most sophisticated hobby aquaria; public aquaria use this approach whenever possible.', u'This approach best simulates the experience of observing in the wild.', u"It typically serves as the healthiest possible artificial environment for the tank's occupants.", u'== Public aquaria ==\n\nMost public aquarium facilities feature a number of smaller aquaria, as well those too large for home aquarists.', u'The largest tanks hold millions of gallons of water and can house large species, including sharks or beluga whales.', u'Dolphinaria are specifically for dolphins.', u'Aquatic and semiaquatic animals, including otters and penguins, may also be kept by public aquaria.', u'Public aquaria may also be included in larger establishments such as a marine mammal park or a marine park.', u'== Virtual aquariums ==\nA virtual aquarium is a computer program which uses 3D graphics to reproduce an aquarium on a personal computer.', u'The swimming fish are rendered in real time, while the background of the tank is usually static.', u'Objects on the floor of the tank may be mapped in simple planes so that the fish may appear to swim both in front and behind them, but a relatively simple 3D map of the general shape of such objects may be used to allow the light and ripples on the surface of the water to cast realistic shadows.', u'Bubbles and water noises are common for virtual aquariums, which are often used as screensavers.', u'The number of each type of fish can usually be selected, often including other animals like starfish, jellyfish, seahorses, and even sea turtles.', u'Most companies that produce virtual aquarium software also offer other types of fish for sale via Internet download.', u'Other objects found in an aquarium can also be added and rearranged on some software, like treasure chests and giant clams that open and close with air bubbles, or a bobbing diver.', u'There are also usually features that allow the user to tap on the glass or put food in the top, both of which the fish will react to.', u'Some also have the ability to allow the user to edit fish and other objects to create new varieties.', u'== See also ==\n\nAquascaping\nAssociation of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA)\nFilter (aquarium)\nFishkeeping\nList of aquarium diseases\nList of aquarium fish by scientific name\nList of brackish aquarium fish {'sentences': [u'Kiwanis International (/k\u026a\u02c8w\u0251\u02d0n\u026as/ ki-WAH-niss) is an international, coeducational service club founded in 1915 in Detroit, Michigan.', u'It is headquartered in Indianapolis, Indiana, United States and is found in more than 80 nations and geographic areas.', u'Membership in Kiwanis and its family of clubs is more than 600,000 members strong.', u'Each year, Kiwanis clubs raise more than US$100 million and report more than 18.5 million volunteer hours to strengthen communities and serve children.', u'Kiwanis International is a volunteer-led organization headed by a Board of Trustees consisting of 19 members: 15 trustees, four elected officers, and an executive director.', u'The trustees serve three-year terms, with five trustees elected each year.', u'As set out in the Bylaws, nine trustees are elected from the United States and Pacific Canada Region, one trustee is elected from the Canada & Caribbean Region, two trustees are elected from the European Region, two trustees are elected from the Asia-Pacific Region, and one trustee is elected "at large" from any region other than the United States and Pacific Canada.', u'The elected officers included (in order of progression): vice president, president-elect, president and immediate past president.', u'These officers, along with the United States and Pacific Canada Region trustees, are elected at the annual convention of Kiwanis International.', u'All trustees and officers are unpaid volunteers.', u"The executive director is a full-time employee who is responsible for the organization's paid staff and serves as a non-voting member of the Board.", u'There are seven regions in Kiwanis: Africa; Asia-Pacific; Canada and Caribbean; Europe; Latin America; Middle East; and United States and Pacific Canada.', u'The United States and Pacific Canada Region incorporates the 50 states of the United States as well as British Columbia and the Yukon Territory of Canada.', u'There are fifty-three administrative areas called districts.', u'District boards typically consist of a governor-elect, governor, and immediate-past governor, secretary, treasurer, and several trustees or lt. governors.', u'Districts are further divided into service areas called divisions, comprising 5 to 20 clubs and headed by a lieutenant governor.', u'Clubs have boards consisting of a vice president (and/or president elect), president, immediate past president, secretary, treasurer, and typically about five directors.', u'At both the district and club level, secretary/treasurer may be combined by one person and may be a volunteer or a paid employee; all other positions are unpaid.', u'== Etymology ==\nThe name \u201cKiwanis\u201d was coined from the Ojibwe language expression derived from the word giiwanizi meaning to "fool around": ningiiwaniz, which is found in the Baraga Dictionary as "nin Kiwanis", meaning "I make noise; I am foolish and wanton" or "I play with noise".', u'However, Random House Dictionary claims that it comes from one of the Algonquian languages to mean "to make oneself known" but in Ojibwe and other related Algonquian languages, this expression would be gikendami\'idizo.', u'The organization\'s founders translated it as "We build," which became the original motto of Kiwanis.', u'In 2005 the organization chose a new motto, "Serving the Children of the World".', u'Members of the club are called Kiwanians.', u'== Ideals ==\n\n\n=== Defining statement ===\n"Kiwanis is a global organization of volunteers dedicated to improving the world, one child and one community at a time."', u'=== Motto ===\nKiwanis\' motto is "Serving the Children of the World."', u'The original motto was "We Trade".', u'A new motto of "We Build" was adopted during the 1920 International Convention and represented Kiwanis for more than 80 years.', u'=== Objects ===\nThe six permanent Objects of Kiwanis International were approved by Kiwanis club delegates at the 1924 Convention in Denver, Colorado.', u'To give primacy to the human and spiritual rather than to the material values of life.', u'To encourage the daily living of the Golden Rule in all human relationships.', u'To promote the adoption and the application of higher social, business, and professional standards.', u'To develop, by precept and example, a more intelligent, aggressive, and serviceable citizenship.', u'To provide, through Kiwanis clubs, a practical means to form enduring friendships, to render altruistic service, and to build better communities.', u'To cooperate in creating and maintaining that sound public opinion and high idealism which make possible the increase of righteousness, justice, patriotism, and goodwill.', u'== History ==\nThe organization originated in August 1914 in Detroit, Michigan from a conversation between Allen S. Browne and Joseph G. Prance.', u"Browne's idea was to solicit business and professional men asking them if they would be interested in organizing a fraternal organization with a health benefit feature.", u'Browne was compensated five dollars per new member that joined for his operating budget.', u'Browne and Prance set out and recruited enough members to apply to the state for a not for profit status.', u'The state approved the application on January 21, 1915 and the Supreme Lodge Benevolent Order Brothers was formed.', u'The name was changed to Kiwanis a year later.', u'The Kiwanis Club of Detroit is the original local club in Kiwanis.', u'By 1927 the organization had more than 100,000 members.', u'Kiwanis became international with the organization of the Kiwanis club of Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, in 1916.', u'Kiwanis limited its membership to the United States and Canada until 1962, when worldwide expansion was approved.', u'Since then, Kiwanis has spread to all inhabited continents of the globe.', u'The original purpose of Kiwanis was to exchange business between members and to serve the poor.', u'The debate as to whether to focus on networking or service was resolved in 1919, when Kiwanis adopted a service-focused mission.', u'In 1924, the Objects of Kiwanis were adopted (see above) and remain unchanged today.', u'Each year, clubs sponsor nearly 150,000 service projects, complete more than 18.5 million hours in volunteer service and raise more than $100 million.', u'As a global project in coordination with UNICEF, members and clubs contributed more than $80 million toward the global elimination of iodine deficiency disorders (IDD), the leading preventable cause of mental retardation.', u'Beginning in 2010 Kiwanis International joined with UNICEF to launch a new worldwide health initiative, The Eliminate Project, dedicated to wiping out maternal and neonatal tetanus (MNT), which kills more than 100,000 babies worldwide each year.', u'Until 1987 the organization accepted only men as members.', u'By action of the International Convention in 1987, the rules were changed to admit women as well.', u'Women constitute about 26% of total members.', u"At the 2013 International Convention, Sue Petrisin was elected as the organization's first female international vice president.", u"Petrisin was installed as Kiwanis International President in 2015, the year of the organization's 100th anniversary.", u'She is the first female to lead any major member service organization.', u"== Service ==\nKiwanis clubs decide for themselves what projects to do in their community, based on their own community's needs and their members' interests.", u'Service to children is a primary focus in Kiwanis.', u'Clubs are encouraged to conduct a community survey each year to determine what unmet needs exist in their community.', u'In some cases, clubs in a geographic region (a "Division" or "District") may take on a project of shared interest, such as paediatric trauma, or children\'s cancer.', u'Service may be provided directly (e.g.', u"reading to children at the library or taking therapy dogs into seniors' facilities) or through raising funds in the community to meet a community need (such as building a playground).", u'Common fund-raising events include breakfast such as pancakes, peanut sales, or food concessions.', u'Areas of service may include assistance to those living in poverty, projects that benefit children and youth, and services for the sick or elderly.', u'As a global project in coordination with UNICEF, members and clubs ==\nKiwanis provides leadership and service opportunities for youth through its Service Leadership Programs.', u'Key Club, Circle K, Builders Clubs and K-Kids are part of Kiwanis Service Leadership Programs.', u'They are sponsored by a local Kiwanis club and receive funding and professional guidance from Kiwanis.', u'=== Key Club ===\nKiwanis founded and supports Key Club International.', {'sentences': [u'Joseph Paul "Joe" DiMaggio (November 25, 1914 \u2013 March 8, 1999), nicknamed "Joltin\' Joe" and "The Yankee Clipper", was an American Major League Baseball center fielder who played his entire 13-year career for the New York Yankees.', u'He is perhaps best known for his 56-game hitting streak (May 15 \u2013 July 16, 1941), a record that still stands.', u'DiMaggio was a three-time MVP winner and an All-Star in each of his 13 seasons.', u'During his tenure with the Yankees, the club won ten American League pennants and nine World Series championships.', u'At the time of his retirement, he ranked fifth in career home runs (361) and sixth in career slugging percentage (.579).', u"He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1955, and was voted the sport's greatest living player in a poll taken during the baseball centennial year of 1969.", u'His brothers Vince (1912\u20131986) and Dom (1917\u20132009) also were major league center fielders.', u'== Early life ==\nDiMaggio was born on November 25, 1914 in Martinez, California, the eighth of nine children born to Sicilian immigrants Giuseppe (1872\u20131949) and Rosalia (Mercurio) (1878\u20131951) DiMaggio .', u'He was delivered by a midwife identified on his birth certificate as Mrs. J. Pico.', u"He was named Paolo after his father Giuseppe's favorite saint, Saint Paul.", u'The family moved to nearby San Francisco when Joe was a year old.', u'Giuseppe was a fisherman, as were generations of DiMaggios before him.', u"According to statements from Joe's brother, Tom, to biographer Maury Allen, Rosalia's father wrote to her with the advice that Giuseppe could earn a better living in California than in their native Isola delle Femmine, a northwestern Sicilian village in the province of Palermo.", u"After being processed on Ellis Island, Giuseppe worked his way across America, eventually settling near Rosalia's father in Pittsburg, California, on the east side of the San Francisco Bay Area.", u'After four years, he earned enough money to send to Italy for Rosalia and their daughter, who was born after he had left for the United States.', u'Giuseppe hoped that his five sons would become fishermen.', u"DiMaggio recalled that he would do anything to get out of cleaning his father's boat, as the smell of dead fish nauseated him.", u'Giuseppe called him "lazy" and "good-for-nothing."', u'DiMaggio was playing semi-pro ball when older brother Vince DiMaggio, playing for the San Francisco Seals of the Pacific Coast League (PCL), talked his manager into letting DiMaggio fill in at shortstop.', u'Joe DiMaggio made his professional debut on October 1, 1932.', u'From May 27 to July 25, 1933, he hit safely in 61 consecutive games, a PCL-record, and second-longest in all of Minor League Baseball history.', u'"Baseball didn\'t really get into my blood until I knocked off that hitting streak," he said.', u'"Getting a daily hit became more important to me than eating, drinking or sleeping."', u'In 1934, DiMaggio suffered a career-threatening knee injury when he tore ligaments while stepping out of a jitney.', u'Scout Bill Essick of the New York Yankees, convinced that the injury would heal, pestered his club to give him another look.', u'After DiMaggio passed a physical examination in November, the Yankees purchased his contract for $50,000 and five players.', u'He remained with the Seals for the 1935 season and batted .398 with 154 runs batted in 1936, batting ahead of Lou Gehrig.', u'The Yankees had not been to the World Series since 1932, but they won the next four Fall Classics.', u'In total, DiMaggio led the Yankees to nine titles in 13 years.', u'In 1939, DiMaggio was nicknamed the "Yankee Clipper" by Yankee\'s stadium announcer Arch McDonald, when he likened DiMaggio\'s speed and range in the outfield to the then-new Pan American airliner.', u'DiMaggio was pictured with his son on the cover of the inaugural issue of SPORT magazine in September 1946.', u'In 1947, Boston Red Sox owner Tom Yawkey and Yankees GM Larry MacPhail verbally agreed to trade DiMaggio for Ted Williams, but MacPhail refused to include Yogi Berra.', u'In the September 1949 issue of SPORT, Hank Greenberg said that DiMaggio covered so much ground in center field that the only way to get a hit against the Yankees was "to hit \'em where Joe wasn\'t."', u'DiMaggio also stole home five times in his career.', u'On February 7, 1949, DiMaggio signed a record contract worth $100,000 ($996,000 in current dollar terms) ($70,000 plus bonuses), and became the first baseball player to break $100,000 in earnings.', u'By 1950, he was ranked the second-best center fielder by the Sporting News, after Larry Doby.', u'After a poor 1951 season, a scouting report by the Brooklyn Dodgers that was turned over to the New York Giants and leaked to the press, and various injuries, DiMaggio announced his retirement at age 37 on December 11, 1951.', u'When remarking on his retirement to the Sporting News on December 19, 1951, he said:\n\nI feel like I have reached the stage where I can no longer produce for my club, my manager, and my teammates.', u'I had a poor year, but even if I had hit .350, this would have been my last year.', u'I was full of aches and pains and it had become a chore for me to play.', u"When baseball is no longer fun, it's no longer a game, and so, I've played my last game.", u"Through May 2009, DiMaggio was tied with Mark McGwire for third place all-time in home runs over the first two calendar years in the major leagues (77), behind Phillies Hall of Famer Chuck Klein (83), and Milwaukee Brewers' Ryan Braun (79).", u'Through 2011, he was one of seven major leaguers to have had at least four 30-homer, 100-RBI seasons in their first five years, along with Chuck Klein, Ted Williams, Ralph Kiner, Mark Teixeira, Albert Pujols, and Ryan Braun.', u'DiMaggio holds the record for most seasons with more home runs than strikeouts (minimum 20 home runs), a feat he accomplished seven times, and five times consecutively from 1937\u20131941.', u'DiMaggio would likely have exceeded 500 home runs and 2,000 RBIs had he not served in the military.', u'DiMaggio might have had better power-hitting statistics fields made home runs almost impossible.', u'Mickey Mantle recalled that he and Whitey Ford witnessed many DiMaggio blasts that would have been home runs anywhere other than Yankee Stadium (Ruth himself fell victim to that problem, as he also hit many long flyouts to center).', u'Bill James calculated that DiMaggio lost more home runs due to his home park than any other player in history.', u"Left-center field went as far back as 457 ft [139 m], where left-center rarely reaches 380 ft [116 m] in today's ballparks.", u"Al Gionfriddo's famous catch in the 1947 World Series, which was close on the road.', u'His slugging percentage at home was .546, and on the road, it was .610.', u'Expert statistician Bill Jenkinson made a statement on these statistics:\n\nFor example, Joe DiMaggio was acutely handicapped by playing at Yankee Stadium.', u'Every time he batted in his home field during his entire career, he did so knowing that it was physically impossible for him to hit a home run to the half of the field directly in front of him.', u'If you look at a baseball field from foul line to foul line, it has a 90-degree radius.', u"From the power alley in left center field (430 in Joe's as a player, Joe became the first hitting instructor of the newly relocated Oakland Athletics from 1968 to 1970.', u"=== Hitting streak ===\n\nDiMaggio's most famous achievement is his MLB record-breaking 56-game hitting streak in 1941.", u'The streak began on May 15, 1941, a couple of weeks before the death of Lou Gehrig, when DiMaggio went one-for-four against Chicago White Sox pitcher Eddie Smith.', u"Major newspapers began to write about DiMaggio's streak early on, but as he approached George Sisler's modern era record of 41 games, it became a national phenomenon.", u'Initially, DiMaggio showed little interest in breaking Sisler\'s record, saying "I\'m not thinking a whole lot about it...', u'I\'ll either break it or I won\'t."', u'As he approached Sisler\'s record, DiMaggio showed more interest, saying, "At the start I didn\'t think much about it... but naturally I\'d like to get the record since I am this close."', u"On June 29, 1941, DiMaggio doubled in the first game of a doubleheader against the Washington Senators at Griffith Stadium to tie Sisler's record, and then singled in the nightcap to extend his streak to 42.", u'A Yankee Stadium crowd of 52,832 fans watched DiMaggio tie the all-time hitting streak record (44 games, Wee Willie Keeler in 1897) on July 1.', u"The next day against the Boston Red Sox, he homered into Yankee Stadium's left field stands to extend his streak to 45, setting a new record.", u'DiMaggio recorded 67 hits in 179 at-bats during the first 45 games of his streak, while Keeler recorded 88 hits in 201 at-bats.', u"DiMaggio continued hitting after breaking Keeler's record, reaching 50 straight games on July 11 against the St. Louis Browns.", u"On July 17 at Cleveland Stadium, DiMaggio's streak was finally snapped at 56 games, thanks in part to two backhand stops by Indians third baseman Ken Keltner.", u'DiMaggio batted .408 during the streak, with 15 home runs and 55 RBI.', u'The day after the streak ended, DiMaggio started another streak that lasted 16 games.', u'The distinction of hitting safely in 72 of 73 games is also a record.', u'The closest anyone has come to equaling DiMaggio since 1941 is Pete Rose, who hit safely in 44 straight games in 1978.', u'During the streak, DiMaggio played in seven doubleheaders.', u"The Yankees' record during the streak was 41\u201313\u20132.", u"Some consider DiMaggio's streak a uniquely outstanding and unbreakable record, and a statistical near-impossibility.", u'Nobel Prize-winning physicist and sabermetrician Edward Mills Purcell calculated that, to have the likelihood of a hitting streak of 50 games occurring in the history of baseball up to the late 1980s be greater than 50%, fifty-two .350 lifetime hitters would have to have existed instead of the actual three (Ty Cobb, Rogers Hornsby, and Shoeless Joe Jackson).', u'His Harvard colleague Stephen Jay Gould, citing Purcell\'s work, called DiMaggio\'s 56-game achievement "the most extraordinary thing that ever happened in American sports".', u'Samuel Arbesman and Steven Strogatz of Cornell University disagree; they conducted 10,000 computer simulations of Major League Baseball from 1871 to 2005, 42% of which produced streaks as long or longer, with record streaks ranging from 39 to 109 games and typical record streaks between 50 and 64 games.', u'== Wartime ==\nDiMaggio enlisted in the United States Army Air Forces on February 17, 1943, rising to the rank of sergeant.', u'He was stationed at Santa Ana, California, Hawaii, and Atlantic City, New Jersey, as a physical education instructor.', u'He was released on medical discharge in September 1945, due to chronic stomach ulcers.', u"Other than now being paid $21 a month, DiMaggio's service was as comfortable as a soldier's life could be.", u'He spent most of his career playing for baseball teams and in exhibition games against fellow Major Leaguers and minor league players, and superiors gave him special privileges due to his prewar fame.', u'DiMaggio ate so well from an athlete-only diet that he gained 10 pounds, and while in Hawaii he and other players mostly tanned on the beach and drank.', u'Embarrassed by his lifestyle, DiMaggio demanded combat duty in 1943, but was turned down.', u'=== Parents as "enemy aliens" ===\nGiuseppe and Rosalia DiMaggio were among the thousands of German, Japanese and Italian immigrants classified as "enemy aliens" by the government after Pearl Harbor was bombed by Japan.', u'They carried photo ID booklets at all times, and were not allowed to travel outside a five-mile radius from their home without a permit.', u'Giuseppe was barred from the San Francisco Bay, where he had fished for decades, and his boat was seized.', u'Rosalia became an face of the electric, drip coffee makers for over 20 years.', u'Vincent Marotta, the CEO of North American Systems, which manufactured Mr. Coffee at the time, recruited DiMaggio for the advertising commercials for the financial institution until 1992.', u'== Death ==\n\nDiMaggio, a heavy smoker for much of his adult life, was admitted to Memorial Regional Hospital in Hollywood, Florida, on October 12, 1998, for lung cancer surgery and remained there for 99 days.', u'He returned to his Hollywood, Florida home on January 19, 1999, where he died on March 8.', u'Joe DiMaggio\'s final words were: "I finally get to see Marilyn", referring to his former wife Marilyn Monroe.', u"DiMaggio's funeral was held on March 11, 1999, at Sts.", u'Peter and Paul Roman Catholic Church in San Francisco; he was interred at Holy Cross Cemetery in Colma, California.', u"DiMaggio's son died the following August at age 57.", u'A highway lining the Hudson River in Manhattan, New York from the end of Lower Manhattan is named the Joe DiMaggio Highway.', u'It runs for the entire way.', u'== Sports legacy ==\nAt his death, The New York Times called DiMaggio\'s 1941 56-game hitting streak "perhaps the most enduring record in sports".', u'In an article in 1976 in Esquire magazine, sportswriter Harry Stein published an "All Time All-Star Argument Starter", consisting of five ethnic baseball teams.', u"Joe DiMaggio was the center fielder on Stein's Italian team.", u"On September 17, 1992, the doors were opened at Joe DiMaggio Children's Hospital at Memorial Regional Hospital in Hollywood, Florida, for which he raised over $4,000,000.", u'On April 13, 1998, DiMaggio was given the Sports Legend Award at the 13th annual American Sportscasters Association Hall of Fame Awards Dinner in New York City.', u"Dr. Henry Kissinger, former Secretary of State and a longtime fan of DiMaggio's, made the presentation to the Yankee great.", u"The event was one of DiMaggio's last public appearances before taking ill.\nYankee Stadium's fifth monument was dedicated to DiMaggio on April 25, 1999, and the West Side Highway was officially renamed in his honor.", u"The Yankees wore DiMaggio's number 5 on the left sleeves of their uniforms for the 1999 season.", u'He is ranked No.', u"11 on The Sporting News' list of the 100 Greatest Baseball Players, and he was elected by fans to the Major League Baseball All-Century Team.", u"In addition to his number 5 being retired by the New York Yankees, DiMaggio's number was also retired by the Florida Marlins, who retired it in honor of their first team president, Carl Barger, who died five months before the team took the field for the first time in 1993.", u'DiMaggio had been his favorite player.', u"An auction of DiMaggio's personal items was held by the adopted daughters of DiMaggio's son in May 2006.", u'Highlights included the ball hit to break Wee Willie Keeler\'s hitting-streak record ($63,250); his 2,000th career hit ball ($29,900); his
