referred to as "Silicon Valley") that was founded by Gordon Moore (of Moore\'s Law fame) and Robert Noyce.', u"It and AMD are the world's largest and highest valued semiconductor chip makers based on revenue., and is the inventor of the x86 series of microprocessors, the processors found in most personal computers (PCs).", u'Intel supplies processors for computer system manufacturers such as Apple, Inc., Lenovo (formerly IBM), Hewlett Packard, Inc. and Dell.', u'Intel also manufactures motherboard chipsets, network interface controllers and integrated circuits, flash memory, graphics chips, embedded processors and other devices related to communications and computing.', u'Intel Corporation was founded on July 18, 1968 by semiconductor pioneers Robert Noyce and Gordon Moore, and widely associated with the executive leadership and vision of Andrew Grove.', u"The company's name was conceived as portmanteau of the words integrated and electronics.", u'The fact that "intel" is the term for intelligence information also made the name appropriate.', u'Intel was an early developer of SRAM and DRAM memory chips, which represented the majority of its business until 1981.', u"Although Intel created the world's first commercial microprocessor chip in 1971, it was not until the success of the personal computer (PC) that this became its primary business.", u'During the 1990s, Intel invested heavily in new microprocessor designs fostering the rapid growth of the computer industry.', u'During this period Intel became the dominant supplier of microprocessors for PCs, and was known for aggressive and anti-competitive tactics in defense of its market position, particularly against Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), as well as a struggle with Microsoft for control over the direction of the PC industry.', u"Intel was placed at #56 on the 2015 rankings of the world's most valuable brands published by Millward Brown Optimor.", u'The Open Source Technology Center at Intel hosts PowerTOP and LatencyTOP, and supports other open-source projects such as Wayland, Intel Array Building Blocks, and Threading Building Blocks (TBB), and Xen.', u'== Current operations ==\n\n\n=== Operating segments ===\nIntel Computing Group \u2013  58% of 2015 revenues \u2013  produces hardware components used in desktop and notebook computers.', u'Data Center Group \u2013  29% of 2015 revenues \u2013  produces hardware components used in server, network, and storage platforms.', u'Internet of Things Group \u2013  4% of 2015 revenues \u2013  offers platforms designed for retail, transportation, industrial, buildings and home use.', u'Software and Services \u2013  4% of 2015 revenues \u2013  produces software, particularly security and antivirus software.', u'Other \u2013  5% of 2015 revenues \u2013  primarily the Non-Volatile Memory Solutions Group and the New Devices Group.', u"=== Top customers ===\nIn 2015, HP Inc. and HP Enterprise collectively accounted for 18% of the company's revenue, Dell for 15%, and Lenovo for 13%.", u'=== Market share ===\n\n\n==== Market share in early 2011 ====\nAccording to IDC, while Intel enjoyed the biggest market share in both the overall worldwide PC microprocessor market (79.3%) and the mobile PC microprocessor (84.4%) in the second quarter of 2011, the numbers decreased by 1.5% and 1.9% compared to the first quarter of 2011.', u'==== Historical market share ====\nIn the 1980s, Intel was among the top ten sellers of semiconductors (10th in 1987) in the world.', u'In 1991, Intel became the biggest chip maker by revenue and has held the position ever since.', u'Other top semiconductor companies include TSMC, Advanced Micro Devices, Samsung, Texas Instruments, Toshiba and STMicroelectronics.', u'==== Major competitors ====\nCompetitors in PC chip sets include Advanced Micro Devices, VIA Technologies, Silicon Integrated Systems, and Nvidia.', u"Intel's competitors in networking include NXP Semiconductors, Infineon, Broadcom Limited, Marvell Technology Group and Applied Micro Circuits Corporation, and competitors in flash memory include Spansion, Samsung, Qimonda, Toshiba, STMicroelectronics, and SK Hynix.", u"The only major competitor in the x86 processor market is Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), with which Intel has had full cross-licensing agreements since 1976: each partner can use the other's patented technological innovations without charge after a certain time.", u'However, the cross-licensing agreement is canceled in the event of an AMD bankruptcy or takeover.', u'Some smaller competitors such as VIA Technologies produce low-power x86 processors for small factor computers and portable equipment.', u'However, the advent of such mobile computing devices, in particular, smartphones, has in recent years led to a decline in PC sales.', u"Since over 95% of the world's smartphones currently use processors designed by ARM Holdings, ARM has become a major competitor for Intel's processor market.", u'ARM is also planning to make inroads into the PC and server market.', u'Intel has been involved in several disputes regarding violation of antitrust laws, which are noted below.', u'== Corporate history ==\n\n\n=== Origins ===\n\nIntel was founded in Mountain View, California in 1968 by Gordon E. Moore (of "Moore\'s Law" fame), a chemist, and Robert Noyce, a physicist and co-inventor of the integrated circuit.', u'Arthur Rock (investor and venture capitalist) helped them find investors, while Max Palevsky was on the board from an early stage.', u'Moore and Noyce had left Fairchild Semiconductor to found Intel.', u'Rock was not an employee, but he was an investor and was chairman of the board.', u'The total initial investment in Intel was $2.5 million convertible debentures and $10,000 from Rock.', u'Just 2 years later, Intel became a public company via an initial public offering (IPO), raising $6.8 million ($23.50 per share).', u"Intel's third employee was Andy Grove, a chemical engineer, who later ran the company through much of the 1980s and the high-growth 1990s.", u'In deciding on a name, Moore and Noyce quickly rejected "Moore Noyce", homophone for "more noise" \u2013 an ill-suited name for an electronics company, since noise in electronics is usually very undesirable and typically associated with bad interference.', u'Instead they used the name NM Electronics before renaming their company Integrated Electronics or "Intel" for short.', u'Since "Intel" was already trademarked by the hotel chain Intelco, they had to buy the rights for the name.', u'=== Early history ===\nAt its founding, Intel was distinguished by its ability to make semiconductors.', u'Its first product, in 1969, was the 3101 Schottky TTL bipolar 64-bit static random-access memory (SRAM), which was nearly twice as fast as earlier Schottky diode implementations by Fairchild and the Electrotechnical Laboratory in Tsukuba, Japan.', u'In the same year Intel also produced the 3301 Schottky bipolar 1024-bit read-only memory (ROM) and the first commercial metal\u2013oxide\u2013semiconductor field-effect transistor (MOSFET) silicon gate SRAM chip, the 256-bit 1101.', u"Intel's business grew during the 1970s as it expanded and improved its manufacturing processes and produced a wider range of products, still dominated by various memory devices.", u'While Intel created the first commercially available microprocessor (Intel 4004) in 1971 and one of the first microcomputers in 1972, by the early 1980s its business was dominated by dynamic random-access memory chips.', u'However, increased competition from Japanese semiconductor manufacturers had, by 1983, dramatically reduced the profitability of this market.', u"The growing success of the IBM personal computer, based on an Intel microprocessor, was among factors that convinced Gordon Moore (CEO since 1975) to shift the company's focus to microprocessors, and to change fundamental aspects of that business model.", u"Moore's decision to sole-source Intel's 386 chip played into the company's continuing success.", u"By the end of the 1980s, buoyed by its fortuitous position as microprocessor supplier to IBM and IBM's competitors within the rapidly growing personal computer market, Intel embarked on a 10-year period of unprecedented growth as the primary (and most profitable) hardware supplier to the PC industry, part of the winning 'Wintel' combination.", u'Moore handed over to Andy Grove in 1987.', u'By launching its Intel Inside marketing campaign in 1991, Intel was able to associate brand loyalty with consumer selection, so that by the end of the 1990s, its line of Pentium processors had become a household name.', u'=== Slowing demand and challenges to dominance in 2000 ===\nAfter 2000, growth in demand for high-end microprocessors slowed.', u"Competitors, notably AMD (Intel's largest competitor in its primary x86 architecture market), garnered significant market share, initially in low-end and mid-range processors but ultimately across the product range, and Intel's dominant position in its core market was greatly reduced.", u"In the early 2000s then-CEO Craig Barrett attempted to diversify the company's business beyond semiconductors, but few of these activities were ultimately successful.", u'=== Litigation ===\nIntel had also for a number of years been embroiled in litigation.', u'US law did not initially recognize intellectual property rights related to microprocessor topology (circuit layouts), until the Semiconductor Chip Protection Act of 1984, a law sought by Intel and the Semiconductor Industry Association (SIA).', u'During the late 1980s and 1990s (after this law was passed), Intel also sued companies that tried to develop competitor chips to the 80386 CPU.', u'The lawsuits were noted to significantly burden the competition with legal bills, even if Intel lost the suits.', u'Antitrust allegations had been simmering since the early 1990s and had been the cause of one lawsuit against Intel in 1991.', u'In 2004 and 2005, AMD brought further claims against Intel related to unfair competition.', u'=== Regaining of momentum (2005\u20132007) ===\nIn 2005, CEO Paul Otellini reorganized the company to refocus its core processor and chipset business on platforms (enterprise, digital home, digital health, and mobility).', u'In 2007, Intel unveiled its Core microarchitecture to widespread critical acclaim; the product range was perceived as an exceptional leap in processor performance that at a stroke regained much of its leadership of the field.', u'In 2008, Intel had another "tick," when it introduced the Penryn microarchitecture, which was 45 nm.', u'Later that year, Intel released a processor with the Nehalem architecture.', u'Nehalem had positive reviews.', u"=== Sale of XScale processor business (2006) ===\nOn June 27, 2006, the sale of Intel's XScale assets was announced.", u'Intel agreed to sell the XScale processor business to Marvell Technology Group for an estimated $600 million and the assumption of unspecified liabilities.', u'The move was intended to permit Intel to focus its resources on its core x86 and server businesses, and the acquisition completed on November 9, 2006.', u'=== Acquisitions (2010\u20132016) ===\nIn 2010, Intel purchased McAfee, a manufacturer of computer security technology for $7.68 billion.', u"As a condition for regulatory approval of the transaction, Intel agreed to provide rival security firms with all necessary information that would allow their products to use Intel's chips and personal computers.", u'After the acquisition, Intel had about 90,000 employees, including about 12,000 software engineers.', u'In September 2016, Intel sold a majority stake in its computer-security unit to TPG, reversing the five-year-old McAfee acquisition.', u"On August 30, 2010, Intel and Infineon Technologies announced that Intel would acquire Infineon's Wireless Solutions business.", u"Intel planned to use Infineon's technology in laptops, smart phones, netbooks, tablets and embedded computers in consumer products, eventually integrating its wireless modem into Intel's silicon chips.", u'In March 2011, Intel bought most of the assets of Cairo-based SySDSoft.', u'In July 2011, Intel announced that it had agreed to acquire Fulcrum Microsystems Inc., a company specializing in network switches.', u'The company used to be included on the EE Times list of 60 Emerging Startups.', u'On October 1, 2011, Intel reached a deal to acquire Telmap, an Israeli-based navigation software company.', u'The purchase price was not disclosed, but Israeli media reported values around $300 million to $350 million.', u'In July 2012, Intel Corporation agreed to buy 10 percent shares of ASML Holding NV for $2.1 billion and another $1 billon for 5 percent shares that need shareholder approval to fund relevant research and development efforts, as part of a EUR3.3 billion ($4.1 billion) deal to accelerate the development of 450-millimeter wafer technology and extreme ultra-violet lithography by as much as two years.', u'In July 2013, Intel confirmed the acquisition of Omek Interactive, an Israeli company that makes technology for gesture-based interfaces, without disclosing the monetary value of the deal.', u'An official statement from Intel read: "The acquisition of Omek Interactive will help increase Intel\'s capabilities in the delivery of more immersive perceptual computing experiences."', u'One report estimated the value of the acquisition between US$30 million and $50 million.', u'The acquisition of a Spanish natural language recognition startup named Indisys was announced on September 13, 2013.', u'The terms of the deal were not disclosed but an email from an Intel representative stated: "Intel has acquired Indisys, a privately held company based in Seville, Spain.', u'The majority of Indisys employees joined Intel.', u'We signed the agreement to acquire the company on May 31 and the deal has been completed."', u'Indysis explains that its artificial intelligence (AI) technology "is a human image, which converses fluently and with common sense in multiple languages and also works in different platforms."', u'In December 2014, Intel bought PasswordBox.', u'In January 2015, Intel purchased a 30% stake in Vuzix, a smart glasses manufacturer.', u'The deal was worth $24.8 million.', u'In February 2015, Intel announced its agreement to purchase German network chipmaker Lantiq, to aid in its expansion of its range of chips in devices with Internet connection capability.', u'In June 2015, Intel announced its agreement to purchase FPGA design company Altera for $16.7 billion, in its largest acquisition to date.', u'The acquisition completed in December 2015.', u'In October 2015, Intel bought cognitive computing company Saffron Technology for an undisclosed price.', u'In August 2016, Intel purchased deep-learning startup Nervana Systems for $350 Million.', u'== Acquisition table (2010\u20132016) ==\n\n\n=== Expansions (2008\u20132011) ===\nIn 2008, Intel spun off key assets of a solar startup business effort to form an independent company, SpectraWatt Inc.', u'In 2011, SpectraWatt filed for bankruptcy.', u'In February 2011, Intel began to build a new microprocessor manufacturing facility in Chandler, Arizona, completed in 2013 at a cost of $5 billion.', u'The building was never used.', u'The company produces three-quarters of its products in the United States, although three-quarters of its revenue comes from overseas.', u"In April 2011, Intel began a pilot project with ZTE Corporation to produce smartphones using the Intel Atom processor for China's domestic market.", u"In December 2011, Intel announced that it reorganized several of its business units into a new mobile and communications group be responsible for the company's smartphone, tablet and wireless efforts.", u'=== Opening up the foundries to other manufacturers (2013) ===\nFinding itself with excess fab capacity after the failure of the Ultrabook to gain market traction and with PC sales declining, in 2013 Intel reached a foundry agreement to produce chips for Altera using 14-nm process.', u"General Manager of Intel's custom foundry division Sunit Rikhi indicated that Intel would pursue further such deals in the future.", u'This was after poor sales of Windows 8 hardware caused a major retrenchment for most of the major semiconductor manufacturers, except for Qualcomm, which continued to see healthy purchases from its largest customer, Apple.', u"As of July 2013, five companies were using Intel's fabs via the Intel Custom Foundry division: Achronix, Tabula, Netronome, Microsemi, and Panasonic \u2013  most are field-programmable gate array (FPGA) makers, but Netronome designs network processors.", u'Only Achronix began shipping chips made by Intel using the 22-nm Tri-Gate process.', u'Several other customers also exist but were not announced at the time.', u'The Alliance for Affordable Internet (A4AI) was launched in October 2013 and Intel is part of the coalition of public and private organisations that also includes Facebook, Google, and Microsoft.', u'Led by Sir Tim Berners-Lee, the A4AI seeks to make Internet access more affordable so that access is broadened in the developing world, where only 31% of people are online.', u"Google will help to decrease internet access prices so that they fall below the UN Broadband Commission's worldwide target of 5% of monthly income.", u"== Product and market history ==\n\n\n=== SRAMS and the microprocessor ===\nIntel's first products were shift register memory and random-access memory integrated circuits, and Intel grew to be a leader in the fiercely competitive DRAM, SRAM, and ROM markets throughout the 1970s.", u"Concurrently, Intel engineers Marcian Hoff, Federico Faggin, Stanley Mazor and Masatoshi Shima invented Intel's first microprocessor.", u"Originally developed for the Japanese company Busicom to replace a number of ASICs in a calculator already produced by Busicom, the Intel 4004 was introduced to the mass market on November 15, 1971, though the microprocessor did not become the core of Intel's business until the mid-1980s.", u"(Note: Intel is usually given credit with Texas Instruments for the almost-simultaneous invention of the microprocessor)\n\n\n=== From DRAM to microprocessors ===\nIn 1983, at the dawn of the personal computer era, Intel's profits came under increased pressure from Japanese memory-chip manufacturers, and then-president Andy Grove focused the company on microprocessors.", u'Grove described this transition in the book Only the Paranoid Survive.', u'A key element of his plan was the notion, then considered radical, of becoming the single source for successors to the popular 8086 microprocessor.', u'Until then, the manufacture of complex integrated circuits was not reliable enough for customers to depend on a single supplier, but Grove began producing processors in three geographically distinct factories, and ceased licensing the chip designs to competitors such as Zilog and AMD.', u'When the PC industry boomed in the late 1980s and 1990s, Intel was one of the primary beneficiaries.', u'=== Intel, x86 processors, and the IBM PC ===\n\nDespite the ultimate importance of the microprocessor, the 4004 and its successors the 8008 and the 8080 were never major revenue contributors at Intel.', u'As the next processor, the 8086 (and its variant the 8088) was completed in 1978, Intel embarked on a major marketing and sales campaign for that chip nicknamed "Operation Crush", and intended to win as many customers for the processor as possible.', u'One design win was the newly created IBM PC division, though the importance of this was not fully realized at the time.', u'IBM introduced its personal computer in 1981, and it was rapidly successful.', u'In 1982, Intel created the 80286 microprocessor, which, two years later, was used in the IBM PC/AT.', u'Compaq, the first IBM PC "clone" manufacturer, produced a desktop system based on the faster 80286 processor in 1985 and in 1986 quickly followed with the first 80386-based system, beating IBM and establishing a competitive market for PC-compatible systems and setting up Intel as a key component supplier.', u'In 1975, the company had started a project to develop a highly advanced 32-bit microprocessor, finally released in 1981 as the Intel iAPX 432.', u'The project was too ambitious and the processor was never able to meet its performance objectives, and it failed in the marketplace.', u'Intel extended the x86 architecture to 32 bits instead.', u'==== 386 microprocessor ====\nDuring this period Andrew Grove dramatically redirected the company, closing much of its DRAM business and directing resources to the microprocessor business.', u'Of perhaps greater importance was his decision to "single-source" the 386 microprocessor.', u'Prior to this, microprocessor manufacturing was in its infancy, and manufacturing problems frequently reduced or stopped production, interrupting supplies to customers.', u'To mitigate this risk, these customers typically insisted that multiple manufacturers produce chips they could use to ensure a consistent supply.', u'The 8080 and 8086-series microprocessors were produced by several companies, notably AMD.', u'Grove made the decision not to license the 386 design to other manufacturers, instead producing it in three geographically distinct factories: Santa Clara, California; Hillsboro, Oregon; and Chandler, a suburb of Phoenix, Arizona.', u'He convinced customers that this would ensure consistent delivery.', u"As the success of Compaq's Deskpro 386 established the 386 as the dominant CPU choice, Intel achieved a position of near-exclusive dominance as its supplier.", u'Profits from this funded rapid development of both higher-performance chip designs and higher-performance manufacturing capabilities, propelling Intel to a position of unquestioned leadership by the early 1990s.', u'==== 486, Pentium, and Itanium ====\nIntel introduced the 486 microprocessor in 1989, and in 1990 established a second design team, designing the processors code-named "P5" and "P6" in parallel and committing to a major new processor every two years, versus the four or more years such designs had taken.', u"Engineers Vinod Dham and Rajeev Chandrasekhar (Member of Parliament, India) were key figures on the core team that invented the 486 chip and later, Intel's signature Pentium chip.", u'The P5 was earlier known as "Operation Bicycle," referring to the cycles of the processor.', u'The P5 was introduced in 1993 as the Intel Pentium, substituting a registered trademark name for the former part number (numbers, such as 486, are hard to register as a trademark).', u'The P6 followed in 1995 as the Pentium Pro and improved into the Pentium II in 1997.', u'New architectures were developed alternately in Santa Clara, California and Hillsboro, Oregon.', u'The Santa Clara design team embarked in 1993 on a successor to the x86 architecture, codenamed "P7".', u'The first attempt was dropped a year later, but quickly revived in a cooperative program with Hewlett-Packard engineers, though Intel soon took over primary design responsibility.', u'The resulting implementation of the IA-64 64-bit architecture was the Itanium, finally introduced in June 2001.', u"The Itanium's performance running legacy x86 code did not meet expectations, and it failed to compete effectively with x86-64, which was AMD's 64-bit extensions to the original x86 architecture (Intel uses the name Intel 64, previously EM64T).", u'As of 2012, Intel continues to develop and deploy the Itanium; known planning continues into 2014.', u'The Hillsboro team designed the Willamette processors (initially code-named P68), which were marketed as the Pentium 4.', u'==== Pentium flaw ====\n\nIn June 1994, Intel engineers discovered a flaw in the floating-point math subsection of the P5 Pentium microprocessor.', u'Under certain data-dependent conditions, the low-order bits of the result of a floating-point division would be incorrect.', u'The error could compound in subsequent calculations.', u'Intel corrected the error in a future chip revision.', u'In October 1994, Thomas Nicely, Professor of Mathematics at Lynchburg College, independently discovered the bug.', u'He contacted Intel, but received no response.', u'On October 30, he posted a message on the Internet.', u'Word of the bug spread quickly and reached the industry press.', u'The bug was easy to replicate; a user could enter specific numbers into the calculator on the operating system.', u'Consequently, many users did not accept Intel\'s statements that the error was minor and "not even an erratum."', u'During Thanksgiving, in 1994, The New York Times ran a piece by journalist John Markoff spotlighting the error.', u'Intel changed its position and offered to replace every chip, quickly putting in place a large end-user support organization.', u"This resulted in a $475 million charge against Intel's 1994 revenue.", u'The "Pentium flaw" incident, Intel\'s response to it, and the surrounding media coverage propelled Intel from being a technology supplier generally unknown to most computer users to a household name.', u'Dovetailing with an uptick in the "Intel Inside" campaign, the episode is considered to have been a positive event for Intel, changing some of its business practices to be more end-user focused and generating substantial public awareness, while avoiding a lasting negative impression.', u'==== "Intel Inside" and other campaigns ====\n\nDuring this period, Intel undertook two major supporting advertising campaigns.', u'The first campaign, the 1991 "Intel Inside" marketing and branding campaign, is widely known and has become synonymous with Intel itself.', u'The idea of "ingredient branding" was new at the time, with only Nutrasweet and a few others making attempts to do so.', u'This campaign established Intel, which had been a component supplier little-known outside the PC industry, as a household name.', u'The second campaign, Intel\'s Systems Group, which began in the early 1990s, showcased manufacturing of PC "motherboards", the main board component of a personal computer, and the one into which the processor (CPU) and memory (RAM) chips are plugged.', u'The Systems Group campaign was lesser known than the Intel Inside campaign.', u'Shortly after, Intel began manufacturing fully configured "white box" systems for the dozens of PC clone companies that rapidly sprang up.', u'At its peak in the mid-1990s, Intel manufactured over 15% of all PCs, making it the third-largest supplier at the time.', u'During the 1990s, Intel Architecture Labs (IAL) was responsible for many of the hardware innovations of the personal computer, including the PCI Bus, the PCI Express (PCIe) bus, the Universal Serial Bus (USB).', u"IAL's software efforts met with a more mixed fate; its video and graphics software was important in the development of software digital video, but later its efforts were largely overshadowed by competition from Microsoft.", u'The competition between Intel and Microsoft was revealed in testimony by IAL Vice-President Steven McGeady at the Microsoft antitrust trial.', u'=== Solid-state drives (SSD) ===\n\nOn September 8, 2008, Intel began shipping its first mainstream solid-state drives, the X18-M and X25-M with 80 GB and 160 GB storage capacities.', u'Reviews measured high performance with these MLC-based drives.', u'Intel released its SLC-based Enterprise X25-E Extreme SSDs on October 15 that same year in capacities of 32GB and 64GB.', u'In July 2009, Intel moved its X25-M and X18-M lines from a 50-nanometer to a 34-nanometer process.', u'These new drives, dubbed by the press as the X25-M and X18-M G2 (or generation 2), reduced prices by up to 60 percent while offering lower latency and improved performance.', u'On February 1, 2010, Intel and Micron announced that they were gearing up for production of NAND flash memory using a new 25-nanometer process.', u'In March of that same year, Intel entered the budget SSD segment with its X25-V drives with an initial capacity of 40 GB.', u"The SSD 310, Intel's first mSATA drive was released on December 2010, providing X25-M G2 performance in a much smaller package.", u'March 2011 saw the introduction of two new SSD lines from Intel.', u'The first, the SSD 510, used a SATA 6 Gigabit per second interface to reach speeds of up to 500 MegaBytes per second.', u'The drive, which uses a controller from Marvell Technology Group, was released using 34 nm NAND Flash and came in capacities of 120 GB and 250 GB.', u"The second product announcement, the SSD 320, is the successor to Intel's earlier X25-M.", u'It uses the new 25 nm process that Intel and Micron announced in 2010, and was released in capacities of 40, 80, 120, 16, 300 and 600 GB.', u'Sequential read performance maxes out at 270 MB/s due to the older SATA 3 Gbit/s interface, and sequential write performance varies greatly based on the size of the drive with sequential write performance of the 40 GB model peaking at 45 MB/s and the 600 GB at 220 MB/s.', u'Micron and Intel announced that they were producing their first 20 nm MLC NAND flash on April 14, 2011.', u'In February 2012, Intel launched the SSD 520 series solid state drives using the SandForce SF-2200 controller with sequential read and write speeds of 550 and 520 MB/s respectively with random read and write IOPS as high as 80,000.', u'These drives will replace the 510 series.', u'Intel has released the budget 330 series solid state drive in 60, 120, and 180 GB capacities using 25 nm flash memory and a SandForce controller that have replaced the 320 series.', u'In late 2015, Intel announced that they were producing their first consumer PCIe-based solid state drive, to be named the 750 series.', u'These new drives would either be plugged directly into a compatible PCIe 3.0 x4 slot or into the U.2 connector on the motherboard.', u'=== Supercomputers ===\nThe Intel Scientific Computers division was founded in 1984 by Justin Rattner, in order to design and produce parallel computers based on Intel microprocessors connected in hypercube topologies.', u'In 1992 the name was changed to the Intel Supercomputing Systems Division, and development of the iWarp architecture was also subsumed.', u'The division designed several supercomputer systems, including the Intel iPSC/1, iPSC/2, iPSC/860, Paragon and ASCI Red.', u'In November 2014, Intel revealed that it is going to use light beams to speed up supercomputers.', u'The renowned chip maker has also disclosed that all its Supercomputer forms will use optical technology for data transfer from 2015.', u'=== Competition, antitrust and espionage ===\n\nTwo factors combined to end this dominance: the slowing of PC demand growth beginning in 2000 and the rise of the low cost PC.', u'By the end of the 1990s, microprocessor performance had outstripped software demand for that CPU power.', u'Aside from high-end server systems and software, whose demand dropped with the end of the "dot-com bubble", consumer systems ran effectively on increasingly low-cost systems after 2000.', u"Intel's strategy of producing ever-more-powerful processors and obsoleting their predecessors stumbled, leaving an opportunity for rapid gains by competitors, notably AMD.", u'This in turn lowered the profitability of the processor line and ended an era of unprecedented dominance of the PC hardware by Intel.', u"Intel's dominance in the x86 microprocessor market led to numerous charges of antitrust violations over the years, including FTC investigations in both the late 1980s and in 1999, and civil actions such as the 1997 suit by Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC) and a patent suit by Intergraph.", u"Intel's market dominance (at one time it controlled over 85% of the market for 32-bit x86 microprocessors) combined with Intel's own hardball legal tactics (such as its infamous 338 patent suit versus PC manufacturers) made it an attractive target for litigation, but few of the lawsuits ever amounted to anything.", u'A case of industrial espionage arose in 1995 that involved both Intel and AMD.', u"Bill Gaede, an Argentine formerly employed both at AMD and at Intel's Arizona plant, was arrested for attempting in 1993 to sell the i486 and P5 Pentium designs to AMD and to certain foreign powers.", u"Gaede videotaped data from his computer screen at Intel and mailed it to AMD, which immediately alerted Intel and authorities, resulting in Gaede's arrest.", u'Gaede was convicted and sentenced to 33 months in prison in June 1996.', u"=== Use of Intel products by Apple Computer (2005-present) ===\n\nOn June 6, 2005, Steve Jobs, then CEO of Apple, announced that Apple would be transitioning from its long favored PowerPC architecture to the Intel x86 architecture, because the future PowerPC road map was unable to satisfy Apple's needs.", u'The first Macintosh computers containing Intel CPUs were announced on January 10, 2006, and Apple had its entire line of consumer Macs running on Intel processors by early August 2006.', u"The Apple Xserve server was updated to Intel Xeon processors from November 2006, and was offered in a configuration similar to Apple's Mac Pro.", u'=== Core 2 Duo advertisement controversy (2007) ===\nIn July 2007, the company released a print advertisement for its Intel Core 2 Duo processor featuring six African American runners appearing to bow down to a Caucasian male inside of an office setting (due to the posture taken by runners on starting blocks).', u'According to Nancy Bhagat, Vice President of Intel Corporate Marketing, viewers found the ad to be "insensitive and insulting."', u"and several Intel executives made public apologies\n\n\n=== Introduction of Classmate PC (2011) ===\nThe Classmate PC is the company's first low-cost netbook computer.", u'In 2014, the company released an updated version of the Classmate PC.', u'=== Introduction of new mobile processor technology (2011) ===\nIn June 2011, Intel introduced the first Pentium mobile processor based on the Sandy Bridge core.', u'The B940, clocked at 2 GHz, is faster than existing or upcoming mobile Celerons, although it is almost identical to dual-core Celeron CPUs in all other aspects.', u"According to IHS iSuppli's report on September 28, 2011, Sandy Bridge chips have helped Intel increase its market share in global processor market to 81.8%, while AMD's market share dropped to 10.4%.", u'Intel planned to introduce Medfield \u2013 a processor for tablets and smartphones \u2013 to the market in 2012, as an effort to compete with ARM.', u"As a 32-nanometer processor, Medfield is designed to be energy-efficient, which is one of the core features in ARM's chips.", u"At the Intel Developers Forum (IDF) 2011 in San Francisco, Intel's partnership with Google was announced.", u"By January 2012, Google's Android 2.3 will use Intel's Atom microprocessor.", u'=== Update to server chips (2011) ===\nIn July 2011, Intel announced that its server chips, the Xeon series, will use new sensors that can improve data center cooling efficiency.', u'=== Introduction of Ivy Bridge 22 nm processors (2011) ===\nIn 2011, Intel announced the Ivy Bridge processor family at the Intel DeveConflict FreeCloper Forum.', u'Ivy Bridge supports both DDR3 memory and DDR3L chips.', u'=== Development of Personal Office Energy Monitor (POEM) (2011) ===\nAs part of its efforts in the Positive Energy Buildings Consortium, Intel has been developing an application, called Personal Office Energy Monitor (POEM), to help office buildings to be more energy-efficient.', u'With this application, employees can get the power consumption info for their office machines, so that they can figure out a better way to save energy in their working environment.', u'=== IT Manager 3: Unseen Forces ===\nIT Manager 3: Unseen Forces was a web-based IT simulation game introduced by Intel in 2009.', u"In it you manage a company's IT department.", u'The goal is to apply technology and skill to enable the company to grow from a small business into a global enterprise.', u'The game has since been discontinued.', u'=== Car Security System (2011) ===\nIn 2011, Intel announced that it is working on a car security system that connects to smartphones via an application.', u'The application works by streaming video to a cloud service if your car is broken into.', u'=== High-Bandwidth Digital Content Protection ===\nIntel also developed High-Bandwidth Digital Content Protection (HDCP) to prevent access of digital audio and video content as it travels across connections.', u'=== Move from Wintel desktop to open mobile platforms (2013\u20132014) ===\nIn 2013, Intel\'s Kirk Skaugen said that Intel\'s exclusive focus on Microsoft platforms was a thing of the past and that they would now support all "tier-one operating systems" such as Linux, Android, iOS, and Chrome.', u'In 2014, Intel cut thousands of employees in response to "evolving market trends", and offered to subsidize manufacturers for the extra costs involved in using Intel chips in their tablets.', u'=== Introduction of Haswell processors (2013) ===\nIn June 2013, Intel unveiled its fourth generation of Intel Core processors (Haswell) in an event named Computex in Taipei.', u'=== Wearable fashion (2014) ===\nOn January 6, 2014, Intel announced that it was "teaming with the Council of Fashion Designers of America, Barneys New York and Opening Ceremony around the wearable tech field."', u'Intel has developed a reference design for wearable smart earbuds that provide biometric and fitness information.', u'The Intel smart earbuds provide full stereo audio, and monitor heart rate, while the applications on the user\u2019s phone keep track of run distance and calories burned.', u'=== Fog computing ===\nOn November 19, 2015, Intel, alongside ARM Holdings, Dell, Cisco Systems, Microsoft, and Princeton University, founded the OpenFog Consortium, to promote interests and development in fog computing.', u"Intel's Chief Strategist for the IoT Strategy and Technology Office, Jeff Faders, became the consortium's first president.", u'=== Conflict Free ===\nIn July 2016, Intel began a campaign announcing that all of their processor products were Conflict Free, meaning that the minerals used to create those products was sourced responsibly, and minimized the risk of human life.', u"Intel's Conflict Free campaign was publicized massively after Intel sent packages to YouTube personalities Linus Sebastian, Lewis Hilsenteger from Unbox Therapy and Joanne Chiang.", u"== Corporate affairs ==\n\n\n=== Leadership and corporate structure ===\n\nRobert Noyce was Intel's CEO at its founding in 1968, followed by co-founder Gordon Moore in 1975.", u"Andy Grove became the company's president in 1979 and added the CEO title in 1987 when Moore became chairman.", u'In 1998, Grove succeeded Moore as Chairman, and Craig Barrett, already company president, took over.', u"On May 18, 2005, Barrett handed the reins of the company over to Paul Otellini, who had been the company president and COO and who was responsible for Intel's design win in the original IBM PC.", u'The board of directors elected Otellini as President and CEO, and Barrett replaced Grove as Chairman of the Board.', u'Grove stepped down as chairman, but is retained as a special adviser.', u'In May 2009, Barrett stepped down as chairman of the Board and was succeeded by Jane Shaw.', u'In May 2012, Intel vice chairman Andy Bryant, who had held the posts of CFO (1994) and Chief Administrative Officer (2007) at Intel, succeeded Shaw as executive chairman.', u"In November 2012, president and CEO Paul Otellini announced that he would step down in May 2013 at the age of 62, three years before the company's mandatory retirement age.", u"During a six-month transition period, Intel's board of directors commenced a search process for the next CEO, in which it considered both internal managers and external candidates such as Sanjay Jha and Patrick Gelsinger.", u"Financial results revealed that, under Otellini, Intel's revenue increased by 55.8 percent (US$34.2 to 53.3 billion), while its net income increased by 46.7% (US$7.5 billion to 11 billion).", u"On May 2, 2013, Executive Vice President and COO Brian Krzanich was elected as Intel's sixth CEO, a selection that became effective on May 16, 2013 at the company's annual meeting.", u"Reportedly, the board concluded that an insider could proceed with the role and exert an impact more quickly, without the need to learn Intel's processes, and Krzanich was selected on such a basis.", u"Intel's software head Ren\xe9e James was selected as president of the company, a role that is second to the CEO position.", u"As of May 2013, Intel's board of directors consists of Andy Bryant, John Donahoe, Frank Yeary, Ambassador Charlene Barshefsky, Susan Decker, Reed Hundt, Paul Otellini, James Plummer, David Pottruck, and David Yoffie.", u'The board was described by former Financial Times journalist Tom Foremski as "an exemplary example of corporate governance of the highest order" and received a rating of ten from GovernanceMetrics International, a form of recognition that has only been awarded to twenty-one other corporate boards worldwide.', u'=== Employment ===\n\nThe firm promotes very heavily from within, most notably in its executive suite.', u'The company has resisted the trend toward outsider CEOs.', u'Paul Otellini was a 30-year veteran of the company when he assumed the role of CEO.', u'All of his top lieutenants have risen through the ranks after many years with the firm.', u"In many cases, Intel's top executives have spent their entire working careers with Intel.", u'Intel has a mandatory retirement policy for its CEOs when they reach age 65.', u'Andy Grove retired at 62, while both Robert Noyce and Gordon Moore retired at 58.', u'Grove retired as Chairman and as a member of the board of directors in 2005 at age 68.', u"Intel's headquarters are located in Santa Clara, California, and the company has operations around the world.", u'Its largest workforce concentration anywhere is in Washington County, Oregon (in the Portland metropolitan area\'s "Silicon Forest"), with 18,600 employees at several facilities.', u'Outside the United States, the company has facilities in China, Costa Rica, Malaysia, Israel, Ireland, India, Russia, Argentina and Vietnam, in 63 countries and regions internationally.', u'In the U.S. Intel employs significant numbers of people in California, Colorado, Massachusetts, Arizona, New Mexico, Oregon, Texas, Washington and Utah.', u"In Oregon, Intel is the state's largest private employer.", u'The company is the largest industrial employer in New Mexico while in Arizona the company has over 10,000 employees.', u'Intel invests heavily in research in China and about 100 researchers \u2013  or 10% of the total number of researchers from Intel \u2013  are located in Beijing.', u'In 2011, the Israeli government offered Intel $290 million to expand in the country.', u'As a condition, Intel would employ 1,500 more workers in Kiryat Gat and between 600\u20131000 workers in the north.', u'In January 2014, it was reported that Intel would cut about 5,000 jobs from its work force of 107,000.', u'The announcement was made a day after it reported earnings that missed analyst targets.', u'In March 2014, it was reported that Intel would embark upon a $6 billion plan to expand its activities in Israel.', u'The plan calls for continued investment in existing and new Intel plants until 2030.', u'As of 2014 Intel employs 10,000 workers at four development centers and two production plants in Israel.', u'==== Diversity ====\nIntel has a Diversity Initiative, including employee diversity groups as well as supplier diversity programs.', u'Like many companies with employee diversity groups, they include groups based on race and nationality as well as sexual identity and religion.', u'In 1994, Intel sanctioned one of the earliest corporate Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual, and Transgender employee groups, and supports a Muslim employees group, a Jewish employees group, and a Bible-based Christian group.', u'Intel received a 100% rating on the first Corporate Equality Index released by the Human Rights Campaign in 2002.', u'It has maintained this rating in 2003 and 2004.', u'In addition, the company was named one of the 100 Best Companies for Working Mothers in 2005 by Working Mother magazine.', u'In January 2015, Intel announced the investment of $300 million over the next five years to enhance gender and racial diversity in their own company as well as the technology industry as a whole.', u'In February 2016, Intel released its Global Diversity & Inclusion 2015 Annual Report.', u'The male-female mix of US employees was reported as 75.2% men and 24.8% women.', u'For US employees in technical roles, the mix was reported as 79.8% male and 20.1% female.', u'NPR reports that Intel is facing a retention problem (particularly for African Americans), not just a pipeline problem.', u"=== Economic impact in Oregon in 2009 ===\nIn 2011, ECONorthwest conducted an economic impact analysis of Intel's economic contribution to the state of Oregon.", u'The report found that in 2009 "the total economic impacts attributed to Intel\'s operations, capital spending, contributions and taxes amounted to almost $14.6 billion in activity, including $4.3 billion in personal income and 59,990 jobs."', u'Through multiplier effects, every 10 Intel jobs supported, on average, was found to create 31 jobs in other sectors of the economy.', u'=== School funding in New Mexico in 1997 ===\nIn Rio Rancho, New Mexico, Intel is the leading employer.', u'In 1997, a community partnership between Sandoval County and Intel Corporation funded and built Rio Rancho High School.', u"=== Ultrabook fund (2011) ===\nIn 2011, Intel Capital announced a new fund to support startups working on technologies in line with the company's concept for next generation notebooks.", u'The company is setting aside a $300 million fund to be spent over the next three to four years in areas related to ultrabooks.', u'Intel announced the ultrabook concept at Computex in 2011.', u'The ultrabook is defined as a thin (less than 0.8 inches [~2 cm] thick) notebook that utilizes Intel processors and also incorporates tablet features such as a touch screen and long battery life.', u"At the Intel Developers Forum in 2011, four Taiwan ODMs showed prototype ultrabooks that used Intel's Ivy Bridge chips.", u'Intel plans to improve power consumption of its chips for ultrabooks, like new Ivy Bridge processors in 2013, which will only have 10W default thermal design power.', u"Intel's goal for Ultrabook's price is below $1000; however, according to two presidents from Acer and Compaq, this goal will not be achieved if Intel does not lower the price of its chips.", u"=== Advertising and brand management ===\n\n\n==== Intel Inside ====\nIntel has become one of the world's most recognizable computer brands following its long-running Intel Inside campaign.", u'The idea for "Intel Inside" came out of a meeting between Intel and one of the major computer resellers, MicroAge.', u"In the late 1980s, Intel's market share was being seriously eroded by upstart competitors such as Advanced Micro Devices (now AMD), Zilog, and others who had started to sell their less expensive microprocessors to computer manufacturers.", u'This was because, by using cheaper processors, manufacturers could make cheaper computers and gain more market share in an increasingly price-sensitive market.', u"In 1989, Intel's Dennis Carter visited MicroAge's headquarters in Tempe, Arizona, to meet with MicroAge's VP of Marketing, Ron Mion.", u'MicroAge had become one of the largest distributors of Compaq, IBM, HP, and others and thus was a primary \u2013  although indirect \u2013  driver of demand for microprocessors.', u'Intel wanted MicroAge to petition its computer suppliers to favor Intel chips.', u'However, Mion felt that the marketplace should decide which processors they wanted.', u"Intel's counterargument was that it would be too difficult to educate PC buyers on why Intel microprocessors were worth paying more for ... and they were right.", u"But Mion felt that the public didn't really need to fully understand why Intel chips were better, they just needed to feel they were better.", u'So Mion proposed a market test.', u'Intel would pay for a MicroAge billboard somewhere saying, "If you\'re buying a personal computer, make sure it has Intel inside."', u'In turn, MicroAge would put "Intel Inside" stickers on the Intel-based computers in their stores in that area.', u'To make the test easier to monitor, Mion decided to do the test in Boulder, Colorado, where it had a single store.', u'Virtually overnight, the sales of personal computers in that store dramatically shifted to Intel-based PCs.', u'Intel very quickly adopted "Intel Inside" as its primary branding and rolled it out worldwide.', u'As is often the case with computer lore, other tidbits have been combined to explain how things evolved.', u'"Intel Inside" has not escaped that tendency and there are other "explanations" that had been floating around.', u'Intel\'s branding campaign started with "The Computer Inside" tagline in 1990 in the US and Europe.', u'The Japan chapter of Intel proposed an "Intel in it" tagline and kicked off the Japanese campaign by hosting EKI-KON (meaning "Station Concert" in Japanese) at the Tokyo railway station dome on Christmas Day, December 25, 1990.', u'Several months later, "The Computer Inside" incorporated the Japan idea to become "Intel Inside" which eventually elevated to the worldwide branding campaign in 1991, by Intel marketing manager Dennis Carter.', u'The case study of the Inside Intel Inside was put together by Harvard Business School.', u'The five-note jingle was introduced in 1994 and by its tenth anniversary was being heard in 130 countries around the world.', u'The initial branding agency for the "Intel Inside" campaign was DahlinSmithWhite Advertising of Salt Lake City.', u'The Intel swirl logo was the work of DahlinSmithWhite art director Steve Grigg under the direction of Intel president and CEO Andy Grove.', u'The Intel Inside advertising campaign sought public brand loyalty and awareness of Intel processors in consumer computers.', u"Intel paid some of the advertiser's costs for an ad that used the Intel Inside logo and xylo-marimba jingle.", u'In 2008, Intel planned to shift the emphasis of its Intel Inside campaign from traditional media such as television and print to newer media such as the Internet.', u'Intel required that a minimum of 35% of the money it provided to the companies in its co-op program be used for online marketing.', u'The Intel 2010 annual financial report indicated that $1.8 billion (6% of the gross margin and nearly 16% of the total net income) was allocated to all advertising with Intel Inside being part of that.', u'==== Sonic logo ====\nThe famous D\u266d  D\u266d  G\u266d  D\u266d  A\u266d xylophone/xylomarimba jingle, sonic logo, tag, audio mnemonic was produced by Musikvergnuegen and written by Walter Werzowa, once a member of the Austrian 1980s sampling band Edelweiss.', u'The sonic Intel logo has undergone substantial changes in tone since the introduction of the Pentium III, Pentium 4, and Core processors, yet keeps the same jingle.', u'==== Processor naming strategy ====\nIn 2006, Intel expanded its promotion of open specification platforms beyond Centrino, to include the Viiv media center PC and the business desktop Intel vPro.', u'In mid-January 2006, Intel announced that they were dropping the long running Pentium name from their processors.', u'The Pentium name was first used to refer to the P5 core Intel processors and was done to comply with court rulings that prevent the trademarking of a string of numbers, so competitors could not just call their processor the same name, as had been done with the prior 386 and 486 processors (both of which had copies manufactured by IBM and AMD).', u'They phased out the Pentium names from mobile processors first, when the new Yonah chips, branded Core Solo and Core Duo, were released.', u'The desktop processors changed when the Core 2 line of processors were released.', u'By 2009, Intel was using a good-better-best strategy with Celeron being good, Pentium better, and the Intel Core family representing the best the company has to offer.', u'According to spokesman Bill Calder, Intel has maintained only the Celeron brand, the Atom brand for netbooks and the vPro lineup for businesses.', u"Since late 2009, Intel's mainstream processors have been called Celeron, Pentium, Core i3, Core i5, and Core i7, in order of performance from lowest to highest.", u'The first generation core products carry a 3 digit name, such as i5 750, and the second generation products carry a 4 digit name, such as the i5 2500.', u'In both cases, a K at the end of it shows that it is an unlocked processor, enabling additional overclocking abilities (for instance, 2500K).', u'vPro products will carry the Intel Core i7 vPro processor or the Intel Core i5 vPro processor name.', u'In October 2011, Intel started to sell its Core i7-2700K "Sandy Bridge" chip to customers worldwide.', u'Since 2010, "Centrino" is only being applied to Intel\'s WiMAX and Wi-Fi technologies.', u'=== Open source support ===\nIntel has a significant participation in the open source communities since 1999.', u'For example, in 2006 Intel released MIT-licensed X.org drivers for their integrated graphic cards of the i965 family of chipsets.', u'Intel released FreeBSD drivers for some networking cards, available under a BSD-compatible license, which were also ported to OpenBSD.', u'Binary firmware files for non-wireless Ethernet devices were also released under a BSD licence allowing free redistribution.', u'Intel ran the Moblin project until April 23, 2009, when they handed the project over to the Linux Foundation.', u'Intel also runs the LessWatts.org campaigns.', u'However, after the release of the wireless products called Intel Pro/Wireless 2100, 2200BG/2225BG/2915ABG and 3945ABG in 2005, Intel was criticized for not granting free redistribution rights for the firmware that must be included in the operating system for the wireless devices to operate.', u'As a result of this, Intel became a target of campaigns to allow free operating systems to include binary firmware on terms acceptable to the open source community.', u'Linspire-Linux creator Michael Robertson outlined the difficult position that Intel was in releasing to open source, as Intel did not want to upset their large customer Microsoft.', u'Theo de Raadt of OpenBSD also claimed that Intel is being "an Open Source fraud" after an Intel employee presented a distorted view of the situation at an open-source conference.', u'In spite of the significant negative attention Intel received as a result of the wireless dealings, the binary firmware still has not gained a license compatible with free software principles.', u'=== Declining PC sales ===\nDue to PC declining sales and the condition prediction will be worse which Intel support the chipsets, so in 2016 Intel cuts 12,000 jobs.', u'In 2014, Intel has also cut 5,000 jobs.', u'== Controversies ==\n\n\n=== Patent infringement litigation (2006\u20132007) ===\nIn October 2006, a Transmeta lawsuit was filed against Intel for patent infringement on computer architecture and power efficiency technologies.', u'The lawsuit was settled in October 2007, with Intel agreeing to pay US$150 million initially and US$20 million per year for the next five years.', u'Both companies agreed to drop lawsuits against each other, while Intel was granted a perpetual non-exclusive license to use current and future patented Transmeta technologies in its chips for 10 years.', u"=== Anti-competitive allegations and litigation (2005\u20132009) ===\n\nIn September 2005, Intel filed a response to an AMD lawsuit, disputing AMD's claims, and claiming that Intel's business practices are fair and lawful.", u"In a rebuttal, Intel deconstructed AMD's offensive strategy and argued that AMD struggled largely as a result of its own bad business decisions, including underinvestment in essential manufacturing capacity and excessive reliance on contracting out chip foundries.", u"Legal analysts predicted the lawsuit would drag on for a number of years, since Intel's initial response indicated its unwillingness to settle with AMD.", u'In 2008 a court date was finally set, but in 2009, Intel settled with a $1.25 billion payout to AMD (see below).', u'On November 4, 2009, New York\'s attorney general filed an antitrust lawsuit against Intel Corp, claiming the company used "illegal threats and collusion" to dominate the market for computer microprocessors.', u'On November 12, 2009, AMD agreed to drop the antitrust lawsuit against Intel in exchange for $1.25 billion.', u'A joint press release published by the two chip makers stated "While the relationship between the two companies has been difficult in the past, this agreement ends the legal disputes and enables the companies to focus all of our efforts on product innovation and development."', u'An antitrust lawsuit and a class-action suit relating to cold calling employees of other companies has been settled.', u'==== Allegations by Japan Fair Trade Commission (2005) ====\nIn 2005, the local Fair Trade Commission found that Intel violated the Japanese Antimonopoly Act.', u'The commission ordered Intel to eliminate discounts that had discriminated against AMD.', u'To avoid a trial, Intel agreed to comply with the order.', u'==== Allegations by the European Union (2007\u20132008) ====\nIn July 2007, the European Commission accused Intel of anti-competitive practices, mostly against AMD.', u'The allegations, going back to 2003, include giving preferential prices to computer makers buying most or all of their chips from Intel, paying computer makers to delay or cancel the launch of products using AMD chips, and providing chips at below standard cost to governments and educational institutions.', u'Intel responded that the allegations were unfounded and instead qualified its market behavior as consumer-friendly.', u'General counsel Bruce Sewell responded that the Commission had misunderstood some factual assumptions as to pricing and manufacturing costs.', u'In February 2008, Intel stated that its office in Munich had been raided by European Union regulators.', u'Intel reported that it was cooperating with investigators.', u'Intel faced a fine of up to 10% of its annual revenue, if found guilty of stifling competition.', u'AMD subsequently launched a website promoting these allegations.', u'In June 2008, the EU filed new charges against Intel.', u'In May 2009, the EU found that Intel had engaged in anti-competitive practices and subsequently fined Intel \u20ac1.06 billion (US$1.44 billion), a record amount.', u'Intel was found to have paid companies, including Acer, Dell, HP, Lenovo and NEC, to exclusively use Intel chips in their products, and therefore harmed other companies including AMD.', u'The European Commission said that Intel had deliberately acted to keep competitors out of the computer chip market and in doing so had made a "serious and sustained violation of the EU\'s antitrust rules".', u'In addition to the fine, Intel was ordered by the Commission to immediately cease all illegal practices.', u"Intel has stated that they will appeal against the Commission's verdict.", u'In June 2014, the General Court, which sits below the European Court of Justice, rejected the appeal.', u'==== Allegations by regulators in South Korea (2007) ====\nIn September 2007, South Korean regulators accused Intel of breaking antitrust law.', u"The investigation began in February 2006, when officials raided Intel's South Korean offices.", u'The company risked a penalty of up to 3% of its annual sales, if found guilty.', u'In June 2008, the Fair Trade Commission ordered Intel to pay a fine of US$25.5 million for taking advantage of its dominant position to offer incentives to major Korean PC manufacturers on the condition of not buying products from AMD.', u'==== Allegations by regulators in the United States (2008\u20132010) ====\nNew York started an investigation of Intel in January 2008 on whether the company violated antitrust laws in pricing and sales of its microprocessors.', u'In June 2008, the Federal Trade Commission also began an antitrust investigation of the case.', u'In December 2009, the FTC announced it would initiate an administrative proceeding against Intel in September 2010.', u'In November 2009, following a two-year investigation, New York Attorney General Andrew Cuomo sued Intel, accusing them of bribery and coercion, claiming that Intel bribed computer makers to buy more of their chips than those of their rivals, and threatened to withdraw these payments if the computer makers were perceived as working too closely with its competitors.', u'Intel has denied these claims.', u'On July 22, 2010, Dell agreed to a settlement with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to pay $100M in penalties resulting from charges that Dell did not accurately disclose accounting information to investors.', u'In particular, the SEC charged that from 2002 to 2006, Dell had an agreement with Intel to receive rebates in exchange for not using chips manufactured by AMD.', u'These substantial rebates were not disclosed to investors, but were used to help meet investor expectations regarding the company\'s financial performance; "These exclusivity payments grew from 10 percent of Dell\'s operating income in FY 2003 to 38 percent in FY 2006, and peaked at 76 percent in the first quarter of FY 2007.".', u"Dell eventually did adopt AMD as a secondary supplier in 2006, and Intel subsequently stopped their rebates, causing Dell's financial performance to fall.", u'=== Corporate responsibility record ===\nIntel has been accused by some residents of Rio Rancho, New Mexico of allowing VOCs to be released in excess of their pollution permit.', u'One resident claimed that a release of 1.4 tons of carbon tetrachloride was measured from one acid scrubber during the fourth quarter of 2003 but an emission factor allowed Intel to report no carbon tetrachloride emissions for all of 2003.', u'Another resident alleges that Intel was responsible for the release of other VOCs from their Rio Rancho site and that a necropsy of lung tissue from two deceased dogs in the area indicated trace amounts of toluene, hexane, ethylbenzene, and xylene isomers, all of which are solvents used in industrial settings but also commonly found in gasoline, retail paint thinners and retail solvents.', u"During a sub-committee meeting of the New Mexico Environment Improvement Board, a resident claimed that Intel's own reports documented more than 1,580 pounds (720 kg) of VOCs were released in June and July 2006.", u"Intel's environmental performance is published annually in their corporate responsibility report.", u'In its 2012 rankings on the progress of consumer electronics companies relating to conflict minerals, the Enough Project rated Intel the best of 24 companies, calling it a "Pioneer of progress".', u"In 2014, chief executive Brian Krzanich urged the rest of the industry to follow Intel's lead by also shunning conflict minerals.", u'=== Age discrimination complaints ===\nIntel has faced complaints of age discrimination in firing and layoffs.', u'Intel was sued in 1993 by nine former employees, over allegations that they were laid off because they were over the age of 40.', u'A group called FACE Intel (Former and Current Employees of Intel) claims that Intel weeds out older employees.', u'FACE Intel claims that more than 90 percent of people who have been laid off or fired from Intel are over the age of 40.', u'Upside magazine requested data from Intel breaking out its hiring and firing by age, but the company declined to provide any.', u"Intel has denied that age plays any role in Intel's employment practices.", u'FACE Intel was founded by Ken Hamidi, who was fired from Intel in 1995 at the age of 47.', u"Hamidi was blocked in a 1999 court decision from using Intel's email system to distribute criticism of the company to employees, which overturned in 2003 in Intel Corp. v. Hamidi.", u'=== Tax dispute in India ===\nIn August 2016, Indian officials of the Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP) blocked the gates of the Intel campus in Bengaluru with garbage trucks for evading payment of property taxes between 2007 and 2008 to the tune of Rs 34 crores.', u'As an interim measure the court had directed Intel to pay Rs 17 crore, which is half the amount the company owed, by July 25, 2016.', u'However, after all such warnings were repeatedly ignored by the IT giant, the BBMP resorted to a very creative tactic and decided to block the gates of the IT major with garbage trucks.', u"According to the Joint Commissioner of the Mahadevapura zone, BBMP Muniveerappa, in-spite of the company's premises being centrally air conditioned, it had been calculating its taxes on the basis that it was not an air conditioned office.", u'Intel has sought time of four weeks to pay their dues.', u'== See also ==\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== External links ==\nOfficial website\n\nIntel at DMOZ'], 'year': '1968-07-18', 'title': 'Intel is incorporated.'}
{'sentences': [u"The Artists' Union of the USSR (Russian: \u0421\u043e\u044e\u0437 \u0445\u0443\u0434\u043e\u0436\u043d\u0438\u043a\u043e\u0432 \u0421\u0421\u0421\u0420, translit.", u'Soyuz khudozhnikov SSSR) was a creative union of the Soviet artists and art critics embracing the Republics of the Soviet Union.', u'The Union started in 1932 to supersede the AKhRR.', u'The integral Union was instituted in 1957.', u'By January 1, 1976 the Union included 14,538 members.', u'In was officially disbanded at its 8th Congress in January 1992 after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, with its rights distributed over the corresponding unions in the post-Soviet states.', u"== History ==\nPrior to the Artists' Union of the USSR, there existed the Union of Soviet Artists (\u0421\u043e\u044e\u0437 \u0441\u043e\u0432\u0435\u0442\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0445 \u0445\u0443\u0434\u043e\u0436\u043d\u0438\u043a\u043e\u0432, Soyuz sovetskikh khudozhnikov), which was founded at Moscow in spring 1930 and included Moscow and Leningrad artists along with former members of the AKhRR.", u'The first exhibition of the Union of Soviet Artists was held on 15 April 1931 in Moscow at the exhibition hall of the co-operative society Khudozhnik.', u'The Union of Soviet Artists ceased to exist in 1932 after the government regulation.', u'Following the resolution "On the Restructuring of Literary and Artistic Organizations" by the Central Committee of the Communist Party (Bolsheviks) on 23 April 1932, unions of Soviet artists were established in the Union and autonomous republics, in krais, in oblasts, and in cities to supersede previous organizations.', u"The first Congress of the Artists' Union of the USSR was convened in February\u2013March 1957.", u"== Chairmen of the Artists' Union of the USSR ==\nKonstantin Yuon - {'sentences': [u'William Sterling Walker (October 29, 1931 \u2013 April 10, 2010) was a baritone with the Metropolitan Opera (1962\u20131980) whose singing career included performances at the White House, at Carnegie Hall and other concert venues across North America and Europe, and some 60 appearances on The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson.', u'From 1991-2002, he produced opera as General Director of Fort Worth Opera in Fort Worth, Texas.', u'== Early life ==\nWilliam Walker was born in Waco, Texas and moved with his family to Fort Worth at the age of 6, where his father eventually went to work for Consolidated Vultee, a predecessor of General Dynamics.', u'Known as "Bill" to his family and friends, Walker began singing professionally at the age of 12 but secretly yearned to play baseball.', u"After watching him strike out four times one night at a high school game, Walker's father suggested that perhaps his son should think more seriously about being a singer.", u'In 1949, upon graduation from Arlington Heights High School, Walker was awarded a vocal scholarship to Texas Christian University.', u'His studies were interrupted when he was drafted into the U.S. Army and sent to serve in the Korean War.', u'During his time in Korea, he was awarded the Bronze Star for meritorious service.', u"Upon his honorable discharge, Walker returned to Fort Worth, completed his bachelor's in voice and graduated from Texas Christian University in 1956.", u'In 1957, he married the former Marci Martin and they moved to New York City.', u'== Singing career ==\nIn 1960, Walker made his Broadway debut as Tattoo in Wildcat, a musical comedy by N. Richard Nash, Cy Coleman, and Carolyn Leigh, starring Lucille Ball, directed by Herbert Ross and choreographed by Michael Kidd.', u'He was listed in the program as "Bill Walker".', u'A frequent performer in summer stock during the 1960s, Walker sang in many performances with the St. Louis Municipal Opera, the Kansas City Starlight Theatre, and the Pittsburgh Civic Light Opera in such works as Blossom Time, The Desert Song, Damn Yankees, and Carousel.', u'In 1962, Walker was a finalist in the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions and was offered a contract to join the Metropolitan Opera.', u'His first roles at the Met were small ones, but subsequent exposure on television shows such as The Bell Telephone Hour, The Voice of Firestone, and most notably The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson\u2014where Walker appeared some 60 times \u2013 led to a higher profile in his opera career.', u'During his 18 seasons there, Walker gave more than 360 performances at the Met and sang the role of Marcello in La boh\xe8me more than 30 times.', u'In 1965, Walker was featured in two new productions at the Met.', u'He was selected to sing the role of Valentin in Faust co-starring Nicolai Gedda, Gabriella Tucci and Cesare Siepi, directed by Jean-Louis Barrault and conducted by Georges Pr\xeatre.', u"He also sang the role of Prince Yeletsky in a new English-language production of Tchaikovsky's The Queen of Spades, conducted by Thomas Schippers.", u'In 1972, Walker repeated the role in the first production of The Queen of Spades ever presented in its original Russian at the Met.', u'In 1975 when the Met toured Japan for the first time, Walker sang the role of Marcello in La boh\xe8me with Franco Corelli and Dorothy Kirsten.', u'The following season, Walker stepped in for an ailing colleague and sang the role of Germont in La traviata for the first time at the Met, a role he had already sung at the Santa Fe Opera and in other regional productions.', u'Critic Harold C. Schonberg wrote in The New York Times, "the best singing of the night came from Mr. Walker," and Time magazine called his Germont "splendidly sung."', u"Other roles at the Met included Figaro in The Barber of Seville, Papageno in The Magic Flute, Lescaut in Manon Lescaut, Sharpless in Madama Butterfly, Ford in Falstaff, Escamillo in Carmen, the High Priest in Samson et Dalila, Peter in Hansel und Gretel, Schaunard in La boh\xe8me, Count Di Luna in Il trovatore, The Herald in Lohengrin, Michele in Il tabarro, Silvio in Pagliacci, Dr. Malatesta in Don Pasquale, and Enrico in Lucia di Lammermoor\nWalker's career included performances at the White House: In 1967 during the Johnson administration he was the principal entertainer at the White House Correspondents' Dinner.", u'During the Carter administration, he sang at a White House state dinner honoring Helmut Schmidt, Chancellor of West Germany.', u'In 1976, under the auspices of the U.S. State department, Walker was sent abroad to perform as a representative of the United States.', u'In addition to recitals in Reykjav\xedk, Iceland and at the Royal Swedish Opera in Stockholm, Walker sang Germont in La traviata and Amonasro in Aida in both Warsaw and \u0141\xf3d\u017a, in Poland.', u'From 1969 to 1976, Walker gave more than 250 solo recitals in the United States and Canada, performing classical operatic arias, art songs and American musical show stoppers, most memorably "Soliloquy" from Carousel and "Surrey With The Fringe On Top" from Oklahoma!.', u'With a technique considered innovative at the time, Walker addressed his recital audiences directly from the stage, interspersing his songs with funny, often self-deprecating stories, making him a more accessible performer to his audiences then the stereotypically aloof classical artist.', u'Walker was a frequent soloist with many great American orchestras, including the Cleveland Orchestra, the New York Philharmonic, and the Philadelphia Orchestra.', u"In the '70s, Walker appeared twice at Carnegie Hall as the baritone soloist in performances of Mahler's 8th Symphony with the Chicago Symphony, conducted by Sir Georg Solti.", u'Walker retired from singing in 1982.', u'In 1980, he was named the Hearndon Distinguished Visiting Professor of Music at Texas Christian University and taught master classes in performance for several years.', u'He also taught master classes as the Carol Kyle Distinguished Visiting Professor of Music at Lamar University in Beaumont, Texas from 1980 to 1984.', u'== General Director, Fort Worth Opera ==\nIn 1991, Walker returned to his hometown of Fort Worth to accept the position of General Director of the Fort Worth Opera, a small regional company "with a low budget, low profile and low community confidence."', u'Even when he was still at the Met and working with world-class stage directors and designers, Walker believed that great singing was what made great opera.', u'"\'That\'s what opera\'s all about, you know: let the opera singer sing and opera will flourish.\'"', u'When he began to produce opera in Fort Worth, Walker capitalized on this philosophy of "a singer\'s opera" by recognizing the opportunity for Fort Worth Opera to be a showcase for up-and-coming vocal talent.', u'Focusing mostly on the standard Italian and French repertory, Walker led the company through "seven seasons of rising artistry and record audiences," ultimately increasing season subscriptions, wiping out deficits, and bolstering the company\'s annual budget and its endowment to what were then record levels.', u"During Walker's tenure, Fort Worth Opera joined other major Fort Worth performing arts organizations (Fort Worth Symphony, Texas Ballet Theater, the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition and Cliburn Concerts series) when they moved into their permanent home at Bass Performance Hall.", u'Tickets for the 1998-1999 inaugural season of Fort Worth Opera at Bass Performance Hall were sold out.', u"In 1998, despite the successes achieved under Walker's tenure, the executive committee of the larger Fort Worth Opera board of directors attempted to force Walker to retire, but their decision was overridden by a vote of the full board.", u'"I\'m the happiest man in America," Walker said at the time.', u'"This is the job I prepared for my whole life.', u'I can\'t wait to get started again."', u"Walker's contract was extended until 2002, when he retired and was named Executive Director Emeritus by the Fort Worth Opera board of directors.", u'== Recordings ==\nCommercially available audio and video recordings of Walker are rare.', u'=== Audio ===\nCole Porter: A Remembrance RCA/NBC, rare recording from a Today Show broadcast in 1965\nThe Texas Christian University, Fort Worth, Texas.', u'== Personal life ==\nIn 2007, Walker and his wife, Marci, celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary.', u'The couple had four children and three grandchildren.', u'One of his sons, popularly known by the pseudonym "Wammo", was a co-founder, songwriter and performer with the Asylum Street Spankers.', u'== References ==\n\n\n== External links
