{'sentences': [u'The United States Customs Service was an agency of the U.S. federal government that collected import tariffs and performed other selected border security duties.', u'In March 2003, as a result of the homeland security reorganization, most of the U.S. Customs Service was merged with the border elements of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, including the entire U.S. Border Patrol and former INS inspectors, together with border agriculture inspectors, to form U.S. Customs and Border Protection, a single, unified border agency for the U.S.', u'The investigative office of U.S. Customs was split off and merged with the INS investigative office and the INS interior detention and removal office to form Immigration and Customs Enforcement, which, among other things, is responsible for interior immigration enforcement.', u'The United States Customs Service had three major missions: collecting tariff revenue, protecting the U.S. economy from smuggling and illegal goods, and processing people and goods at ports of entry.', u'== History ==\nResponding to the urgent need for revenue following the American Revolutionary War, the First United States Congress passed and President George Washington signed the Tariff Act of July 4, 1789, which authorized the collection of duties on imported goods.', u'Four weeks later, on July 31, the fifth act of Congress established the United States Customs Service and its ports of entry.', u'As part of this new government agency, a new role was created for government officials which was known as "Customs Collector".', u'In this role, one person would have responsibility to supervise the collection of custom duties in a particular city or region.', u"For over 100 years after its birth, the U.S. Customs Service was the primary source of funds for the entire government, and paid for the country's early growth and infrastructure.", u"Purchases include the Louisiana and Oregon territories; Florida and Alaska; funding the National Road and the Transcontinental Railroad; building many of the nation's lighthouses; the U.S. Military and Naval academies, and Washington, D.C.", u'The flag of the Customs Service was designed in 1799 by Secretary of the Treasury Oliver Wolcott, Jr. and consists of 16 vertical red and white stripes with a coat of arms depicted in blue on the white canton.', u'The original design had the Customs Service seal that was an eagle with three arrows in his left talon, an olive branch in his right and surrounded by an arc of 13 stars.', u'In 1951, this was changed to the eagle depicted on the Great Seal of the United States.', u'Its actual name is the Revenue Ensign, as it was flown by ships of the Revenue Cutter Service, later the Coast Guard, and at customs houses.', u'In 1910, President William Howard Taft issued an order to add an emblem to the flag flown by ships from the one flown on land at customs houses.', u'The version with the badge continues to be flown by Coast Guard vessels.', u'Until 2003, the land version was flown at all United States ports of entry.', u'The U.S. Customs Service employed a number of federal law enforcement officers throughout the 19th and 20th centuries.', u'Customs Special Agents investigated smuggling and other violations of customs, narcotics and revenue laws.', u'Customs Inspectors were uniformed officers at airports, seaports and land border ports of entry who inspected people and vehicles entering the U.S. for contraband and dutiable merchandise.', u'Customs Patrol Officers conducted uniformed and plainclothes patrol of the borders on land, sea and air to deter smuggling and apprehend smugglers.', u'In the 20th century, as international trade and travel increased dramatically, the Customs Service transitioned from an administrative bureau to a federal law enforcement agency.', u'Inspectors still inspected goods and took customs declarations from travelers at ports of entry, but Customs Special Agents used modern police methods\u2014often in concert with allied agencies, such as the Federal Bureau of Investigation, U.S.', u'Postal Inspection Service, U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service and U.S. Border Patrol\u2014to investigate cases often far from international airports, bridges and land crossings.', u'With the passage of the Homeland Security Act, the U.S. Customs Service passed from under jurisdiction of the Treasury Department to the Department of Homeland Security.', u'On March 1, 2003, parts of the U.S. Customs Service combined with the Inspections Program of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, Plant Protection and Quarantine from USDA, and the Border Patrol of the Immigration and Naturalization Service to form U.S. Customs and Border Protection.', u'The Federal Protective Service, along with the investigative arms of the U.S. Customs Service and the Immigration and Naturalization Service, combined to form U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement.', u'== Examples of illegal items ==\nAll Cuban products without a specific license for their importation, such as cigars.', u'Child pornography\nCounterfeit merchandise (i.e.', u'cellphones, perfume and other consumer products)\nExcessive quantities of textiles\nIllegally imported Motor Vehicles\nItems violating intellectual property rights\nIllegal drugs\nStolen property\nTobacco products over allowable limits\nUndeclared firearms and weapons\nUndeclared liquor over allowable limits\nUnreported money or monetary instruments over $10,000\nUnscreened fruits and meats\n\n\n== Commissioners ==\nThis table lists all Commissioners of Customs, their dates of service, and under which administration they served.', u'== See also ==\nComputer Assisted Passenger Prescreening System\nImmigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE)\nU.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP)\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== External links ==\nUnited States Customs Service (Archive)\nUnited States Customs & Border Protection\nProposed and finalized federal regulations from the United States Customs Service'], 'year': '1789-08-01', 'title': 'US Customs begins enforcing Tariff Act'}
{'sentences': [u'A peace treaty is an agreement between two or more hostile parties, usually countries or governments, which formally ends a state of war between the parties.', u'It is different from an armistice, which is an agreement to stop hostilities, or a surrender, in which an army agrees to give up arms, or a ceasefire or truce in which the parties may agree to temporarily or permanently stop fighting.', u"== Elements of treaties ==\nA treaty's content usually depends on the nature of the conflict being concluded.", u'In the case of large conflicts between numerous parties there may be one international treaty covering all issues or separate treaties signed between each party.', u'There are many possible issues which may be included in a peace treaty.', u'Some of these may be:\nFormal designation of borders.', u'Processes for resolving future disputes\nAccess to and apportioning of resources\nStatus of refugees\nStatus of POW\nSettling of existing debts\nDefining of unjust behavior\nThe re-application of existing treaties\nIn modern times certain intractable conflict situations may first be brought to a ceasefire and are then dealt with via a peace process where a number of discrete steps are taken on each side to eventually reach the mutually desired goal of peace and the signing of a treaty.', u'A peace treaty also is often not used to end a civil war, especially in cases of a failed secession, as it implies mutual recognition of statehood.', u'In cases such as the American Civil War, it usually ends when the armies of the losing side surrender and the government collapse.', u'By contrast, a successful secession or declaration of independence is often formalized by means of a peace treaty.', u'Treaties are often ratified in territories deemed neutral in the previous  conflict and delegates from these neutral territories act as witnesses to the signatories.', u'== Role of the United Nations ==\nSince its founding after World War II the United Nations has sought to act as a forum for resolution in matters of international conflict.', u'A number of international treaties and obligations are involved in which member states seek to limit and control behavior during wartime.', u'This has meant that formal declarations of war are frequently not undertaken.', u'== Historic peace treaties ==\n\n\n=== Ancient history ===\n\nProbably the earliest recorded peace treaty, although rarely mentioned or remembered, was between the Hittite Empire and the Hayasa-Azzi confederation, circa 1350 BC.', u'More famously, one of the earliest recorded peace treaties was concluded between the Hittite and Egyptian empires after the ca.1274 BC Battle of Kadesh (see Egyptian-Hittite peace treaty).', u'The battle took place in what is modern-day Syria, the entire Levant being at that time contested between the two empires.', u'After an extremely costly four-day battle, in which neither side gained a substantial advantage, both sides claimed victory.', u'The lack of resolution led to further conflict between Egypt and the Hittites, with Ramesses II capturing the city of Kadesh and Amurru in his 8th year as king.', u'However, the prospect of further protracted conflict between the two states eventually persuaded both their rulers, Hatusili\u0161 III and Ramesses, to end their dispute and sign a peace treaty.', u'Neither side could afford the possibility of a longer conflict since they were threatened by other enemies: Egypt was faced with the task of defending her long western border with Libya against the incursion of Libyan tribesmen by building a chain of fortresses stretching from Mersa Matruh to Rakotis, while the Hittites faced a more formidable threat in the form of the Assyrian Empire, which "had conquered Hanigalbat, the heartland of Mitanni, between the Tigris and the Euphrates" rivers that had previously been a Hittite vassal state.', u'The peace treaty was recorded in two versions, one in Egyptian hieroglyphs, and the other in Akkadian using cuneiform script; fortunately, both versions survive.', u'Such dual-language recording is common to many subsequent treaties.', u'This treaty differs from others, however, in that the two language versions are worded differently.', u'Although the majority of the text is identical, the Hittite version claims that the Egyptians came suing for peace, while the Egyptian version claims the reverse.', u'The treaty was given to the Egyptians in the form of a silver plaque, and this "pocket-book" version was taken back to Egypt and carved into the Temple of Karnak.', u"The Treaty was concluded between Ramesses II and Hatusili\u0161 III in Year 21 of Ramesses' reign (c.1258 BC).", u'Its eighteen articles call for peace between Egypt and Hatti and then proceed to maintain that their respective gods also demand peace.', u"It contains many elements found in more modern treaties, although it is perhaps more far-reaching than later treaties' simple declaration of the end of hostilities.", u'It also contains a mutual-assistance pact in the event that one of the empires should be attacked by a third party, or in the event of internal strife.', u'There are articles pertaining to the forced repatriation of refugees and provisions that they should not be harmed; this might be thought of as the first extradition treaty.', u'There are also threats of retribution, should the treaty be broken.', u'This treaty is considered of such importance in the field of international relations that a reproduction of it hangs in the United Nations headquarters.', u"=== Modern history ===\nFamous examples include the Treaty of Paris (1815), signed after Napoleon's defeat at the Battle of Waterloo, and the Treaty of Versailles, formally ending the First World War conflict between Germany and the Western Allies.", u'This is held to have ended World War I completely, but in fact that did not happen until the Allies concluded peace with the Ottoman Empire in 1920.', u'The Versailles treaty is possibly the most notorious of peace treaties, in that it is "blamed" by some historians for the rise of National Socialism in Germany and the eventual outbreak of the Second World War.', u'The costly reparations that Germany was forced to pay the victors, the fact that Germany had to accept sole responsibility for starting the war, and the harsh restrictions on German rearmament were all listed in the treaty and caused massive resentment in Germany.', u'Whether the Treaty of Versailles can be blamed for starting another war or not, it shows the difficulties involved in making peace.', u'It might be noted that no such conflict resulted from the more punitive settlement with the Ottomans.', u'Another famous example would be the series of peace treaties known as the Peace of Westphalia.', u'It initiated modern diplomacy, involving the modern system of nation-states.', u'Subsequent wars were no longer over religion, but rather revolved around issues of state.', u'This allowed Catholic and Protestant powers to ally, leading to a number of major realignments.', u'The Korean War is an example of a war which was stopped by the Korean Armistice Agreement but never closed with a peace treaty.', u'== See also ==\nDiplomacy\nList of treaties\nPact\nPeace\nSeparate peace\nUppsala Conflict Data Program provides a dataset of all comprehensive agreements, partial agreements or peace process agreements between actors in armed conflict between 1975-2007.', u"== References ==\n\n\n== External links {'sentences': [u'The Soviet Union (Russian: \u0421\u043e\u0432\u0435\u0301\u0442\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0439 \u0421\u043e\u044e\u0301\u0437, tr.', u"Sovetskiy Soyuz; IPA: [s\u0250'v\u02b2etsk\u02b2\u026aj s\u0250\u02c8j\u0289s]), officially the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (Russian: \u0421\u043e\u044e\u0301\u0437 \u0421\u043e\u0432\u0435\u0301\u0442\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0445 \u0421\u043e\u0446\u0438\u0430\u043b\u0438\u0441\u0442\u0438\u0301\u0447\u0435\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0445 \u0420\u0435\u0441\u043f\u0443\u0301\u0431\u043b\u0438\u043a, tr.", u'Soyuz Sovetskikh Sotsialisticheskikh Respublik; IPA: [s\u0250\u02c8jus s\u0250\u02c8v\u02b2\u025btsk\u02b2\u026ax s\u0259ts\u0268\u0259l\u02b2\u026as\u02c8t\u02b2it\u0255\u026ask\u02b2\u026ax r\u02b2\u026a\u02c8spubl\u02b2\u026ak]), abbreviated to USSR (Russian: \u0421\u0421\u0421\u0420, tr.', u'SSSR), was a socialist state on the Eurasian continent that existed from 1922 to 1991.', u'A union of multiple subnational Soviet republics, its government and economy were highly centralized.', u'The Soviet Union was a one-party federation, governed by the Communist Party with Moscow as its capital.', u'The Soviet Union had its roots in the October Revolution of 1917, when the Bolsheviks, led by Vladimir Lenin, overthrew the provisional government that had replaced the Tsar.', u'They established the Russian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic (renamed Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic in 1936), beginning a civil war between the revolutionary "Reds" and the counter-revolutionary "Whites."', u'The Red Army entered several territories of the former Russian Empire and helped local Communists take power through soviets, which nominally acted on behalf of workers and peasants.', u'In 1922, the Communists were victorious, forming the Soviet Union with the unification of the Russian, Transcaucasian, Ukrainian, and Byelorussian republics.', u"Following Lenin's death in 1924, a troika and a brief power struggle, Joseph Stalin came to power in the mid-1920s.", u'Stalin suppressed all political opposition to his rule, committed the state ideology to Marxism\u2013Leninism (which he created), and initiated a centrally planned command economy.', u'As a result, the country underwent a period of rapid industrialization and collectivization which laid the foundation for its victory in World War II and post-war dominance of Eastern Europe.', u'Stalin also fomented political paranoia, and conducted the Great Purge to remove opponents of his from the Communist Party through the mass arbitrary arrest of many people (military leaders, Communist Party members, and ordinary citizens alike) who were then sent to correctional labor camps or sentenced to death.', u'Shortly before World War II, Stalin signed the non-aggression pact with Nazi Germany, after which the two countries invaded Poland in September 1939.', u'In June 1941 the Germans invaded, opening the largest and bloodiest theater of war in history.', u'Soviet war casualties accounted for the highest proportion of the conflict in the cost of acquiring the upper hand over Axis forces at intense battles such as Stalingrad.', u'Soviet forces eventually captured Berlin in 1945.', u'The territory overtaken by the Red Army became satellite states of the Eastern Bloc.', u'The Cold War emerged by 1947 as the Soviet bloc confronted the Western states that united in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in 1949.', u'Following Stalin\'s death in 1953, a period of political and economic liberalization, known as "de-Stalinization" and "Khrushchev\'s Thaw", occurred under the leadership of Nikita Khrushchev.', u'The country developed rapidly, as millions of peasants were moved into industrialized cities.', u'The USSR took an early lead in the Space Race with the first ever satellite and the first human spaceflight.', u'In the 1970s, there was a brief d\xe9tente of relations with the United States, but tensions resumed when the Soviet Union deployed troops in Afghanistan in 1979.', u'The war drained economic resources and was matched by an escalation of American military aid to Mujahideen fighters.', u'In the mid-1980s, the last Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, sought to further reform and liberalize the economy through his policies of glasnost and perestroika.', u'The goal was to preserve the Communist Party while reversing economic stagnation.', u'The Cold War ended during his tenure, and in 1989 Soviet satellite countries in Eastern Europe overthrew their respective communist regimes.', u'This led to the rise of strong nationalist and separatist movements inside the USSR as well.', u'Central authorities initiated a referendum\u2014boycotted by the Baltic republics, Armenia, Georgia, and Moldova\u2014which resulted in the majority of participating citizens voting in favor of preserving the Union as a renewed federation.', u"In August 1991, a coup d'\xe9tat was attempted by Communist Party hardliners.", u'It failed, with Russian President Boris Yeltsin playing a high-profile role in facing down the coup, resulting in the banning of the Communist Party.', u'On 25 December 1991, Gorbachev resigned and the remaining twelve constituent republics emerged from the dissolution of the Soviet Union as independent post-Soviet states.', u"The Russian Federation (formerly the Russian SFSR) assumed the Soviet Union's rights and obligations and has emerged as the recognized primary legal successor of the Soviet Union.", u'== Name ==\n\nThe word \u201cSoviet\u201d is derived from a Russian word meaning council, assembly, advice, harmony, concord, and all ultimately deriving from the Proto-Slavic verbal stem of *v\u011bt-iti "to inform", related to Slavic "v\u011bst" ("news"), English "wise", the root in "ad-vis-or" (which came to English through French), or the Dutch "weten" (to know; cf.', u'"wetenschap" = science).', u'The word "sovietnik" means councillor.', u'A number of organizations in Russian history were called "council" (Russian: \u0441\u043e\u0432\u0435\u0301\u0442).', u'For example, in the Russian Empire, the State Council, which functioned from 1810 to 1917, was referred to as a Council of Ministers after the revolt of 1905.', u'From the beginning, the Soviet Union was the called the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics from its founding, although all the republics began as Socialist Soviet and did not change to the other order until 1936.', u'In addition, in the national languages of several republics the word "Council/Conciliar" in the respective language was only quite late changed to an adaptation of the Russian "Soviet" - and never in others, e.g., Ukraine.', u'The names of the Soviet Union are as follows in several languages of its 15 constituent republics:\nRussian: \u0421\u043e\u044e\u0437 \u0421\u043e\u0432\u0435\u0442\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0445
