Hawai\u02bbi (800\u20131778) ===\n\nBased on archaeological evidence, the earliest habitation of the Hawaiian Islands dates to around 300 CE, probably by Polynesian settlers from the Marquesas Islands.', u'A second wave of migration from Raiatea and Bora Bora took place in the 11th century.', u'The date of the human discovery and habitation of the Hawaiian Islands is the subject of academic debate.', u'Some archaeologists and historians believe there was an early settlement from the Marquesas.', u'They think it was a later wave of immigrants from Tahiti around 1000 CE who introduced a new line of high chiefs, the kapu system, the practice of human sacrifice, and the building of heiau.', u'This later immigration is detailed in Hawaiian mythology (mo\u02bbolelo) about Pa\u02bbao.', u'Other authors say there is no archaeological or linguistic evidence for a later influx of Tahitian settlers and that Pa\u02bbao must be regarded as a myth.', u'The history of the islands is marked by a slow, steady growth in population and the size of the chiefdoms, which grew to encompass whole islands.', u'Local chiefs, called ali\u02bbi, ruled their settlements, and launched wars to extend their influence and defend their communities from predatory rivals.', u'Ancient Hawaii was a caste-based society, much like that of Hindus in India.', u"=== European arrival ===\n\nIt is possible that Spanish explorers arrived in the Hawaiian Islands in the 16th century\u2014200 years before Captain James Cook's first documented visit in 1778.", u'Ruy L\xf3pez de Villalobos commanded a fleet of six ships that left Acapulco in 1542 bound for the Philippines with a Spanish sailor named Juan Gaetano aboard as pilot.', u"Depending on the interpretation, Gaetano's reports describe an encounter with either Hawai\u02bbi or the Marshall Islands.", u"If de Villalobos' crew spotted Hawai\u02bbi, Gaetano would be considered the first European to see the islands.", u'Some scholars have dismissed these claims due to a lack of credibility.', u'Spanish archives contain a chart that depicts islands at the same latitude as Hawai\u02bbi but with a longitude ten degrees east of the islands.', u'In this manuscript, the island of Maui is named La Desgraciada (The Unfortunate Island), and what appears to be Hawai\u02bbi Island is named La Mesa (The Table).', u'Islands resembling Kahoolawe, Lanai, and Molokai are named Los Monjes (The Monks).', u'For two-and-a-half centuries, Spanish galleons crossed the Pacific from Mexico along a route that passed south of Hawai\u02bbi on their way to Manila.', u'The exact route was kept secret to protect the Spanish trade monopoly against competing powers.', u'The 1778 arrival of British explorer James Cook was the first documented contact by a European explorer with Hawaii.', u'Cook named the archipelago as the Sandwich Islands in honor of his sponsor John Montagu, 4th Earl of Sandwich.', u"Cook published the islands' location and rendered the native name as Owyhee.", u'This spelling lives on in Owyhee County, Idaho.', u'It was named after three native Hawaiian members of a trapping party who went missing in that area.', u'The Owyhee Mountains were also named for them.', u'Cook visited the Hawaiian Islands twice.', u'As he prepared for departure after his second visit in 1779, a quarrel ensued as Cook took temple idols and fencing as "firewood", and a minor chief and his men took a ship\'s boat.', u"Cook abducted the King of Hawai\u02bbi Island, Kalani\u02bb\u014dpu\u02bbu, and held him for ransom aboard his ship in order to gain return of Cook's boat.", u'This tactic had worked in Tahiti and other islands.', u"Instead, Kalani\u02bb\u014dpu\u02bbu's supporters fought back, killing Cook and four marines as Cook's party retreated along the beach to their ship.", u"They departed without the ship's boat.", u"After Cook's visit and the publication of several books relating his voyages, the Hawaiian islands attracted many European visitors: explorers, traders, and eventually whalers, who found the islands to be a convenient harbor and source of supplies.", u'Early British influence can be seen in the design of the flag of Hawai\u02bbi, which bears the Union Jack in the top-left corner.', u'These visitors introduced diseases to the once-isolated islands, causing the Hawaiian population to drop precipitously.', u'Native Hawaiians had no resistance to Eurasian diseases, such as influenza, smallpox and measles.', u'By 1820, disease, famine and wars between the chiefs killed more than half of the Native Hawaiian population.', u"During the 1850s, measles killed a fifth of Hawaii's people.", u"Historical records indicated the earliest Chinese immigrants to Hawaii originated from Guangdong Province; a few sailors arrived in 1778 with Captain Cook's journey and more arrived in 1789 with an American trader, who settled in Hawaii in the late 18th century.", u'It appears that leprosy was introduced by Chinese workers by 1830; as with the other new infectious diseases, it proved damaging to the Hawaiians.', u'=== Kingdom of Hawai\u02bbi ===\n\n\n==== House of Kamehameha ====\n\nDuring the 1780s and 1790s, chiefs often fought for power.', u'After a series of battles that ended in 1795, all inhabited islands were subjugated under a single ruler, who became known as King Kamehameha the Great.', u'He established the House of Kamehameha, a dynasty that ruled the kingdom until 1872.', u'After Kamehameha II inherited the throne in 1819, American Protestant missionaries to Hawaii converted many Hawaiians to Christianity.', u'They used their influence to end many traditional practices of the people.', u"The islands' first Christan king was Kamehameha III.", u'Hiram Bingham I, a prominent Protestant missionary, was a trusted adviser to the monarchy during this period.', u'Other missionaries and their descendants became active in commercial and political affairs, leading to conflicts between the monarchy and its restive American subjects.', u'Catholic and Mormon missionaries were also active in the kingdom, but they converted a minority of the Native Hawaiian population.', u'Missionaries from each major group administered to the leper colony at Kalaupapa on Moloka\u02bbi, which was established in 1866 and operated well into the 20th century.', u'The best known were Father Damien and Mother Marianne Cope, both of whom were canonized in the early 21st century as Roman Catholic saints.', u'The death of the bachelor King Kamehameha V\u2014who did not name an heir\u2014resulted in the popular election of Lunalilo over Kal\u0101kaua.', u'Lunalilo died the next year, also without naming an heir.', u'In 1874, the election was contested within the legislature between Kal\u0101kaua and Emma, Queen Consort of Kamehameha IV.', u'After riots broke out, the United States and Britain landed troops on the islands to restore order.', u'Governance passed to the House of Kal\u0101kaua.', u'==== 1887 Constitution and overthrow preparations ====\nIn 1887, Kal\u0101kaua was forced to sign the 1887 Constitution of the Kingdom of Hawaii.', u'Drafted by white businessmen and lawyers, the document stripped the king of much of his authority.', u'It established a property qualification for voting that effectively disenfranchised most Hawaiians and immigrant laborers and favored the wealthier, white elite.', u'Resident whites were allowed to vote but resident Asians were not.', u'Because the 1887 Constitution was signed under threat of violence, it is known as the Bayonet Constitution.', u'King Kal\u0101kaua, reduced to a figurehead, reigned until his death in 1891.', u'His sister, Queen Lili\u02bbuokalani, succeeded him; she was the last monarch of Hawai\u02bbi.', u'In 1893, Queen Lili\u02bbuokalani announced plans for a new constitution.', u"On January 14, 1893, a group of mostly Euro-American business leaders and residents formed the Committee of Safety to stage a coup d'\xe9tat against the kingdom and seek annexation by the United States.", u'United States Government Minister John L. Stevens, responding to a request from the Committee of Safety, summoned a company of U.S. Marines.', u'According to historian William Russ, these troops effectively rendered the monarchy unable to protect itself.', u'=== Overthrow of 1893 \u2013 the Republic of Hawaii (1894\u20131898) ===\n\nIn January 1893, Queen Lili\u02bbuokalani was overthrown and replaced by a provisional government composed of members of the American Committee of Safety.', u'American lawyer Sanford B. Dole became President of the Republic when the Provisional Government of Hawaii ended on July 4, 1894.', u'Controversy ensued in the following years as the Queen tried to regain her throne.', u'The administration of President Grover Cleveland commissioned the Blount Report, which concluded that the removal of Lili\u02bbuokalani had been illegal.', u'The U.S. government first demanded that Queen Lili\u02bbuokalani be reinstated, but the Provisional Government refused.', u'Congress conducted an independent investigation, and on February 26, 1894, submitted the Morgan Report, which found all parties, including Minister Stevens\u2014with the exception of the Queen\u2014"not guilty" and not responsible for the coup.', u'Partisans on both sides of the debate questioned the accuracy and impartiality of both the Blount and Morgan reports over the events of 1893.', u'In 1993, the US Congress passed a joint Apology Resolution regarding the overthrow; it was signed by President Bill Clinton.', u'The resolution apologized for the overthrow of the Hawaiian Kingdom and acknowledged that the United States had annexed Hawaii unlawfully.', u'=== Annexation \u2013 the Territory of Hawaii (1898\u20131959) ===\n\nAfter William McKinley won the 1896 U.S. presidential election, advocates pressed to annex the Republic of Hawaii.', u'The previous president, Grover Cleveland, was a friend of Queen Lili\u02bbuokalani.', u'McKinley was open to persuasion by U.S. expansionists and by annexationists from Hawai\u02bbi.', u'He met with three annexationists: Lorrin A. Thurston, Francis March Hatch and William Ansel Kinney.', u'After negotiations in June 1897, Secretary of State John Sherman agreed to a treaty of annexation with these representatives of the Republic of Hawaii.', u'The U.S. Senate never ratified the treaty.', u'Despite the opposition of most native Hawaiians, the Newlands Resolution was used to annex the Republic to the U.S.; it became the Territory of Hawaii.', u'The Newlands Resolution was passed by the House on June 15, 1898, by 209 votes in favor to 91 against, and by the Senate on July 6, 1898, by a vote of 42 to 21.', u'In 1900, Hawaii was granted self-governance and retained \u02bbIolani Palace as the territorial capitol building.', u'Despite several attempts to become a state, Hawaii remained a territory for sixty years.', u'Plantation owners and capitalists, who maintained control through financial institutions such as the Big Five, found territorial status convenient because they remained able to import cheap, foreign labor.', u'Such immigration and labor practices were prohibited in many states.', u"Puerto Rican immigration to Hawaii began in 1899 when Puerto Rico's sugar industry was devastated by two hurricanes, causing a worldwide shortage of sugar and a huge demand for sugar from Hawaii.", u'Hawaiian sugarcane plantation owners began to recruit experienced, unemployed laborers in Puerto Rico.', u'Two waves of Korean immigration to Hawaii occurred in the 20th century.', u'The first wave arrived between 1903 and 1924; the second wave began in 1965 after President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965 which removed racial and national barriers and resulted in significantly altering the demographic mix in the U.S.\nO\u02bbahu was the target of a surprise attack on Pearl Harbor by Imperial Japan on December 7, 1941.', u'The attack on Pearl Harbor and other military and naval installations, carried out by aircraft and by midget submarines, brought the United States into World War II.', u'=== Political changes of 1954 \u2013 the State of Hawaii (1959\u2013present) ===\n\nIn the 1950s, the power of the plantation owners was broken by the descendants of immigrant laborers, who were born in the incorporated U.S. territory and were U.S. citizens.', u'They voted against the Hawaii Republican Party, strongly supported by plantation owners.', u'The new majority voted for the Democratic Party of Hawaii, which dominated territorial and state politics for more than 40 years.', u"Eager to gain full voting rights, Hawaii's residents actively campaigned for statehood.", u'There was concern from both political parties in the U.S. that Hawaii would be a permanent Republican Party stronghold so the admission of Alaska, thought to be a permanent Democratic Party stronghold, was to happen the same year.', u'These predictions turned out to be inaccurate; today, Hawaii votes Democratic predominately, and Alaska votes Republican.', u'In March 1959, Congress passed the Hawaii Admission Act, which U.S. President Dwight D. rapidly growing tourism economy.', u'Later, state programs promoted Hawaiian culture.', u'The Hawaii State Constitutional Convention of 1978 created institutions such as the Office of Hawaiian Affairs to promote indigenous language and culture.', u'== Demographics ==\n\n\n=== Population ===\n\nAfter the arrival of Europeans and Americans, the population of Hawaii fell dramatically until an influx total population.', u'According to the United States Census, there were over 24,000 total speakers of the language in Hawaii in 2006\u20132008.', u'Hawaiian is a Polynesian member of the Austronesian language family.', u'It is closely related to other Polynesian languages, such as Marquesan, Tahitian, M\u0101ori, Rapa Nui (the language of Easter Island), and less closely to Samoan and Tongan.', u'According to Sch\xfctz, the Marquesans colonized the archipelago in roughly 300 CE and were later followed by waves of seafarers from the Society Islands, Samoa and Tonga.', u'These Polynesians remained in the islands; they eventually became the Hawaiian people and their languages evolved into the Hawaiian language.', u'Kimura and Wilson say, "[l]inguists agree that Hawaiian is closely related to Eastern Polynesian, with a particularly strong link in the Southern Marquesas, and a secondary link in Tahiti, which may be explained by voyaging between the Hawaiian and Society u'They assigned to the Hawaiian phonemes letters from the Latin alphabet.', u'Interest in Hawaiian increased significantly in the late 20th century.', u'With the help of the Office of Hawaiian Affairs, specially designated immersion schools in which all subjects would be taught in Hawaiian were established.', u'The University of Hawaii developed a Hawaiian language graduate studies program.', u'Municipal codes were altered to favor Hawaiian place and street names for new civic developments.', u'A sign language for the deaf, based on the Hawaiian language, has been in use in the apostrophe or left-hanging (opening) single quotation mark.', u'==== Hawaiian Pidgin ====\n\nSome residents of Hawaii speak Hawai\u02bbi Creole English (HCE), endonymically called pidgin or pidgin English.', u'The lexicon of HCE derives mainly from English but also uses words that have derived from Hawaiian, Chinese, Japanese, Portuguese, Ilocano and Tagalog.', u'During the 19th century, the increase in immigration\u2014mainly from China, Japan, Portugal\u2014especially from the Azores and Madeira, and Spain\u2014catalyzed the development of a hybrid variant of English known to its speakers as pidgin.', u'By the early 20th century, pidgin speakers had children who acquired it as their first language.', u'HCE speakers use some Hawaiian words without those words being considered archaic.', u'Most place names are retained from Hawaiian, as are some names for plants and animals.', u'For example, tuna fish is often called by its Hawaiian name, ahi.', u'HCE speakers have modified the meanings of some English words.', u'For example, "aunty" and "uncle" may either refer to any adult who is a friend or be used to show respect to an elder.', u'Syntax and grammar follow distinctive traversed gender as defined by Western standards, were a respected group of pre-colonization people who were widely known in society as healers.', u'Another Hawaiian word, aik\u0101ne, referred to Kame\u02bbeleihiwa said, "If you didn\'t sleep with a man, how could you trust him when you went into battle?', u'How would you know if he was going to be the warrior that would protect you at all costs, if he wasn\'t your lover?"', u'A 2012 poll by Gallup found that Hawaii had the largest proportion of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) adults in the U.S., at 5.1%, comprising an estimated adult LGBT population of 53,966 individuals.', u'The number of same-sex couple households in 2010 was 3,239; a 35.45% increase of figures from a decade earlier.', u'In 2013, Hawaii became the fifteenth U.S. state to legalize same-sex marriage; a University of Hawaii researcher said the law may boost tourism by $217 million.', u"== Economy ==\n\nThe history of Hawaii's economy can be traced through a succession of dominant industries; sandalwood, whaling, sugarcane, pineapple, the military, tourism and education.", u'Since statehood in 1959, tourism has been the largest industry, contributing 24.3% of the gross state product (GSP) in 1997, despite efforts to diversify.', u"The state's gross output for 2003 was US$47 billion; per capita income for Hawaii residents in 2014 was US$54,516.", u'Hawaiian exports include food and clothing.', u'These industries play a small role in the Hawaiian economy, due to the shipping distance to viable markets, such as the West Coast of the the fourth-largest number of millionaires per capita in the United States, with a ratio of 7.18%.', u'=== Taxation ===\nHawaii residents pay the most per person in state taxes in the United States.', u'Millions of tourists pay general excise tax and hotel room tax.', u"The Hawaii Tax Foundation considers the state's tax burden too high, which it says contributes to higher prices and the perception of an unfriendly business climate.", u'State Senator Sam Slom says state taxes are comparatively higher than other states because the state government handles education, health care, and social services that are usually handled at a county or municipal level in most other states.', u'=== Cost of living ===\nThe cost of living in Hawaii, specifically Honolulu, is high compared to that of most major U.S. cities.', u'However, the cost of living in Honolulu is 6.7% lower than in New York City and 3.6% lower than in San Francisco.', u'These numbers may not take some costs, such as increased travel costs for flights, additional shipping fees, and the loss of promotional participation opportunities for customers outside the continental U.S., into account.', u'While some online stores offer free shipping on orders to Hawaii, many merchants exclude Hawaii, Alaska, Puerto Rico and certain other U.S. territories.', u"Hawaiian Electric Industries, a privately owned company, provides 95% of the state's population with electricity, mostly from fossil-fuel power stations.", u'Average electricity prices in October 2014 (36.41 cents per kilowatt-hour) were nearly three times the national average (12.58 cents per kilowatt-hour) and 80% higher than the second-highest state, Connecticut.', u'The median home value in Hawaii in the 2000 U.S. Census was US$272,700, while the national median home value was US$119,600.', u'Hawaii home values were the highest of all states, including California with a median home value of US$211,500.', u'Research from the National Association of Realtors places the 2010 median sale price of a single family home in Honolulu, Hawaii, at US$607,600 and the U.S. median sales price at US$173,200.', u'The sale price of single family homes in Hawaii was the highest of any U.S. city in 2010, just above that of the Silicon Valley area of California (US$602,000).', u"Hawaii's very high cost of living is the result of several interwoven factors of the global economy in addition to domestic U.S. government trade policy.", u'Like other regions with desirable weather throughout the year, such as areas of California, Arizona and Florida, Hawaii\'s residents can be considered to be subject to a "Sunshine tax".', u'This situation is further exacerbated by the natural factors of geography and world distribution that lead to higher prices for goods due to increased shipping costs, a problem which many island states and territories suffer from as well.', u'The situation is compounded even further by what could possibly be the single largest contributor to the high costs of living in Hawaii, a U.S. trade law known as the Jones Act, or the Merchant Marine Act of 1920.', u'This trade regulation prohibits any foreign-flagged ships from carrying cargo between two American ports\u2014a practice known as cabotage.', u'Most consumer goods in the United States are manufactured by outsourced labor in East Asia, then transported by container ships to ports on the U.S. mainland, and Hawaii also receives the same goods.', u'Being located in the central Pacific Ocean, right between major Pacific shipping lanes, it would be very economical to unload Hawaiian-bound goods in Honolulu, before continuing on to the mainland.', u'However, this would effectively make the second leg of the voyage between Hawaii and the mainland a domestic route between two American ports.', u'Because most large cargo ships operate under foreign "flags of convenience" such as Liberia, Vanuatu or Papua New Guinea, allowing them to avoid the more stringent, and thus more costly, regulations of developed nations\' ports, the domestic leg of the voyage would be disallowed by the Jones Act.', u'Instead, those cargo ships must proceed directly to the West Coast, where distributors break bulk and transport the Hawaiian-bound, Asian-manufactured goods back across the ocean by U.S.-flagged ships and increasing the length of the voyage by more than 50%.', u"This highly-inefficient system of shipping Hawaii's consumer cargo comes at a very hefty price for the average Hawaiian citizen, and makes the cost of living in Hawaii much, much higher than it would otherwise be.", u'Hawaiian consumers ultimately bear the expense of transporting goods imposed by the Jones Act.', u'This law makes Hawaii less competitive than West Coast ports as a shopping destination for tourists from countries with much higher taxes like Japan, even though prices for Asian-manufactured goods should be cheaper because Hawaii is much closer than mainland states to Asia.', u'== Culture ==\n\nThe aboriginal culture of Hawaii is Polynesian.', u'Hawaii represents the northernmost extension of the vast Polynesian Triangle of the south and central Pacific Ocean.', u'While traditional Hawaiian culture remains as vestiges in modern Hawaiian society, there are re-enactments of the ceremonies and traditions throughout the islands.', u'Some of these cultural influences, including the popularity (in greatly modified form) of l\u016b\u02bbau and hula, are strong enough to affect the wider United States.', u'=== Cuisine ===\n\nThe cuisine of Hawaii is a fusion of many foods brought by immigrants to the Hawaiian Islands, including the earliest Polynesians and Native Hawaiian cuisine, and American, Chinese, Filipino, Japanese, Korean, Polynesian and Portuguese origins.', u'Plant and animal food sources are imported from around the world for agricultural use in Hawaii.', u'Poi, a starch made by pounding taro, is one of the traditional foods of the islands.', u'Many local restaurants serve the ubiquitous plate lunch, which features two scoops of rice, a simplified version of American macaroni salad and a variety of toppings including hamburger patties, a fried egg, and gravy of a loco moco, Japanese style tonkatsu or the traditional l\u016b\u02bbau favorites, including k\u0101lua pork and laulau.', u'Spam musubi is an example of the fusion of ethnic cuisine that developed on the islands among the mix of immigrant groups and military personnel.', u'In the 1990s, a group of chefs developed Hawaii regional cuisine as a contemporary fusion cuisine.', u"=== Customs and etiquette ===\n\nSome key customs and etiquette in Hawaii are as follows: when visiting a home, it is considered good manners to bring a small gift for one's host (for example, a dessert).", u'Thus, parties are usually in the form of potlucks.', u'Most locals take their shoes off before entering a home.', u"It is customary for Hawaiian families, regardless of ethnicity, to hold a luau to celebrate a child's first birthday.", u'It is also customary at Hawaiian weddings, especially at Filipino weddings, for the bride and groom to do a money dance (also called the pandanggo).', u'Print media and local residents recommend that one refer to non-Hawaiians as "locals of Hawaii" or "people of Hawaii".', u'=== Hawaiian mythology ===\n\nHawaiian mythology comprises the legends, historical tales, and sayings of the ancient Hawaiian people.', u'It is considered a variant of a more general Polynesian mythology that developed a unique character for several centuries before about 1800.', u'It is associated with the Hawaiian religion, which was officially suppressed in the 19th century but was kept alive by some practitioners to the modern day.', u'Prominent figures and terms include Aumakua, the spirit of an ancestor or family god and K\u0101ne, the highest of the four major Hawaiian deities.', u'=== Polynesian mythology ===\n\nPolynesian mythology is the oral traditions of the people of Polynesia, a grouping of Central and South Pacific Ocean island archipelagos in the Polynesian triangle together with the scattered cultures known as the Polynesian outliers.', u'Polynesians speak languages that descend from a language reconstructed as Proto-Polynesian that was probably spoken in the area around Tonga and Samoa in around 1000 BCE.', u'Prior to the 15th century, Polynesian people migrated east to the Cook Islands, and from there to other island groups such as Tahiti and the Marquesas.', u'Their descendants later discovered the islands Tahiti, Rapa Nui and later the Hawaiian Islands and New Zealand.', u'The Polynesian languages are part of the Austronesian language family.', u'Many are close enough in terms of vocabulary and grammar to be mutually intelligible.', u'There are also substantial cultural similarities between the various groups, especially in terms of social organization, childrearing, horticulture, building and textile technologies.', u'Their mythologies in particular demonstrate local reworkings of commonly shared tales.', u'The Polynesian cultures each have distinct but related oral traditions; legends or myths are traditionally considered to recount ancient history (the time of "p\u014d") and the adventures of gods ("atua") and deified ancestors.', u'=== List of state parks ===\n\nThere are many Hawaiian state parks.', u'The Island of Hawai\u02bbi has state parks, recreation areas, and historical parks.', u'Kaua\u02bbi has the Ahukini State Recreation Pier, six state parks, and the Russian Fort Elizabeth State Historical Park.', u'Maui has two state monuments, several state parks, and the Polipoli Spring State Recreation Area.', u"Moloka\u2018i has the Pala'au State Park.", u'O\u02bbahu has several state parks, a number of state recreation areas, and a number of monuments, including the Ulu P\u014d Heiau State Monument.', u'=== Literature ===\n\nThe literature of Hawaii is diverse and includes authors Kiana Davenport, Lois-Ann Yamanaka, and Kaui Hart Hemmings.', u'Hawaiian magazines include Hana Hou!, Hawaii Business Magazine and Honolulu, among others.', u'=== Music ===\n\nThe music of Hawaii includes traditional and popular styles, ranging from native Hawaiian folk music to modern rock and hip hop.', u"Hawaii's musical contributions to the music of the United States are out of proportion to the state's small size.", u'Styles such as slack-key guitar are well-known worldwide, while Hawaiian-tinged music is a frequent part of Hollywood soundtracks.', u'Hawaii also made a major contribution to country music with the introduction of the steel guitar.', u"Traditional Hawaiian folk music is a major part of the state's musical heritage.", u'The Hawaiian people have inhabited the islands for centuries and have retained much of their traditional musical knowledge.', u'Their music is largely religious in nature, and includes chanting and dance music.', u'Hawaiian music has had an enormous impact on the music of other Polynesian islands; according to Peter Manuel, the influence of Hawaiian music a "unifying factor in the development of modern Pacific musics".', u'== Tourism ==\n\nTourism is an important part of the Hawaiian economy.', u'In 2003, according to state government data, there were over 6.4 million visitors, with expenditures of over $10 billion, to the Hawaiian Islands.', u'Due to the mild year-round weather, tourist travel is popular throughout the year.', u'The major holidays are the most popular times for outsiders to visit, especially in the winter months.', u'Substantial numbers of Japanese tourists still visit the islands but have now been surpassed by Chinese and Koreans due to the collapse of the value of the Yen and the weak Japanese economy.', u'The average Japanese stays only 5 days while other Asians spend over 9.5 days and spend 25% more.', u'Hawaii hosts numerous cultural events.', u'The annual Merrie Monarch Festival is an international Hula competition.', u'The Hawaii International Film Festival is the premier film festival for Pacific rim cinema.', u"Honolulu hosts the state's long-running LGBT film festival, the Rainbow Film Festival.", u"== Health ==\n\nAs of 2009, Hawaii's health care system insures 92% of residents.", u"Under the state's plan, businesses are required to provide insurance to employees who work more than twenty hours per week.", u'Heavy regulation of insurance companies helps reduce the cost to employers.', u'Due in part to heavy emphasis on preventive care, Hawaiians require hospital treatment less frequently than the rest of the United States, while total health care expenses measured as a percentage of state GDP are substantially lower.', u'Proponents of universal health care elsewhere in the U.S. sometimes use Hawaii as a model for proposed federal and state health care plans.', u'== Education ==\n\n\n=== Public schools ===\n\nHawaii has the only school system within the U.S. that is unified statewide.', u'Policy decisions are made by the fourteen-member state Board of Education, which sets policy and hires the superintendent of schools, who oversees the state Department of Education.', u'The Department of Education is divided into seven districts; four on O\u02bbahu and one for each of the other three counties.', u'The main rationale for centralization is to combat inequalities between highly populated O\u02bbahu and the more rural Neighbor Islands, and between lower-income and more affluent areas.', u'In most of the U.S., schools are funded from local property taxes.', u'Educators struggle with children of non-native-English-speaking immigrants, whose cultures are different from those of the mainland, where most course materials and testing standards originate.', u'Public elementary, middle and high school test scores in Hawaii are below national averages on tests mandated under the No Child Left Behind Act.', u'The Hawaii Board of Education requires all eligible students to take these tests and report all student test scores; some other states\u2014Texas and Michigan, for example\u2014do not.', u'This may have unbalanced the results that reported in August 2005 that of 282 schools across the state, 185 failed to reach federal minimum performance standards in mathematics and reading.', u"The ACT college placement tests show that in 2005, seniors scored slightly above the national average (21.9 compared with 20.9), but in the widely accepted SAT examinations, Hawaii's college-bound seniors tend to score below the national average in all categories except mathematics.", u'=== Private schools ===\nHawaii has the highest rates of private school attendance in the nation.', u'During the 2011-2012 school year, Hawaii public and charter schools had an enrollment of 181,213, while private schools had 37,695.', u'Private schools educated over 17% of students in Hawaii that school year, nearly three times the approximate national average of 6%.', u'It has four of the largest independent schools; \u02bbIolani School, Kamehameha Schools, rest attend an institution of higher learning in Hawaii.', u'The largest is the University of Hawaii System, which consists of: the research university at M\u0101noa, two comprehensive campuses at in the United States.', u'Modelled after the M\u0101ori language K\u014dhanga reo of New Zealand, they provide preschool aged children the opportunity to engage in early education through a Hawaiian language medium, generally taught by elders.', u'Graduates from the P\u016bnana Leo schools have achieved several measures of academic success in later life.', u'As of 2006, there were a total of eleven P\u016bnana Leo preschools, with locations on five of the islands.', u'== Transportation ==\n\nA system of state highways encircles each main island.', u'Only O\u02bbahu has federal highways, and is the only area outside the contiguous 48 states to have signed Interstate highways.', u'Narrow, winding roads and congestion in populated places can slow traffic.', u'Each major island has a public bus system.', u'Honolulu International Airport (IATA: HNL), which shares runways with the adjacent Hickam Field (IATA: HIK), is the major commercial aviation hub of Hawaii.', u'The commercial aviation airport offers intercontinental service to North America, Asia, Australia and Oceania.', u'Hawaiian Airlines, Mokulele Airlines and go!', u'use jets to provide services between the large airports in Honolulu, L\u012bhu\u02bbe, Kahului, Kona and Hilo.', u'Island Air and Pacific Wings serve smaller airports.', u'These airlines also provide air freight services between the islands.', u'Until air passenger services began in the 1920s, private boats were the sole means of traveling between the islands.', u'Seaflite operated hydrofoils between the major islands in the mid-1970s.', impact statements ended the service, though the company operating Superferry has expressed a wish to recommence ferry services in the future.', u'Currently there are passenger ferry services in Maui services between the larger islands.', u'=== Rail ===\nAt one time Hawaii had a network of railroads on each of the larger islands that transported farm commodities and passengers.', u'Most were 3 ft (914 mm) narrow gauge systems but there were some 2 ft 6 in (762 mm) gauge on some of the smaller islands.', u'The standard gauge in the U.S. is 4 ft 8 1\u20442 in (1,435 mm).', u'By far the largest railroad was the Oahu Railway and Land Company (OR&L) that ran lines from Honolulu across the western and northern part of Oahu.', u'The OR&L was important for moving troops and goods during World War II.', u'Traffic on this line was busy enough for signals to be used to facilitate movement of trains and to require wigwag signals at some railroad crossings for the protection of motorists.', u'The main line was officially abandoned in 1947, although part of it was bought by the U.S. Navy and operated until 1970.', u'Thirteen miles (21 km) of track remain; preservationists occasionally run trains over a portion of this line.', u'The Honolulu High-Capacity Transit Corridor Project aims to add elevated passenger rail on Oahu to relieve highway congestion.', u'== Governance ==\n\n\n=== State government ===\nThe state government of Hawaii is modeled after the federal government with adaptations originating from the kingdom era of Hawaiian history.', u'As codified in the Constitution of Hawaii, there are three branches of government: executive, legislative and judicial.', u'The executive branch is led by the Governor of Hawaii, who is assisted by the Lieutenant Governor of Hawaii, both of whom are elected on the same ticket.', u'The governor is the only state public official elected statewide; all others are appointed by the governor.', u'The lieutenant governor acts as the Secretary of State.', u'The governor and lieutenant governor oversee twenty agencies and departments from offices in the State Capitol.', u'The official residence of the governor is Washington Place.', u'The legislative branch consists of the bicameral Hawaii State Legislature, which is composed of the 51-member Hawaii House of Representatives led by the Speaker of the House, and the 25-member Hawaii Senate led by the President of the Senate.', u'The Legislature meets at the State Capitol.', u'The unified judicial branch of Hawaii is the Hawaii State Judiciary.', u"The state's highest court is the Supreme Court of Hawaii, which uses Ali\u02bbi\u014dlani Hale as its chambers.", u'=== Political subdivisions and local government ===\n\nThe movement of the Hawaiian royal family from Hawai\u02bbi Island to Maui, and subsequently to O\u02bbahu, explains the modern-day distribution of population centers.', u'Kamehameha III chose the largest city, Honolulu, as his capital because of its natural harbor\u2014the present-day Honolulu Harbor.', u'Now the state capital, Honolulu is located along the southeast coast of O\u02bbahu.', u'The previous capital was Lahaina, Maui, and before that Kailua-Kona, Hawai\u02bbi.', u'Some major towns are Hilo; K\u0101ne\u02bbohe; Kailua; Pearl City; Waipahu; Kahului; Kailua-Kona.', u'K\u012bhei; and L\u012bhu\u02bbe.', u'Hawaii comprises five counties: the City and County of Honolulu, Hawaii County, Maui County, Kauai County, and Kalawao County.', u'Hawaii has the fewest local governments among U.S. states.', u'Unique to this state is the lack of municipal governments.', u'All local governments are generally administered at the county level.', u'The only incorporated area in the state is Honolulu County, a consolidated city\u2013county that governs the entire island of Oahu.', u'County executives are referred to as mayors; these are the Mayor of Hawaii County, Mayor of Honolulu, Mayor of Kaua\u02bbi, and the Mayor of Maui.', u'The mayors are all elected in nonpartisan elections.', u'Kalawao County has no elected government, and as mentioned above there are no local school districts and instead all local public education is administered at the state level by the Hawaii Department of Education.', u'The remaining local governments are special districts.', u'=== Federal government ===\nHawaii is represented in the United States Congress by two senators and two representatives.', u'As of 2016, all four seats are held by Democrats.', u'Colleen Hanabusa won a special election for the 1st congressional district representing southeastern Oahu, including central Honolulu, on November 8, 2016 to finish the term of Rep. Mark Takai who passed away July 20, 2016.', u'Tulsi Gabbard represents the 2nd congressional district, representing the rest of the state, which is largely rural and semi-rural.', u'Brian Schatz is the senior United States Senator from Hawaii.', u'He was appointed to the office on December 26, 2012, by Governor Neil Abercrombie, following the death of former senator Daniel Inouye.', u"The state's junior senator is Mazie Hirono, the former representative from the second congressional district.", u'Hirono is the first female Asian American senator and the first Buddhist senator.', u'Hawaii incurred the biggest seniority shift between the 112th and 113th Congresses.', u'The state went from a delegation consisting of senators who were first and twenty-first in seniority to their respective replacements, relative newcomers Schatz and Hirono.', u'Federal officials in Hawaii are based at the Prince K\u016bhi\u014d Federal Building near the Aloha Tower and Honolulu Harbor.', u'The Federal Bureau of Investigation, Internal Revenue Service and the Secret Service maintain their offices there; the building is also the site of the federal District Court for the District of Hawaii and the United States Attorney for the District of Hawaii.', u'=== National politics ===\nSince gaining statehood and participating in its first election in 1960, Hawaii has supported Democrats in all but two presidential elections; 1972 and 1984, both of which were landslide victories for Republicans Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan respectively.', u"In Hawaii's statehood tenure, only Minnesota has supported Republican candidates fewer times in presidential elections.", u"Hawaii hasn't elected a Republican to represent the state in the U.S. Senate since Hiram Fong in 1970; since 1977, both of the state's U.S.", u'Senators have been Democrats.', u"In 2004, John Kerry won the state's four electoral votes by a margin of nine percentage points with 54% of the vote.", u'Every county supported the Democratic candidate.', u'In 1964, favorite son candidate senator Hiram Fong of Hawaii sought the Republican presidential nomination, while Patsy Mink ran in the Oregon primary in 1972.', u'Honolulu-born Barack Obama, then serving as United States Senator from Illinois, was elected the 44th President of the United States on November 4, 2008 and was re-elected for a second term on November 6, 2012.', u'Obama had won the Hawaii Democratic caucus on February 19, 2008, with 76% of the vote.', u'He was the third Hawaii-born candidate to seek the nomination of a major party and the first presidential nominee from Hawaii.', u'== Legal status of Hawaii ==\n\nWhile Hawaii is internationally recognized as a state of the United States while also being broadly accepted as such in mainstream understanding, the legality of this status has been raised in U.S. District Court, the U.N., and other international forums.', u'Domestically, the debate is a topic covered in the Kamehameha Schools curriculum.', u'On September 29, 2015 the Department of the Interior announced a procedure to recognize a Native Hawaiian government.', u'=== Hawaiian sovereignty movement ===\n\nPolitical organizations seeking some form of sovereignty for Hawaii have been active since the 1880s.', u'Generally, their focus is on self-determination and self-governance, either for Hawaii as an independent nation (in many proposals, for "Hawaiian nationals" descended from subjects of the Hawaiian Kingdom or declaring themselves as such by choice), or for people of whole or part native Hawaiian ancestry in an indigenous "nation to nation" relationship akin to tribal sovereignty with US federal recognition of Native Hawaiians.', u'A 2005 Grassroot Institute poll found the majority of Hawaiian residents opposed the Akaka Bill.', u'Some groups also advocate some form of redress from the United States for the 1893 overthrow of Queen Lili\u02bbuokalani, and for what is described as a prolonged military occupation beginning with the 1898 annexation.', u'The movement generally views both the overthrow and annexation as illegal, with the Apology Resolution passed by US Congress in 1993 cited as a major impetus by the movement for Hawaiian sovereignty.', u'The sovereignty movement considers Hawaii to be an illegally occupied nation.', u'== Gallery ==\n\n\n== See also ==\n\nIndex transition to high-speed Internet and start the world's first mobile TV broadcast with 97% of cellphones already having Internet access.", u'== Etymology ==\n\nThe name Korea derives from Goryeo (also spelled as Kory\u014f), the successor state of Goguryeo (Kogury\u014f), and the first Korean dynasty visited by Persian merchants, who called it "Korea".', u'The name Goryeo (a shortened form of Goguryeo) originally referred to the ancient kingdom of Goguryeo, which referred to itself, and was widely referred to, as "Goryeo" since the 5th century.', u'The modern spelling, "Korea", first appeared in the late 17th century in the travel writings of the Dutch East India Company\'s Hendrick Hamel.', u'Despite the coexistence of the spellings Corea and Korea in 19th century publications, some Koreans believe that Imperial Japan, around the time of the Japanese occupation, intentionally standardised the spelling on Korea, making Japan appear first alphabetically.', u'After Goryeo was replaced by Joseon in 1392, Joseon became the official name for the entire territory, though it was not universally accepted.', u'The new official name has its origin in the ancient country of Gojoseon (Old Joseon).', u'In 1897, the Joseon dynasty changed the official name of the country from Joseon to Daehan Jeguk (Korean Empire).', u'The name Daehan, which means "great Han" literally, derives from Samhan (Three Hans).', u'However, the name Joseon was still widely used by Koreans to refer to their country, though it was no longer the official name.', u'Under Japanese rule, the two names Han and Joseon coexisted.', u'There were several groups who fought for independence, the most notable being the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea (\ub300\ud55c\ubbfc\uad6d
