2014 on a two-day trip to Shanghai, President Putin signed a deal on behalf of Gazprom for the Russian energy giant to supply China with 38 billion cubic meters of natural gas per year.', u'Construction of a pipeline to facilitate the deal was agreed whereby Russia would contribute $55bn to the cost, and China $22bn, in what Putin described as "the world\'s biggest construction project for the next four years."', u'The natural gas would begin to flow sometime between 2018 and 2020 and would continue for 30 years at an ultimate cost to China of $400bn.', u'=== Transport ===\n\nRailway transport in Russia is mostly under the control of the state-run Russian Railways monopoly.', u"The company accounts for over 3.6% of Russia's GDP and handles 39% of the total freight traffic (including pipelines) and more than 42% of passenger traffic.", u'The total length of common-used railway tracks exceeds 85,500 km (53,127 mi), second only to the United States.', u'Over 44,000 km (27,340 mi) of tracks are electrified, which is the largest number in the world, and additionally there are more than 30,000 km (18,641 mi) of industrial non-common carrier lines.', u'Railways in Russia, unlike in the most of the world, use broad gauge of 1,520 mm (4 ft 11 27\u204432 in), with the exception of 957 km (595 mi) on Sakhalin island using narrow gauge of 1,067 mm (3 ft 6 in).', u'The most renowned railway in Russia is Trans-Siberian (Transsib), spanning a record 7 time zones and serving the longest single continuous services in the world, Moscow-Vladivostok (9,259 km (5,753 mi)), Moscow\u2013Pyongyang (10,267 km (6,380 mi)) and Kiev\u2013Vladivostok (11,085 km (6,888 mi)).', u'As of 2006 Russia had 933,000 km of roads, of which 755,000 were paved.', u'Some of these make up the Russian federal motorway system.', u'With a large land area the road density is the lowest of all the G8 and BRIC countries.', u"Much of Russia's inland waterways, which total 102,000 km (63,380 mi), are made up of natural rivers or lakes.", u'In the European part of the country the network of channels connects the basins of major rivers.', u'Russia\'s capital, Moscow, is sometimes called "the port of the five seas", because of its waterway connections to the Baltic, White, Caspian, Azov and Black Seas.', u'Major sea ports of Russia include Rostov-on-Don on the Azov Sea, Novorossiysk on the Black Sea, Astrakhan and Makhachkala on the Caspian, Kaliningrad and St Petersburg on the Baltic, Arkhangelsk on the White Sea, Murmansk on the Barents Sea, Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky and Vladivostok on the Pacific Ocean.', u'In 2008 the country owned 1,448 merchant marine ships.', u"The world's only fleet of nuclear-powered icebreakers advances the economic exploitation of the Arctic continental shelf of Russia and the development of sea trade through the Northern Sea Route between Europe and East Asia.", u'By total length of pipelines Russia is second only to the United States.', u'Currently many new pipeline projects are being realized, including Nord Stream and South Stream natural gas pipelines to Europe, and the Eastern Siberia \u2013 Pacific Ocean oil pipeline (ESPO) to the Russian Far East and China.', u'Russia has 1,216 airports, the busiest being Sheremetyevo, Domodedovo, and Vnukovo in Moscow, and Pulkovo in St. Petersburg.', u'Typically, major Russian cities have well-developed systems of public transport, with the most common varieties of exploited vehicles being bus, trolleybus and tram.', u'Seven Russian cities, namely Moscow, Saint Petersburg, Nizhny Novgorod, Novosibirsk, Samara, Yekaterinburg, and Kazan, have underground metros, while Volgograd features a metrotram.', u'The total length of metros in Russia is 465.4 kilometres (289.2 mi).', u'Moscow Metro and Saint Petersburg Metro are the oldest in Russia, opened in 1935 and 1955 respectively.', u'These two are among the fastest and busiest metro systems in the world, and are famous for rich decorations and unique designs of their stations, which is a common tradition in Russian metros and railways.', u'=== Science and technology ===\n\nScience and technology in Russia blossomed since the Age of Enlightenment, when Peter the Great founded the Russian Academy of Sciences and Saint Petersburg State University, and polymath Mikhail Lomonosov established the Moscow State University, paving the way for a strong native tradition in learning and innovation.', u'In the 19th and 20th centuries the country produced a large number of notable scientists and inventors.', u'The Russian physics school began with Lomonosov who proposed the law of conservation of matter preceding the energy conservation law.', u"Russian discoveries and inventions in physics include the electric arc, electrodynamical Lenz's law, space groups of crystals, photoelectric cell, superfluidity, Cherenkov radiation, electron paramagnetic resonance, heterotransistors and 3D holography.", u'Lasers and masers were co-invented by Nikolai Basov and Alexander Prokhorov, while the idea of tokamak for controlled nuclear fusion was introduced by Igor Tamm, Andrei Sakharov and Lev Artsimovich, leading eventually the modern international ITER project, where Russia is a party.', u'Since the time of Nikolay Lobachevsky (the "Copernicus of Geometry" who pioneered the non-Euclidean geometry) and a prominent tutor Pafnuty Chebyshev, the Russian mathematical school became one of the most influential in the world.', u"Chebyshev's students included Aleksandr Lyapunov, who founded the modern stability theory, and Andrey Markov who invented the Markov chains.", u'In the 20th century Soviet mathematicians, such as Andrey Kolmogorov, Israel Gelfand, and Sergey Sobolev, made major contributions to various areas of mathematics.', u'Nine Soviet/Russian mathematicians were awarded with Fields Medal, a most prestigious award in mathematics.', u'Recently Grigori Perelman was offered the first ever Clay Millennium Prize Problems Award for his final proof of the Poincar\xe9 conjecture in 2002.', u'Russian chemist Dmitry Mendeleev invented the Periodic table, the main framework of modern chemistry.', u'Aleksandr Butlerov was one of the creators of the theory of chemical structure, playing a central role in organic chemistry.', u'Russian biologists include Dmitry Ivanovsky who discovered viruses, Ivan Pavlov who was the first to experiment with the classical conditioning, and Ilya Mechnikov who was a pioneer researcher of the immune system and probiotics.', u'Many Russian scientists and inventors were \xe9migr\xe9s, like Igor Sikorsky, who built the first airliners and modern-type helicopters; Vladimir Zworykin, often called the father of TV; chemist Ilya Prigogine, noted for his work on dissipative structures and complex systems; Nobel Prize-winning economists Simon Kuznets and Wassily Leontief; physicist Georgiy Gamov (an author of the Big Bang theory) and social scientist Pitirim Sorokin.', u'Many foreigners worked in Russia for a long time, like Leonard Euler and Alfred Nobel.', u'Russian inventions include arc welding by Nikolay Benardos, further developed by Nikolay Slavyanov, Konstantin Khrenov and other Russian engineers.', u'Gleb Kotelnikov invented the knapsack parachute, while Evgeniy Chertovsky introduced the pressure suit.', u'Alexander Lodygin and Pavel Yablochkov were pioneers of electric lighting, and Mikhail Dolivo-Dobrovolsky introduced the first three-phase electric power systems, widely used today.', u'Sergei Lebedev invented the first commercially viable and mass-produced type of synthetic rubber.', u'The first ternary computer, Setun, was developed by Nikolay Brusentsov.', u'In the 20th century a number of prominent Soviet aerospace engineers, inspired by the fundamental works of Nikolai Zhukovsky, Sergei Chaplygin and others, designed many hundreds of models of military and civilian aircraft and founded a number of KBs (Construction Bureaus) that now constitute the bulk of Russian United Aircraft Corporation.', u'Famous Russian aircraft include the civilian Tu-series, Su and MiG fighter aircraft, Ka and Mi-series helicopters; many Russian aircraft models are on the list of most produced aircraft in history.', u'Famous Russian battle tanks include T34, the most heavily produced tank design of World War II, and further tanks of T-series, including the most produced tank in history, T54/55.', u'The AK47 and AK74 by Mikhail Kalashnikov constitute the most widely used type of assault rifle throughout the world\u2014so much so that more AK-type rifles have been manufactured than all other assault rifles combined.', u'With all these achievements, however, since the late Soviet era Russia was lagging behind the West in a number of technologies, mostly those related to energy conservation and consumer goods production.', u'The crisis of the 1990s led to the drastic reduction of the state support for science and a brain drain migration from Russia.', u'In the 2000s, on the wave of a new economic boom, the situation in the Russian science and technology has improved, and the government launched a campaign aimed into modernisation and innovation.', u"Russian President Dmitry Medvedev formulated top priorities for the country's technological development:\nEfficient energy use\nInformation technology, including both common products and the products combined with space technology\nNuclear energy\nPharmaceuticals\nCurrently Russia has completed the GLONASS satellite navigation system.", u'The country is developing its own fifth-generation jet fighter and constructing the first serial mobile nuclear plant in the world.', u'=== Space exploration ===\n\nRussian achievements in the field of space technology and space exploration are traced back to Konstantin Tsiolkovsky, the father of theoretical astronautics.', u'His works had inspired leading Soviet rocket engineers, such as Sergey Korolyov, Valentin Glushko, and many others who contributed to the success of the Soviet space program on early stages of the Space Race and beyond.', u'In 1957 the first Earth-orbiting artificial satellite, Sputnik 1, was launched; in 1961 the first human trip into space was successfully made by Yury Gagarin.', u'Many other Soviet and Russian space exploration records ensued, including the first spacewalk performed by Alexey Leonov, Luna 9 was the first spacecraft to land on the Moon, Venera 7 was the first to land on another planet (Venus), Mars 3 then the first to land on Mars, the first space exploration rover Lunokhod 1 and the first space station Salyut 1 and Mir.', u'After the collapse of the Soviet Union, some government-funded space exploration programs, including the Buran space shuttle program, were cancelled or delayed, while participation of the Russian space industry in commercial activities and international cooperation intensified.', u'Nowadays Russia is the largest satellite launcher.', u'After the United States Space Shuttle program ended in 2011, Soyuz rockets became the only provider of transport for astronauts at the International Space Station.', u'=== Water supply and sanitation ===\n\nIn Russia, approximately 70 per cent of drinking water comes from surface water and 30 per cent from groundwater.', u'In 2004, water supply systems had a total capacity of 90 million cubic metres a day.', u'The average residential water use was 248 litres per capita per day.', u"One fourth of the world's fresh surface and groundwater is located in Russia.", u'The water utilities sector is one of the largest industries in Russia serving the entire Russian population.', u"== Demographics ==\n\nEthnic Russians comprise 81% of the country's population.", u'The Russian Federation is also home to several sizeable minorities.', u'In all, 160 different other ethnic groups and indigenous peoples live within its borders.', u"Though Russia's population is comparatively large, its density is low because of the country's enormous size.", u'Population is densest in European Russia, near the Ural Mountains, and in southwest Siberia.', u'73% of the population lives in urban areas while 27% in rural ones.', u'The results of the 2010 Census show a total population of 142,856,536.', u"Russia's population peaked at 148,689,000 in 1991, just before the dissolution of the Soviet Union.", u'It began to experience a rapid decline starting in the mid-1990s.', u'The decline has slowed to near stagnation in recent years because of reduced death rates, increased birth rates and increased immigration.', u'In 2009, Russia recorded annual population growth for the first time in fifteen years, with total growth of 10,500.', u'279,906 migrants arrived to the Russian Federation the same year, of which 93% came from CIS countries.', u'The number of Russian emigrants steadily declined from 359,000 in 2000 to 32,000 in 2009.', u'There are also an estimated 10 million illegal immigrants from the ex-Soviet states in Russia.', u'Russia is home to approximately 116 million ethnic Russians and about 20 million ethnic Russians live outside Russia in the former republics of the Soviet Union, mostly in Ukraine and Kazakhstan.', u'The 2010 census recorded 81% of the population as ethnically Russian, and 19% as other ethnicities: 3.7% Tatars; 1.4% Ukrainians; 1.1% Bashkirs; 1% Chuvashes; 11.8% others and unspecified.', u'According to the Census, 84.93% of the Russian population belongs to European ethnic groups (Slavic, Germanic, Finnic other than Ugric, Greek, and others).', u'This is a decline from the 2002, when they constituted for more than 86% of the population.', u"Russia's birth rate is higher than that of most European countries (13.3 births per 1000 people in 2014 compared to the European Union average of 10.1 per 1000), but its death rate is also substantially higher (in 2014, Russia's death rate was 13.1 per 1000 people compared to the EU average of 9.7 per 1000).", u'The Russian Ministry of Health and Social Affairs predicted that by 2011 the death rate would equal the birth rate because of increase in fertility and decline in mortality.', u'The government is implementing a number of programs designed to increase the birth rate and attract more migrants.', u'Monthly government child-assistance payments were doubled to US$55, and a one-time payment of US$9,200 was offered to women who had a second child since 2007.', u'In 2006, in a bid to compensate for the country\'s demographic decline, the Russian government started simplifying immigration laws and launched a state program "for providing assistance to voluntary immigration of ethnic Russians from former Soviet republics".', u'In 2009 Russia experienced its highest birth rate since the dissolution of the Soviet Union.', u'In 2012, the birth rate increased again.', u'Russia recorded 1,896,263 births, the highest number since 1990, and even exceeding annual births during the period 1967\u20131969, with a TFR of about 1.7, the highest since 1991.', u"(Source: Vital statistics table below)\nIn August 2012, as the country saw its first demographic growth since the 1990s, President Putin declared that Russia's population could reach 146 million by 2025, mainly as a result of immigration.", u"=== Largest cities ===\n\n\n=== Ethnic groups ===\n\n\n=== Language ===\n\nRussia's 160 ethnic groups speak some 100 languages.", u'According to the 2002 Census, 142.6 million people speak Russian, followed by Tatar with 5.3 million and Ukrainian with 1.8 million speakers.', u'Russian is the only official state language, but the Constitution gives the individual republics the right to establish their own state languages in addition to Russian.', u'Despite its wide distribution, the Russian language is homogeneous throughout the country.', u'Russian is the most geographically widespread language of Eurasia, as well as the most widely spoken Slavic language.', u'It belongs to the Indo-European language family and is one of the living members of the East Slavic languages, the others being Belarusian and Ukrainian (and possibly Rusyn).', u'Written examples of Old East Slavic (Old Russian) are attested from the 10th century onwards.', u'Russian is the second-most used language on the Internet after English, one of two official languages aboard the International Space Station and is one of the six official languages of the UN.', u'35 languages are officially recognized in Russia in various regions by local governments.', u"=== Religion ===\n\nThe ancestors of many of today's Russians practised Orthodox Christianity since the 10th century.", u'According to the Orthodox Church Tradition, Christianity was first brought to the territory of modern Belarus, Russia and Ukraine by Saint Andrew, the first Apostle of Jesus Christ.', u"Following the Primary Chronicle, the definitive Christianization of Kievan Rus' dates from the year 988 (the year is disputed), when Vladimir the Great was baptized in Chersonesus and proceeded to baptize his family and people in Kiev.", u"The latter events are traditionally referred to as baptism of Rus' (Russian: \u041a\u0440\u0435\u0449\u0435\u043d\u0438\u0435 \u0420\u0443\u0441\u0438, Ukrainian: \u0425\u0440\u0435\u0449\u0435\u043d\u043d\u044f \u0420\u0443\u0441\u0456) in Russian and Ukrainian literature.", u'At the time of the 1917 Revolution, the Russian Orthodox Church was deeply integrated into the autocratic state, enjoying official status.', u'This was a significant factor that contributed to the Bolshevik attitude to religion and the steps they took to control it.', u'Bolsheviks consisted of many people with non-Russian, Communist Russians and influential Jewish backgrounds such as Vladimir Lenin, Leon Trotsky, Grigory Zinoviev, Lev Kamenev, Grigori Sokolnikov who were indifferent towards Christianity and based on the writings of Jewish philosopher Karl Marx with Marxism\u2013Leninism as an ideology went on to form the Communist party.', u'Thus the USSR became the first state to have, as an ideological objective, the elimination of religion and its replacement with universal atheism.', u'The communist regime confiscated religious property, ridiculed religion, harassed believers, and propagated atheism in schools.', u'The confiscation of religious assets was often based on accusations of illegal accumulation of wealth.', u'The vast majority of people in the Russian empire were, at the time of the revolution, religious believers, whereas the communists aimed to break the power of all religious institutions and eventually replace religious belief with atheism.', u'"Science" was counterposed to "religious superstition" in the media and in academic writing.', u'The main religions of pre-revolutionary Russia persisted throughout the entire Soviet period, but they were only tolerated within certain limits.', u'Generally, this meant that believers were free to worship in private and in their respective religious buildings (churches, mosques, etc.', u'), but public displays of religion outside of such designated areas were prohibited.', u'In addition, religious institutions were not allowed to express their views in any type of mass media, and many religious buildings were demolished or used for other purposes.', u'State Atheism in the Soviet Union was known as gosateizm, and was based on the ideology of Marxism\u2013Leninism.', u'Marxist\u2013Leninist Atheism has consistently advocated the control, suppression, and elimination of religion.', u'Within about a year of the revolution, the state expropriated all church property, including the churches themselves, and in the period from 1922 to 1926, 28 Russian Orthodox bishops and more than 1,200 priests were killed.', u'Many more were persecuted.', u'Currently, there is no official census of religion in Russia, and estimates are based on surveys only.', u'In August 2012, ARENA estimated that about 46.8% of Russians are Christians (including Orthodox, Catholic, Protestant, and non-denominational), while 25% believed in God but without any religion.', u'However, later that year, the Levada Center estimated that 76% of Russians are Christians, and in June 2013, the Public Opinion Foundation estimated that 65% of Russians are Christians.', u"These findings are in line with Pew Research Center's 2011 survey, which estimated that 73.6% of Russians are Christians, with Russian Public Opinion Research Center (VCIOM)'s 2010 survey (~77% Christian), and with Ipsos MORI's 2011 survey (69%).", u'Orthodox Christianity, Islam, Judaism and Buddhism are Russia\'s traditional religions, and are all legally a part of Russia\'s "historical heritage".', u"Traced back to the Christianization of Kievan Rus' in the 10th century, Russian Orthodoxy is the dominant religion in the country; smaller Christian denominations such as Catholics, Armenian Gregorians and various Protestant churches also exist.", u"The Russian Orthodox Church was the country's state religion prior to the Revolution and remains the largest religious body in the country.", u'An estimated 95% of the registered Orthodox parishes belong to the Russian Orthodox Church while there are a number of smaller Orthodox Churches.', u'However, the vast majority of Orthodox believers do not attend church on a regular basis.', u'Easter is the most popular religious holiday in Russia, celebrated by a large segment of the Russian population, including large numbers of those who are non-religious.', u'More than three-quarters of the Russian population celebrate Easter by making traditional Easter cakes, coloured eggs and paskha.', u'Islam is the second largest religion in Russia after Russian Orthodoxy.', u'It is the traditional or predominant religion amongst some Caucasian ethnicities (notably the Chechens, the Ingush and the Circassians), and amongst some Turkic peoples (notably the Tatars and the Bashkirs).', u"Altogether, there are 9,400,000 Muslims in Russia or 6.5% of the total population as of 2012 (the share of Muslims is probably much higher because the survey doesn't include detailed data for the traditionally Islamic states of Chechnya and Ingushetia).", u'Notwithstanding, various differences split the Muslim population in different groups.', u'According to the survey, most of the Muslims (approximately 6,700,000 or 4.6% of the total population) are "unaffiliated" to any Islamic schools and branches or Islamic organisation, this is mainly because it is not essential for Muslims to be affiliated with any specific sect or organization.', u'Those who are affiliated are mostly Sunni Muslims, with Shia and Ahmadiyya minorities.', u'Unaffiliated Muslims constitute significant numbers of over 10% in Kabardino-Balkaria (49%), Bashkortostan (38%), Karachay-Cherkessia (34%), Tatarstan (31%), Yamalia (13%), Orenburg Oblast (11%), Adygea (11%) and Astrakhan Oblast (11%).', u'Most of the regions of Siberia have an unaffiliated Muslim population of 1% to 2%.', u'Buddhism is traditional in three regions of the Russian Federation: Buryatia, Tuva, and Kalmykia.', u'Some residents of the Siberian and Far Eastern regions, such as Yakutia and Chukotka, practice shamanist, pantheistic, and pagan rites, along with the major religions.', u'Induction into religion takes place primarily along ethnic lines.', u'Slavs are significantly Orthodox Christian, Turkic speakers are predominantly Muslim, and Mongolic peoples are generally Buddhists.', u'According to various western purposive reports, the number of non-religious in Russia is between 16% and 48% of the population.', u'The number of atheists has decreased significantly; according to the recent statistic, only seven percent declared themselves atheists, a decrease of 5% in three years.', u'In a 2012 poll by Gallup International, 6% of Russian people reported that they were "convinced atheists which is lowest among European countries"\nIn cultural and social affairs Putin has collaborated closely with the Russian Orthodox Church.', u'Patriarch Kirill of Moscow, head of the Church, endorsed his election in 2012.', u'Steven Myers reports, "The church, once heavily repressed, had emerged from the Soviet collapse as one of the most respected institutions....Now Kiril led the faithful directly into an alliance with the state."', u'Mark Woods provides specific examples of how the Church under Patriarch Kirill of Moscow has backed the expansion of Russian power into Crimea and eastern Ukraine.', u"More broadly the New York Times reports in September 2016 how that Church's policy prescriptions support the Kremlin's appeal to social conservatives:\nA fervent foe of homosexuality and any attempt to put individual rights above those of family, community or nation, the Russian Orthodox Church helps project Russia as the natural ally of all those who pine for a more secure, illiberal world free from the tradition-crushing rush of globalization, multiculturalism and women\u2019s and gay rights.", u'=== Health ===\n\nThe Russian Constitution guarantees free, universal health care for all its citizens.', u'In practice, however, free health care is partially restricted because of mandatory registration.', u'While Russia has more physicians, hospitals, and health care workers than almost any other country in the world on a per capita basis, since the dissolution of the Soviet Union the health of the Russian population has declined considerably as a result of social, economic, and lifestyle changes; the trend has been reversed only in the recent years, with average life expectancy having increased 5.2 years for males and 3.1 years for females between 2006 and 2014.', u'As of 2014, the average life expectancy in Russia was 65.29 years for males and 76.49 years for females.', u'The biggest factor contributing to the relatively low life expectancy for males is a high mortality rate among working-age males.', u'Deaths mostly occur because of preventable causes (e.g., alcohol poisoning, smoking, traffic accidents, violent crime).', u'As a result of the large gender difference in life expectancy, and also because of the lasting effect of high casualties in World War II, the gender imbalance remains to this day; there are 0.859 males to every female.', u'=== Education ===\n\nRussia has the most college-level or higher graduates in terms of percentage of population in the world, at 54%.', u'Russia has a free education system, which is guaranteed for all citizens by the Constitution, however entry to subsidized higher education is highly competitive.', u'As a result of great emphasis on science and technology in education, Russian medical, mathematical, scientific, and aerospace research is generally of a high order.', u'Since 1990, the 11-year school education has been introduced.', u'Education in state-owned secondary schools is free.', u'University level education is free, with exceptions.', u'A substantial share of students is enrolled for full pay (many state institutions started to open commercial positions in the last years).', u'In 2004, state spending for education amounted to 3.6% of the GDP, or 13% of the consolidated state budget.', u'The Government allocates funding to pay the tuition fees within an established quota or number of students for each state institution.', u'In higher education institutions, students are paid a small stipend and provided with free housing if they are from out of town.', u'The oldest and largest Russian universities are Moscow State University and Saint Petersburg State University.', u'In the 2000s, in order to create higher education and research institutions of comparable scale in Russian regions, the government launched a program of establishing "federal universities", mostly by merging existing large regional universities and research institutes and providing them with a special funding.', u'These new institutions include the Southern Federal University, Siberian Federal University, Kazan Volga Federal University, North-Eastern Federal University, and Far Eastern Federal University.', u'== Culture ==\n\n\n=== Folk culture and cuisine ===\n\nThere are over 160 different ethnic groups and indigenous peoples in Russia.', u"The country's vast cultural diversity spans ethnic Russians with their Slavic Orthodox traditions, Tatars and Bashkirs with their Turkic Muslim culture, Buddhist nomadic Buryats and Kalmyks, Shamanistic peoples of the Extreme North and Siberia, highlanders of the Northern Caucasus, and Finno-Ugric peoples of the Russian North West and Volga Region.", u'Handicraft, like Dymkovo toy, khokhloma, gzhel and palekh miniature represent an important aspect of Russian folk culture.', u'Ethnic Russian clothes include kaftan, kosovorotka and ushanka for men, sarafan and kokoshnik for women, with lapti and valenki as common shoes.', u'The clothes of Cossacks from Southern Russia include burka and papaha, which they share with the peoples of the Northern Caucasus.', u'Russian cuisine widely uses fish, poultry, mushrooms, berries, and honey.', u'Crops of rye, wheat, barley, and millet provide the ingredients for various breads, pancakes and cereals, as well as for kvass, beer and vodka drinks.', u'Black bread is rather popular in Russia, compared to the rest of the world.', u'Flavourful soups and stews include shchi, borsch, ukha, solyanka and okroshka.', u'Smetana (a heavy sour cream) is often added to soups and salads.', u'Pirozhki, blini and syrniki are native types of pancakes.', u'Chicken Kiev, pelmeni and shashlyk are popular meat dishes, the last two being of Tatar and Caucasus origin respectively.', u'Other meat dishes include stuffed cabbage rolls (golubtsy) usually filled with meat.', u'Salads include Olivier salad, vinegret and dressed herring.', u"Russia's large number of ethnic groups have distinctive traditions regarding folk music.", u'Typical ethnic Russian musical instruments are gusli, balalaika, zhaleika, and garmoshka.', u'Folk music had a significant influence on Russian classical composers, and in modern times it is a source of inspiration for a number of popular folk bands, like Melnitsa.', u'Russian folk songs, as well as patriotic Soviet songs, constitute the bulk of the repertoire of the world-renowned Red Army choir and other popular ensembles.', u'Russians have many traditions, including the washing in banya, a hot steam bath somewhat similar to sauna.', u'Old Russian folklore takes its roots in the pagan Slavic religion.', u'Many Russian fairy tales and epic bylinas were adapted for animation films, or for feature movies by the prominent directors like Aleksandr Ptushko (Ilya Muromets, Sadko) and Aleksandr Rou (Morozko, Vasilisa the Beautiful).', u'Russian poets, including Pyotr Yershov and Leonid Filatov, made a number of well-known poetical interpretations of the classical fairy tales, and in some cases, like that of Alexander Pushkin, also created fully original fairy tale poems of great popularity.', u"=== Architecture ===\n\nSince the Christianization of Kievan Rus' for several ages Russian architecture was influenced predominantly by the Byzantine architecture.", u"Apart from fortifications (kremlins), the main stone buildings of ancient Rus' were Orthodox churches with their many domes, often gilded or brightly painted.", u"Aristotle Fioravanti and other Italian architects brought Renaissance trends into Russia since the late 15th century, while the 16th century saw the development of unique tent-like churches culminating in Saint Basil's Cathedral.", u'By that time the onion dome design was also fully developed.', u'In the 17th century, the "fiery style" of ornamentation flourished in Moscow and Yaroslavl, gradually paving the way for the Naryshkin baroque of the 1690s.', u'After the reforms of Peter the Great the change of architectural styles in Russia generally followed that in the Western Europe.', u'The 18th-century taste for rococo architecture led to the ornate works of Bartolomeo Rastrelli and his followers.', u'The reigns of Catherine the Great and her grandson Alexander I saw the flourishing of Neoclassical architecture, most notably in the capital city of Saint Petersburg.', u'The second half of the 19th century was dominated by the Neo-Byzantine and Russian Revival styles.', u'Prevalent styles of the 20th century were the Art Nouveau, Constructivism, and the Stalin Empire style.', u'In 1955, a new Soviet leader, Nikita Khrushchev, condemned the "excesses" of the former academic architecture, and the late Soviet era was dominated by plain functionalism in architecture.', u'This helped somewhat to resolve the housing problem, but created a large quantity of buildings of low architectural quality, much in contrast with the previous bright styles.', u'The situation improved in the recent two decades.', u'Many temples demolished in Soviet times were rebuilt, and this process continues along with the restoration of various historical buildings destroyed in World War II.', u'A total of 23,000 Orthodox churches have been rebuilt between 1991 and 2010, which effectively quadrapled the number of operating churches in Russia.', u'=== Visual arts ===\n\nEarly Russian painting is represented in icons and vibrant frescos, the two genres inherited from Byzantium.', u'As Moscow rose to power, Theophanes the Greek, Dionisius and Andrei Rublev became vital names associated with a distinctly Russian art.', u'The Russian Academy of Arts was created in 1757 and gave Russian artists an international role and status.', u'Ivan Argunov, Dmitry Levitzky, Vladimir Borovikovsky and other 18th century academicians mostly focused on portrait painting.', u'In the early 19th century, when neoclassicism and romantism flourished, mythological and Biblical themes inspired many prominent paintings, notably by Karl Briullov and Alexander Ivanov.', u'In the mid-19th century the Peredvizhniki (Wanderers) group of artists broke with the Academy and initiated a school of art liberated from academic restrictions.', u'These were mostly realist painters who captured Russian identity in landscapes of wide rivers, forests, and birch clearings, as well as vigorous genre scenes and robust portraits of their contemporaries.', u'Some artists focused on depicting dramatic moments in Russian history, while others turned to social criticism, showing the conditions of the poor and caricaturing authority; critical realism flourished under the reign of Alexander II.', u'Leading realists include Ivan Shishkin, Arkhip Kuindzhi, Ivan Kramskoi, Vasily Polenov, Isaac Levitan, Vasily Surikov, Viktor Vasnetsov, Ilya Repin, and Boris Kustodiev.', u'The turn of the 20th century saw the rise of symbolist painting, represented by Mikhail Vrubel, Kuzma Petrov-Vodkin, and Nicholas Roerich.', u'The Russian avant-garde was a large, influential wave of modernist art that flourished in Russia from approximately 1890 to 1930.', u'The term covers many separate, but inextricably related art movements that occurred at the time, namely neo-primitivism, suprematism, constructivism, rayonism, and Russian Futurism.', u'Notable artists from this era include El Lissitzky, Kazimir Malevich, Wassily Kandinsky, and Marc Chagall.', u'Since the 1930s the revolutionary ideas of the avant-garde clashed with the newly emerged conservative direction of socialist realism.', u'Soviet art produced works that were furiously patriotic and anti-fascist during and after the Great Patriotic War.', u'Multiple war memorials, marked by a great restrained solemnity, were built throughout the country.', u'Soviet artists often combined innovation with socialist realism, notably the sculptors Vera Mukhina, Yevgeny Vuchetich and Ernst Neizvestny.', u'=== Music and dance ===\n\nMusic in 19th century Russia was defined by the tension between classical composer Mikhail Glinka along with other members of The Mighty Handful, who embraced Russian national identity and added religious and folk elements to their compositions, and the Russian Musical Society led by composers Anton and Nikolay Rubinsteins, which was musically conservative.', u'The later tradition of Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, one of the greatest composers of the Romantic era, was continued into the 20th century by Sergei Rachmaninoff.', u'World-renowned composers of the 20th century include Alexander Scriabin, Igor Stravinsky, Sergei Prokofiev, Dmitri Shostakovich and Alfred Schnittke.', u'Russian conservatories have turned out generations of famous soloists.', u'Among the best known are violinists Jascha Heifetz, David Oistrakh, Leonid Kogan, Gidon Kremer, and Maxim Vengerov; cellists Mstislav Rostropovich, Natalia Gutman; pianists Vladimir Horowitz, Sviatoslav Richter, Emil Gilels, Vladimir Sofronitsky and Evgeny Kissin; and vocalists Fyodor Shalyapin, Mark Reizen, Elena Obraztsova, Tamara Sinyavskaya, Nina Dorliak, Galina Vishnevskaya, Anna Netrebko and Dmitry Hvorostovsky.', u"During the early 20th century, Russian ballet dancers Anna Pavlova and Vaslav Nijinsky rose to fame, and impresario Sergei Diaghilev and his Ballets Russes' travels abroad profoundly influenced the development of dance worldwide.", u"Soviet ballet preserved the perfected 19th century traditions, and the Soviet Union's choreography schools produced many internationally famous stars, including Galina Ulanova, Maya Plisetskaya, Rudolf Nureyev, and Mikhail Baryshnikov.", u'The Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow and the Mariinsky Ballet in St Petersburg remain famous throughout the world.', u'Modern Russian rock music takes its roots both in the Western rock and roll and heavy metal, and in traditions of the Russian bards of the Soviet era, such as Vladimir Vysotsky and Bulat Okudzhava.', u'Popular Russian rock groups include Mashina Vremeni, DDT, Aquarium, Alisa, Kino, Kipelov, Nautilus Pompilius, Aria, Grazhdanskaya Oborona, Splean and Korol i Shut.', u'Russian pop music developed from what was known in the Soviet times as estrada into full-fledged industry, with some performers gaining wide international recognition, such as t.A.T.u., Nu Virgos and Vitas.', u'=== Literature and philosophy ===\n\nIn the 18th century, during the era of Russian Enlightenment, the development of Russian literature was boosted by the works of Mikhail Lomonosov and Denis Fonvizin.', u'By the early 19th century a modern native tradition had emerged, producing some of the greatest writers in Russian history.', u'This period, known also as the Golden Age of Russian Poetry, began with Alexander Pushkin, who is considered the founder of the modern Russian literary language and often described as the "Russian Shakespeare".', u'It continued into the 19th century with the poetry of Mikhail Lermontov and Nikolay Nekrasov, dramas of Alexander Ostrovsky and Anton Chekhov, and the prose of Nikolai Gogol and Ivan Turgenev.', u'Leo Tolstoy and Fyodor Dostoyevsky have been described by literary critics as the greatest novelists of all time.', u'By the 1880s, the age of the great novelists was over, and short fiction and poetry became the dominant genres.', u'The next several decades became known as the Silver Age of Russian Poetry, when the previously dominant literary realism was replaced by symbolism.', u'Leading authors of this era include such poets as Valery Bryusov, Vyacheslav Ivanov, Alexander Blok, Nikolay Gumilev and Anna Akhmatova, and novelists Leonid Andreyev, Ivan Bunin, and Maxim Gorky.', u'Russian philosophy blossomed in the 19th century, when it was defined initially by the opposition of Westernizers, advocating Western political and economical models, and Slavophiles, insisting on developing Russia as a unique civilization.', u'The latter group includes Nikolai Danilevsky and Konstantin Leontiev, the founders of eurasianism.', u'In its further development Russian philosophy was always marked by a deep connection to literature and interest in creativity, society, politics and nationalism; Russian cosmism and religious philosophy were other major areas.', u'Notable philosophers of the late 19th and the early 20th centuries include Vladimir Solovyev, Sergei Bulgakov, and Vladimir Vernadsky.', u'Following the Russian Revolution of 1917 many prominent writers and philosophers left the country, including Bunin, Vladimir Nabokov and Nikolay Berdyayev, while a new generation of talented authors joined together in an effort to create a distinctive working-class culture appropriate for the new Soviet state.', u'In the 1930s censorship over literature was tightened in line with the policy of socialist realism.', u'In the late 1950s restrictions on literature were eased, and by the 1970s and 1980s, writers were increasingly ignoring official guidelines.', u'Leading authors of the Soviet era include novelists Yevgeny Zamyatin, Ilf and Petrov, Mikhail Bulgakov and Mikhail Sholokhov, and poets Vladimir Mayakovsky, Yevgeny Yevtushenko, and Andrey Voznesensky.', u'The Soviet Union was also a major producer of science fiction, written by authors like Arkady and Boris Strugatsky, Kir Bulychov, Alexander Belayev and Ivan Yefremov.', u'Traditions of Russian science fiction and fantasy are continued today by numerous writers.', u'=== Cinema, animation and media ===\n\nRussian and later Soviet cinema was a hotbed of invention in the period immediately following 1917, resulting in world-renowned films such as The Battleship Potemkin by Sergei Eisenstein.', u"Eisenstein was a student of filmmaker and theorist Lev Kuleshov, who developed the Soviet montage theory of film editing at the world's first film school, the All-Union Institute of Cinematography.", u'Dziga Vertov, whose kino-glaz ("film-eye") theory\u2014that the camera, like the human eye, is best used to explore real life\u2014had a huge impact on the development of documentary film making and cinema realism.', u'The subsequent state policy of socialist realism somewhat limited creativity; however, many Soviet films in this style were artistically successful, including Chapaev, The Cranes Are Flying, and Ballad of a Soldier.', u'The 1960s and 1970s saw a greater variety of artistic styles in Soviet cinema.', u"Eldar Ryazanov's and Leonid Gaidai's comedies of that time were immensely popular, with many of the catch phrases still in use today.", u"In 1961\u201368 Sergey Bondarchuk directed an Oscar-winning film adaptation of Leo Tolstoy's epic War and Peace, which was the most expensive film made in the Soviet Union.", u"In 1969, Vladimir Motyl's White Sun of the Desert was released, a very popular film in a genre of ostern; the film is traditionally watched by cosmonauts before any trip into space.", u'Russian animation dates back to late Russian Empire times.', u'During the Soviet era, Soyuzmultfilm studio was the largest animation producer.', u'Soviet animators developed a great variety of pioneering techniques and aesthetic styles, with prominent directors including Ivan Ivanov-Vano, Fyodor Khitruk and Aleksandr Tatarsky.', u'Many Soviet cartoon heroes such as the Russian-style Winnie-the-Pooh, cute little Cheburashka, Wolf and Hare from Nu, Pogodi!, are iconic images in Russia and many surrounding countries.', u'The late 1980s and 1990s were a period of crisis in Russian cinema and animation.', u'Although Russian filmmakers became free to express themselves, state subsidies were drastically reduced, resulting in fewer films produced.', u'The early years of the 21st century have brought increased viewership and subsequent prosperity to the industry on the back of the economic revival.', u'Production levels are already higher than in Britain and Germany.', u"Russia's total box-office revenue in 2007 was $565 million, up 37% from the previous year.", u'In 2002 the Russian Ark became the first feature film ever to be shot in a single take.', u'The traditions of Soviet animation were developed recently by such directors as Aleksandr Petrov and studios like Melnitsa Animation.', u'While there were few stations or channels in the Soviet time, in the past two decades many new state and privately owned radio stations and TV channels have appeared.', u'In 2005 a state-run English language Russia Today TV started broadcasting, and its Arabic version Rusiya Al-Yaum was launched in 2007.', u'Censorship and Media freedom in Russia has always been a main theme of Russian media.', u'=== Sports ===\n\nCombining the total medals of the Soviet Union and Russia, the country is second among all nations by number of gold medals both at the Summer Olympics and at the Winter Olympics.', u'Soviet and later Russian athletes have always been in the top three for the number of gold medals collected at the Summer Olympics.', u'Soviet gymnasts, track-and-field athletes, weight lifters, wrestlers, boxers, fencers, shooters, cross country skiers, biathletes, speed skaters and figure skaters were consistently among the best in the world, along with Soviet basketball, handball, volleyball and ice hockey players.', u'The 1980 Summer Olympics were held in Moscow while the 2014 Winter Olympics were hosted in Sochi.', u'Although ice hockey was only introduced during the Soviet era, the national team managed to win gold at almost all the Olympics and World Championships they contested.', u'Russian players Valery Kharlamov, Sergei Makarov, Vyacheslav Fetisov and Vladislav Tretiak hold four of six positions in the IIHF Team of the Century.', u'Russia has not won the Olympic ice hockey tournament since the Unified Team won gold in 1992.', u'Recently Russia won the 2008, 2009, 2012 and the 2014 IIHF World Championships.', u'Russia dominated the 2012 tournament, winning all of its ten matches\u2014the first time any team had done so since the Soviet Union in 1989.', u'The most sports in Russia is volleyball.', u"Russia men's national volleyball team winner four gold medalist in Olympics (1964, 1968, 1980, 2012) and won six gold medalist and two hosted in FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship (1949, 1952, 1960, 1962, 1978, 1982).", u'The Kontinental Hockey League (KHL) was founded in 2008 as a successor to the Russian Superleague.', u'It is seen as a rival to the National Hockey League (NHL), is ranked the top hockey league in Europe as of 2009, and the second-best in the world.', u'It is an international professional ice hockey league in Eurasia and consists of 29 teams, of which 21 are based in Russia and 7 more are located in Latvia, Kazakhstan, Belarus, Finland, Slovakia, Croatia and China.', u'Bandy, also known as Russian hockey, is another traditionally popular ice sport.', u'The Soviet Union won all the Bandy World Championships for men between 1957\u201379 and some thereafter too.', u'After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Russia has continuously been one of the most successful teams, winning many world championships.', u'Association football is one of the most popular sports in modern Russia.', u'The Soviet national team became the first ever European Champions by winning Euro 1960.', u'Appearing in four FIFA World Cups from 1958 to 1970, Lev Yashin is regarded to be one of the greatest goalkeepers in the history of football, and was chosen on the FIFA World Cup Dream Team.', u'The Soviet national team reached the final of Euro 1988.', u'In 1956 and 1988, the Soviet Union won gold at the Olympic football tournament.', u'Russian clubs CSKA Moscow and Zenit St Petersburg won the UEFA Cup in 2005 and 2008 respectively.', u'The Russian national football team reached the semi-finals of Euro 2008, losing only to the eventual champions Spain.', u'Russia will host the 2018 FIFA World Cup, with 11 host cities located in the European part of the country and in the Ural region.', u'In 2007, the Russian national basketball team won the European Basketball Championship.', u'Russian basketball club PBC CSKA Moscow is one of the top teams in Europe, winning the Euroleague in 2006 and 2008.', u'Larisa Latynina, who currently holds the record for the most gold Olympic medals won by a woman (and held the record for most Olympic medals won per person from 1964 until 2012 when swimmer Michael Phelps replaced her record), established the USSR as the dominant force in gymnastics for many years.', u'Today, Russia is the leading nation in rhythmic gymnastics with Yevgeniya Kanayeva.', u'Russian synchronized swimming is the best in the world, with almost all gold medals at Olympics and World Championships having been swept by Russians in recent decades.', u'Figure skating is another popular sport in Russia, especially pair skating and ice dancing.', u'With the exception of 2010 a Soviet or Russian pair has won gold at every Winter Olympics since 1964.', u"Since the end of the Soviet era, tennis has grown in popularity and Russia has produced a number of famous players, including Maria Sharapova, the world's highest paid female athlete.", u'In martial arts, Russia produced the sport Sambo and renowned fighters, like Fedor Emelianenko.', u'Chess is a widely popular pastime in Russia; from 1927, Russian grandmasters have held the world chess championship almost continuously.', u'The 2014 Winter Olympics were held in Sochi in the south of Russia.', u'Russia won the largest number of medals among the participating nations with 13 gold, 11 silver, and 9 bronze medals for a total of 33 medals.', u'Commentators evaluated the Games as having been an overall success.', u'Formula One is also becoming increasingly popular in Russia.', u'In 2010 Vitaly Petrov of Vyborg became the first Russian to drive in Formula One, and was soon followed by a second - Daniil Kvyat, from Ufa - in 2014.', u'There had only been two Russian Grands Prix (in 1913 and 1914), but the Russian Grand Prix returned as part of the Formula One season in 2014, as part of a six-year deal.', u'=== National holidays and symbols ===\n\nThere are seven public holidays in Russia, except those always celebrated on Sunday.', u'Russian New Year traditions resemble those of the Western Christmas, with New Year Trees and gifts, and Ded Moroz (Father Frost) playing the same role as Santa Claus.', u'Orthodox Christmas falls on January 7, because the Russian Orthodox Church still follows the Julian calendar, and all Orthodox holidays are 13 days after Western ones.', u'Two other major Christian holidays are Easter and Trinity Sunday.', u'Kurban Bayram and Uraza Bayram are celebrated by Russian Muslims.', u"Further Russian public holidays include Defender of the Fatherland Day (February 23), which honors Russian men, especially those serving in the army; International Women's Day (March 8), which combines the traditions of Mother's Day and Valentine's Day; Spring and Labor Day (1 May); Victory Day; Russia Day (June 12); and Unity Day (November 4), commemorating the popular uprising which expelled the Polish occupation force from Moscow in 1612.", u'Victory Day is the second most popular holiday in Russia; it commemorates the victory over Nazism in the Great Patriotic War.', u'A huge military parade, hosted by the President of Russia, is annually organised in Moscow on Red Square.', u'Similar parades take place in all major Russian cities and cities with the status Hero city or City of Military Glory.', u"Popular non-public holidays include Old New Year (the New Year according to the Julian Calendar on January 14), Tatiana Day (students holiday on January 25), Maslenitsa (a pre-Christian spring holiday a week before the Great Lent), Cosmonautics Day (in tribute to the first human trip into space), Ivan Kupala Day (another pre-Christian holiday on July 7) and Peter and Fevronia Day (which takes place on July 8 and is the Russian analogue of Valentine's Day, focusing, however, on family love and fidelity).", u'State symbols of Russia include the Byzantine double-headed eagle, combined with St. George of Moscow in the Russian coat of arms.', u'The Russian flag dates from the late Tsardom of Russia period and has been widely used since the time of the Russian Empire.', u'The Russian anthem shares its music with the Soviet Anthem, though not the lyrics.', u'The imperial motto God is with us and the Soviet motto Proletarians of all countries, unite!', u'are now obsolete and no new motto has replaced them.', u'The hammer and sickle and the full Soviet coat of arms are still widely seen in Russian cities as a part of old architectural decorations.', u'The Soviet Red Stars are also encountered, often on military equipment and war memorials.', u'The Red Banner continues to be honored, especially the Banner of Victory of 1945.', u"The Matryoshka doll is a recognizable symbol of Russia, and the towers of Moscow Kremlin and Saint Basil's Cathedral in Moscow are Russia's main architectural icons.", u'Cheburashka is a mascot of the Russian national Olympic team.', u"St. Mary, St. Nicholas, St. Andrew, St. George, St. Alexander Nevsky, St. Sergius of Radonezh and St. Seraphim of Sarov are Russia's patron saints.", u'Chamomile is the national flower, while birch is the national tree.', u'The Russian bear is an animal symbol and a national personification of Russia, though this image has a Western origin and Russians themselves have accepted it only fairly recently.', u'The native Russian national personification is Mother Russia.', u'=== Tourism ===\n\nTourism in Russia has seen rapid growth since the late Soviet period, first domestic tourism and then international tourism, fueled by the rich cultural heritage and great natural variety of the country.', u'Major tourist routes in Russia include a journey around the Golden Ring of ancient cities, cruises on the big rivers like the Volga, and long journeys on the famous Trans-Siberian Railway.', u'In 2013, Russia was visited by 28.4 million tourists; it is the ninth most visited country in the world and the seventh most visited in Europe.', u'The number of Western visitors dropped in 2014.', u'The most visited destinations in Russia are Moscow and Saint Petersburg, the current and former capitals of the country.', u"Recognized as World Cities, they feature such world-renowned museums as the Tretyakov Gallery and the Hermitage, famous theaters like Bolshoi and Mariinsky, ornate churches like Saint Basil's Cathedral, Cathedral of Christ the Saviour, Saint Isaac's Cathedral and Church of the Savior on Blood, impressive fortifications like the Kremlin and Peter and Paul Fortress, beautiful squares and streets like Red Square, Palace Square, Tverskaya Street and Nevsky Prospect.", u'Rich palaces and parks are found in the former imperial residences in suburbs of Moscow (Kolomenskoye, Tsaritsyno) and St Petersburg (Peterhof, Strelna, Oranienbaum, Gatchina, Pavlovsk and Tsarskoye Selo).', u'Moscow displays Soviet architecture at its best, along with modern skyscrapers, while St Petersburg, nicknamed Venice of the North, boasts of its classical architecture, many rivers, channels and bridges.', u'Kazan, the capital of Tatarstan, shows a mix of Christian Russian and Muslim Tatar cultures.', u'The city has registered a brand The Third Capital of Russia, though a number of other major cities compete for this status, including Novosibirsk, Yekaterinburg and Nizhny Novgorod.', u'The warm subtropical Black Sea coast of Russia is the site for a number of popular sea resorts, like Sochi, the follow-up host of the 2014 Winter Olympics.', u'The mountains of the Northern Caucasus contain popular ski resorts such as Dombay.', u'The most famous natural destination in Russia is Lake Baikal, the Blue Eye of Siberia.', u'This unique lake, the oldest and deepest in the world, has crystal-clear waters and is surrounded by taiga-covered mountains.', u'Other popular natural destinations include Kamchatka with its volcanoes and geysers, Karelia with its lakes and granite rocks, the snowy Altai Mountains, and the wild steppes of Tyva.',
