(1863\u20131885) who was Houdini's half-brother, by Rabbi Weisz's first marriage; Nathan J.", u'(1870\u20131927); Gottfried William (1872\u20131925); Theodore (1876\u20131945); Leopold D. (1879\u20131962); and Carrie Gladys (1882\u20131959), who was left almost blind after a childhood accident.', u'Weisz arrived in the United States on July 3, 1878, on the SS Fresia with his mother (who was pregnant) and his four brothers.', u'The family changed their name to the German spelling Weiss, and Erik became Ehrich.', u'The family lived in Appleton, Wisconsin, where his father served as Rabbi of the Zion Reform Jewish Congregation.', u'According to the 1880 census, the family lived on Appleton Street.', u'On June 6, 1882, Rabbi Weiss became an American citizen.', u'Losing his tenure at Zion in 1887, Rabbi Weiss moved with Ehrich to New York City, where they lived in a boarding house on East 79th Street.', u'He was joined by the rest of the family once Rabbi Weiss found permanent housing.', u'As a child, Ehrich Weiss took several jobs, making his public d\xe9but as a 9-year-old trapeze artist, calling himself "Ehrich, the Prince of the Air".', u'He was also a champion cross country runner in his youth.', u'When Weiss became a professional magician he began calling himself "Harry Houdini", after the French magician Jean Eug\xe8ne Robert-Houdin, after reading Robert-Houdin\'s autobiography in 1890.', u'Weiss incorrectly believed that an i at the end of a name meant "like" in French.', u'In later life, Houdini claimed that the first part of his new name, Harry, was an homage to Harry Kellar, whom he also admired.', u'The magician Joseph Rinn had coached Houdini as a teenager at the Pastime Athletic Club.', u'Houdini was an active Freemason and was a member of St. Cecile Lodge #568 in New York City.', u'In 1918, he registered for selective service as Harry Handcuff Houdini.', u'== Magic career ==\n\nHe began his magic career in 1891, but had little success.', u'He appeared in a tent act with strongman Emil Jarrow.', u'He performed in dime museums and sideshows, and even doubled as "The Wild Man" at a circus.', u'Houdini focused initially on traditional card tricks.', u'At one point, he billed himself as the "King of Cards".', u'He soon began experimenting with escape acts.', u'In 1893, while performing with his brother "Dash" (Theodore) at Coney Island as "The Brothers Houdini," Harry met a fellow performer, Wilhelmina Beatrice "Bess" Rahner.', u'Bess was initially courted by Dash, but she and Houdini married in 1894, with Bess replacing Dash in the act, which became known as "The Houdinis."', u"For the rest of Houdini's performing career, Bess worked as his stage assistant.", u"Houdini's big break came in 1899 when he met manager Martin Beck in St. Paul, Minnesota.", u"Impressed by Houdini's handcuffs act, Beck advised him to concentrate on escape acts and booked him on the Orpheum vaudeville circuit.", u'Within months, he was performing at the top vaudeville houses in the country.', u'In 1900, Beck arranged for Houdini to tour Europe.', u"After some days of unsuccessful interviews in London, Houdini's British agent Harry Day helped him to get an interview with C. Dundas Slater, then manager of the Alhambra Theatre.", u'He was introduced to William Melville and gave a demonstration of escape from handcuffs at Scotland Yard.', u'He succeeded in baffling the police so effectively that he was booked at the Alhambra for six months.', u'His show was an immediate hit and his salary rose to $300 a week.', u'Houdini became widely known as "The Handcuff King."', u'He toured England, Scotland, the Netherlands, Germany, France, and Russia.', u'In each city, Houdini challenged local police to restrain him with shackles and lock him in their jails.', u'In many of these challenge escapes, Houdini was first stripped nude and searched.', u'In Moscow, Houdini escaped from a Siberian prison transport van.', u'Houdini claimed that, had he been unable to free himself, he would have had to travel to Siberia, where the only key was kept.', u'In Cologne, he sued a police officer, Werner Graff, who alleged that he made his escapes via bribery.', u"Houdini won the case when he opened the judge's safe (he later said the judge had forgotten to lock it).", u'With his new-found wealth, Houdini purchased a dress said to have been made for Queen Victoria.', u'He then arranged a grand reception where he presented his mother in the dress to all their relatives.', u'Houdini said it was the happiest day of his life.', u'In 1904, Houdini returned to the U.S. and purchased a house for $25,000, a brownstone at 278 W. 113th Street in Harlem, New York City.', u"In 1906, Houdini created his own publication, the Conjurers' Monthly Magazine.", u'It was a competitor to The Sphinx, but was short-lived and only two volumes were released until August 1908.', u'Magic historian Jim Steinmeyer has noted that "Houdini couldn\'t resist using the journal for his own crusades, attacking his rivals, praising his own appearances, and subtly rewriting history to favor his view of magic."', u'From 1907 and throughout the 1910s, Houdini performed with great success in the United States.', u'He freed himself from jails, handcuffs, chains, ropes, and straitjackets, often while hanging from a rope in sight of street audiences.', u'Because of imitators, on January 25, 1908, Houdini put his "handcuff act" behind him and began escaping from a locked, water-filled milk can.', u'The possibility of failure and death thrilled his audiences.', u'Houdini also expanded his repertoire with his escape challenge act, in which he invited the public to devise contraptions to hold him.', u'These included nailed packing crates (sometimes lowered into water), riveted boilers, wet sheets, mail bags, and even the belly of a whale that had washed ashore in Boston.', u'Brewers in Scranton, Pennsylvania and other cities challenged Houdini to escape from a barrel after they filled it with beer.', u'Many of these challenges were arranged with local merchants in one of the first uses of mass tie-in marketing.', u"Rather than promote the idea that he was assisted by spirits, as did the Davenport Brothers and others, Houdini's advertisements showed him making his escapes via dematerializing, although Houdini himself never claimed to have supernatural powers.", u'Whilst on tour in Europe in 1902, Houdini visited Blois with the aim of meeting the widow of Emile Houdin, the son of Jean Eug\xe8ne Robert-Houdin, for an interview and permission to visit his grave.', u'He did not receive permission but still visited the grave.', u'Houdini believed that he had been treated unfairly and later wrote a negative account of the incident in his magazine claiming he was "treated most discourteously by Madame W. Emile Robert-Houdin."', u'In 1906, he sent a letter to the French magazine L\'Illusionniste stating "You will certainly enjoy the article on Robert Houdin I am about to publish in my magazine.', u'Yes, my dear friend, I think I can finally demolish your idol, who has so long been placed on a pedestal that he did not deserve."', u'After much research, Houdini wrote a collection of articles on the history of magic, which were expanded into The Unmasking of Robert-Houdin published in 1908.', u'In this book he attacked his former idol Robert-Houdin as liar and a fraud for having claimed the invention of automata and effects such as aerial suspension, which had been in existence for many years.', u'Many of the allegations in the book were dismissed by magicians and researchers who defended Robert-Houdin.', u"Magician Jean Hugard would later write a full rebuttal to Houdini's book.", u'In 1913, Houdini introduced perhaps his most famous act, the Chinese Water Torture Cell, in which he was suspended upside-down in a locked glass-and-steel cabinet full to overflowing with water.', u'The act required that Houdini hold his breath for more than three minutes.', u'Houdini performed the escape for the rest of his career.', u'During his career, Houdini explained some of his tricks in books written for the magic brotherhood.', u'In Handcuff Secrets (1909), he revealed how many locks and handcuffs could be opened with properly applied force, others with shoestrings.', u'Other times, he carried concealed lockpicks or keys.', u'When tied down in ropes or straitjackets, he gained wiggle room by enlarging his shoulders and chest, moving his arms slightly away from his body.', u'His straitjacket escape was originally performed behind curtains, with him popping out free at the end.', u"Houdini's brother, (who was also an escape artist, billing himself as Theodore Hardeen), discovered that audiences were more impressed when the curtains were eliminated so they could watch him struggle to get out.", u'On more than one occasion, they both performed straitjacket escapes while dangling upside-down from the roof of a building in the same city.', u'For most of his career, Houdini was a headline act in vaudeville.', u'For many years, he was the highest-paid performer in American vaudeville.', u"One of Houdini's most notable non-escape stage illusions was performed at the New York Hippodrome, when he vanished a full-grown elephant from the stage.", u'He had purchased this trick from the magician Charles Morritt.', u"In 1923, Houdini became president of Martinka & Co., America's oldest magic company.", u'The business is still in operation today.', u'He also served as President of the Society of American Magicians (aka S.A.M.)', u'from 1917 until his death in 1926.', u"Founded on May 10, 1902, in the back room of Martinka's magic shop in New York, the Society expanded under the leadership of Harry Houdini during his term as National President from 1917 to 1926.", u"Houdini was magic's greatest visionary.", u'He sought to create a large, unified national network of professional and amateur magicians.', u'Wherever he traveled, Houdini gave a lengthy formal address to the local magic club, made speeches, and usually threw a banquet for the members at his own expense.', u'He said "The Magicians Clubs as a rule are small: they are weak...but if we were amalgamated into one big body the society would be stronger, and it would mean making the small clubs powerful and worth while.', u'Members would find a welcome wherever they happened to be and, conversely, the safeguard of a city-to-city hotline to track exposers and other undesirables."', u'For most of 1916, while on his vaudeville tour, Houdini, at his own expense, had been recruiting local magic clubs to join the S.A.M.', u'in an effort to revitalize what he felt was a weak organization.', u'Houdini persuaded groups in Buffalo, Detroit, Pittsburgh, and Kansas City to join.', u'As had happened in London, Houdini persuaded magicians to join.', u'The Buffalo club joined as the first branch, (later assembly) of the Society.', u'Chicago Assembly No.', u'3 was, as the name implies, the third regional club to be established by the S.A.M., whose assemblies now number in the hundreds.', u"In 1917, he signed Assembly Number Three's charter into existence, and that charter and this club continue to provide Chicago magicians with a connection to each other and to their past.", u'Houdini dined with, addressed, and got pledges from similar clubs in Detroit, Rochester, Pittsburgh, Kansas City, Cincinnati and elsewhere.', u'This was the biggest movement ever in the history of magic.', u'In places where no clubs existed, he rounded up individual magicians, introduced them to each other, and urged them into the fold.', u"By the end of 1916, magicians' clubs in San Francisco and other cities that Houdini had not visited were offering to become assemblies.", u'He had created the richest and longest-surviving organization of magicians in the world.', u'It now embraces almost 6,000 dues-paying members and almost 300 assemblies worldwide.', u'In July 1926, Houdini was elected for the ninth successive time President of the Society of American Magicians.', u'Every other president has only served for one year.', u"He also was President of the Magicians' Club of London.", u'In the final years of his life (1925/26), Houdini launched his own full-evening show, which he billed as "Three Shows in One: Magic, Escapes, and Fraud Mediums Exposed".', u'== Notable escapes ==\n\n\n=== Mirror challenge ===\n\nIn 1904, the London Daily Mirror newspaper challenged Houdini to escape from special handcuffs that it claimed had taken Nathaniel Hart, a locksmith from Birmingham, five years to make.', u"Houdini accepted the challenge for March 17 during a matin\xe9e performance at London's Hippodrome theater.", u'It was reported that 4000 people and more than 100 journalists turned out for the much-hyped event.', u'The escape attempt dragged on for over an hour, during which Houdini emerged from his "ghost house" (a small screen used to conceal the method of his escape) several times.', u'On one occasion he asked if the cuffs could be removed so he could take off his coat.', u'The Mirror representative, Frank Parker, refused, saying Houdini could gain an advantage if he saw how the cuffs were unlocked.', u'Houdini promptly took out a pen-knife and, holding the knife in his teeth, used it to cut his coat from his body.', u"Some 56 minutes later, Houdini's wife appeared on stage and gave him a kiss.", u'Many thought that in her mouth was the key to unlock the special handcuffs.', u'However, it has since been suggested that Bess did not in fact enter the stage at all, and that this theory is unlikely due to the size of the 6-inch key Houdini then went back behind the curtain.', u'After an hour and ten minutes, Houdini emerged free.', u'As he was paraded on the shoulders of the cheering crowd, he broke down and wept.', u'Houdini later said it was the most difficult escape of his career.', u"After Houdini's death, his friend Martin Beck was quoted in Will Goldston's book, Sensational Tales of Mystery Men, as admitting that Houdini was bested that day and had appealed to his wife, Bess, for help.", u'Goldston goes on to claim that Bess begged the key from the Mirror representative, then slipped it to Houdini in a glass of water.', u'It was stated in the book The Secret Life of Houdini that the key required to open the specially designed Mirror handcuffs was 6 inches long, and could not have been smuggled to Houdini in a glass of water.', u'Goldston offered no proof of his account, and many modern biographers have found evidence (notably in the custom design of the handcuffs) that the Mirror challenge may have been arranged by Houdini and that his long struggle to escape was pure showmanship.', u"This escape was discussed in depth on the Travel Channel's Mysteries at the Museum in an interview with Houdini expert, magician and escape artist Dorothy Dietrich of Scranton's Houdini Museum.", u'A full-sized design of the same Mirror Handcuffs, as well as a replica of the Bramah style key for it, is on display to the public at The Houdini Museum in Scranton, Pennsylvania.', u'This set of cuffs is believed to be one of only six in the world, some of which are not on display.', u'=== Milk can escape ===\nIn 1908, Houdini introduced his own original act, the milk can escape.', u'In this act, Houdini was handcuffed and sealed inside an oversized milk can filled with water and made his escape behind a curtain.', u'As part of the effect, Houdini invited members of the audience to hold their breath along with him while he was inside the can.', u'Advertised with dramatic posters that proclaimed "Failure Means A Drowning Death," the escape proved to be a sensation.', u'Houdini soon modified the escape to include the milk can being locked inside a wooden chest, being chained or padlocked.', u'Houdini performed the milk can escape as a regular part of his act for only four years, but it has remained one of the acts most associated with him.', u"Houdini's brother, Theodore Hardeen, continued to perform the milk can escape and its wooden chest variant into the 1940s.", u'The American Museum of Magic has the milk can and overboard box used by Houdini.', u'=== Chinese water torture cell ===\n\nAround 1912, the vast number of imitators prompted Houdini to replace his milk can act with the Chinese water torture cell.', u"In this escape, Houdini's feet were locked in stocks, and he was lowered upside down into a tank filled with water.", u'The mahogany and metal cell featured a glass front, through which audiences could clearly see Houdini.', u'The stocks were locked to the top of the cell, and a curtain concealed his escape.', u'In the earliest version of the torture cell, a metal cage was lowered into the cell, and Houdini was enclosed inside that.', u'While making the escape more difficult - the cage prevented Houdini from turning - the cage bars also offered protection should the front glass break.', u'The original cell was built in England, where Houdini first performed the escape for an audience of one person as part of a one-act play he called "Houdini Upside Down."', u'This was so he could copyright the effect and have grounds to sue imitators, which he did.', u'While the escape was advertised as "The Chinese Water Torture Cell" or "The Water Torture Cell," Houdini always referred to it as "the Upside Down" or "USD".', u'The first public performance of the USD was at the Circus Busch in Berlin, on September 21, 1912.', u'Houdini continued to perform the escape until his death in 1926.', u"=== Suspended straitjacket escape ===\nOne of Houdini's most popular publicity stunts was to have himself strapped into a regulation straitjacket and suspended by his ankles from a tall building or crane.", u'Houdini would then make his escape in full view of the assembled crowd.', u'In many cases, Houdini drew tens of thousands of onlookers who brought city traffic to a halt.', u'Houdini would sometimes ensure press coverage by performing the escape from the office building of a local newspaper.', u'In New York City, Houdini performed the suspended straitjacket escape from a crane being used to build the New York subway.', u'After flinging his body in the air, he escaped from the straitjacket.', u'Starting from when he was hoisted up in the air by the crane, to when the straitjacket was completely off, it took him two minutes and thirty-seven seconds.', u'There is film footage in the Library of Congress of Houdini performing the escape.', u'Films of his escapes are also shown at The Houdini Museum in Scranton, PA. After being battered against a building in high winds during one escape, Houdini performed the escape with a visible safety wire on his ankle so that he could be pulled away from the building if necessary.', u"The idea for the upside-down escape was given to Houdini by a young boy named Randolph Osborne Douglas (March 31, 1895 \u2013 December 5, 1956), when the two met at a performance at Sheffield's Empire Theatre.", u"=== Overboard box escape ===\n\nAnother of Houdini's most famous publicity stunts was to escape from a nailed and roped packing crate after it had been lowered into water.", u"Houdini first performed the escape in New York's East River on July 7, 1912.", u'Police forbade him from using one of the piers, so Houdini hired a tugboat and invited press on board.', u'Houdini was locked in handcuffs and leg-irons, then nailed into the crate which was roped and weighed down with two hundred pounds of lead.', u'The crate was then lowered into the water.', u'Houdini escaped in 57 seconds.', u'The crate was pulled to the surface and found still to be intact, with the manacles inside.', u"Houdini performed this escape many times, and even performed a version on stage, first at Hamerstein's Roof Garden where a 5,500-US-gallon (21,000 l) tank was specially built, and later at the New York Hippodrome.", u'=== Buried alive stunt ===\nHoudini performed at least three variations on a buried alive stunt during his career.', u'The first was near Santa Ana, California in 1915, and it almost cost Houdini his life.', u'Houdini was buried, without a casket, in a pit of earth six feet deep.', u'He became exhausted and panicked while trying to dig his way to the surface and called for help.', u'When his hand finally broke the surface, he fell unconscious and had to be pulled from the grave by his assistants.', u'Houdini wrote in his diary that the escape was "very dangerous" and that "the weight of the earth is killing."', u"Houdini's second variation on buried alive was an endurance test designed to expose mystical Egyptian performer Rahman Bey, who had claimed to use supernatural powers to remain in a sealed casket for an hour.", u"Houdini bettered Bey on August 5, 1926, by remaining in a sealed casket, or coffin, submerged in the swimming pool of New York's Hotel Shelton for one and a half hours.", u'Houdini claimed he did not use any trickery or supernatural powers to accomplish this feat, just controlled breathing.', u'He repeated the feat at the YMCA in Worcester, Massachusetts on September 28, 1926, this time remaining sealed for one hour and eleven minutes.', u"Houdini's final buried alive was an elaborate stage escape that featured in his full evening show.", u'Houdini escaped after being strapped in a straitjacket, sealed in a casket, and then buried in a large tank filled with sand.', u'While posters advertising the escape exist (playing off the Bey challenge by boasting "Egyptian Fakirs Outdone!', u'"), it is unclear whether Houdini ever performed buried alive on stage.', u'The stunt was to be the feature escape of his 1927 season, but Houdini died on October 31, 1926.', u"The bronze casket Houdini created for buried alive was used to transport Houdini's body from Detroit to New York following his death on Halloween.", u'== Movie career ==\n\nIn 1906, Houdini started showing films of his outside escapes as part of his vaudeville act.', u'In Boston, he presented a short film called Houdini Defeats Hackenschmidt.', u'Georg Hackenschmidt was a famous wrestler of the day, but the nature of their contest is unknown as the film is lost.', u'In 1909, Houdini made a film in Paris for Cinema Lux titled Merveilleux Exploits du C\xe9l\xe9bre Houdini \xe0 Paris (Marvellous Exploits of the Famous Houdini in Paris).', u"It featured a loose narrative designed to showcase several of Houdini's famous escapes, including his straitjacket and underwater handcuff escapes.", u'That same year Houdini got an offer to star as Captain Nemo in a silent version of 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea, but the project never made it into production.', u'It is often erroneously reported that Houdini served as special-effects consultant on the Wharton/International cliffhanger serial, The Mysteries of Myra, shot in Ithaca, New York, because Harry Grossman, director of The Master Mystery also filmed a serial in Ithaca at about the same time.', u'The consultants on the serial were pioneering Hereward Carrington and Aleister Crowley.', u'In 1918, Houdini signed a contract with film producer B.A.', u'Rolfe to star in a 15-part serial, The Master Mystery (released in January 1919).', u'As was common at the time, the film serial was released simultaneously with a novel.', u'Financial difficulties resulted in B.A.', u'Rolfe Productions going out of business, but The Master Mystery led to Houdini being signed by Famous Players-Lasky Corporation/Paramount Pictures, for whom he made two pictures, The Grim Game (1919) and Terror Island (1920).', u"The Grim Game was Houdini's first full-length movie and is reputed to be his best.", u'Because of the flammable nature of nitrate film and the inherent chemical instability of the acetate "safety" film that supplanted it, only 10 percent of old silent movies exist.', u'Film historians considered the film lost.', u'One copy did exist hidden in the collection of a private collector only known to a tiny group of magicians that saw it.', u'Dick Brookz and Dorothy Dietrich of The Houdini Museum in Scranton, Pennsylvania had seen it twice on the invitation of the collector.', u'After many years of trying, they finally got him to agree to sell the film to Turner Classic Movies who restored the complete 71-minute film.', u'The film, not seen by the general public for 96 years was shown by TCM on March 29, 2015, as a highlight of their yearly 4-day festival in Hollywood.', u'While filming an aerial stunt for The Grim Game, two biplanes collided in mid-air with a stuntman doubling Houdini dangling by a rope from one of the planes.', u'Publicity was geared heavily toward promoting this dramatic "caught on film" moment, claiming it was Houdini himself dangling from the plane.', u'While filming these movies in Los Angeles, Houdini rented a home in Laurel Canyon.', u'Following his two-picture stint in Hollywood, Houdini returned to New York and started his own film production company called the "Houdini Picture Corporation".', u'He produced and starred in two films, The Man from Beyond (1921) and Haldane of the Secret Service (1923).', u'He also founded his own film laboratory business called The Film Development Corporation (FDC), gambling on a new process for developing motion picture film.', u"Houdini's brother, Theodore Hardeen, left his own career as a magician and escape artist to run the company.", u'Magician Harry Kellar was a major investor.', u'Neither Houdini\'s acting career nor FDC found success, and he gave up on the movie business in 1923, complaining that "the profits are too meager".', u"In April 2008, Kino International released a DVD box set of Houdini's surviving silent films, including The Master Mystery, Terror Island, The Man From Beyond, Haldane of the Secret Service, and five minutes from The Grim Game.", u"The set also includes newsreel footage of Houdini's escapes from 1907 to 1923, and a section from Merveilleux Exploits du C\xe9l\xe9bre Houdini \xe0 Paris, although it is not identified as such.", u'== Aviator ==\nIn 1909, Houdini became fascinated with aviation.', u'He purchased a French Voisin biplane for $5,000 and hired a full-time mechanic, Antonio Brassac.', u'After crashing once, he made his first successful flight on November 26 in Hamburg, Germany.', u'The following year, Houdini toured Australia.', u'He brought along his Voisin biplane with the intention to be the first person in Australia to fly.', u'=== Falsely reported as pioneer ===\nOn March 18, 1910, he made three flights at Diggers Rest, Victoria, near Melbourne.', u'It was reported at the time that this was the first aerial flight in Australia, and a century later, some major news outlets still credit him with this feat.', u'Wing Commander Harry Cobby wrote in Aircraft in March 1938 that "the first aeroplane flight in the Southern Hemisphere was made on December 9, 1909 by Mr Colin Defries, a Londoner, at Victoria Park Racecourse, Sydney, in a Wilbur Wright aeroplane".', u'Colin Defries was a trained pilot, having learnt to fly in Cannes, France.', u'By modern standards his flight time was minimal, but in 1909 he had accumulated enough to become an instructor.', u'On his first flight he took off, maintained straight and level flight, albeit briefly, and landed safely.', u'His crash landing on his second flight, when he tried to retrieve his hat which was blown off, demonstrated what a momentary lack of attention could cause while flying a Wright Model A.', u'It is accepted by Australian historians and the Aviation Historical Society of Australia that the definition of flight established by the Gorell Committee on behalf of the Aero Club of Great Britain dictates the acceptance of a flight or its rejection, giving Colin Defries credit as the first to make an aeroplane flight in Australia, and the Southern Hemisphere.', u'Additionally, aviation pioneer Richard Pearse is believed by many New Zealand historians to have undertaken his first flight as early as 1902, which would give him not only the Southern Hemisphere but the World record, although this is disputed.', u'In 1965, aviation journalist Stanley Brogden formed the view that the first powered flight in Australia took place at Bolivar in South Australia; the aircraft was a Bleriot monoplane with Fred Custance as the pilot.', u'The flight took place on March 17, 1910.', u"The next day when Houdini took to the air, the Herald newspaper reported Custance's flight, stating it had lasted 5 minutes 25 seconds at a height of between 12 and 15 feet.", u'In 2010, Australia Post issued stamps commemorating Colin Defries, Houdini and John Robertson Duigan, crediting only Defries and Duigan with historical firsts.', u'Duigan was an Australian pioneer aviator who built and flew the first Australian-made aircraft.', u"Australia Post did acknowledge the part Houdini played (Harry Houdini can't escape being part of Australia's history) but did not attribute any record to him.", u'=== After Australia ===\nAfter completing his Australia tour, Houdini put the Voisin into storage in England.', u'He announced he would use it to fly from city to city during his next Music Hall tour, and even promised to leap from it handcuffed, but he never flew again.', u'== Debunking spiritualists ==\n\nIn the 1920s, Houdini turned his energies toward debunking psychics and mediums, a pursuit that inspired and was followed by latter-day stage magicians.', u"Houdini's training in magic allowed him to expose frauds who had successfully fooled many scientists and academics.", u'He was a member of a Scientific American committee that offered a cash prize to any medium who could successfully demonstrate supernatural abilities.', u'None was able to do so, and the prize was never collected.', u'The first to be tested was medium George Valiantine of Wilkes Barre, Pennsylvania.', u'As his fame as a "ghostbuster" grew, Houdini took to attending s\xe9ances in disguise, accompanied by a reporter and police officer.', u'Possibly the most famous medium whom he debunked was Mina Crandon, also known as "Margery".', u'Joaqu\xedn Argamasilla known as the "Spaniard with X-ray Eyes" claimed to be able to read handwriting or numbers on dice through closed metal boxes.', u'In 1924, he was exposed by Houdini as a fraud.', u'Argamasilla peeked through his simple blindfold and lifted up the edge of the box so he could look inside it without others noticing.', u'Houdini also investigated the Italian medium Nino Pecoraro, whom he considered to be fraudulent.', u"Houdini's exposing of phony mediums has inspired other magicians to follow suit, including The Amazing Randi, Dorothy Dietrich, Penn & Teller, and Dick Brookz.", u'Houdini chronicled his debunking exploits in his book, A Magician Among the Spirits, co-authored with C. M. Eddy, Jr., who was not credited.', u'These activities cost Houdini the friendship of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.', u"Doyle, a firm believer in spiritualism during his later years, refused to believe any of Houdini's expos\xe9s.", u'Doyle came to believe that Houdini was a powerful spiritualist medium, and had performed many of his stunts by means of paranormal abilities and was using these abilities to block those of other mediums that he was "debunking".', u'This disagreement led to the two men becoming public antagonists and led Sir Arthur to view Houdini as a dangerous enemy.', u'Before Houdini died, he and his wife agreed that if Houdini found it possible to communicate after death, he would communicate the message "Rosabelle believe", a secret code which they agreed to use.', u'Rosabelle was their favorite song.', u"Bess held yearly s\xe9ances on Halloween for ten years after Houdini's death.", u'She did claim to have contact through Arthur Ford in 1929 when Ford conveyed the secret code, but Bess later said the incident had been faked.', u'The code seems to have been such that it could be broken by Ford or his associates using existing clues.', u"Evidence to this effect was discovered by Ford's biographer after he died in 1971.", u'In 1936, after a last unsuccessful s\xe9ance on the roof of the Knickerbocker Hotel, she put out the candle that she had kept burning beside a photograph of Houdini since his death.', u'In 1943, Bess said that "ten years is long enough to wait for any man."', u'The tradition of holding a s\xe9ance for Houdini continues, held by magicians throughout the world.', u'The Official Houdini S\xe9ance was organized in the 1940s by Sidney Hollis Radner, a Houdini aficionado from Holyoke, Massachusetts.', u'Yearly Houdini s\xe9ances are also conducted in Chicago at the Excalibur nightclub by "necromancer" Neil Tobin on behalf of the Chicago Assembly of the Society of American Magicians; and at the Houdini Museum in Scranton by magician Dorothy Dietrich, who previously held them at New York\'s Magic Towne House with such magical notables as Houdini biographers Walter B. Gibson and Milbourne Christopher.', u'Gibson was asked by Bess Houdini to carry on the original seance tradition.', u"After doing them for many years at New York's Magic Towne House, before he died, Walter passed on the tradition of conducting of the Original Seances to Dorothy Dietrich.", u'In 1926, Harry Houdini hired H. P. Lovecraft and his friend C. M. Eddy, Jr., to write an entire book about debunking religious miracles, which was to be called The Cancer of Superstition.', u'Houdini had earlier asked Lovecraft to write an article about astrology, for which he paid $75.', u'The article does not survive.', u"Lovecraft's detailed synopsis for Cancer does survive, as do three chapters of the treatise written by Eddy.", u"Houdini's death derailed the plans, as his widow did not wish to pursue the project.", u'== Appearance and voice recordings ==\n\nUnlike the image of the classic magician, Houdini was short and stocky and typically appeared on stage in a long frock coat and tie.', u'Most biographers give his height as 5 ft 5 in, but descriptions vary.', u'Houdini was also said to be slightly bow-legged, which aided in his ability to gain slack during his rope escapes.', u'In the 1997 biography Houdini!!!', u': The Career of Ehrich Weiss, author Kenneth Silverman summarizes how reporters described Houdini\'s appearance during his early career:\n\nThey stressed his smallness\u2014"somewhat undersized"\u2014and angular, vivid features: "He is smooth-shaven with a keen, sharp-chinned, sharp-cheekboned face, bright blue eyes and thick, curly, black hair."', u'Some sensed how much his complexly expressive smile was the outlet of his charismatic stage presence.', u'It communicated to audiences at once warm amiability, pleasure in performing, and, more subtly, imperious self-assurance.', u'Several reporters tried to capture the charming effect, describing him as "happy-looking", "pleasant-faced", "good natured at all times", "the young Hungarian magician with the pleasant smile and easy confidence".', u'Houdini made the only known recordings of his voice on Edison wax cylinders on October 29, 1914, in Flatbush, New York.', u'On them, Houdini practices several different introductory speeches for his famous Chinese water torture cell.', u'He also invites his sister, Gladys, to recite a poem.', u'Houdini then recites the same poem in German.', u'The six wax cylinders were discovered in the collection of magician John Mulholland after his death in 1970.', u'They are part of the David Copperfield collection.', u"== Death ==\n\nHarry Houdini died of peritonitis, secondary to a ruptured appendix at 1:26 p.m. on October 31, 1926 in Room 401 at Detroit's Grace Hospital, aged 52.", u'In his final days, he optimistically held to a strong belief that he would recover, but his last words before dying were reportedly, "I\'m tired of fighting."', u"Eyewitnesses to an incident at Houdini's dressing room in the Princess Theatre in Montreal gave rise to speculation that Houdini's death was caused by a McGill University student, J. Gordon Whitehead, who delivered a surprise attack of multiple blows to Houdini's abdomen.", u'The eyewitnesses, students named Jacques Price and Sam Smilovitz (sometimes called Jack Price and Sam Smiley), proffered accounts of the incident that generally corroborated one another.', u'Price describes Whitehead asking Houdini "if he believed in the miracles of the Bible" and "whether it was true that punches in the stomach did not hurt him".', u'He then delivered "some very hammer-like blows below the belt".', u'Houdini was reclining on a couch at the time, having broken his ankle while performing several days earlier.', u'Price states that Houdini winced at each blow and stopped Whitehead suddenly in the midst of a punch, gesturing that he had enough, and adding that he had no opportunity to prepare himself against the blows, as he did not expect Whitehead to strike him so suddenly and forcefully.', u'Had his ankle not been broken, he would have risen from the couch into a better position to brace himself.', u'Throughout the evening, Houdini performed in great pain.', u'He was unable to sleep and remained in constant pain for the next two days, but did not seek medical help.', u'When he finally saw a doctor, he was found to have a fever of 102 \xb0F (39 \xb0C) and acute appendicitis, and advised to have immediate surgery.', u'He ignored the advice and decided to go on with the show.', u'When Houdini arrived at the Garrick Theater in Detroit, Michigan, on October 24, 1926, for what would be his last performance, he had a fever of 104 \xb0F (40 \xb0C).', u'Despite the diagnosis, Houdini took the stage.', u'He was reported to have passed out during the show, but was revived and continued.', u"Afterwards, he was hospitalized at Detroit's Grace Hospital.", u"It is not entirely clear what relationship the encounter in the dressing room had on Houdini's eventual death.", u'As Snopes points out, the relationship between blunt trauma and appendicitis is not clear.', u'One theory suggests that Houdini was unaware that he was suffering from appendicitis.', u'If he had not realized that his stomach pains were symptomatic of appendicitis, he would not have appreciated the potentially critical effect of the blows to his abdomen.', u"After taking statements from Price and Smilovitz, Houdini's insurance company concluded that the death was due to the dressing-room incident and paid double indemnity.", u"== Houdini grave site ==\nHoudini's funeral was held on November 4, 1926, in New York City, with more than 2,000 mourners in attendance.", u'He was interred in the Machpelah Cemetery in Glendale, Queens, with the crest of the Society of American Magicians inscribed on his grave site.', u'A statuary bust was added to the exedra in 1927, a rarity, because graven images are forbidden in Jewish cemeteries.', u'In 1975, the bust was destroyed by vandals.', u"Temporary busts were placed at the grave until 2011 when a group who came to be called The Houdini Commandos from the Houdini Museum in Scranton, Pennsylvania placed a permanent bust with the permission of Houdini's family and of the cemetery.", u'The Society of American Magicians took responsibility for the upkeep of the site, as Houdini had willed a large sum of money to the organization he had grown from one club to 5,000-6,000 dues-paying membership worldwide.', u"The payment of upkeep was abandoned by the society's dean George Schindler, who said \u201cHoudini paid for perpetual care, but there\u2019s nobody at the cemetery to provide it,\u201d adding that the operator of the cemetery, David Jacobson, \u201csends us a bill for upkeep every year but we never pay it because he never provides any care.\u201d The Society tidies the grave themselves.", u'Machpelah Cemetery operator Jacobson said, they "never paid the cemetery for any restoration of the Houdini family plot in my tenure since 1988," claiming that the money came from the cemetery\'s dwindling funds.', u"The granite monuments of Houdini's sister, Gladys, and brother, Leopold were also destroyed by vandals.", u'For many years, until recently, The Houdini grave site has been only cared for by Dorothy Dietrich and Dick Brookz of the Houdini Museum in Scranton, Pennsylvania.', u"The Society of American Magicians, at its National Council Meeting in Boca Raton, Florida, in 2013, under the prompting of The Houdini Museum's Dorothy Dietrich and Dick Brookz, voted to assume the financial responsibilities for the care and maintenance of the Houdini Gravesite.", u'In MUM Magazine, the Society\'s official magazine, President Dal Sanders announced "Harry Houdini is an icon as revered as Elvis Presley or Marilyn Monroe.', u'He is not only a magical icon; his gravesite bears the seal of The Society of American Magicians.', u'That seal is our brand and we should be proud to protect it.', u'This gravesite is clearly our responsibility and I\u2019m proud to report that the National Council unanimously voted to maintain Houdini\u2019s final resting place."', u'The Houdini Gravesite Restoration Committee under the Chairmanship of National President David Bowers, is working closely with National President Kenrick "Ice" McDonald to see this project to completion.', u'Bowers said it is a foregone conclusion that the Society will approve the funding request, because \u201cHoudini is responsible for the Society of American Magicians being what it is today.', u'We owe a debt of gratitude to him.\u201d Like Bowers, McDonald said the motivation behind the repairs is to properly honor the grave of the \u201cBabe Ruth of magicians.\u201d \u201cThis is hallowed ground,\u201d he said.', u'\u201cWhen you ask people about magicians, the first thing they say is Harry Houdini.\u201d While the actual plot will remain under the control of Machpelah Cemetery management, the Society of American Magicians, with the help of the Houdini Museum in Pennsylvania, will be in charge of the restoration.', u'Magicians Dorothy Dietrich and Dick Brookz have been caring for the escape artist\u2019s Queens grave over the years.', u'\u201cThis is a monument where people go and visit on a daily basis,\u201d said Dietrich who is spearheading restoration efforts.', u'"The nearly 80-year-old popular plot at the Machpelah Cemetery has fallen into disrepair over the years."', u'"The Houdini Museum has teamed with The Society of American Magicians, one of the oldest fraternal magic organizations in the world, to give the beloved site a facelift."', u'The organization has a specific Houdini gravesite committee made up of nine members headed up by President elect David Bowers who brought this project to the Society\u2019s attention.', u'Kenrick \u201cIce\u201d McDonald, the current president of the Society of American Magicians said \u201cYou have to know the history.', u'Houdini served as President from 1917 until his death in 1926.', u'Houdini\u2019s burial site needs an infusion of cash to restore it to its former glory."', u'Magician Dietrich said the repairs could cost \u201ctens of thousands of dollars,\u201d after consulting with glass experts and grave artisans.', u'\u201cIt\u2019s a wonderful project, but it\u2019s taken a lifetime to get people interested,\u201d she said.', u'\u201cIt\u2019s long overdue, and it\u2019s great that it\u2019s happening.\u201d Houdini was a living superhero,\u201d Dietrich said.', u'\u201cHe wasn\u2019t just a magician and escape artist, he was great humanitarian.\u201d\nTo this day, the Society holds a broken wand ceremony at the grave every November.', u"Houdini's widow, Bess, died of a heart attack on February 11, 1943, aged 67, in Needles, California while on a train en route from Los Angeles to New York City.", u'She had expressed a wish to be buried next to her husband, but instead was interred 35 miles due north at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Westchester County, New York, as her Catholic family refused to allow her to be buried in a Jewish cemetery.', u"=== Proposed exhumation ===\nOn March 22, 2007, Houdini's grand-nephew (the grandson of his brother Theo), George Hardeen, announced that the courts would be asked to allow exhumation of Houdini's body, to investigate the possibility of Houdini being murdered by spiritualists, as suggested in the biography The Secret Life of Houdini.", u'In a statement given to the Houdini Museum in Scranton, the family of Bess Houdini opposed the application and suggested it was a publicity ploy for the book.', u'The Washington Post stated that the press conference was not arranged by the family of Houdini.', u'Instead, the Post reported, it was orchestrated by authors Kalush and Sloman, who hired the PR firm Dan Klores Communications to promote their book.', u'In 2008, it was revealed the parties involved never filed legal papers to perform an exhumation.', u"== Legacy ==\n\nHoudini's brother, Theodore Hardeen, who returned to performing after Houdini's death, inherited his brother's effects and props.", u'Houdini\'s will stipulated that all the effects should be "burned and destroyed" upon Hardeen\'s death.', u'Hardeen sold much of the collection to magician and Houdini enthusiast Sidney Hollis Radner during the 1940s, including the water torture cell.', u'Radner allowed choice pieces of the collection to be displayed at The Houdini Magical Hall of Fame in Niagara Falls, Ontario.', u'In 1995, a fire destroyed the museum.', u"The water torture cell's metal frame remained, and it was restored by illusion builder John Gaughan.", u"Many of the props contained in the museum such as the mirror handcuffs, Houdini's original packing crate, a milk can, and a straitjacket, survived the fire and were auctioned in 1999 and 2008.", u'Radner loaned the bulk of his collection for archiving to the Outagamie Museum in Appleton, Wisconsin; but reclaimed it in 2003, and auctioned it in Las Vegas, on October 30, 2004.', u'Houdini was a "formidable collector," and bequeathed many of his holdings and paper archives on magic and spiritualism to the Library of Congress, which became the basis for the Houdini collection in cyberspace.', u"More than half of Houdini's archival estate holdings and memorabilia were willed to his fellow magician and friend, John Mulholland (1898\u20131970).", u"In 1991, illusionist and television performer David Copperfield purchased all of Mulholland's Houdini holdings from Mulholland's estate.", u"These are now archived and preserved in Copperfield's warehouse at his headquarters in Las Vegas.", u"It contains the world's largest collection of Houdini memorabilia, and preserves approximately 80,000 items of memorabilia of Houdini and other magicians, including Houdini's stage props and material, his rebuilt water torture cabinet and his metamorphosis trunk.", u'It is not open to the public, but tours are available by invitation to magicians, scholars, researchers, journalists and serious collectors.', u'In a posthumous ceremony on October 31, 1975, Houdini was given a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame at 7001 Hollywood Blvd.', u'The Houdini Museum in Scranton, Pennsylvania, bills itself as "the only building in the world entirely dedicated to Houdini".', u'It is open to the public year round by reservation.', u"It includes Houdini films, a guided tour about Houdini's life and a stage magic show.", u'Magicians Dorothy Dietrich and Dick Brookz opened the facility in 1991.', u'The Magic Castle, a nightclub for magicians and magic {'sentences': [u'Colbert Dale (Toby) Harrah (born October 26, 1948) is a former professional baseball player who played with the Texas Rangers both before (Washington Senators era) and after their 1971 franchise shift.', u'He also played for the Cleveland Indians and the New York Yankees.', u'In 1992, he briefly served as manager of the Rangers.', u'Harrah most recently served as the assistant hitting coach for the Detroit Tigers.', u'== Playing career ==\nHarrah played high school baseball in his hometown of LaRue, Ohio and was scouted out but was not signed at graduation as most scouts thought he planned to attend college on a baseball scholarship.', u'A few months later, Tony Lucadello followed up and found that Harrah was not attending school, but was instead working in a factory in nearby Marion, Ohio.', u'Lucadello signed Harrah for the Philadelphia Phillies in December, 1966.', u'After one year in the Phillies organization, Harrah was drafted by the Washington Senators in the fall of 1967.', u'He advanced to the major league club in 1971; the next year the franchise relocated and became the Texas Rangers.', u'He was the regular shortstop through 1976, then moved to third base, although he still saw some action at short.', u'He was selected to the American League All-Star team in 1972, 1975, and 1976.', u'He had a career best 93 RBIS in 1975.', u'On June 26, 1976, Harrah played an entire doubleheader at shortstop without recording a single chance in the field.', u'In 1978, Toby was traded to the Cleveland Indians for Buddy Bell, a player thought to be fairly similar in many respects.', u'He was the Indians regular third baseman through 1983 and made the All-Star team in 1982.', u'That year he had 100 runs and a career best .304 batting average.', u'In 1984, Harrah was traded to the New York Yankees, where he was a part-time player, then he was traded again to the Rangers, where he played regularly again for the 1985 and 1986 seasons, primarily at second base.', u'With the retirement of Jeff Burroughs in 1985, Harrah became the last active major leaguer to have played for the Washington Senators franchise.', u'He was also the last player to see a pitch for the Senators in their final game on September 30, 1971 when Tommy McCraw was caught stealing during his plate-appearance for the Senators final out in the bottom of the 8th.', u'Harrah was noted for his good eye at the plate, placing in the top ten in the league for base on balls on nine occasions, including an AL-best 109 in 1977.', u'He finished his career with more base on balls than strikeouts, with 1153 and 868, respectively.', u'He also had better than average power for a defensive infielder, hitting 195 career home runs.', u'Combined with good speed, he accumulated three seasons of 20 home runs and 20 stolen bases.', u"Harrah's on-base skills and respectable slugging ability led to a solid career Adjusted OPS of 114.", u'According to sabermetrician Jay Jaffe of Baseball Prospectus, Harrah is the 25th best third baseman in Major League Baseball history, outpacing several Hall of Famers.', u'Despite his superior statistical accomplishments, Harrah only received a single vote for the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1992, thereby removing his name from future ballots.', u"Harrah's chances for the Hall were seemingly hurt by his multiple position switches: from shortstop, to third base, to second base, and often back and forth.", u'He did not match the awards or "counting stats" (avg, HR, RBI) of well-hitting contemporary shortstops like Cal Ripken Jr. and Barry Larkin, or third baseman such as Wade Boggs or George Brett, all of whom were on their way to HOF careers by the time Harrah was eligible in 1992.', u"Contemporary baseball historians have placed more value on Harrah's career after the fact, noting that he was a solid all-around player who placed among the league leaders in Wins Above Replacement on 5 occasions.", u'In 2009, Harrah was named to the Texas Rangers Hall of Fame.', u'== Coaching career ==\nFollowing his playing career, Harrah moved on to coaching in professional baseball.', u'From 1987\u20131988 he managed the Triple A Oklahoma City 89ers.', u'From 1989\u20131991 he served as the first base coach for the Texas Rangers under manager Bobby Valentine.', u'In 1992 he shifted to bench coach under Valentine then replaced him as manager with 76 games left to go in the season.', u'As interim manager, the Rangers under Harrah went 32-44.', u'In 1995 Harrah managed the Triple A Norfolk Tides to an 86-56 record, finishing in first place in the International League East Division.', u'In 1996 he served as the third base coach for the Cleveland Indians under Mike Hargrove, replacing Buddy Bell, who had been named manager of the Detroit Tigers.', u'In 1997, he served as a minor league hitting coach within the Tigers organization.', u'In 1998 he joined the Tigers major league club as hitting coach, serving under manager Bell and interim manager Larry Parrish, both teammates of Harrah with the Rangers in the mid 1980s.', u'When Bell was hired as the manager of the Colorado Rockies in 2000, Harrah joined him once again by serving as bench coach through the 2002 season.', u'In 2004, Harrah was named minor league hitting coordinator for the Tigers, where he worked with players at all levels as a roving instructor.', u'He remained in that position until part way through the 2012 season.', u'In June 2012, Harrah joined the Detroit Tigers major league coaching staff in an unofficial capacity.', u'Tigers manager Jim Leyland noted that with so many players struggling at once, hitting coach Lloyd McClendon had been stretched thin.', u'The notion of two hitting coaches had been recommended to Leyland by friend and former colleague Tony La Russa.', u'LaRussa had been the first to adopt a two-coach system when he named an assistant hitting coach, (John Mabry), with the St. Louis Cardinals in 2011.', u"In the month following Harrah's arrival, the Tigers offense increased their average runs per game from 4.3 to 5.6.", u'Following the 2012 season, Harrah was officially named assistant hitting coach by the Tigers for the 2013 season.', u'Following the 2013 season and the retirement of Tigers manager Jim Leyland, Harrah was informed that his contract would not be renewed.', u'== See also ==\n\nList of {'sentences': [u'Sir William Huggins OM KCB PRS (7 February 1824 \u2013 12 May 1910) was an English astronomer best known for his pioneering work in astronomical spectroscopy together with his wife Margaret Lindsay Huggins.', u'== Biography ==\n\nWilliam Huggins was born at Cornhill, Middlesex in 1824.', u'In 1875 he married Margaret Lindsay, daughter of John Murray of Dublin, who also had an interest in astronomy and scientific research.', u"She encouraged her husband's photography and helped to put their research on a systematic footing.", u'Huggins built a private observatory at 90 Upper Tulse Hill, London from where he and his wife carried out extensive observations of the spectral emission lines and absorption lines of various celestial objects.', u'On 29 August 1864, Huggins was the first to take the spectrum of a planetary nebula when he analysed NGC 6543.', u'He was also the first to distinguish between nebulae and galaxies by showing that some (like the Orion Nebula) had pure emission spectra characteristic of gas, while others like the Andromeda Galaxy had the spectral characteristics of stars.', u'Huggins was assisted in the analysis of spectra by his neighbour, the chemist William Allen Miller.', u'Huggins was also the first to adopt dry plate photography in imaging astronomical objects.', u'With observations of Sirius showing a redshift in 1868, Huggins hypothesized that a radial velocity of the star could be computed.', u'Huggins won the Gold Medal of the Royal Astronomical Society in 1867, jointly with William Allen Miller.', u'He later served as President of the Royal Astronomical Society from 1876\u20131878, and received the Gold Medal again (this time alone) in 1885.', u'He served as an officer of the Royal Astronomical Society for a total of 37 years, more than any other person.', u'Huggins was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in June 1865, was awarded their Royal Medal (1866), Rumford Medal (1880) and Copley Medal (1898) and delivered their Bakerian Lecture in 1885.', u'He then served as President of the Royal Society from 1900 to 1905.', u'For example, his Presidential Address in 1904 praised the fallen Fellows and distributed the prizes of that year.', u'He died at his home in Tulse Hill, London after an operation for a hernia in 1910 and was buried at Golders Green Cemetery.', u'== Honours and awards ==\nAwards\nRoyal Medal (1866)\nGold Medal of the Royal Astronomical Society (jointly with William Allen Miller in 1867, solo in 1885)\nRumford Medal (1880)\nValz Prize (1882)\nMember of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences (1883)\nKnight Commander of the Order of the Bath (1897)\nCopley Medal (1898)\nHenry Draper Medal from the National Academy of Sciences (1901)\nOrder of Merit (1902)\nBruce Medal (1904)\nNamed after him\nHuggins (lunar crater)\nHuggins (Martian crater)\nAsteroid 2635 Huggins\n\n\n== Publications ==\n\n1870: Spectrum analysis in its application to the heavenly bodies.', u'Manchester, (Science lectures for the people; series 2, no.', u'3)\n1872: (editor) Spectrum analysis in its application to terrestrial substances and the physical constitution of heavenly bodies by H. Schellen, translated by Jane and Caroline Lassell, link from HathiTrust.', u'1899: (with Lady Huggins): An Atlas of Representative Stellar Spectra from \n  \n    \n      \n        \u03bb\n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle \\lambda }\n  4870 to \n  \n    \n      \n        \u03bb\n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle \\lambda }\n  3300, together with a discussion of the evolution order of the stars, and the interpretation of their spectra; preceded by a short history of the observatory.', u"London, (Publications of Sir William Huggins's Observatory; v. 1)\n1906: The Royal Society, or, Science in the state and in the schools.", u'London.', u'1909: The Scientific Papers of Sir William Huggins; edited by Sir William and Lady Huggins.', u"London, (Publications of Sir William Huggins's Observatory; v. 2)\n\n\n== See also ==\nPlanetary nebula#Observations\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== External links ==\n Works written by or about William Huggins at Wikisource\nHuggins, Sir William (1824\u20131910) Barbara J. {'sentences': [u'Fly tying is the process of producing an artificial fly used by fly fishing anglers to catch fish.', u'Helen Shaw, an American professional fly tyer, defined it as the "simple process of binding various materials to a hook with thread".', u'However, thread is no longer always necessary since modern materials such as UV-cured resins can be used to fix the materials to the hook.', u'Fly tying requires some basic equipment, a fly pattern to follow or replicate, and the appropriate materials for the particular fly pattern selected.', u'Fly tying equipment enables the fly tyer to efficiently and effectively assemble and secure the materials on the hook.', u'Fly tying materials were originally limited to various furs, feathers, threads and hooks.', u'Today, many more natural and synthetic materials are used to tie flies.', u'Fly patterns are the instructions or recipe required to create the fly.', u'They specify hook sizes and types, the materials and colors to be used, as well as the sequence to be followed and the assembly methods.', u'There are thousands of possible fly patterns available to the tyer.', u'Hand-tied flies on the commercial market sell for under a US dollar to several US dollars each.', u'Fly tying is a challenging and rewarding hobby for some, a money-saving strategy for others, and a profitable commercial enterprise for the professional tyer.', u'The professional or commercial fly tyer may produce upwards of 36 thousand flies annually, whereas the amateur fly tyer may tie only a few flies each season for personal use.', u'== Approach ==\nSome view fly tying as an art form.', u'E. C. Gregg, in his 1940 publication, stated that "The object of this book will be throughout its entirety to teach in a practical manner the Art of Fly Tying in all its branches."', u'In contrast, A. K. Best suggests practical ways to streamline the tying technique.', u'Best emphasizes that fly tying is not only a handicraft but also a science rooted in carefully observing fish and their prey, and then designing and tying artificial flies to replicate that prey in order to catch fish.', u'One of the first contributions to this approach was made by Preston Jennings in his A Book of Trout Flies.', u'== Fly tying history ==\n\nThe history of fly tying (and fly design) reflects the evolution and history of fly fishing.', u'Basic fly-tying methods have not changed dramatically from the mid-19th century to the present.', u'Most changes resulted from the introduction and adaptation of new materials, especially synthetics, and new hook designs.', u'Images from the early literature devoted to fly tying and fly construction do not show processes significantly different from those used today.', u'The tools associated with fly tying today have, however, evolved along with new technologies.', u'In the mid-19th century flies were tied without benefit of a hook vise.', u'Instead, the hook was held by the fingers as the fly was constructed.', u'The following is from Rod Fishing in Clear Waters (London 1860):\n\nYour materials being now in a state of readiness, the hook must be first tied on with waxed silk to the finest end of the hair or gut left after cutting off the curled end, in this manner (Plate vii.', u'No.', u'1): Take the bend of the hook between your left finger and thumb, the shank projecting; place an end of the waxed silk, which should be about six inches in length, and the end of the gut along the underside of the shank; pass the silk over until you have wrapped it down to the end of the shank, and two or three turns back for the head of the fly; take the feather or hackle as prepared (Plate vii.', u'No.', u'2), put the point of the feather from where it is turned back with the outside next the hook, and hold it there with your left finger and thumb until you pass the silk over it, just where you left off, wrapping it twice or thrice on its downward rounds to the bend of the hook; take your scissors and cut off the root of the feather, and the superfluous gut under the bend of the hook, leaving it not quite so long as the body of the fly has to be made; take the thick end of your feather in your tweezers or pliers and wrap it over three or four times close together, following the silk wrappings until it is all, or as much as you deem sufficient, twirled on; then take your silk and pass over the end once or twice; cut off the superfluous part of the feather and wrap up the shank with the silk, evenly and regularly, to form the body of the fly, and fasten off by a loop-knot or two; or, if you want a thick-bodied fly or one of flossed silk, turn down again and fasten off at the shoulder; cut off the silk left, set the feather right with your needle and finger and thumb, and the fly is made or dressed.', u'This is the simplest method.', u'One of the earliest references to the use of a fly-tying vise is in Ogden on Fly Tying (London, 1887).', u'Other fly-tying tools\u2014scissors, hackle pliers, bodkins, etc.\u2014have remained remarkably similar over the last 120 years.', u'== Imitation of prey ==\nTying artificial flies has always been about imitating some form of fish prey.', u'Significant literature on the concepts of imitation exists especially for trout flies.', u'A Book of Trout Flies \u2013 Jennings (1935), Streamside Guide to Naturals & Their Imitations \u2013 Art Flick (1947), Matching the Hatch \u2013 Schweibert (1955), Selective Trout - Swisher and Richards (1971), Nymphs - Schweibert (1973), Caddisflies - LaFontaine (1989), Prey - Richards (1995) are a few 20th-century titles that deal extensively with imitating natural prey.', u'From a human perspective, many fly patterns do not exactly imitate fish prey found in nature, but they are nevertheless successful.', u'A successful or "killing" fly pattern imitates something that the target species preys on.', u'This has resulted in fly tyers and fishers devising additional terms to characterize those flies that obviously do not imitate anything in particular, yet are nevertheless successful at catching fish.', u'These additional terms are inconsistently but commonly associated with trout-fly patterns because of their huge variety, both historical and contemporary.', u'The term Attractor pattern has been applied to flies which resemble nothing in particular but are successful in attracting strikes from fish (Trout Fishing, Brooks 1972).', u'In Flies for Trout (1993) Dick Stewart characterizes these same patterns as General Purpose.', u'Dave Hughes, in Trout Flies-The Tier\u2019s Reference (1999), describes the same flies as Searching flies and characterizes three levels of imitation: Impressionistic, Suggestive and Imitative.', u'Paul Schullery in American Fly Fishing \u2013 A History (1996) and The Rise (2006) explains that although much has been written about imitation theories of fly design, all successful fly patterns must imitate something to attract the fish to strike.', u'The huge range of fly patterns documented today for all sorts of target species\u2014trout, salmon, bass and panfish, pike, saltwater, tropical exotics, etc.\u2014are not easily categorized as merely imitative, attractors, searching or impressionistic.', u'== Fly tying tools and materials ==\n\n\n=== Tools ===\n\nVarious tools enable and optimize fly tying.', u'Skip Morris, a professional fly tyer, lists the essential tools as being a vise to hold the hook of the fly to be tied, bobbins, a magnifying glass for delicate work, hackle pliers, hackle gauges, lights, hair stackers, and scissors.', u'Other optional tools are pliers, toothpicks, bodkins, dubbing twisters, blenders, floss bobbins, whip finishers, wing burners and bobbin threaders.', u'=== Materials ===\nFly tying material can be anything used to construct a fly on a hook.', u'Traditional materials were threads, yarns, furs, feathers, hair, tinsels, cork, balsa and wire.', u"Today's materials include not only all sorts of natural and dyed furs, hair and feathers, but also a wide array of synthetic materials.", u'Rabbit, mink, muskrat, fox, bear, squirrel and other furs, deer, elk, moose hair and chicken, pheasant, turkey, duck, goose and partridge feathers are commonly incorporated into artificial flies.', u'Chicken neck and saddle hackle, so essential for many artificial fly patterns, are from animals especially bred to produce hackles of superior performance and color.', u'Synthetics have allowed fly tyers to replicate rare and sometimes endangered furs and feathers as well as create completely new types of flies.', u"Synthetics such as rubber legs, plastic wings and transparent plastic cords, chenilles, and all sorts and colors of flashy materials that can be incorporated into the wings and bodies of today's artificial fly are available to the 21st-century fly tyer.", u"Whereas lead wire was the traditional method of weighting flies, today's weighting materials include glass, brass and tungsten beads and cones as well as lead.", u'Silicone, epoxy, kevlar thread and other modern materials are regularly incorporated in artificial fly patterns.', u'=== Hooks ===\nThe hook determines the basic size and shape of each fly and is generally an important part of any fly pattern description.', u'Hooks come in a wide range of size, shape, length and weight, and must be selected to complement the pattern being tied and the method by which it will be fished.', u'Additionally, flies constructed for use in salt water are typically tied on corrosion-resistant hooks.', u'== The fly pattern ==\nThe fly pattern is the recipe for any particularly named fly.', u'In older literature, especially prior to the 20th century, fly patterns were referred to as dressings.', u'The pattern specifies the size range and type of hook to be used, materials including type, color and size, and in some cases specific instructions to achieve a particular effect or configuration.', u'Fly patterns allow tyers to consistently reproduce any given fly over time.', u'A Light Cahill dry fly produced by one tyer will look remarkably similar to the same fly produced by a completely different tyer if the pattern is followed with reasonable accuracy and with comparable materials.', u'Patterns may also lay out alternatives for different materials and variations.', u'Fly patterns are usually found in fly-fishing and fly-tying literature and periodicals, including online sources.', u'Although fly patterns do provide some consistency, different writers may publish patterns with small to moderate differences across pattern descriptions for the same fly.', u'In many cases, greatest differences are in the tying technique rather than in the form, color or materials.', u'Fly patterns may or may not have an image or drawing of the finished fly to guide the tyer.', u'Historically, fly patterns have been included in texts that discuss fishing with a particular genre of fly, fly-fishing technique or fly-fishing for specific species or genre of gamefish.', u'There are, however, texts that are pure fly pattern and tying references with little or no instruction on how to fish them.', u'=== Parts of an artificial fly ===\nSalmon flies have historically been the most complex and gaudy of artificial flies.', u'Texts describing fly tying techniques often use an image of a salmon fly to describe all the parts of an artificial fly.', u'The parts described below are typical.', u'=== Fly names ===\nThere is no convention or consistency in the naming of artificial flies.', u'Long-standing popular patterns have names that have persisted over time.', u'However, fly designers and amateur or professional fly tyers are free to create any fly they choose and to give it any name they want.', u'Angling writers, the popular angling press, and professional fly tackle dealers have always introduced new patterns with new names.', u'The only naming convention is that there is no convention.', u"Flies have been named to honor or celebrate fellow anglers: Royal Wulff, Jock Scott, Quill Gordon, Adams; named to describe their color and composition: Ginger Quill, Gold-ribbed Hare's Ear, Partridge and Orange; named to reflect some regional origin: Bow River Bugger, Tellico nymph, San Juan worm; named to reflect the prey they represent: Golden stone, Blue-wing Olive, Pale Morning Dun, Elk Hair Caddis, White swimming shrimp; named to reflect nothing in particular: Woolly Bugger, Crazy Charlie, Club Sandwich; and, more often than not, named to evoke the designer: Copper John nymph (John Barr), Clouser Deep Minnow (Bob Clouser), Brooks' Montana stone (Charles Brooks), Parks' Salmonfly (Merton Parks), Carey Special (Colonel Carey), Dahlberg Diver (Larry Dahlberg) or Dave's Hopper (Dave Whitlock).", u'The following is an example of how flies get their names and how those names evolve over time.', u"The Coachman\n\nMost famous of all trout flies is the Coachman, originated by Tom Bosworth, who drove Queen Victoria's coach\n\nThe Royal Coachman\n\nThe Royal Coachman was first made by John Haily a professional fly dresser living in New York City.", u'In writing of other matters, he enclosed this fly for us to see, saying "A gentleman wanted me to tie up some Coachman for him to take to the north woods and to make them extra strong, so I have tied them with a little band of silk in the middle to prevent the peacock bodies from fraying out.', u'I have also added a tail of the barred feathers of the wood-duck, and I think it makes a very handsome fly."', u'A few evenings later, a circle of us were together "disputing the fly in question", one of the party claiming that numbers were "quite as suitable to designate the flies as so many nonsensical names".', u'The others did not agree with him, but he said: "What can you do?', u'Here is a fly intended to be a Coachman; but it is not the true Coachman; it is quite unlike it and what can you call it?"', u'Mr. L. C. Orvis, brother of Mr. Charles Orvis, who was present said: "Oh that is easy enough; call it the Royal Coachman it is so finely dressed!"', u'And this name in time came to be known and used by all who are familiar with the fly.', u'The Royal Wulff\n\nI will be forever indebted to Dan [Dan Bailey] for his companionship and inspiration.', u'Indebted, too, because it was Dan who insisted on giving my name to the Wulff Series and gave me stature I might never have had otherwise.', u"We were fishing together on the Esopus in the spring of 1930 when I was trying out some new flies I'd designed in revolt to the then available Catskill patterns.", u'The new flies had bucktail wings and tails for better floatation.', u'I had planned to call one of them the Bucktail Coachman.', u'It was Dan who insisted that I call them Wulffs and he started tying them under that name\u2014 Lee Wulff in the tribute in Mist on the River-Remembrances of Dan Bailey.', u'=== Typical fly patterns or dressing descriptions ===\nThe typical fly pattern appears something like one of the illustrative patterns below for the Adams dry fly (without tying instructions) or the Clouser Deep Minnow (with tying instructions).', u'Based on the fly pattern, a knowledgeable fly tyer can reproduce the fly with the materials specified.', u'=== Fly pattern types ===\nHistorically, fly pattern types have evolved along with fly fishing itself and today there are generally recognized pattern types.', u'However, none are absolute, as there is much crossover in patterns and pattern types.', u'Typically the fly tyer will encounter patterns classified as Dry Flies, Wet Flies, Soft Hackles, Emergers, Nymphs, Terrestrials, Bucktails and Streamers, Salmon (Atlantic) Flies, Steelhead and Salmon (Pacific) Flies, Bass Flies and Bugs, Poppers, Panfish Flies, Saltwater Flies, or Pike Flies.', u'Even within these categories, there can be many sub-categories of imitative and non-imitative flies.', u'== Further guitarist of the Beatles.', u'Often referred to as "the quiet Beatle", Harrison embraced Hindu mythology and helped broaden the horizons of his fellow Beatles as well as their Western audience by incorporating Indian instrumentation in their music.', u"Although most of the Beatles' songs were written by John Lennon and Paul McCartney, most Beatles albums from 1965 onwards contained at least Flown)".', u"Having initiated the band's embracing of Transcendental Meditation in 1967, he subsequently developed an association with the Hare Krishna movement.", u'After the band\'s break-up in
