{'sentences': [u'Japan (Japanese: \u65e5\u672c Nippon [nip\u031ap\xf5\u031e\u0274] or Nihon [nih\xf5\u031e\u0274]; formally \u65e5\u672c\u56fd  Nippon-koku or Nihon-koku, "State of Japan") is an island country in East Asia.', u'Located in the Pacific Ocean, it lies to the east of the Sea of Japan, the East China Sea, China, Korea and Russia, stretching from the Sea of Okhotsk in the north to the East China Sea and Taiwan in the southwest.', u'The kanji that make up Japan\'s name mean "sun origin", and it is often called the "Land of the Rising Sun".', u'Japan is a stratovolcanic archipelago of 6,852 islands.', u"The four largest are Honshu, Hokkaido, Kyushu and Shikoku, which make up about ninety-seven percent of Japan's land area.", u'The country is divided into 47 prefectures in eight regions.', u"The population of 127 million is the world's tenth largest.", u"Japanese people make up 98.5% of Japan's total population.", u'Approximately 9.1 million people live in the core city of Tokyo, the capital of Japan.', u'Archaeological research indicates that Japan was inhabited as early as the Upper Paleolithic period.', u'The first written mention of Japan is in Chinese history texts from the 1st century AD.', u"Influence from other regions, mainly China, followed by periods of isolation, particularly from Western Europe, has characterized Japan's history.", u'From the 12th century until 1868, Japan was ruled by successive feudal military shoguns who ruled in the name of the Emperor.', u'Japan entered into a long period of isolation in the early 17th century, which was ended in 1853 when a United States fleet pressured Japan to open to the West.', u'After nearly two decades of internal conflict and insurrection, the Imperial Court regained its political power in 1868 through the help of several clans from Ch\u014dsh\u016b and Satsuma, and the Empire of Japan was established.', u'In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, victories in the First Sino-Japanese War, the Russo-Japanese War and World War I allowed Japan to expand its empire during a period of increasing militarism.', u'The Second Sino-Japanese War of 1937 expanded into part of World War II in 1941, which came to an end in 1945 following the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.', u'Since adopting its revised constitution in 1947, Japan has maintained a unitary constitutional monarchy with an Emperor and an elected legislature called the National Diet.', u'Japan is a member of the UN, the G7, the G8, and the G20 and is considered a great power.', u"The country has the world's third-largest economy by nominal GDP and the world's fourth-largest economy by purchasing power parity.", u"It is also the world's fourth-largest exporter and fourth-largest importer.", u'The country benefits from a highly skilled workforce and is among the most educated countries in the world with the one of the highest percentage of its citizens holding a tertiary education degree.', u"Although Japan has officially renounced its right to declare war, it maintains a modern military with the world's eighth largest military budget, used for self-defense and peacekeeping roles.", u'Japan is a developed country with a very high standard of living and Human Development Index whose population enjoys the highest life expectancy and the third lowest infant mortality in the world.', u'== Etymology ==\n\nThe Japanese word for Japan is \u65e5\u672c, which is pronounced Nippon or Nihon.', u'The English word Japan possibly derives from the historical Chinese pronunciation of \u65e5\u672c.', u'The Old Mandarin or possibly early Wu Chinese pronunciation of Japan was recorded by Marco Polo as Cipangu.', u'In modern Shanghainese, a Wu dialect, the pronunciation of characters \u65e5\u672c Japan is Zeppen [z\u0259\u0294p\u0259n].', u'The old Malay word for Japan, Jepang, was borrowed from a southern coastal Chinese dialect, probably Fukienese or Ningpo, and this Malay word was encountered by Portuguese traders in Malacca in the 16th century.', u'Early Portuguese traders then brought the word to Europe.', u'An early record of the word in English is in a 1565 letter, spelled Giapan.', u'From the Meiji Restoration until the end of World War II, the full title of Japan was Dai Nippon Teikoku (\u5927\u65e5\u672c\u5e1d\u570b), meaning "the Empire of Great Japan".', u'Today the name Nippon-koku / Nihon-koku (\u65e5\u672c\u56fd) is used as a formal modern-day equivalent simply meaning "the State of Japan"; countries like Japan whose long form does not contain a descriptive designation are generally given a name appended by the character koku (\u56fd), meaning "country", "nation" or "state".', u'The character nichi (\u65e5) means "sun" or "day"; hon (\u672c) means "base" or "origin".', u'The compound means "origin of the sun" or "sunrise", and is the source of the popular Western epithet "Land of the Rising Sun".', u'== History ==\n\n\n=== Prehistory and ancient history ===\n\nA Paleolithic culture around 30,000 BC constitutes the first known habitation of the Japanese archipelago.', u'This was followed from around 14,000 BC (the start of the J\u014dmon period) by a Mesolithic to Neolithic semi-sedentary hunter-gatherer culture, who include ancestors of both the contemporary Ainu people and Yamato people, characterized by pit dwelling and rudimentary agriculture.', u'Decorated clay vessels from this period are some of the oldest surviving examples of pottery in the world.', u'Around 300 BC, the Yayoi people began to enter the Japanese islands, intermingling with the J\u014dmon.', u'The Yayoi period, starting around 500 BC, saw the introduction of practices like wet-rice farming, a new style of pottery, and metallurgy, introduced from China and Korea.', u'Japan first appears in written history in the Chinese Book of Han.', u'According to the Records of the Three Kingdoms, the most powerful kingdom on the archipelago during the 3rd century was called Yamataikoku.', u'Buddhism was first introduced to Japan from Baekje, Korea and was promoted by Prince Sh\u014dtoku, but the subsequent development of Japanese Buddhism was primarily influenced by China.', u'Despite early resistance, Buddhism was promoted by the ruling class and gained widespread acceptance beginning in the Asuka period (592\u2013710).', u'The Nara period (710\u2013784) of the 8th century marked an emergence of the centralized Japanese state centered on the Imperial Court in Heij\u014d-ky\u014d (modern Nara).', u'The Nara period is characterized by the appearance of a nascent literature as well as the development of Buddhist-inspired art and architecture.', u"The smallpox epidemic of 735\u2013737 is believed to have killed as much as one-third of Japan's population.", u'In 784, Emperor Kanmu moved the capital from Nara to Nagaoka-ky\u014d before relocating it to Heian-ky\u014d (modern Kyoto) in 794.', u'This marked the beginning of the Heian period (794\u20131185), during which a distinctly indigenous Japanese culture emerged, noted for its art, poetry and prose.', u'Murasaki Shikibu\'s The Tale of Genji and the lyrics of Japan\'s national anthem "Kimigayo" were written during this time.', u'Buddhism began to spread during the Heian era chiefly through two major sects, Tendai by Saich\u014d, and Shingon by K\u016bkai.', u'Pure Land Buddhism (J\u014ddo-sh\u016b, J\u014ddo Shinsh\u016b) became greatly popular in the latter half of the 11th century.', u"=== Feudal era ===\n\nJapan's feudal era was characterized by the emergence and dominance of a ruling class of warriors, the samurai.", u'In 1185, following the defeat of the Taira clan in the Genpei War, sung in the epic Tale of Heike, samurai Minamoto no Yoritomo was appointed shogun by Emperor Go-Toba, and he established a base of power in Kamakura.', u'After his death, the H\u014dj\u014d clan came to power as regents for the shoguns.', u'The Zen school of Buddhism was introduced from China in the Kamakura period (1185\u20131333) and became popular among the samurai class.', u'The Kamakura shogunate repelled Mongol invasions in 1274 and 1281, but was eventually overthrown by Emperor Go-Daigo.', u'Emperor Go-Daigo was himself defeated by Ashikaga Takauji in 1336.', u'Ashikaga Takauji established the shogunate in Muromachi, Kyoto.', u'This was the start of the Muromachi period (1336\u20131573).', u'The Ashikaga shogunate achieved glory in the age of Ashikaga Yoshimitsu, and the culture based on Zen Buddhism (art of Miyabi) prospered.', u'This evolved to Higashiyama Culture, and prospered until the 16th century.', u'On the other hand, the succeeding Ashikaga shogunate failed to control the feudal warlords (daimyo), and a civil war (the \u014cnin War) began in 1467, opening the century-long Sengoku period ("Warring States").', u'During the 16th century, traders and Jesuit missionaries from Portugal reached Japan for the first time, initiating direct commercial and cultural exchange between Japan and the West.', u'This allowed Oda Nobunaga to obtain European technology and firearms, which he used to conquer many other daimyo.', u'His consolidation of power began what was known as the Azuchi\u2013Momoyama period (1573\u20131603).', u'After he was assassinated in 1582, his successor Toyotomi Hideyoshi unified the nation in 1590 and launched two unsuccessful invasions of Korea in 1592 and 1597.', u"Tokugawa Ieyasu served as regent for Hideyoshi's son and used his position to gain political and military support.", u'When open war broke out, he defeated rival clans in the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600.', u'Tokugawa Ieyasu was appointed shogun by Emperor Go-Y\u014dzei in 1603, and he established the Tokugawa shogunate in Edo (modern Tokyo).', u'The Tokugawa shogunate enacted measures including buke shohatto, as a code of conduct to control the autonomous daimyo; and in 1639, the isolationist sakoku ("closed country") policy that spanned the two and a half centuries of tenuous political unity known as the Edo period (1603\u20131868).', u'The study of Western sciences, known as rangaku, continued through contact with the Dutch enclave at Dejima in Nagasaki.', u'The Edo period also gave rise to kokugaku ("national studies"), the study of Japan by the Japanese.', u'=== Modern era ===\n\nOn March 31, 1854, Commodore Matthew Perry and the "Black Ships" of the United States Navy forced the opening of Japan to the outside world with the Convention of Kanagawa.', u'Subsequent similar treaties with Western countries in the Bakumatsu period brought economic and political crises.', u'The resignation of the shogun led to the Boshin War and the establishment of a centralized state nominally unified under the Emperor (the Meiji Restoration).', u'Adopting Western political, judicial and military institutions, the Cabinet organized the Privy Council, introduced the Meiji Constitution, and assembled the Imperial Diet.', u'The Meiji Restoration transformed the Empire of Japan into an industrialized world power that pursued military conflict to expand its sphere of influence.', u'After victories in the First Sino-Japanese War (1894\u20131895) and the Russo-Japanese War (1904\u20131905), Japan gained control of Taiwan, Korea, and the southern half of Sakhalin.', u"Japan's population grew from 35 million in 1873 to 70 million in 1935.", u'World War I enabled Japan, on the side of the victorious Allies, to widen its influence and territorial holdings in Asia.', u'The early 20th century saw a brief period of "Taish\u014d democracy (1912\u20131926)" but the 1920s saw a fragile democracy buckle under a political shift towards fascism, the passing of laws against political dissent and a series of attempted coups.', u'The subsequent "Sh\u014dwa period" initially saw the power of the military increased and brought about Japanese expansionism and militarization along with the totalitarianism and ultranationalism that are a part of fascist ideology.', u'In 1931 Japan invaded and occupied Manchuria and following international condemnation of this occupation, Japan resigned from the League of Nations in 1933.', u'In 1936, Japan signed the Anti-Comintern Pact with Germany, and the 1940 Tripartite Pact made it one of the Axis Powers.', u'In 1941, following its defeat in the brief Soviet\u2013Japanese Border War, Japan negotiated the Soviet\u2013Japanese Neutrality Pact, which lasted until 1945 with the Soviet invasion of Manchuria.', u'The Empire of Japan invaded other parts of China in 1937, precipitating the Second Sino-Japanese War (1937\u20131945).', u'The Imperial Japanese Army swiftly captured the capital Nanjing and conducted the Nanking Massacre.', u'In 1940, the Empire then invaded French Indochina, after which the United States placed an oil embargo on Japan.', u'On December 7\u20138, 1941, Japanese forces carried out surprise attacks on Pearl Harbor, British forces in Malaya, Singapore, and Hong Kong and declared war on the United States and the British Empire, bringing the US and the UK into World War II in the Pacific.', u'After Allied victories across the Pacific during the next four years, which culminated in the Soviet invasion of Manchuria and the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945, Japan agreed to an unconditional surrender on August 15.', u"The war cost Japan, its colonies, China and the war's other combatants tens of millions of lives and left much of Japan's industry and infrastructure destroyed.", u'The Allies (led by the US) repatriated millions of ethnic Japanese from colonies and military camps throughout Asia, largely eliminating the Japanese empire and restoring the independence of its conquered territories.', u'The Allies also convened the International Military Tribunal for the Far East on May 3, 1946 to prosecute some Japanese leaders for war crimes.', u'However, the bacteriological research units and members of the imperial family involved in the war were exonerated from criminal prosecutions by the Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers despite calls for the trial of both groups.', u'In 1947, Japan adopted a new constitution emphasizing liberal democratic practices.', u'The Allied occupation ended with the Treaty of San Francisco in 1952 and Japan was granted membership in the United Nations in 1956.', u'Japan later achieved rapid growth to become the second-largest economy in the world, until surpassed by China in 2010.', u'This ended in the mid-1990s when Japan suffered a major recession.', u'In the beginning of the 21st century, positive growth has signaled a gradual economic recovery.', u'On March 11, 2011, Japan suffered the strongest earthquake in its recorded history; this triggered the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster, one of the worst disasters in the history of nuclear power.', u'== Geography ==\n\nJapan has a total of 6,852 islands extending along the Pacific coast of East Asia.', u'The country, including all of the islands it controls, lies between latitudes 24\xb0 and 46\xb0N, and longitudes 122\xb0 and 146\xb0E.', u'The main islands, from north to south, are Hokkaido, Honshu, Shikoku and Kyushu.', u'The Ryukyu Islands, which include Okinawa, are a chain to the south of Kyushu.', u'Together they are often known as the Japanese archipelago.', u'About 73 percent of Japan is forested, mountainous, and unsuitable for agricultural, industrial, or residential use.', u'As a result, the habitable zones, mainly located in coastal areas, have extremely high population densities.', u'Japan is one of the most densely populated countries in the world.', u'The islands of Japan are located in a volcanic zone on the Pacific Ring of Fire.', u'They are primarily the result of large oceanic movements occurring over hundreds of millions of years from the mid-Silurian to the Pleistocene as a result of the subduction of the Philippine Sea Plate beneath the continental Amurian Plate and Okinawa Plate to the south, and subduction of the Pacific Plate under the Okhotsk Plate to the north.', u'The Boso Triple Junction off the coast of Japan is a triple junction where the North American Plate, the Pacific Plate and the Philippine Sea Plate meets.', u'Japan was originally attached to the eastern coast of the Eurasian continent.', u'The subducting plates pulled Japan eastward, opening the Sea of Japan around 15 million years ago.', u'Japan has 108 active volcanoes.', u'During the twentieth century several new volcanoes emerged, including Sh\u014dwa-shinzan on Hokkaido and My\u014djin-sh\u014d off the Bayonnaise Rocks in the Pacific.', u'Destructive earthquakes, often resulting in tsunami, occur several times each century.', u'The 1923 Tokyo earthquake killed over 140,000 people.', u'More recent major quakes are the 1995 Great Hanshin earthquake and the 2011 T\u014dhoku earthquake, a 9.0-magnitude quake which hit Japan on March 11, 2011, and triggered a large tsunami.', u'Japan is substantially prone to earthquakes, tsunami and volcanoes due to its location along the Pacific Ring of Fire.', u'It has the 15th highest natural disaster risk as measured in the 2013 World Risk Index.', u'=== Climate ===\n\nThe climate of Japan is predominantly temperate, but varies greatly from north to south.', u"Japan's geographical features divide it into six principal climatic zones: Hokkaido, Sea of Japan, Central Highland, Seto Inland Sea, Pacific Ocean, and Ryukyu Islands.", u'The northernmost zone, Hokkaido, has a humid continental climate with long, cold winters and very warm to cool summers.', u'Precipitation is not heavy, but the islands usually develop deep snowbanks in the winter.', u"In the Sea of Japan zone on Honshu's west coast, northwest winter winds bring heavy snowfall.", u'In the summer, the region is cooler than the Pacific area, though it sometimes experiences extremely hot temperatures because of the foehn.', u'The Central Highland has a typical inland humid continental climate, with large temperature differences between summer and winter seasons, as well as large diurnal variation; precipitation is light, though winters are usually snowy.', u'The mountains of the Ch\u016bgoku and Shikoku regions shelter the Seto Inland Sea from seasonal winds, bringing mild weather year-round.', u'The Pacific coast features a humid subtropical climate that experiences milder winters with occasional snowfall and hot, humid summers because of the southeast seasonal wind.', u'The Ryukyu Islands have a subtropical climate, with warm winters and hot summers.', u'Precipitation is very heavy, especially during the rainy season.', u'The average winter temperature in Japan is 5.1 \xb0C (41.2 \xb0F) and the average summer temperature is 25.2 \xb0C (77.4 \xb0F).', u'The highest temperature ever measured in Japan 40.9 \xb0C (105.6 \xb0F) was recorded on August 16, 2007.', u'The main rainy season begins in early May in Okinawa, and the rain front gradually moves north until reaching Hokkaido in late July.', u'In most of Honshu, the rainy season begins before the middle of June and lasts about six weeks.', u'In late summer and early autumn, typhoons often bring heavy rain.', u'=== Biodiversity ===\n\nJapan has nine forest ecoregions which reflect the climate and geography of the islands.', u'They range from subtropical moist broadleaf forests in the Ry\u016bky\u016b and Bonin Islands, to temperate broadleaf and mixed forests in the mild climate regions of the main islands, to temperate coniferous forests in the cold, winter portions of the northern islands.', u'Japan has over 90,000 species of wildlife, including the brown bear, the Japanese macaque, the Japanese raccoon dog, the Large Japanese Field Mouse, and the Japanese giant salamander.', u'A large network of national parks has been established to protect important areas of flora and fauna as well as thirty-seven Ramsar wetland sites.', u'Four sites have been inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List for their outstanding natural value.', u'=== Environment ===\n\nIn the period of rapid economic growth after World War II, environmental policies were downplayed by the government and industrial corporations; as a result, environmental pollution was widespread in the 1950s and 1960s.', u'Responding to rising concern about the problem, the government introduced several environmental protection laws in 1970.', u"The oil crisis in 1973 also encouraged the efficient use of energy because of Japan's lack of natural resources.", u'Current environmental issues include urban air pollution (NOx, suspended particulate matter, and toxics), waste management, water eutrophication, nature conservation, climate change, chemical management and international co-operation for conservation.', u'As of June 2015, more than 40 coal-fired power plants are planned or under construction in Japan.', u'The NGO Climate Action Network announced Japan as the winner of its "Fossil of the Day" award for "doing the most to block progress on climate action."', u"Japan ranks 39th in the 2016 Environmental Performance Index, which measures a nation's commitment to environmental sustainability.", u'As a signatory of the Kyoto Protocol, and host of the 1997 conference that created it, Japan is under treaty obligation to reduce its carbon dioxide emissions and to take other steps to curb climate change.', u'== Politics ==\n\n\n=== Government ===\n\nJapan is a constitutional monarchy whereby the power of the Emperor is very limited.', u'As a ceremonial figurehead, he is defined by the constitution as "the symbol of the State and of the unity of the people."', u'Power is held chiefly by the Prime Minister and other elected members of the Diet, while sovereignty is vested in the Japanese people.', u'Akihito is the current Emperor of Japan; Naruhito, Crown Prince of Japan, stands as next in line to the Chrysanthemum Throne.', u"Japan's legislative organ is the National Diet, seated in Chiyoda, Tokyo.", u'The Diet is a bicameral body, consisting of a House of Representatives with 480 seats, elected by popular vote every four years or when dissolved, and a House of Councillors of 242 seats, whose popularly elected members serve six-year terms.', u'There is universal suffrage for adults over 18 years of age, with a secret ballot for all elected offices.', u'The Diet is dominated by the social liberal Democratic Party of Japan and the conservative Liberal Democratic Party (LDP).', u'The LDP has enjoyed near continuous electoral success since 1955, except for a brief 11-month period between 1993 and 1994, and from 2009 to 2012.', u'As of September 2016, it holds 291 seats in the lower house and 122 seats in the upper house.', u'The Prime Minister of Japan is the head of government and is appointed by the Emperor after being designated by the Diet from among its members.', u'The Prime Minister is the head of the Cabinet, and he appoints and dismisses the Ministers of State.', u"Following the LDP's landslide victory in the 2012 general election, Shinz\u014d Abe replaced Yoshihiko Noda as the Prime Minister on December 26, 2012 and became the country's sixth prime minister to be sworn in during a span of six years.", u'Although the Prime Minister is formally appointed by the Emperor, the Constitution of Japan explicitly requires the Emperor to appoint whoever is designated by the Diet.', u'Historically influenced by Chinese law, the Japanese legal system developed independently during the Edo period through texts such as Kujikata Osadamegaki.', u'However, since the late 19th century the judicial system has been largely based on the civil law of Europe, notably Germany.', u'For example, in 1896, the Japanese government established a civil code based on a draft of the German B\xfcrgerliches Gesetzbuch; with the code remaining in effect with post\u2013World War II modifications.', u"Statutory law originates in Japan's legislature and has the rubber stamp of the Emperor.", u'The Constitution requires that the Emperor promulgate legislation passed by the Diet, without specifically giving him the power to oppose legislation.', u"Japan's court system is divided into four basic tiers: the Supreme Court and three levels of lower courts.", u'The main body of Japanese statutory law is called the Six Codes.', u'=== Administrative divisions ===\n\nJapan consists of 47 prefectures, each overseen by an elected governor, legislature and administrative bureaucracy.', u'Each prefecture is further divided into cities, towns and villages.', u'The nation is currently undergoing administrative reorganization by merging many of the cities, towns and villages with each other.', u'This process will reduce the number of sub-prefecture administrative regions and is expected to cut administrative costs.', u'=== Foreign relations ===\n\nJapan has diplomatic relations with nearly all independent nations and has been an active member of the UN since December 1956.', u'Japan is a member of the G8, APEC, and "ASEAN Plus Three", and is a participant in the East Asia Summit.', u'Japan signed a security pact with Australia in March 2007 and with India in October 2008.', u"It is the world's fifth largest donor of official development assistance, donating US$9.2 billion in 2014.", u'Japan has close ties to the United States.', u"Since Japan's defeat by the United States in World War II, the two countries have maintained close economic and defense relations.", u'The United States is a major market for Japanese exports and the primary source of Japanese imports, and is committed to defending the country, having military bases in Japan for that purpose.', u"Japan contests Russia's control of the Southern Kuril Islands (including Etorofu, Kunashiri, Shikotan, and the Habomai group) which were occupied by the Soviet Union in 1945.", u'South Korea\'s assertions concerning Liancourt Rocks (Japanese: "Takeshima", Korean: "Dokdo") are acknowledged, but not accepted by Japan.', u"Japan has strained relations with the People's Republic of China (PRC) and the Republic of China (Taiwan) over the Senkaku Islands; and with the People's Republic of China over the status of Okinotorishima.", u"Japan's relationship with South Korea has been strained due to Japan's treatment of Koreans during Japanese colonial rule, particularly over the issue of comfort women.", u'However, in December 2015, Japan and South Korea agreed to settle the issue with Japan issuing a formal apology and taking responsibility for the issue and paying money to the surviving comfort women.', u'== Military ==\n\nJapan maintains one of the largest military budgets of any country in the world.', u"The country's military (the Japan Self-Defense Forces) is restricted by Article 9 of the Japanese Constitution, which renounces Japan's right to declare war or use military force in international disputes.", u"Accordingly, Japan's Self-Defence force is an unusual military that has never fired shots outside Japan.", u'Japan is the highest-ranked Asian country in the Global Peace Index.', u'The military is governed by the Ministry of Defense, and primarily consists of the Japan Ground Self-Defense Force (JGSDF), the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force (JMSDF) and the Japan Air Self-Defense Force (JASDF).', u'The Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force (JMSDF) is a regular participant in RIMPAC maritime exercises.', u"The forces have been recently used in peacekeeping operations; the deployment of troops to Iraq marked the first overseas use of Japan's military since World War II.", u'Japan Business Federation has called on the government to lift the ban on arms exports so that Japan can join multinational projects such as the Joint Strike Fighter.', u'The 21st century is witnessing a rapid change in global power balance along with globalization.', u'The security environment around Japan has become increasingly severe as represented by nuclear and missile development by North Korea.', u'Transnational threats grounded on technological progress including international terrorism and cyber attacks are also increasing their significance.', u'Japan, including its Self Defense Forces, has contributed to the maximum extent possible to the efforts to maintain and restore international peace and security, such as UN peacekeeping operations.', u'Building on the ongoing efforts as a peaceful state, the Government of Japan has been making various efforts on its security policy which include: the establishment of the National Security Council (NSC), the adoption of the National Security Strategy (NSS), and the National Defense Program Guidelines (NDPG).', u'These efforts are made based on the belief that Japan, as a "Proactive Contributor to Peace", needs to contribute more actively to the peace and stability of the region and the international community, while coordinating with other countries including its ally, the United States.', u"Japan has close economic and military relations with the United States; the US-Japan security alliance acts as the cornerstone of the nation's foreign policy.", u'A member state of the United Nations since 1956, Japan has served as a non-permanent Security Council member for a total of 20 years, most recently for 2009 and 2010.', u'It is one of the G4 nations seeking permanent membership in the Security Council.', u'In May 2014, Prime Minister Shinz\u014d Abe said Japan wanted to shed the passiveness it has maintained since the end of World War II and take more responsibility for regional security.', u"He said Japan wanted to play a key role and offered neighboring countries Japan's support.", u'In recent years, they have been engaged in international peacekeeping operations including the UN peacekeeping.', u'Recent tensions, particularly with North Korea, have reignited the debate over the status of the JSDF and its relation to Japanese society.', u'New military guidelines, announced in December 2010, will direct the JSDF away from its Cold War focus on the former Soviet Union to a focus on China, especially regarding the territorial dispute over the Senkaku Islands.', u'== Economy ==\n\nJapan is the third largest national economy in the world, after the United States and China, in terms of nominal GDP, and the fourth largest national economy in the world, after the United States, China and India, in terms of purchasing power parity.', u"As of 2014, Japan's public debt was estimated at more than 200 percent of its annual gross domestic product, the largest of any nation in the world.", u"In August 2011, Moody's rating has cut Japan's long-term sovereign debt rating one notch from Aa3 to Aa2 inline with the size of the country's deficit and borrowing level.", u'The large budget deficits and government debt since the 2009 global recession and followed by the earthquake and tsunami in March 2011 caused the rating downgrade.', u'The service sector accounts for three quarters of the gross domestic product.', u'Japan has a large industrial capacity, and is home to some of the largest and most technologically advanced producers of motor vehicles, electronics, machine tools, steel and nonferrous metals, ships, chemical substances, textiles, and processed foods.', u"Agricultural businesses in Japan cultivate 13 percent of Japan's land, and Japan accounts for nearly 15 percent of the global fish catch, second only to China.", u"As of 2010, Japan's labor force consisted of some 65.9 million workers.", u'Japan has a low unemployment rate of around four percent.', u'Some 20 million people, around 17 per cent of the population, were below the poverty line in 2007.', u'Housing in Japan is characterized by limited land supply in urban areas.', u"Japan's exports amounted to US$4,210 per capita in 2005.", u"As of 2012, Japan's main export markets were China (18.1 percent), the United States (17.8 percent), South Korea (7.7 percent), Thailand (5.5 percent) and Hong Kong (5.1 percent).", u'Its main exports are transportation equipment, motor vehicles, iron and steel products, semiconductors and auto parts.', u"Japan's main import markets as of 2012 were China (21.3 percent), the US (8.8 percent), Australia (6.4 percent), Saudi Arabia (6.2 percent), United Arab Emirates (5.0 percent), South Korea (4.6 percent) and Qatar (4.0 percent).", u"Japan's main imports are machinery and equipment, fossil fuels, foodstuffs (in particular beef), chemicals, textiles and raw materials for its industries.", u'By market share measures, domestic markets are the least open of any OECD country.', u"Junichir\u014d Koizumi's administration began some pro-competition reforms, and foreign investment in Japan has soared.", u'Japan ranks 27th of 189 countries in the 2014 Ease of doing business index and has one of the smallest tax revenues of the developed world.', u'The Japanese variant of capitalism has many distinct features: keiretsu enterprises are influential, and lifetime employment and seniority-based career advancement are relatively common in the Japanese work environment.', u'Japanese companies are known for management methods like "The Toyota Way", and shareholder activism is rare.', u"=== Economic history ===\nModern Japan's economic growth began in the Edo period.", u'Some of the surviving elements of the Edo period are roads and water transportation routes, as well as financial instruments such as futures contracts, banking and insurance of the Osaka rice brokers.', u'During the Meiji period from 1868, Japan expanded economically with the embrace of the market economy.', u"Many of today's enterprises were founded at the time, and Japan emerged as the most developed nation in Asia.", u'The period of overall real economic growth from the 1960s to the 1980s has been called the Japanese post-war economic miracle: it averaged 7.5 percent in the 1960s and 1970s, and 3.2 percent in the 1980s and early 1990s.', u'Growth slowed in the 1990s during the "Lost Decade" due to after-effects of the Japanese asset price bubble and government policies intended to wring speculative excesses from the stock and real estate markets.', u'Efforts to revive economic growth were unsuccessful and further hampered by the global slowdown in 2000.', u'The economy recovered after 2005; GDP growth for that year was 2.8 percent, surpassing the growth rates of the US and European Union during the same period.', u'Today Japan ranks highly for competitiveness and economic freedom.', u'It is ranked sixth in the Global Competitiveness Report for 2015\u20132016.', u"=== Agriculture and fishery ===\n\nThe Japanese agricultural sector accounts for about 1.4% of the total country's GDP.", u"Only 12% of Japan's land is suitable for cultivation.", u'Due to this lack of arable land, a system of terraces is used to farm in small areas.', u"This results in one of the world's highest levels of crop yields per unit area, with an overall agricultural self-sufficiency rate of about 50% on fewer than 56,000 square kilometres (14,000,000 acres) cultivated.", u"Japan's small agricultural sector, however, is also highly subsidized and protected, with government regulations that favor small-scale cultivation instead of large-scale agriculture as practiced in North America.", u'There has been a growing concern about farming as the current farmers are aging with a difficult time finding successors.', u"Rice accounts for almost all of Japan's cereal production.", u'Japan is the second-largest agricultural product importer in the world.', u'Rice, the most protected crop, is subject to tariffs of 777.7%.', u'In 1996, Japan ranked fourth in the world in tonnage of fish caught.', u'Japan captured 4,074,580 metric tons of fish in 2005, down from 4,987,703 tons in 2000, 9,558,615 tons in 1990, 9,864,422 tons in 1980, 8,520,397 tons in 1970, 5,583,796 tons in 1960 and 2,881,855 tons in 1950.', u'In 2003, the total aquaculture production was predicted at 1,301,437 tonnes.', u"In 2010, Japan's total fisheries production was 4,762,469 fish.", u"Offshore fisheries accounted for an average of 50% of the nation's total fish catches in the late 1980s although they experienced repeated ups and downs during that period.", u"Today, Japan maintains one of the world's largest fishing fleets and accounts for nearly 15% of the global catch, prompting some claims that Japan's fishing is leading to depletion in fish stocks such as tuna.", u'Japan has also sparked controversy by supporting quasi-commercial whaling.', u"=== Industry ===\n\nJapan's industrial sector makes up approximately 27.5% of its GDP.", u"Japan's major industries are motor vehicles, electronics, machine tools, metals, ships, chemicals and processed foods; some major Japanese industrial companies include Toyota, Canon Inc., Toshiba and Nippon Steel.", u"Japan is the third largest automobile producer in the world, and is home to Toyota, the world's largest automobile company.", u'The Japanese consumer electronics industry, once considered the strongest in the world, is currently in a state of decline as competition arises in countries like South Korea, the United States and China.', u'However, despite also facing similar competition from South Korea and China, the Japanese shipbuilding industry is expected to remain strong thanks to an increased focus on specialized, high-tech designs.', u"=== Services ===\n\nJapan's service sector accounts for about three-quarters of its total economic output.", u'Banking, insurance, real estate, retailing, transportation, and telecommunications are all major industries, with companies such as Mitsubishi UFJ, Mizuho, NTT, TEPCO, Nomura, Mitsubishi Estate, \xc6ON, Mitsui Sumitomo, Softbank, JR East, Seven & I, KDDI and Japan Airlines listed as some of the largest in the world.', u'Four of the five most circulated newspapers in the world are Japanese newspapers.', u"Japan Post, one of the country's largest providers of savings and insurance services, was slated for privatization by 2015.", u'The six major keiretsus are the Mitsubishi, Sumitomo, Fuyo, Mitsui, Dai-Ichi Kangyo and Sanwa Groups.', u'=== Tourism ===\n\nJapan attracted 19.73 million international tourists in 2015.', u'Japan has 19 World Heritage Sites, including Himeji Castle, Historic Monuments of Ancient Kyoto and Nara.', u"Popular tourist attractions include Tokyo and Hiroshima, Mount Fuji, ski resorts such as Niseko in Hokkaido, Okinawa, riding the shinkansen and taking advantage of Japan's hotel and hotspring network.", u'In inbound tourism, Japan was ranked 16th in the world in 2015.', u'In 2009, the Yomiuri Shimbun published a modern list of famous sights under the name Heisei Hyakkei (the Hundred Views of the Heisei period).', u'The Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report 2015 ranks Japan 9th out of 141 countries overall, which was the best in Asia.', u'Japan gained relatively high scores in almost all aspects, especially health and hygiene, safety and security, cultural resources and business travel.', u'In 2015, 19,737,409 foreign tourists visited Japan.', u"Neighbouring South Korea is Japan's most important source of foreign tourists.", u'In 2010, the 2.4 million arrivals made up 27% of the tourists visiting Japan.', u'Chinese travelers are the highest spenders in Japan by country, spending an estimated 196.4 billion yen (US$2.4 billion) in 2011, or almost a quarter of total expenditure by foreign visitors, according to data from the Japan Tourism Agency.', u'The Japanese government hopes to receive 40 million foreign tourists every year by 2020.', u'== Science and technology ==\n\nJapan is a leading nation in scientific research, particularly in fields related to the natural sciences and engineering.', u'The country ranks second among the most innovative countries in the Bloomberg Innovation Index.', u'Nearly 700,000 researchers share a US$130 billion research and development budget.', u'The amount spent on research and development relative to its gross domestic product third highest in the world.', u'The country is a world leader in fundamental scientific research, having produced twenty-two Nobel laureates in either physics, chemistry or medicine, and three Fields medalists.', u'Japanese scientists and engineers have contributed to the advancement of agricultural sciences, electronics, industrial robotics, optics, chemicals, semiconductors, life sciences and various fields of engineering.', u"Japan leads the world in robotics production and use, possessing more than 20% (300,000 of 1.3 million) of the world's industrial robots as of 2013\u2014though its share was historically even higher, representing one-half of all industrial robots worldwide in 2000.", u'Japan boasts the third highest number of scientists, technicians, and engineers per capita in the world with 83 scientists, technicians, and engineers per 10,000 employees.', u"=== Electronics and automotive engineering ===\n\nThe Japanese electronics and automotive manufacturing industry is well known throughout the world, and the country's electronic and automotive products account for a large share in the global market, compared to a majority of other countries.", u'Brands such as Fujifilm, Sony, Panasonic, Toyota, Nissan, and Honda are internationally famous.', u"It's estimated that 16% of the world's gold and 22% of the world's silver is contained in electronic technology in Japan.", u"Japan has started a project to build the world's fastest supercomputer by the end of 2017.", u"=== Aerospace ===\n\nThe Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) is Japan's space agency; it conducts space, planetary, and aviation research, and leads development of rockets and satellites.", u'It is a participant in the International Space Station: the Japanese Experiment Module (Kibo) was added to the station during Space Shuttle assembly flights in 2008.', u"Japan's plans in space exploration include: launching a space probe to Venus, Akatsuki; developing the Mercury Magnetospheric Orbiter to be launched in 2016; and building a moon base by 2030.", u'On September 14, 2007, it launched lunar explorer SELENE (Selenological and Engineering Explorer) on an H-IIA (Model H2A2022) carrier rocket from Tanegashima Space Center.', u'SELENE is also known as Kaguya, after the lunar princess of The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter.', u'Kaguya is the largest lunar mission since the Apollo program.', u"Its purpose is to gather data on the moon's origin and evolution.", u'It entered a lunar orbit on October 4, flying at an altitude of about 100 km (62 mi).', u"The probe's mission was ended when it was deliberately crashed by JAXA into the Moon on June 11, 2009.", u'=== Nobel laureates ===\n\nJapan has received the most science Nobel prizes in Asia and ranked 8th in the world.', u'Japanese researchers have won several Nobel prizes.', u'Hideki Yukawa, educated at Kyoto University, was awarded the prize for physics in 1949.', u'Sin-Itiro Tomonaga followed in 1965.', u'Solid-state physicist Leo Esaki, educated at the University of Tokyo, received the prize in 1973.', u"Kenichi Fukui of Kyoto University shared the 1981 chemistry prize, and Susumu Tonegawa, also educated at Kyoto University, became Japan's first (and, as of 2007, only) laureate in physiology or medicine in 1987.", u'Japanese chemists took prizes in 2000 and 2001: first Hideki Shirakawa (Tokyo Institute of Technology) and then Ry\u014dji Noyori (Kyoto University).', u'Masatoshi Koshiba (University of Tokyo) and Koichi Tanaka (Tohoku University) won in physics and chemistry, respectively, in 2002.', u'Makoto Kobayashi, Toshihide Masukawa, and Yoichiro Nambu who is an American citizen when awarded, shared the physics prize and Osamu Shimomura also won the chemistry prize in 2008.', u'Isamu Akasaki, Hiroshi Amano, Shuji Nakamura, who is an American citizen when awarded, shared the physics prize in 2014, and the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded to Yoshinori Ohsumi in 2016.', u"== Infrastructure ==\n\n\n=== Transportation ===\n\nJapan's road spending has been extensive.", u'Its 1.2 million kilometres (0.75 million miles) of paved road are the main means of transportation.', u'As of April 2012 Japan has approximately 1,215,000 kilometres (134,000 miles) of roads made up of 1,022,000 kilometres (14,000 miles) of city, town and village roads, 129,000 kilometres (80,000 miles) of prefectural roads, 55,000 kilometres (34,000 miles) of general national highways and 8,050 kilometres (5,000 miles) of national expressways.', u'The Foreign Press Center/Japan cites a total length of expressways at 7,641 kilometres (4,748 miles) (fiscal 2008).', u'A single network of high-speed, divided, limited-access toll roads connects major cities on Honshu, Shikoku and Kyushu.', u'Hokkaido has a separate network, and Okinawa Island has a highway of this type.', u'A single network of high-speed, divided, limited-access toll roads connects major cities and is operated by toll-collecting enterprises.', u'New and used cars are inexpensive; car ownership fees and fuel levies are used to promote energy efficiency.', u'However, at just 50 percent of all distance traveled, car usage is the lowest of all G8 countries.', u'Since privatisation in 1987, dozens of Japanese railway companies compete in regional and local passenger transportation markets; major companies include seven JR enterprises, Kintetsu, Seibu Railway and Keio Corporation.', u'Some 250 high-speed Shinkansen trains connect major cities and Japanese trains are known for their safety and punctuality.', u'Proposals for a new Maglev route between Tokyo and Osaka are at an advanced stage.', u"There are 175 airports in Japan; the largest domestic airport, Haneda Airport, is Asia's second-busiest airport.", u'The largest international gateways are Narita International Airport, Kansai International Airport and Ch\u016bbu Centrair International Airport.', u"Nagoya Port is the country's largest and busiest port, accounting for 10 percent of Japan's trade value.", u'=== Energy ===\n\nAs of 2011, 46.1% of energy in Japan was produced from petroleum, 21.3% from coal, 21.4% from natural gas, 4.0% from nuclear power, and 3.3% from hydropower.', u"Nuclear power produced 9.2 percent of Japan's electricity, as of 2011, down from 24.9 percent the previous year.", u"However, by May 2012 all of the country's nuclear power plants had been taken offline because of ongoing public opposition following the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster in March 2011, though government officials continued to try to sway public opinion in favor of returning at least some of Japan's 50 nuclear reactors to service.", u'As of November 2014, two reactors at Sendai are likely to restart in early 2015.', u'Japan lacks significant domestic reserves and so has a heavy dependence on imported energy.', u'Japan has therefore aimed to diversify its sources and maintain high levels of energy efficiency.', u'=== Water supply and sanitation ===\n\nThe government took responsibility for regulating the water and sanitation sector is shared between the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare in charge of water supply for domestic use; the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism in charge of water resources development as well as sanitation; the Ministry of the Environment in charge of ambient water quality and environmental preservation; and the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications in charge of performance benchmarking of utilities.', u'Access to an improved water source is universal in Japan.', u'97% of the population receives piped water supply from public utilities and 3% receive water from their own wells or unregulated small systems, mainly in rural areas.', u'Access to improved sanitation is also universal, either through sewers or on-site sanitation.', u'All collected waste water is treated at secondary-level treatment plants.', u'All effluents discharged to closed or semi-closed water bodies, such as Tokyo Bay, Osaka Bay, or Lake Biwa, are further treated to tertiary level.', u'This applies to about 15% of waste water.', u'The effluent quality is remarkably good at 3\u201310 mg/l of BOD for secondary-level treatment, well below the national effluent standard of 20 mg/l.', u'Water supply and sanitation in Japan is facing some challenges, such as a decreasing population, declining investment, fiscal constraints, ageing facilities, an ageing workforce, a fragmentation of service provision among thousands of municipal utilities, and the vulnerability of parts of the country to droughts that are expected to become more frequent due to climate change.', u"== Demographics ==\n\n\n=== Population ===\nJapan's population is estimated at around 127 million, with 80% of the population living on Honsh\u016b.", u'Japanese society is linguistically and culturally homogeneous, composed of 98.5% ethnic Japanese, with small populations of foreign workers.', u'Zainichi Koreans, Chinese, Filipinos, Brazilians mostly of Japanese descent, Peruvians mostly of Japanese descent and Americans are among the small minority groups in Japan.', u'In 2003, there were about 134,700 non-Latin American Western (not including more than 33,000 American military personnel and their dependents stationed throughout the country) and 345,500 Latin American expatriates, 274,700 of whom were Brazilians (said to be primarily Japanese descendants, or nikkeijin, along with their spouses), the largest community of Westerners.', u'The most dominant native ethnic group is the Yamato people; primary minority groups include the indigenous Ainu and Ryukyuan peoples, as well as social minority groups like the burakumin.', u'There are persons of mixed ancestry incorporated among the Yamato, such as those from Ogasawara Archipelago.', u'In 2014, foreign-born non-naturalized workers made up only 1.5% of the total population.', u'Japan is widely regarded as ethnically homogeneous, and does not compile ethnicity or race statistics for Japanese nationals; however, at least one analysis describes Japan as a multiethnic society.', u'Most Japanese continue to see Japan as a monocultural society.', u'Former Japanese Prime Minister and current Finance Minister Tar\u014d As\u014d described Japan as being a nation of "one race, one civilization, one language and one culture", which drew criticism from representatives of ethnic minorities such as the Ainu.', u'Japan has the second longest overall life expectancy at birth of any country in the world: 83.5 years for persons born in the period 2010\u20132015.', u'The Japanese population is rapidly aging as a result of a post\u2013World War II baby boom followed by a decrease in birth rates.', u'In 2012, about 24.1 percent of the population was over 65, and the proportion is projected to rise to almost 40 percent by 2050.', u'=== Religion ===\n\nJapan has full religious freedom based on Article 20 of its Constitution.', u'Upper estimates suggest that 84\u201396 percent of the Japanese population subscribe to Shinto as its indigenous religion (50% to 80% of which considering degrees of syncretism with Buddhism, shinbutsu-sh\u016bg\u014d).', u'However, these estimates are based on people affiliated with a temple, rather than the number of true believers.', u'The number of Shinto shrines in Japan is estimated to be around 100,000.', u'Other studies have suggested that only 30 percent of the population identify themselves as belonging to a religion.', u'According to Edwin Reischauer and Marius Jansen, some 70\u201380% of the Japanese do not consider themselves believers in any religion.', u'Nevertheless, the level of participation remains high, especially during festivals and occasions such as the first shrine visit of the New Year.', u'Taoism and Confucianism from China have also influenced Japanese beliefs and customs.', u'Japanese streets are decorated on Tanabata, Obon and Christmas.', u'Shinto is the largest religion in Japan, practiced by nearly 80% of the population, yet only a small percentage of these identify themselves as "Shintoists" in surveys.', u'This is due to the fact that "Shinto" has different meanings in Japan: most of the Japanese attend Shinto shrines and beseech kami without belonging to Shinto organisations, and since there are no formal rituals to become a member of folk "Shinto", "Shinto membership" is often estimated counting those who join organised Shinto sects.', u'Shinto has 100,000 shrines and 78,890 priests in the country.', u'Buddhism first arrived in Japan in the 6th century; it was introduced in the year 538 or 552 from the kingdom of Baekje in Korea.', u'Christianity was first introduced into Japan by Jesuit missions starting in 1549.', u'Today, fewer than 1% to 2.3% are Christians.', u"Most of them living in the western part of the country, where the missionaries' activities were greatest during the 16th century.", u'Nagasaki Prefecture has the highest percentage of Christians: about 5.1% in 1996.', u'As of 2007 there are 32,036 Christian priests and pastors in Japan.', u"Throughout the latest century, some Western customs originally related to Christianity (including Western style weddings, Valentine's Day and Christmas) have become popular as secular customs among many Japanese.", u'Islam in Japan is mostly represented by small immigrant communities from other parts of Asia.', u'In 2008, Keiko Sakurai estimated that 80\u201390% of the Muslims in Japan were foreign born migrants primarily from Indonesia, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Iran.', u'It has been estimated that the Muslim immigrant population amounts to 70,000\u2013100,000 people, while the "estimated number of Japanese Muslims ranges from thousands to tens of thousands".', u'Other minority religions include Hinduism, Sikhism, and Judaism, and since the mid-19th century numerous new religious movements have emerged in Japan.', u'=== Languages ===\n\nMore than 99 percent of the population speaks Japanese as their first language.', u'Japanese is an agglutinative language distinguished by a system of honorifics reflecting the hierarchical nature of Japanese society, with verb forms and particular vocabulary indicating the relative status of speaker and listener.', u'Japanese writing uses kanji (Chinese characters) and two sets of kana (syllabaries based on cursive script and radical of kanji), as well as the Latin alphabet and Arabic numerals.', u'Besides Japanese, the Ryukyuan languages (Amami, Kunigami, Okinawan, Miyako, Yaeyama, Yonaguni), also part of the Japonic language family, are spoken in the Ryukyu Islands chain.', u'Few children learn these languages, but in recent years the local governments have sought to increase awareness of the traditional languages.', u'The Okinawan Japanese dialect is also spoken in the region.', u'The Ainu language, which has no proven relationship to Japanese or any other language, is moribund, with only a few elderly native speakers remaining in Hokkaido.', u'Public and private schools generally require students to take Japanese language classes as well as English language courses.', u'=== Problems ===\nThe changes in demographic structure have created a number of social issues, particularly a potential decline in workforce population and increase in the cost of social security benefits like the public pension plan.', u'A growing number of younger Japanese are not marrying or remain childless.', u"In 2011, Japan's population dropped for a fifth year, falling by 204,000 people to 126.24 million people.", u'This was the greatest decline since at least 1947, when comparable figures were first compiled.', u'This decline was made worse by the March 11 earthquake and tsunami, which killed nearly 16,000 people with approximately another 2,600 still listed as missing as of 2014.', u"Japan's population is expected to drop to 95 million by 2050; demographers and government planners are currently in a heated debate over how to cope with this problem.", u"Immigration and birth incentives are sometimes suggested as a solution to provide younger workers to support the nation's aging population.", u'Japan accepts a steady flow of 15,000 new Japanese citizens by naturalization (\u5e30\u5316) per year.', u'According to the UNHCR, in 2012 Japan accepted just 18 refugees for resettlement, while the US took in 76,000.', u'Japan suffers from a high suicide rate.', u'In 2009, the number of suicides exceeded 30,000 for the twelfth straight year.', u'Suicide is the leading cause of death for people under 30.', u'== Education ==\n\nPrimary schools, secondary schools and universities were introduced in 1872 as a result of the Meiji Restoration.', u'Since 1947, compulsory education in Japan comprises elementary and middle school, which together last for nine years (from age 6 to age 15).', u'Almost all children continue their education at a three-year senior high school.', u"Japan's education system played a central part in the country's recovery and rapid economic growth in the decades following the end of World War II.", u'After World War II, the Fundamental Law of Education and the School Education Law were enacted.', u'The latter law defined the school system that would be in effect for many decades: six years of elementary school, three years of junior high school, three years of high school, and two or four years of university.', u'Starting in April 2016, various schools began the academic year with elementary school and junior high school integrated into one nine-year compulsory schooling program, in hopes to mitigate bullying and truancy; MEXT plans for this approach to be adopted nationwide in the coming years.', u'In Japan, having a strong educational background greatly improves the likelihood of finding a job and earning enough money to support oneself.', u'Highly educated individuals are less affected by unemployment trends as higher levels of educational attainment make an individual more attractive in the workforce.', u'The lifetime earnings also increase with each level of education attained.', u"Furthermore, skills needed in the modern 21st century labor market are becoming more knowledge-based and strong aptitude in science and mathematics are more strong predictors of employment prospects in Japan's highly technological economy.", u'Japan is one of the top-performing OECD countries in reading literacy, maths and sciences with the average student scoring 540 and has one of the worlds highest-educated labor forces among OECD countries.', u"The Japanese populace is well educated and its society highly values education as a platform for social mobility and for gaining employment in the country's competitive high-tech economy.", u"The country's large pool of highly educated and skilled individuals is largely responsible for ushering Japan\u2019s post-war economic growth.", u"Tertiary-educated adults in Japan, particularly graduates in sciences and engineering benefit economically and socially from their education and skills in the country's high tech economy.", u'Spending on education as a proportion of GDP is below the OECD average.', u'Although expenditure per student is comparatively high in Japan, total expenditure relative to GDP remains small.', u'In 2015, Japan\u2019s public spending on education amounted to just 3.5 percent of its GDP, below the OECD average of 4.7%.', u'In 2014, the country ranked fourth for the percentage of 25- to 64-year-olds that have attained tertiary education with 48 percent.', u"In addition, bachelor's degrees are held by 59 percent of Japanese aged 25\u201334, the second most in the OECD after South Korea.", u'As the Japanese economy is largely scientific and technological based, the labor market demands people who have achieved some form of higher education, particularly related to science and engineering in order to gain a competitive edge when searching for employment opportunities.', u'About 75.9 percent of high school graduates attended a university, junior college, trade school, or other higher education institution.', u'The two top-ranking universities in Japan are the University of Tokyo and Kyoto University.', u'The Programme for International Student Assessment coordinated by the OECD currently ranks the overall knowledge and skills of Japanese 15-year-olds as sixth best in the world.', u'== Health ==\n\nIn Japan, health care is provided by national and local governments.', u'Payment for personal medical services is offered through a universal health insurance system that provides relative equality of access, with fees set by a government committee.', u'People without insurance through employers can participate in a national health insurance program administered by local governments.', u'Since 1973, all elderly persons have been covered by government-sponsored insurance.', u'Patients are free to select the physicians or facilities of their choice.', u'== Culture ==\n\nJapanese culture has evolved greatly from its origins.', u'Contemporary culture combines influences from Asia, Europe and North America.', u'Traditional Japanese arts include crafts such as ceramics, textiles, lacquerware, swords and dolls; performances of bunraku, kabuki, noh, dance, and rakugo; and other practices, the tea ceremony, ikebana, martial arts, calligraphy, origami, onsen, Geisha and games.', u'Japan has a developed system for the protection and promotion of both tangible and intangible Cultural Properties and National Treasures.', u'Nineteen sites have been inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List, fifteen of which are of cultural significance.', u'=== Architecture ===\n\nJapanese architecture is a combination between local and other influences.', u'It has traditionally been typified by wooden structures, elevated slightly off the ground, with tiled or thatched roofs.', u'Sliding doors (fusuma) were used in place of walls, allowing the internal configuration of a space to be customized for different occasions.', u'People usually sat on cushions or otherwise on the floor, traditionally; chairs and high tables were not widely used until the 20th century.', u'Since the 19th century, however, Japan has incorporated much of Western, modern, and post-modern architecture into construction and design, and is today a leader in cutting-edge architectural design and technology.', u'The introduction of Buddhism during the sixth century was a catalyst for large-scale temple building using complicated techniques in wood.', u'Influence from the Chinese Tang and Sui Dynasties led to the foundation of the first permanent capital in Nara.', u"Its checkerboard street layout used the Chinese capital of Chang'an as a template for its design.", u'A gradual increase in the size of buildings led to standard units of measurement as well as refinements in layout and garden design.', u'The introduction of the tea ceremony emphasised simplicity and modest design as a counterpoint to the excesses of the aristocracy.', u'During the Meiji Restoration of 1868 the history of Japanese architecture was radically changed by two important events.', u'The first was the Kami and Buddhas Separation Act of 1868, which formally separated Buddhism from Shinto and Buddhist temples from Shinto shrines, breaking an association between the two which had lasted well over a thousand years.', u'Second, it was then that Japan underwent a period of intense Westernization in order to compete with other developed countries.', u'Initially architects and styles from abroad were imported to Japan but gradually the country taught its own architects and began to express its own style.', u'Architects returning from study with western architects introduced the International Style of modernism into Japan.', u'However, it was not until after the Second World War that Japanese architects made an impression on the international scene, firstly with the work of architects like Kenzo Tange and then with theoretical movements like Metabolism.', u'=== Art ===\n\nThe Shrines of Ise have been celebrated as the prototype of Japanese architecture.', u'Largely of wood, traditional housing and many temple buildings see the use of tatami mats and sliding doors that break down the distinction between rooms and indoor and outdoor space.', u'Japanese sculpture, largely of wood, and Japanese painting are among the oldest of the Japanese arts, with early figurative paintings dating back to at least 300 BC.', u'The history of Japanese painting exhibits synthesis and competition between native Japanese aesthetics and adaptation of imported ideas.', u'The interaction between Japanese and European art has been significant: for example ukiyo-e prints, which began to be exported in the 19th century in the movement known as Japonism, had a significant influence on the development of modern art in the West, most notably on post-Impressionism.', u'Famous ukiyo-e artists include Hokusai and Hiroshige.', u'Hokusai coined the term manga.', u'Japanese comics now known as manga developed in the 20th century and have become popular worldwide.', u'Japanese animation is called anime.', u'Japanese-made video game consoles have been popular since the 1980s.', u'=== Music ===\n\nJapanese music is eclectic and diverse.', u'Many instruments, such as the koto, were introduced in the 9th and 10th centuries.', u'The accompanied recitative of the Noh drama dates from the 14th century and the popular folk music, with the guitar-like shamisen, from the sixteenth.', u'Western classical music, introduced in the late 19th century, now forms an integral part of Japanese culture.', u'The imperial court ensemble Gagaku has influenced the work of some modern Western composers.', u'Notable classical composers from Japan include Toru Takemitsu and Rentar\u014d Taki.', u'Popular music in post-war Japan has been heavily influenced by American and European trends, which has led to the evolution of J-pop, or Japanese popular music.', u'Karaoke is the most widely practiced cultural activity in Japan.', u'A 1993 survey by the Cultural Affairs Agency found that more Japanese had sung karaoke that year than had participated in traditional pursuits such as flower arranging (ikebana) or tea ceremonies.', u"=== Literature ===\n\nThe earliest works of Japanese literature include the Kojiki and Nihon Shoki chronicles and the Man'y\u014dsh\u016b poetry anthology, all from the 8th century and written in Chinese characters.", u'In the early Heian period, the system of phonograms known as kana (Hiragana and Katakana) was developed.', u'The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter is considered the oldest Japanese narrative.', u"An account of Heian court life is given in The Pillow Book by Sei Sh\u014dnagon, while The Tale of Genji by Murasaki Shikibu is often described as the world's first novel.", u'During the Edo period, the ch\u014dnin ("townspeople") overtook the samurai aristocracy as producers and consumers of literature.', u'The popularity of the works of Saikaku, for example, reveals this change in readership and authorship, while Bash\u014d revivified the poetic tradition of the Kokinsh\u016b with his haikai (haiku) and wrote the poetic travelogue Oku no Hosomichi.', u'The Meiji era saw the decline of traditional literary forms as Japanese literature integrated Western influences.', u'Natsume S\u014dseki and Mori \u014cgai were the first "modern" novelists of Japan, followed by Ry\u016bnosuke Akutagawa, Jun\'ichir\u014d Tanizaki, Yukio Mishima and, more recently, Haruki Murakami.', u'Japan has two Nobel Prize-winning authors\u2014Yasunari Kawabata (1968) and Kenzabur\u014d \u014ce (1994).', u'=== Philosophy ===\n\nJapanese Philosophy has historically been a fusion of both foreign; particularly Chinese and Western, and uniquely Japanese elements.', u'In its literary forms, Japanese philosophy began about fourteen centuries ago.', u'Archaeological evidence and early historical accounts suggest that Japan was originally an animistic culture, which viewed the world as infused with kami (\u795e) or sacred presence as taught by Shinto, though it is not a philosophy as such, but has greatly influenced all other philosophies in their Japanese interpretations.', u'Confucianism entered Japan from China around the 5th century A.D., as did Buddhism.', u'Confucian ideals are still evident today in the Japanese concept of society and the self, and in the organization of the government and the structure of society.', u'Buddhism has profoundly impacted Japanese psychology, metaphysics, and aesthetics.', u'Neo-Confucianism, which became prominent in the sixteenth century during the Tokugawa era, shaped Japanese ideas of virtue and social responsibility, and, through its emphasis on investigating the principle or configuration of things, stimulated the Japanese study of the natural world.', u'Also since the 16th century, certain indigenous ideas of loyalty and honour have been held.', u'Western philosophy has had its major impact in Japan only since the middle of the 19th century.', u'=== Cuisine ===\n\nJapanese cuisine is based on combining staple foods, typically Japanese rice or noodles, with a soup and okazu\u2014dishes made from fish, vegetable, tofu and the like\u2014to add flavor to the staple food.', u'In the early modern era ingredients such as red meats that had previously not been widely used in Japan were introduced.', u'Japanese cuisine is known for its emphasis on seasonality of food, quality of ingredients and presentation.', u'Japanese cuisine offers a vast array of regional specialties that use traditional recipes and local ingredients.', u'The phrase ichij\u016b-sansai (\u4e00\u6c41\u4e09\u83dc, "one soup, three sides") refers to the makeup of a typical meal served, but has roots in classic kaiseki, honzen, and y\u016bsoku cuisine.', u'The term is also used to describe the first course served in standard kaiseki cuisine nowadays.', u'Traditional Japanese sweets are known as wagashi.', u'Ingredients such as red bean paste and mochi are used.', u'More modern-day tastes includes green tea ice cream, a very popular flavor.', u'Almost all manufacturers produce a version of it.', u'Kakigori is a shaved ice dessert flavored with syrup or condensed milk.', u'It is usually sold and eaten at summer festivals.', Holidays ===\n\nOfficially, Japan has 15 national, government-recognized holidays.', u'Public holidays in Japan are regulated under the Public Holiday Law moved a number of national holidays to Monday in order to obtain a long weekend.', u'In 2006, the country decided to add Sh\u014dwa Day, a new national holiday, in place of Greenery Day on April 29, Sh\u014dwa Day on April 29, Constitution Memorial Day on May 3, Greenery Day on May 4, Children's Day on May 5, Marine Day on Third Monday of July, Mountain Day on August 11, Respect for the Aged Day on Third Monday of September, Autumnal Equinox on September 23 or 24, Health and Sports Day on Second Monday of October, Culture Day on November 3, Labour Thanksgiving Day on November 23, and The Emperor's Birthday on December 23.", u'=== Festivals ===\n\nThere are many festivals in Japan, which are called in Japanese as matsuri (\u796d) which celebrate annually.', u'There are no specific festival days for all of Japan; dates vary from area to area, and even within a specific area, but festival days do tend to cluster around traditional holidays such as Setsubun or Obon.', u'Festivals are often based around one event, with food stalls, entertainment, and carnival games to keep people entertained.', u'Its usually sponsored by a local shrine or temple, though they can be secular.', u'Notable festival often feature processions which may include elaborate floats.', u'Preparation for these processions is usually organised at the level of neighborhoods, or machi (\u753a).', u'Prior television changed with the emergence of commercial news broadcasting in the mid-1980s.', u"Over the last decade, television has clearly come to surpass newspapers as Japan's main information and {'sentences': [u'The Cherokee Outlet, often mistakenly referred to as the Cherokee Strip, was located in what is now the state of Oklahoma, in the United States.', u'It was a sixty-mile (97 km) wide strip of land south of the Oklahoma-Kansas border between the 96th and 100th meridians.', u'It was about 225 miles (362 km) long and in 1891 contained 8,144,682.91 acres (32,960 km\xb2).', u'Enid and Woodward fall within the historical boundaries of the Cherokee Outlet.', u'The Cherokee Strip was a two-mile strip running along the northern border of much of the Cherokee Outlet, and it was the result of a surveying error.', u'This section of land was known as the Cherokee Strip but the term has often been applied to the whole of the Cherokee Outlet.', u'== Formation ==\nThe Treaty of New Echota assigned the Cherokee Outlet, along with other lands, to the Cherokee Nation.', u'Ratified on May 23, 1836, it was to be a perpetual outlet to use for passage to travel and hunt in the West from their reservation in the eastern part of what became Oklahoma.', u'This was in addition to the land given to the Cherokees for settlement after their arrival from their home in Georgia.', u'== Loss of Cherokee control ==\nAfter the Civil War, the United States required a new peace treaty (see Reconstruction Treaties) with the people of the Cherokee Nation due to their alliance with the Confederacy.', u'The new treaty (ratified on July 19, 1866) allowed the United States government to dispose of the land in the Cherokee Outlet: "The United States may settle friendly Indians in any part of the Cherokee country west of 96\xb0... [sale proceeds] to be paid for to the Cherokee Nation..."\nThe settlement of several tribes in the eastern part of the Cherokee Outlet (including the Kaw, Osage, Pawnee, Ponca, and Tonkawa tribes) separated it from the Cherokee Nation proper and left them unable to use it for grazing or hunting.', u'After the Civil War, Texans began driving their cattle across the Outlet to markets in Kansas.', u'Soon other European-American ranchers began using the land for grazing.', u'In the early 1880s, with the support of the Cherokee, the ranchers using the land got organized and began fencing off individual claims.', u'The Cherokee believed such organization would help them collect rents due them for land use.', u'Also during the 1880s, Bill McDonald, acting as deputy U.S.', u'Marshal for the Southern District of Kansas and the Northern District of Texas, cleared the Cherokee Strip of cattle thieves and train robbers, who had taken to hiding out in what they thought was a kind of "no-man\'s land".', u'In March 1883, Kansas cattlemen incorporated under the laws of Kansas to form the The Cherokee Strip Live Stock Association.', u'They negotiated a five-year lease for the entire outlet for $100,000 per year, payable semi-annually in advance.', u'At the end of the five years, the Cherokee Nation Tribal Council put the lease up for bid, hoping to get a better price.', u'The Cherokee Strip Live Stock Association eventually got the bid for $200,000 per year, but the lease was nullified by Congress, which then authorized purchasing the land for $1.25 per acre.', u'Having previously rejected a bid from the cattlemen to buy the land for $3.00 per acre, the Cherokee protested in vain that the government price was too low.', u'President Benjamin Harrison forbade all grazing in the Cherokee Outlet after October 2, 1890, which eliminated all profit from leasing the land.', u'After that, the Cherokee sold off the land at prices ranging from $1.40 to $2.50 per acre.', u'The Cherokee Strip Live Stock Association would disband in 1893, the same year the Outlet was opened to non-Indian settlement.', u'Actual payment did not occur until 1964, when the Cherokee finally settled their claims against the U.S. government for the actual value of the Cherokee Strip land opened to settlement in 1893.', u'This amounted to about $14.7 million, which was paid to the original allotment holders or their heirs.', u'The tribe also received an additional $2 million in accrued interest.', u'The Organic Act of 1890 incorporated the Unassigned Lands into the new Oklahoma Territory.', u'In 1907 Oklahoma became the 46th state.', u'== Cherokee Strip land run ==\nIn 1889, Congress authorized the Cherokee Commission to persuade the Cherokee to cede their complete title to the Cherokee Outlet.', u'After a great amount of pressure, and confirmed by a treaty Congress approved March 17, 1893, the Cherokee agreed, for "the sum of $8,595,736.12, over and above all other sums" to turn title over to the United States government.', u'On September 16, 1893, the eastern end of the Cherokee Outlet was settled in the Cherokee Strip land run, the largest land run in the United States and possibly the largest event of its kind in the history of the world.', u'== In popular fiction ==\nThe Cherokee Outlet and the actions of the cattlemen play a prominent role in a portion of the Matt Braun western novel The Kincades.', u'The names of the characters have been changed, but the basic actions taken are explored.', u'== See also ==\nCherokee Strip (Kansas)\nLand Run
