{'sentences': [u'A full moon is the lunar phase that occurs when the Moon is completely illuminated as seen from Earth.', u'This occurs when Earth is located directly between the Sun and the Moon (more exactly, when the ecliptic longitudes of the Sun and Moon differ by 180 degrees).', u'This means that the hemisphere of the Moon that is facing Earth (the near side) is almost fully illuminated by the Sun and appears round (while the far side is almost completely unilluminated).', u"On some occasions at the time of full moon there is also a lunar eclipse so the moon's face appears reddish due to the rayleigh scattering of blue light in Earth's atmosphere.", u"Lunar eclipses can occur only at full moon, where the Moon's orbit allows it to pass through Earth's shadow.", u"Lunar eclipses do not occur every month because the Moon usually passes above or below Earth's shadow (which is mostly restricted to the ecliptic plane).", u'Lunar eclipses can occur only when the full moon occurs near the two nodes of the orbit, either the ascending or descending node.', u'This causes eclipses to only occur about every 6 months, and often 2 weeks before or after a solar eclipse at new moon at the opposite node.', u'The time interval between similar lunar phases\u2014the synodic month\u2014averages about 29.53 days.', u'Therefore, in those lunar calendars in which each month begins on the new moon, the full moon falls on either the 14th or 15th of the lunar month.', u'Because calendar months have a whole number of days, lunar months may be either 29 or 30 days long.', u"== Characteristics ==\nA full moon is often thought of as an event of a full night's duration.", u'This is somewhat misleading because the Moon seen from Earth is continuously becoming larger and/or smaller (though much too slowly to notice with the naked eye).', u'Its absolute maximum size occurs at the moment expansion has stopped.', u'For any given location, about half of these absolute maximum full moons will be potentially visible, as the other half occur during the day, when the full moon is below the horizon.', u'Many almanacs list full moons not just by date, but by their exact time as well, usually in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).', u'Typical monthly calendars that include phases of the Moon may be off by one day if intended for use in a different time zone.', u'Full moons are generally a poor time to conduct astronomical observations, because the bright reflected sunlight from the Moon overwhelms the dimmer light from stars.', u'On 12 December 2008, the full moon occurred closer to the Earth than it had been at any time for the previous 15 years, called a supermoon.', u'On 19 March 2011, another super full moon occurred, closer to the Earth than at any time for the previous ~18 years.', u'(cycle)\nOn 14 November 2016, a super full moon occurred closer to the Earth than at any time for the previous 68 years.', u'=== Formula ===\nThe date and approximate time of a specific full moon (assuming a circular orbit) can be calculated from the following equation:\n\n  \n    \n      \n        d\n        =\n        20.362955\n        +\n        29.530588861\n        \xd7\n        N\n        +\n        102.026\n        \xd7\n        \n          10\n          \n            \u2212\n            12\n          \n        \n        \xd7\n        \n          N\n          \n            2\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle d=20.362955+29.530588861\\times N+102.026\\times 10^{-12}\\times N^{2}}\n  \nwhere d is the number of days since 1 January 2000 00:00:00 in the Terrestrial Time scale used in astronomical ephemerides; for Universal Time (UT) add the following approximate correction to d:\n\n  \n    \n      \n        \u2212\n        0.000739\n        \u2212\n        (\n        235\n        \xd7\n        \n          10\n          \n            \u2212\n            12\n          \n        \n        )\n        \xd7\n        \n          N\n          \n            2\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle -0.000739-(235\\times 10^{-12})\\times N^{2}}\n   days\nwhere N is the number of full moons since the first full moon of 2000.', u"The true time of a full moon may differ from this approximation by up to about 14.5 hours as a result of the non-circularity of the moon's orbit.", u'See New moon for an explanation of the formula and its parameters.', u'The age and apparent size of the full moon vary in a cycle of just under 14 synodic months, which has been referred to as a full moon cycle.', u'== In folklore and tradition ==\n\nFull moons are traditionally associated with temporal insomnia (inability to sleep), insanity (hence the terms lunacy and lunatic) and various "magical phenomena" such as lycanthropy.', u'Psychologists, however, have found that there is no strong evidence for effects on human behavior around the time of a full moon.', u'They find that studies are generally not consistent, with some showing a positive effect and others showing a negative effect.', u'In one instance, the 23 December 2000 issue of the British Medical Journal published two studies on dog bite admission to hospitals in England and Australia.', u'The study of the Bradford Royal Infirmary found that dog bites were twice as common during a full moon, whereas the study conducted by the public hospitals in Australia found that they were less likely.', u'All this is relevant to canine rather than human behavior.', u'=== Full moon names ===\nHistorically, month names are names of moons (lunations, not necessarily full moons) in lunisolar calendars.', u'Since the introduction of the solar Julian calendar in the Roman Empire, and later the Gregorian calendar worldwide, month names have ceased to be perceived as "moon names".', u'The traditional Old English month names were equated with the names of the Julian calendar from an early time (soon after Christianization, according to the testimony of Bede ca.', u'AD 700).', u'Some full moons have developed new names in modern times, e.g., the blue moon, and the names "harvest moon" and "hunter\'s moon" for the full moons of autumn.', u'==== Harvest and hunter\'s moons ====\n\nThe "harvest moon" and "hunter\'s moon" are traditional terms for the full moons occurring during late summer and in the autumn, in the northern hemisphere usually in August, September and October respectively.', u'The "harvest moon" is the full moon closest to the autumnal equinox (22 or 23 September), and the "hunter\'s moon" is the one following it.', u'The names are recorded from the early 18th century.', u'The Oxford English Dictionary entry for "harvest moon" cites a 1706 reference, and for "hunter\'s moon" a 1710 edition of The British Apollo, where the term is attributed to "the country people" (The Country People call this the Hunters-Moon.)', u'The names became traditional in American folklore, where they are now often popularly attributed to the Native Americans.', u"The Feast of the Hunters' Moon is a yearly festival in West Lafayette, Indiana, held in late September or early October each year since 1968.", u'In 2010, the Harvest moon occurred on the night of equinox itself (some 5\u200a1\u20442 hours after the point of equinox) for the first time since 1991.', u'All full moons rise around the time of sunset.', u'Because the moon moves eastward among the stars faster than the sun its meridian passage is delayed, causing it to rise later each day \u2013 on average by about 50.47 minutes.', u"The harvest moon and hunter's moon are unique because the time difference between moonrises on successive evenings is much shorter than average.", u'The moon rises approximately 30 minutes later from one night to the next, as seen from about 40 degrees N or S latitude.', u'(This is because a full moon in September appears to move not straight east but north-east in the sky.)', u'Thus, there is no long period of darkness between sunset and moonrise for several days following the actual date of the full moon.', u'==== Farmers\' Almanacs ====\nThe Maine Farmers\' Almanac from c. the 1930s began to publish Native American "Indian" full moon names.', u"The Farmers' Almanac (since 1955 published in Maine, but not the same publication as the Maine Farmers' Almanac) continues to do so.", u'An early list of "Indian month names" was published in 1918 by Daniel Carter Beard in his The American Boy\'s Book of Signs, Signals and Symbols for use by the boy scouts.', u'Beard\'s "Indian" month names were:\nJanuary: Difficulty, Black Smoke\nFebruary: Raccoon, Bare Spots on the Ground\nMarch: Wind, Little Grass, Sore-Eye\nApril: Ducks, Goose-Eggs\nMay: Green Grass, Root-Food\nJune: Corn-Planting, Strawberry\nJuly: Buffalo (Bull), Hot Sun\nAugust: Harvest, Cow Buffalo\nSeptember: Wild Rice, Red Plum\nOctober: Leaf-Falling, Nuts\nNovember: Deer-Mating, Fur-Pelts\nDecember: Wolves, Big Moon\nSuch names have gained currency in American folklore.', u'They appear in print more widely outside of the almanac tradition from the 1990s in popular publications about the Moon.', u'Mysteries of the Moon by Patricia Haddock ("Great Mysteries Series", Greenhaven Press, 1992) gave an extensive list of such names along with the individual tribal groups they were supposedly associated with.', u'Haddock supposes that certain "Colonial American" moon names were adopted from Algonquian languages (which were formerly spoken in the territory of New England), while others are based in European tradition (e.g., the Colonial American names for the May moon, "Milk Moon", "Mother\'s Moon", "Hare Moon" have no parallels in the supposed native names, while the name of November, "Beaver Moon" is supposedly based in the Algonquin).', u'The individual names given in Farmers\' Almanac include:\nJanuary: "Wolf Moon" (this is the name of December in Beard 1918) also "Old Moon"\nFebruary: "Snow Moon", also calendars ==\n\nMost pre-modern calendars the world over were lunisolar, combining the solar year with the lunation by means of intercalary months.', u'The Julian calendar abandoned this method in favour of a purely solar reckoning while conversely the 7th-century Islamic calendar opted for a purely lunar one.', u'A continuing lunisolar calendar is in the Hebrew calendar.', u'Evidence of this is noted in the dates of Passover and Easter in Judaism and Christianity, respectively.', u'The date of the Jewish Rosh Hashana and Sukkot festivals along with all other Jewish holidays are dependent on the dates of the new moons.', u'=== Intercalary months ===\n\nIn lunisolar calendars, an intercalary month occurs 7 times in the 19 years of the Metonic cycle, or on average every 2.7 years (19/7).', u'In the Hebrew Calendar this is noted with a periodic extra month of Adar in the early spring.', u'==== Blue moon ====\n\nIn the modern system of "traditional" full moon names tied to the solstice and equinox points, a supernumerary full moon in such a period is called a blue moon.', u'The term "blue moon" used in this sense may date to as early as the 16th century, but it became well known in the United States due to the Farmers\' Almanac (published since 1818).', u'According to the Farmers\' Almanac, a "blue moon" is the third full moon in any period between either solstice and equinox, or between equinox and solstice, (calculated using the mean tropical year), which contains four full moons.', u"These seasons are equal in length, unlike the astronomical ones, which vary in length depending on the Earth's speed in its elliptical orbit round the sun.", u'To compare, in 1983 the equal length seasons began at 1.48 AM on 23 March, 9.15 AM on 22 June, 4.42 PM on 21 September and 12.10 AM on 22 December, while the astronomical seasons began at 4.39 AM on 21 March, 11.09 PM on 21 June, 2.42 PM on 23 September and 10.30 AM on 22 December (all times GMT).', u'Due to a misinterpretation of this definition in the March 1946 Sky & Telescope magazine, "blue moon" has also been used in the sense of "the second full moon in any month which contains two full moons (this usage has been noted as "erroneous" by Sky & Telescope in 1999).', u'According to either definition, "blue moons" occur with the average frequency of intercalary months, seven times in 19 years, the Farmers\' Almanac system of "full moon names" effectively defining a lunisolar calendar.', u'== See also ==\n\nLunar eclipse\nLunar phase\nMonth\nNear side of the Moon\nNew moon\nOrbit of the u'Ceratopsians (Ceratopsia)\nThe largest ceratopsians were Triceratops and its ancestor Eotriceratops from the late Cretaceous of North America.', u'Both estimated to have reached about 9 m (30 ft) in length and weighed 12 tonnes.', u'==== Birds (Aves) ====\n\nThe largest living bird, a member of the Struthioniformes, is the common ostrich (Struthio camelus), from the plains of Africa and Arabia.', u'A large male ostrich can reach a height of 2.8 m (9.2 ft) and weigh over 156 kg (344 lb).', u'A mass of 200 kg (440 lb) has been cited for the common ostrich but no wild ostriches of this massive weight have been verified.', u'Eggs laid by the ostrich can weigh 1.4 kg (3.1 lb) and are the largest eggs in the world today.', u'The largest bird in the fossil record may be the extinct elephant birds (Aepyornis) of Madagascar, which were related to the ostrich.', u'They exceeded 3 m (9.8 ft) in height and 500 kg (1,100 lb).', u'The last of the elephant birds became extinct about 300 years ago.', u'Of almost exactly the same upper proportions as the largest elephant birds was Dromornis stirtoni of Australia, part of a 26,000-year-old group called mihirungs of the family Dromornithidae.', u'The largest carnivorous bird was Brontornis, an extinct flightless bird from South America which reached a weight of 350 to 400 kg (770 to 880 lb) and a height of about 2.8 m (9 ft 2 in).', u'The tallest carnivorous bird was Kelenken, which could reach 3 to 3.2 meters in height and 220 to 250 kilograms.', u'The tallest bird ever was the giant moa (Dinornis maximus), part of the moa family of New Zealand that went extinct around 1500 AD.', u'This particular species of moa stood up to 3.7 m (12 ft) tall, but weighed about half as much as a large elephant bird or mihirung due to its comparatively slender frame.', u'The largest bird ever capable of flight was Argentavis magnificens, the largest member of the now extinct family Teratornithidae, found in Miocene-aged fossil beds of Argentina, with a wingspan up to 8.3 m (27 ft), a length of up to 3.5 m (11 ft), a height on the ground of up to 2 m (6.6 ft) and a body weight of at least 80 kg (180 lb).', u'Pelagornis sandersi is thought to have had a wingspan of comparable size.', u'Table of heaviest living birds\nThe following is a list of the heaviest living bird species ranked by average weight.', u'These species are almost all flightless, which allows for these particular birds to have denser bones and heavier bodies.', u'Flightless birds comprise less than 2% of all living bird species.', u'==== Amphibians (Amphibia) ====\n\nThe largest living amphibian is the Chinese giant salamander (Andrias davidianus).', u'The maximum size of this nearly human-sized river-dweller is 64 kg (141 lb) and almost 1.83 m (6.0 ft).', u'Before amniotes became the dominant tetrapods, several giant amphibian proto-tetrapods existed and were certainly the dominant animals in their ecosystems.', u'The largest known was the crocodile-like Prionosuchus, which reached a length of 9 m (30 ft).', u'Frogs (Anura)\nThe largest member of the largest order of amphibians is the African Goliath frog (Conraua goliath).', u'The maximum size this species is verified to attain is a weight of 3.8 kg (8.4 lb) and a snout-to-vent length of 39 cm (15 in).', u'The largest of the toads, the cane toad (Rhinella marina), is also the second largest member of the frog order.', u'This infamous, often invasive species can grow to maximum mass of 2.65 kg (5.8 lb) and measure a maximum of 33 cm (13 in) from snout-to-vent.', u'Rivaling the previous two species, the African bullfrog (Pyxicephalus adspersus) can range up to a weight of 2 kg (4.4 lb) and 25.5 cm (10.0 in) from snout to vent.', u'Another large frog is the largest frog in North America, the American bullfrog, which can reach weights of up to 0.8 kg (1.8 lb) and snout-to-vent-length (SVL) of 20 cm (7.9 in).', u'However, the toad Beelzebufo ampinga, found in fossil from the Cretaceous era in what is now Madagascar, could grow to be 41 cm (16 in) long and weigh up to 4.5 kg (9.9 lb), making it the largest frog ever known.', u'The largest tree frog is the Australasian white-lipped tree frog (Litoria infrafrenata), the females of which can reach a length of 14 cm (5.5 in) from snout to vent and can weigh up to 115 g (4.1 oz).', u'The family Leptodactylidae, one of the most diverse anuran families, also has some very large members.', u'The largest is the Surinam horned frog (Ceratophrys cornuta), which can reach 20 cm (7.9 in) in length from snout to vent and weigh up to 0.48 kg (1.1 lb).', u'While not quite as large as Ceratophrys cornuta, Leptodactylus pentadactylus is often heavier; it can reach 18.5 cm (7.3 in) long and weigh 0.60 kilograms (1.3 pounds).', u'The largest dendrobatid is the Colombian golden poison frog (Phyllobates terribilis), which can attain a length of 6 cm (2.4 in) and nearly 28.3 g (1.00 oz).', u'Most frogs are classified under the suborder Neobatrachia, although nearly 200 species are part of the Mesobatrachia suborder, or ancient frogs.', u'The largest of these are the little-known Brachytarsophrys or Karin Hills frogs, of South Asia, which can grow to a maximum snout-to-vent length of 17 cm (6.7 in) and a maximum weight of 0.54 kg (1.2 lb).', u"Caecilians (Gymnophiona)\nThe largest of the worm-like caecilians is the Colombian Thompson's caecilian (Caecilia thompsoni), which reaches a length of 1.5 m (4.9 ft), a width of about 4.6 cm (1.8 in) and can weigh up to about 1 kg (2.2 lb).", u'Salamanders (Urodela)\nBesides the previously mentioned Chinese giant salamander, the closely related Japanese giant salamander (Andrias japonicus) is also sometimes cited as the largest living amphibian, but salamanders of a greater size than 1.53 m (5.0 ft) and 36 kg (79 lb) have never been verified for this species.', u'Another giant of the amphibian world is the North American Hellbender (Cryptobranchus alleganiensis), which can measure up to 0.76 m (2.5 ft).', u'The largest of the newts is the Iberian ribbed newt (Pleurodeles waltl), which can grow up to 30 cm (12 in) in length.', u'==== Fish ====\n\n\n=== Invertebrates ===\n\n\n==== Sponges (Porifera) ====\n\nThe largest known species of sea sponge is the giant barrel sponge, Xestospongia muta.', u'These massively built sponges can reach 2.4 m (8 ft) in height and can be of about the same number of feet across at the thickest part of the "body".', u'Some of these creatures have been estimated to be over 2,400 years of age.', u'Calcareous sponges (Calcarea)\nThe largest known of these small, inconspicuous sponges is probably the species Pericharax heteroraphis, attaining a height of 30 cm (0.98 ft).', u'Most calcareous sponges do not exceed 10 cm (3.9 in) tall.', u'Hexactinellid sponges (Hexactinellida)\nA relatively common species, Rhabdocalyptus dawsoni, can reach a height of 1 m (3.3 ft) once they are of a very old age.', u'This is the maximum size recorded for a hexactinellid sponge.', u"==== Cnidarians (Cnidaria) ====\n\nThe lion's mane jellyfish (Cyanea capillata) is the largest cnidaria species, of the class Scyphozoa.", u'The largest known specimen of this giant, found washed up on the shore of Massachusetts Bay in 1870, had a bell diameter of 2.5 m (8.2 ft), a weight of 150 kg (330 lb).', u'The tentacles of this specimens were as long as 37 m (121 ft) and were projected to have a tentacular spread of about 75 m (246 ft) making it one of the longest extant animals.', u'Corals and sea-anemones (Anthozoa)\nThe largest individual species are the sea-anemones of the genus Discoma, which can attain a mouth disc diameter of 60 cm (2.0 ft).', u'Longer, but much less massive overall, are the anemones of the genus Ceriantharia, at up to 2 m (6.6 ft) tall.', u'Communities of coral can be truly massive, a single colony of the Porites genus can be over 10 m (33 ft), but the actual individual organisms are quite small.', u'Lion\'s mane jellyfish\nThe largest known species of jellyfish is the "lion\'s mane jellyfish".', u'The largest of its kind was found in 1870 in Massachusetts Bay with a recorded bell size of 2.3 metres (7 feet 7 inches) and a tentacle length of 37 metres (121 feet).', u'Hydrozoans (Hydrozoa)\nThe colonial siphonophore Praya dubia can ====\n\nThe largest terrestrial species of this phylum of mostly parasites, commonly called flatworms, is the greenhouse planarian (Bipalium kewense).', u'This planarian can reach a length of 60 cm (2.0 ft) and is quite massive for a flatworm.', u'Monogenean flatworms (Monogenea)\nThe largest known members of this group of very small parasites are among the genus of capsalids, Listrocephalos, reaching a length of 2 cm (0.79 in).', u'Flukes (Trematoda)\nThe largest known species of fluke is Fasciolopsis buski, which most often attacks humans and livestock.', u'One of these flukes can be up u'==== Roundworms (Nematoda) ====\nThe largest roundworm, Placentonema gigantissima, is a parasite found in the placentas of sperm whales which can reach up to 9 m (30 ft) in length.', u'==== Segmented worms (Annelida) ====\nThe largest of the segmented worms (commonly called earthworms) is the African giant earthworm (Microchaetus rappi).', u'Although it averages about 1.36 m (4.5 ft) in length, this huge worm can reach a length of as much as 6.7 m (22 ft) and can weigh over 1.5 kg (3.3 lb).', u'Only the giant Gippsland earthworm, Megascolides australis, and a few giant polychaetes reach nearly comparable sizes, reaching 4 and 3.6 m (13 and 12 ft), respectively.', u'==== Echinoderms (Echinodermata) ====\n\nThe largest species of echinoderm in terms of bulk is probably the starfish species Thromidia gigas, of the class Asteroidea, which reaches a weight of over 6 kg (13 lb), but it might be beaten by some giant sea cucumbers such as Thelenota anax.', u'However, at a maximum span of 63 cm (25 in), Thromidia gigas is quite a bit shorter than some other echinoderms.', u'The longest echinoderm known is the conspicuous sea cucumber Synapta maculata, with a slender u'Evasterias echinosoma is another giant echinoderm and can measure up to 1 m (3.3 ft) across and weigh 5.1 kg (11 lb).', u'Crinoids (Crinoidea)\nThe largest species of crinoid is the unstalked feather-star Heliometra glacialis, reaching a total width of 78 cm (31 in) and an individual arm length of 35 cm (14 in).', u'A width of 91.4 cm (36.0 in) was claimed for one unstalked feather-star but is not confirmed.', u'The genus Metacrinus has a stalk span of 61 cm (24 in) but, due to its bulk and multiple arms, it is heavier than Heliometra.', u'In the past, crinoids grew much larger, and and Thelenota anax, weighing several pounds, being about 21 cm (8.3 in) in diameter, and reaching a length of 1 m (3.3 ft) when fully extended.', u'Synapta maculata can reach an extended length of 3 m of about 14.3 cm (5.6 in).', u'Outside from euryalids, the biggest ophiurid brittle star may be Ophiopsammus maculata (6-7 inches).', u'Sea stars (Asteroidea)\nThe heaviest sea star is Thromidia gigas at a length of 55 m (180 ft).', u'==== Mollusks (Mollusca) ====\n\nBoth the largest mollusks and the largest of all invertebrates (in terms of mass) are the largest squids.', u'The colossal squid (Mesonychoteuthis hamiltoni) is projected to be the largest invertebrate.', u'Current estimates put its maximum size at 12 to 14 m (39 to 46 ft) long and 750 kg (1,650 lb), based on analysis of smaller specimens.', u'In 2007, authorities in New Zealand announced the capture of the largest known colossal squid specimen.', u'It was initially thought to be 10 m (33 ft) and 450 kg (990 lb).', u'It was later measured at 4.2 m (14 ft) long and 495 kg (1,091 lb) in weight.', u'The mantle was 2.5 m (8.2 ft) long when measured.', u'The giant squid (Architeuthis dux) was previously thought to be the largest squid, and while it is less massive and has a smaller mantle than the colossal squid, it may exceed the colossal squid in overall length including tentacles.', u'One giant squid specimen that washed ashore in 1878 in Newfoundland reportedly measured 18 m (59 ft) in total length (from the tip of the mantle to the end of the long tentacles), head and body length 6.1 m (20 ft), 4.6 m (15 ft) in diameter at the thickest part of mantle, and weighed about 900 kg (2,000 lb).', u'This specimen is still often cited as the largest invertebrate that has ever been examined.', u"However, no animals approaching this size have been scientifically documented and, according to giant squid expert Steve O'Shea, such lengths were likely achieved by greatly stretching the two tentacles like elastic bands.", u'Aplacophorans (Aplacophora)\nThe largest known of these worm-like, shell-less mollusks are represented in the genus Epimenia, which can reach 30 cm (12 in) long.', u'Most weigh over 2 kg (4.4 lb).', u'Bivalves (Bivalvia)\nThe largest of the bivalve mollusks is the giant clam, Tridacna gigas.', u'Although even larger sizes have been reported for this passive animal, the top verified size was for a specimen from the Great Barrier Reef.', u'This creature weighed 270 kg (600 lb), had an axial length of 1.14 m (3.7 ft) and depth of 0.75 m (2.5 ft).', u'The largest bivalve ever was Platyceramus platinus, a Cretaceous giant that reached an axial length of up to 3 m (nearly 10 ft).', u'Gastropods (Gastropoda)\nThe "largest" of this most diverse and successful mollusk class of slugs and snails can be defined in various ways.', u'The living gastropod species that has the largest (longest) shell is Syrinx aruanus with a maximum shell length of 0.91 m (3.0 125 kg (276 lb) but are unverified.', u'==== Arthropods (Arthropoda) ====\n\nThe largest arthropod known to have existed is the eurypterid (sea scorpion) Jaekelopterus, reaching up to 2.5 m (8.2 ft) in body length, followed by the millipede relative Arthropleura at around 2.1 m (6.9 ft) in length.', u'Among living arthropods, the Japanese spider crab (Macrocheira kaempferi) is the largest in u'A nearly complete specimen of Isotelus rex from Manitoba attained a length over 70 cm (28 in), and an Ogyginus forteyi from Portugal was almost as long.', u'Fragments of trilobites suggest even easily the most numerous class of organisms, with over one million identified species, and probably many undescribed species.', u'The heaviest insect is almost certainly a species of beetle, which incidentally is the most species-rich order of organisms.', u"Although heavyweight giant wetas (Deinacrida heteracantha) are known, the elephant beetles of Central and South America, (Megasoma elephas) and (M. actaeon), the Titan beetle (Titanus giganteus) of the neotropical rainforests or the Goliath beetles, (Goliathus goliatus) and (G. regius), of Africa's rainforests are thought to range up to 25 cm (9.8 in).", u'Some moths and butterflies have much larger areas than the heaviest beetles, but weigh a fraction as much.', u'The longest insects are the stick insects, see below.', u'Representatives of the extinct dragonfly-like order Protodonata such as the Carboniferous Meganeura monyi of what is now France and the Permian Meganeuropsis permiana of what is now North America are the largest insect species yet known to have existed.', u'These creatures had a wingspan of some 75 cm (30 in) and a mass of over 1 pound (450 g), making them about the size of a crow.', u'Cockroaches and termites (Blattodea)\n\nThe largest cockroach is the Australian giant burrowing cockroach (Macropanesthia rhinoceros).', u'This species can attain a length of 8.3 cm (3.3 in) and a weight of 36 g (1.3 oz).', u'The giant cockroach (Blaberus giganteus) of the neotropics reaches comparable lengths although is not as massive as the burrowing species.', u'The termites, traditionally classified in their own order (Isoptera), have recently been re-considered to belong in Blattodea.', u'The largest of the termites is the African species Macrotermes bellicosus.', u'The queen of this species can attain a length of 14 cm (5.5 in) and breadth of 5.5 cm (2.2 in) across the abdomen; other adults, on the other hand, are about a third of the size.', u'Beetles (Coleoptera)\nThe beetles are the largest order of organisms on earth, with about 400,000 species so far identified.', u'The most massive species are the Goliathus, Megasoma and Titanus beetles already mentioned.', u'Another fairly large species is the Hercules beetle (Dynastes hercules) of the neotropic rainforests with a maximum overall length of at least 19 cm (7.5 in) including the extremely long pronotal horn.', u'The weight in this species does not exceed 16.5 g (0.58 oz).', u'The longest overall beetle is a species of longhorn beetle, Batocera wallacei, from New Guinea, which can attain a length of 26.6 cm (10.5 in), about 19 cm (7.5 in) of which is comprised by the long antennae.', u'Earwigs (Dermaptera)\nThe largest of the earwigs is the Saint Helena giant earwig (Labidura herculeana), endemic to the island of its name, which is up to 8 cm (3.1 in) in length.', u'True flies (Diptera)\n\nThe largest species of this order, which includes the common housefly, is the neotropical species Gauromydas heros, which can reach a length of 6 cm (2 3\u20448 in) and a wingspan of 10 cm (3.9 in).', u'Species of crane fly, the largest of which is Holorusia brobdignagius, can attain a length of 23 cm (9.1 in) but are extremely slender and much lighter in weight than Gauromydas.', u'Mayflies (Ephemeroptera)\nThe largest mayflies are members of the genus Proboscidoplocia from Madagascar.', u'These insects can reach a length of 7 cm (2.8 in).', u'True bugs (Hemiptera)\n\nThe largest species of this diverse order is usually listed as the giant water bug in the genus Lethocerus, with L. maximus from the Neotropics being the absolutely largest.', u'They can surpass 12 cm (4.7 in) in length, with some suggesting that the maximum size is 15 cm (5.9 in).', u'It is more slender and less heavy than most other insects of this size (principally the huge beetles).', u'The largest cicada is Megapomponia imperatoria, which has a head-body length of about 7 cm (2.8 in) and a wingspan of 18\u201320 cm (7\u20138 in).', u'The cicadas of the genus Tacua can also grow to comparably large sizes.', u'The largest type of aphid is the giant oak aphid (Stomaphis quercus), which can reach an overall length of 2 cm (0.79 in).', u'The biggest species of leafhopper is Ledromorpha planirostris, which can reach a length of 2.8 cm (1.1 in).', u'Ants and allies (Hymenoptera)\nThe largest of the ants, and the heaviest species of the order, are the females of the African Dorylus helvolus, reaching a length of 5.1 cm (2.0 in) and a weight of 8.5 g (0.30 oz).', u'The ant that averages the largest for the mean size within the whole colony is a ponerine ant, Dinoponera gigantea, from South America, averaging up to 3.3 cm (1.3 in) from the mandibles to the end of abdomen.', u'Workers of the bulldog ant (Myrmecia brevinoda) of Australia are up to 3.7 cm (1.5 in) in total length, although much of this is from their extremely large mandibles.', u'The largest of the bee species, also in the order Hymenoptera, is Megachile pluto of Indonesia, the females of which can be 3.8 cm (1.5 in) long, with a 6.3 cm (2.5 in) wingspan.', u'Nearly as large, the carpenter bees can range up to 2.53 cm (1.00 in).', u'The largest wasp is probably the so-called tarantula hawk species Pepsis pulszkyi of South America, at up to 6.8 cm (2.7 in) long and 11.6 cm (4.6 in) wingspan, although many other Pepsis approach a similar size.', u'Moths and allies (Lepidoptera)\n\nThe Hercules moth (Coscinocera hercules), in the family Saturniidae, is endemic to New Guinea and northern Australia, and its wings have the largest documented surface area (300 square centimeters) of any living insect, and a maximum wingspan which is confirmed to 28 cm (11 in) while unconfirmed specimens have spanned up to 35.5 cm (14.0 in).', u"The largest species overall is often claimed to be either the Queen Alexandra's birdwing (Ornithoptera alexandrae), a butterfly from Papua New Guinea, or the Atlas moth (Attacus atlas), a moth from Southeast Asia.", u'Both of these species can reach a length of 8 cm (3.1 in), a wingspan of 28 cm (11 in) and a weight of 12 g (0.42 oz).', u'One Atlas moth allegedly had a wingspan of 30 cm (12 in) but this measurement was not verified.', u'The larvae in the previous species can weigh up to 58 and 54 g (2.0 and 1.9 oz), respectively.', u'However, there are no reported measurements of surface area that would exceed the Hercules moth, and the white witch (Thysania agrippina) of Central and South America, has the largest recorded wingspan of the order, and indeed of any living insect, though the white witch is exceeded in surface area by the Hercules moth.', u'The verified record-sized Thysania spanned 30.8 cm (12.1 in) across the wings, although specimens have been reported to 36 cm (14 in).', u"The heaviest mature moths have been cited in the giant carpenter moth (Xyleutes boisduvali) of Australia, which has weighed up to 20 g (0.71 oz) although the species doesn't surpass 25.5 cm (10.0 in) in wingspan.", u'Mantises (Mantodea)\nThe largest species of this order is Toxodera denticulata from Java, which has been measured up to 20 cm (7.9 in) in overall length.', u'However, an undescribed species from the Cameroon jungle is allegedly much larger than any other mantis and may rival the larger stick insects for the longest living insect.', u'Among widespread mantis species, the largest is the Chinese mantis (Tenodera aridifolia).', u'The females of this species can attain a length of up to 10.6 cm (4.2 in).', u'Alderflies and allies (Megaloptera)\nThis relatively small insect order includes some rather large species, many of which are noticeable for their elongated, imposing mandibles.', u'The dobsonflies reach the greatest sizes of the order and can range up to 12.5 cm (4.9 in) in length.', u'Net-winged insects (Neuroptera)\n\nThese flying insects reach their largest size in Palparellus voeltzkowi, which can have a wingspan over 16 cm (6.3 in).', u'The largest lacewing is the "blue eyes lacewing" (Nymphes myrmeleonides) of Australia, which can measure up to 4 cm (1.6 in) in length and span 11 cm (4.3 in) across the wings.', u'Some forms of this ancient order could grow extremely large during the Jurassic Era and may have ranked among the largest insects ever.', u'Dragonflies (Odonata)\nThe largest living species of dragonfly is Megaloprepus caerulatus of the neotropics, attaining a size of as much as 19 cm (7.5 in) across the wings and a body length of over 12 cm (4.7 in).', u'Spanning up to 17.6 cm (6.9 in) and measuring up to 11.8 cm (4.6 in) long, Tetracanthagyna plagiata of Southeast Asia is bulkier and heavier than Megaloprepus at up to 7 g (0.25 oz).', u'The largest species of dragonfly ever is the extinct aforementioned Meganeura, although it is not certain to be included in the modern dragonfly order.', u'Grasshoppers and allies (Orthoptera)\n\nThe largest of this widespread, varied complex of insects are the giant wetas of New Zealand, which is now split among 12 species.', u'The largest of these is the Little Barrier Island giant weta (Deinacrida heteracantha), the largest specimen was weighed at 71.3 g (2.52 oz), one of the largest insects weights ever known.', u'These heavyweight insects can be over 9 cm (3.5 in) long.', u'The largest grasshopper species is often considered to be the Australian giant grasshopper (Valanga irregularis), which ranges up to 9 cm (3.5 in) in length.', u'The American eastern lubber grasshopper (Romalea guttata) can allegedly range up to 10 cm (3.9 in) in length.', u'However, the greatest grasshopper sizes known, to 12 cm (4.7 in), have been cited in the South American giant grasshopper (Tropidacris violaceus).', u'The longest members of this order (although much lighter than the giant wetas) is the katydid Macrolyristes corporalis of Southeast Asia which can range up to 21.5 cm (8.5 in) with its long legs extended and can have a wingspan of 20 cm (7.9 in).', u'Stick insects (Phasmatodea)\nThe longest known stick insect, and indeed the longest insect ever known, is Phobaeticus chani of the Bornean rainforests, with one specimen held in the Natural History Museum in London measuring 56.7 cm (22.3 in) in total length.', u'This measurement is, however, with the front legs fully extended.', u'The body alone still measures 35.7 cm (14.1 in).', u'The species with the second longest body is Phobaeticus kirbyi, also of Borneo, which measures up to 32.8 cm (12.9 in), while the overall length (from the hind to the front legs) is up to 54.6 cm (21.5 in).', u'The second longest insect in terms of total length is Phobaeticus serratipes of Malaysia and Singapore, measuring up to 55.5 cm (21.9 in).', u'Another extremely long stick insect is Pharnacia maxima, which measured 51 cm (20 in) with its legs extended.', u'The spiny stick insect (Heteropteryx dilatata) of Malaysia does not reach the extreme lengths of its cousins, the body reaching up to 16 cm (6.3 in) long, but it is much bulkier.', u'The largest Heteropteryx weighed about 65 g (2.3 oz) and was 3.5 cm (1.4 in) wide across the thickest part of the body.', u'Lice (Phthiraptera)\nThese insects, which live parasitically on other animals, are as a rule quite small.', u'The largest known species is the hog louse, Haematopinus suis, a sucking louse that lives on large livestock like pigs and cattle.', u'It can range up to 6 mm (0.24 in) in length.', u'Stoneflies (Plecoptera)\n\nThe largest species of stonefly is Pteronarcys californica of western North America, a species favored by fishermen as lures.', u'This species can attain a length of 5 cm (2.0 in) and a wingspan of over 9.5 cm (3.7 in).', u'Booklice (Psocoptera)\nThe largest of this order of very small insects are the barklice of the genus Psocus, the top size of which is about 1 cm.', u'Fleas (Siphonaptera)\nThe largest species of flea is Hystrichopsylla schefferi.', u'This parasite is known exclusively from the fur of the mountain beaver (Aplodontia rufa) and can reach a length of 1.2 cm (0.47 in).', u'Silverfishes and allies (Thysanura)\nThese strange-looking insects, known to feed on human household objects, can range up to 4.3 cm (1.7 in) in length.', u'A 350 million year old form was known to grow quite large, at up to 6 cm (2.4 in).', u'Thrips (Thysanoptera)\nMembers of the genus Phasmothrips are the largest kinds of thrips.', u'The maximum size these species attain is approximately 1.3 cm (0.51 in) in length.', u'Caddisflies (Trichoptera)\nThe largest of the small, moth-like caddisflies is Eubasilissa maclachlani.', u'This species can range up to 7 cm (2.8 in) across the wings.', u'== Fungi ==\n\nThe largest living fungus may be a honey fungus of the species Armillaria ostoyae.', u'A mushroom of this type in the Malheur National Forest in the Blue Mountains of eastern Oregon, U.S. was found to be the largest fungal colony in the world, spanning 8.9 km2 (2,200 acres) of area.', u'This organism is estimated to be 2,400 years old.', u'The fungus was written about in the April 2003 issue of the Canadian Journal of Forest Research.', u'While an accurate estimate has not been made, the total weight of the colony may be as much as 605 tons.', u'If this colony is considered a single organism, then it is the largest known organism in the world by area, and rivals the aspen grove "Pando" as the known organism with the highest living biomass.', u'It is not known, however, whether it is a single organism with all parts of the mycelium connected.', u'In Armillaria ostoyae, each individual mushroom (the fruiting body, similar to a flower on a plant) has only a 5 cm (2.0 in) stipe, and a pileus up to 12.5 cm (4.9 in) across.', u'There are many other fungi which produce a larger individual size mushroom.', u'The largest known fruiting body of a fungus is a specimen of Phellinus ellipsoideus (formerly Fomitiporia ellipsoidea) found on Hainan Island.', u'The fruiting body masses up to 500 kg (1,100 lb).', u'Until P. ellipsoideus replaced it, the largest individual fruit body came from Rigidoporus ulmarius.', u'R. ulmarius can grow up to 284 kg (626 lb), 1.66 m (5.4 ft) tall, 1.46 m (4.8 ft) across, and has a circumference of up to 4.9 m (16 ft).', u'== Protists ==\n\n(Note: the group Protista is not used in current taxonomy.)', u'=== Amoebozoans (Amoebozoa) ===\nAmong the organisms that are not multicellular, the largest are the slime moulds, such as Physarum polycephalum, some of which can reach a diameter over 30 cm (12 in).', u'These organisms are unicellular, but they are multinucleate.', u'=== Euglenozoans (Euglenozoa) ===\nSome euglenophytes, such as certain species of Euglena, reach lengths of 400 \u03bcm.', u'=== Rhizarians (Rhizaria) ===\nThe largest species traditionally considered protozoa are giant amoeboids like foraminiferans.', u'One such species, the xenophyophore Syringammina fragilissima, can attain a size of 20 cm (7.9 in).', u'=== Alveolates (Alveolata) ===\nThe largest ciliates, such as Spirostomum, can attain a length over 4 mm (0.16 in).', u'=== Stramenopiles (Stramenopila) ===\nThe largest stramenopiles are giant kelp from the northwestern Pacific.', u'The floating stem of Macrocystis pyrifera can grow to a height of over 45 m (148 ft).', u'Macrocystis also qualifies as the largest brown alga, the largest chromist, and the largest protist generally.', u'== Bacteria ==\n\nThe largest known species of bacterium is Thiomargarita namibiensis, which grows to 0.75 mm (0.030 in) in diameter, making it visible to the naked eye and a thousand times the size of more typical bacteria.', u'Cyanobacteria\nOne of the largest "blue green algae" is Lyngbya, whose filamentous cells can be 50 \u03bcm wide.', u'== Viruses ==\n\nThe largest virus on record so far is the Pithovirus sibericum with the length of 1.5 micrometres, comparable to the typical size of a bacterium and large enough to be seen in light microscopes.', u'It was discovered in March 2014 in a soil sample collected from a riverbank in Siberia.', u'Prior to this discovery, the largest virus was the peculiar Pandoravirus genus of viruses, which have a size of approximately 1 micrometer and whose genome contains 1,900,000 to 2,500,000 base pairs of DNA.', u'Both these viruses infect amoebas specifically.',
