10% of adjusted gross income are deductible, as are uninsured casualty losses.', u'Other income producing expenses in excess of 2% of adjusted gross income are also deductible.', u'For years before 2010, the allowance of itemized deductions was phased out at higher incomes.', u'The phase out expired for 2010.', u'== Capital gains ==\n\nTaxable income includes capital gains.', u'However, individuals are taxed at a lower rate on long term capital gains and qualifying dividends (see below).', u'A capital gain is the excess of the sales price over the tax basis (usually, the cost) of capital assets, generally those assets not held for sale to customers in the ordinary course of business.', u'Capital losses (where basis is more than sales price) are deductible, but deduction for long term capital losses is limited to the total capital gains for the year, plus for individuals up to $3,000 of ordinary income ($1,500 if married filing separately).', u"An individual may exclude $250,000 ($500,000 for a married couple filing jointly) of capital gains on the sale of the individual's primary residence, subject to certain conditions and limitations.", u'Gains on depreciable property used in a business are treated as ordinary income to the extent of depreciation previously claimed.', u'In determining gain, it is necessary to determine which property is sold and the amount of basis of that property.', u'This may require identification conventions, such as first-in-first-out, for identical properties like shares of stock.', u'Further, tax basis must be allocated among properties purchased together unless they are sold together.', u'Original basis, usually cost paid for the asset, is reduced by deductions for depreciation or loss.', u'Certain capital gains are deferred; that is, they are taxed at a time later than the year of disposition.', u'Gains on property sold for installment payments may be recognized as those payments are received.', u'Gains on property exchanged for like kind property are not recognized, and the tax basis of the new property is based on the tax basis of the old property.', u'Before 1986 and from 2004 onward, individuals have been subject to a reduced rate of federal tax on capital gains (called long-term capital gains) on certain property held more than 12 months.', u'This reduced rate (15% or 20%, depending on regular tax bracket) applies for regular tax and the Alternative Minimum Tax.', u'The reduced rate also applies to dividends from corporations organized in the United States or a country with which the United States has an income tax treaty.', u'* Capital gains up to $250,000 ($500,000 if filed jointly) on real estate used as primary residence are exempt.', u'After 2012, an additional tax bracket of 39.6% applies to ordinary income.', u'The tax rate on long-term capital gains and dividends beginning 2013 for those in the 39.6% bracket is 20% plus a 3.8% surcharge for high-income filers.', u'== Partnerships and LLCs ==\nBusiness entities treated as partnerships are not subject to income tax at the entity level.', u'Instead, their members include their shares of income, deductions, and credits in computing their own tax.', u"The character of the partner's share of income (such as capital gains) is determined at the partnership level.", u'Many types of business entities, including limited liability companies (LLCs), may elect to be treated as a corporation or as a partnership.', u'Distributions from partnerships are not taxed as dividends.', u'== Corporate tax ==\n\nCorporate tax is imposed in the United States at the federal, most state, and some local levels on the income of entities treated for tax purposes as corporations.', u'Shareholders of a corporation wholly owned by U.S. citizens and resident individuals may elect for the corporation to be taxed similarly to partnerships (see S Corporation).', u'Corporate income tax is based on taxable income, which is defined similarly to individual taxable income.', u'Shareholders (including other corporations) of corporations (other than S Corporations) are taxed on dividend distributions from the corporation.', u'They are also subject to tax on capital gains upon sale or exchange of their shares for money or property.', u'However, certain exchanges, such as in reorganizations, are not taxable.', u'Multiple corporations may file a consolidated return at the federal and some state levels with their common parent.', u'=== Corporate tax rates ===\nFederal corporate income tax is imposed at graduated rates from 15% to 35%.', u'The lower rate brackets are phased out at higher rates of income, with all income subject to tax at 34% to 35% where taxable income exceeds $335,000.', u'Additional tax rates imposed at the state and local level vary widely by jurisdiction, from under 1% to over 16%.', u'State and local income taxes are allowed as tax deductions in computing federal taxable income.', u'=== Deductions for corporations ===\nCorporations are not allowed the personal deductions allowed to individuals, such as deductions for exemptions and the standard deduction.', u'However, most other deductions are allowed.', u'In addition, corporations are allowed certain deductions unique to corporate status.', u'These include a partial deduction for dividends received from other corporations, deductions related to organization costs, and certain other items.', u'Some deductions of corporations are limited at federal or state levels.', u'Limitations apply to items due to related parties, including interest and royalty expenses.', u'== Estates and trusts ==\nEstates and trusts may be subject to income tax at the estate or trust level, or the beneficiaries may be subject to income tax on their share of income.', u'Where the all income must be distributed, the beneficiaries are taxed similarly to partners in a partnership.', u'Where income may be retained, the estate or trust is taxed.', u'It may get a deduction for later distributions of income.', u'Estates and trusts are allowed only those deductions related to producing income, plus $1,000.', u'They are taxed at graduated rates that increase rapidly to the maximum rate for individuals.', u'The tax rate for trust and estate income in excess of $11,500 was 35% for 2009.', u'Estates and trusts are eligible for the reduced rate of tax on dividends and capital gains through 2011.', u'== Retirement savings and fringe benefit plans ==\nEmployers get a deduction for amounts contributed to a qualified employee retirement plan or benefit plan.', u'The employee does not recognize income with respect to the plan until he or she receives a distribution from the plan.', u'The plan itself is organized as a trust and is considered a separate entity.', u'For the plan to qualify for tax exemption, and for the employer to get a deduction, the plan must meet minimum participation, vesting, funding, and operational standards.', u'Examples of qualified plans include:\nPension plans (defined benefit pension plan),\nProfit sharing plans (defined contribution plan),\nEmployee Stock Ownership Plan (ESOPs),\nStock purchase plans,\nHealth insurance plans,\nEmployee benefit plans,\nCafeteria plans.', u'Employees or former employees are generally taxed on distributions from retirement or stock plans.', u'Employees are not taxed on distributions from health insurance plans to pay for medical expenses.', u'Cafeteria plans allow employees to choose among benefits (like choosing food in a cafeteria), and distributions to pay those expenses are not taxable.', u'In addition, individuals may make contributions to Individual Retirement Accounts (IRAs).', u'Those not currently covered by other retirement plans may claim a deduction for contributions to certain types of IRAs.', u'Income earned within an IRA is not taxed until the individual withdraws it.', u'== Credits ==\n\nThe federal and state systems offer numerous tax credits for individuals and businesses.', u'Among the key federal credits for individuals are:\nChild credit: a credit up to $1,000 per qualifying child.', u'Child and dependent care credit: a credit up to $6,000, phased out at incomes above $15,000.', u'Earned Income Tax Credit: this refundable credit is granted for a percentage of income earned by a low income individual.', u'The credit is calculated and capped based on the number of qualifying children, if any.', u'This credit is indexed for inflation and phased out for incomes above a certain amount.', u'For 2015, the maximum credit was $6,422.', u'Credit for the elderly and disabled: A nonrefundable credit up to $1,125\nTwo mutually exclusive credits for college expenses.', u'Businesses are also eligible for several credits.', u'These credits are available to individuals and corporations, and can be taken by partners in business partnerships.', u'Among the federal credits included in a "general business credit" are:\nCredit for increasing research expenses.', u'Work Incentive Credit or credit for hiring people in certain enterprise zones or on welfare.', u'A variety of industry specific credits.', u'In addition, a federal foreign tax credit is allowed for foreign income taxes paid.', u'This credit is limited to the portion of federal income tax arising due to foreign source income.', u'The credit is available to all taxpayers.', u'Business credits and the foreign tax credit may be offset taxes in other years.', u'States and some localities offer a variety of credits that vary by jurisdiction.', u'States typically grant a credit to resident individuals for income taxes paid to other states, generally limited in proportion to income taxed in the other state(s).', u'== Alternative minimum tax ==\n\nTaxpayers must pay the higher of the regular income tax or the alternative minimum tax (AMT).', u'Taxpayers who have paid AMT in prior years may claim a credit against regular tax for the prior AMT.', u'The credit is limited so that regular tax is not reduced below current year AMT.', u'AMT is imposed at a nearly flat rate (20% for corporations, 26% or 28% for individuals, estates, and trusts) on taxable income as modified for AMT.', u'Key differences between regular taxable income and AMT taxable income include:\nThe standard deduction and personal exemptions are replaced by a single deduction, which is phased out at higher income levels,\nNo deduction is allowed individuals for state taxes,\nMost miscellaneous itemized deductions are not allowed for individuals,\nDepreciation deductions are computed differently, and\nCorporations must make a complex adjustment to more closely reflect economic income.', u'== Accounting periods and methods ==\nThe United States tax system allows individuals and entities to choose their tax year.', u'Most individuals choose the calendar year.', u'There are restrictions on choice of tax year for some closely held entities.', u'Taxpayers may change their tax year in certain circumstances, and such change may require IRS approval.', u'Taxpayers must determine their taxable income based on their method of accounting for the particular activity.', u'Most individuals use the cash method for all activities.', u'Under this method, income is recognized when received and deductions taken when paid.', u'Taxpayers may choose or be required to use the accrual method for some activities.', u'Under this method, income is recognized when the right to receive it arises, and deductions are taken when the liability to pay arises and the amount can be reasonably determined.', u'Taxpayers recognizing cost of goods sold on inventory must use the accrual method with respect to sales and costs of the inventory.', u'Methods of accounting may differ for financial reporting and tax purposes.', u'Specific methods are specified for certain types of income or expenses.', u'Gain on sale of property other than inventory may be recognized at the time of sale or over the period in which installment sale payments are received.', u'Income from long term contracts must be recognized ratably over the term of the contract, not just at completion.', u'Other special rules also apply.', u'== Tax exempt entities ==\n\nU.S. tax law exempts certain types of entities from income and some other taxes.', u'These provisions arose during the late 19th century.', u'Charitable organizations and cooperatives may apply to the IRS for tax exemption.', u'Exempt organizations are still taxed on any business income.', u'An organization which participates in lobbying, political campaigning, or certain other activities may lose its exempt status.', u'Special taxes apply to prohibited transactions and activities of tax-exempt entities.', u'== Special taxes ==\nThere are many federal tax rules designed to prevent people from abusing the tax system.', u'Provisions related to these taxes are often complex.', u'Such rules include:\nAccumulated earnings tax on corporation accumulations in excess of business needs,\nPersonal holding company taxes,\nPassive foreign investment company rules, and\nControlled foreign corporation provisions.', u'== Special industries ==\nTax rules recognize that some types of businesses do not earn income in the traditional manner and thus require special provisions.', u'For example, insurance companies must ultimately pay claims to some policy holders from the amounts received as premiums.', u'These claims may happen years after the premium payment.', u'Computing the future amount of claims requires actuarial estimates until claims are actually paid.', u"Thus, recognizing premium income as received and claims expenses as paid would seriously distort an insurance company's income.", u'Special rules apply to some or all items in the following industries:\nInsurance companies (rules related to recognition of income and expense; different rules apply to life insurance and to property and casualty insurance)\nShipping (rules related to the revenue recognition cycle)\nExtractive industries (rules related to expenses for exploration and development and for recovery of capitalized costs)\nIn addition, mutual funds (regulated investment companies) are subject to special rules allowing them to be taxed only at the owner level.', u'The company must report to each owner his/her share of ordinary income, capital gains, and creditable foreign taxes.', u'The owners then include these items in their own tax calculation.', u'The fund itself is not taxed, and distributions are treated as a return of capital to the owners.', u'Similar rules apply to real estate investment trusts and real estate mortgage investment conduits.', u'== International aspects ==\n\nThe United States imposes tax on all citizens of the United States, including those who are residents of other countries, and U.S. corporations.', u'Federal income tax is imposed on citizens, residents, and U.S. corporations based on their worldwide income.', u'To mitigate double taxation, a credit is allowed for foreign income taxes.', u'This foreign tax credit is limited to that part of current year tax caused by foreign source income.', u'Determining such part involves determining the source of income and allocating and apportioning deductions to that income.', u'States tax resident individuals and corporations on their worldwide income, but few allow a credit for foreign taxes.', u'In addition, Federal income tax may be imposed on non-resident non-citizens, including corporations, on U.S. source income.', u'Federal tax applies to interest, dividends, royalties, and certain other income of nonresident aliens and foreign corporations at a flat rate of 30%.', u'This rate is often reduced under tax treaties.', u'Foreign persons are taxed on income from a U.S. business and gains on U.S. realty similarly to U.S. persons.', u'Nonresident aliens who are present in the United States for a period of 183 days in a given year are subject to U.S. capital gains tax on certain net capital gains realized during that year from sources within the United States.', u'The states tax non-resident individuals only on income earned within the state (wages, etc.', u'), and tax individuals and corporations on business income apportioned to the state.', u'The United States has income tax treaties with over 65 countries.', u'These treaties reduce the chance of double taxation by allowing each country to fully tax its citizens and residents and reducing the amount the other country can tax them.', u'Generally the treaties provide for reduced rates of tax on investment income and limits as to which business income can be taxed.', u'The treaties each define which taxpayers can benefit from the treaty.', u'== Social Insurance taxes ==\n\nThe United States social insurance system is funded by a tax similar to an income tax.', u'Social Security tax of 6.2% is imposed on wages paid to employees.', u'The tax is imposed on both the employer and the employee.', u'For 2011 and 2012, the employee tax has been reduced from 6.2% to 4.2%.', u'The maximum amount of wages subject to the tax for 2009, 2010, and 2011 was/is $106,800.', u'This amount is indexed for inflation.', u'A companion Medicare Tax of 1.45% of wages is imposed on employers and employees, with no limitation.', u'A self-employment tax in like amounts (totaling 15.3%, 13.3% for 2011 and 2012) is imposed on self-employed persons.', u'== Withholding of tax ==\n\nPersons paying wages or making certain payments to foreign persons are required to withhold income tax from such payments.', u'Income tax withholding on wages is based on declarations by employees and tables provided by the IRS.', u'Persons paying interest, dividends, royalties, and certain other amounts to foreign persons must also withhold income tax at a flat rate of 30%.', u'This rate may be reduced by a tax treaty.', u'These withholding requirements also apply to non-U.S. financial institutions.', u'Additional backup withholding provisions apply to some payments of interest or dividends to U.S. persons.', u'The amount of income tax withheld is treated as a payment of tax by the person receiving the payment on which tax was withheld.', u'Employers and employees must also pay Social Security tax, the employee portion of which is also be withheld from wages.', u'Withholding of income and Social Security taxes are often referred to as payroll tax.', u'== Tax returns ==\nIndividuals (with income above a minimum level), corporations, partnerships, estates, and trusts must file annual reports, called tax returns, with federal and appropriate state tax authorities.', u'These returns vary greatly in complexity level depending on the type of filer and complexity of their affairs.', u'On the return, the taxpayer reports income and deductions, calculates the amount of tax owed, reports payments and credits, and calculates the balance due.', u'Federal individual, estate, and trust income tax returns are due by April 15 for most taxpayers.', u"Corporate and partnership Federal returns are due two and one half months following the corporation's year end.", u"Tax exempt entity returns are due four and one half months following the entity's year end.", u'All federal returns may be extended, with most extensions available upon merely filing a single page form.', u'Due dates and extension provisions for state and local income tax returns vary.', u'Income tax returns generally consist of the basic form with attached forms and schedules.', u"Several forms are available for individuals and corporations, depending on complexity and nature of the taxpayer's affairs.", u'Many individuals are able to use the one page Form 1040-EZ, which requires no attachments except wage statements from employers (Forms W-2).', u'Individuals claiming itemized deductions must complete Schedule A.', u'Similar schedules apply for interest (B), dividends (B), business income (C), capital gains (D), farm income (F), and self-employment tax (SE).', u'All taxpayers must file those forms for credits, depreciation, AMT, and other items that apply to them.', u'Electronic filing of tax returns may be done for taxpayers by registered tax preparers.', u'If a taxpayer discovers an error on a return, or determines that tax for a year should be different, the taxpayer should file an amended return.', u'These returns constitute claims for refund if taxes are determined to have been overpaid.', u'== Tax examinations ==\n\nThe IRS, state, and local tax authorities may examine a tax return and propose changes.', u'Changes to tax returns may be made with minimal advance involvement by taxpayers, such as changes to wage or dividend income to correct errors.', u'Other examination of returns may require extensive taxpayer involvement, such as an audit by the IRS.', u'These audits often require that taxpayers provide the IRS or other tax authority access to records of income and deductions.', u'Audits of businesses are usually conducted by IRS personnel at the business location.', u'Changes to returns are subject to appeal by the taxpayer, including going to court.', u'IRS changes are often first issued as proposed adjustments.', u'The taxpayer may agree to the proposal, or may advise the IRS why it disagrees.', u'Proposed adjustments are often resolved by the IRS and taxpayer agreeing to what the adjustment should be.', u'For those adjustments to which agreement is not reached, the IRS issues a 30-day letter advising of the adjustment.', u'The taxpayer may appeal this preliminary assessment within 30 days within the IRS.', u'The Appeals Division reviews the IRS field team determination and taxpayer arguments, and often proposes a solution that the IRS team and the taxpayer find acceptable.', u'Where agreement is still not reached, the IRS issues an assessment as a notice of deficiency or 90-day letter.', u'The taxpayer then has three choices: file suit in United States Tax Court without paying the tax, pay the tax and sue for refund in regular court, or pay the tax and be done.', u'Recourse to court can be costly and time consuming, but is often successful.', u'IRS computers routinely make adjustments to correct mechanical errors in returns.', u'In addition, the IRS conducts an extensive document matching computer program that compares taxpayer amounts of wages, interest, dividends, and other items to amounts reported by taxpayers.', u'These programs automatically issue 30-day letters advising of proposed changes.', u'Only a very small percentage of tax returns are actually examined.', u'These are selected by a combination of computer analysis of return information and random sampling.', u'The IRS has long maintained a program to identify patterns on returns most likely to require adjustment.', u'Procedures for examination by state and local authorities vary by jurisdiction.', u'=== Tax collection ===\nTaxpayers are required to pay all taxes owed based on the self-assessed tax returns, as adjusted.', u'The IRS collection process allows taxpayers to in certain circumstances, and provides time payment plans that include interest and a "penalty" that is merely added interest.', u'Where taxpayers do not pay tax owed, the IRS has strong means to enforce collection.', u'These include the ability to levy bank accounts and seize property.', u'Generally, significant advance notice is given before levy or seizure.', u'However, in certain rarely used jeopardy assessments the IRS may immediately seize money and property.', u'The IRS Collection Divisions are responsible for most collection activities.', u'== Statute of limitations ==\nThe IRS is precluded from assessing additional tax after a certain period of time.', u'In the case of federal income tax, this period is generally three years from the later of the due date of the original tax return or the date the original return was filed.', u'The IRS has an additional three more years to make changes if the taxpayer has substantially understated gross income.', u'The period under which the IRS may make changes is unlimited in the case of fraud, or in the case of failure to file a return.', u'== Penalties ==\n\nTaxpayers who fail to file returns, file late, or file returns that are wrong, may be subject to penalties.', u'These penalties vary based on the type of failure.', u'Some penalties are computed like interest, some are fixed amounts, and some are based on other measures.', u'Penalties for filing or paying late are generally based on the amount of tax that should have been paid and the degree of lateness.', u'Penalties for failures related to certain forms are fixed amounts, and vary by form from very small to huge.', u'Intentional failures, including tax fraud, may result in criminal penalties.', u'These penalties may include jail time or forfeiture of property.', u'Criminal penalties are assessed in coordination with the United States Department of Justice.', u'== History ==\n\n\n=== Constitutional ===\n\nArticle I, Section 8, Clause 1 of the United States Constitution (the "Taxing and Spending Clause"), specifies Congress\'s power to impose "Taxes, Duties, Imposts and Excises", but Article I, Section 8 requires that, "Duties, Imposts and Excises shall be uniform throughout the United States."', u'The Constitution specifically stated Congress\' method of imposing direct taxes, by requiring Congress to distribute direct taxes in proportion to each state\'s population "determined by adding to the whole Number of free Persons, including those bound to Service for a Term of Years, and excluding Indians not taxed, three fifths of all other Persons".', u'It has been argued that head taxes and property taxes (slaves could be taxed as either or both) were likely to be abused, and that they bore no relation to the activities in which the federal government had a legitimate interest.', u'The fourth clause of section 9 therefore specifies that, "No Capitation, or other direct, Tax shall be laid, unless in Proportion to the Census or enumeration herein before directed to be taken."', u'Taxation was also the subject of Federalist No.', u'33 penned secretly by the Federalist Alexander Hamilton under the pseudonym Publius.', u'In it, he asserts that the wording of the "Necessary and Proper" clause should serve as guidelines for the legislation of laws regarding taxation.', u'The legislative branch is to be the judge, but any abuse of those powers of judging can be overturned by the people, whether as states or as a larger group.', u'The courts have generally held that direct taxes are limited to taxes on people (variously called "capitation", "poll tax" or "head tax") and property.', u'All other taxes are commonly referred to as "indirect taxes," because they tax an event, rather than a person or property per se.', u'What seemed to be a straightforward limitation on the power of the legislature based on the subject of the tax proved inexact and unclear when applied to an income tax, which can be arguably viewed either as a direct or an indirect tax.', u'=== Early federal income taxes ===\nThe first income tax suggested in the United States was during the War of 1812.', u'The idea for the tax was based on the British Tax Act of 1798.', u'The British tax law applied progressive rates to income.', u'The British tax rates ranged from 0.833% on income starting at \xa360 to 10% on income above \xa3200.', u'The tax proposal was developed in 1814.', u'Because the treaty of Ghent was signed in 1815, ending hostilities and the need for additional revenue, the tax was never imposed in the United States.', u'In order to help pay for its war effort in the American Civil War, Congress imposed its first personal income tax in 1861.', u'It was part of the Revenue Act of 1861 (3% of all incomes over US $800).', u'This tax was repealed and replaced by another income tax in 1862.', u'In 1894, Democrats in Congress passed the Wilson-Gorman tariff, which imposed the first peacetime income tax.', u'The rate was 2% on income over $4000, which meant fewer than 10% of households would pay any.', u'The purpose of the income tax was to make up for revenue that would be lost by tariff reductions.', u"In 1895 the United States Supreme Court, in its ruling in Pollock v. Farmers' Loan & Trust Co., held a tax based on receipts from the use of property to be unconstitutional.", u'The Court held that taxes on rents from real estate, on interest income from personal property and other income from personal property (which includes dividend income) were treated as direct taxes on property, and therefore had to be apportioned (divided among the states based on their populations).', u'Since apportionment of income taxes is impractical, this had the effect of prohibiting a federal tax on income from property.', u'However, the Court affirmed that the Constitution did not deny Congress the power to impose a tax on real and personal property, and it affirmed that such would be a direct tax.', u'Due to the political difficulties of taxing individual wages without taxing income from property, a federal income tax was impractical from the time of the Pollock decision until the time of ratification of the Sixteenth Amendment (below).', u'=== Ratification of the Sixteenth Amendment ===\n\nIn response, Congress proposed the Sixteenth Amendment (ratified by the requisite number of states in 1913), which states:\n\nThe Congress shall have power to lay and collect taxes on incomes, from whatever source derived, without apportionment among the several States, and without regard to any census or enumeration.', u"The Supreme Court in Brushaber v. Union Pacific Railroad, 240 U.S. 1 (1916), indicated that the amendment did not expand the federal government's existing power to tax income (meaning profit or gain from any source) but rather removed the possibility of classifying an income tax as a direct tax on the basis of the source of the income.", u'The Amendment removed the need for the income tax to be apportioned among the states on the basis of population.', u'Income taxes are required, however, to abide by the law of geographical uniformity.', u'Some tax protesters and others opposed to income taxes cite what they contend is evidence that the Sixteenth Amendment was never properly ratified, based in large part on materials sold by William J. Benson.', u'In December 2007, Benson\'s "Defense Reliance Package" containing his non-ratification argument which he offered for sale on the Internet, was ruled by a federal court to be a "fraud perpetrated by Benson" that had "caused needless confusion and a waste of the customers\' and the IRS\' time and resources".', u'The court stated: "Benson has failed to point to evidence that would create a genuinely disputed fact regarding whether the Sixteenth Amendment was properly ratified or whether United States Citizens are legally obligated to pay federal taxes."', u'See also Tax protester Sixteenth Amendment arguments.', u'=== Modern interpretation of the power to tax incomes ===\nThe modern interpretation of the Sixteenth Amendment taxation power can be found in Commissioner v. Glenshaw Glass Co. 348 U.S. 426 (1955).', u'In that case, a taxpayer had received an award of punitive damages from a competitor for antitrust violations and sought to avoid paying taxes on that award.', u'The Court observed that Congress, in imposing the income tax, had defined gross income, under the Internal Revenue Code of 1939, to include:\n\ngains, profits, and income derived from salaries, wages or compensation for personal service ... of whatever kind and in whatever form paid, or from professions, vocations, trades, businesses, commerce, or sales, or dealings in property, whether real or personal, growing out of the ownership or use of or interest in such property; also from interest, rent, dividends, securities, or the transaction of any business carried on for gain or profit, or gains or profits and income derived from any source whatever.', u'(Note: The Glenshaw Glass case was an interpretation of the definition of "gross income" in section 22 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1939.', u'The successor to section 22 of the 1939 Code is section 61 of the current Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended.)', u'The Court held that "this language was used by Congress to exert in this field the full measure of its taxing power", id., and that "the Court has given a liberal construction to this broad phraseology in recognition of the intention of Congress to tax all gains except those specifically exempted."', u'The Court then enunciated what is now understood by Congress and the Courts to be the definition of taxable income, "instances of undeniable accessions to wealth, clearly realized, and over which the taxpayers have complete dominion."', u'Id.', u'at 431.', u'The defendant in that case suggested that a 1954 rewording of the tax code had limited the income that could be taxed, a position which the Court rejected, stating:\n\nThe definition of gross income has been simplified, but no effect upon its present broad scope was intended.', u'Certainly punitive damages cannot reasonably be classified as gifts, nor do they come under any other exemption provision in the Code.', u'We would do violence to the plain meaning of the statute and restrict a clear legislative attempt to bring the taxing power to bear upon all receipts constitutionally taxable were we to say that the payments in question here are not gross income.', u'Tax statutes passed after the ratification of the Sixteenth Amendment in 1913 are sometimes referred to as the "modern" tax statutes.', u'Hundreds of Congressional acts have been passed since 1913, as well as several codifications (i.e., topical reorganizations) of the statutes (see Codification).', u'In Central Illinois Public Service Co. v. United States, 435 U.S. 21 (1978), the U.S. Supreme Court confirmed that wages and income are not identical as far as taxes on income are concerned, because income not only includes wages, but any other gains as well.', u'The Court in that case noted that in enacting taxation legislation, Congress "chose not to return to the inclusive language of the Tariff Act of 1913, but, specifically, \'in the interest of simplicity and ease of administration,\' confined the obligation to withhold [income taxes] to \'salaries, wages, and other forms of compensation for personal services\'" and that "committee reports ... stated consistently that \'wages\' meant remuneration \'if paid for services performed by an employee for his employer\'".', u'Other courts have noted this distinction in upholding the taxation not only of wages, but also of personal gain derived from other sources, recognizing some limitation to the reach of income taxation.', u'For example, in Conner v. United States, 303 F. Supp.', u'1187 (S.D.', u'Tex.', u"1969), aff'd in part and rev'd in part, 439 F.2d 974 (5th Cir.", u'1971), a couple had lost their home to a fire, and had received compensation for their loss from the insurance company, partly in the form of hotel costs reimbursed.', u'The court acknowledged the authority of the IRS to assess taxes on all forms of payment, but did not permit taxation on the compensation provided by the insurance company, because unlike a wage or a sale of goods at a profit, this was not a gain.', u'As the Court noted, "Congress has taxed income, not compensation".', u'By contrast, other courts have interpreted the Constitution as providing even broader taxation powers for Congress.', u'In Murphy v. IRS, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit upheld the federal income tax imposed on a monetary settlement recovery that the same court had previously indicated was not income, stating: "[a]lthough the \'Congress cannot make a thing income which is not so in fact,\'... it can label a thing income and tax it, so long as it acts within its constitutional authority, which includes not only the Sixteenth Amendment but also Article I, Sections 8 and 9."', u'Similarly, in Penn Mutual Indemnity Co. v. Commissioner, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit indicated that Congress could properly impose the federal income tax on a receipt of money, regardless of what that receipt of money is called:\n\nIt could well be argued that the tax involved here [an income tax] is an "excise tax" based upon the receipt of money by the taxpayer.', u'It certainly is not a tax on property and it certainly is not a capitation tax; therefore, it need not be apportioned.', u'... Congress has the power to impose taxes generally, and if the particular imposition does not run afoul of any constitutional restrictions then the tax is lawful, call it what you will.', u'=== Income tax rates in history ===\n\n\n==== History of top rates ====\n\nIn 1913, the top tax rate was 7% on incomes above $500,000 (equivalent to $12 million in 2015 dollars) and a total of $28.3 million was collected.', u'During World War I, the top rate rose to 77% and the income threshold to be in this top bracket increased to $1,000,000 (equivalent to $18.5 million in 2015 dollars).', u'Under Treasury Secretary Andrew Mellon, top tax rates were reduced in 1921, 1924, 1926, and 1928.', u'Mellon argued that lower rates would spur economic growth.', u'By 1928, the top rate was scaled down to 24% along with the income threshold for paying this rate lowered to $100,000 (equivalent to $1.38 million in 2015 dollars).', u'During the Great Depression and World War II, the top income tax rate rose from pre-war levels.', u'In 1939, the top rate was 75% applied to incomes above $5,000,000 (equivalent to $85.2 million in 2015 dollars).', u'During 1944 and 1945, the top rate was its all-time high at 94% applied to income above $200,000 (equivalent to $2.69 million in 2015 dollars).', u'The highest marginal tax rate for individuals for U.S. federal income tax purposes for tax years 1952 and 1953 was 92%.', u'From 1964-2013, the threshold for paying top income tax rate has generally been between $200,000 and $400,000 (unadjusted for inflation).', u'The one exception is the period from 1982 to 1992 when the topmost income tax brackets were removed.', u'From 1981 until 1986 the top marginal rate was lowered to 50% on $86,000 and up (equivalent to $224 thousand in 2015 dollars).', u'From 1988 to 1990, the threshold for paying the top rate was even lower, with incomes above $29,750 (equivalent to $59.6 thousand in 2015 dollars) paying the top rate of 28% in those years.', u'Top tax rates were increased in 1992 and 1994, culminating in a 39.6% top individual rate applicable to all classes of income.', u'Top individual tax rates were lowered in 2004 to 35% and tax rates on dividends and capital gains lowered to 15%, with the Bush administration claiming lower rates would spur economic growth.', u"Based on the summary of federal tax income data in 2009, with a tax rate of 35%, the highest earning 1% of people paid 36.7% of the United States' income tax revenue.", u'In 2012, President Obama announced plans to raise the two top tax rates from 35% to 39.6% and from 33% to 36%.', u'==== Federal income tax rates ====\nFederal and state income tax rates have varied widely since 1913.', u'For example, in 1954, the federal income tax was based on layers of 24 income brackets at tax rates ranging from 20% to 91% (for a chart, see Internal Revenue Code of 1954).', u'Below is a table of historical marginal income tax rates for married filing jointly tax payers at stated income levels.', u'These income numbers are not the amounts used in the tax laws at the time.', u'== Sources of U.S. income tax laws ==\nUnited States income tax law comes from a number of sources.', u'These sources have been divided by one author into three tiers as follows:\nTier 1\nUnited States Constitution\nInternal Revenue Code (IRC) (legislative authority, written by the United States Congress through legislation)\nTreasury regulations\nFederal court opinions (judicial authority, written by courts as interpretation of legislation)\nTreaties (executive authority, written in conjunction with other countries)\n\nTier 2\nAgency interpretative regulations (executive authority, written by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and Department of the Treasury), including:\nFinal, Temporary and Proposed Regulations promulgated under IRC \xa7 7805;\nTreasury Notices and Announcements;\n\nPublic Administrative Rulings (IRS Revenue Rulings, which provide informal guidance on specific questions and are binding on all taxpayers)\n\nTier 3\nLegislative History\nPrivate Administrative Rulings (private parties may approach the IRS directly and ask for a Private Letter Ruling on a specific issue \u2013 these rulings are binding only on the requesting taxpayer).', u'Where conflicts exist between various sources of tax authority, an authority in Tier 1 outweighs an authority in Tier 2 or 3.', u'Similarly, an authority in Tier 2 outweighs an authority in Tier 3.', u'Where conflicts exist between two authorities in the same tier, the "last-in-time rule" is applied.', u'As the name implies, the "last-in-time rule" states that the authority that was issued later in time is controlling.', u'Regulations and case law serve to interpret the statutes.', u'Additionally, various sources of law attempt to do the same thing.', u'Revenue Rulings, for example, serves as an interpretation of how the statutes apply to a very specific set of facts.', u'Treaties serve in an international realm.', u'== The complexity of the U.S. income tax laws ==\nUnited States tax law attempts to define a comprehensive system of measuring income in a complex economy.', u'Many provisions defining income or granting or removing benefits require significant definition of terms.', u'Further, many state income tax laws do not conform with federal tax law in material respects.', u'These factors and others have resulted in substantial complexity.', u'Even venerable legal scholars like Judge Learned Hand have expressed amazement and frustration with the complexity of the U.S. income tax laws.', u'In the article, Thomas Walter Swan, 57 Yale Law Journal No.', u'2, 167, 169 (December 1947), Judge Hand wrote:\n\nIn my own case the words of such an act as the Income Tax ... merely dance before my eyes in a meaningless procession: cross-reference to cross-reference, exception upon exception\u2014couched in abstract terms that offer [me] no handle to seize hold of [and that] leave in my mind only a confused sense of some vitally important, but successfully concealed, purport, which it is my duty to extract, but which is within my power, if at all, only after the most inordinate expenditure of time.', u'I know that these monsters are the result of fabulous industry and ingenuity, plugging up this hole and casting out that net, against all possible evasion; yet at times I cannot help recalling a saying of William James about certain passages of Hegel: that they were no doubt written with a passion of rationality; but that one cannot help wondering whether to the reader they have any significance save that the words are strung together with syntactical correctness.', u'Complexity is a separate issue from flatness of rate structures.', u'Also, in the United States, income tax laws are often used by legislatures as policy instruments for encouraging numerous undertakings deemed socially useful \u2014 including the buying of life insurance, the funding of employee health care and pensions, the raising of children, home ownership, development of alternative energy sources and increased investment in conventional energy.', u"Special tax provisions granted for any purpose increase complexity, irrespective of the system's flatness or lack thereof.", u'== State, local and territorial income taxes ==\n\nIncome tax is also levied by most U.S. states and many localities on individuals, corporations, estates, and trusts.', u'These taxes are in addition to federal income tax and are deductible for federal tax purposes.', u'State and local income tax rates vary from 1% to 16% of taxable income.', u'Some state and local income tax rates are flat (single rate) and some are graduated.', u'State and local definitions of what income is taxable vary highly.', u'Some states incorporate the federal definitions by reference.', u'Taxable income is defined separately and differently for individuals and corporations in some jurisdictions.', u'Some states impose alternative or additional taxes based on a second measure of income or capital.', u'States and localities tend to tax all income of residents.', u'States and localities only tax nonresidents on income allocated or apportioned to the jurisdiction.', u'Generally, nonresident individuals are taxed on wages earned in the state based on the portion of days worked in the state.', u'Many states require partnerships to pay tax for nonresident partners.', u'Tax returns are filed separately for states and localities imposing income tax, and may be due on dates that differ from federal due dates.', u'Some states permit related corporations to file combined or consolidated returns.', u'Most states and localities imposing income tax require estimated payments where tax exceeds certain thresholds, and require withholding tax on payment of wages.', u'Puerto Rico is treated as a separate taxing entity from the USA; its income tax rates are set independently, and only some residents there pay federal income taxes (though everyone must pay all other federal taxes).', u'The unincorporated territories Guam, American Samoa, and the Virgin Islands also impose income tax separately, under a "mirror" tax law based on federal income tax law.', u'== Controversies ==\n\n\n=== Proposals for changes of income taxation ===\nProposals have been made frequently to change tax laws, often with the backing of specific interest groups.', u'Organizations making such proposals include Citizens for Tax Justice, Americans for Tax Reform, Americans for Tax Fairness, Citizens for an Alternative Tax System, Americans For Fair Taxation, and FreedomWorks.', u'Various proposals have been put forth for tax simplification in Congress including the Fair Tax Act and various Flat tax plans.', u'=== Alternatives ===\nProponents of a consumption tax argue that the income tax system creates perverse incentives by encouraging taxpayers to spend rather than save: a taxpayer is only taxed once on income spent immediately, while any interest earned on saved income is itself taxed.', u'To the extent that this is considered unjust, it may be remedied in a variety of ways, e.g.', u'excluding investment income from taxable income, making investments deductible and therefore only taxing them when gains are realized, or replacing the income tax by other forms of tax, such as a sales tax.', u'=== Taxation vs. the states ===\nSome economists believe income taxation offers the federal government a technique to diminish the power of the states, because the federal government is then able to distribute funding to states with conditions attached, often giving the states no choice but to submit to federal demands.', u'=== Tax protestors ===\nNumerous tax protester arguments have been raised asserting that the federal income tax is unconstitutional, including discredited claims that the Sixteenth Amendment was not properly ratified.', u'All such claims have been repeatedly rejected by the federal courts as frivolous.', u'=== Distribution ===\n\nIn the United States, a progressive tax system is employed which equates to higher income earners paying a larger percentage of their income in taxes.', u'According to the IRS, the top 1% of income earners for 2008 paid 38% of income tax revenue, while earning 20% of the income reported.', u'The top 5% of income earners paid 59% of the total income tax revenue, while earning 35% of the income reported.', u'The top 10% paid 70%, earning 46% and the top 25% paid 86%, earning 67%.', u'The top 50% paid 97%, earning 87% and leaving the bottom 50% paying 3% of the taxes collected and earning 13% of the income reported.', u'From 1979 to 2007 the average federal income tax rate fell 110% for the second lowest quintile, 56% for the middle quintile, 39% for the fourth quintile, 8% for the highest quintile, and 15% for the top 1%, with the bottom quintile moving from a tax rate of zero to negative liability.', u'Despite this, individual income tax revenue only dropped from 8.7 to 8.5% of GDP over that time, and total federal revenue was 18.5% of GDP in both 1979 and 2007, above the postwar average of 18%.', u'Tax code changes have dropped millions of lower earning people from the federal income tax rolls in recent decades.', u'Those with zero or negative liability who were not claimed as dependents by a payer increased from 14.8% of the population in 1984 to 49.5% in 2009.', u'While there is consensus that overall federal taxation is progressive, there is dispute over whether progressivity has increased or decreased in recent decades, and by how much.', u'The total effective federal tax rate for the top 0.01% of income earners declined from around 75% to around 35% between 1960 and 2005.', u'Total effective federal tax rates fell from 19.1% to 12.5% for the three middle quintiles between 1979 and 2010, from 27.1% to 24% for the top quintile, from 7.5% to 1.5% for the bottom quintile, and from 35.1% to 29.4% for the top 1%.', u'A 2008 OECD study ranked 24 OECD nations by progressiveness of taxes and separately by progressiveness of cash transfers, which include pensions, unemployment and other benefits.', u'The United States had the highest concentration coefficient in income tax, a measure of progressiveness, before adjusting for income inequality.', u'The United States was not at the top of either measure for cash transfers.', u'Adjusting for income inequality, Ireland had the highest concentration coefficient for income taxes.', u'In 2008, overall income tax rates for the US were below the OECD average.', u'=== Effects on income inequality ===\n\nAccording to the CBO, U.S. federal tax policies substantially reduce income inequality measured after taxes.', u'Taxes became less progressive (i.e., they reduced income inequality relatively less) measured from 1979 to 2011.', u'The tax policies of the mid-1980s were the least progressive period since 1979.', u'Government transfer payments contributed more to reducing inequality than taxes.', u'== See also ==\nHylton v. {'sentences': [u'An address is a collection of information, presented in a mostly fixed format, used to give the location of a building, apartment, or other structure or a plot of land, generally using political boundaries and street names as references, along with other identifiers such as house or apartment numbers.', u'Some addresses also contain special codes, such as a post code, to aid routing of mail.', u'== Functions ==\nAddresses have several functions:\nproviding a means of physically locating a building, especially in a city where there are many buildings and streets;\nidentifying buildings as the end points of a postal system;\nsignalling social status;\nas parameters in statistics collection, especially in census-taking and the insurance industry;\naddresses are the most accepted representation of a location.', u'Addresses may have drawbacks:\nThey are a non-standardised means of representing a location;\nThey do not contain the coordinates of the location they represent.', u'== History ==\nUntil the advent of modern postal systems around the 18th-19th century, most houses and buildings were not numbered.', u'Streets may have been named for landmarks, such as a city gate or market, or for the professions of their inhabitants.', u'In many cities in Asia, most minor streets were never named.', u'This is still the case today in much of Japan.', u'A local postman would be familiar with the area and thus able to deliver mail, but as postal systems developed, it became necessary to number buildings to aid in mail delivery.', u'== Current addressing schemes ==\n\n\n=== House numbering or naming ===\n\nIn most English-speaking countries, the usual method of house numbering is an alternating numbering scheme progressing in one direction along a street, with odd numbers on one side (often west or south or the left-hand side leading away from a main road) and even numbers on the other side, although there is significant variation on this basic pattern.', u'Many older towns and cities in the UK have "up and down" numbering where the numbers progress sequentially along one side of the road, and then sequentially back down the other side.', u'Cities in North America, particularly those planned on a grid plan, often incorporate block numbers, quadrants (explained below), and cardinal directions into their street numbers, so that in many such cities, addresses roughly follow a Cartesian coordinate system.', u'Some other cities around the world have their own schemes.', u'Although house numbering is the principal identification scheme in many parts of the world, it is also common for houses in the United Kingdom and Ireland to be identified by name, rather than number, especially in villages.', u'In these cases, the street name will usually follow the house name.', u'Such an address might read: "Smith Cottage, Frog Lane, Barchester, Barsetshire, BZ9 9BA" or "Dunroamin, Emo, Co. Laois, Ireland" (fictional examples).', u'=== Quadrants ===\nIn cities with Cartesian-coordinate-based addressing systems, the streets that form the north-south and east-west dividing lines constitute the x and y axes of a Cartesian coordinate plane and thus divide the city into quadrants.', u'The quadrants are typically identified in the street names, although the manner of doing so varies from city to city.', u'For example, in one city, all streets in the northeast quadrant may have "NE" prefixed or suffixed to their street names, while in another, the intersection of North Calvert Street and East 27th Street can be only in the northeast quadrant.', u'=== Street-naming conventions ===\nStreet names may follow a variety of themes.', u'In many North American cities, such as, San Francisco USA, and Edmonton, Alberta, Canada, streets are simply numbered sequentially across the street grid.', u'Washington, D.C. has its numbered streets running north-south and lettered or alphabetically named streets running east-west, while diagonal avenues are typically named after states.', u'In Salt Lake City, and many other Utah cities, streets are in a large grid and are numbered in increments of 100 based on their location relative to the center of the city in blocks.', u'A similar system is in use in Detroit with the Mile Road System.', u'In some housing developments in North America and elsewhere, street names may all follow the same theme (for example, bird species), or start with the same letter.', u'Streets in Continental Europe, the Middle East, and Latin America are often named after famous people or significant dates.', u'=== Postal codes ===\nPostal codes are a relatively recent development in addressing, designed to speed the sorting and processing of mail by assigning unique numeric or alphanumeric codes to each geographical locality.', u"=== Postal alternatives to physical addresses ===\nFor privacy and other purposes, postal services have made it possible to receive mail without revealing one's physical address or even having a fixed physical address.", u'Examples are post office boxes, service addresses and poste restante (general delivery).', u'== Address format ==\n\nIn most of the world, addresses are written in order from most specific to general, i.e.', u'finest to coarsest information, starting with the addressee and ending with the largest geographical unit.', u'For example:\nIn English-speaking countries, the postal code usually comes last.', u'In much of Europe, the code precedes the town name, thus: "1010 Lausanne".', u'Often, the country code is still placed in front of the postal code: "CH-1010 Lausanne".', u'However, this is no longer demanded by postal authorities and has even been forbidden in certain countries.', u'If a house number is provided, it is written on the same line as the street name; a house name is written on the previous line.', u'When addresses are written inline, line breaks are replaced by commas.', u'Conventions on the placing of house numbers differ: either before or after the street name.', u'Similarly, there are differences in the placement of postal codes: in the UK, they are written on a separate line at the end of the address; in Australia, Canada and the United States, they usually appear immediately after the state or province, on the same line; in Austria, Belgium, France, Germany and The Netherlands they appear before the city, on the same line.', u'East Asian addressing systems, including Chinese, Japanese and Korean addressing systems, when written in their native scripts, use the opposite ordering, starting with the province/prefecture, ending with the addressee.', u'However both have the same order as western countries when written in the Latin alphabet.', u'The Hungarian system also goes from large to small units, except the name of the addressee is put into the first line.', u'The Universal Postal Convention strongly recommends the following:\n"The addressee\u2019s address shall be worded in a precise and complete manner.', u'It shall be written very legibly in roman letters and arabic numerals.', u'If other letters and numerals are used in the country of destination, it shall be recommended that the address be given also in these letters and numerals.', u'The name of the place of destination and the name of the country of destination shall be written in capital letters together with the correct postcode number or delivery zone number or post office box number, if any.', u'The name of the country of destination shall be written preferably in the language of the country of origin.', u'To avoid any difficulty in the countries of transit, it is desirable for the name of the country of destination to be added in an internationally known language.', u'Designated operators may recommend that, on items addressed to countries where the recommended position of the postcode is in front of the name of the location of destination, the postcode should be preceded by the EN ISO 3166\u20131 Alpha 2 country code followed by a hyphen.', u'This shall in no way detract from the requirement for the name of the destination country to be printed in full."', u'== Mailing address format by country ==\n\n\n=== Argentina ===\nIn Argentina, an address must be mailed this way:\nThe postal code has been changed from a four digit format to an eight digit format, which is shown in the example.', u'The new format adds a district or province letter code at the beginning, which allows it to be identified.', u'As the system has been changed recently, the four digit format can still be used: in that case it is necessary to add the name of the province or district.', u'=== Australia ===\nIn common with the rest of the English-speaking world, addresses in Australia put the street number\u2014which may be a range\u2014before the street name, and the placename before the postcode.', u'Unlike addresses in most other comparable places, the city is not included in the address, but rather a much more fine-grained locality is used, usually referred to in Australia as a suburb or town \u2013 although these words are understood in a different way than in other countries.', u'Because the suburb or town serves to locate the street or delivery type, the postcode serves only as routing information rather than to distinguish previous other parts of an address.', u'As an example, there are around 8000 localities in Victoria (cf.', u'List of localities in Victoria (Australia) and List of Melbourne suburbs), yet regular postal codes in that they do not have a street name line.', u'Some bulk customer postal codes are shared between several organizations.', u'There are a few places that have house numbers but P.O.', u'boxes.', u"Post codes follow the structure of DPAG's mail routing, not administrative boundaries.", u'Each post code is used exclusively for street addresses, P.O.', u'boxes or bulk recipients.', u'Sub-building information, such as apartment numbers, is rarely used - a name on the post box is usually the only method of identification of an addressee within a building.', u"=== Greece ===\nHellenic Post recommends the following format for Greek addresses:\nThe most widespread format, shown above, gives at the last line the recipient's five-digit post code (with a single space between the third and fourth digits) and the name of the town or village that is the base of a post office, in capital letters and separated from the postcode by two spaces.", u'When sending mail abroad, or when sending mail from abroad to Greece, Hellenic Post recommends the following format:\nLike mail for delivery within the country, mail sent from abroad must contain the postcode in the same manner, but the postcode must be preceded by the international prefix of the country of delivery (for Greece, GR).', u'Below the destination, the country of delivery must be written in capital letters, either in English or French (for Greece, GR\xc8CE or GREECE).', u'=== Hong Kong ===\nThe official languages of Hong Kong are English and Cantonese Chinese.', u'For domestic mail within Hong Kong, the address may be written entirely in either English or Chinese.', u'For overseas mail going out from Hong Kong, the address may be written in the language of the destination country, provided that the city name and the country name are in English.', u'However, for an overseas mail from Hong Kong to China, Macao, Taiwan or Singapore, the address may be written entirely in Chinese.', u"While traditional Chinese characters are commonly used in Hong Kong, simplified Chinese characters are also understood by Hong Kong's postmen.", u'Note that Hong Kong does not use any follows:\nThe locality is required only where its absence would cause ambiguity, for example where a post town or postcode district includes two streets with the same name.', u'Royal Mail specifies that post towns should be written in block capitals.', u'Until 1996 a postal county (or permitted abbreviation) was required after the post town, unless it was a special post town, for example London.', u'The post town and postcode should each be on a separate line.', u'Historically, each line of an address ended with a comma and was indented from the previous line.', u'Royal Mail discourage this usage and specify that all lines should start from the same point and not be staggered or aligned to the centre.', u'The postcode identifies, from left to right, increasingly smaller this reason the recipient may choose to insert their physical (aka street) address as line two, expanding the complete address to four lines.', u'Providing both allows a sender to ship via the USPS or via a private carrier.', u'Some USPS facilities allow a user of a P.O.', u'box to use the street address of the postal facility with the P.O.', u'box number in the place of a suite number, in which case the user may receive packages from private carriers.', u'Mail will be delivered to the line immediately above the city, state, zip code line.', u'The state and type of street, e.g.', u'Lane, is often abbreviated as shown in the PO standard.', u'The USPS discourages the use of all punctuation except the hyphen in ZIP+4 codes, slashes in fractional addresses, hyphenated street numbers, and periods in decimal addresses (e.g.', u'the street name contains a decimal point).', u'Hyphenated street numbers are common in the New York City borough of Queens, Hawaii, and Southern California; see house numbering.', u'Sometimes the name of the town required by United States Postal Service does not necessarily mean that address is within that city.', u'See also ZIP codes and previous zoning lines.', u'Standards for variations on this format (apartment, rural route, general delivery, grid, P.O.', u'Box and highway addresses) are covered in USPS Publication 28.', u'Puerto Rico addresses often include an urbanization or condominium name.', u'The USPS allows for Spanish conventions in addresses in Puerto Rico.', u'The USPS prefers that territories be addressed in the standard domestic format (e.g.', u'"San Juan PR 00907") but in practice territory names are sometimes written as if they are a country (e.g.', u'"San Juan 00907 Puerto Rico").', u'International United States Department of State mail will use "DPO" as the city; military mail will use "APO" or "FPO".', u'Both use "AE", "AP", or "AA" in place of the state code, depending on the continent.', u'Three independent
