oil, like Manchego cheese.', u'Atlantic Spain \u2013 the whole Northern coast, including Asturian, Basque, Cantabrian and Galician cuisine \u2013 vegetable and fish-based stews like caldo gallego and marmitako.', u'Also, the lightly cured lac\xf3n ham.', u'The best known cuisine of the northern countries often rely on ocean seafood, like the Basque-style cod, albacore or anchovy or the Galician style association football since the early 20th century.', u'Real Madrid C.F.', u'and FC Barcelona are two of the most successful football clubs in the world.', u"The country's national football team festivities in Spain.', u'Some of them are known worldwide, and every year millions of people from all over the world go to Spain to experience one of these festivals.', u'One of the most famous is San Ferm\xedn, in Pamplona.', u'While its most famous event is the encierro, or the running of the bulls, which happens at 8:00 am from 7 to 14 July, the week-long celebration involves many other traditional and folkloric events.', u'Its events were central to the plot of The Sun Also Rises, by Ernest Hemingway, which brought it to the general attention of English-speaking people.', u'As a result, it has become one of the most internationally renowned fiestas in Spain, with over 1,000,000 people attending every year.', u'Other festivals include the carnivals in the Canary Islands, the Falles in Valencia or the Holy Week in Andalusia and Castile and Le\xf3n.', u'== See also ==\nOutline of Spain\n Spain \u2013 Wikipedia book\n\n\n== Notes ==\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== Further reading ==\nGates, David (2001).', u'The Spanish Ulcer: A History of the Peninsular War.', u'Da Capo Press.', u'p. 20.', u'ISBN 978-0-306-81083-1.', u'== External links ==\n\n"Spain".', u'The World Factbook.', u'Central Intelligence Agency.', u'Spain from UCB Libraries GovPubs\nSpain at DMOZ\nSpain from the BBC News\nKey Development Forecasts for Spain from International Futures\nGovernment\nE-Government portal for Spain\nMaps\n Wikimedia Atlas of Spain\n Geographic data related to Spain at OpenStreetMap\nTourism\nOfficial tourism portal for Spain'], 'year': '1886-10-07', 'title': 'Spain abolishes slavery in Cuba'}
{'sentences': [u'Andrei Dmitrievich Sakharov (Russian: \u0410\u043d\u0434\u0440\u0435\u0301\u0439 \u0414\u043c\u0438\u0301\u0442\u0440\u0438\u0435\u0432\u0438\u0447 \u0421\u0430\u0301\u0445\u0430\u0440\u043e\u0432; 21 May 1921 \u2013 14 December 1989) was a Russian nuclear physicist, Soviet dissident, an activist for disarmament, peace and human rights.', u"He became renowned as the designer of the Soviet Union's Third Idea, a codename for Soviet development of thermonuclear weapons.", u'Sakharov later became an advocate of civil liberties and civil reforms in the Soviet Union, for which he faced state persecution; these efforts earned him the Nobel Peace Prize in 1975.', u'The Sakharov Prize, which is awarded annually by the European Parliament for people and organizations dedicated to human rights and freedoms, is named in his honour.', u'== Biography ==\n\nSakharov was born in Moscow on May 21, 1921.', u'His father was Dmitri Ivanovich Sakharov, a private school physics teacher and an amateur pianist.', u'His father later taught at the Second Moscow State University.', u"Andrei's grandfather Ivan had been a prominent lawyer in the Russian Empire who had displayed respect for social awareness and humanitarian principles (including advocating the abolition of capital punishment) that would later influence his grandson.", u"Sakharov's mother was Yekaterina Alekseyevna Sakharova, a great-granddaughter of the prominent military commander Alexey Semenovich Sofiano (who was of Greek ancestry).", u"Sakharov's parents and paternal grandmother, Maria Petrovna, largely shaped his personality.", u"Although Sakharov's paternal great-grandfather had been a priest in the Russian Orthodox Church, and his pious mother had him baptised, Sakharov was an atheist in later life.", u'However, he did believe that a "guiding principle" governed the universe and human life.', u'=== Education and career ===\nSakharov entered Moscow State University in 1938.', u"Following evacuation in 1941 during the Great Patriotic War (World War II), he graduated in A\u015fgabat, in today's Turkmenistan.", u'He was then assigned to laboratory work in Ulyanovsk.', u'In 1943, he married Klavdia Alekseyevna Vikhireva, with whom he raised two daughters and a son before she died in 1969.', u'He returned to Moscow in 1945 to study at the Theoretical Department of FIAN (the Physical Institute of the Soviet Academy of Sciences).', u'He received his Ph.D. in 1947.', u'=== Development of thermonuclear devices ===\n\nAfter the end of World War II, he researched cosmic rays.', u'In mid-1948 he participated in the Soviet atomic bomb project under Igor Kurchatov and Igor Tamm.', u"Sakharov's study group at FIAN in 1948 came up with a second concept in August\u2013September 1948.", u'Adding a shell of natural, unenriched uranium around the deuterium would increase the deuterium concentration at the uranium-deuterium boundary and the overall yield of the device, because the natural uranium would capture neutrons and itself fission as part of the thermonuclear reaction.', u'This idea of a layered fission-fusion-fission bomb led Sakharov to call it the sloika, or layered cake.', u'The first Soviet atomic device was tested on August 29, 1949.', u"After moving to Sarov in 1950, Sakharov played a key role in the development of the first megaton-range Soviet hydrogen bomb using a design known as Sakharov's Third Idea in Russia and the Teller-Ulam design in the United States.", u'Before his Third Idea, Sakharov tried a "layer cake" of alternating layers of fission and fusion fuel.', u'The results were disappointing, yielding no more than a typical fission bomb.', u'However the design was seen to be worth pursuing because deuterium is abundant and uranium is scarce, and he had no idea how powerful the US design was.', u'One of the Bikini atomic experiments changed that, because the magnitude of the explosion became public knowledge when there was a dispute between Japan and the US over the contamination of a large area of ocean.', u'Sakharov was surprised by the size of the explosion and realized that the Americans had harnessed the power of a separate fission explosion to compress the fusion fuel.', u'Sakharov realised that in order to cause the explosion of one side of the fuel to symmetrically compress the fusion fuel, a mirror could be used to reflect the radiation.', u'The details had not been officially declassified in Russia when Sakharov was writing his memoirs, but in the Teller-Ulam design, soft X-rays emitted by the fission bomb were focused onto a cylinder of lithium deuteride to compress it symmetrically.', u'This is called radiation implosion.', u'The Teller-Ulam design also had a secondary fission device inside the fusion cylinder to assist with the compression of the fusion fuel and generate neutrons to convert some of the lithium to tritium, producing a mixture of deuterium and tritium.', u"Sakharov's idea was first tested as RDS-37 in 1955.", u'A larger variation of the same design which Sakharov worked on was the 50 Mt Tsar Bomba of October 1961, which was the most powerful nuclear device ever detonated.', u'Sakharov saw "striking parallels" between his fate and those of J. Robert Oppenheimer and Edward Teller in the USA.', u'Sakharov believed that in this "tragic confrontation of two outstanding people", both deserved respect, because "each of them was certain he had right on his side and was morally obligated to go to the end in the name of truth."', u'While Sakharov strongly disagreed with Teller over nuclear testing in the atmosphere and the Strategic Defense Initiative, he believed that American academics had been unfair to Teller\'s resolve to get the H-bomb for the United States since "all steps by the Americans of a temporary or permanent rejection of developing thermonuclear weapons would have been seen either as a clever feint, or as the manifestation of stupidity.', u'In both cases, the reaction would have been the same \u2013 avoid the trap and immediately take advantage of the enemy\'s stupidity."', u'Sakharov never felt that by creating nuclear weapons he had "known sin", in Oppenheimer\'s expression.', u'He later wrote: "After more than forty years, we have had no third world war, and the balance of nuclear terror ... may have helped to prevent one.', u"But I am not at all sure of this; back then, in those long-gone years, the question didn't even arise.", u'What most troubles me now is the instability of the balance, the extreme peril of the current situation, the appalling waste of the arms race ... Each of us has a responsibility to think about this in global terms, with tolerance, trust, and candor, free from ideological dogmatism, parochial interests, or national egotism."', u'=== Support for peaceful use of nuclear technology ===\n\nIn 1950 he proposed an idea for a controlled nuclear fusion reactor, the tokamak, which is still the basis for the majority of work in the area.', u'Sakharov, in association with Igor Tamm, proposed confining extremely hot ionized plasma by torus shaped magnetic fields for controlling thermonuclear fusion that led to the development of the tokamak device.', u'=== Efforts to improve nuclear reactor technology ===\nIn 1951 he invented and tested the first explosively pumped flux compression generators, compressing magnetic fields by explosives.', u'He called these devices MC or MK (for magnetocumulative) generators.', u'The radial MK-1 produced a pulsed magnetic field of 25 megagauss (2500 teslas).', u'The resulting helical MK-2 generated 1000 million amperes in 1953.', u'Sakharov then tested a MK-driven "plasma cannon" where a small aluminum ring was vaporized by huge eddy currents into a stable, self-confined toroidal plasmoid and was accelerated to 100 km/s.', u'Sakharov later suggested replacing the copper coil in MK generators with a large superconductor solenoid to magnetically compress and focus underground nuclear explosions into a shaped charge effect.', u'He theorized this could focus 1023 protons per second on a 1 mm2 surface.', u'=== Research and physics ===\nAfter 1965 Sakharov returned to fundamental science and began working on particle physics and cosmology.', u'He tried to explain the baryon asymmetry of the universe, being the first scientist to introduce two universes called "sheets", linked by the Big Bang.', u'Sakharov achieved there a complete CPT symmetry since the second sheet is enantiomorph (P-symmetry), has an opposite arrow of time (T-symmetry) and is mainly populated by antimatter (C-symmetry) because of an opposite CP-violation.', u'In this model the two universes do not interact, except via local matter accumulation whose density and pressure become high enough to connect the two sheets through a bridge without spacetime between them, but with geodesics continuity beyond the radius limit allowing an exchange of matter.', u'Sakharov called such singularities a collapse and an anticollapse, which are an alternative to the couple black hole and white hole in the wormhole theory.', u'Sakharov also proposed the idea of induced gravity as an alternative theory of quantum gravity.', u'=== Turn to activism ===\nSince the late 1950s Sakharov had become concerned about the moral and political implications of his work.', u'Politically active during the 1960s, Sakharov was against nuclear proliferation.', u'Pushing for the end of atmospheric tests, he played a role in the 1963 Partial Test Ban Treaty, signed in Moscow.', u'Sakharov was also involved in an event with political consequences in 1964, when the USSR Academy of Sciences nominated for full membership Nikolai Nuzhdin, a follower of Trofim Lysenko (initiator of the Stalin-supported anti-genetics campaign Lysenkoism).', u'Contrary to normal practice Sakharov, a member of the Academy, publicly spoke out against full membership for Nuzhdin, holding him responsible for "for the defamation, firing, arrest, even death, of many genuine scientists."', u'In the end, Nuzhdin was not elected, but the episode prompted Sergei Khrushchev to order the KGB to gather compromising material on Sakharov.', u"The major turn in Sakharov's political evolution came in 1967, when anti-ballistic missile defense became a key issue in US\u2013Soviet relations.", u'In a secret detailed letter to the Soviet leadership of July 21, 1967, Sakharov explained the need to "take the Americans at their word" and accept their proposal for a "bilateral rejection by the USA and the Soviet Union of the development of antiballistic missile defense", because otherwise an arms race in this new technology would increase the likelihood of nuclear war.', u'He also asked permission to publish his manuscript (which accompanied the letter) in a newspaper to explain the dangers posed by this kind of defense.', u'The government ignored his letter and refused to let him initiate a public discussion of ABMs in the Soviet press.', u'In May 1968 Sakharov completed an essay entitled "Reflections on Progress, Peaceful Coexistence, and Intellectual Freedom".', u'In it, he described the anti-ballistic missile defense as a major threat of world nuclear war.', u'After this essay was circulated in samizdat and then published outside the Soviet Union, Sakharov was banned from conducting any military-related research and returned to FIAN to study fundamental theoretical physics.', u'Over the next twelve years, until his exile to Gorky (Nizhny Novgorod) in January 1980, Andrei Sakharov assumed the role of a widely recognized and open dissident in Moscow.', u'He stood vigil outside of closed courtrooms, wrote appeals on behalf of more than two hundred individual prisoners, and continued to write essays about the need for democratization.', u'In 1970 Sakharov was among the three founding members of the Committee on Human Rights in the USSR along with Valery Chalidze and Andrei Tverdokhlebov.', u'The Committee wrote appeals, collected signatures for petitions and succeeded in affiliating with several international human rights organizations.', u'Its work was the subject of many KGB reports and brought Sakharov under increasing pressure from the government.', u'Sakharvov married a fellow human rights activist, Yelena Bonner, in 1972.', u'By 1973 Sakharov was meeting regularly with Western correspondents, holding press conferences in his apartment.', u"He appealed to the U.S. Congress to approve the 1974 Jackson-Vanik Amendment to a trade bill, which coupled trade tariffs to the Kremlin's willingness to allow freer emigration.", u'=== Attacked by Soviet establishment, 1972 onwards ===\n\nIn 1972 Sakharov became the target of sustained pressure and intimidation, from his fellow scientists in the USSR Academy of Sciences, the Soviet press and direct threats of physical assault.', u'Dissident activists, including the writer Solzhenitsyn, sprang to his defence.', u'In 1973 and 1974, the Soviet media campaign continued, targeting both Sakharov and Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn.', u"While Sakharov disagreed with Solzhenitsyn's vision of Russian revival, he deeply respected him for his courage.", u"Only a few individuals in the Soviet Union were willing to defend 'traitors' like Sakharov and Solzhenitsyn, and those who had dared were inevitably punished.", u'Sakharov later described that it took "years" for him to "understand how much substitution, deceit, and lack of correspondence with reality there was" in the Soviet ideals.', u'"At first I thought, despite everything that I saw with my own eyes, that the Soviet State was a breakthrough into the future, a kind of prototype for all countries".', u'Then he came, in his words, to "the theory of symmetry: all governments and regimes to a first approximation are bad, all peoples are oppressed, and all are threatened by common dangers."', u'After that he realized that there is not much "symmetry between a cancer cell and a normal one.', u'Yet our state is similar to a cancer cell \u2013 with its messianism and expansionism, its totalitarian suppression of dissent, the authoritarian structure of power, with a total absence of public control in the most important decisions in domestic and foreign policy, a closed society that does not inform its citizens of anything substantial, closed to the outside world, without freedom of travel or the exchange of information."', u"Sakharov's ideas on social development led him to put forward the principle of human rights as a new basis of all politics.", u'In his works he declared that "the principle \'what is not prohibited is allowed\' should be understood literally", defying the unwritten ideological rules imposed by the Communist ruling elite on the society in spite of the seemingly democratic (1936) USSR Constitution.', u'In no way did Sakharov consider himself a prophet or the like: "I am no volunteer priest of the idea, but simply a man with an unusual fate.', u'I am against all kinds of self-immolation (for myself and for others, including the people closest to me)."', u'In a letter written from exile, he cheered up a fellow physicist and human rights activist with the words: "Fortunately, the future is unpredictable and also \u2013 because of quantum effects \u2013 uncertain."', u'For Sakharov the indeterminacy of the future supported his belief that he could, and should, take personal responsibility for it.', u'=== Nobel Peace Prize (1975) ===\nIn 1973, Sakharov was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize and in 1974 was awarded the Prix mondial Cino Del Duca.', u'Sakharov was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1975.', u'The Norwegian Nobel Committee called him "a spokesman for the conscience of mankind".', u'In the words of the Nobel Committee\'s citation: "In a convincing manner Sakharov has emphasised that Man\'s inviolable rights provide the only safe foundation for genuine and enduring international cooperation."', u'Sakharov was not allowed to leave the Soviet Union to collect the prize.', u'His wife Yelena Bonner read his speech at the ceremony in Oslo, Norway.', u'On the day the prize was awarded, Sakharov was in Vilnius, where human rights activist Sergei Kovalev was being tried.', u'In his Nobel lecture, titled "Peace, Progress, Human Rights", Sakharov called for an end to the arms race, greater respect for the environment, international cooperation, and universal respect for human rights.', u'He included a list of prisoners of conscience and political prisoners in the USSR, stating that he shares the prize with them.', u'By 1976 head of the KGB Yuri Andropov was prepared to call Sakharov "Domestic Enemy Number One" before a group of KGB officers.', u'=== Internal exile (1980\u20131986) ===\n\nSakharov was arrested on January 22, 1980, following his public protests against the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan in 1979, and was sent to internal exile in the city of Gorky, now Nizhny Novgorod, a city that was off limits to foreigners.', u'Between 1980 and 1986, Sakharov was kept under tight Soviet police surveillance.', u'In his memoirs he mentions that their apartment in Gorky was repeatedly subjected to searches and heists.', u'Sakharov was named the 1980 Humanist of the Year by the American Humanist Association.', u"In May 1984, Sakharov's wife, Yelena Bonner, was detained and Sakharov began a hunger strike, demanding permission for his wife to travel to the United States for heart surgery.", u'He was forcibly hospitalized and force-fed.', u'He was held in isolation for four months.', u'In August 1984 Yelena Bonner was sentenced by a court to five years of exile in Gorky.', u'In April 1985, Sakharov started a new hunger strike for his wife to travel abroad for medical treatment.', u'He again was taken to a hospital and force-fed.', u'In August the Politburo discussed what to do about Sakharov.', u'He remained in the hospital until October 1985 when his wife was allowed to travel to the United States.', u'She had heart surgery in the United States and returned to Gorky in June 1986.', u'In December 1985, the European Parliament established the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought, to be given annually for outstanding contributions to human rights.', u'On December 19, 1986, Mikhail Gorbachev, who had initiated the policies of perestroika and glasnost, called Sakharov to tell him that he and his wife could return to Moscow.', u'=== Political leader ===\nIn 1988, Sakharov was given the International Humanist Award by the International Humanist and Ethical Union.', u"He helped to initiate the first independent legal political organizations and became prominent in the Soviet Union's growing political opposition.", u"In March 1989, Sakharov was elected to the new parliament, the All-Union Congress of People's Deputies and co-led the democratic opposition, the Inter-Regional Deputies Group.", u"In November the head of the KGB reported to Mikhail Gorbachev on Sakharov's encouragement and support for the coal-miners' strike in Vorkuta.", u'=== Death ===\n\nSoon after 21:00 on December 14, 1989, Sakharov went to his study to take a nap before preparing an important speech he was to deliver the next day in the Congress.', u'His wife went to wake him at 23:00 as he had requested but she found Sakharov dead on the floor.', u'According to the notes of Yakov Rapoport, a senior pathologist present at the autopsy, it is most likely that Sakharov died of an arrhythmia consequent to dilated cardiomyopathy at the age of 68.', u'He was interred in the Vostryakovskoye Cemetery in Moscow.', u'== Influence ==\n\n\n=== Memorial prizes ===\nThe Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought was established in 1988 by the European Parliament in his honour, and is the highest tribute to human rights endeavours awarded by the European Union.', u'It is awarded annually by the parliament to "those who carry the spirit of Soviet dissident Andrei Sakharov"; to "Laureates who, like Sakharov, dedicate their lives to peaceful struggle for human rights."', u'An Andrei Sakharov prize has also been awarded by the American Physical Society every second year since 2006 "to recognize outstanding leadership and/or achievements of scientists in upholding human rights".', u"The Andrei Sakharov Prize For Writer's Civic Courage was established in October 1990.", u'In 2004, with the approval of Elena Bonner, an annual Sakharov Prize for journalism was established for reporters and commentators in Russia.', u'Funded by former Soviet dissident Pyotr Vins, now a businessman in the USA, the prize is administered by the Glasnost Defence Foundation in Moscow.', u'The prize "for journalism as an act of conscience" has been won over the years by famous journalists such as Anna Politkovskaya and young reporters and editors working far from Russia\'s media capital, Moscow.', u'The 2015 winner was Yelena Kostyuchenko.', u'=== Andrei Sakharov Archives and Human Rights Center ===\nThe Andrei Sakharov Archives and Human Rights Center, established at Brandeis University in 1993, are now housed at Harvard University.', u'The documents from that archive were published by the Yale University Press in 2005.', u'These documents are available online.', u'Most of documents of the archive are letters from the head of the KGB to the Central Committee about activities of Soviet dissidents and recommendations about the interpretation in newspapers.', u'The letters cover the period from 1968 to 1991 (Brezhnev stagnation).', u"The documents characterize not only Sakharov's activity, but that of other dissidents, as well as that of highest-position apparatchiks and the KGB.", u'No Russian equivalent of the KGB archive is available.', u'== Legacy and remembrance ==\n\n\n=== Places ===\nIn Moscow, there is Academician Sakharov Avenue and Sakharov Center\nDuring the 1980s, the block of 16th Street NW between L and M streets, in front of the Russian ambassador\'s residence in Washington, D.C. was renamed "Andrei Sakharov Plaza" as a form of protest against his 1980 arrest and detention.', u'In Yerevan, the capital of Armenia, Sakharov Square, located in the heart of the city, is named after him.', u'The Sakharov Gardens (est.', u'1990) are located at the entrance to Jerusalem, Israel, off the Jerusalem\u2013Tel Aviv Highway.', u'There is also a street named after him in Haifa.', u'In Nizhny Novgorod, there is a Sakharov Museum in the apartment on the first floor of the 12-storeyed house where the Sakharov family lived for seven years; in 2014 his monument was erected near the house.', u'In St. Petersburg, his monument stands in Sakharov Square, and there is a Sakharov Park.', u'In 1979, an asteroid \u2013 1979 Sakharov \u2013 was named after him.', u'A public square in Vilnius in front of the Press House is named after Sakharov.', u'The square was named on March 16, 1991, as the Press House was still occupied by the Soviet Army.', u'Andreja Saharova iela in the district of P\u013cavnieki in R\u012bga, Latvia is named after Sakharov.', u'Andreij-Sacharow-Platz in downtown Nuremberg is named in honor of Sakharov.', u'In Belarus International Sakharov Environmental University was named after him.', u'Intersection of Ventura Blvd and Laurel Canyon Blvd in Studio City, Los Angeles is named Andrei Sakharov Square.', u'In Arnhem, the bridge over the Nederrijn is called the Andrej Sacharovbrug.', u'The Andrej Sacharovweg is a street in Assen, Netherlands.', u'There are also streets named in his honor in Amsterdam, Amstelveen, The Hague, Hellevoetsluis, Leiden, Purmerend, Rotterdam and Utrecht.', u'Quai Andre\xef Sakharov in Tournai, Belgium is named in honor of Sakharov.', u'In Poland- streets named in his honor in Warsaw and Krak\xf3w.', u'Andre\xef Sakharov Boulevard in the district of Mladost in Sofia, Bulgaria is named after him.', u'In New York, a street sign at the southwest corner of Third Avenue and 67th Street reads Sakharov-Bonner Corner, in honor of Sakharov and his wife, Yelena Bonner.', u'The corner is just down the block from the Russian (then Soviet) Mission to the United Nations and was the scene of repeated anti-Soviet demonstrations.', u'=== Media ===\nIn the 1984 made-for-TV film Sakharov starring Jason Robards.', u"In the television series Star Trek: The Next Generation, one of the Enterprise-D's Shuttlecraft is named after Sakharov, and is featured prominently in several episodes.", u'This follows the Star Trek tradition of naming Shuttlecraft after prominent scientists, and particularly in The Next Generation, physicists.', u'The fictitious interplanetary spacecraft Cosmonaut Alexei Leonov from the novel 2010: Odyssey Two by Arthur C. Clarke is powered by a "Sakharov drive".', u'The novel was published in 1982, when Sakharov was in exile in Nizhny Novgorod, and was dedicated both to Sakharov and to Alexey Leonov.', u'Italian painter Vinzela has dedicated his artwork "Saharov" to the great personality of human right activist.', u'In the PC games, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.', u': Shadow of Chernobyl and S.T.A.L.K.E.R.', u': Clear Sky, there is a scientist called Sakharov.', u'Russian singer Alexander Gradsky wrote and performed the song "\u041f\u0430\u043c\u044f\u0442\u0438 \u0410. \u0414. \u0421\u0430\u0445\u0430\u0440\u043e\u0432\u0430" ("In memory of Andrei Sakharov"), which features on his Live In "Russia" 2 (\u0416\u0438\u0432\u0435\u043c \u0432 "\u0420\u043e\u0441\u0441\u0438\u0438" 2) CD.', u'in the TV series Seinfeld, a Russian cable TV installer who had been imprisoned in the Gulag is described as "the Sakharov of cable guys".', u'== Quotations ==\n\n\n== Honours and awards ==\nHero of Socialist Labour (three times: August 12, 1953; June 20, 1956; March 7, 1962).', u'Four Orders of Lenin.', u'Lenin Prize (1956).', u'Stalin Prize (1953).', u'In 1980, Sakharov was stripped of all Soviet awards for "anti-Soviet activities".', u'Later, during glasnost, he declined the return of his awards and, consequently, Mikhail Gorbachev did not sign the necessary decree.', u'Prix mondial Cino Del Duca (1974).', u'Nobel Peace Prize (1975).', u'Laurea Honoris Causa of the Sapienza University of Rome (1980).', u'Grand Cross of Order of the Cross of Vytis (posthumously on January 8, 2003).', u'== See also ==\nYelena Bonner, his wife\nSakharov conditions\nSakharov Prize\nSergei Kovalev\nNatan Sharansky\nEdward Teller\nStanislaw Ulam\nOmid Kokabee, Mordechai Vanunu\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== Bibliography ==\n\n\n=== Books ===\nSakharov, Andrei (1974).', u'Sakharov speaks.', u'Collins: Harvill Press.', u'ISBN 0-00-262755-8.', u'Sakharov, Andrei (1975).', u'My country and the world.', u'Knopf.', u'ISBN 0-394-40226-X.', u'Sakharov, Andrei (1978).', u'Alarm and hope.', u'The world-renowned Nobel laureate and political dissident speaks out on human rights, disarmament, and d\xe9tente.', u'Knopf.', u'ISBN 0-394-50369-4.', u'Sakharov, Andrei (1982).', u'Collected scientific works.', u'Marcel Dekker Inc. ScienceTemplate:Deadlinl \u0413\u041e\u0421\u0422\u0418\u041d\u041d\u0410\u042f: \u0444\u043e\u0440\u0443\u043c:\u0410\u041b\u0415\u041a\u0410\u0421\u041d\u0414\u0420 \u0410\u041b\u0415\u041a\u0421\u0410\u041d\u0414\u0420\u041e\u0412"\u0421\u0431\u043e\u0440\u043d\u0438\u043a \u0440\u0430\u0441\u0441\u043a\u0430\u0437\u043e\u0432":Gaina Alex: \u0420\u0435\u043f\u0440\u0435\u0441\u0441\u0438\u0440\u043e\u0432\u0430\u043d\u043d\u0430\u044f \u043d\u0430\u0443\u043a\u0430 (Purged Science)'], 'year': '1975-10-09', 'title': 'Andrei Sakharov wins Nobel Peace Prize'}
{'sentences': [u'A society is a group of people involved in persistent social interaction, or a large social grouping sharing the same geographical or social territory, typically subject to the same political authority and dominant cultural expectations.', u'Societies are characterized by patterns of relationships (social relations) between individuals who share a distinctive culture and institutions; a given society may be described as the sum total of such relationships among its constituent members.', u'In the social sciences, a larger society often evinces stratification or dominance patterns in subgroups.', u'Insofar as it is collaborative, a society can enable its members to benefit in ways that would not otherwise be possible on an individual basis; both individual and social (common) benefits can thus be distinguished, or in many cases found to overlap.', u'A society can also consist of like-minded people governed by their own norms and values within a dominant, larger society.', u'This is sometimes referred to as a subculture, a term used extensively within criminology.', u'More broadly, and especially within structuralist thought, a society may be illustrated as an economic, social, industrial or cultural infrastructure, made up of, yet distinct from, a varied collection of individuals.', u'In this regard society can mean the objective relationships people have with the material world and with other people, rather than "other people" beyond the individual and their familiar social environment.', u'== Etymology and usage ==\n\nThe term "society" came from the Latin word societas, which in turn was derived from the noun socius ("comrade, friend, ally"; adjectival form socialis) used to describe a bond or interaction between parties that are friendly, or at least civil.', u'Without an article, the term can refer to the entirety of humanity (also: "society in general", "society at large", etc.', u'), although those who are unfriendly or uncivil to the remainder of society in this sense may be deemed to be "antisocial".', u'However, the Scottish economist, Adam Smith taught instead that a society "may subsist among different men, as among different merchants, from a sense of its utility without any mutual love or affection, if only they refrain from doing injury to each other."', u'Used in the sense of an association, a society is a body of individuals outlined by the bounds of functional interdependence, possibly comprising characteristics such as national or cultural identity, social solidarity, language, or hierarchical structure.', u'== Conceptions ==\nSociety, in general, addresses the fact that an individual has rather limited means as an autonomous unit.', u'The great apes have always been more (Bonobo, Homo, Pan) or less (Gorilla, Pongo) social animals, so Robinson Crusoe-like situations are either fictions or unusual corner cases to the ubiquity of social context for humans, who fall between presocial and eusocial in the spectrum of animal ethology.', u'Societies are most often organized according to their primary means of subsistence.', u'Social scientists have identified hunter-gatherer societies, nomadic pastoral societies, horticulturalist or simple farming societies, and intensive agricultural societies, also called civilizations.', u'Some consider industrial and post-industrial societies to be qualitatively different from traditional agricultural societies.', u'Today, anthropologists and many social scientists vigorously oppose the notion of cultural evolution and rigid "stages" such as these.', u'In fact, much anthropological data has suggested that complexity (civilization, population growth and density, specialization, etc.)', u'does not always take the form of hierarchical social organization or stratification.', u'Cultural relativism as a widespread approach or ethic has largely replaced notions of "primitive", better/worse, or "progress" in relation to cultures (including their material culture/technology and social organization).', u"According to anthropologist Maurice Godelier, one critical novelty in society, in contrast to humanity's closest biological relatives (chimpanzees and bonobos), is the parental role assumed by the males, which supposedly would be absent in our nearest relatives for whom paternity is not generally determinable.", u'=== In political science ===\nSocieties may also be structured politically.', u'In order of increasing size and complexity, there are bands, tribes, chiefdoms, and state societies.', u'These structures may have varying degrees of political power, depending on the cultural, geographical, and historical environments that these societies must contend with.', u'Thus, a more isolated society with the same level of technology and culture as other societies is more likely to survive than one in closer proximity to others that may encroach on their resources.', u'A society that is unable to offer an effective response to other societies it competes with will usually be subsumed into the culture of the competing society.', u'=== In sociology ===\n\nSociologist Peter L. Berger defines society as "...a human product, and nothing but a human product, that yet continuously acts upon its producers."', u'According to him, society was created by humans but this creation turns back and creates or molds humans every day.', u'Sociologist Gerhard Lenski differentiates societies based on their level of technology, communication, and economy: (1) hunters and gatherers, (2) simple agricultural, (3) advanced agricultural, (4) industrial, and (5) special (e.g.', u'fishing societies or maritime societies).', u'This is similar to the system earlier developed by anthropologists Morton H. Fried, a conflict theorist, and Elman Service, an integration theorist, who have produced a system of classification for societies in all human cultures based on the evolution of social inequality and the role of the state.', u'This system of classification contains four categories:\nHunter-gatherer bands (categorization of duties and responsibilities).', u'Tribal societies in which there are some limited instances of social rank and prestige.', u'Stratified structures led by chieftains.', u'Civilizations, with complex social hierarchies and organized, institutional governments.', u"In addition to this there are:\nHumanity, mankind, upon which rest all the elements of society, including society's beliefs.", u'Virtual society, a society based on online identity, which is evolving in the information age.', u'Over time, some cultures have progressed toward more complex forms of organization and control.', u'This cultural evolution has a profound effect on patterns of community.', u'Hunter-gatherer tribes settled around seasonal food stocks to become agrarian villages.', u'Villages grew to become towns and cities.', u'Cities turned into city-states and nation-states.', u'Many societies distribute largess at the behest of some individual or some larger group of people.', u'This type of generosity can be seen in all known cultures; typically, prestige accrues to the generous individual or group.', u'Conversely, members of a society may also shun or scapegoat members of the society who violate its norms.', u'Mechanisms such as gift-giving, joking relationships and scapegoating, which may be seen in various types of human groupings, tend to be institutionalized within a society.', u'Social evolution as a phenomenon carries with it certain elements that could be detrimental to the population it serves.', u'Some societies bestow status on an individual or group of people when that individual or group performs an admired or desired action.', u'This type of recognition is bestowed in the form of a name, title, manner of dress, or monetary reward.', u'In many societies, adult male or female status is subject to a ritual or process of this type.', u'Altruistic action in the interests of the larger group is seen in virtually all societies.', u'The phenomena of community action, shunning, scapegoating, generosity, shared risk, and reward are common to many forms of society.', u'== Types ==\nSocieties are social groups that differ according to subsistence strategies, the ways that humans use technology to provide needs for themselves.', u'Although humans have established many types of societies throughout history, anthropologists tend to classify different societies according to the degree to which different groups within a society have unequal access to advantages such as resources, prestige, or power.', u'Virtually all societies have developed some degree of inequality among their people through the process of social stratification, the division of members of a society into levels with unequal wealth, prestige, or power.', u'Sociologists place societies in three broad categories: pre-industrial, industrial, and postindustrial.', u'=== Pre-industrial ===\n\nIn a pre-industrial society, food production, which is carried out through the use of human and animal labor, is the main economic activity.', u'These societies can be subdivided according to their level of technology and their method of producing food.', u'These subdivisions are hunting and gathering, pastoral, horticultural, agricultural, and feudal.', u'==== Hunting and gathering ====\n\nThe main form of food production in such societies is the daily collection of wild plants and the hunting of wild animals.', u'Hunter-gatherers move around constantly in search of food.', u'As a result, they do not build permanent villages or create a wide variety of artifacts, and usually only form small groups such as bands and tribes.', u'However, some hunting and gathering societies in areas with abundant resources (such as people of tlingit) lived in larger groups and formed complex hierarchical social structures such as chiefdom.', u'The need for mobility also limits the size of these societies.', u'They generally consist of fewer than 60 people and rarely exceed 100.', u'Statuses within the tribe are relatively equal, and decisions are reached through general agreement.', u'The ties that bind the tribe are more complex than those of the bands.', u'Leadership is personal\u2014charismatic\u2014and used for special purposes only in tribal society.', u'There are no political offices containing real power, and a chief is merely a person of influence, a sort of adviser; therefore, tribal consolidations for collective action are not governmental.', u'The family forms the main social unit, with most societal members being related by birth or marriage.', u'This type of organization requires the family to carry out most social functions, including production and education.', u'==== Pastoral ====\n\nPastoralism is a slightly more efficient form of subsistence.', u'Rather than searching for food on a daily basis, members of a pastoral society rely on domesticated herd animals to meet their food needs.', u'Pastoralists live a nomadic life, moving their herds from one pasture to another.', u'Because their food supply is far more reliable, pastoral societies can support larger populations.', u'Since there are food surpluses, fewer people are needed to produce food.', u'As a result, the division of labor (the specialization by individuals or groups in the performance of specific economic activities) becomes more complex.', u'For example, some people become craftworkers, producing tools, weapons, and jewelry.', u'The production of goods encourages trade.', u'This trade helps to create inequality, as some families acquire more goods than others do.', u'These families often gain power through their increased wealth.', u'The passing on of property from one generation to another helps to centralize wealth and power.', u'Over time emerge hereditary chieftainships, the typical form of government in pastoral societies.', u'==== Horticultural ====\n\nFruits and vegetables grown in garden plots that have been cleared from the jungle or forest provide the main source of food in a horticultural society.', u'These societies have a level of technology and complexity similar to pastoral societies.', u'Some horticultural groups use the slash-and-burn method to raise crops.', u'The wild vegetation is cut and burned, and ashes are used as fertilizers.', u'Horticulturists use human labor and simple tools to cultivate the land for one or more seasons.', u'When the land becomes barren, horticulturists clear a new plot and leave the old plot to revert to its natural state.', u'They may return to the original land several years later and begin the process again.', u'By rotating their garden plots, horticulturists can stay in one area for a fairly long period of time.', u'This allows them to build semipermanent or permanent villages.', u"The size of a village's population depends on the amount of land available for farming; thus villages can range from as few as 30 people to as many as 2000.", u'As with pastoral societies, surplus food leads to a more complex division of labor.', u'Specialized roles in horticultural societies include craftspeople, shamans (religious leaders), and traders.', u'This role specialization allows people to create a wide variety of artifacts.', u'As in pastoral societies, surplus food can lead to inequalities in wealth and power within horticultural political systems, developed because of the settled nature of horticultural life.', u'==== Agrarian ====\n\nAgrarian societies use agricultural technological advances to cultivate crops over a large area.', u'Sociologists use the phrase agricultural revolution to refer to the technological changes that occurred as long as 8,500 years ago that led to cultivating crops and raising farm animals.', u'Increases in food supplies then led to larger populations than in earlier communities.', u'This meant a greater surplus, which resulted in towns that became centers of trade supporting various rulers, educators, craftspeople, merchants, and religious leaders who did not have to worry about locating nourishment.', u'Greater degrees of social stratification appeared in agrarian societies.', u'For example, women previously had higher social status because they shared labor more equally with men.', u'In hunting and gathering societies, women even gathered more food than men.', u'However, as food stores improved and women took on lesser roles in providing food for the family, they increasingly became subordinate to men.', u'As villages and towns expanded into neighboring areas, conflicts with other communities inevitably occurred.', u'Farmers provided warriors with food in exchange for protection against invasion by enemies.', u'A system of rulers with high social status also appeared.', u'This nobility organized warriors to protect the society from invasion.', u'In this way, the nobility managed to extract goods from \u201clesser\u201d members of society.', u'==== Feudal ====\n\nFeudalism was a form of society based on ownership of land.', u"Unlike today's farmers, vassals under feudalism were bound to cultivating their lord's land.", u'In exchange for military protection, the lords exploited the peasants into providing food, crops, crafts, homage, and other services to the landowner.', u"The estates of the realm system of feudalism was often multigenerational; the families of peasants may have cultivated their lord's land for generations.", u'=== Industrial ===\n\nBetween the 15th and 16th centuries, a new economic system emerged that began to replace feudalism.', u'Capitalism is marked by open competition in a free market, in which the means of production are privately owned.', u"Europe's exploration of the Americas served as one impetus for the development of capitalism.", u'The introduction of foreign metals, silks, and spices stimulated great commercial activity in European societies.', u'Industrial societies rely heavily on machines powered by fuels for the production of goods.', u'This produced further dramatic increases in efficiency.', u'The increased efficiency of production of the industrial revolution produced an even greater surplus than before.', u'Now the surplus was not just agricultural goods, but also manufactured goods.', u'This larger surplus caused all of the changes discussed earlier in the domestication revolution to become even more pronounced.', u'Once again, the population boomed.', u'Increased productivity made more goods available to everyone.', u'However, inequality became even greater than before.', u'The breakup of agricultural-based feudal societies caused many people to leave the land and seek employment in cities.', u'This created a great surplus of labor and gave capitalists plenty of laborers who could be hired for extremely low wages.', u'=== Post-industrial ===\n\nPost-industrial societies are societies dominated by information, services, and high technology more than the production of goods.', u'Advanced industrial societies are now seeing a shift toward an increase in service sectors over manufacturing and production.', u'The United States is the first country to have over half of its work force employed in service industries.', u'Service industries include government, research, education, health, sales, law, and banking.', u'== Contemporary usage ==\nThe term "society" is currently used to cover both a number of political and scientific connotations as well as a variety of associations.', u'=== Western ===\n\nThe development of the Western world has brought with it the emerging concepts of Western culture, politics, and ideas, often referred to simply as "Western society".', u'Geographically, it covers at the very least the countries of Western Europe, North America, Australia, and New Zealand.', u'It sometimes also includes Eastern Europe, South America, and Israel.', u'The cultures and lifestyles of all of these stem from Western Europe.', u'They all enjoy relatively strong economies and stable governments, allow freedom of religion, have chosen democracy as a form of governance, favor capitalism and international trade, are heavily influenced by Judeo-Christian values, and have some form of political and military alliance or cooperation.', u'=== Information ===\n\nAlthough the concept of information society has been under discussion since the 1930s, in the modern world it is almost always applied to the manner in which information technologies have impacted society and culture.', u'It therefore covers the effects of computers and telecommunications on the home, the workplace, schools, government, and various communities and organizations, as well as the emergence of new social forms in cyberspace.', u"One of the European Union's areas of interest is the information extended from the information society to the knowledge society.', u'An analysis by the Irish government stated, "The capacity to manipulate, store and transmit large quantities of information cheaply has increased at a staggering rate over recent years.', u'The digitisation of information and the associated pervasiveness of the Internet are facilitating a new intensity in the application of knowledge to economic activity, to the extent that it has become the predominant factor in the creation of wealth.', u'As much as 70 to 80 percent of economic growth is now said to be due to new and better knowledge."', u'The Second World Summit on the Knowledge Society, held in Chania, Crete, in September 2009, gave special attention to the following topics:\nbusiness and enterprise also said to form a society (such as Judeo-Christian, Eastern, and Western).', u'When used in this context, the term is employed as a means of contrasting two or more "societies" whose members the first cities.', u'Some theorists have speculated on what they consider suitable pre-conditions and basic mechanisms that might have been important driving forces.', u'The conventional view holds that cities first formed after the Neolithic revolution.', u'The Neolithic revolution brought agriculture, which made denser human populations possible, thereby supporting city development.', u'The advent of farming encouraged hunter-gatherers to abandon nomadic lifestyles and to settle near others who lived by agricultural production.', u'The increased population density encouraged by farming and the increased output of food per unit of land created conditions that seem more suitable for city-like activities.', u'In his book, Cities and Economic Development, Paul Bairoch takes up this position in his argument that agricultural activity appears necessary before true cities can form.', u'According to Vere Gordon Childe, for a settlement to qualify as a city, it must have enough surplus of raw materials to support trade and a relatively large population.', u'Bairoch points out that, due to sparse population densities that would have persisted in pre-Neolithic, hunter-gatherer societies, the amount of land that would be required to produce enough food for subsistence and trade for a large population would make it impossible to control the flow of trade.', u'To illustrate this point, Bairoch offers an example: "Western Europe during the pre-Neolithic, [where] the density must have been less than 0.1 person per square kilometre".', u'Using this population density as a base for calculation, and allotting 10% of food towards surplus for trade and assuming that city dwellers do no farming, he calculates that "...to maintain a city with a population of 1,000, and without taking the cost of transport into account, an area of 100,000 square kilometres would have been required.', u'When the cost of transport is taken into account, the figure rises to 200,000 square kilometres ...".', u'Bairoch noted that this is roughly the size of Great Britain.', u'The urban theorist Jane Jacobs suggests that city formation preceded the birth of agriculture, but this view is not widely accepted.', u'In his book City Economics, Brendan O\'Flaherty asserts "Cities could persist\u2014as they have for thousands of years\u2014only if their advantages offset the disadvantages" (O\'Flaherty 2005, p. 12).', u"O'Flaherty illustrates two similar attracting advantages known as increasing returns to scale and economies of scale, which are concepts usually associated with businesses.", u'Their applications are seen in more basic economic systems as well.', u'Increasing returns to scale occurs when "doubling all inputs more than doubles the output [and] an activity has economies of scale if doubling output less than doubles cost" (O\'Flaherty 2005, pp.', u'572\u2013573).', u'To offer an example of these concepts, O\'Flaherty makes use of "one of the oldest reasons why cities were built: military protection" (O\'Flaherty 2005, p. 13).', u'In this example, the inputs are anything that would be used for protection (e.g., a wall) and the output is the area protected and everything of value contained in it.', u"O'Flaherty then asks that we suppose the protected area is square, and each hectare inside it has the same value of protection.", u"The advantage is expressed as: (O'Flaherty 2005, p. 13)\n(1) \n  \n    \n      \n        O\n        =\n        \n          s\n          \n            2\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle O=s^{2}}\n  , where O is the output (area protected) and s stands for the length of a side.", u'This equation shows that output is proportional to the square of the length of a side.', u'The inputs depend on the length of the perimeter:\n(2) \n  \n    \n      \n        I\n        =\n        4\n        s\n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle I=4s}\n  , where I stands for the quantity of inputs.', u'So there are increasing returns to scale:\n(3) \n  \n    \n      \n        O\n        =\n        \n          I\n          \n            2\n          \n        \n        \n          /\n        \n        16\n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle O=I^{2}/16}\n  .', u'This equation (solving for \n  \n    \n      \n        s\n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle s}\n   in (1) and substituting in (2)) shows that with twice the inputs, you produce quadruple the output.', u'Also, economies of scale:\n(4) \n  \n    \n      \n        I\n        =\n        4\n        \n          O\n          \n            1\n            \n              /\n            \n            2\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle I=4O^{1/2}}\n  .', u'This equation (solving for \n  \n    \n      \n        I\n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle I}\n   in equation (3)) shows that the same output requires less input.', u'"Cities, then, economize on protection, and so protection against marauding barbarian u'Benefits include reduced transport costs, exchange of ideas, sharing of natural resources, large local markets, and later in their development, amenities such as running water and sewage disposal.', roster of early urban traditions is notable for its diversity.', u'Excavations at early urban sites show that some cities were sparsely populated political capitals, others were trade centers, and creating their own microclimates.', u'This is due to the large clustering of heat absorbent surfaces that heat up in sunlight and that channel rainwater into underground ducts.', u'Waste and sewage are two major problems for cities, as is air pollution from various forms of combustion, including fireplaces, wood or coal-burning stoves, other heating systems, and internal combustion engines.', u'The impact of cities on places elsewhere, be it hinterlands or places far away, is considered in the notion of city footprinting (ecological footprint).', u'Other negative external effects include health consequences such as communicable diseases, crime, and high traffic and commuting times.', u'Cities cause more interaction with more people than rural areas, leading to a higher probability of contracting contagious diseases.', u'However, many inventions such as inoculations, vaccines, and water filtration systems have also lowered health concerns.', u'Crime is also a concern in the cities.', u'Studies have shown that crime rates in cities are higher and the chance of punishment after getting caught is lower.', u'In cases such as burglary, the higher concentration of people in cities create more items of higher value worth the risk of crime.', u'The high concentration of people also makes using auto mobiles inconvenient and pedestrian traffic is more prominent in metropolitan areas than a rural or suburban one.', u'Cities also generate positive external effects.', u'The close physical proximity facilitates knowledge spillovers, helping people and firms exchange information and generate new ideas.', u'A thicker labor market allows for better skill matching between firms and individuals.', u'Population density enables also sharing of common infrastructure and production facilities, however in very dense cities, increased crowding and waiting times may lead to some negative effects.', u'Cities may have a positive influence on the environment.', u'UN-HABITAT stated in its reports that city living can be the best solution for dealing with the rising population numbers (and thus still be a good approach on dealing with diocesan cathedral; in more recent times towns apply to receive city status at times of national celebration.', u'Larger settlements which are not designated as cities are towns, smaller settlements ==\n\nA global city, also known as a world city, is a prominent centre of trade, banking, finance, innovation, and markets.', u'The term "global city", as opposed to megacity, was coined by Saskia Sassen in a seminal 1991 work.', u'Whereas "megacity" refers to any city of enormous size, a global city is one of enormous power or influence.', u'Global cities, according to Sassen, have more in common with each other than with other cities in their host nations.', u'The notion of global cities is rooted in the concentration of power and capabilities within all cities.', u'The city is seen as a container where skills and resources are concentrated: the better able a city is to concentrate its skills and resources, the more successful and powerful the city.', u'This makes the city itself more powerful in the sense that it can influence what is happening around the world.', u"Following this view of cities, it is possible to rank the world's cities hierarchically.", u'Critics of the notion point to the different realms of power and interchange.', u'The term "global city" is heavily influenced by economic factors and, thus, may not account for places that are otherwise significant.', u"One writer, for example argues that the term is 'reductive and skewed':\n\nAgainst those writers who, by emphasizing the importance of financial exchange systems, distinguish a few colonial times.', u'The American City Beautiful architecture movement of the late 19th century was a reaction to perceived urban decay and sought to provide stately civic buildings and boulevards to inspire civic pride in the motley residents of the urban core.', u'Modern anti-urban attitudes are found in the United States in the form of a planning profession that continues to develop land on a low-density suburban basis, where access to amenities, work and shopping is provided almost exclusively by car rather than by foot or transit.', u'There is a growing movement in North America called "New Urbanism" that calls for a return to traditional city planning methods where mixed-use zoning allows people to walk from one type of land-use to another.', u'The idea is that housing, shopping, office space, and leisure facilities are all provided within walking distance of each other, thus reducing the demand for road-space and also improving the efficiency and effectiveness of mass knowledge economy.', u'Knowledge-based development of cities, globalization of innovation networks, and broadband services are driving forces of a new city planning paradigm towards smart cities that use technology and communication to create more efficient agglomerations in terms of competitiveness, innovation, environment, energy, utilities, governance, and delivery of services to the citizen.', {'sentences': [u'A flag is a piece of fabric (most often rectangular or quadrilateral) with a distinctive design that is used as a symbol, as a signaling device, or as decoration.', u'The term flag is also used to refer to the graphic design employed, and flags have since evolved into a general tool for rudimentary signalling and identification, especially in environments where communication is similarly challenging (such as the maritime environment where semaphore is used).', u'National flags are potent patriotic symbols with varied wide-ranging interpretations, often including strong military associations due to their original and ongoing military uses.', u'Flags are also used in messaging, advertising, or for other decorative purposes.', u'The study of flags is known as vexillology, from the Latin word vexillum, meaning flag or banner.', u"Due to the use of flags by military units, 'flag' is also used as the name of some military units.", u'A flag (Arabic: \u0644\u0648\u0627\u0621) is equivalent to a brigade in Arab countries, and in Spain, a flag (Spanish: bandera) is a battalion-equivalent in the Spanish Legion.', u"== History ==\n\nIn antiquity, field signs or standards were used in warfare that can be categorized as vexilloid or 'flag-like'.", u"Examples include the Sassanid battle standard Derafsh Kaviani, and the standards of the Roman legions such as the eagle of Augustus Caesar's Xth legion, or the dragon standard of the Sarmatians; the latter was let fly freely in the wind, carried by a horseman, but judging from depictions it was more similar to an elongated dragon kite than to a simple flag.", u'During the High Middle Ages flags came to be used primarily as a heraldic device in battle, allowing more easily to identify a knight than only from the heraldic device painted on the shield.', u'Already during the high medieval period, and increasingly during the Late Middle Ages, city states and communes such as those of the Old Swiss Confederacy also began to use flags as field signs.', u'Regimental flags for individual units became commonplace during the Early Modern period.', u'During the peak of the age of sail, beginning in the early 17th century, it was customary (and later a legal requirement) for ships to carry flags designating their nationality; these flags eventually evolved into the national flags and maritime flags of today.', u'Flags also became the preferred means of communications at sea, resulting in various systems of flag signals; see, International maritime signal flags.', u'Use of flags outside of military or naval context begins only with the rise of nationalist sentiment by the end of the 18th century; the earliest national flags date to that period, and during the 19th century it became common for every sovereign state to introduce a national flag.', u'== National flags ==\n\nOne of the most popular uses of a flag is to symbolize a nation or country.', u'Some national flags have been particularly inspirational to other nations, countries, or subnational entities in the design of their own flags.', u'Some prominent examples include:\nThe flag of Denmark, the Dannebrog, is designs are often used to signify nationality in other forms, such as flag patches.', u'=== Civil flags ===\n\nA civil flag is a version of the national flag that is flown by civilians on non-government installations or craft.', u'The use of civil flags was more common in the past, in order to denote buildings or ships that were not manned by the military.', u"In some countries the civil flag is the same as the war flag or state flag, but without the coat of arms, such as in the case of Spain, and in others it's an alteration of the war flag.", u'=== War flags ===\n\nSeveral countries (including the United Kingdom and the Soviet Union) have had unique flags flown by their armed forces, rather than the national flag.', u"Other countries' armed forces (such as those of the United States or Switzerland) use their standard national flag.", u"The Philippines' armed forces may use their standard national flag, but during times of war the flag is turned upside down.", u"Bulgaria's flag is also turned upside down during times of war.", u"These are also considered war flags, though the terminology only applies to the flag's military usage.", u"Large versions of the war flag flown on the warships of countries' navies are known as battle ensigns.", u'In war waving a white flag is a banner of truce or surrender.', u'Four distinctive African flags currently in the known as the Benin flag and one is referred to as Nana Olomu's flag.", u'=== International flags ===\nAmong international flags are the Flag of the United Nations, the Olympic flag, and the Paralympic flag.', u'== At sea ==\n\nFlags are particularly important at sea, where they can mean the difference between life and death, and consequently where the rules and regulations for the flying of flags are strictly enforced.', u'A national flag flown at sea is known as an ensign.', u'A courteous, peaceable merchant ship or yacht customarily flies its ensign (in the usual ensign position), together with the flag of whatever nation it is currently visiting at the mast (known as a courtesy flag).', u"To fly one's ensign alone in foreign waters, a foreign port or in the face of a foreign warship traditionally indicates a willingness to fight, with cannon, for the right to do so.", u'As of 2009, this custom is still taken seriously by many naval and port authorities and is readily enforced in many parts of the world by boarding, confiscation and other civil penalties.', u'In some countries yacht ensigns are different from merchant ensigns in order to signal that the yacht is not carrying cargo that requires a customs declaration.', u'Carrying commercial cargo on a boat with a yacht ensign is deemed to be smuggling in many jurisdictions.', u'There is a system of international maritime signal flags for numerals and letters of the alphabet.', u'Each flag or pennant has a specific meaning when flown individually.', u'As well, semaphore flags can be used to communicate on an ad hoc basis from ship to ship over short distances.', u"Traditionally, a vessel flying under the courtesy flag of a specific nation, regardless of the vessel's country of registry, is considered to be operating under the law of her 'host' nation.", u'Another category of maritime flag flown by some United States Government ships is the distinguishing mark.', u'Although the United States Coast Guard has its own service ensign, all other U.S. Government ships fly the national ensign their service ensign, following United States Navy practice.', u"To distinguish themselves from ships of the Navy, such ships historically have flown their parent organisation's flag from a forward mast as a distinguishing mark.", u'Today, for example, commissioned ships of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) fly the NOAA flag as a distinguishing mark.', u'== Shapes and designs ==\n\nFlags are usually rectangular in shape (often in the ratio 2:3, 1:2, or 3:5), but may be of any shape or size that is practical for flying, including square, triangular, or swallow tailed.', u'A more unusual flag shape is that of the flag of Nepal, which is in the shape of two stacked triangles.', u'Other unusual flag shapes include the flag of Ohio and the flag of Tampa.', u"Many flags are dyed through and through to be inexpensive to manufacture, such that the reverse side is the mirror image of the obverse (front) side, generally the side displayed when the flag is flying from the observer's point of view from left, the side of the pole, to right.", u'This presents two possibilities:\nIf the design is symmetrical in an axis parallel to the flag pole, obverse and reverse will be identical despite the mirror-reversal, such as the Indian Flag or Canadian Flag\nIf not, the obverse and reverse will present two variants of the same design, one with the hoist on the left (usually considered the obverse side, the other with the hoist on the right (usually considered the reverse side of the flag).', u'This is very common and usually not disturbing if there is no text in the design.', u'Some complex flag designs are not intended for through and through implementation, requiring separate obverse and reverse sides if made correctly.', u"In these cases there is a design element (usually text) which is not symmetric and should be read in the same direction, regardless of whether the hoist is to the viewer's left or right.", u'These cases can be divided into two types:\nThe same (asymmetric) design may be duplicated on both sides.', u"Such flags can be manufactured by creating two identical through and through flags and then sewing them back to back, though this can affect the resulting combination's responsiveness to the wind.", u'Depictions of such flags may be marked with the symbol , indicating the reverse is congruent to (rather than a mirror image of) the obverse.', u'Rarely, the reverse design may differ, in whole or in part, from that of the obverse.', u'Examples of flags whose reverse differs from the obverse include the flag of Paraguay, the flag of Oregon, and the historical flag of the Soviet Union.', u'Depictions of such flags may be marked with the symbol .', u'Common designs on flags include crosses, stripes, and divisions of the surface, or field, into bands or quarters\u2014patterns and principles mainly derived from heraldry.', u'A heraldic coat of arms may also be flown as a banner of arms, as is done on both the state flag of Maryland and the flag of Kiribati.', u'The de jure flag of Libya under Muammar Gaddafi, which consisted of a rectangular field of green, was for a long period the only national flag using a single colour and no design or insignia.', u'However, other historical states have also used flags without designs or insignia, such as the Soviet Republic of Hungary, whose flag was a plain field of red.', u'Colours are normally described with common names, such as "red", but may be further specified using colourimetry.', u'The largest flag flown from a flagpole worldwide, according to Guinness World Records, is the flag of Mexico flown in Piedras Negras, Mexico.', u'This flag was about 2,058 m2 (22,150 sq ft).', u'The largest flag ever made was the flag of Qatar; the flag, which measures at 101,978 m2 (1,097,680 sq ft), was completed in December 2013 in Doha.', u'=== Parts of a flag ===\n\nThe general parts of a flag are: canton\u2014the upper inner section of the flag; field or ground\u2014the entire flag except the canton, and the field and hoist ends; fly end\u2014the furthest edge from the hoist end; and hoist end\u2014the edge used to attach the flag to the hoist.', u'=== Vertical flags ===\nVertical flags are sometimes used in lieu of the standard horizontal flag in central and eastern Europe, particularly in the German-speaking countries.', u'This practice came about because the relatively brisk wind needed to display horizontal flags is not common in these countries.', u'The standard horizontal flag (no.', u'1 in the preceding illustration) is nonetheless the form most often used even in these countries.', u'The vertical flag (German: Hochformatflagge or Knatterflagge; no.', u'2) is a vertical form of the standard flag.', u"The flag's design may remain unchanged (No.", u'2a) or it may change, e.g.', u'by changing horizontal stripes to vertical ones (no.', u'2b).', u'If the flag carries an emblem, it may remain centered or may be shifted slightly upwards.', u'The vertical flag for hoisting from a beam (German: Auslegerflagge or Galgenflagge; no.', u'3) is additionally attached to a horizontal beam, ensuring that it is fully displayed even if there is no wind.', u'The vertical flag for hoisting from a horizontal pole (German: H\xe4ngeflagge; no.', u'4) is hoisted from a horizontal pole, normally attached to a building.', u'The topmost stripe on the horizontal version of the flag faces away from the building.', u'The vertical flag for hoisting from a crossbar or banner (German: Bannerflagge; no.', u'5) is firmly attached to a horizontal crossbar from which it is hoisted, either by a vertical pole (no.', u'5a) or a horizontal one (no.', u'5b).', u'The topmost stripe on the horizontal version of the flag normally faces to the left.', u'== Religious flags ==\n\nFlags can play many different roles in religion.', u'In Buddhism, prayer flags are used, usually in sets of five differently coloured flags.', u'Many national flags and other flags include religious symbols such as the cross, the crescent, or a reference to a patron saint.', u'Flags are also adopted by religious groups and flags such as the Jain flag and the Christian flag are used to represent a whole religion.', u'== Linguistic flags ==\n\nAs languages rarely have a flag designed to represent them, it is a common but unofficial practice to use national flags to identify them.', u'The practice is deprecated because it is often considered insulting and because flags tend to evoke feelings other than the intended meaning.', u'Examples of such use include:\nrepresenting language skills of an individual, like a staff member of a company\ndisplaying available languages on a multilingual website or software.', u'Though this can be done in an uncontroversial manner in some cases, this can easily lead to some problems for certain languages:\nlanguages generating language secessionism, such as Serbo-Croatian which since the breakup of Yugoslavia in 1991, has lost its unitary codification and its official unitary status and is now divided into four official languages: Croatian language, Bosnian language, Serbian language and the Montenegrin language\nlanguages spoken in more than one country, such as English or Arabic.', u'In this second case, common solutions include symbolising these languages by:\nthe flag of the country where the language originated\nthe flag of the country having the largest number of native speakers\na mixed flag of the both (when this is not the same)\nthe flag of the country most identified with that language in a specific region (e.g.', u'Portuguese Language: Flag of Portugal in Europe and Flag of Brazil in South America).', u'A Portugal-Brazil mixed flag, usually divided diagonally, is also a possibility.', u'Thus, on the Internet, it is common to see the English language associated with the flag of the United Kingdom, or sometimes the flag of England, the flag of the United States or a U.S.-UK mixed flag, usually divided diagonally.', u'== In sports ==\nBecause of their ease of signalling and identification, flags are often used in sports.', u'In association football, linesmen carry small flags along the touch lines.', u'They use the flags to indicate to the referee potential infringements of the laws, or who is entitled to possession of the ball that has gone out of the field of play, or, most famously, raising the flag to indicate an offside offence.', u'Officials called touch judges use flags for similar purposes in both codes of rugby.', u'In American and Canadian football, referees use penalty flags to indicate that a foul has been committed in game play.', u'The phrase used for such an indication is flag on the play.', u'The flag itself is a small, weighted handkerchief, tossed on the field at the approximate point of the infraction; the intent is usually to sort out the details after the current play from scrimmage has concluded.', u'In American football, the flag is usually yellow; in Canadian football, it is usually orange.', u'In the National Football League, coaches also use red challenge flags to indicate that they wish to contest a ruling on the field.', u'In yacht racing, flags are used to communicate information from the race committee boat to the racers.', u'Different flags hoisted from the committee boat may communicate a false start, changes in the course, a cancelled race, or other important information.', u'Racing boats themselves may also use flags to symbolize a protest or distress.', u'The flags are often part of the nautical alphabetic system of International maritime signal flags, in which 26 different flags designate the 26 letters of the Latin alphabet.', u'In auto and motorcycle racing, racing flags are used to communicate with drivers.', u'Most famously, a checkered flag of black and white squares indicates the end of the race, and victory for the leader.', u'A yellow flag is used to indicate caution requiring slow speed and a red flag requires racers to stop immediately.', u'A black flag is used to indicate penalties.', u'In addition, fans of almost all sports wave flags in the stands to indicate their support for the participants.', u'Many sports teams have their own flags, and, in individual sports, fans will indicate their support for a player by waving the flag of his or her home country.', u"Capture the flag is a popular children's sport.", u'In Gaelic football and Hurling a green flag is used to indicate a goal while a white flag is used to indicate a point\nIn Australian rules football, the goal umpire will wave two flags to indicate a goal (worth six points) and a single flag to indicate a behind (worth one point).', u'For safety, dive flags indicate the locations of underwater scuba divers or that diving operations are being conducted in the vicinity.', u'In water sports such as Wakeboarding and Water-Skiing, an orange flag is held in between runs to indicate someone is in the water.', u'In golf, the hole is almost always marked with a flag.', u'The flagpole is designed to fit centered within the base of the hole and is removable.', u'Many courses will use colour-coded flags to determine a hole location at the front, middle or rear of the green.', u'However colour-coded flags are not used in the professional tours.', u'(A rare example of a golf course that does not use flags to mark the hole is the East Course of Merion Golf visual enhancement in performances.', u'== Diplomatic flags ==\n\nSome countries use diplomatic flags, such as the United Kingdom(Image of the Embassy flag) and the Kingdom of Thailand(Image of the Embassy flag)\n\n\n== In politics ==\n\nSocial and political movements have adopted flags, to increase their visibility and as a unifying symbol.', u'The socialist movement uses red flags to represent their cause.', u'The anarchist movement has a variety of different flags, but the primary flag associated with them is the black flag.', u'In the Spanish civil war, the anarchists used the red-and-black bisected flag.', u'In the 20th century, the rainbow flag was adopted as a symbol of the LGBT social movements.', u"Bisexual and transgender pride flags were later designed, in an attempt to emulate the rainbow flag's success.", u'Some of these political flags have become national flags, such as the red flag of the Soviet Union and national socialist banners for Nazi Germany.', u'The
