flags ==\nFlags are often representative of an individual's affinity or allegiance to a country, team or business and can be presented in various ways.", u"A popular trend that has surfaced revolves around the idea of the 'mobile' flag in which an individual displays their particular flag of choice on their vehicle.", u'These items are commonly referred to as car flags and are usually manufactured from high strength polyester material and are attached to a vehicle via a polypropylene pole and clip window attachment.', u'== Swimming flags ==\n\nIn Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the Philippines, and the United Kingdom a pair of red/yellow flags is used to mark the limits of the bathing area on a beach, usually guarded by surf lifesavers.', u'If the beach is closed, the poles of the flags are crossed.', u'The flags are coloured with a red triangle and a yellow triangle making a rectangular flag, or a red rectangle over a yellow rectangle.', u'On many Australian beaches there is a slight variation with beach condition signaling.', u'A red flag signifies a closed beach (in the UK also other dangers), yellow signifies strong current or difficult swimming conditions, and green represents a beach safe for general swimming.', u'In Ireland, a red and yellow flag indicates that it is safe to swim; a red flag that it is unsafe; and no flag indicates that there are no lifeguards on duty.', u'Blue flags may also be used away from the yellow-red lifesaver area to designate a zone for surfboarding and other small, non-motorised watercraft.', u'Reasons for closing the beach include:\ndangerous rip\nhurricane warning\nno lifeguards in attendance\noverpolluted water\nsharks\ntsunami\nwaves too strong\nA surf flag exists, divided into four quadrants.', u'The top left and bottom right quadrants are black, and the remaining area is white.', u'Signal flag "India" (a black circle on a yellow square) is frequently used to denote a "blackball" zone where surfboards cannot be used but other water activities are permitted.', u'== Railway flags ==\nRailways use a number of coloured flags.', u'When used as wayside signals they usually use the following meanings (exact meanings are set by the individual railroad company):\nred = stop\nyellow = proceed with care\ngreen or white = proceed.', u'a flag of any colour waved vigorously means stop\na blue flag on the side of a locomotive means that it should not be moved because someone is working on it (or on the train attached to it).', u'A blue flag on a track means that nothing on that track should be moved.', u'The flag can only be removed by the person or group that placed it.', u'In the railway dominated steel industry this principle of "blue flag and tag" was extended to all operations at Bethlehem Steel, Lackawanna, NY.', u'If a man went inside a large machine or worked on an electrical circuit for example, his blue flag and tag was sacrosanct.', u'The "Lock Out/Tag Out" practice is similar and now used in other industries to comply with safety regulations.', u'At night, the flags are replaced with lanterns showing the same colours.', u'Flags displayed on the front of a moving locomotive are an acceptable replacement for classification lights and usually have the following meanings (exact meanings are set by the individual railroad company):\nwhite = extra (not on the timetable)\ngreen = another section following\nred = last section\nAdditionally, a railroad brakeman will typically carry a red flag to make his or her hand signals more visible to the engineer.', u'Railway signals are a development of railway flags.', u'== Flagpoles ==\n\nA flagpole, flagmast, flagstaff, or staff can be a simple support made of wood or metal.', u'If it is taller than can be easily reached to raise the flag, a cord is used, looping around a pulley at the top of the pole with the ends tied at the bottom.', u'The flag is fixed to one lower end of the cord, and is then raised by pulling on the other end.', u'The cord is then tightened and tied to the pole at the bottom.', u'The pole is usually topped by a flat plate or ball called a "truck" (originally meant to keep a wooden pole from splitting) or a finial in a more complex shape.', u'Very high flagpoles may require more complex support structures than a simple pole, such as a guyed mast.', u'Dwajasthambam are flagpoles commonly found at the entrances of South Indian Hindu temples.', u'=== Record heights ===\n\nSince 23 September 2014, the tallest free-standing flagpole in the world is the Jeddah Flagpole in Saudi Arabia with a height of 171 m (561 ft), beating the formerly record holding Dushanbe Flagpole in Tajikistan (height: 165 m, 541 ft), National Flagpole in Azerbaijan (height: 162 m, 531 ft) and the North Korean flagpole at Kij\u014fng-dong (height: 160 m, 520 ft).', u'The tallest flagpole in the United Kingdom from 1959 until 2013 stood in Kew Gardens.', u'It was made from a Canadian Douglas-fir tree and was 68.5 m (225 ft) in height.', u'The current tallest flagpole in the United States (and the tallest containing an American flag) is a 400 ft (120 m) pole completed near Memorial Day 2014 and custom-made with a large 11 feet (3.4 m) base in concrete by wind turbine manufacturer Broadwind Energy, which is situated on the north side of the Acuity Insurance headquarters campus along Interstate 43 in Sheboygan, Wisconsin and is visible from Cedar Grove.', u'The pole will hold a 220-pound flag for pleasant conditions and a thicker 350-pound flag for harsh weather.', u'Acuity had made three separate attempts in the 2000s at the tallest flagpole which were all removed due to collapses or wind-swaying, following the example of a nearby Perkins location which had put up a flag visible on their property from the WI 28 exit.', u'=== Design ===\nFlagpoles can be designed in one piece with a taper (typically a steel taper or a Greek entasis taper), or be made from multiple pieces to make them able to expand.', u'In the United States, ANSI/NAAMM guide specification FP-1001-97 covers the engineering design of metal flagpoles to ensure safety.', u'== Hoisting the flag ==\nHoisting the flag is the act of raising the flag on the flagpole.', u'Raising or lowering flags, especially national flags, usually involves ceremonies and certain sets of rules, depending on the country, and usually involve the performance of a national anthem.', u'A flag-raising squad is a group of people, usually troops, cadets, or students, that marches in and brings the flags for the flag-hoisting ceremony.', u'Flag-hoisting ceremonies involving flag-raising squads can be simple or elaborate, involving large numbers of squads.', u'Elaborate flag-hoisting ceremonies are usually performed on national holidays.', u'== Flags and communication ==\n\nSemaphore is a form of communication that utilizes flags.', u'The signalling is performed by an individual using two flags (or lighted wands), the positions of the flags indicating a symbol.', u'The person who holds the flags is known as the signalman.', u'This form of communication is primarily used by naval signallers.', u'This technique of signalling was adopted in the early 19th century and is still used in various forms today.', u'The colours of the flags can also be used to communicate.', u'For example; a white flag means, among other things, surrender or peace, a red flag can be used as a warning signal, and a black flag can mean war, or determination to defeat enemies.', u'Orientation of a flag is also used for communication, though the practice is rarely used given modern communication systems.', u'Raising a flag upside-down was indicative that the raising force controlled that particular area, but that it was in severe distress.', u'== Flapping ==\n\nWhen blown by the wind, flags are subject to wave-like motions that grow in amplitude along the length of the flag.', u'This is sometimes ascribed to the flag pole giving vortex shedding, however flags that are held by lanyards also can be seen to flap.', u'== See also ==\nLists and galleries of flags\nGallery of sovereign state flags\nList of flag {'sentences': [u'A battle is a combat in warfare between two or more armed forces, or combatants.', u'A war sometimes consists of many battles.', u'Battles generally are well defined in duration, area, and force commitment.', u'Wars and military campaigns are guided by strategy, whereas battles take place on a level of planning and execution known as operational mobility.', u'German strategist Carl von Clausewitz stated that "the employment of battles ... to achieve the object of war" was the essence of strategy.', u'== Etymology ==\nBattle is a loanword from the Old French bataille, first attested in 1297, from Late Latin battualia, meaning "exercise of soldiers and gladiators in fighting and fencing", from Late Latin (taken from Germanic) battuere "beat", from which the English word battery is also derived via Middle English batri.', u'== Characteristics ==\nThe defining characteristic of the fight as a concept in Military science has been a dynamic one through the course of military history, changing with the changes in the organisation, employment and technology of military forces.', u'While the English military historian Sir John Keegan suggested an ideal definition of battle as "something which happens between two armies leading to the moral then physical disintegration of one or the other of them", the origins and outcomes of battles can rarely be summarized so neatly.', u'In general a battle during the 20th century was, and continues to be, defined by the combat between opposing forces representing major components of total forces committed to a military campaign, used to achieve specific military objectives.', u'Where the duration of the battle is longer than a week, it is often for reasons of staff operational planning called an operation.', u'Battles can be planned, encountered, or forced by one force on the other when the latter is unable to withdraw from combat.', u'A battle always has as its purpose the reaching of a mission goal by use of military force.', u'A victory in the battle is achieved when one of the opposing sides forces the other to abandon its mission, or to surrender its forces, or routs the other, i.e., forces it to retreat or renders it militarily ineffective for further combat operations.', u'However, a battle may end in a Pyrrhic victory, which ultimately favors the defeated party.', u'If no resolution is reached in a battle, it can result in a stalemate.', u'A conflict in which one side is unwilling to reach a decision by a direct battle using conventional warfare often becomes an insurgency.', u'Until the 19th century the majority of battles were of short duration, many lasting a part of a day.', u'(The Battle of Nations (1813) and the Battle of Gettysburg (1863) were exceptional in lasting three days.)', u'This was mainly due to the difficulty of supplying armies in the field, or conducting night operations.', u'The means of prolonging a battle was typically by employment of siege warfare.', u'Improvements in transportation and the sudden evolving of trench warfare, with its siege-like nature during World War I in the 20th century, lengthened the duration of battles to days and weeks.', u'This created the requirement for unit rotation to prevent combat fatigue, with troops preferably not remaining in a combat area of operations for more than a month.', u'Trench warfare had become largely obsolete in conflicts between advanced armies by the start of the Second World War.', u'The use of the term "battle" in military history has led to its misuse when referring to almost any scale of combat, notably by strategic forces involving hundreds of thousands of troops that may be engaged in either a single battle at one time (Battle of Leipzig) or multiple operations (Battle of Kursk).', u'The space a battle occupies depends on the range of the weapons of the combatants.', u'A "battle" in this broader sense may be of long duration and take place over a large area, as in the case of the Battle of Britain or the Battle of the Atlantic.', u'Until the advent of artillery and aircraft, battles were fought with the two sides within sight, if not reach, of each other.', u'The depth of the battlefield has also increased in modern warfare with inclusion of the supporting units in the rear areas; supply, artillery, medical personnel etc.', u'often outnumber the front-line combat troops.', u"Battles are, on the whole, made up of a multitude of individual combats, skirmishes and small engagements within the context of which the combatants will usually only experience a small part of the events of the battle's entirety.", u"To the infantryman, there may be little to distinguish between combat as part of a minor raid or as a major offensive, nor is it likely that he anticipates the future course of the battle; few of the British infantry who went over the top on the first day on the Somme, July 1, 1916, would have anticipated that they would be fighting the same battle in five months' time.", u'Conversely, some of the Allied infantry who had just dealt a crushing defeat to the French at the Battle of Waterloo fully expected to have to fight again the next day (at the Battle of Wavre).', u'== Battlespace ==\n\nBattlespace is a unified strategy to integrate and combine armed forces for the military theatre of operations, including air, information, land, sea and space.', u'It includes the environment, factors and conditions that must be understood to successfully apply combat power, protect the force, or complete the mission.', u'This includes enemy and friendly armed forces; facilities; weather; terrain; and the electromagnetic spectrum within the operational areas and areas of interest.', u'== Factors ==\nBattles are decided by various factors.', u'The number and quality of combatants and equipment, the skill of the commanders of each army, and the terrain advantages are among the most prominent factors.', u'A unit may charge with high morale but less discipline and still emerge victorious.', u'This tactic was effectively used by the early French Revolutionary Armies.', u'Weapons and armour can be a decisive factor.', u'On many occasions armies have achieved victories largely owing to the employment of more advanced weapons than those of their opponents.', u'An extreme example was in the Battle of Omdurman, in which a large army of Sudanese Mahdists armed in a traditional manner were destroyed by an Anglo-Egyptian force equipped with Maxim guns.', u'On some occasions, simple weapons employed in an unorthodox fashion have proven advantageous, as with the Swiss pikemen who gained many victories through their ability to transform a traditionally defensive weapon into an offensive one.', u'Likewise, the Zulus in the early 19th century were victorious in battles against their rivals in part because they adopted a new kind of spear, the iklwa.', u'Even so, forces with inferior weapons have still emerged victorious at times, for example in the Wars of Scottish Independence and in the First Italo\u2013Ethiopian War.', u'Discipline within the troops is often of greater importance; at the Battle of Alesia, the Romans were greatly outnumbered but won because of superior training.', u'Battles can also be determined by terrain.', u'Capturing high ground, for example, has been the central strategy in innumerable battles.', u'An army that holds the high ground forces the enemy to climb, and thus wear themselves down.', u'Areas of dense vegetation, such as jungles and forest, act as force-multipliers, of benefit to inferior armies.', u'Arguably, terrain is of less importance in modern warfare, due to the advent of aircraft, though terrain is still vital for camouflage, especially for guerrilla warfare.', u'Generals and commanders also play a decisive role during combat.', u'Hannibal, Julius Caesar, Khalid ibn Walid and Napoleon Bonaparte were all skilled generals and, consequently, their armies were extremely successful.', u'An army that can trust the commands of their leaders with conviction in its success invariably has a higher morale than an army that doubts its every move.', u'The British in the naval Battle of Trafalgar, for example, owed its success to the reputation of celebrated admiral Lord Nelson.', u'== Types ==\n\nBattles can be fought on land, at sea and, in the modern age, in the air.', u'Naval battles have occurred since before the 5th century BC.', u'Air battles have been far less common, due to their late conception, the most prominent being the Battle of Britain in 1940.', u'However, since the Second World War land or sea battles have come to rely on air support.', u'Indeed, during the Battle of Midway, five aircraft carriers were sunk without either fleet coming into direct contact.', u'There are numerous types of battles:\nA battle of encounter (or encounter battle) is a meeting engagement where the opposing sides collide in the field without either having prepared their attack or defence.', u"A battle of attrition aims to inflict losses on an enemy that are less sustainable compared to one's own losses.", u'These need not be greater numerical losses \u2013 if one side is much more numerous than the other than pursuing a strategy based on attrition can work even if casualties on both sides are about equal.', u'Many battles of the Western Front in the First World War were intentionally (Verdun) or unintentionally (Somme) attrition battles.', u"A battle of breakthrough aims to pierce the enemy's defences, thereby exposing the vulnerable flanks which can be turned.", u'A battle of encirclement\u2014the Kesselschlacht of the German Blitzkrieg\u2014surrounds the enemy in a pocket.', u'A battle of envelopment involves an attack on one or both flanks; the classic example being the double-envelopment of the Battle of Cannae.', u'A battle of annihilation is one in which the defeated party is destroyed in the field, such as the French fleet at the Battle of the Nile.', u'Battles frequently do not fit one particular type perfectly, and are usually hybrids of different types listed above.', u'A decisive battle is one of particular importance; often by bringing hostilities to an end, such as the Battle of Hastings or the Battle of Hattin, or as a turning point in the fortunes of the belligerents, such as the Battle of Stalingrad.', u'A decisive battle can have political as well as military impact, changing the balance of power or boundaries between countries.', u"The concept of the decisive battle became popular with the publication in 1851 of Edward Creasy's The Fifteen Decisive Battles of the World.", u'British military historians J.F.C.', u'Fuller (The Decisive Battles of the Western World) and B.H.', u"Liddell Hart (Decisive Wars of History), among many others, have written books in the style of Creasy's work.", u'=== Land ===\nThere is an obvious difference in the way battles have been fought throughout time.', u'Early battles were probably fought between rival hunting bands as disorganized mobs.', u'However, during the Battle of Megiddo, the first reliably documented battle in the fifteenth century BC, actual discipline was instilled in both armies.', u'However, during the many wars of the Roman Empire, barbarians continued using mob tactics.', u'As the Age of Enlightenment dawned, armies began to fight in highly disciplined lines.', u'Each would follow the orders from their officers and fight as a single unit instead of individuals.', u'Each army was successively divided into regiments, battalions, companies, and platoons.', u'These armies would march, line up, and fire in divisions.', u'Native Americans, on the other hand, did not fight in lines, utilizing instead guerrilla tactics.', u'American colonists and European forces continued using disciplined lines, continuing into the American Civil War.', u'A new style, during World War I, known as trench warfare, developed nearly half a century later.', u'This also led to radio for communication between battalions.', u'Chemical warfare also emerged with the use of poisonous gas during World War I.', u'By World War II, the use of the smaller divisions, platoons and companies became much more important as precise operations became vital.', u'Instead of the locked trench warfare of World War I, during World War II, a dynamic network of battles developed where small groups encountered other platoons.', u'As a result, elite squads became much more recognized and distinguishable.', u'Maneuver warfare also developed with an astonishing pace with the advent of the tank, replacing the archaic cannons of the Enlightenment Age.', u'Artillery has since gradually replaced the use of frontal troops.', u'Modern battles now continue to resemble those of World War II, though prominent innovations have been added.', u'Indirect combat through the use of aircraft and missiles now constitutes a large portion of wars in place of battles, where battles are now mostly reserved for capturing cities.', u'=== Naval ===\n\nOne significant difference of modern naval battles as opposed to earlier forms of combat is the use of marines, which introduced amphibious warfare.', u'Today, a marine is actually an infantry regiment that sometimes fights solely on land and is no longer tied to the navy.', u'A good example of an old naval battle is the Battle of Salamis.', u'Most ancient naval battles were fought by fast ships using the battering ram to sink opposing fleets or steer close enough for boarding in hand-to-hand combat.', u'Troops were often used to storm enemy ships as used by Romans and pirates.', u'This tactic was usually used by civilizations that could not beat the enemy with ranged weaponry.', u'Another invention in the late Middle Ages was the use of Greek fire by the Byzantines, which was used to set enemy fleets on fire.', u'Empty demolition ships utilized the tactic to crash into opposing ships and set it afire with an explosion.', u'After the invention of cannons, naval warfare became useful as support units for land warfare.', u'During the 19th century, the development of mines led to a new type of naval warfare.', u'The ironclad, first used in the American Civil War, resistant to cannons, soon made the wooden ship obsolete.', u'The invention of military submarines, during World War I, brought naval warfare to both above and below the surface.', u'With the development of military aircraft during World War II, battles were fought in the sky as well as below the ocean.', u'Aircraft carriers have since become the central unit in naval warfare, acting as a mobile base for lethal aircraft.', u'=== Aerial ===\nAlthough the use of aircraft has for the most part always been used as a supplement to land or naval engagements, since their first major military use in World War I aircraft have increasingly taken on larger roles in warfare.', u'During World War I, the primary use was for reconnaissance, and small-scale bombardment.', u'Aircraft began becoming much more prominent in the Spanish Civil War and especially World War II.', u'Aircraft design began specializing, primarily into two types: bombers, which carried explosive payloads to bomb land targets or ships; and fighter-interceptors, which were used to either intercept incoming aircraft or to escort and protect bombers (engagements between fighter aircraft were known as dog fights).', u'Some of the more notable aerial battles in this period include the Battle of Britain and the Battle of Midway.', u'Another important use of aircraft came with the development of the helicopter, which first became heavily used during the Vietnam War, and still continues to be widely used today to transport and augment ground forces.', u'Today, direct engagements between aircraft are rare \u2013 the most modern fighter-interceptors carry much more extensive bombing payloads, and are used to bomb precision land targets, rather than to fight other aircraft.', u'Anti-aircraft batteries are used much more extensively to defend against incoming aircraft than interceptors.', u'Despite this, aircraft today are much more extensively used as the primary tools for both army and navy, as evidenced by the prominent use of helicopters to transport and support troops, the use of aerial bombardment as the "first strike" in many engagements, and the replacement of the battleship with the aircraft carrier as the center of most modern navies.', u'== Naming ==\n\nBattles are usually named after some feature of the battlefield geography, such as the name of a town, forest or river, commonly prefixed "Battle of...".', u'Occasionally battles are named after the date on which they took place, such as The Glorious First of June.', u'In the Middle Ages it was considered important to settle on a suitable name for a battle which could be used by the chroniclers.', u'For example, after Henry V of England defeated a French army on October 25, 1415, he met with the senior French herald and they agreed to name the battle after the nearby castle and so it was called the Battle of Agincourt.', u'In other cases, the sides adopted different names for the same battle, such as the Battle of Gallipoli which is known in Turkey as the Battle of \xc7anakkale.', u'During the American Civil War, the Union tended to name the battles after the nearest watercourse, such as the Battle of Wilsons Creek and the Battle of Stones River, whereas the Confederates favoured the nearby towns, as in the Battles of Chancellorsville and Murfreesboro.', u'Occasionally both names for the same battle entered the popular culture, such as the First and Second Battle of Bull Run, which are also referred to as the First and Second Battle of Manassas.', u'Sometimes in desert warfare, there is no nearby town name to use; map coordinates gave the name to the Battle of 73 Easting in the First Gulf War.', u'Some place names have become synonymous with the battles that took place there, such as the Passchendaele, Pearl Harbor, the Alamo, Thermopylae, or Waterloo.', u'Military operations, many of which result in battle, are given codenames, which are not necessarily meaningful or indicative of the type or the location of the battle.', u'Operation Market Garden and Operation Rolling Thunder are examples of battles known by their military codenames.', u'When a battleground is the site of more than one battle in the same conflict, the instances are distinguished by ordinal number, such as the First and Second Battles of Bull Run.', u'An extreme case are the twelve Battles of the Isonzo\u2014First to Twelfth\u2014between Italy and Austria-Hungary during the First World War.', u'Some battles are named for the convenience of military historians so that periods of combat can be neatly distinguished from one another.', u'Following the First World War, the British Battles Nomenclature Committee was formed to decide on standard names for all battles and subsidiary actions.', u'To the soldiers who did the fighting, the distinction was usually academic; a soldier fighting at Beaumont Hamel on November 13, 1916 was probably unaware he was taking part in what the committee would call the "Battle of the Ancre".', u'Many combats are too small to merit a name.', u'Terms such as "action", "skirmish", "firefight", "raid" or "offensive patrol" are used to describe small-scale battle-like encounters.', u'These combats often take place within the time and space of a battle and while they may have an objective, they are not necessarily "decisive".', u'Sometimes the soldiers are unable to immediately gauge the significance of the combat; in the aftermath of the Battle of Waterloo, some British officers were in doubt as to whether the day\'s events merited the title of "battle" or would be passed off as merely an "action".', u'== Effects ==\nBattles affect the individuals who take part, as well as the political actors.', u'Personal effects of battle range from mild psychological issues to permanent and crippling injuries.', u'Some battle-survivors have nightmares about the conditions they encountered, or abnormal reactions to certain sights or sounds.', u'Some suffer flashbacks.', u'Physical effects of battle can include scars, amputations, lesions, loss of bodily functions, blindness, paralysis \u2014 and death.', u'Battles also affect politics.', u'A decisive battle can cause the losing side to surrender, while a Pyrrhic Victory such as the Battle of Asculum can cause the winning side to reconsider its long-term goals.', u'Battles in civil wars have often decided the fate of monarchs or political factions.', u'Famous examples include the War of the Roses, as well as the Jacobite Uprisings.', u'Battles also affect the commitment of one side or the other to the continuance of a war, for example the Battle of Incheon and the Battle of Hue during the Tet Offensive.', u'== See also ==\nList of battles\nMilitary strategy\nMilitary tactics\nNaval battle\nPitched in the period between its creation on 23 May 1949 to German reunification on 3 October 1990.", u'During this Cold War era, NATO-aligned West Germany and Warsaw Pact-aligned East Germany were divided capital city (Berlin was symbolically named the de jure capital city in the West German Basic Law).', u'The fourth Allied occupation zone (the East Zone, or Ostzone) was held by the Soviet Union.', u'The parts of this zone lying east of the Oder-Neisse were in fact annexed by the Soviet Union and communist Poland; the remaining central part around Berlin became the communist German Democratic Republic (abbreviated GDR; in German Deutsche Demokratische Republik or DDR) with its de facto capital in East Berlin.', u'As a result, West Germany had a territory about half the size of the interbellum democratic Weimar Republic.', u'At the onset of the Cold War, Germany (and, indeed, Europe) was divided among the Western and Eastern blocs.', u'Germany was de facto divided into two reorganised continuation of the 1871\u20131945 German Reich.', u'It took the line that the GDR was an illegally constituted puppet state.', u'Though the GDR did hold regular elections, these were not facto 11th state.', u'While legally not part of the Federal Republic of Germany, as Berlin was under the control of the Allied Control Council, West Berlin aligned itself politically with West Germany line of "two German states within one German nation", but formally maintained the exclusive mandate.', u'It recognised the GDR as a de facto government within a single German nation that in turn was represented de jure by the West German state alone.', u'From 1973 onward, East Germany recognised the existence of two German countries de jure, and the West as both de facto and de jure foreign country.', u'The Federal Republic and the GDR agreed that neither of them could speak in the name of the other.', u"The foundation for the influential position held by Germany today was laid during agreements that developed into the present-day European Union.', u'When the G6/G8 was established in 1975, there was no question whether the Federal Republic of Germany would be a member as well.', u'With the collapse of communism in Central and Eastern Europe in 1989, symbolised by the opening of the Berlin Wall, there was a rapid move towards German reunification.', u'East Germany voted to dissolve itself and accede to the Federal Republic in 1990.', u'Its five post-war states (L\xe4nder) were reconstituted along with the reunited Berlin, which ended its special status and formed an West Germany's political culture and continued its existing memberships in international organisations, as well as its Western foreign policy alignment and affiliation to Western alliances like NATO and the European Union.", u'== Naming conventions ==\n\nThe official name of West Germany, adopted in 1949 and unchanged since, is Bundesrepublik Deutschland (Federal Republic of Germany).', u'Its abbreviation "BRD" (German) or "FRG" (English) was sometimes also used.', u'In East Germany usage, the terms Westdeutschland (West Germany) or westdeutsche Bundesrepublik (West German Federal Republic) were preferred during the 1950s and 1960s.', u'This changed once East Germany considered West Germans and West Berliners foreigners under its 1968 constitution, where the idea of a single German nation was abandoned.', u'In the early 1970s, starting in the East German Neues Deutschland, the initialism "BRD" (FRG) for the "Federal Republic of Germany" began to prevail.', u'In 1973 official East German sources adopted it as a standard expression and other Eastern Bloc nations soon followed suit.', u'In reaction to this move, in 1965 the Federal Minister of All-German Affairs Erich Mende issued the Directives for the appellation of Germany recommending avoiding the initialism.', u'On 31 May 1974 the heads of German federal and state governments recommended to always use the full name in official publications.', u'From then on West German sources avoided the abbreviated form, with the exception of left-leaning organizations which embraced it.', u'In November 1979 the federal government informed the Bundestag that the West German public broadcasters ARD and ZDF had agreed to refuse to use the initialism.', u'The colloquial term "West Germany" or its equivalent was used in many languages.', u'"Westdeutschland" was also a widespread colloquial form used in German-speaking countries, usually without political overtones.', u'== History ==\n\nOn 4\u201311 February 1945 leaders from the United States, the United Kingdom and the Soviet Union held the Yalta Conference where future arrangements as regards post-war Europe and strategy against Japan in the Pacific were negotiated.', u'The conference agreed to split Germany into four occupation zones: a French Zone in the far west; a British Zone in the northwest; an American Zone in the south; and a Soviet Zone in the east.', u'At the time, the intention was not to split Germany, only to designate zones of administration.', u'Former German areas east of the rivers Oder and Neisse were put under Polish administration.', u'Millions of Germans were expelled and replaced by Poles.', u'In similar fashion, the Soviet Union took over areas of eastern Poland and East Prussia.', u'Between 1946 and 1949, three of the occupation zones began to merge.', u'First, the British and American zones were combined into the quasi-state of Bizonia.', u'Soon afterwards, the French zone was included into Trizonia.', u'At the same time, new federal states (L\xe4nder) were formed in the Allied zones, replacing the pre-war states.', u'In 1949 with the continuation and aggravation of the Cold War (witness the Berlin Airlift of 1948\u201349), the two German states that were originated in the Western Allied and the Soviet Zones became known internationally as West Germany and East Germany.', u'Commonly known in English as East Germany, the former Soviet Occupation Zone, eventually became the German Democratic Republic or GDR.', u"From 3 October 1990, after the reformation of the GDR's L\xe4nder, the East German states joined the Federal Republic.", u'=== NATO membership ===\n\nWith territories and frontiers that coincided largely with the ones of old Medieval East Francia and the 19th-century Napoleonic Confederation of the Rhine, the Federal Republic of Germany, founded on 23 May 1949, under the terms of the Bonn\u2013Paris conventions it obtained "the full authority of a sovereign state" on 5 May 1955 (although "full sovereignty" was not obtained until the Two Plus Four Agreement in 1990).', u'The former occupying Western troops remained on the ground, now as part of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), which West Germany joined on 9 May 1955, promising to rearm itself soon.', u'West Germany became a focus of the Cold War with its juxtaposition to East Germany, a member of the subsequently founded Warsaw Pact.', u'The former capital, Berlin, had been divided into four sectors, with the Western Allies joining their sectors to form West Berlin, while the Soviets held East Berlin.', u'West Berlin was completely surrounded by East German territory and had suffered a Soviet blockade in 1948\u201349, which was overcome by the Berlin airlift.', u'The outbreak of the Korean War in June 1950 led to U.S. calls to rearm West Germany to help defend Western Europe from the perceived Soviet threat.', u"Germany's partners in the Coal and Steel Community proposed to establish a European Defence Community (EDC), with an integrated army, navy and air force, composed of the armed forces of its member states.", u'The West German military would be subject to complete EDC control, but the other EDC member states (Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) would cooperate in the EDC while maintaining independent control of their own armed forces.', u'Though the EDC treaty was signed (May 1952), it never entered into force.', u"France's Gaullists rejected it on the grounds that it threatened national sovereignty, and when the French National Assembly refused to ratify it (August 1954), the treaty died.", u"The French Gaullists and communists had killed the French government's proposal.", u'Other means then had to be found to allow West German rearmament.', u'In response, at the London and Paris Conferences, the Brussels Treaty was modified to include West Germany, and to form the Western European Union (WEU).', u'West Germany was to be permitted to rearm (an idea many Germans rejected), and have full sovereign control of its military, called the Bundeswehr.', u'The WEU, however, would regulate the size of the armed forces permitted to each of its member states.', u'Also, the German constitution prohibited any military action, except in case of an external attack against Germany or its allies (B\xfcndnisfall).', u'Also, Germans could reject military service on grounds of conscience, and serve for civil purposes instead.', u'The three Western Allies retained occupation powers in Berlin and certain responsibilities for Germany as a whole.', u'Under the new arrangements, the Allies stationed troops within West Germany for NATO defense, pursuant to stationing and status-of-forces agreements.', u"With the exception of 55,000 French troops, Allied forces were under NATO's joint defense command.", u'(France withdrew from the collective military command structure of NATO in 1966.)', u'=== Reforms during the 1960s ===\nKonrad Adenauer was 73 years old when he became chancellor, and for this reason he was initially reckoned as a caretaker.', u'However, he stayed in power for 14 years.', u'The grand old man of German postwar politics had to be dragged\u2014almost literally\u2014out of office in 1963.', u'In 1959 it was time to elect a new President and Adenauer decided that he would nominate Erhard, the architect of the economic miracle.', u"Erhard was not enthusiastic, and to everybody's surprise, Adenauer decided at the age of 83 that he would take on the position.", u'He apparently believed that this would allow him to dominate the scene for up to ten more years in spite of the growing mood for change.', u'However, when his advisers informed him that the powers of the president were almost entirely ceremonial, he quickly lost interest.', u'An alternative candidate was needed and eventually the Minister of Agriculture, Heinrich L\xfcbke took on the task and was duly elected.', u'In October 1962 the weekly news magazine Der Spiegel published an analysis of the West German military defence.', u'The conclusion was that there were several weaknesses in the system.', u'Ten days after publication, the offices of Der Spiegel in Hamburg were raided by the police and quantities of documents were seized.', u'Chancellor Adenauer proclaimed in the Bundestag that the article was tantamount to high treason and that the authors would be prosecuted.', u'The editor/owner of the magazine, Rudolf Augstein spent some time in jail before the public outcry over the breaking of laws on freedom of the press became too loud to be ignored.', u"The FDP members of Adenauer's cabinet resigned from the government, demanding the resignation of Franz Josef Strauss, Defence Minister, who had decidedly overstepped his competence during the crisis.", u'Adenauer was still wounded by his brief run for president, and this episode damaged his reputation even further.', u'He announced that he would step down in the Fall of 1963.', u'His successor was to be Ludwig Erhard.', u'In the early 1960s the rate of economic growth slowed down significantly.', u'In 1962 growth rate was 4.7% and the following year, 2.0%.', u'After a brief recovery, the growth rate slowed again into a recession, with no growth in 1967.', u'A new coalition was formed to deal with this problem.', u'Erhard stepped down in 1966 and was succeeded by Kurt Georg Kiesinger.', u"He led a grand coalition between West Germany's two largest parties, the CDU/CSU and the Social Democratic Party (SPD).", u'This was important for the introduction of new emergency acts: the grand coalition gave the ruling parties the two-thirds majority of votes required for their ratification.', u'These controversial acts allowed basic constitutional rights such as freedom of movement to be limited in case of a state of emergency.', u'During the time leading up to the passing of the laws, there was fierce opposition to them, above all by the Free Democratic Party, the rising German student movement, a group calling itself Notstand der Demokratie ("Democracy in Crisis") and members of the Campaign against Nuclear Armament.', u'A key event in the development of open democratic debate occurred in 1967, when the Shah of Iran, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, visited West Berlin.', u'Several thousand demonstrators gathered outside the Opera House where he was to attend a special performance.', u'Supporters of the Shah (later known as Jubelperser), armed with staves and bricks attacked the protesters while the police stood by and watched.', u'A demonstration in the centre was being forcibly dispersed when a bystander named Benno Ohnesorg was shot in the head and killed by a plainclothes policeman.', u'(It has now been established that the policeman, Kurras, was a paid spy of the East German security forces.)', u'Protest demonstrations continued, and calls for more active opposition by some groups of students were made, which was declared by the press, especially the tabloid Bild-Zeitung newspaper, as a massive disruption to life in Berlin, in a massive campaign against the protesters.', u'Protests against the US intervention in Vietnam, mingled with anger over the vigour with which demonstrations were repressed led to mounting militance among the students at the universities in Berlin.', u'One of the most prominent campaigners was a young man from East Germany called Rudi Dutschke who also criticised the forms of capitalism that were to be seen in West Berlin.', u'Just before Easter 1968, a young man tried to kill Dutschke as he bicycled to the student union, seriously injuring him.', u'All over West Germany, thousands demonstrated against the Springer newspapers which were seen as the prime cause of the violence against students.', u'Trucks carrying newspapers were set on fire and windows in office buildings broken.', u"In the wakes of these demonstrations, in which the question of America's role in Vietnam began to play a bigger role, came a desire among the students to find out more about the role of the parent-generation in the Nazi era.", u'The proceedings of the War Crimes Tribunal at Nuremberg had been widely publicised in Germany but until a new generation of teachers, educated with the findings of historical studies, could begin to reveal the truth about the war and the crimes committed in the name of the German people.', u'One courageous attorney, Fritz Bauer patiently gathered evidence on the guards of the Auschwitz concentration camp and about twenty were put on trial in Frankfurt in 1963.', u'Daily newspaper reports and visits by school classes to the proceedings revealed to the German public the nature of the concentration camp system and it became evident that the Shoah was of vastly greater dimensions than the German population had believed.', u'(The term "Holocaust" for the systematic mass-murder of Jews first came into use in 1979, when an American mini-series with that name was shown on German television.)', u'The processes set in motion by the Auschwitz trial reverberated decades later.', u'The calling in question of the actions and policies of government led to a new climate of debate.', u'The issues of emancipation, colonialism, environmentalism and grass roots democracy were discussed at all levels of society.', u'In 1979 the environmental party, the Greens, reached the 5% limit required to obtain parliamentary seats in the Free Hanseatic City of Bremen provincial election.', u'Also of great significance was the steady growth of a feminist movement in which women demonstrated for equal rights.', u'Until 1977 a married woman had to have the permission of her husband if she wanted to take on a job or open a bank account.', u'Further reforms in 1979 to parental rights law gave equal legal rights to the mother and the father, abolishing the legal authority of the father.', u'Parallel to this, a gay movement began to grow in the larger cities, especially in West Berlin, where homosexuality had been widely accepted during the twenties in the Weimar Republic.', u'Anger over the treatment of demonstrators following the death of Benno Ohnesorg and the attack on Rudi Dutschke, coupled with growing frustration over the lack of success in achieving their aims led to growing militance among students and their supporters.', u'In May 1968, three young people set fire to two department stores in Frankfurt, they were brought to trial and made very clear to the court that they regarded their action as a legitimate act in what they described as the "struggle against imperialism".', u'The student movement began to split into different factions, ranging from the unattached liberals to the Maoists and supporters of direct action in every form\u2014the anarchists.', u'Several groups set as their objective the aim of radicalising the industrial workers and taking an example from activities in Italy of the Red Brigades (Brigade Rosse), many students went to work in the factories, but with little or no success.', u'The most notorious of the underground groups was the "Baader-Meinhof Group", later known as the Red Army Faction which began by making bank raids to finance their activities and eventually went underground having killed a number of policemen, several bystanders and eventually two prominent West Germans, whom they had taken captive in order to force the release of prisoners sympathetic to their ideas.', u'In the 1990s attacks were still being committed under the name "RAF".', u'The last action took place in 1993 and the group announced it was giving up its activities in 1998.', u'Evidence that the groups had been infiltrated by German Intelligence undercover agents has since emerged, partly through the insistence of the son of one of their prominent victims, the State Counsel Buback.', u'=== Political developments 1969\u201390 ===\nIn the 1969 election, the SPD\u2014headed by Willy Brandt\u2014gained enough votes to form a coalition government with the FDP.', u'Although Chancellor for only just over four years, Willy Brandt was one of the most popular politicians in the whole period.', u'Brandt was a gifted speaker and the growth of the Social Democrats from there on was in no small part due to his personality.', u"Brandt began a policy of rapprochement with West Germany's eastern neighbours, a policy opposed by the CDU.", u'The issue of improving relations with Poland, Czechoslovakia and East Germany made for an increasingly aggressive tone in public debates but it was a huge step forward when Willy Brandt and the Foreign Minister, Walther Scheel (FDP) negotiated agreements with all three countries.', u'(Moscow Agreement, August 1970, Warsaw Agreement, December 1970, Four Power Agreement over the status of West Berlin in 1971 and an agreement on relations between West and East Germany, signed in December 1972.)', u"These agreements were the basis for a rapid improvement in the relations between east and west and led, in the long-term to the dismantlement of the Warsaw Treaty and the Soviet Union's control over Eastern Europe.", u'Chancellor Brandt was forced to resign in May 1974, after G\xfcnter Guillaume, a senior member of his staff, was uncovered as a spy for the East German intelligence service, the Stasi.', u"Brandt's contributions to world peace led to his nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize in 1971.", u'Finance Minister Helmut Schmidt (SPD) formed a coalition and he served as Chancellor from 1974 to 1982.', u'Hans-Dietrich Genscher, a leading FDP official, became Vice Chancellor and Foreign Minister.', u'Schmidt, a strong supporter of the European Community (EC) and the Atlantic alliance, emphasized his commitment to "the political unification of Europe in partnership with the USA".', u'In October 1982 the SPD\u2013FDP coalition fell apart when the FDP joined forces with the CDU/CSU to elect CDU Chairman Helmut Kohl as Chancellor in a constructive vote of no confidence.', u'Following national elections in March 1983, Kohl emerged in firm control of both the government and the CDU.', u'The CDU/CSU fell just short of an absolute majority, due to the entry into the Bundestag of the Greens, who received 5.6% of the vote.', u'In January 1987 the Kohl\u2013Genscher government was returned to office, but the FDP and the Greens gained at the expense of the larger parties.', u"Kohl's CDU and its Bavarian sister party, the CSU, slipped from 48.8% of the vote in 1983 to 44.3%.", u'The SPD fell to 37%; long-time SPD Chairman Brandt subsequently resigned in April 1987 and was succeeded by Hans-Jochen Vogel.', u"The FDP's share rose from 7% to 9.1%, its best showing since 1980.", u"The Greens' share rose to 8.3% from their 1983 share of 5.6%.", u'=== Reunification ===\n\nThe official German reunification ceremony on 3 October 1990 was held at the Reichstag building, including Chancellor Helmut Kohl, President Richard von Weizs\xe4cker, former Chancellor Willy Brandt and many others.', u'One day later, the parliament of the united Germany would assemble in an act of symbolism in the Reichstag building.', u'Germany had split into two places in 1945, after the end of World War Two.', u'However, at that time, the role of Berlin had not yet been decided upon.', u'Only after a fierce debate, considered by many as one of the most memorable sessions of parliament, the Bundestag concluded on 20 June 1991, with quite a slim majority, that both government and parliament should move to Berlin from Bonn.', u'== West German "economic miracle" ==\nThe West German Wirtschaftswunder ("economic miracle", coined by The Times in 1950) was partly due to the economic aid provided by the United States and the Marshall Plan, but mainly due to the currency reform of 1948 which replaced the Reichsmark with the Deutsche Mark and halted rampant inflation.', u'The Allied dismantling of the West German coal and steel industry finally ended in 1950.', u'In addition to the physical obstacles that had to be overcome for the German economic recovery (see the Morgenthau Plan) there were also intellectual challenges.', u'The Allies confiscated intellectual privileges of huge value, such as all German patents, both in Germany and abroad, and used them to strengthen their own industrial competitiveness by licensing them to Allied companies.', u'Meanwhile, some of the best German researchers were being put to work in the Soviet Union and in the USA.', u'Contrary to popular belief, the Marshall Plan, which was extended to include the newly formed West Germany in 1949, was not the main force behind the Wirtschaftswunder.', u'Had that been the case, other countries such as the United Kingdom and France (which both received higher economic assistance from the plan than Germany) should have experienced the same phenomenon.', u'In fact, the amount of monetary aid (which was in the form of loans) received by Germany through the Marshall Plan was far overshadowed by the amount the Germans had to pay back as war reparations and by the charges the Allies exacted from the Germans for the ongoing cost of occupation (about $2.4 billion per year).', u'In 1953 it was decided that Germany was to repay $1.1 billion of the aid it had received.', u'The last repayment was made in June 1971.', u'As demand for consumer goods increased after WWII, the resulting shortage helped overcome lingering resistance to the purchase of German products.', u'At the time Germany had a large pool of skilled and cheap labour, partly as a result of the flight and expulsion of Germans from Central and Eastern Europe, which affected up to 16.5 million Germans.', u'This helped Germany to more than double the value of its exports during the war.', u'Apart from these factors, hard work and long hours at full capacity among the population and in the late 1950s and 1960s extra labour supplied by thousands of Gastarbeiter ("guest workers") provided a vital base for the economic upturn.', u'This would have implications later on for successive German governments as they tried to assimilate this group of workers.', u'From the late 1950s onwards, West Germany had one of the strongest economies in the world, almost as strong as before the Second World War.', u'The East German economy showed a certain growth, but not as much as in West Germany, partly because of continued reparations to the USSR in terms of resources.', u'In 1952 West Germany became part of the European Coal and Steel Community, which would later evolve into the European Union.', u'On 5 May 1955 West Germany was declared to have the "authority of a sovereign state".', u'The British, French and U.S. militaries remained in the country, just as the Soviet Army remained in East Germany.', u'Four days after obtaining the "authority of a sovereign state" in 1955, West Germany joined NATO.', u'The UK and the USA retained an especially strong presence in West Germany, acting as a deterrent in case of a Soviet invasion.', u'In 1976 West Germany became one of the founding nations of the Group of Six (G6).', u"In 1973, West Germany\u2014home to roughly 1.26% of the world's population\u2014featured the world's fourth largest GDP of 944 billion (5.9% of the world total).", u'In 1987 the FRG held a 7.4% share of total world production.', u'== Demographics ==\n\n\n=== Population ===\nTotal population of West Germany from 1950 to 1990, as collected by the Statistisches Bundesamt.', u'=== Religion ===\n\nReligious affiliation in West Germany as collected by fowid (Forschungsgruppe Weltanschauungen in Deutschland).', u'Protestantism in Germany (EKD)\nRoman Catholicism in Germany\nIslam in Germany\nCentral Council of Jews in Germany\n\n\n== Position towards East Germany ==\n\nThe official position of West Germany concerning East Germany at the outset was that the West German government was the only democratically elected, and therefore the only legitimate, representative of the German people.', u'According to the Hallstein Doctrine, any country (with the exception of the USSR) that recognised the authorities of the German Democratic Republic would not have diplomatic relations with West Germany.', u'In the early 1970s, Willy Brandt\'s policy of "Neue Ostpolitik" led to a form of mutual recognition between East and West Germany.', u'The Treaty of Moscow (August 1970), the Treaty of Warsaw (December 1970), the Four Power Agreement on Berlin (September 1971), the Transit Agreement (May 1972), and the Basic Treaty (December 1972) helped to normalise relations between East and West Germany and led to both German states joining the United Nations.', u'The Hallstein Doctrine was relinquished, and West Germany ceased to claim an exclusive mandate for Germany as a whole.', u'The West German Constitution (Grundgesetz, "Basic Law") provided two articles for the unification with other parts of Germany:\nArticle 23 provided the possibility for other parts of Germany to join the Federal Republic (under the constitution of the Federal Republic of Germany).', u'Article 146 provided the possibility for unification of all parts of Germany under a new constitution.', u'After the peaceful revolution of 1989 in East Germany, the first freely elected East German parliament decided in June 1990 that the L\xe4nder soon to be re-established would join the Federal Republic under Article 23 of the (West) German Basic Law (Grundgesetz).', u'This made a quick unification possible.', u'In July/August 1990 the East German parliament enacted a law for the re-establishment of L\xe4nder on the territory of the German Democratic Republic.', u'The two German states entered into a currency and customs union in July 1990, and on 3 October 1990, the German Democratic Republic dissolved and the re-established five East German L\xe4nder (as well as a unified Berlin) joined the Federal Republic of Germany, bringing an end to the East-West divide.', u'== Politics ==\nPolitical life in West Germany was remarkably stable and orderly.', u'The Adenauer era (1949\u201363) was followed by a brief period under Ludwig Erhard (1963\u201366) who, in turn, was replaced by Kurt Georg Kiesinger (1966\u201369).', u'All governments between 1949 and 1966 were formed by the united caucus of the Christian-Democratic Union (CDU) and Christian Social Union (CSU), either alone or in coalition with the smaller Free Democratic Party (FDP) or other right-wing parties.', u'Kiesinger\'s 1966\u201369 "Grand Coalition" was between West Germany\'s two largest parties, the CDU/CSU and the Social Democratic Party (SPD).', u'This was important for the introduction of new emergency acts\u2014the Grand Coalition gave the ruling parties the two-thirds majority of votes required to see them in.', u'These controversial acts allowed basic constitutional rights such as freedom of movement to be limited in case of a state of emergency.', u'Leading up to the passing of the laws, there was fierce opposition to them, above all by the FDP, the rising German student movement, a group calling itself Notstand der Demokratie ("Democracy in a State of Emergency") and the labour unions.', u'Demonstrations and protests grew in number, and in 1967 the student Benno Ohnesorg was shot in the head by a policeman.', u'The press, especially the tabloid Bild-Zeitung newspaper, launched a campaign against the protesters.', u'By 1958 a stronger desire to confront the Nazi past had come into being.', u'In the 1960s environmentalism and anti-nationalism became fundamental values among left-wing Germans.', u'As a result, in 1979 the Greens were able to reach the 5% minimum required to obtain parliamentary seats in the Free Hanseatic City of Bremen state election, and with the foundation of the national party in 1980 developed into one of the most politically successful green movements in the world.', u'Another result of the unrest in the 1960s was the founding of the Red Army Faction (RAF).', u'The RAF was active from 1968, carrying out a succession of terrorist attacks in West Germany during the 1970s.', u'Even in the 1990s, attacks were still being committed under the name RAF.', u'The last action took place in 1993, and in 1998 the group announced it was ceasing activities.', u'In the 1969 election, the SPD gained enough votes to form a coalition government with the FDP.', u'SPD leader and Chancellor Willy Brandt remained head of government until May 1974, when he resigned after the Guillaume Affair, in which a senior member of his staff was uncovered as a spy for the East German intelligence service, the Stasi.', u"However the affair is widely considered to have been merely a trigger for Brandt's resignation, not a fundamental cause.", u'Instead, Brandt, dogged by scandal relating to alcohol and depression as well as the economic fallout of the 1973 oil crisis, almost seems simply to have had enough.', u'As Brandt himself later said, "I was exhausted, for reasons which had nothing to do with the process going on at the time".', u'Finance Minister Helmut Schmidt (SPD) then formed a government, continuing the SPD\u2013FDP coalition.', u'He served as Chancellor from 1974 to 1982.', u'Hans-Dietrich Genscher, a leading FDP official, was Vice Chancellor and Foreign Minister in the same years.', u'Schmidt, a strong supporter of the European Community (EC) and the Atlantic alliance, emphasized his commitment to "the political unification of Europe in partnership with the USA".', u'The goals of SPD and FDP however drifted apart in the late 1970s and early 1980s.', u'On 1 October 1982 the FDP joined forces with the CDU/CSU to elect CDU Chairman Helmut Kohl as Chancellor in a constructive vote of no confidence.', u'Following national elections in March 1983, Kohl emerged in firm control of both the government and the CDU.', u'The CDU/CSU fell just short of an absolute majority, because of the entry into the Bundestag of the Greens, who received 5.6% of the vote.', u'In January 1987 the Kohl\u2013Genscher government was returned to office, but the FDP and the Greens gained at the expense of the larger parties.', u'The Social Democrats concluded that not only were the Greens unlikely to form a coalition, but also that such a coalition would be far from a majority.', u'Neither condition changed until 1998.', u'== Culture ==\nIn many aspects, German culture continued in spite of the dictatorship and wartime.', u'Old and new forms coexisted next to each other, and the American influence, already strong in the 1920s, grew.', u'=== Sport ===\n\nIn the 20th century association football became the largest sport in Germany.', u'The Germany national football team, established in 1900, continued its tradition based in the Federal Republic of Germany, winning the 1954 FIFA World Cup in a stunning upset dubbed the miracle of Bern.', u'Earlier, the German team was not considered part of the international top.', u'The 1974 FIFA World Cup was held in West German cities and West Berlin.', u'After having been beaten by their East German counterparts in the first round, the team of the German Football Association won the cup again, defeating the Netherlands 2\u20131 in the final.', u'With the process of unification in full swing in the summer of 1990, the Germans won a third World Cup, with players that had been capped for East Germany not yet permitted to contribute.', u'European championships have been won too, in 1972, 1980 and 1996.', u'After both Olympic Games of 1936 had been held in Germany, Munich was selected to host the 1972 Summer Olympics.', u'These were also the first summer games in which the East Germans showed up with the separate flag and anthem of the GDR.', u'Since the 1950s, Germany at the Olympics had been represented by a united team led by the pre-war German NOC officials as the IOC had denied East German demands for a separate team.', u'As in 1957, when the Saarland acceded, East German sport organisations ceased to exist in late 1990 as their subdivisions and their members joined their Western counterparts.', u'Thus, the present German organisations and teams in football, Olympics and elsewhere are identical to those that had been informally called "West German" before 1991.', u'The only differences were a larger membership and a different name used by some foreigners.', u'These organisations and teams in turn mostly continued the traditions of those that represented Germany before the Second World War, and even the First World War, thus providing a century-old continuity despite political changes.', u'On the other hand, the separate East German teams and organisations were founded in the 1950s; they were an episode lasting less than four decades, yet quite successful in that time.', u'As of 2012, West Germany have played a record 43 matches at the European Championships.', u'=== Literary scene ===\nBesides the interest in the older generation of writers, new authors emerged on the background of the experiences of war and after war period.', u'Wolfgang Borchert, a former soldier who died young in 1947, is one of the best known representatives of the Tr\xfcmmerliteratur.', u'Heinrich B\xf6ll is considered an observer of the young Federal Republic from the 1950s to the 1970s, and caused some political controversies because of his increasingly critical view on society.', u'The Frankfurt Book Fair (and its Peace Prize of the German Book Trade) soon developed into a regarded institution.', u"Exemplary for West Germany's literature are \u2013 among others \u2013 Siegfried Lenz (with The German Lesson) and G\xfcnter Grass (with The Tin Drum and The Flounder).", u'=== Daily life ===\nDuring the 40 years of separation some divergence occurred in the cultural life of the two parts of the severed nation.', u'Both West Germany and East Germany followed along traditional paths of the common German culture, but West Germany, being obviously more affected by influences from western Europe and North America, became more cosmopolitan.', u'Conversely, East Germany, while remaining more conservative than West Germany in its adherence to some aspects of the received tradition, was strongly moulded by the dictates of a state socialist ideology of predominantly Soviet inspiration.', u"On the non-political level, East Germany was also influenced by the Eastern Bloc's Slavic cultures that manifested in art, culinary scene, and sports.", u'Nevertheless, young East Germans were also fascinated by Western and particularly American culture, which they had a degree of access to in a variety of ways, not least through West German television and radio, whose broadcasts reached many parts of the country.', u'For the majority of Germans in present-day Germany who lived in pre-reunification West Germany, there has been minimal change in daily life stemming from German reunification as the reunified country is essentially West Germany incorporating East Germany on a West German base.', u'In contrast, for East Germans the scale of change has been sweeping in all aspects of life from that before die Wende.', u'Although movements like Ostalgie exist attempting to celebrate and preserve parts of the GDR culture, since reunification the former East Germany has been converging towards the western part of the country in most parts of daily life.', u'== Geographical distribution of government ==\nIn West Germany, most of the political agencies and buildings were located in Bonn, while the German Stock Market was located in Frankfurt am Main, which became the economic center.', u'The judicial branch of both the German Federal Constitutional Court (Bundesverfassungsgericht) and the highest Court of Appeals, were located in Karlsruhe.', u'The West German government was known to be much more decentralised than its state socialist East German counterpart, the former being a federal state and the latter a unitary one.', u'Whilst East Germany was divided into 15 administrative districts (Bezirke), which were merely local branches of the national government, West Germany was divided into states (L\xe4nder) with independently elected state parliaments and control of the Bundesrat, the second legislative chamber of the Federal Government.', u'== Present geographical and political terminology ==\nToday, North Rhine-Westphalia is often considered to be Western Germany in geographical terms.', u'When distinguishing between former West Germany and former East Germany as parts of present-day unified Germany, it has become most common to refer to the Alte Bundesl\xe4nder (old states) and the Neue Bundesl\xe4nder (new states), although Westdeutschland and Ostdeutschland are still heard as well.', u'== See also ==\n\nBonn\u2013Paris conventions\nPetersberg Agreement\nWest Berlin\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== Further reading ==\nBark, Dennis L., and David R. spring-powered clocks, which appeared as early as the 14th century.', u'During most of its history the watch was a mechanical device, driven by clockwork, powered by winding a mainspring, and keeping appeared in 15th century Europe.', u"Watches weren't widely worn in pockets until the 17th century.", u'One account says that the word "watch" came from the Old English word woecce which meant "watchman", because it was used by town watchmen to keep track of their shifts at work.', u'Another says that the term came from 17th century sailors, who used the new mechanisms to time the length of their shipboard watches (duty shifts).', u'A great leap forward in accuracy occurred in 1657 with the addition of the balance spring to the balance wheel, an invention disputed both at the time and ever since between Robert Hooke and Christiaan Huygens.', u"This innovation increased watches' accuracy enormously, reducing error from perhaps several hours per day to perhaps 10 minutes per day, resulting in the addition of the minute hand to the face from around 1680 in Britain and 1700 in France.", u'The increased accuracy of the balance wheel focused attention on errors caused by other parts of the movement, igniting a two century wave of watchmaking innovation.', u'The first thing to be improved was the escapement.', u'The verge escapement was replaced in quality watches by the cylinder escapement, invented by Thomas Tompion in 1695 and further developed by George Graham in the 1720s.', u'Improvements in manufacturing such as the tooth-cutting machine devised by Robert Hooke allowed some increase in the volume of watch production, although finishing and assembling was still done by hand until well into the 19th century.', u'A major cause of error in balance wheel timepieces, caused by changes in elasticity of the balance spring from temperature changes, was solved by the bimetallic temperature compensated balance wheel invented in 1765 by Pierre Le Roy and improved by Thomas Earnshaw.', u'The lever escapement was the single most important technological breakthrough, and was invented by Thomas Mudge in 1759 and improved by Josiah Emery in 1785, although it only gradually came into use from about 1800 onwards, chiefly in Britain.', u'The British had predominated in watch manufacture for much of the 17th and 18th centuries, but maintained a system of production that was geared towards high quality products for the elite.', u'Although there was an attempt to modernise clock manufacture with mass production techniques and the application of used interchangeable parts, and by 1861 it was running a successful enterprise incorporated as the Waltham Watch Company.', u'=== Wristwatch ===\n\nThe concept of the wristwatch goes back to the production of the very earliest watches in the 16th century.', u'Elizabeth I of England received a wristwatch from Robert Dudley in 1571, described as an arm watch.', u'The oldest surviving Wristwatch (then described as a bracelet watch) is one made in 1806 and given to Jos\xe9phine de Beauharnais.', u'From the beginning, wrist watches were almost exclusively worn by women, while men used pocket-watches up until the early 20th century.', u'Wristwatches were first worn by military men towards the end of the 19th century, when the importance of synchronizing manoeuvres during war, without potentially revealing the plan to the enemy through signalling, was increasingly recognized.', u"The Garstin Company of London patented a 'Watch Wristlet' design in 1893, but they were probably producing similar designs from the 1880s.", u'Officers in the British Army began using wristwatches during colonial military campaigns in the 1880s, such as during the Anglo-Burma War of 1885.', u'During the First Boer War, the importance of coordinating troop movements and synchronizing attacks against the highly mobile Boer insurgents became paramount, and the use of wristwatches
