improvement in watch technology.', u'In place of a balance wheel which oscillated at perhaps 5 or 6 beats per second, it used a quartz crystal resonator which vibrated at 8,192 Hz, driven by a battery-powered oscillator circuit.', u'Since the 1980s, more quartz watches than mechanical ones have been marketed.', u'== Movement ==\n\nA movement of a watch is the mechanism that measures the passage of time and displays the current time (and possibly other information including date, month and day).', u'Movements may be entirely mechanical, entirely electronic (potentially with no moving parts), or they might be a blend of both.', u'Most watches intended mainly for timekeeping today have electronic movements, with mechanical hands on the watch face indicating the time.', u'=== Mechanical ===\n\nCompared to electronic movements, mechanical watches are less accurate, often with errors of seconds per day, and they are sensitive to position, temperature and magnetism.', u'They are also costly to produce, require regular maintenance and adjustments, and are more prone to failures.', u'Nevertheless, the craftsmanship of mechanical watches still attracts interest from part of the watch-buying public, especially among the watch collectors.', u'Skeleton watches are designed to leave the mechanism visible for aesthetic purposes.', u'A mechanical movement uses an escapement mechanism to control and limit the unwinding and winding parts of a spring, converting what would otherwise be a simple unwinding into a controlled and periodic energy release.', u'A mechanical movement also uses a balance wheel together with the balance spring (also known as a hairspring) to control motion of the gear system of the watch in a manner analogous to the pendulum of a pendulum clock.', u'The tourbillon, an optional part for mechanical movements, is a rotating frame for the escapement, which is used to cancel out or reduce the effects of gravitational bias to the timekeeping.', u'Due to the complexity of designing a tourbillon, they are very expensive, and only found in prestigious watches.', u'The pin-lever escapement (called the Roskopf movement after its inventor, Georges Frederic Roskopf), which is a cheaper version of the fully levered movement, was manufactured in huge quantities by many Swiss manufacturers as well as by Timex, until it was replaced by quartz movements.', u'Tuning-fork watches use a type of electromechanical movement.', u'Introduced by Bulova in 1960, they use a tuning fork with a precise frequency (most often 360 hertz) to drive a mechanical watch.', u'The task of converting electronically pulsed fork vibration into rotary movements is done via two tiny jeweled fingers, called pawls.', u'Tuning-fork watches were rendered obsolete when electronic quartz watches were developed.', u'Quartz watches were cheaper to produce besides being more accurate.', u'Traditional mechanical watch movements use a spiral spring called a mainspring as a power source.', u'In manual watches the spring must be rewound periodically by the user by turning the watch crown.', u'Antique pocketwatches were wound by inserting a separate key into a hole in the back of the watch and turning it.', u'Most modern watches are designed to run 40 hours on a winding and thus must be wound daily, but some run for several days and a few have 192-hour mainsprings and are wound weekly.', u"==== Automatic watches ====\n\nA self-winding or automatic watch is one that rewinds the mainspring of a mechanical movement by the natural motions of the wearer's body.", u'The first self-winding mechanism was invented for pocket watches in 1770 by Abraham-Louis Perrelet, but the first "self-winding", or "automatic", wristwatch was the invention of a British watch repairer named John Harwood in 1923.', u'This type of watch winds itself without requiring any special action by the wearer.', u"It uses an eccentric weight, called a winding rotor, which rotates with the movement of the wearer's wrist.", u'The back-and-forth motion of the winding rotor couples to a ratchet to wind the mainspring automatically.', u"Self-winding watches usually can also be wound manually to keep them running when not worn or if the wearer's wrist motions are inadequate to keep the watch wound.", u'In April 2014 the Swatch Group launched the sistem51 wristwatch.', u'It has a purely mechanical movement consisting of only 51 parts, including a novel self-winding mechanism with a transparent oscillating weight.', u'So far, it is the only mechanical movement manufactured entirely on a fully automated assembly line.', u'The low parts count and the automated assembly make it an inexpensive mechanical Swiss watch, which can be considered a successor to Roskopf movements, although of higher quality.', u'=== Electronic ===\n\nElectronic movements, also known as quartz movements, have few or no moving parts, except a quartz crystal which is made to vibrate by the piezoelectric effect.', u'A varying electric voltage is applied to the crystal, which responds by changing its shape so, in combination with some electronic components, it functions as an oscillator.', u'It resonates at a specific highly stable frequency, which is used to accurately pace a timekeeping mechanism.', u'Most quartz movements are primarily electronic but are geared to drive mechanical hands on the face of the watch to provide a traditional analog display of the time, a feature most consumers still prefer.', u"In 1959 Seiko placed an order with Epson (a daughter company of Seiko and the 'brain' behind the quartz revolution) to start developing a quartz wristwatch.", u'The project was codenamed 59A.', u'By the 1964 Tokyo Summer Olympics, Seiko had a working prototype of a portable quartz watch which was used as the time measurements throughout the event.', u'The first prototypes of an electronic quartz wristwatch (not just portable quartz watches as the Seiko timekeeping devices at the Tokyo Olympics in 1964) were made by the CEH research laboratory in Neuch\xe2tel, Switzerland.', u'From 1965 through 1967 pioneering development work was done on a miniaturized 8192 Hz quartz oscillator, a thermo-compensation module and an inhouse-made, dedicated integrated circuit (unlike the hybrid circuits used in the later Seiko Astron wristwatch).', u'As a result, the BETA 1 prototype set new timekeeping performance records at the International Chronometric Competition held at the Observatory of Neuch\xe2tel in 1967.', u'In 1970, 18 manufacturers exhibited production versions of the beta 21 wristwatch, including the Omega Electroquartz as well as Patek Philippe, Rolex Oysterquartz and Piaget.', u"The first quartz watch to enter production was the Seiko 35 SQ Astron, which hit the shelves on 25 December 1969, swiftly followed by the Swiss Beta 21, and then a year later the prototype of one of the world's most accurate wristwatches to date: the Omega Marine Chronometer.", u'Since the technology having been developed by contributions from Japanese, American and Swiss, nobody could patent the whole movement of the quartz wristwatch, thus allowing other manufacturers to participate in the rapid growth and development of the quartz watch market.', u'This ended \u2014 in less than a decade \u2014 almost 100 years of dominance by the mechanical wristwatch legacy.', u'Modern quartz movements are produced in very large quantities, and even the cheapest wristwatches typically have quartz movements.', u"Whereas mechanical movements can typically be off by several seconds a day, an inexpensive quartz movement in a child's wristwatch may still be accurate to within half a second per day \u2014 ten times more accurate than a mechanical movement.", u'After a consolidation of the mechanical watch industry in Switzerland during the 1970s, mass production of quartz wristwatches took off under the leadership of the Swatch Group of companies, a Swiss conglomerate with vertical control of the production of Swiss watches and related products.', u'For quartz wristwatches, subsidiaries of Swatch manufacture watch batteries (Renata), oscillators (Oscilloquartz, now Micro Crystal AG) and integrated circuits (Ebauches Electronic SA, renamed EM Microelectronic-Marin).', u'The launch of the new SWATCH brand in 1983 was marked by bold new styling, design and marketing.', u"Today, the Swatch Group maintains its position as the world's largest watch company.", u"Seiko's efforts to combine the quartz and mechanical movements bore fruit after 20 years of research, leading to the introduction of the Seiko Spring Drive, first in a limited domestic market production in 1999 and to the world in September 2005.", u'The Spring Drive keeps time within quartz standards without the use of a battery, using a traditional mechanical gear train powered by a spring, without the need for a balance wheel either.', u'In 2010, Miyota (Citizen Watch) of Japan introduced a newly developed movement that uses 3 prongs quartz crystal that exclusively produce for Bulova to be used in the Precisionist or Accutron II line, a new type of quartz watch with ultra-high frequency (262.144 kHz) which is claimed to be accurate to +/- 10 seconds a year and has a smooth sweeping second hand rather than one that jumps each second.', u'Radio time signal watches are a type of electronic quartz watch which synchronizes (time transfers) its time with an external time source such as in atomic clocks, time signals from GPS navigation satellites, the German DCF77 signal in Europe, WWVB in the US, and others.', u'Movements of this type may \u2014 among others \u2014 synchronize the time of day and the date, the leap-year status, and the state of daylight saving time (on or off).', u'However, other than the radio receiver, these watches are normal quartz watches in all other aspects.', u'Electronic watches require electricity as a power source, and some mechanical movements and hybrid electronic-mechanical movements also require electricity.', u'Usually the electricity is provided by a replaceable battery.', u'The first use of electrical power in watches was as a substitute for the mainspring, to remove the need for winding.', u'The first electrically powered watch, the Hamilton Electric 500, was released in 1957 by the Hamilton Watch Company of Lancaster, Pennsylvania.', u'Watch batteries (strictly speaking cells, as a battery is composed of multiple cells) are specially designed for their purpose.', u'They are very small and provide tiny amounts of power continuously for very long periods (several years or more).', u'In most cases, replacing the battery requires a trip to a watch-repair shop or watch dealer; this is especially true for watches that are water-resistant, as special tools and procedures are required for the watch to remain water-resistant after battery replacement.', u'Silver-oxide and lithium batteries are popular today; mercury batteries, formerly quite common, are no longer used, for environmental reasons.', u'Cheap batteries may be alkaline, of the same size as silver-oxide cells but providing shorter life.', u'Rechargeable batteries are used in some solar-powered watches.', u'Some electronic watches are powered by the movement of the wearer.', u"For instance, Seiko's kinetic-powered quartz watches use the motion of the wearer's arm: turning a rotating weight which causes a tiny generator to supply power to charge a rechargeable battery that runs the watch.", u'The concept is similar to that of self-winding spring movements, except that electrical power is generated instead of mechanical spring tension.', u'Solar powered watches are powered by light.', u'A photovoltaic cell on the face (dial) of the watch converts light to electricity, which is used to charge a rechargeable battery or capacitor.', u'The movement of the watch draws its power from the rechargeable battery or capacitor.', u'As long as the watch is regularly exposed to fairly strong light (such as sunlight), it never needs battery replacement.', u'Some models need only a few minutes of sunlight to provide weeks of energy (as in the Citizen Eco-Drive).', u'Some of the early solar watches of the 1970s had innovative and unique designs to accommodate the array of solar cells needed to power them (Synchronar, Nepro, Sicura and some models by Cristalonic, Alba, Seiko and Citizen).', u'As the decades progressed and the efficiency of the solar cells increased while the power requirements of the movement and display decreased, solar watches began to be designed to look like other conventional watches.', u"A rarely used power source is the temperature difference between the wearer's arm and the surrounding environment (as applied in the Citizen Eco-Drive Thermo).", u'== Display ==\n\n\n=== Analog ===\n\nTraditionally, watches have displayed the time in analog form, with a numbered dial upon which are mounted at least a rotating hour hand and a longer, rotating minute hand.', u'Many watches also incorporate a third hand that shows the current second of the current minute.', u'Watches powered by quartz usually have a second hand that snaps every second to the next marker.', u'Watches powered by a mechanical movement appears to have a gliding second hand, although it is actually not gliding; the hand merely moves in smaller steps, typically 1/5 of a second, corresponding to the beat (half period) of the balance wheel.', u'In some escapements (for example the duplex escapement), the hand advances every two beats (full period) of the balance wheel, typically 1/2 second in those watches, or even every four beats (two periods, 1 second), in the double duplex escapement.', u'A truly gliding second hand is achieved with the tri-synchro regulator of Spring Drive watches.', u'All of the hands are normally mechanical, physically rotating on the dial, although a few watches have been produced with "hands" that are simulated by a liquid-crystal display.', u'Analog display of the time is nearly universal in watches sold as jewelry or collectibles, and in these watches, the range of different styles of hands, numbers, and other aspects of the analog dial is very broad.', u'In watches sold for timekeeping, analog display remains very popular, as many people find it easier to read than digital display; but in timekeeping watches the emphasis is on clarity and accurate reading of the time under all conditions (clearly marked digits, easily visible hands, large watch faces, etc.).', u'They are specifically designed for the left wrist with the stem (the knob used for changing the time) on the right side of the watch; this makes it easy to change the time without removing the watch from the wrist.', u'This is the case if one is right-handed and the watch is worn on the left wrist (as is traditionally done).', u'If one is left-handed and wears the watch on the right wrist, one has to remove the watch from the wrist to reset the time or to wind the watch.', u'Analog watches as well as clocks are often marketed showing a display time of approximately 1:50 or 10:10.', u"This creates a visually pleasing smile-like face on upper half of the watch, in addition to enclosing the manufacturer's name.", u'Digital wristwatch with a touch-sensitive face that vibrates to help the user to tell time eyes-free.', u'The bezel of the watch features raised bumps at each hour mark; after briefly touching the face of the watch, the wearer runs a finger around the bezel clockwise.', u'When the finger reaches the bump indicating the hour, the watch vibrates continuously, and when the finger reaches the bump indicating the minute, the watch vibrates intermittently.', u'Eone Timepieces, Washington D.C.-based company, launched its first tactile analog wristwatch, the "Bradley", on 11 July 2013 on the Kickstarter website.', u"The device is primarily designed for sight-impaired users, who can use the watch's two ball bearings to determine the time, but it is also suitable for general use.", u'The watch features raised marks at each hour and two moving, magnetically attached ball bearings.', u'One ball bearing, on the edge of the watch, indicates the hour, while the other, on the face, indicates the minute.', u'=== Digital ===\n\nA digital display simply shows the time as a number, e.g., 12:08 instead of a short hand pointing towards the number 12 and a long hand 8/60 of the way round the dial.', u'The digits are usually shown as a seven-segment display.', u'The first digital mechanical pocket watches appeared in the late 19th century.', u'In the 1920s, the first digital mechanical wristwatches appeared.', u'The first digital electronic watch, a Pulsar LED prototype in 1970, was developed jointly by Hamilton Watch Company and Electro-Data, founded by George H. Thiess.', u"John Bergey, the head of Hamilton's Pulsar division, said that he was inspired to make a digital timepiece by the then-futuristic digital clock that Hamilton themselves made for the 1968 science fiction film 2001: A Space Odyssey.", u'On 4 April 1972, the Pulsar was finally ready, made in 18-carat gold and sold for $2,100.', u'It had a red light-emitting diode (LED) display.', u'Digital LED watches were very expensive and out of reach to the common consumer until 1975, when Texas Instruments started to mass-produce LED watches inside a plastic case.', u'These watches, which first retailed for only $20, reduced to $10 in 1976, saw Pulsar lose $6 million and the Pulsar brand sold to Seiko.', u'An early LED watch that was rather problematic was The Black Watch made and sold by British company Sinclair Research in 1975.', u'This was only sold for a few years, as production problems and returned (faulty) product forced the company to cease production.', u'Most watches with LED displays required that the user press a button to see the time displayed for a few seconds, because LEDs used so much power that they could not be kept operating continuously.', u'Usually the LED display color would be red.', u'Watches with LED displays were popular for a few years, but soon the LED displays were superseded by liquid crystal displays (LCDs), which used less battery power and were much more convenient in use, with the display always visible and no need to push a button before seeing the time.', u'Only in darkness you had to press a button to light the display with a tiny light bulb, later illuminating LEDs.', u'The first LCD watch with a six-digit LCD was the 1973 Seiko 06LC, although various forms of early LCD watches with a four-digit display were marketed as early as 1972 including the 1972 Gruen Teletime LCD Watch, and the Cox Electronic Systems Quarza.', u'In Switzerland, Ebauches Electronic SA presented a prototype eight-digit LCD wristwatch showing time and date at the MUBA Fair, Basle, in March 1973, using a Twisted Nematic LCD manufactured by Brown, Boveri & Cie, Switzerland, which became the supplier of LCDs to Casio for the CASIOTRON watch in 1974.', u'A problem with Liquid Crystal Displays is that they use polarized light.', u'If, for example, the user is wearing polarized sunglasses, the watch may be difficult to read because the plane of polarization of the display is roughly perpendicular to that of the glasses.', u'If the light that illuminates the display is polarized, for example if it comes from a blue sky, the display may be difficult or impossible to read.', u'From the 1980s onward, digital watch technology vastly improved.', u'In 1982 Seiko produced the Seiko TV Watch  that had a television screen built in, and Casio produced a digital watch with a thermometer as well as another that could translate 1,500 Japanese words into English.', u'In 1985, Casio produced the CFX-400 scientific calculator watch.', u'In 1987 Casio produced a watch that could dial your telephone number and Citizen revealed one that would react to your voice.', u'In 1995 Timex released a watch which allowed the wearer to download and store data from a computer to their wrist.', u'Some watches, such as the Timex Datalink USB, feature dot matrix displays.', u'Since their apex during the late 1980s to mid-1990s high technology fad, digital watches have mostly become simpler, less expensive time pieces with little variety between models.', u'=== Illuminated ===\n\nMany watches have displays that are illuminated, so they can be used in darkness.', u'Various methods have been used to achieve this.', u'Mechanical watches often have luminous paint on their hands and hour marks.', u'In the mid-20th century, radioactive material was often incorporated in the paint, so it would continue to glow without any exposure to light.', u'Radium was often used but produced small amounts of radiation outside the watch that might have been hazardous.', u'Tritium was used as a replacement, since the radiation it produces has such low energy that it cannot penetrate a watch glass.', u'However, tritium is expensive \u2014 it has to be made in a nuclear reactor \u2014 and it has a half-life of only about 12 years so the paint remains luminous for only a few years.', u'Nowadays, tritium is used in specialized watches, e.g., for military purposes (See Tritium illumination).', u'For other purposes, luminous paint is sometimes used on analog displays, but no radioactive material is contained in it.', u'This means that the display glows soon after being exposed to light and quickly fades.', u'Watches that incorporate batteries often have electric illumination of their displays.', u'However, lights consume far more power than electronic watch movements.', u'To conserve the battery, the light is activated only when the user presses a button.', u'Usually, the light remains lit for a few seconds after the button is released, which allows the user to move the hand out of the way.', u'In some early digital watches, LED displays were used, which could be read as easily in darkness as in daylight.', u'The user had to press a button to light up the LEDs, which meant that the watch could not be read without the button being pressed, even in full daylight.', u'In some cheaper types of watches, small incandescent lamps or LEDs illuminate the display, which is not intrinsically luminous.', u'These tend to produce very non-uniform illumination.', u'Incandescent lamps are very wasteful of electricity.', u'Other watches use electroluminescent material to produce uniform illumination of the background of the display, against which the hands or digits can be seen.', u'== Speech synthesis ==\nTalking watches are available, intended for the blind or visually impaired.', u'They speak the time out loud at the press of a button.', u'This has the disadvantage of disturbing others nearby, or at least alerting the non-deaf that the wearer is checking the time.', u'Tactile watches are preferred to avoid this awkwardness, but talking watches are preferred for those who are not confident in their ability to read a tactile watch reliably.', u'== Handedness ==\nWristwatches with analog displays generally have a small knob, called the crown, that can be used to adjust the time and, in mechanical watches, wind the spring.', u'Almost always, the crown is located on the right-hand side of the watch.', u'This makes it inconvenient to use if the watch is being worn on the right wrist.', u'In exceptional cases, the crown is on the left side of the watch.', u'This is, for example, to prevent it from digging into the wrists of golf players.', u'Digital watches generally have push-buttons that can be used to make adjustments.', u'These are usually equally easy to use on either wrist.', u'== Functions ==\n\nAll watches provide the time of day, giving at least the hour and minute, and usually the second.', u'Most also provide the current date, and often the day of the week as well.', u'However, many watches also provide a great deal of information beyond the basics of time and date.', u'Some watches include alarms.', u'Other elaborate and more expensive watches, both pocket and wrist models, also incorporate striking mechanisms or repeater functions, so that the wearer could learn the time by the sound emanating from the watch.', u'This announcement or striking feature is an essential characteristic of true clocks and distinguishes such watches from ordinary timepieces.', u'This feature is available on most digital watches.', u'A complicated watch has one or more functions beyond the basic function of displaying the time and the date; such a functionality is called a complication.', u'Two popular complications are the chronograph complication, which is the ability of the watch movement to function as a stopwatch, and the moonphase complication, which is a display of the lunar phase.', u'Other more expensive complications include Tourbillon, Perpetual calendar, Minute repeater, and Equation of time.', u'A truly complicated watch has many of these complications at once (see Calibre 89 from Patek Philippe for instance).', u'Some watches can both indicate the direction of Mecca and have alarms that can be set for all daily prayer requirements.', u'Among watch enthusiasts, complicated watches are especially collectible.', u'Some watches include a second 12-hour or 24-hour display for UTC or GMT.', u'The similar-sounding terms chronograph and chronometer are often confused, although they mean altogether different things.', u'A chronograph is a watch with an added duration timer, often a stopwatch complication (as explained above), while a chronometer watch is a timepiece that has met an industry standard test for performance under pre-defined conditions: a chronometer is a high quality mechanical or a thermo-compensated movement that has been tested and certified to operate within a certain standard of accuracy by the COSC (Contr\xf4le Officiel Suisse des Chronom\xe8tres).', u'The concepts are different but not mutually exclusive; so a watch can be a chronograph, a chronometer, both, or neither.', u'Many computerized wristwatches have been developed, but none have had long-term sales success, because they have awkward user interfaces due to the tiny screens and buttons, and a short battery life.', u'As miniaturized electronics became cheaper, watches have been developed containing calculators, tonometers, barometers, altimeters, a compass using both hands to show the N/S direction, video games, digital cameras, keydrives, GPS receivers and cellular phones.', u'A few astronomical watches show phase of the Moon and other celestial phenomena.', u'In the early 1980s Seiko marketed a watch with a television in it.', u'Such watches have also had the reputation as unsightly and thus mainly geek toys.', u'Several companies have however attempted to develop a computer contained in a wristwatch (see also wearable computer).', u'Electronic sports watches, combining timekeeping with GPS and/or activity tracking, address the general fitness market and have the potential for commercial success (Garmin forerunner, Garmin Vivofit, Epson, announced model of Swatch Touch series).', u'Braille watches have analog displays with raised bumps around the face to allow blind users to tell the time.', u'Their digital equivalents use synthesised speech to speak the time on command.', u'=== Fashion ===\nWristwatches and antique pocket watches are often appreciated as jewelry or as collectible works of art rather than just as timepieces.', u'This has created several different markets for wristwatches, ranging from very inexpensive but accurate watches (intended for no other purpose than telling the correct time) to extremely expensive watches that serve mainly as personal adornment or as examples of high achievement in miniaturization and precision mechanical engineering.', u"Traditionally, men's dress watches appropriate for informal (business), semi-formal, and formal attire are gold, thin, simple, and plain, but increasingly rugged, complicated, or sports watches are considered by some to be acceptable for such attire.", u"Some dress watches have a cabochon on the crown and many women's dress watches have faceted gemstones on the face, bezel, or bracelet.", u'Some are made entirely of faceted sapphire (corundum).', u'Many fashion and department stores offer a variety of less-expensive, trendy, "costume" watches (usually for women), many of which are similar in quality to basic quartz timepieces but which feature bolder designs.', u'In the 1980s, the Swiss Swatch company hired graphic designers to redesign a new annual collection of non-repairable watches.', u'Trade in counterfeit watches, which mimic expensive brand-name watches, constitutes an estimated US$1 billion market per year.', u'=== Space ===\n\nThe zero-gravity environment and other extreme conditions encountered by astronauts in space require the use of specially tested watches.', u'The first ever watch to be sent into space was a Russian "Pobeda" watch from the Petrodvorets Watch Factory.', u'It was sent on a single orbit flight on the space ship Korabl-Sputnik 4 on March 9, 1961.', u"The watch had been attached without authorisation to the wrist of Chernuchka, a dog that successfully did exactly the same trip as Yuri Gagarin, with exactly the same rocket and equipment, just a month before Gagarin's flight.", u'On 12 April 1961, Yuri Gagarin wore a Shturmanskie (a transliteration of \u0428\u0442\u0443\u0440\u043c\u0430\u043d\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0435 which actually means "navigator\'s") wristwatch during his historic first flight into space.', u'The Shturmanskie was manufactured at the First Moscow Factory.', u'Since 1964, the watches of the First Moscow Factory have been marked by the trademark "\u041f\u043e\u043b\u0451\u0442", transliterated as "POLJOT", which means "flight" in Russian and is a tribute to the many space trips its watches have accomplished.', u'In the late 1970s, Poljot launched a new chrono movement, the 3133.', u'With a 23 jewel movement and manual winding (43 hours), it was a modified Russian version of the Swiss Valjoux 7734 of the early 1970s.', u'Poljot 3133 were taken into space by astronauts from Russia, France, Germany and Ukraine.', u'On the arm of Valeriy Polyakov, a Poljot 3133 chronograph movement-based watch set a space record for the longest space flight in history.', u'Through the 1960s, a large range of watches were tested for durability and precision under extreme temperature changes and vibrations.', u'The Omega Speedmaster Professional was selected by NASA, the U.S. space agency.', u'Heuer became the first Swiss watch in space thanks to a Heuer Stopwatch, worn by John Glenn in 1962 when he piloted the Friendship 7 on the first manned U.S. orbital mission.', u'The Breitling Navitimer Cosmonaute was designed with a 24-hour analog dial to avoid confusion between AM and PM, which are meaningless in space.', u'It was first worn in space by U.S. astronaut Scott Carpenter on 24 May 1962 in the Aurora 7 mercury capsule.', u'Since 1994 Fortis is the exclusive supplier for manned space missions authorized by the Russian Federal Space Agency.', u'China National Space Administration (CNSA) astronauts wear the Fiyta spacewatches.', u'At BaselWorld, 2008, Seiko announced the creation of the first watch ever designed specifically for a space walk, Spring Drive Spacewalk.', u'Timex Datalink is flight certified by NASA for space missions and is one of the watches qualified by NASA for space travel.', u'The Casio G-Shock DW-5600C and 5600E, DW 6900, and DW 5900 are Flight-Qualified for NASA space travel.', u'Various Timex Datalink models were used both by cosmonauts and astronauts.', u'=== Scuba diving ===\n\nWatches may be crafted to become water resistant.', u'These watches are sometimes called diving watches when they are suitable for scuba diving or saturation diving.', u'The International Organization for Standardization issued a standard for water resistant watches which also prohibits the term "waterproof" to be used with watches, which many countries have adopted.', u'Water resistance is achieved by the gaskets which forms a watertight seal, used in conjunction with a sealant applied on the case to help keep water out.', u'The material of the case must also be tested in order to pass as water resistant.', u'None of the tests defined by ISO 2281 for the Water Resistant mark are suitable to qualify a watch for scuba diving.', u'Such watches are designed for everyday life and must be water resistant during exercises such as swimming.', u'They can be worn in different temperature and pressure conditions but are under no circumstances designed for scuba diving.', u'The standards for diving watches are regulated by the ISO 6425 international standard.', u'The watches are tested in static or still water under 125% of the rated (water)pressure, thus a watch with a 200-metre rating will be water resistant if it is stationary and under 250 metres of static water.', u'The testing of the water resistance is fundamentally different from non-dive watches, because every watch has to be fully tested.', u"Besides water resistance standards to a minimum of 100 metre depth rating ISO 6425 also provides eight minimum requirements for mechanical diver's watches for scuba diving (quartz and digital watches have slightly differing readability requirements).", u"For diver's watches for mixed-gas saturation diving two additional requirements have to be met.", u'Watches are classified by their degree of water resistance, which roughly translates to the following (1 metre = 3.281 feet):\nSome watches use bar instead of meters, which may then be multiplied by 10, and then subtract 10 to be approximately equal to the rating based on metres.', u'Therefore, a 5 bar watch is equivalent to a 40-metre watch.', u'Some watches are rated in atmospheres (atm), which are roughly equivalent to bar.', u'=== Navigation ===\n\nThere is a traditional method by which an analog watch can be used to locate north and south.', u'The Sun appears to move in the sky over a 24-hour period while the hour hand of a 12-hour clock face takes twelve hours to complete one rotation.', u"In the northern hemisphere, if the watch is rotated so that the hour hand points toward the Sun, the point halfway between the hour hand and 12 o'clock will indicate south.", u"For this method to work in the southern hemisphere, the 12 is pointed toward the Sun and the point halfway between the hour hand and 12 o'clock will indicate north.", u"During daylight saving time, the same method can be employed using 1 o'clock instead of 12.", u'This method is accurate enough to be useful only at fairly high latitudes.', u'== See also ==\nAmerican Watchmakers-Clockmakers Institute\nCoin watch\nList of watch manufacturers\nMarine chronometer\nNational Association of Watch and Clock Collectors\nTachymeter (watch)\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== Further reading ==\nBeckett, Edmund, A Rudimentary Treatise on Clocks, Watches and Bells, 1903, from Project Gutenberg\nBerner, G.A., {'sentences': [u'A treaty is an agreement under international law entered into by actors in international law, namely sovereign states and international organizations.', u'A treaty may also be known as an (international) agreement, protocol, covenant, convention, pact, or exchange of letters, among other terms.', u'Regardless of terminology, all of these forms of agreements are, under international law, equally considered treaties and the rules are the same.', u'Treaties can be loosely compared to contracts: both are means of willing parties assuming obligations among themselves, and a party to either that fails to live up to their obligations can be held liable under international law.', u'== Modern usage ==\nA treaty is an official, express written agreement that states use to legally bind themselves.', u'A treaty is the official document which expresses that agreement in words; and it is also the objective outcome of a ceremonial occasion which acknowledges the parties and their defined relationships.', u'== Modern form ==\nSince the late 19th century, most treaties have followed a fairly consistent format.', u'A treaty typically begins with a preamble describing the contracting parties and their joint objectives in executing the treaty, as well as summarizing any underlying events (such as a war).', u'Modern preambles are sometimes structured as a single very long sentence formatted into multiple paragraphs for readability, in which each of the paragraphs begins with a verb (desiring, recognizing, having, and so on).', u"The contracting parties' full names or sovereign titles are often included in the preamble, along with the full names and titles of their representatives, and a boilerplate clause about how their representatives have communicated (or exchanged) their full powers (i.e., the official documents appointing them to act on behalf of their respective states) and found them in good or proper form.", u'The end of the preamble and the start of the actual agreement is often signaled by the words "have agreed as follows."', u"After the preamble comes numbered articles, which contain the substance of the parties' actual agreement.", u'Each article heading usually encompasses a paragraph.', u'A long treaty may further group articles under chapter headings.', u'Modern treaties, regardless of subject matter, usually contain articles governing where the final authentic copies of the treaty will be deposited and how any subsequent disputes as to their interpretation will be peacefully resolved.', u'The end of a treaty, the eschatocol (or closing protocol), is often signaled by a clause like "in witness whereof" or "in faith whereof," the parties have affixed their signatures, followed by the words "DONE at," then the site(s) of the treaty\'s execution and the date(s) of its execution.', u'The date is typically written in its most formal, longest possible form.', u'For example, the Charter of the United Nations was "DONE at the city of San Francisco the twenty-sixth day of June, one thousand nine hundred and forty-five."', u'If the treaty is executed in multiple copies in different languages, that fact is always noted, and is followed by a stipulation that the versions in different languages are equally authentic.', u"The signatures of the parties' representatives follow at the very end.", u'When the text of a treaty is later reprinted, such as in a collection of treaties currently in effect, an editor will often append the dates on which the respective parties ratified the treaty and on which it came into effect for each party.', u'== Bilateral and Multilateral Treaties ==\nBilateral treaties are concluded between two states or entities.', u'It is possible, however, for a bilateral treaty to have more than two parties; consider for instance the bilateral treaties between Switzerland and the European Union (EU) following the Swiss rejection of the European Economic Area agreement.', u'Each of these treaties has seventeen parties.', u'These however are still bilateral, not multilateral, treaties.', u'The parties are divided into two groups, the Swiss ("on the one part") and the EU and its member states ("on the other part").', u'The treaty establishes rights and obligations between the Swiss and the EU and the member states severally\u2014it does not establish any rights and obligations amongst the EU and its member states.', u'A multilateral treaty is concluded among several countries.', u'The agreement establishes rights and obligations between each party and every other party.', u'Multilateral treaties are often regional.', u'Treaties of "mutual guarantee" are international compacts, e.g., the Treaty of Locarno which guarantees each signatory against attack from another.', u"== Adding and amending treaty obligations ==\n\n\n=== Reservations ===\n\nReservations are essentially caveats to a state's acceptance of a treaty.", u'Reservations are unilateral statements purporting to exclude or to modify the legal obligation and its effects on the reserving state.', u'These must be included at the time of signing or ratification, i.e.', u'"a party cannot add a reservation after it has already joined a treaty".', u'Originally, international law was unaccepting of treaty reservations, rejecting them unless all parties to the treaty accepted the same reservations.', u'However, in the interest of encouraging the largest number of states to join treaties, a more permissive rule regarding reservations has emerged.', u'While some treaties still expressly forbid any reservations, they are now generally permitted to the extent that they are not inconsistent with the goals and purposes of the treaty.', u'When a state limits its treaty obligations through reservations, other states party to that treaty have the option to accept those reservations, object to them, or object and oppose them.', u"If the state accepts them (or fails to act at all), both the reserving state and the accepting state are relieved of the reserved legal obligation as concerns their legal obligations to each other (accepting the reservation does not change the accepting state's legal obligations as concerns other parties to the treaty).", u'If the state opposes, the parts of the treaty affected by the reservation drop out completely and no longer create any legal obligations on the reserving and accepting state, again only as concerns each other.', u'Finally, if the state objects and opposes, there are no legal obligations under that treaty between those two state parties whatsoever.', u'The objecting and opposing state essentially refuses to acknowledge the reserving state is a party to the treaty at all.', u'=== Amendments ===\nThere are three ways an existing treaty can be amended.', u'First, formal amendment requires State parties to the treaty to go through the ratification process all over again.', u'The re-negotiation of treaty provisions can be long and protracted, and often some parties to the original treaty will not become parties to the amended treaty.', u'When determining the legal obligations of states, one party to the original treaty and one a party to the amended treaty, the states will only be bound by the terms they both agreed upon.', u'Treaties can also be amended informally by the treaty executive council when the changes are only procedural, technical change in customary international law can also amend a treaty, where state behavior evinces a new interpretation of the legal obligations under the treaty.', u'Minor corrections to a treaty may be adopted by a proc\xe8s-verbal; but a proc\xe8s-verbal is generally reserved for changes to rectify obvious errors in the text adopted, i.e.', u'where the text adopted does not correctly reflect the intention of the parties adopting it.', u'=== Protocols ===\n\nIn international law and international relations, a protocol is generally a treaty or international agreement that supplements a previous treaty or international agreement.', u'A protocol can amend the previous treaty, or add additional provisions.', u'Parties to the earlier agreement are not required to adopt the protocol.', u'Sometimes this is made clearer by calling it an "optional protocol", especially where many parties to the first agreement do not support the protocol.', u'Some examples: the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) established a framework for the development of binding greenhouse gas emission limits, while the Kyoto Protocol contained the specific provisions and regulations later agreed upon.', u"== Execution and implementation ==\nTreaties may be seen as 'self-executing', in that merely becoming a party puts the treaty and all of its obligations in action.", u"Other treaties may be non-self-executing and require 'implementing legislation'\u2014a change in the domestic law of a state party that will direct or enable it to fulfill treaty obligations.", u'An example of a treaty requiring such legislation would be one mandating local prosecution by a party for particular crimes.', u'The division between the two is often not clear and is often politicized in disagreements within a government over a treaty, since a non-self-executing treaty cannot be acted on without the proper change in domestic law.', u'If a treaty requires implementing legislation, a state may be in default of its obligations by the failure of its legislature to pass the necessary domestic laws.', u'=== Interpretation ===\nThe language of treaties, like that of any law or contract, must be interpreted when the wording does not seem clear or it is not immediately apparent how it should be applied in a perhaps unforeseen circumstance.', u'The Vienna Convention states that treaties are to be interpreted "in good faith" according to the "ordinary meaning given to the terms of the treaty in their context and in the light of its object and purpose."', u"International legal experts also often invoke the 'principle of maximum effectiveness,' which interprets treaty language as having the fullest force and effect possible to establish obligations between the parties.", u'No one party to a treaty can impose its particular interpretation of the treaty upon the other parties.', u'Consent may be implied, however, if the other parties fail to explicitly disavow that initially unilateral interpretation, particularly if that state has acted upon its view of the treaty without complaint.', u"Consent by all parties to the treaty to a particular interpretation has the legal effect of adding another clause to the treaty \u2013 this is commonly called an 'authentic interpretation'.", u'International tribunals and arbiters are often called upon to resolve substantial disputes over treaty interpretations.', u'To establish the meaning in context, these judicial bodies may review the preparatory work from the negotiation and drafting of the treaty as well as the final, signed treaty itself.', u'=== Consequences of terminology ===\nOne significant part of treaty making is that signing a treaty implies recognition that the other side is a sovereign state and that the agreement being considered is enforceable under international law.', u'Hence, nations can be very careful about terming an agreement to be a treaty.', u'For example, within the United States, agreements between states are compacts and agreements between states and the federal government or between agencies of the government are memoranda of understanding.', u'Another situation can occur when one party wishes to create an obligation under international law, but the other party does not.', u'This factor has been at work with respect to discussions between North Korea and the United States over security guarantees and nuclear proliferation.', u'The terminology can also be confusing because a treaty may and usually is named something other than a treaty, such as a convention, protocol, or simply agreement.', u'Conversely some legal documents such as the Treaty of Waitangi are internationally considered to be documents under domestic law.', u'== Ending treaty obligations ==\n\n\n=== Withdrawal ===\nTreaties are not necessarily permanently binding upon the signatory parties.', u'As obligations in international law are traditionally viewed as arising only from the consent of states, many treaties expressly allow a state to withdraw as long as it follows certain procedures of notification.', u'For example, the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs provides that the treaty will terminate if, as a result of denunciations, the number of parties falls below 40.', u'Many treaties expressly forbid withdrawal.', u'Article 56 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties provides that where a treaty is silent over whether or not it can be denounced there is a rebuttable presumption that it cannot be unilaterally denounced unless:\nit can be shown that the parties intended to admit the possibility, or\na right of withdrawal can be inferred from the terms of the treaty.', u'The possibility of withdrawal depends on the terms of the treaty and its travaux preparatoire.', u'It has, for example, been held that it is not possible to withdraw from the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.', u'When North Korea declared its intention to do this the Secretary-General of the United Nations, acting as registrar, said that original signatories of the ICCPR had not overlooked the possibility of explicitly providing for withdrawal, but rather had deliberately intended not to provide for it.', u'Consequently, withdrawal was not possible.', u'In practice, because of sovereignty, any state can purport to withdraw from any treaty at any time, and cease to abide by its terms.', u'The question of whether this is lawful can be regarded as the success or failure to anticipate community acquiescence or enforcement, that is, how other states will react; for instance, another state might impose sanctions or go to war over a treaty violation.', u"If a state party's withdrawal is successful, its obligations under that treaty are considered terminated, and withdrawal by one party from a bilateral treaty of course terminates the treaty.", u'When a state withdraws from a multi-lateral treaty, that treaty will still otherwise remain in force among the other parties, unless, of course, otherwise should or could be interpreted as agreed upon between the remaining states parties to the treaty.', u'=== Suspension and termination ===\nIf a party has materially violated or breached its treaty obligations, the other parties may invoke this breach as grounds for temporarily suspending their obligations to that party under the treaty.', u'A material breach may also be invoked as grounds for permanently terminating the treaty itself.', u'A treaty breach does not automatically suspend or terminate treaty relations, however.', u'It depends on how the other parties regard the breach and how they resolve to respond to it.', u'Sometimes treaties will provide for the seriousness of a breach to be determined by a tribunal or other independent arbiter.', u"An advantage of such an arbiter is that it prevents a party from prematurely and perhaps wrongfully suspending or terminating its own obligations due to another's alleged material breach.", u'Treaties sometimes include provisions for self-termination, meaning that the treaty is automatically terminated if certain defined conditions are met.', u'Some treaties are intended by the parties to be only temporarily binding and are set to expire on a given date.', u'Other treaties may self-terminate if the treaty is meant to exist only under certain conditions.', u'A party may claim that a treaty should be terminated, even absent an express provision, if there has been a fundamental change in circumstances.', u'Such a change is sufficient if unforeseen, if it undermined the \u201cessential basis\u201d of consent by a party, if it radically transforms the extent of obligations between the parties, and if the obligations are still to be performed.', u'A party cannot base this claim on change brought about by its own breach of the treaty.', u'This claim also cannot be used to invalidate treaties that established or redrew political boundaries.', u'== Invalid treaties ==\nThere are several reasons an otherwise valid and agreed upon treaty may be rejected as a binding international agreement, most of which involve problems created at the formation of the treaty.', u'For example, the serial Japan-Korea treaties of 1905, 1907 and 1910 were protested; and they were confirmed as "already null and void" in the 1965 Treaty on Basic Relations between Japan and the Republic of Korea.', u"=== Ultra vires treaties ===\nA party's consent to a treaty is invalid if it had been given by an agent or body without power to do so under that state's domestic law.", u'States are reluctant to inquire into the internal affairs and processes of other states, and so a "manifest violation" is required such that it would be "objectively evident to any State dealing with the matter".', u'A strong presumption exists internationally that a head of state has acted within his proper authority.', u'It seems that no treaty has ever actually been invalidated on this provision.', u'Consent is also invalid if it is given by a representative who ignored restrictions he is subject to by his sovereign during the negotiations, if the other parties to the treaty were notified of those restrictions prior to his signing.', u'According to the preamble in The Law of Treaties, treaties are a source of international law.', u'If an act or lack thereof is condemned under international law, the act will not assume international legality even if approved by internal law.', u'This means that in case of a conflict with domestic law, international law will always prevail.', u'=== Misunderstanding, fraud, corruption, coercion ===\nArticles 46\u201353 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties set out the only ways that treaties can be invalidated\u2014considered unenforceable and void under international law.', u'A treaty will be invalidated due to either the circumstances by which a state party joined the treaty, or due to the content of the treaty itself.', u'Invalidation is separate from withdrawal, suspension, or termination (addressed above), which all involve an alteration in the consent of the parties of a previously valid treaty rather than the invalidation of that consent in the first place.', u'A state\'s consent may be invalidated if there was an erroneous understanding of a fact or situation at the time of conclusion, which formed the "essential basis" of the state\'s consent.', u"Consent will not be invalidated if the misunderstanding was due to the state's own conduct, or if the truth should have been evident.", u'Consent will also be invalidated if it was induced by the fraudulent conduct of another party, or by the direct or indirect "corruption" of its representative by another party to the treaty.', u'Coercion of either a representative, or the state itself through the threat or use of force, if used to obtain the consent of that state to a treaty, will invalidate that consent.', u'=== Contrary to peremptory norms ===\nA treaty is null and void if it is in violation of a peremptory norm.', u'These norms, unlike other principles of customary law, are recognized as permitting no violations and so cannot be altered through treaty obligations.', u'These are limited to such universally accepted prohibitions as those against the aggressive use of force, genocide and other crimes against humanity, piracy, hostilities directed at civilian population, racial discrimination and apartheid, slavery and torture, meaning that no state can legally assume an obligation to commit or permit such acts.', u'== Role of the United Nations ==\nThe United Nations Charter states that treaties must be registered with the UN to be invoked before it or enforced in its judiciary organ, the International Court of Justice.', u'This was done to prevent the proliferation of secret treaties that occurred in the 19th and 20th century.', u"Section 103 of the Charter also states that its members' obligations under it outweigh any competing obligations under other treaties.", u'After their adoption, treaties as well as their amendments have to follow the official legal procedures of the United Nations, as applied by the Office of Legal Affairs, including signature, ratification and entry into force.', u'In function and effectiveness, the UN has been compared to the pre-Constitutional United States Federal government by some, giving a comparison between modern treaty law and the historical Articles of Confederation.', u'== Relation between national law and treaties by country ==\n\n\n=== Brazilian law ===\nThe Brazilian federal constitution states that the power to enter into treaties is vested in the president and that such treaties must be approved by Congress (articles 84, clause VIII, and 49, clause I).', u'In practice, this has been interpreted as meaning that the executive branch is free to negotiate and sign a treaty, but its ratification by the president is contingent upon the prior approval of Congress.', u'Additionally, the Federal Supreme Court has ruled that, following ratification and entry into force, a treaty must be incorporated into domestic law by means of a presidential decree published in the federal register in order to be valid in Brazil and applicable by the Brazilian authorities.', u'The Federal Supreme Court has established that treaties are subject to constitutional review and enjoy the same hierarchical position as ordinary legislation (leis ordin\xe1rias, or "ordinary laws", in Portuguese).', u'A more recent ruling by the Supreme Court in 2008 has altered that scheme somewhat, by stating that treaties containing human rights provisions enjoy a status above that of ordinary legislation, though they remain beneath the constitution itself.', u'Additionally, as per the 45th amendment to the constitution, human rights treaties which are approved by Congress by means of a special procedure enjoy the same hierarchical position as a constitutional amendment.', u'The hierarchical position of treaties in relation to domestic legislation is of relevance to the discussion on whether (and how) the latter can abrogate the former and vice versa.', u'The Brazilian federal constitution does not have a supremacy clause with the same effects as the one on the U.S. constitution, a fact that is of interest to the discussion on the relation between treaties and state legislation.', u'=== United States law ===\n\nIn the United States, the term "treaty" has a different, more restricted legal sense than exists in international law.', u'United States law distinguishes what it calls treaties from executive agreement, congressional-executive agreements, and sole executive agreements.', u'All four classes are equally treaties under international law; they are distinct only from the perspective of internal American law.', u'The distinctions are primarily concerning their method of approval.', u'Whereas treaties require advice and consent by two-thirds of the Senators present, sole executive agreements may be executed by the President acting alone.', u'Some treaties grant the President the authority to fill in the gaps with executive agreements, rather than additional treaties or protocols.', u'And finally, congressional-executive agreements require majority approval by both the House and the Senate, either before or after the treaty is signed by the President.', u'Currently, international agreements are executed by executive agreement rather than treaties at a rate of 10:1.', u'Despite the relative ease of executive agreements, the President still often chooses to pursue the formal treaty process over an executive agreement in order to gain congressional support on matters that require the Congress to pass implementing legislation or appropriate funds, and those agreements that impose long-term, complex legal obligations on the United States.', u'For example, the deal by the United States, Iran and other countries is not a Treaty.', u'See the article on the Bricker Amendment for history of the relationship between treaty powers and Constitutional provisions.', u'The Supreme Court ruled in the Head Money Cases that "treaties" do not have a privileged position over Acts of Congress and can be repealed or modified (for the purposes of U.S. law) by any subsequent Act of Congress, just like with any other regular law.', u'The Supreme Court also ruled in Reid v. Covert that any treaty provision that conflicts with the Constitution are null and void under U.S. law.', u'=== Indian law ===\nIn India, the legislation subjects are divided into 3 lists -Union List, State List and Concurrent List .', u'In the normal legislation process, the subjects in Union list can only be legislated upon by central legislative body called Parliament of India, for subjects in state list only respective state legislature can legislate.', u'While for Concurrent subjects, both center and state can make laws.', u'But to implement international treaties, Parliament can legislate on any subject overriding the general division of subject lists.', u'== Treaties and indigenous peoples ==\nTreaties formed an important part of European colonization and, in many parts of the world, Europeans attempted to legitimize their sovereignty by signing treaties with indigenous peoples.', u'In most cases these treaties were in extremely disadvantageous terms to the native people, who often did not appreciate the implications of what they were signing.', u'In some rare cases, such as with Ethiopia and Qing Dynasty China, the local governments were able to use the treaties to at least mitigate the impact of European colonization.', u'This involved learning the intricacies of European diplomatic customs and then using the treaties to prevent a power from overstepping their agreement or by playing different powers against each other.', u'In other cases, such as New Zealand and Canada, treaties allowed native peoples to maintain a minimum amount of autonomy.', u'In the case of indigenous Australians, unlike with the M\u0101ori of New Zealand, no treaty was ever entered into with the indigenous peoples entitling the Europeans to land ownership, under the doctrine of terra nullius (later overturned by Mabo v Queensland, establishing the concept of native title well after colonization was already a fait accompli).', u'Such treaties between colonizers and indigenous peoples are an important part of political discourse in the late 20th and early 21st century, the treaties being discussed have international standing as has been stated in a treaty study by the UN.', u'Prior to 1871, the government of the United States regularly entered into treaties with Native Americans but the Indian Appropriations Act of March 3, 1871 (ch.', u'120, 16 Stat.', u'563) had a rider (25 U.S.C.', u'\xa7 71) attached that effectively ended the President\u2019s treaty making by providing that no Indian nation or tribe shall be acknowledged as an independent nation, tribe, or power with whom the United States may contract by treaty.', u'The federal government continued to provide similar contractual relations with the Indian tribes after 1871 by agreements, statutes, and executive orders.', u'== See also ==\nPeace treaty\nJus tractatuum\nList of intergovernmental organizations\nList of treaties\nManrent (feudal Scottish Clan treaty)\nTreaty ratification\nVienna Convention on the Law of Treaties\n\n\n== Notes ==\n\n\n== References ==\nKorean Mission to the Conference on the Limitation of Armament, Washington, D.C., 1921\u20131922.', u'(1922).', u"Korea's Appeal to the Conference on Limitation of Armament.", u'Washington: U.S. Government Printing Office.', u'OCLC 12923609\nNicolson, Harold.', u'(1936).', u'Diplomacy, 1st ed.', u'Oxford: Oxford University Press.', u'OCLC 502863836\nShaw, Malcolm Nathan.', u'(1977).', u'International Law, 1st ed.', u'Sevenoaks, Kent: Hodder and Stoughton.', u'OCLC 637940121\nTimothy L. Meyer, "From Contract to Legislation: The Logic of Modern International Lawmaking" 14 Chicago Journal of International Law 559 (2014), available at http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2378870.', u'Seah, Daniel.', u'"Problems Concerning the International Law-Making Practice of ASEAN: A Reply to Chen Zhida" Asian Journal of International Law (2015)\n\n\n== External links ==\nTreaties and Selected other International Instruments \u2013 Resources\nUnited Nations Treaty Collection\nProcedural history and related documents on The Guide to Practice on Reservations to Treaties in the Historic Archives of the United Nations Audiovisual Library of International Law\nProcedural history and related documents on the Articles on the Effects of Armed Conflicts on Treaties in the Historic Archives of the United Nations Audiovisual Library of International Law\nISEA International Energy Treaties\nTreaties from UCB Libraries GovPubs\nResource Guide on Treaties from the American Society of International Law\nTreaty Affairs at the United States Department of State\nTreaties Office at the European Union\nPeace Palace Library - Research Guide'], 'year': '1795-10-27', 'title': 'Treaty of San Lorenzo provides free navigation of Mississippi'}
{'sentences': [u'A rocket engine is a type of jet engine that uses only stored rocket propellant mass for forming its high speed propulsive jet.', u"Rocket engines are reaction engines, obtaining thrust in accordance with Newton's third law.", u'Most rocket engines are internal combustion engines, although non-combusting forms (such as cold gas thrusters) also exist.', u'Vehicles propelled by rocket engines are commonly called rockets.', u'Since they need no external material to form their jet, rocket engines can perform in a vacuum and thus can be used to propel spacecraft and ballistic missiles.', u'Compared to other types of jet engines, rocket engines have the highest thrust, are by far the lightest, but are the least propellant efficient (have the lowest specific impulse).', u'The ideal exhaust is hydrogen, the lightest of all gases, but chemical rockets produce a mix of heavier species, reducing the exhaust velocity.', u'Rocket engines become more efficient at high velocities (due to greater propulsive efficiency and Oberth effect).', u'Since they do not require an atmosphere, they are well suited for uses at very high altitude and in space.', u'== Terminology ==\nHere, "rocket" is used as an abbreviation for "rocket engine".', u'Chemical rockets are powered by exothermic chemical reactions of the propellant.', u'Thermal rockets use an inert propellant, heated by a power source such as electric or nuclear power.', u'Solid-fuel rockets (or solid-propellant rockets or motors) are chemical rockets which use propellant in a solid state.', u'Liquid-propellant rockets use one or more liquid propellants fed from tanks.', u'Hybrid rockets use a solid propellant in the combustion chamber, to which a second liquid or gas oxidiser or propellant is added to permit combustion.', u'Monopropellant rockets use a single propellant decomposed by a catalyst.', u'The most common monopropellants are hydrazine and hydrogen peroxide.', u'== Principle of operation ==\nRocket engines produce thrust by the expulsion of an exhaust fluid which has been accelerated to a high speed through a propelling nozzle.', u'The fluid is usually a gas created by high pressure (150-to-2,900-pound-per-square-inch (10 to 200 bar)) combustion of solid or liquid propellants, consisting of fuel and oxidiser components, within a combustion chamber.', u'The nozzle uses the heat energy released by expansion of the gas to accelerate the exhaust to very high (supersonic) speed, and the reaction to this pushes the engine in the opposite direction.', u'Combustion is most frequently used for practical rockets, as high temperatures and pressures are desirable for the best performance, permitting a longer nozzle, giving higher exhaust speeds and better thermodynamic efficiency.', u'An alternative to combustion is the water rocket, which uses water pressurised by compressed air, carbon dioxide, nitrogen, or manual pumping, for model rocketry.', u'=== Propellant ===\nRocket propellant is mass that is stored, usually in some form of propellant tank, or within the combustion chamber itself, prior to being ejected from a rocket engine in the form of a fluid jet to produce thrust.', u'Chemical rocket propellants are most commonly used, which undergo exothermic chemical reactions which produce hot gas which is used by a rocket for propulsive purposes.', u'Alternatively, a chemically inert reaction mass can be heated using a high-energy power source via a heat exchanger, and then no combustion chamber is used.', u"Solid rocket propellants are prepared as a mixture of fuel and oxidising components called 'grain' and the propellant storage casing effectively becomes the combustion chamber.", u'=== Injection ===\nLiquid-fuelled rockets force separate fuel and oxidiser components into the combustion chamber, where they mix and burn.', u'Hybrid rocket engines use a combination of solid and liquid or gaseous propellants.', u'Both liquid and hybrid rockets use injectors to introduce the propellant into the chamber.', u'These are often an array of simple jets - holes through which the propellant escapes under pressure; but sometimes may be more complex spray nozzles.', u'When two or more propellants are injected, the jets usually deliberately cause the propellants to collide as this breaks up the flow into smaller droplets that burn more easily.', u'=== Combustion chamber ===\n\nFor chemical rockets the combustion chamber is typically just a cylinder, and flame holders are rarely used.', u'The dimensions of the cylinder are such that the propellant is able to combust thoroughly; different rocket propellants require different combustion chamber sizes for this to occur.', u'This leads to a number called \n  \n    \n      \n        \n          L\n          \n            \u2217\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle L^{*}}\n  :\n\n  \n    \n      \n        \n          L\n          \n            \u2217\n          \n        \n        =\n        \n          \n            \n              V\n              \n                c\n              \n            \n            \n              A\n              \n                t\n              \n            \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle L^{*}={\\frac {V_{c}}{A_{t}}}}\n  \nwhere:\n\n  \n    \n      \n        \n          V\n          \n            c\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle V_{c}}\n   is the volume of the chamber\n\n  \n    \n      \n        \n          A\n          \n            t\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle A_{t}}\n   is the area of the throat\nL* is typically in the range of 25\u201360 inches (0.64\u20131.52 m).', u'The combination of temperatures and pressures typically reached in a combustion chamber is usually extreme by any standards.', u'Unlike in airbreathing jet engines, no atmospheric nitrogen is present to dilute and cool the combustion, and the temperature can reach true stoichiometric ratios.', u'This, in combination with the high pressures, means that the rate of heat conduction through the walls is very high.', u'=== Nozzle ===\n\nThe hot gas produced in the combustion chamber is permitted to escape through an opening (the "throat"), and then through a diverging expansion section.', u'When sufficient pressure is provided to the nozzle (about 2.5-3 times ambient pressure), the nozzle chokes and a supersonic jet is formed, dramatically accelerating the gas, converting most of the thermal energy into kinetic energy.', u'Exhaust speeds vary, depending on the expansion ratio the nozzle is designed for, but exhaust speeds as high as ten times the speed of sound in air at sea level are not uncommon.', u"About half of the rocket engine's thrust comes from the unbalanced pressures inside the combustion chamber, and the rest comes from the pressures acting against the inside of the nozzle (see diagram).", u"As the gas expands (adiabatically) the pressure against the nozzle's walls forces the rocket engine in one direction while accelerating the gas in the other.", u'The most commonly used nozzle is the de Laval nozzle, a fixed geometry nozzle with a high expansion-ratio.', u'The large bell- or cone-shaped nozzle extension beyond the throat gives the rocket engine its characteristic shape.', u'The exit static pressure of the exhaust jet depends on the chamber pressure and the ratio of exit to throat area of the nozzle.', u'As exit pressure varies from the ambient (atmospheric) pressure, a choked nozzle is said to be underexpanded (exit pressure greater than ambient), perfectly expanded (exit pressure equals ambient), overexpanded (exit pressure less than ambient; shock diamonds form outside the nozzle), or grossly overexpanded (a shock wave forms inside the nozzle extension).', u'In practice, perfect expansion is only achievable with a variable-exit area nozzle (since ambient pressure decreases as altitude increases), and is not possible above a certain altitude as ambient pressure approaches zero.', u'If the nozzle is not perfectly expanded, then loss of efficiency occurs.', u'Grossly overexpanded nozzles lose less efficiency, but can cause mechanical problems with the nozzle.', u'Fixed-area nozzles become progressively more underexpanded as they gain altitude.', u'Almost all de Laval nozzles will be momentarily grossly overexpanded during startup in an atmosphere.', u'Nozzle efficiency is affected by operation in the atmosphere because atmospheric pressure changes with altitude; but due to the supersonic speeds of the gas exiting from a rocket engine, the pressure of the jet may be either below or above ambient, and equilibrium between the two is not reached at all altitudes (see diagram).', u"==== Back pressure and optimal expansion ====\nFor optimal performance the pressure of the gas at the end of the nozzle should just equal the ambient pressure: if the exhaust's pressure is lower than the ambient pressure, then the vehicle will be slowed by the difference in pressure between the top of the engine and the exit; on the other hand, if the exhaust's pressure is higher, then exhaust pressure that could have been converted into thrust is not converted, and energy is wasted.", u"To maintain this ideal of equality between the exhaust's exit pressure and the ambient pressure, the diameter of the nozzle would need to increase with altitude, giving the pressure a longer nozzle to act on (and reducing the exit pressure and temperature).", u'This increase is difficult to arrange in a lightweight fashion, although is routinely done with other forms of jet engines.', u"In rocketry a lightweight compromise nozzle is generally used and some reduction in atmospheric performance occurs when used at other than the 'design altitude' or when throttled.", u'To improve on this, various exotic nozzle designs such as the plug nozzle, stepped nozzles, the expanding nozzle and the aerospike have been proposed, each providing some way to adapt to changing ambient air pressure and each allowing the gas to expand further against the nozzle, giving extra thrust at higher altitudes.', u'When exhausting into a sufficiently low ambient pressure (vacuum) several issues arise.', u'One is the sheer weight of the nozzle\u2014beyond a certain point, for a particular vehicle, the extra weight of the nozzle outweighs any performance gained.', u"Secondly, as the exhaust gases adiabatically expand within the nozzle they cool, and eventually some of the chemicals can freeze, producing 'snow' within the jet.", u'This causes instabilities in the jet and must be avoided.', u'On a de Laval nozzle, exhaust gas flow detachment will occur in a grossly over-expanded nozzle.', u'As the detachment point will not be uniform around the axis of the engine, a side force may be imparted to the engine.', u'This side force may change over time and result in control problems with the launch vehicle.', u'Advanced altitude-compensating designs, such as the aerospike or plug nozzle, attempt to minimize performance losses by adjusting to varying expansion ratio caused by changing altitude.', u'=== Propellant efficiency ===\n\nFor a rocket engine to be propellant efficient, it is important that the maximum pressures possible be created on the walls of the chamber and nozzle by a specific amount of propellant; as this is the source of the thrust.', u"This can be achieved by all of:\nheating the propellant to as high a temperature as possible (using a high energy fuel, containing hydrogen and carbon and sometimes metals such as aluminium, or even using nuclear energy)\nusing a low specific density gas (as hydrogen rich as possible)\nusing propellants which are, or decompose to, simple molecules with few degrees of freedom to maximise translational velocity\nSince all of these things minimise the mass of the propellant used, and since pressure is proportional to the mass of propellant present to be accelerated as it pushes on the engine, and since from Newton's third law the pressure that acts on the engine also reciprocally acts on the propellant, it turns out that for any given engine the speed that the propellant leaves the chamber is unaffected by the chamber pressure (although the thrust is proportional).", u'However, speed is significantly affected by all three of the above factors and the exhaust speed is an excellent measure of the engine propellant efficiency.', u'This is termed exhaust velocity, and after allowance is made for factors that can reduce it, the effective exhaust velocity is one of the most important parameters of a rocket engine (although weight, cost, ease of manufacture etc.', u'are usually also very important).', u'For aerodynamic reasons the flow goes sonic ("chokes") at the narrowest part of the nozzle, the \'throat\'.', u'Since the speed of sound in gases increases with the square root of temperature, the use of hot exhaust gas greatly improves performance.', u'By comparison, at room temperature the speed of sound in air is about 340 m/s while the speed of sound in the hot gas of a rocket engine can be over 1700 m/s; much of this performance is due to the higher temperature, but additionally rocket propellants are chosen to be of low molecular mass, and this also gives a higher velocity compared to air.', u'Expansion in the rocket nozzle then further multiplies the speed, typically between 1.5 and 2 times, giving a highly collimated hypersonic exhaust jet.', u'The speed increase of a rocket nozzle is mostly determined by its area expansion ratio\u2014the ratio of the area of the throat to the area at the exit, but detailed properties of the gas are also important.', u'Larger ratio nozzles are more massive but are able to extract more heat from the combustion gases, increasing the exhaust velocity.', u'=== Thrust vectoring ===\n\nVehicles typically require the overall thrust to change direction over the length of the burn.', u'A number of different ways to achieve this have been flown:\nThe entire engine is mounted on a hinge or gimbal and any propellant feeds reach the engine via low pressure flexible pipes or rotary couplings.', u'Just the combustion chamber and nozzle is gimballed, the pumps are fixed, and high pressure feeds attach to the engine.', u'Multiple engines (often canted at slight angles) are deployed but throttled to give the overall vector that is required, giving only a very small penalty.', u'High-temperature vanes protrude into the exhaust and can be tilted to deflect the jet.', u'== Overall performance ==\nRocket technology can combine very high thrust (meganewtons), very high exhaust speeds (around 10 times the speed of sound in air at sea level) and very high thrust/weight ratios (>100) simultaneously as well as being able to operate outside the atmosphere, and while permitting the use of low pressure and hence lightweight tanks and structure.', u'Rockets can be further optimised to even more extreme performance along one or more of these axes at the expense of the others.', u'=== Specific impulse ===\n\nThe most important metric for the efficiency of a rocket engine is impulse per unit of propellant, this is called specific impulse (usually written \n  \n    \n      \n        \n          I\n          \n            s\n            p\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle I_{sp}}\n  ).', u'This is either
