measured as a speed (the effective exhaust velocity \n  \n    \n      \n        \n          v\n          \n            e\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle v_{e}}\n   in metres/second or ft/s) or as a time (seconds).', u'An engine that gives a large specific impulse is normally highly desirable.', u'The specific impulse that can be achieved is primarily a function of the propellant mix (and ultimately would limit the specific impulse), but practical limits on chamber pressures and the nozzle expansion ratios reduce the performance that can be achieved.', u"=== Net thrust ===\n\nBelow is an approximate equation for calculating the net thrust of a rocket engine:\n\n  \n    \n      \n        \n          F\n          \n            n\n          \n        \n        =\n        \n          \n            \n              m\n              \u02d9\n            \n          \n        \n        \n        \n          v\n          \n            e\n          \n        \n        =\n        \n          \n            \n              m\n              \u02d9\n            \n          \n        \n        \n        \n          v\n          \n            e\n            \u2212\n            o\n            p\n            t\n          \n        \n        +\n        \n          A\n          \n            e\n          \n        \n        (\n        \n          p\n          \n            e\n          \n        \n        \u2212\n        \n          p\n          \n            a\n            m\n            b\n          \n        \n        )\n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle F_{n}={\\dot {m}}\\;v_{e}={\\dot {m}}\\;v_{e-opt}+A_{e}(p_{e}-p_{amb})}\n  \n\nSince, unlike a jet engine, a conventional rocket motor lacks an air intake, there is no 'ram drag' to deduct from the gross thrust.", u'Consequently, the net thrust of a rocket motor is equal to the gross thrust (apart from static back pressure).', u'The \n  \n    \n      \n        \n          \n            \n              m\n              \u02d9\n            \n          \n        \n        \n        \n          v\n          \n            e\n            \u2212\n            o\n            p\n            t\n          \n        \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle {\\dot {m}}\\;v_{e-opt}\\,}\n   term represents the momentum thrust, which remains constant at a given throttle setting, whereas the \n  \n    \n      \n        \n          A\n          \n            e\n          \n        \n        (\n        \n          p\n          \n            e\n          \n        \n        \u2212\n        \n          p\n          \n            a\n            m\n            b\n          \n        \n        )\n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle A_{e}(p_{e}-p_{amb})\\,}\n   term represents the pressure thrust term.', u'At full throttle, the net thrust of a rocket motor improves slightly with increasing altitude, because as atmospheric pressure decreases with altitude, the pressure thrust term increases.', u'At the surface of the Earth the pressure thrust may be reduced by up to 30%,depending on the engine design.', u'This reduction drops roughly exponentially to zero with increasing altitude.', u'Maximum efficiency for a rocket engine is achieved by maximising the momentum contribution of the equation without incurring penalties from over expanding the exhaust.', u'This occurs when \n  \n    \n      \n        \n          p\n          \n            e\n          \n        \n        =\n        \n          p\n          \n            a\n            m\n            b\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle p_{e}=p_{amb}}\n  .', u'Since ambient pressure changes with altitude, most rocket engines spend very little time operating at peak efficiency.', u'=== Vacuum Isp ===\nDue to the specific impulse varying with pressure, a quantity that is easy to compare and calculate with is useful.', u'Because rockets choke at the throat, and because the supersonic exhaust prevents external pressure influences travelling upstream, it turns out that the pressure at the exit is ideally exactly proportional to the propellant flow \n  \n    \n      \n        \n          \n            \n              m\n              \u02d9\n            \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle {\\dot {m}}}\n  , provided the mixture ratios and combustion efficiencies are maintained.', u'It is thus quite usual to rearrange the above equation slightly:\n\n  \n    \n      \n        \n          F\n          \n            v\n            a\n            c\n          \n        \n        =\n        \n          C\n          \n            f\n          \n        \n        \n        \n          \n            \n              m\n              \u02d9\n            \n          \n        \n        \n        \n          c\n          \n            \u2217\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle F_{vac}=C_{f}\\,{\\dot {m}}\\,c^{*}}\n  \nand so define the vacuum Isp to be:\n\n  \n    \n      \n        \n          v\n          \n            e\n            v\n            a\n            c\n          \n        \n        =\n        \n          C\n          \n            f\n          \n        \n        \n        \n          c\n          \n            \u2217\n          \n        \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle v_{evac}=C_{f}\\,c^{*}\\,}\n  \nwhere:\n  \n  \n    \n      \n        \n          c\n          \n            \u2217\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle c^{*}}\n   \u2009= \u2009the speed of sound constant at the throat\n\n  \n    \n      \n        \n          C\n          \n            f\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle C_{f}}\n   \u2009= \u2009the thrust coefficient constant of the nozzle (typically about 2)\nAnd hence:\n\n  \n    \n      \n        \n          F\n          \n            n\n          \n        \n        =\n        \n          \n            \n              m\n              \u02d9\n            \n          \n        \n        \n        \n          v\n          \n            e\n            v\n            a\n            c\n          \n        \n        \u2212\n        \n          A\n          \n            e\n          \n        \n        \n        \n          p\n          \n            a\n            m\n            b\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle F_{n}={\\dot {m}}\\,v_{evac}-A_{e}\\,p_{amb}}\n  \n\n\n=== Throttling ===\nRockets can be throttled by controlling the propellant combustion rate \n  \n    \n      \n        \n          \n            \n              m\n              \u02d9\n            \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle {\\dot {m}}}\n   (usually measured in kg/s or lb/s).', u'In liquid and hybrid rockets, the propellant flow entering the chamber is controlled using valves, in solid rockets it is controlled by changing the area of propellant that is burning and this can be designed into the propellant grain (and hence cannot be controlled in real-time).', u'Rockets can usually be throttled down to an exit pressure of about one-third of ambient pressure (often limited by flow separation in nozzles) and up to a maximum limit determined only by the mechanical strength of the engine.', u'In practice, the degree to which rockets can be throttled varies greatly, but most rockets can be throttled by a factor of 2 without great difficulty; the typical limitation is combustion stability, as for example, injectors need a minimum pressure to avoid triggering damaging oscillations (chugging or combustion instabilities); but injectors can be optimised and tested for wider ranges.', u'For example, some more recent liquid-propellant engine designs that have been optimised for greater throttling capability can be throttled to as low as 18\u201320 percent of rated thrust.', u'Solid rockets can be throttled by using shaped grains that will vary their surface area over the course of the burn.', u'=== Energy efficiency ===\n\nRocket engine nozzles are surprisingly efficient heat engines for generating a high speed jet, as a consequence of the high combustion temperature and high compression ratio.', u'Rocket nozzles give an excellent approximation to adiabatic expansion which is a reversible process, and hence they give efficiencies which are very close to that of the Carnot cycle.', u'Given the temperatures reached, over 60% efficiency can be achieved with chemical rockets.', u'For a vehicle employing a rocket engine the energetic efficiency is very good if the vehicle speed approaches or somewhat exceeds the exhaust velocity (relative to launch); but at low speeds the energy efficiency goes to 0% at zero speed (as with all jet propulsion.)', u'See Rocket energy efficiency for more details.', u'=== Thrust-to-weight ratio ===\n\nRockets, of all the jet engines, indeed of essentially all engines, have the highest thrust to weight ratio.', u'This is especially true for liquid rocket engines.', u'This high performance is due to the small volume of pressure vessels that make up the engine\u2014the pumps, pipes and combustion chambers involved.', u'The lack of inlet duct and the use of dense liquid propellant allows the pressurisation system to be small and lightweight, whereas duct engines have to deal with air which has a density about one thousand times lower.', u'Rocket thrusts are vacuum thrusts unless otherwise noted\nOf the liquid propellants used, density is worst for liquid hydrogen.', u'Although this propellant is marvellous in many ways, it has a very low density, about one fourteenth that of water.', u'This makes the turbopumps and pipework larger and heavier, and this is reflected in the thrust-to-weight ratio of engines that use it (for example the SSME) compared to those that do not (NK-33).', u'== Cooling ==\nFor efficiency reasons, and because they physically can, rockets run with combustion temperatures that can reach ~3,500 K (~3,200 \xb0C or ~5,800 \xb0F).', u'Most other jet engines have gas turbines in the hot exhaust.', u'Due to their larger surface area, they are harder to cool and hence there is a need to run the combustion processes at much lower temperatures, losing efficiency.', u'In addition, duct engines use air as an oxidant, which contains 78% largely unreactive nitrogen, which dilutes the reaction and lowers the temperatures.', u'Rockets have none of these inherent disadvantages.', u'Therefore, temperatures used in rockets are very often far higher than the melting point of the nozzle and combustion chamber materials (~1,200 K for copper).', u'Two exceptions are graphite and tungsten, although both are subject to oxidation if not protected.', u'Indeed, many construction materials can make perfectly acceptable propellants in their own right.', u'It is important that these materials be prevented from combusting, melting or vaporising to the point of failure.', u'This is sometimes somewhat facetiously termed an "engine-rich exhaust".', u'Materials technology could potentially place an upper limit on the exhaust temperature of chemical rockets.', u'Alternatively, rockets may use more common construction materials such as aluminium, steel, nickel or copper alloys and employ cooling systems that prevent the construction material itself becoming too hot.', u'Regenerative cooling, where the propellant is passed through tubes around the combustion chamber or nozzle, and other techniques, such as curtain cooling or film cooling, are employed to give longer nozzle and chamber life.', u'These techniques ensure that a gaseous thermal boundary layer touching the material is kept below the temperature which would cause the material to catastrophically fail.', u'In rockets, the heat fluxes that can pass through the wall are among the highest in engineering; fluxes are generally in the range of 1-200 MW/m2.', u'The strongest heat fluxes are found at the throat, which often sees twice that found in the associated chamber and nozzle.', u'This is due to the combination of high speeds (which gives a very thin boundary layer), and although lower than the chamber, the high temperatures seen there.', u'(See rocket nozzles above for temperatures in nozzle).', u'In rockets the coolant methods include:\nuncooled (used for short runs mainly during testing)\nablative walls (walls are lined with a material that is continuously vaporised and carried away).', u'radiative cooling (the chamber becomes almost white hot and radiates the heat away)\ndump cooling (a propellant, usually hydrogen, is passed around the chamber and dumped)\nregenerative cooling (liquid rockets use the fuel, or occasionally the oxidiser, to cool the chamber via a cooling jacket before being injected)\ncurtain cooling (propellant injection is arranged so the temperature of the gases is cooler at the walls)\nfilm cooling (surfaces are wetted with liquid propellant, which cools as it evaporates)\nIn all cases the cooling effect that prevents the wall from being destroyed is caused by a thin layer of insulating fluid (a boundary layer) that is in contact with the walls that is far cooler than the combustion temperature.', u'Provided this boundary layer is intact the wall will not be damaged.', u'Disruption of the boundary layer may occur during cooling failures or combustion instabilities, and wall failure typically occurs soon after.', u'With regenerative cooling a second boundary layer is found in the coolant channels around the chamber.', u'This boundary layer thickness needs to be as small as possible, since the boundary layer acts as an insulator between the wall and the coolant.', u'This may be achieved by making the coolant velocity in the channels as high as possible.', u'In practice, regenerative cooling is nearly always used in conjunction with curtain cooling and/or film cooling.', u'Liquid-fuelled engines are often run fuel-rich, which lowers combustion temperatures.', u'This reduces heat loads on the engine and allows lower cost materials and a simplified cooling system.', u'This can also increase performance by lowering the average molecular weight of the exhaust and increasing the efficiency with which combustion heat is converted to kinetic exhaust energy.', u'== Mechanical issues ==\nRocket combustion chambers are normally operated at fairly high pressure, typically 10-200 bar (1 to 20 MPa, 150-3,000 psi).', u'When operated within significant atmospheric pressure, higher combustion chamber pressures give better performance by permitting a larger and more efficient nozzle to be fitted without it being grossly overexpanded.', u'However, these high pressures cause the outermost part of the chamber to be under very large hoop stresses \u2013 rocket engines are pressure vessels.', u'Worse, due to the high temperatures created in rocket engines the materials used tend to have a significantly lowered working tensile strength.', u'In addition, significant temperature gradients are set up in the walls of the chamber and nozzle, these cause differential expansion of the inner liner that create internal stresses.', u'== Acoustic issues ==\nThe extreme vibration and acoustic environment inside a rocket motor commonly result in peak stresses well above mean values, especially in the presence of organ pipe-like resonances and gas turbulence.', u'=== Combustion instabilities ===\nThe combustion may display undesired instabilities, of sudden or periodic nature.', u'The pressure in the injection chamber may increase until the propellant flow through the injector plate decreases; a moment later the pressure drops and the flow increases, injecting more propellant in the combustion chamber which burns a moment later, and again increases the chamber pressure, repeating the cycle.', u'This may lead to high-amplitude pressure oscillations, often in ultrasonic range, which may damage the motor.', u'Oscillations of \xb1200 psi at 25 kHz were the cause of failures of early versions of the Titan II missile second stage engines.', u'The other failure mode is a deflagration to detonation transition; the supersonic pressure wave formed in the combustion chamber may destroy the engine.', u'Combustion instability was also a problem during Atlas development.', u'The Rocketdyne engines used in the Atlas family were found to suffer from this effect in several static firing tests, and three missile launches exploded on the pad due to rough combustion in the booster engines.', u'In most cases, it occurred while attempting to start the engines with a "dry start" method whereby the igniter mechanism would be activated prior to propellant injection.', u'During the process of man-rating Atlas for Project Mercury, solving combustion instability was a high priority, and the final two Mercury flights sported an upgraded propulsion system with baffled injectors and a hypergolic igniter.', u'The problem affecting Atlas vehicles was mainly the so-called "racetrack" phenomenon, where burning propellant would swirl around in a circle at faster and faster speeds, eventually producing vibration strong enough to rupture the engine, leading to complete destruction of the rocket.', u'It was eventually solved by adding several baffles around the injector face to break up swirling propellant.', u'More significantly, combustion instability was a problem with the Saturn F-1 engines.', u'Some of the early units tested exploded during static firing, which led to the addition of injector baffles.', u'In the Soviet space program, combustion instability also proved a problem on some rocket engines, including the RD-107 engine used in the R-7 family and the RD-216 used in the R-14 family, and several failures of these vehicles occurred before the problem was solved.', u'Soviet engineering and manufacturing processes never satisfactorily resolved combustion instability in larger RP-1/LOX engines, so the RD-180 engine used to power the Zenit family still used four smaller thrust chambers fed by a common engine mechanism.', u'The combustion instabilities can be provoked by remains of cleaning solvents in the engine (e.g.', u'the first attempted launch of a Titan II in 1962), reflected shock wave, initial instability after ignition, explosion near the nozzle that reflects into the combustion chamber, and many more factors.', u'In stable engine designs the oscillations are quickly suppressed; in unstable designs they persist for prolonged periods.', u'Oscillation suppressors are commonly used.', u'Periodic variations of thrust, caused by combustion instability or longitudinal vibrations of structures between the tanks and the engines which modulate the propellant flow, are known as "pogo oscillations" or "pogo", named after the pogo stick.', u'Three different types of combustion instabilities occur:\nChugging\nThis is a low frequency oscillation at a few Hertz in chamber pressure usually caused by pressure variations in feed lines due to variations in acceleration of the vehicle.', u'This can cause cyclic variation in thrust, and the effects can vary from merely annoying to actually damaging the payload or vehicle.', u'Chugging can be minimised by using gas-filled damping tubes on feed lines of high density propellants.', u'Buzzing\nThis can be caused due to insufficient pressure drop across the injectors.', u'It generally is mostly annoying, rather than being damaging.', u'However, in extreme cases combustion can end up being forced backwards through the injectors \u2013 this can cause explosions with monopropellants.', u'Screeching\nThis is the most immediately damaging, and the hardest to control.', u'It is due to acoustics within the combustion chamber that often couples to the chemical combustion processes that are the primary drivers of the energy release, and can lead to unstable resonant "screeching" that commonly leads to catastrophic failure due to thinning of the insulating thermal boundary layer.', u'Acoustic oscillations can be excited by thermal processes, such as the flow of hot air through a pipe or combustion in a chamber.', u'Specifically, standing acoustic waves inside a chamber can be intensified if combustion occurs more intensely in regions where the pressure of the acoustic wave is maximal.', u'Such effects are very difficult to predict analytically during the design process, and have usually been addressed by expensive, time consuming and extensive testing, combined with trial and error remedial correction measures.', u'Screeching is often dealt with by detailed changes to injectors, or changes in the propellant chemistry, or vaporising the propellant before injection, or use of Helmholtz dampers within the combustion chambers to change the resonant modes of the chamber.', u"Testing for the possibility of screeching is sometimes done by exploding small explosive charges outside the combustion chamber with a tube set tangentially to the combustion chamber near the injectors to determine the engine's impulse response and then evaluating the time response of the chamber pressure- a fast recovery indicates a stable system.", u'=== Exhaust noise ===\n\nFor all but the very smallest sizes, rocket exhaust compared to other engines is generally very noisy.', u'As the hypersonic exhaust mixes with the ambient air, shock waves are formed.', u'The Space Shuttle generates over 200 dB(A) of noise around its base.', u'The sound intensity from the shock waves generated depends on the size of the rocket and on the exhaust velocity.', u'Such shock waves seem to account for the characteristic crackling and popping sounds produced by large rocket engines when heard live.', u'These noise peaks typically overload microphones and audio electronics, and so are generally weakened or entirely absent in recorded or broadcast audio reproductions.', u'For large rockets at close range, the acoustic effects could actually kill.', u'More worryingly for space agencies, such sound levels can also damage the launch structure, or worse, be reflected back at the comparatively delicate rocket above.', u'This is why so much water is typically used at launches.', u'The water spray changes the acoustic qualities of the air and reduces or deflects the sound energy away from the rocket.', u'Generally speaking, noise is most intense when a rocket is close to the ground, since the noise from the engines radiates up away from the jet, as well as reflecting off the ground.', u'Also, when the vehicle is moving slowly, little of the chemical energy input to the engine can go into increasing the kinetic energy of the rocket (since useful power P transmitted to the vehicle is \n  \n    \n      \n        P\n        =\n        F\n        \u2217\n        V\n      \n    \n    {\\displaystyle P=F*V}\n   for thrust F and speed V).', u"Then the largest portion of the energy is dissipated in the exhaust's interaction with the ambient air, producing noise.", u'This noise can be reduced somewhat by flame trenches with roofs, by water injection around the jet and by deflecting the jet at an angle.', u'== Testing ==\nRocket engines are usually statically tested at a test facility before being put into production.', u'For high altitude engines, either a shorter nozzle must be used, or the rocket must be tested in a large vacuum chamber.', u'== Safety ==\nRockets have a reputation for unreliability and danger; especially catastrophic failures.', u'Contrary to this reputation, carefully designed rockets can be made arbitrarily reliable.', u'In military use, rockets are not unreliable.', u'However, one of the main non-military uses of rockets is for orbital launch.', u'In this application, the premium has typically been placed on minimum weight, and it is difficult to achieve high reliability and low weight simultaneously.', u'In addition, if the number of flights launched is low, there is a very high chance of a design, operations or manufacturing error causing destruction of the vehicle.', u'Essentially all launch vehicles are test vehicles by normal aerospace standards (as of 2006).', u'=== Saturn family (1961-1975) ===\nThe Rocketdyne H-1 engine, used in a cluster of eight in the first stage of the Saturn I and Saturn IB launch vehicles, had no catastrophic failures in 152 engine-flights.', u'The Pratt and Whitney RL10 engine, used in a cluster of six in the Saturn I second stage, had no catastrophic failures in 36 engine-flights.', u'The Rocketdyne F-1 engine, used in a cluster of five in the first stage of the Saturn V, had no failures in 65 engine-flights.', u'The Rocketdyne J-2 engine, used in a cluster of five in the Saturn V second stage, and singly in the Saturn IB second stage and Saturn V third stage, had no catastrophic failures in 86 engine-flights.', u'=== Space Shuttle (1981-2011) ===\nThe Space Shuttle Main Engine, used in a cluster of three, had no catastrophic in-flight failures in 405 engine-flights.', u'However, the Space Shuttle Solid Rocket Booster, used in pairs, caused one notable catastrophic failure in 270 engine-flights.', u'== Chemistry ==\nRocket propellants require a high specific energy (energy per unit mass), because ideally all the reaction energy appears as kinetic energy of the exhaust gases, and exhaust velocity is the single most important performance parameter of an engine, on which vehicle performance depends.', u'Aside from inevitable losses and imperfections in the engine, incomplete combustion, etc., after specific reaction energy, the main theoretical limit reducing the exhaust velocity obtained is that, according to the laws of thermodynamics, a fraction of the chemical energy may go into rotation of the exhaust molecules, where it is unavailable for producing thrust.', u'Monatomic gases like helium have only three degrees of freedom, corresponding to the three dimensions of space, {x,y,z}, and only such spherically symmetric molecules escape this kind of loss.', u'A diatomic molecule like H2 can rotate about either of the two axes perpendicular to the one joining the two atoms, and as the equipartition law of statistical mechanics demands that the available thermal energy be divided equally among the degrees of freedom, for such a gas in thermal equilibrium 3/5 of the energy can go into unidirectional motion, and 2/5 into rotation (actually, the vibration of the molecule should not be neglected, see gas heat capacity).', u'A triatomic molecule like water has six degrees of freedom, so the energy is divided equally among rotational and translational degrees of freedom.', u'For most chemical reactions the latter situation is the case.', u'This issue is traditionally described in terms of the ratio, gamma, of the specific heat of the gas at constant volume to that at constant pressure.', u'The rotational energy loss is largely recovered in practice if the expansion nozzle is large enough to allow the gases to expand and cool sufficiently, the function of the nozzle being to convert the random thermal motions of the molecules in the combustion chamber into the unidirectional translation that produces thrust.', u'As long as the exhaust gas remains in equilibrium as it expands, the initial rotational energy will be largely returned to translation in the nozzle.', u'Although the specific reaction energy per unit mass of reactants is key, low mean molecular weight in the reaction products is also important in practice in determining exhaust velocity.', u'This is because the high gas temperatures in rocket engines pose serious problems for the engineering of survivable motors.', u'Because temperature is proportional to the mean energy per molecule, a given amount of energy distributed among more molecules of lower mass permits a higher exhaust velocity at a given temperature.', u'This means low atomic mass elements are favoured.', u'Liquid hydrogen (LH2) and oxygen (LOX, or LO2), are the most effective propellants in terms of exhaust velocity that have been widely used to date, though a few exotic combinations involving boron or liquid ozone are potentially somewhat better in theory if various practical problems could be solved.', u'It is important to note in computing the specific reaction energy, that the entire mass of the propellants, including both fuel and oxidiser, must be included.', u'The fact that air-breathing engines are typically able to obtain oxygen "for free" without having to carry it along, accounts for one factor of why air-breathing engines are very much more propellant-mass efficient, and one reason that rocket engines are far less suitable for most ordinary terrestrial applications.', u'Fuels for car or turbojet engines, use atmospheric oxygen and so have a much better effective energy output per unit mass of propellant that must be carried, but are similar per unit mass of fuel.', u'Computer programs that predict the performance of propellants in rocket engines are available.', u'== Ignition ==\n\nWith liquid and hybrid rockets, immediate ignition of the propellant(s) as they first enter the combustion chamber is essential.', u'With liquid propellants (but not gaseous), failure to ignite within milliseconds usually causes too much liquid propellant to be inside the chamber, and if/when ignition occurs the amount of hot gas created can exceed the maximum design pressure of the chamber, causing a catastrophic failure of the pressure vessel.', u'This is sometimes called a hard start or a rapid unscheduled disassembly (RUD).', u'Ignition can be achieved by a number of different methods; a pyrotechnic charge can be used, a plasma torch can be used, or electric spark ignition may be employed.', u'Some fuel/oxidiser combinations ignite on contact (hypergolic), and non-hypergolic fuels can be "chemically ignited" by priming the fuel lines with hypergolic propellants (popular in Russian engines).', u'Gaseous propellants generally will not cause hard starts, with rockets the total injector area is less than the throat thus the chamber pressure tends to ambient prior to ignition and high pressures cannot form even if the entire chamber is full of flammable gas at ignition.', u'Solid propellants are usually ignited with one-shot pyrotechnic devices.', u'Once ignited, rocket chambers are self-sustaining and igniters are not needed.', u'Indeed, chambers often spontaneously reignite if they are restarted after being shut down for a few seconds.', u'However, when cooled, many rockets cannot be restarted without at least minor maintenance, such as replacement of the pyrotechnic igniter.', u'== Jet physics ==\n\nRocket jets vary depending on the rocket engine, design altitude, altitude, thrust and other factors.', u'Carbon rich exhausts from kerosene fuels are often orange in colour due to the black body radiation of the unburnt particles, in addition to the blue Swan bands.', u'Peroxide oxidizer-based rockets and hydrogen rocket jets contain largely steam and are nearly invisible to the naked eye but shine brightly in the ultraviolet and infrared.', u'Jets from solid rockets can be highly visible as the propellant frequently contains metals such as elemental aluminium which burns with an orange-white flame and adds energy to the combustion process.', u'Some exhausts, notably alcohol fuelled rockets, can show visible shock diamonds.', u"These are due to cyclic variations in the jet pressure relative to ambient creating shock waves that form 'Mach disks'.", u'The shape of the jet varies from the design altitude, at high altitude all rockets are grossly under-expanded, and a quite small percentage of exhaust gases actually end up expanding forwards.', u'== Types of rocket engines ==\n\n\n=== Physically powered ===\n\n\n=== Chemically powered ===\n\n\n=== Electrically powered ===\n\n\n=== Thermal ===\n\n\n==== Preheated ====\n\n\n==== Solar thermal ====\nThe Solar thermal rocket would make use of solar power to directly heat reaction mass, and therefore does not require an electrical generator as most other forms of solar-powered propulsion do.', u'A solar thermal rocket only has to carry the means of capturing solar energy, such as concentrators and mirrors.', u'The heated propellant is fed through a conventional rocket nozzle to produce thrust.', u'The engine thrust is directly related to the surface area of the solar collector and to the local intensity of the solar radiation and inversely proportional to the Isp.', u'==== Beamed thermal ====\n\n\n==== Nuclear thermal ====\n\n\n=== Nuclear ===\nNuclear propulsion includes a wide variety of propulsion methods that use some form of nuclear reaction as their primary power source.', u'Various types of nuclear propulsion have been proposed, and some of them tested, for spacecraft applications:\n\n\n== History of rocket engines ==\nAccording to the writings of the Roman Aulus Gellius, in c. 400 BC, a Greek Pythagorean named Archytas, propelled a wooden bird along wires using steam.', u'However, it would not appear to have been powerful enough to take off under its own thrust.', u"The aeolipile described in the first century BC (often known as Hero's engine) essentially consists of a steam rocket on a bearing.", u'It was created almost two millennia before the Industrial Revolution but the principles behind it were not well understood, and its full potential was not realised for a millennium.', u'The availability of black powder to propel projectiles was a precursor to the development of the first solid rocket.', u'Ninth Century Chinese Taoist alchemists discovered black powder in a search for the elixir of life; this accidental discovery led to fire arrows which were the first rocket engines to leave the ground.', u'It is stated that "the reactive forces of incendiaries were probably not applied to the propulsion of projectiles prior to the 13th century".', u'A turning point in rocket technology emerged with a short manuscript entitled Liber Ignium ad Comburendos Hostes (abbreviated as The Book of Fires).', u'The manuscript is composed of recipes for creating incendiary weapons from the mid-eighth to the end of the thirteenth centuries\u2014two of which are rockets.', u'The first recipe calls for one part of colophonium and sulfur added to six parts of saltpeter (potassium nitrate) dissolved in laurel oil, then inserted into hollow wood and lit to "fly away suddenly to whatever place you wish and burn up everything".', u'The second recipe combines one pound of sulfur, two pounds of charcoal, and six pounds of saltpeter\u2014all finely powdered on a marble slab.', u'This powder mixture is packed firmly into a long and narrow case.', u'The introduction of saltpeter into pyrotechnic mixtures connected the shift from hurled Greek fire into self-propelled rocketry.', u'.', u'Articles and books on the subject of rocketry appeared increasingly from the fifteenth through seventeenth centuries.', u'In the sixteenth century, German military engineer Conrad Haas (1509-1576) wrote a manuscript which introduced the construction to multi-staged rockets.', u'Rocket engines were also brought in use by Tippu Sultan, the king of Mysore.', u'These rockets could be of various sizes, but usually consisted of a tube of soft hammered iron about 8 in (20 cm) long and 1 1\u20442\u20133 in (3.8\u20137.6 cm) diameter, closed at one end and strapped to a shaft of bamboo about 4 ft (120 cm) long.', u'The iron tube acted as a combustion chamber and contained well packed black powder propellant.', u'A rocket carrying about one pound of powder could travel almost 1,000 yards (910 m).', u"These 'rockets', fitted with swords used to travel long distance, several meters above in air before coming down with swords edges facing the enemy.", u'These rockets were used against British empire very effectively.', u'Slow development of this technology continued up to the later 19th century, when Russian Konstantin Tsiolkovsky first wrote about liquid-fueled rocket engines.', u'He was the first to develop the Tsiolkovsky rocket equation, though it was not published widely for some years.', u'The modern solid- and liquid-fueled engines became realities early in the 20th century, thanks to the American physicist Robert Goddard.', u'Goddard was the first to use a De Laval nozzle on a solid-propellant (gunpowder) rocket engine, doubling the thrust and increasing the efficiency by a factor of about twenty-five.', u'This was the birth of the modern rocket engine.', u'He calculated from his independently-derived rocket equation that a reasonably sized rocket, using solid fuel, could place a one-pound payload on the Moon.', u'He began to use liquid propellants in 1921 and was the first to launch, in 1926, a liquid-propellant rocket.', u'Goddard pioneered the use of the De Laval nozzle, lightweight propellant tanks, thrust vectoring, the smoothly-throttled liquid fuel engine, regenerative cooling, and curtain cooling.', u'During the late 1930s, German scientists, such as Wernher von Braun and Hellmuth Walter, investigated installing liquid-fueled rockets in military aircraft (Heinkel He 112, He 111, He 176 and Messerschmitt Me 163).', u'The turbopump was first employed by German scientists in WWII.', u'Until then cooling the nozzle had been problematic, and the A4 ballistic missile used dilute alcohol for the fuel, which reduced the combustion temperature sufficiently.', u'Staged combustion (\u0417\u0430\u043c\u043a\u043d\u0443\u0442\u0430\u044f \u0441\u0445\u0435\u043c\u0430) was first proposed by Alexey Isaev in 1949.', u'The first staged combustion engine was the S1.5400 used in the Soviet planetary rocket, designed by Melnikov, a former assistant to Isaev.', u"About the same time (1959), Nikolai Kuznetsov began work on the closed cycle engine NK-9 for Korolev's orbital ICBM, GR-1.", u'Kuznetsov later evolved that design into the NK-15 and NK-33 engines for the unsuccessful Lunar N1 rocket.', u'In the West, the first laboratory staged-combustion test engine was built in Germany in 1963, by Ludwig Boelkow.', u"Hydrogen peroxide / kerosene fueled engines such as the British Gamma of the 1950s used a closed-cycle process (arguably not staged combustion, but that's mostly a question of semantics) by catalytically decomposing the peroxide to drive turbines before combustion with the kerosene in the combustion chamber proper.", u'This gave the efficiency advantages of staged combustion, whilst avoiding the major engineering problems.', u'Liquid hydrogen engines were first successfully developed in America, the RL-10 engine first flew in 1962.', u'Hydrogen engines were used as part of the Project Apollo; the liquid hydrogen fuel giving a rather lower stage mass and thus reducing the overall size and cost of the vehicle.', u"== See also ==\nComparison of orbital rocket engines\nJet damping an effect of the exhaust jet of a rocket that tends to slow a vehicle's rotation speed\nLaser propulsion\nModel rocket motor classification lettered engines\nNERVA - NASA's Nuclear Energy for Rocket Vehicle Applications, a US nuclear thermal rocket programme\nPhoton rocket\nProject Prometheus, NASA development of nuclear propulsion for long-duration spaceflight, begun in 2003\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== External links ==\nDesigning for rocket engine life expectancy\nRocket Engine performance analysis with to division championships.', u'Martin had a distinguished playing career in the 1950s, highlighted by his years with the Yankees during which he performed at a high level in appearances in the World Series.', u'He was also selected for the American League All Star team in 1956.', u'In these years his infamous propensity for fisticuffs became established, both on and off the baseball field.', u'As eight months later; for this reason, Jenny always referred to Alfred, her second husband, as the "jackass."', u"(She had been married before to a native Italian named Donato Pisani, whom her family arranged her to marry, and later married a singer named Jack Downey and took his name; the marriage lasted until Jack's death many years later.)", u'Eventually, Jenny changed the family name to "Martin."', u'He began being called "Billy" after his grandmother (Joan\'s mother) started calling him "Bello" (Italian masculine for "beautiful"; Martin said in his autobiography Number One that she was fired on July 20 and Frank Lucchesi, one of Martin's coaches and a man who Martin thought was undermining him to Corbett so he could take the managerial position himself, was named as his replacement.", u'=== First stint with the Yankees ===\n\nMartin was not out of work for very long, as the Yankees had also fired their manager, Bill Virdon.', u"The former Yankee second baseman was hired to take his place, marking Martin's first time in a Yankee uniform since the 1957 trade.", u'With Martin at the helm, the Yankees went 30-26 in their final 56 games of the 1975 season; he then managed them to the World Series in 1976 (their first pennant since 1964) and 1977, winning in 1977.', u'He feuded publicly with both Yankee owner George Steinbrenner and star outfielder Reggie Jackson.', u'In one especially infamous incident, on June 18, 1977, in the middle game of what would prove to be a three-game series sweep by the Boston Red Sox at Fenway Park, Martin pulled Jackson off the field (replacing him with Paul Blair) in mid-inning for failing to hustle and catch a shallow outfield fly ball by Jim Rice, allowing Rice to reach second base.', u'The extremely angry and highly animated Martin had to be restrained by coaches Elston Howard and Yogi Berra from getting into a fight with Jackson in the dugout during the nationally-televised Saturday afternoon game.', u'In 1978, Martin had another major incident with Jackson and it eventually led to him losing his position.', u'On July 17 against the Kansas City Royals, Jackson came to the plate in the bottom of the tenth inning with Thurman Munson on base and Martin put the bunt sign on.', u'After Jackson fouled the first pitch off, the sign was taken off and Jackson was given the sign to swing away.', u'Jackson bunted again, and then on the third pitch he bunted again and popped out.', u'A furious Martin demanded Jackson be suspended for the remainder of the season after the game, but after conversing with upper management Martin agreed on a five-game suspension.', u'Then, when Jackson returned, he told reporters that he did not know why Martin had suspended him.', u"To make matters worse for Martin, he was accused of racism for demanding Jackson's suspension after word leaked to the press that Sparky Lyle, who was going through his own issues with team management, violated team rules that same day when he left the stadium and went home without permission after refusing to pitch a second full inning, yet received no punishment.", u'Then he learned that Steinbrenner was looking to trade his manager to the Chicago White Sox, and in return would receive White Sox manager Bob Lemon.', u'Martin finally had enough, and following the July 23 game in Chicago Martin lashed out at his star player and his owner.', u'Martin told reporters in Chicago, "They deserve each other.', u'One\'s a born liar [Jackson], and the other\'s convicted [Steinbrenner]."', u"(Martin was referring to Steinbrenner's conviction for making illegal donations to Richard Nixon's 1972 election campaign, a conviction that resulted in Steinbrenner being suspended from baseball for 15 months).", u'The next day, having thought over the impact of his words Martin resigned in a tearful press conference in Kansas City (it was said, including by Martin in his 1980 autobiography, that Steinbrenner had sent Al Rosen, who was the team president at the time, to fire Martin at the hotel but Martin resigned before he could).', u'Steinbrenner replaced Martin with Lemon, who had lost his job with the White Sox approximately a month earlier despite winning AL Manager of the Year in 1977.', u"Soon afterward, at the annual Old-Timers' Game at Yankee Stadium, in a grandstanding gesture and an overwhelming demand by the fans, the Yankees had public address announcer Bob Sheppard introduce an unemployed Martin as the Yankees' next manager for the 1980 season (with Lemon moving to the front office).", u'Steinbrenner and Martin had apparently patched up their differences, but Lemon managed the team for 1978\u20131979.', u'=== Second stint with the Yankees ===\n\nIn 1979, the Yankees got off to a slow start under Lemon.', u'Injuries to Reggie Jackson and Goose Gossage as well as the death of Thurman Munson mid-season had the Yankees reeling.', u'Steinbrenner fired Lemon and brought back Martin earlier than previously planned.', u'The Yankees failed to improve, however, and their streak of American League East division titles ended at three.', u'After the 1979 season, Martin got into a fight with marshmallow salesman Joseph Cooper at a hotel in Minneapolis.', u'According to Cooper, the fight started over a dispute on who should be "Manager of the Year", with Cooper saying Dick Williams or Earl Weaver.', u'Martin reportedly egged Cooper on, offering a $500 bet and later sucker punching Cooper when he agreed.', u'Steinbrenner fired him after that and replaced him with Dick Howser for the 1980 season.', u'=== Oakland Athletics ===\nMartin, an East Bay native born and raised in Berkeley, resurfaced with the Oakland Athletics, where he perfected a style of play that became known as "Billyball" (characterized as featuring aggressive base running).', u"Martin won the American League West Division title in the split season of 1981, swept the Kansas City Royals in the special division series (due to a players' strike), and then met the Yankees in the 1981 ALCS where his A's were swept by the Yankees.", u"Martin's early success with the A's led to his designation as the club's general manager\u2014giving him control over the baseball operations of the entire Oakland organization in 1981.", u"Martin was fired from both positions when the 1982 Athletics plummeted to a 68-94 record, largely because he'd overworked many of the pitchers from the 1981 team.", u'Years later, Rob Neyer estimated that the four top starters from the 1981 team threw anywhere from 120-140 pitches per complete game\u2014a heavy workload for pitchers as young as the members of the 1981 staff were.', u'=== Remaining stints with the Yankees ===\nMartin returned to the New York Yankees in 1983, 1985, and 1988, but never for more than one full season.', u'During his years as a major league manager, Art Fowler usually served as his pitching coach.', u'Each time, while his teams managed to make good accounts of themselves on the field, he was fired due to his behavior on and off the field.', u'During the 1983 season, Martin was involved in one of the most controversial regular season games, known as the Pine Tar Incident, where umpires nullified a go-ahead home run by Yankee nemesis, Kansas City Royals third baseman George Brett, when Martin protested that there was too much pine tar on his bat.', u"Ultimately, American League President Lee MacPhail ruled in favor of the Royals' protest, reinstating the home run, and replaying the game from the point of the nullification.", u'At the start of the replayed game, Martin tried to protest on the grounds that Brett had missed a base.', u'The umpires working this game, however, had anticipated this, and had obtained an affidavit from the crew who had worked the original game saying that Brett had indeed touched all the bases.', u'On September 22, 1985, while at a hotel bar in Baltimore, Maryland, Martin fought one of his pitchers, Ed Whitson, who was 4 inches (100 mm) taller and 40 pounds (18 kg) heavier.', u'Martin suffered a broken arm, bruises, and cuts, while Whitson had a broken rib and a split lip.', u'He was fired after the 1985 season.', u'At the time of his death, Martin was preparing to manage the Yankees a sixth time for the 1990 season, to the point of having assembled a coaching staff.', u"=== Managerial record ===\n\n\n== Honors ==\n\nOn August 10, 1986, the Yankees retired Martin's uniform number 1 and dedicated a plaque in his honor for Monument Park at Yankee Stadium.", u'The plaque contains the words, There has never been a greater competitor than Billy.', u'Martin told the crowd, "I may not have been the greatest Yankee to put on the uniform, but I am the proudest."', u'The baseball fields at Bushrod Park in Oakland California are named for baseball player and manager Billy Martin\nMartin appeared on the 2011 Baseball Hall of Fame ballot.', u'He did not receive enough votes for induction.', u"Many of his contemporaries have remarked on Martin's ability to surprise the opposition and his outside-the-box thinking.", u'Commenting on Martin\'s strategy as a manager, Dave Winfield has stated that opposing players would often ask each other, "What\'s Billy doing now?"', u'George Steinbrenner has stated that when Martin was in his best form, he was a "baseball genius."', u'He has also been cited as an influence to other prominent managers, including Lou Piniella.', u'Martin both preceded and succeeded Piniella as Yankees manager.', u'== In popular culture ==\nIn 1978, Martin played himself in the CBS TV movie One in a Million: The Ron LeFlore Story.', u'On the comedy show Bizarre, Martin laid into Super Dave Osborne (albeit behind Martin\'s closed manager\'s office door at the Oakland Coliseum) after Osborne prodded him with insults such as "Your Billy Ball stinks" and "You\'re a stupid little Greek".', u'Osborne then amended the latter to "stupid Italian", which caused Martin to thrash the stuntman some more.', u"Martin was a guest celebrity ring announcer at the inaugural WrestleMania in March 1985, during his time as the manager of the Yankees, where he was referred to as 'New York's Number One'.", u'The crowd gave him a standing ovation.', u'Martin was the first baseball celebrity to appear at WrestleMania.', u'On May 24, 1986, on the season finale of Saturday Night Live, co-host Martin was "fired" by executive producer Lorne Michaels for being "drunk" in a skit, slurring his lines.', u'During the goodnights, Martin set the dressing room on fire in retaliation, a staged scene set as a cliffhanger for the following season.', u'In 1988, on Saturday Night Live\'s "Weekend Update", comedian Dennis Miller opened the sports with, "In Calgary tonight, Katarina Witt won the gold medal in figure skating, prompting Yankees owner George Steinbrenner to fire manager Billy Martin", as part of a continuous running gag on the segment where a recent sporting event "forces" Steinbrenner to fire whomever is managing the team in retaliation.', u'Martin was played by John Turturro in the 2007 ESPN mini-series The Bronx is Burning, which follows the tumultuous summer of 1977 in New York City.', u'== Personal life ==\nMartin was married four times and had two children, a daughter named Kelly Ann and a son named Billy Joe.', u'His first marriage was to Lois Berndt, by whom he had his daughter.', u'She divorced him in 1955, after he had contested the action for more than a year on the grounds that he was Catholic.', u'He married Gretchen Winkler in 1961, by whom he had his son, and stayed married to her until 1979, when the two divorced.', u'He was married a third time, to Heather Ervolino, while he was managing in Oakland, but was never faithful to his third wife and eventually married his mistress, a woman named Jillian Guiver, in January 1988.', u'In 1978, Martin and sports agent Doug Newton opened "Billy Martin\'s", a western wear boutique.', u'Newton bought out Martin in 1982, and the store remained open until 2010.', u'== Death ==\n\nMartin was working as a special consultant to George Steinbrenner when he was killed in a low speed, single vehicle collision during an ice storm at the end of the driveway to his farm in Port Crane, north of Binghamton, New York, on Christmas Day 1989.', u'He was pronounced dead at a hospital in Johnson City, New York, where efforts to revive him were unsuccessful.', u"Martin was eulogized by Cardinal John O'Connor at St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York, before his funeral at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, New York.", u'His grave is located about 150 feet (46 m) from the grave of Babe Ruth in Section 25.', u'The following epitaph, said by Martin himself at his number retiring ceremony at Yankee Stadium in 1986, appears on the headstone: I may not have been the greatest Yankee to put on the uniform, but I was the proudest.', u"Former United States President Richard Nixon and Yankee owner George Steinbrenner, along with many former New York Yankees greats, attended Martin's funeral service.", u'== See also ==\n\nNew York Yankees managers
