{'sentences': [u'Lee Harvey Oswald (October 18, 1939 \u2013 November 24, 1963) was an American sniper who assassinated President John F. Kennedy on November 22, 1963.', u'According to five U.S. government investigations, Oswald shot and killed Kennedy as he traveled by motorcade through Dealey Plaza in the city of Dallas, Texas.', u'Oswald was a former U.S. Marine who defected to the Soviet Union in October 1959.', u'He lived in the Belarusian city of Minsk until June 1962, at which time he returned to the United States with Marina, his Russian wife, eventually settling in Dallas.', u"Following Kennedy's assassination, Oswald was initially arrested for the murder of police officer J. D. Tippit, who was killed on a Dallas street about 45 minutes after Kennedy was shot.", u'Oswald was later charged with the murder of Kennedy; he denied shooting anybody, saying that he was a patsy.', u'Two days later, while being transferred from the city jail to the county jail, Oswald was fatally shot by Dallas nightclub owner Jack Ruby in full view of television cameras broadcasting live.', u'In September 1964, the Warren Commission concluded that Oswald acted alone in assassinating Kennedy by firing three shots from the Texas School Book Depository.', u'This conclusion was supported by previous investigations carried out by the FBI, the Secret Service, and the Dallas Police Department.', u'Despite forensic, ballistic, and eyewitness evidence supporting the lone gunman theory, public opinion polls taken over the years have shown that most Americans believe that Oswald did not act alone, but conspired with others to kill the president.', u'The assassination has spawned numerous conspiracy theories.', u'== Early life ==\n\n\n=== Childhood ===\nOswald was born in New Orleans, Louisiana, on October 18, 1939.', u"Lee's elder brother Robert, Jr. (born 1934) was also a former Marine.", u"Through Marguerite's first marriage to Edward John Pic, Jr., Lee and Robert Jr. were the half-brothers of Air Force veteran John Edward Pic (1932 \u2013 2000).", u'In 1944, Marguerite moved the family from New Orleans to Dallas, Texas.', u'Oswald entered the 1st grade in 1945 and over the next half-dozen years attended several different schools through the 6th grade in the Dallas and Fort Worth areas .', u'Oswald took an IQ test in the 4th grade and scored 103; "on achievement tests in [grades 4 to 6], he twice did best in reading and twice did worst in spelling."', u'As a child, Oswald was described by several people who knew him as withdrawn and temperamental.', u"In August 1952, when Oswald was 12, his mother took him to New York City where they lived for a short time with Oswald's half-brother, John.", u"Oswald and his mother were later asked to leave after an argument in which Oswald allegedly struck his mother and threatened John's wife with a pocket knife.", u'Oswald attended the 7th grade in the Bronx, New York, but was often truant, which led to a psychiatric assessment at a juvenile reformatory.', u'The reformatory psychiatrist, Dr. Renatus Hartogs, described Oswald as immersed in a "vivid fantasy life, turning around the topics of omnipotence and power, through which [Oswald] tries to compensate for his present shortcomings and frustrations."', u'Dr. Hartogs detected a "personality pattern disturbance with schizoid features and passive-aggressive tendencies" and recommended continued treatment.', u"In January 1954, Oswald's mother returned to New Orleans, taking Oswald with her.", u"At the time, there was a question pending before a New York judge as to whether Oswald should be removed from the care of his mother to finish his schooling, although Oswald's behavior appeared to improve during his last months in New York.", u'In New Orleans, Oswald completed the 8th and 9th grades.', u'He entered the 10th grade in 1955 but quit school after one month.', u'After leaving school, Oswald worked for several months as an office clerk and messenger in New Orleans.', u"In July 1956, Oswald's mother moved the family to Fort Worth, Texas, and Oswald re-enrolled in the 10th grade for the September session at Arlington Heights High School in Fort Worth.", u'A few weeks later in October, Oswald quit school at age 17 to join the Marines (see below); he never received a high school diploma.', u'By the age of 17, he had resided at 22 different locations and attended 12 different schools.', u'Though the young Oswald had trouble spelling and may have had a "reading-spelling disability", he read voraciously.', u'By age 15, he claimed to be a Marxist, writing in his diary, "I was looking for a key to my environment, and then I discovered socialist literature.', u'I had to dig for my books in the back dusty shelves of libraries."', u'At 16 he wrote to the Socialist Party of America for information on their Young People\'s Socialist League, saying he had been studying socialist principles for "well over fifteen months."', u'However, Edward Voebel, "whom the Warren Commission had established was Oswald\'s closest friend during his teenage years in New Orleans..... said that reports that Oswald was already \'studying Communism\' were a \'lot of baloney.\'', u'" Voebel said that "Oswald commonly read \'paperback trash.\'"', u'As a teenager, in 1955, Oswald attended Civil Air Patrol meetings in New Orleans.', u"Oswald's fellow cadets recalled him attending C.A.P.", u'meetings "three or four" times, or "10 or 12 times" over a one- or two-month period.', u'=== Marine Corps ===\n\nOswald enlisted in the United States Marine Corps on October 24, 1956, just after his seventeenth birthday.', u'Because he was underage, his brother Robert, Jr. signed the forms as his guardian.', u'Oswald also named his mother and his half-brother John as beneficiaries.', u"Oswald idolized his older brother Robert Jr.; a photograph taken after Lee Harvey's arrest by Dallas police shows him wearing his brother's Marine Corps ring.", u'John Pic (Oswald\'s half-brother) testified to the Warren Commission that Oswald\'s enlistment was motivated by wanting "to get from out and under ... the yoke of oppression from my mother."', u"Oswald's enlistment papers record his vital statistics as 5 feet 8 inches (1.73 meters) in height, 135 pounds (61 kg) in weight, with hazel eyes and brown hair.", u'His primary training was radar operation, a position requiring a security clearance.', u'A May 1957 document states that he was "granted final clearance to handle classified matter up to and including confidential after careful check of local records had disclosed no derogatory data."', u'At Keesler Air Force Base in Biloxi, Mississippi, Oswald finished seventh in a class of thirty in the Aircraft Control and Warning Operator Course which "included instruction in aircraft surveillance and the use of radar."', u'He was given the military occupational specialty of Aviation Electronics Operator.', u'On July 9, he reported to the Marine Corps Air Station El Toro then departed for Japan the following month, where he was assigned to Marine Air Control Squadron 1 near Tokyo.', u'Like all Marines, Oswald was trained and tested in shooting and he scored 212 in December 1956, slightly above the requirements for the designation of sharpshooter.', u'In May 1959 he scored 191, which reduced his rating to marksman.', u'Oswald was court-martialed after accidentally shooting himself in the elbow with an unauthorized .22 handgun, then court-martialed again for fighting with a sergeant who he thought was responsible for his punishment in the shooting matter.', u'He was demoted from private first class to private and briefly imprisoned in the brig.', u'He was later punished for a third incident: while on night-time sentry duty in the Philippines, he inexplicably fired his rifle into the jungle.', u'Slightly built, Oswald was nicknamed Ozzie Rabbit after the cartoon character; he was also called Oswaldskovich because he espoused pro-Soviet sentiments.', u'In November 1958, Oswald transferred back to El Toro where his unit\'s function "was to serveil  [sic] for aircraft, but basically to train both enlisted men and officers for later assignment overseas."', u'An officer there said that Oswald was a "very competent" crew chief and was "brighter than most people."', u'While in the Marines, Oswald made an effort to teach himself rudimentary Russian.', u'Although this was an unusual endeavor, in February 1959, he was invited to take a Marine proficiency exam in written and spoken Russian.', u'His level at the time was rated "poor."', u'On September 11, 1959, he received a hardship discharge from active service, claiming his mother needed care, and was put on reserve.', u'== Adult life and early crimes ==\n\n\n=== Defection to the Soviet Union ===\nIn October 1959, just before turning 20, Oswald traveled to the Soviet Union, a trip he planned well in advance.', u'Along with his self-taught Russian, he had saved $1,500 of his Marine Corps salary.', u'Oswald spent two days with his mother in Fort Worth, then embarked by ship from New Orleans on September 20 to Le Havre, France, and immediately proceeded to the United Kingdom.', u'Arriving in Southampton on October 9, he told officials he had $700 and planned to remain in the United Kingdom for one week before proceeding to a school in Switzerland.', u'However, on the same day, he flew to Helsinki, where he was issued a Soviet visa on October 14.', u'Oswald left Helsinki by train on the following day, crossed the Soviet border at Vainikkala, and arrived in Moscow on October 16.', u'His visa, valid only for a week, was due to expire on October 21.', u'Almost immediately after arriving, Oswald told his Intourist guide of his desire to become a Soviet citizen.', u'When asked why by the various Soviet officials he encountered\u2014all of whom, by Oswald\'s account, found his wish incomprehensible\u2014he said that he was a communist, and gave what he described in his diary as "vauge [sic] answers about \'Great Soviet Union\'".', u'On October 21, the day his visa was due to expire, he was told that his citizenship application had been refused, and that he had to leave the Soviet Union that evening.', u'Distraught, Oswald inflicted a minor but bloody wound to his left wrist in his hotel room bathtub soon before his Intourist guide was due to arrive to escort him from the country, according to his diary because he wished to kill himself in a way that would shock her.', u"Delaying Oswald's departure because of his self-inflicted injury, the Soviets kept him in a Moscow hospital under psychiatric observation until October 28, 1959.", u'According to Oswald, he met with four more Soviet officials that same day, who asked if he wanted to return to the United States; he insisted to them that he wanted to live in the Soviet Union as a Soviet national.', u'When pressed for identification papers, he provided his Marine Corps discharge papers.', u'On October 31, Oswald appeared at the United States embassy in Moscow, declaring a desire to renounce his U.S. citizenship.', u'"I have made up my mind," he said; "I\'m through."', u'He told the U.S. embassy interviewing officer, Richard Edward Snyder, that "he had been a radar operator in the Marine Corps and that he had voluntarily stated to unnamed Soviet officials that as a Soviet citizen he would make known to them such information concerning the Marine Corps and his specialty as he possessed.', u'He intimated that he might know something of special interest."', u"(Such statements led to Oswald's hardship/honorable military reserve discharge being changed to undesirable.)", u'The Associated Press story of the defection of a former U.S. Marine to the Soviet Union was reported on the front pages of some newspapers in 1959.', u'Though Oswald had wanted to attend Moscow State University, he was sent to Minsk to work as a lathe operator at the Gorizont Electronics Factory, which produced radios, televisions, and military and space electronics.', u"Stanislau Shushkevich, who later became independent Belarus's first head of state, was also engaged by Gorizont at the time, and was assigned to teach Oswald Russian.", u'Oswald received a government-subsidized, fully furnished studio apartment in a prestigious building and an additional supplement to his factory pay\u2014all in all, an idyllic existence by working-class Soviet standards, though he was kept under constant surveillance.', u'From approximately June 1960 to February 1961, Oswald had a relationship with Ella German, a co-worker at the factory.', u'He proposed marriage to her at the beginning of 1961 but she refused with the explanation that she did not love him and was afraid to marry an American.', u"Some researchers believe that German's rejection of Oswald's marriage proposal may have had much to do with his disillusionment with life in the Soviet Union and his decision to return to the United States.", u'Oswald wrote in his diary in January 1961: "I am starting to reconsider my desire about staying.', u'The work is drab, the money I get has nowhere to be spent.', u'No nightclubs or bowling alleys, no places of recreation except the trade union dances.', u'I have had enough."', u'Shortly afterwards, Oswald (who had never formally renounced his U.S. citizenship) wrote to the U.S. Embassy in Moscow requesting return of his American passport, and proposing to return to the U.S. if any charges against him would be dropped.', u'In March 1961, Oswald met Marina Prusakova, a 19-year-old pharmacology student; they married less than six weeks later in April.', u"The Oswalds' first child, June, was born on February 15, 1962.", u'On May 24, 1962, Oswald and Marina applied at the U.S. Embassy in Moscow for documents enabling her to immigrate to the U.S. and, on June 1, the U.S. Embassy gave Oswald a repatriation loan of $435.71.', u"Oswald, Marina, and their infant daughter left for the United States, where they received no attention from the press, much to Oswald's disappointment.", u"=== Dallas\u2013Fort Worth ===\nThe Oswalds soon settled in the Dallas/Fort Worth area, where Lee's mother and brother lived.", u'Lee began a manuscript on Soviet life, though he eventually gave up the project.', u'The Oswalds also became acquainted with a number of anti-Communist Russian and East European \xe9migr\xe9s in the area.', u'In testimony to the Warren Commission, Alexander Kleinlerer said that the Russian \xe9migr\xe9s sympathized with Marina, while merely tolerating Oswald, whom they regarded as rude and arrogant.', u'Although the Russian \xe9migr\xe9s eventually abandoned Marina when she made no sign of leaving Lee, Oswald found an unlikely friend in 51-year-old Russian \xe9migr\xe9 George de Mohrenschildt, a well-educated petroleum geologist with international business connections.', u'A native of Russia, Mohrenschildt later was to tell the Warren Commission that Oswald had a "remarkable fluency in Russian."', u'Marina, meanwhile, befriended Ruth Paine, a Quaker who was trying to learn Russian, and her husband Michael Paine, who worked for Bell Helicopter.', u'In July 1962, Oswald was hired by the Leslie Welding Company in Dallas; he disliked the work and quit after three months.', u'In October, he was hired by the graphic-arts firm of Jaggars-Chiles-Stovall as a photoprint trainee.', u"A fellow employee at Jaggars-Chiles-Stovall testified that Oswald's rudeness at his new job was such that fights threatened to break out, and that he once saw Oswald reading a Russian-language publication.", u'Oswald was fired during the first week of April 1963.', u'Some have suggested that Oswald might have used equipment at the firm to forge identification documents.', u'=== Edwin Walker assassination attempt ===\nIn March 1963, Oswald purchased a 6.5 mm caliber Carcano rifle for $29.95 by mail-order, using the alias "A. Hidell", as well as a .38 Smith & Wesson Model 10 revolver by the same method.', u"On April 10, 1963, Oswald attempted to kill retired U.S. Major General Edwin Walker, firing that rifle at Walker through a window, from less than 100 feet (30 m) away, as Walker sat at a desk in his Dallas home; the bullet struck the window-frame and Walker's only injuries were bullet fragments to the forearm.", u'(The United States House Select Committee on Assassinations stated that the "evidence strongly suggested" that Oswald carried out the shooting.)', u'General Walker was an outspoken anti-communist, segregationist, and member of the John Birch Society.', u'In 1961, Walker had been relieved of his command of the 24th Division of the U.S. Army in West Germany for distributing right-wing literature to his troops.', u"Walker's later actions in opposition to racial integration at the University of Mississippi led to his arrest on insurrection, seditious conspiracy, and other charges.", u"He was temporarily held in a mental institution on orders from President Kennedy's brother, Attorney General Robert Kennedy, but a grand jury refused to indict him.", u"Marina Oswald testified that her husband told her that he traveled by bus to General Walker's house and shot at Walker with his rifle.", u'She said that Oswald considered Walker to be the leader of a "fascist organization."', u'A note Oswald left for Marina on the night of the attempt, telling her what to do if he did not return, was not found until ten days after the Kennedy assassination.', u"Before the Kennedy assassination, Dallas police had no suspects in the Walker shooting, but Oswald's involvement was suspected within hours of his arrest following the assassination.", u'The Walker bullet was too damaged to run conclusive ballistics studies on it, but neutron activation analysis later showed that it was "extremely likely" that it was made by the same manufacturer and for the same rifle make as the two bullets which later struck Kennedy.', u'George de Mohrenschildt testified that he "knew that Oswald disliked General Walker."', u'Regarding this, de Mohrenschildt and his wife Jeanne recalled an incident that occurred the weekend following the Walker assassination attempt.', u'The de Mohrenschildts testified that on April 14, 1963, just before Easter Sunday, they were visiting the Oswalds at their new apartment and had brought them a toy Easter bunny to give to their child.', u"As Oswald's wife Marina was showing Jeanne around the apartment, they discovered Oswald's rifle standing upright, leaning against the wall inside a closet.", u'Jeanne told George that Oswald had a rifle, and George joked to Oswald, "Were you the one who took a pot-shot at General Walker?"', u'When asked about Oswald\'s reaction to this question, George de Mohrenschildt told the Warren Commission that Oswald "smiled at that."', u'When George\'s wife Jeanne was asked about Oswald\'s reaction, she said, "I didn\'t notice anything"; she continued, "we started laughing our heads off, big joke, big George\'s joke."', u'Jeanne de Mohrenschildt testified that this was the last time she or her husband ever saw the Oswalds.', u'=== New Orleans ===\n\nOswald returned to New Orleans on April 24, 1963.', u"Marina's friend, Ruth Paine, drove her by car from Dallas to join Oswald in New Orleans the next month in May.", u'On May 10, Oswald was hired by the Reily Coffee Company as a machinery greaser.', u'He was fired in July "because his work was not satisfactory and because he spent too much time loitering in Adrian Alba\'s garage next door, where he read rifle and hunting magazines."', u'On May 26, Oswald wrote to the New York City headquarters of the pro-Castro Fair Play for Cuba Committee, proposing to rent "a small office at my own expense for the purpose of forming a FPCC branch here in New Orleans."', u'Three days later, the FPCC responded to Oswald\'s letter advising against opening a New Orleans office "at least not ... at the very beginning."', u'In a follow-up letter, Oswald replied, "Against your advice, I have decided to take an office from the very beginning."', u'On May 29, Oswald ordered the following items from a local printer: 500 application forms, 300 membership cards, and 1,000 leaflets with the heading, "Hands Off Cuba."', u'According to Lee Oswald\'s wife Marina, Lee told her to sign the name "A.J.', u'Hidell" as chapter president on his membership card.', u'On August 5 and 6, according to anti-Castro militant Carlos Bringuier, Oswald visited him at a store he owned in New Orleans.', u'Bringuier was the New Orleans delegate for the anti-Castro organization Directorio Revolucionario Estudantil (DRE).', u"Bringuier would later tell the Warren Commission that he believed Oswald's visits were an attempt by Oswald to infiltrate his group.", u'On August 9, Oswald turned up in downtown New Orleans handing out pro-Castro leaflets.', u"Bringuier confronted Oswald, claiming he was tipped off about Oswald's leafleting by a friend.", u"A scuffle ensued and Oswald, Bringuier, and two of Bringuier's friends were arrested for disturbing the peace.", u'Prior to leaving the police station, Oswald requested to speak with an FBI agent.', u'Oswald stated that he was a member of the New Orleans branch of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee which he claimed had 35 members and was led by A. J. Hidell.', u"In fact, Oswald was the branch's only member and it had never been chartered by the national organization.", u'A week later, on August 16, Oswald again passed out Fair Play for Cuba leaflets with two hired helpers, this time in front of the International Trade Mart.', u'The incident was filmed by WDSU, a local TV station.', u"The next day, Oswald was interviewed by WDSU radio commentator William Stuckey, who probed Oswald's background.", u"A few days later, Oswald accepted Stuckey's invitation to take part in a radio debate with Carlos Bringuier and Bringuier's associate Edward Scannell Butler, head of the right-wing Information Council of the Americas (INCA).", u"=== Mexico ===\nMarina's friend Ruth Paine transported Marina and her child by car from New Orleans to the Paine home in Irving, Texas, near Dallas, on September 23, 1963.", u'Oswald stayed in New Orleans at least two more days to collect a $33 unemployment check.', u'It is uncertain when he left New Orleans; he is next known to have boarded a bus in Houston on September 26\u2014bound for the Mexican border, rather than Dallas\u2014and to have told other bus passengers that he planned to travel to Cuba via Mexico.', u'He arrived in Mexico City on September 27, where he applied for a transit visa at the Cuban Embassy, claiming he wanted to visit Cuba on his way to the Soviet Union.', u'The Cuban embassy officials insisted Oswald would need Soviet approval, but he was unable to get prompt co-operation from the Soviet embassy.', u'After five days of shuttling between consulates\u2014that included a heated argument with an official at the Cuban consulate, impassioned pleas to KGB agents, and at least some CIA scrutiny\u2014Oswald was told by a Cuban consular officer that he was disinclined to approve the visa, saying "a person like [Oswald] in place of aiding the Cuban Revolution, was doing it harm."', u'Later, on October 18, the Cuban embassy approved the visa, but by this time Oswald was back in the United States and had given up on his plans to visit Cuba and the Soviet Union.', u'Still later, eleven days before the assassination of President Kennedy, Oswald wrote to the Soviet embassy in Washington, D.C., saying, "Had I been able to reach the Soviet Embassy in Havana, as planned, the embassy there would have had time to complete our business."', u'While the Warren Commission concluded that Oswald had visited Mexico City and the Cuban and Soviet consulates, questions regarding whether someone posing as Oswald had appeared at the embassies were serious enough to be investigated by the House Select Committee on Assassinations.', u'Later, the Committee agreed with the Warren Commission that Oswald had visited Mexico City and concluded that "the majority of evidence tends to indicate" that Oswald in fact visited the consulates, but the Committee could not rule out the possibility that someone else had used his name in visiting the consulates.', u'=== Return to Dallas ===\n\nOn October 2, 1963, Oswald left Mexico City by bus and arrived in Dallas the next day.', u"Ruth Paine said that her neighbor told her, on October 14, that there was a job opening at the Texas School Book Depository, where her neighbor's brother, Wesley Frazier, worked.", u'Mrs. Paine informed Oswald, who was interviewed at the Depository and was hired there on October 16 as a $1.25 an hour order filler.', u'Oswald\'s supervisor, Roy S. Truly (1907-1985), said that Oswald "did a good day\'s work" and was an above-average employee.', u'During the week, Oswald stayed in a Dallas rooming house (under the name "O.H.', u'Lee"), but he spent his weekends with Marina at the Paine home in Irving.', u'Oswald did not drive, but commuted to and from Dallas on Mondays and Fridays with his co-worker Wesley Frazier.', u"On October 20, the Oswalds' second daughter, Audrey, was born.", u'FBI agents twice visited the Paine home in early November, when Oswald was not present, and spoke to Mrs. Paine.', u'Oswald visited the Dallas FBI office about 2 to 3 weeks before the assassination, asking to see Special Agent James P. Hosty.', u'When he was told that Hosty was unavailable, Oswald left a note that, according to the receptionist, read: "Let this be a warning.', u'I will blow up the FBI and the Dallas Police Department if you don\'t stop bothering my wife" [signed] "Lee Harvey Oswald."', u'The note allegedly contained some sort of threat, but accounts vary as to whether Oswald threatened to "blow up the FBI" or merely "report this to higher authorities".', u'According to Hosty, the note said, "If you have anything you want to learn about me, come talk to me directly.', u'If you don\'t cease bothering my wife, I will take the appropriate action and report this to the proper authorities."', u"Agent Hosty said that he destroyed Oswald's note on orders from his superior, Gordon Shanklin, after Oswald was named the suspect in the Kennedy assassination.", u"== John F. Kennedy and J. D. Tippit shootings ==\n\nIn the days before Kennedy's arrival, several newspapers described the route of the presidential motorcade as passing the Book Depository.", u'On November 21 (a Thursday) Oswald asked Frazier for an unusual mid-week lift back to Irving, saying he had to pick up some curtain rods.', u'The next morning (Friday) he returned to Dallas with Frazier; he left behind $170 and his wedding ring, but took with him a paper bag.', u'Frazier reported that Oswald told him the bag contained curtain rods, The evidence demonstrated that the package of "curtain rods" actually contained the rifle that Oswald was going to use for the assassination.', u"Oswald's co-worker, Charles Givens, testified to the Commission that he last saw Oswald on the 6th floor of the Texas School Book Depository (TSBD) at approximately 11:55 a.m.\u201435 minutes before the assassination.", u'The Commission report stated that Oswald was not seen again "until after the shooting."', u'However, in an FBI report taken the day after the assassination, Givens said that the encounter took place at 11:30 a.m. and that he later saw Oswald reading a newspaper in the first floor domino room at 11:50 a.m. William Shelley, a foreman at the Depository, also testified that he saw Oswald making a phone call on the first floor between 11:45 and 11:50 a.m. Janitor Eddie Piper also testified that he spoke to Oswald on the first floor at 12:00 p.m. Another co-worker, Bonnie Ray Williams, was on the sixth floor of the Depository eating his lunch and was there until at least 12:10 p.m.', u'He said that during that time, he did not see Oswald, or anyone else, on the sixth floor and thought that he was the only person up there.', u'However, he also said that some boxes in the southeast corner may have prevented him from seeing deep into the "sniper\'s nest."', u'Carolyn Arnold, the secretary to the Vice President of the TSBD, informed the FBI that as she left the building to watch the motorcade, she caught a glimpse of a man whom she believed to be Oswald standing in the first floor hallway of the building just prior to the assassination.', u"As Kennedy's motorcade passed through Dealey Plaza at about 12:30 p.m. on November 22, Oswald fired three rifle shots from the sixth-floor window of the Book Depository, killing the President and seriously wounding Texas Governor John Connally.", u'One shot apparently missed the presidential limousine entirely, another struck both Kennedy and Connally, and a third bullet struck Kennedy in the head, killing him.', u'Bystander James Tague received a minor facial injury from a small piece of curbstone that fragmented when it was struck by one of the bullets.', u'Howard Brennan, a steamfitter who was sitting across the street from the Texas School Book Depository, notified police that as he watched the motorcade go by, he heard a shot come from above, and looked up to see a man with a rifle make another shot from the southeast-corner window on the sixth floor.', u'He said he had seen the same man minutes earlier looking thought the window.', u'Brennan gave a description of the shooter, and Dallas police subsequently broadcast descriptions between 12:45 p.m., 12:48 p.m., and 12:55 p.m. After the second shot was fired, Brennan recalled, "This man I saw previous[ly] was aiming for his last shot ... and maybe paused for another second as though to assure himself that he had hit his mark."', u'According to the investigations, after the attack, Oswald hid and covered the rifle with boxes and descended through the rear stairwell.', u"About 90 seconds after the assassination, in the second-floor lunchroom, Oswald encountered police officer Marrion Baker accompanied by Oswald's supervisor Roy Truly; Baker let Oswald pass after Truly identified him as an employee.", u'According to Baker, Oswald did not appear to be "nervous" or "out of breath."', u'Truly said that Oswald look "startled" when Baker directly pointed his gun to him.', u'Mrs. Robert Reid\u2014clerical supervisor at the Depository, returning to her office within two minutes after the shooting\u2014said that she saw Oswald "was very calm" on the second floor with a Coke in his hands.', u'As they walked past each other, Mrs. Reid said to Oswald, "The President has been shot" to which he mumbled something in response, but Reid did not understand him.', u'Oswald was believed to have left the Depository through the front entrance just before police sealed it off.', u'Truly later pointed out to officers that Oswald was the only employee that he was certain was missing.', u'At about 12:40 p.m., Oswald boarded a city bus but (probably due to heavy traffic) requested a transfer from the bus driver and got off two blocks later.', u'Oswald took a taxicab to his rooming house, at 1026 North Beckley Avenue, arriving at about 1:00 p.m.', u'He entered through the front door and, according to his housekeeper Earlene Roberts, immediately went to his room, "walking pretty fast."', u'Roberts said that Oswald left "a very few minutes" later, zipping up a jacket he was not wearing when he had entered earlier.', u'As Oswald left, Roberts looked out of the window of her house and last saw him standing at the northbound Beckley Avenue bus stop in front of her house.', u'The Warren Commission concluded that at approximately 1:15 p.m., Dallas Patrolman J. D. Tippit drove up in his patrol car alongside Oswald\u2014presumably because Oswald resembled the police broadcast description of the man seen by witness Howard Brennan firing shots at the presidential motorcade.', u'He encountered Oswald near the corner of East 10th Street and North Patton Avenue.', u'This location is about nine-tenths of a mile (1.4 km) southeast of Oswald\'s rooming house\u2014a distance that the Warren Commission concluded "Oswald could have easily walked."', u'Tippit pulled alongside Oswald and "apparently exchanged words with [him] through the right front or vent window."', u'"Shortly after 1:15 p.m.", Tippit exited his car, Oswald immediately struck and killed him with four shots.', u'Numerous witnesses heard the shots and saw Oswald flee the scene holding a revolver; nine positively identified him as the man who shot Tippit and fled.', u"Four cartridge cases found at the scene were identified by expert witnesses before the Warren Commission and the House Select Committee as having been fired from the revolver later found in Oswald's possession, to the exclusion of all other weapons.", u"However, the bullets taken from Tippit's body could not be positively identified as having been fired from Oswald's revolver as the bullets were too extensively damaged to make conclusive assessments.", u'=== Capture ===\n\nShoe store manager Johnny Brewer testified that he saw Oswald "ducking into" the entrance alcove of his store.', u'Suspicious of this activity, Brewer watched Oswald continue up the street and slip into the nearby Texas Theatre without paying.', u"He alerted the theater's ticket clerk, who telephoned police at about 1:40 p.m.\nAs police arrived, the house lights were brought up and Brewer pointed out Oswald sitting near the rear of the theater.", u'Police Officer Nick McDonald testified that he was the first to reach Oswald and that Oswald seemed ready to surrender saying, "Well, it is all over now."', u'However, Officer McDonald said that Oswald pulled out a pistol tucked into the front of his pants, then pointed the pistol at him, and pulled the trigger.', u"McDonald stated that the pistol did not fire because the pistol's hammer came down on the webbing between the thumb and index finger of his hand as he grabbed for the pistol.", u'McDonald also said that Oswald struck him, but that he struck back and Oswald was disarmed.', u'As he was led from the theater, Oswald shouted he was a victim of police brutality.', u'At about 2 p.m., Oswald arrived at the Police Department building, where he was questioned by Detective Jim Leavelle about the shooting of Officer Tippit.', u"When Captain J. W. Fritz heard Oswald's name, he recognized it as that of the Book Depository employee who was reported missing and was already a suspect in the assassination.", u'Oswald was formally arraigned for the murder of Officer Tippit at 7:10 p.m., and by the end of the night (shortly after 1:30 a.m.) he had been arraigned for the assassination of President Kennedy as well.', u'Soon after his capture, Oswald encountered reporters in a hallway.', u'Oswald declared, "I didn\'t shoot anybody" and, "They\'ve taken me in because of the fact that I lived in the Soviet Union.', u'I\'m just a patsy!"', u'Later, at an arranged press meeting, a reporter asked, "Did you kill the President?"', u'and Oswald\u2014who by that time had been advised of the charge of murdering Tippit, but had not yet been arraigned in Kennedy\'s death\u2014answered, "No, I have not been charged with that.', u'In fact, nobody has said that to me yet.', u'The first thing I heard about it was when the newspaper reporters in the hall asked me that question."', u'As he was led from the room the question was called out, "What did you do in Russia?"', u'and, "How did you hurt your eye?', u'"; Oswald answered, "A policeman hit me."', u'== Police interrogation ==\n\nOswald was interrogated several times during his two days at Dallas Police Headquarters.', u'He admitted that he went to his rooming house after leaving the book depository.', u'He also admitted that he changed his clothes and armed himself with a .38 revolver before leaving his house to go to the theater.', u'However, Oswald denied killing Kennedy and Tippit, denied owning a rifle, and said two photographs of him holding a rifle and a pistol were fakes.', u'He denied telling his co-worker he wanted a ride to Irving to get curtain rods for his apartment (he said that the package contained his lunch).', u'He also denied carrying a long, bulky package to work the morning of the assassination.', u'Oswald denied knowing an "A. J. Hidell".', u'Oswald was then shown a forged Selective Service System card bearing his photograph and the alias, "Alek James Hidell" that he had in his possession at the time of his arrest.', u'Oswald refused to answer any questions concerning the card, saying "you have the card yourself and you know as much about it as I do."', u'The first interrogation of Oswald was conducted by FBI Special Agent James P. Hosty and Dallas Police Captain Will Fritz (chief of homicide) on Friday, November 22.', u'Asked to account for himself at the time of the assassination, Oswald replied that he was eating his lunch in the first floor lounge (known as the "domino room").', u'He said that he then went to the second-floor lunchroom to buy a Coca-Cola from the soda machine there and was drinking it when he encountered Dallas motorcycle policeman Marrion L. Baker, who had entered the building with his gun drawn.', u'Oswald said that while he was in the domino room, he saw two "Negro employees" walking by, one he recognized as "Junior" and a shorter man whose name he could not recall.', u'Junior Jarman and Harold Norman confirmed to the Warren Commission that they had "walked through" the domino room around noon during their lunch break.', u'When asked if anyone else was in the domino room, Norman testified that somebody else was there, but he could not remember who it was.', u'Jarman testified that Oswald was not in the domino room when he was there.', u'During one of the interrogation sessions, Deputy-sheriff Roger D. Craig entered the room and noticed that the suspect had openly confessed before his interrogators that he had left the Texas School Book Depository building around the time of the shooting, and when Capt.', u'Will Fritz tried to imply wrongdoing at Oswald\u2019s sudden departure from the building, saying to him: \u201cThis man (i.e.', u'deputy Craig) saw you leave,\u201d Oswald quickly retorted with no sense of guilt, \u201cI told you people I did.\u201d Meaning, there was nothing to conceal, in Oswald\u2019s view, at his departure from the building.', u'When Oswald was asked about the car he had gotten into, he replied: \u201cThat station wagon belongs to Mrs. Paine.', u"Don't try to drag her into this.\u201d At one point in the investigation, according to Craig, Oswald said in utter dismay, \u201cEverybody will know who I am now.\u201d The Warren Commission report, however, made it appear as though it was said in a dramatic tone, writing instead: \u201cNOW everybody will know who I am,\u201d transposing the now.", u'According to Craig, the real intonation was that of someone who had heretofore tried to conceal his identity as Deputy and that now it would be known to all; his reaction was that of dismay and disappointment at being exposed.', u'During his last interrogation on November 24, according to postal inspector Harry Holmes, Oswald was again asked where he was at the time of the shooting.', u'Holmes (who attended the interrogation at the invitation of Captain Will Fritz) said that Oswald replied that he was working on an upper floor when the shooting occurred, then went downstairs where he encountered Dallas motorcycle policeman Marrion L. Baker.', u'Oswald asked for legal representation several times while being interrogated, as well as in encounters with reporters.', u'But when H. Louis Nichols, President of the Dallas Bar Association met with him in his cell on Saturday, he declined their services, saying he wanted to be represented by John Abt, chief counsel to the Communist Party USA, or by lawyers associated with the American Civil Liberties Union.', u'Both Oswald and Ruth Paine tried to reach Abt by telephone several times Saturday and Sunday, but Abt was away for the weekend.', u"Oswald also declined his brother Robert's offer on Saturday to obtain a local attorney.", u'During an interrogation with Captain Fritz, when asked, "Are you a communist?', u'", he replied, "No, I am not a communist.', u'I am a Marxist."', u'== Death ==\n\nOn Sunday, November 24, Oswald was being led through the basement of Dallas Police Headquarters toward an armored car that was to take him to the nearby county jail.', u'At 11:21 a.m. CST, Dallas nightclub operator Jack Ruby stepped from the crowd and shot Oswald in the abdomen.', u"Oswald was taken unconscious by ambulance to Parkland Memorial Hospital\u2014the same hospital where doctors tried to save President Kennedy's life two days earlier.", u"Oswald died at 1:07 p.m. Oswald's death was announced on a TV news broadcast by Dallas police chief Jesse Curry.", u'An autopsy on Oswald was performed in the Office of the County Medical Examiner at 2:45 p.m. the same day.', u'Announcing the results of the gross autopsy, Dallas County medical examiner Earl Rose said: "The two things that we could determine were, first, that he died from a hemorrhage from a gunshot wound, and that otherwise he was a physically healthy male."', u"Rose's examination found that Ruby's bullet entered Oswald's left side in the front part of the abdomen and caused damage to his spleen, stomach, aorta, vena cava, kidney, liver, diaphragm, and eleventh rib before coming to rest on his right side.", u'A network television pool camera, there to cover the transfer, was broadcasting live; millions watching on NBC witnessed the shooting as it happened and on other networks within minutes afterward.', u'In 1964, Robert H. Jackson of the Dallas Times Herald was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for Photography for his photograph of the murder of Lee Harvey Oswald by Jack Ruby.', u'=== Ruby\'s motive ===\nRuby later said he had been distraught over Kennedy\'s death and that his motive for killing Oswald was "saving Mrs. Kennedy the discomfiture of coming back to trial."', u'Others have hypothesized that Ruby was part of a conspiracy.', u'G. Robert Blakey, chief counsel for the House Select Committee on Assassinations from 1977 to 1979, said: "The most plausible explanation for the murder of Oswald by Jack Ruby was that Ruby had stalked him on behalf of organized crime, trying to reach him on at least three occasions in the forty-eight hours before he silenced him forever."', u'=== Burial ===\n\nOswald was buried on November 25 in Shannon Rose Hill Memorial Burial Park in Fort Worth.', u'Reporters present to report on the burial were asked by officials to act as pallbearers.', u"A marker inscribed simply Oswald replaces the stolen original tombstone, which gave Oswald's full name, and birth and death dates.", u'His mother was buried beside him in 1981.', u'A claim that a look-alike Russian agent was buried in place of Oswald led to his exhumation on October 4, 1981.', u"Dental records confirmed that it was Oswald's body in the grave and he was reburied in a new coffin due to water damage to the original.", u"In 2010, the Fort Worth funeral home that held Oswald's original coffin employed a Los Angeles auction house to sell it to an undisclosed bidder for $87,468.", u"The sale was halted after Oswald's brother, Robert, learned of the transaction in a Texas newspaper and sued to reclaim the coffin.", u'In January 2015, a district judge in Tarrant County, Texas ruled that the funeral home intentionally concealed the existence of the pine coffin from Robert Oswald who had originally purchased it and believed that it been discarded after the exhumation.', u"The court ordered it returned to Oswald's brother, plus damages equal to the sale price.", u'Robert Oswald\'s attorney stated that the coffin would likely be destroyed "as soon as possible".', u'== Official investigations ==\n\n\n=== Warren Commission ===\nThe Warren Commission, created by President Lyndon B. Johnson to investigate the assassination, concluded that Oswald acted alone in assassinating Kennedy.', u"The Commission could not ascribe any one motive or group of motives to Oswald's actions:\n\nIt is apparent, however, that Oswald was moved by an overriding hostility to his environment.", u'He does not appear to have been able to establish meaningful relationships with other people.', u'He was perpetually discontented with the world around him.', u'Long before the assassination he expressed his hatred for American society and acted in protest against it.', u"Oswald's search for what he conceived to be the perfect society was doomed from the start.", u'He sought for himself a place in history\u2014a role as the "great man" who would be recognized as having been in advance of his times.', u'His commitment to Marxism and communism appears to have been another important factor in his motivation.', u'He also had demonstrated a capacity to act decisively and without regard to the consequences when such action would further his aims of the moment.', u'Out of these and the many other factors which may have molded the character of Lee Harvey Oswald there emerged a man capable of assassinating President Kennedy.', u'The proceedings of the commission were closed, though not secret, and about 3% of its files have yet to be released to the public, which has continued to provoke speculation among researchers.', u'=== Ramsey Clark Panel ===\nIn 1968, the Ramsey Clark Panel examined various photographs, X-ray films, documents, and other evidence, concluding that Kennedy was struck by two bullets fired from above and behind him, one of which traversed the base of the neck on the right side without striking bone, and the other of which entered the skull from behind and destroyed its right side.', u'=== House Select Committee ===\n\nIn 1979, after a review of the evidence and of prior investigations, the United States House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) largely concurred with the Warren Commission and was preparing to issue a finding that Oswald had acted alone in killing Kennedy.', u"However, late in the Committee's proceedings a dictabelt recording was introduced, purportedly recording sounds heard in Dealey Plaza before, during and after the shots were fired.", u'After an analysis by the firm Bolt, Beranek and Newman appeared to indicate more than three gunshots, the HSCA revised its findings to assert a "high probability that two gunmen fired" at Kennedy and that Kennedy "was probably assassinated as the result of a conspiracy."', u'Although the Committee was "unable to identify the other gunman or the extent of the conspiracy," it made a number of further findings regarding the likelihood or unlikelihood that particular groups, named in the findings, were involved.', u'Four of the twelve members of the HSCA dissented from this conclusion.', u'The acoustical evidence has since been discredited.', u'Officer H.B.', u'McLain, from whose motorcycle radio the HSCA acoustic experts said the Dictabelt evidence came, has repeatedly stated that he was not yet in Dealey Plaza at the time of the assassination.', u'McLain asked the Committee, "\u2018If it was my radio on my motorcycle, why did it not record the revving up at high speed plus my siren when we immediately took off for Parkland Hospital?\u2019\u201d\nIn 1982, a panel of twelve scientists appointed by the National Academy of Sciences, including Nobel laureates Norman Ramsey and Luis Alvarez, unanimously concluded that the acoustic evidence submitted to the HSCA was "seriously flawed", was recorded after the President had been shot, and did not indicate additional gunshots.', u'Their conclusions were later published in the journal Science.', u'In a 2001 article in the journal Science & Justice, D.B.', u'Thomas wrote that the NAS investigation was itself flawed.', u'He concluded with a 96.3 percent certainty that there were at least two gunmen firing at President Kennedy and that at least one shot came from the grassy knoll.', u"In 2005, Thomas's conclusions were rebutted in the same journal.", u'Ralph Linsker and several members of the original NAS team reanalyzed the timings of the recordings and reaffirmed the earlier conclusion of the NAS report that the alleged shot sounds were recorded approximately one minute after the assassination.', u'In 2010, D.B.', u'Thomas challenged in a book the 2005 Science & Justice article and restated his conclusion that there were at least two gunmen.', u'== Other investigations and dissenting theories ==\n\nSome critics have not accepted the conclusions of the Warren Commission and have proposed several other theories, such as that Oswald conspired with others, or was not involved at all and was framed.', u"In October 1981, with Marina's support, Oswald's grave was opened to test a theory propounded by writer Michael Eddowes: that during Oswald's stay in the Soviet Union he was replaced with a Soviet double; that it was this double, not Oswald, who killed Kennedy and who is buried in Oswald's grave; and that the exhumed remains would therefore not exhibit a surgical scar Oswald was known to carry.", u"Dental records positively identified the exhumed corpse as Oswald's, and the scar was present.", u'=== Public opinion ===\nA 2003 Gallup poll reported that 75% of Americans do not believe that Lee Harvey Oswald acted alone in assassinating President Kennedy.', u'That same year an ABC News poll found that 70% of respondents suspected that the assassination involved more than one person.', u'A 2004 Fox News poll found that 66% of Americans thought there had been a conspiracy while 74% thought there had been a cover-up.', u'A Gallup Poll taken in mid-November 2013, showed 61% believed in a conspiracy, and only 30% thought Oswald acted alone.', u'=== Fictional trials ===\nSeveral films have fictionalized a trial of Oswald, depicting what may have happened had Ruby not killed Oswald.', u'The Trial of Lee Harvey Oswald (1964); The Trial of Lee Harvey Oswald (1977); and On Trial: Lee Harvey Oswald (1986) have fictionalized a trial of Oswald.', u'In 1988, a 21-hour unscripted mock trial was held on television, argued by lawyers before a judge, with unscripted testimony from surviving witnesses to the events surrounding the assassination; the jury returned a verdict of guilty.', u'In 1992 the American Bar Association conducted two mock Oswald trials.', u'The first trial ended in a hung jury.', u'In the second trial the jury acquitted Oswald.', u'== Backyard photos ==\n\nThe "backyard photos", taken by Marina Oswald probably around March 31, 1963 using a camera belonging to Oswald, show Oswald holding two Marxist newspapers\u2014The Militant and The Worker\u2014and a rifle, and wearing a pistol in a holster.', u"Shown the pictures after his arrest, Oswald insisted they were forgeries, but Marina testified in 1964 that she had taken the photographs at Oswald's request\u2014 testimony she reaffirmed repeatedly over the decades.", u'These photos were labelled CE 133-A and CE 133-B.', u"CE 133-A shows the rifle in Oswald's left hand and newspapers in front of his chest in the other, while the rifle is held with the right hand in CE 133-B.", u'Oswald\'s mother testified that on the day after the assassination she and Marina destroyed another photograph with Oswald holding the rifle with both hands over his head, with "To my daughter June" written on it.', u'The HSCA obtained another first-generation print (from CE 133-A) on April 1, 1977, from the widow of George de Mohrenschildt.', u'The words "Hunter of fascists\u2014ha ha ha!"', u'written in block Russian were on the back.', u'Also in English were added in script: "To my friend George, Lee Oswald, 5/IV/63 [April 5, 1963]."', u'Handwriting experts for the HSCA concluded the English inscription and signature were by Oswald.', u'After two original photos, one negative and one first-generation copy had been found, the Senate Intelligence Committee located (in 1976) a third backyard photo (CE 133-C) showing Oswald with newspapers held away from his body in his right hand.', u'These photos, widely recognized as some of the most significant evidence against Oswald, have been subjected to rigorous analysis.', u'Photographic experts consulted by the HSCA concluded they were genuine, answering twenty-one points raised by critics.', u"Marina Oswald has always maintained she took the photos herself, and the 1963 de Mohrenschildt print bearing Oswald's signature clearly indicate they existed before the assassination.", u'Nonetheless, some continue to contest their authenticity.', u'In 2009, after digitally analyzing the photograph of Oswald holding the rifle and paper, computer scientist Hany Farid concluded that the photo "almost certainly was not altered."', u'== See also ==\n\nJohn F. Kennedy assassination conspiracy theories\n\n\n== Notes ==\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== Further reading ==\nBugliosi, Vincent.', u'Reclaiming History: The Assassination of President John F. {'sentences': [u'A crew is a body or a class of people who work at a common activity, generally in a structured or hierarchical organization.', u'A location in which a crew works is called a crewyard or a workyard.', u"The word has nautical resonances: the tasks involved in operating a ship, particularly a sailing ship, providing numerous specialities within a ship's crew, often organised with a chain of command.", u"Traditional nautical usage strongly distinguishes officers from crew, though the two groups combined form the ship's company.", u'Members of a crew are often referred to by the title Crewman.', u'Crew also refers to the sport of rowing, where teams row competitively in racing shells.', u'== See also ==\nFor a specific sporting usage, see rowing crew.', u'For filmmaking usage, see film crew.', u'For live music usage, see road crew.', u'For analogous entities in research on human judgment and decision-making, see team and judge\u2013advisor system.', u'For stagecraft usage, see stage crew.', u'For video production usage, see television crew.', u"For the comic strip, see Motley's Crew.", u'For the sports team, see Columbus Crew.', u'For the 2014 video game, see The Crew (video game).', u'For crews in aviation and the airline industry, see groundcrew and aircrew.', u'Tank crew\nBoat crew\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== External links ==\nYacht Job Descriptions and Salary Guide'], 'year': '1978-11-02', 'title': 'Crew of Soyuz 29 returns to Earth aboard Soyuz 31'}
{'sentences': [u'This is a list of diplomatic missions of the United States of America.', u"== History ==\nIt is said that Morocco, in December 1777, became the first nation to seek diplomatic relations with the United States and together they maintain the United States' longest unbroken treaty.", u'However the claim also goes to the Netherlands, as they were the first to recognize the United States as an independent government.', u'Benjamin Franklin established the first overseas mission of the United States in Paris in 1779.', u'On April 19, 1782, John Adams was received by the States-General and the Dutch Republic as they were the first country together with Morocco and France, to recognize the United States as an independent government.', u'Adams then became the first U.S. ambassador to the Netherlands and the house that he had purchased at Fluwelen Burgwal 18 in The Hague, became the first American embassy anywhere in the world.', u'In the period following the American Revolution, George Washington sent a number of close advisers to the courts of European potentates in order to garner recognition of U.S. independence with mixed results, including Thomas Jefferson, John Adams, Francis Dana, and John Jay.', u'Much of the first fifty years of the Department of State concerned negotiating with imperial European powers over the territorial integrity of the borders of the United States as known today.', u'The first overseas consulate of the fledgling United States was founded in 1790 at Liverpool, England, by James Maury Jr., who was appointed by Washington.', u'Maury held the post from 1790 to 1829.', u"Liverpool was at the time Britain's leading port for transatlantic commerce and therefore of great economic importance to the United States.", u'The first overseas property owned, and the longest continuously owned, by the United States is the American Legation in Tangier, which was a gift of the Sultan of Morocco in 1821.', u"In general during the nineteenth century, the United States' diplomatic activities were done on a minimal budget.", u'The U.S. owned no property abroad and provided no official residences for its foreign envoys, paid them a minimal salary, and gave them the rank of ministers rather than ambassadors who represented the great powers\u2014a position which the U.S. only achieved towards the end of the nineteenth century.', u'In the latter half of the nineteenth century, the State Department was concerned with expanding commercial ties in Asia, establishing Liberia, foiling diplomatic recognition of the Confederacy during the American Civil War, and securing its presence in North America.', u'The Confederacy had diplomatic missions in the United Kingdom, France, Belgium, the Papal States, Russia, Mexico, and Spain, and consular missions in Ireland, Canada, Cuba, Italy, Bermuda, and Nassau and New Providence.', u"The United States' global prominence became evident in the twentieth century, and the State {'sentences': [u'A battle is a combat in warfare between two or more armed forces, or combatants.', u'A war sometimes consists of many battles.', u'Battles generally are well defined in duration, area, and force commitment.', u'Wars and military campaigns are guided by strategy, whereas battles take place on a level of planning and execution known as operational mobility.', u'German strategist Carl von Clausewitz stated that "the employment of battles ... to achieve the object of war" was the essence of strategy.', u'== Etymology ==\nBattle is a loanword from the Old French bataille, first attested in 1297, from Late Latin battualia, meaning "exercise of soldiers and gladiators in fighting and fencing", from Late Latin (taken from Germanic) battuere "beat", from which the English word battery is also derived via Middle English batri.', u'== Characteristics ==\nThe defining characteristic of the fight as a concept in Military science has been a dynamic one through the course of military history, changing with the changes in the organisation, employment and technology of military forces.', u'While the English military historian Sir John Keegan suggested an ideal definition of battle as "something which happens between two armies leading to the moral then physical disintegration of one or the other of them", the origins and outcomes of battles can rarely be summarized so neatly.', u'In general a battle during the 20th century was, and continues to be, defined by the combat between opposing forces representing major components of total forces committed to a military campaign, used to achieve specific military objectives.', u'Where the duration of the battle is longer than a week, it is often for reasons of staff operational planning called an operation.', u'Battles can be planned, encountered, or forced by one force on the other when the latter is unable to withdraw from combat.', u'A battle always has as its purpose the reaching of a mission goal by use of military force.', u'A victory in the battle is achieved when one of the opposing sides forces the other to abandon its mission, or to surrender its forces, or routs the other, i.e., forces it to retreat or renders it militarily ineffective for further combat operations.', u'However, a battle may end in a Pyrrhic victory, which ultimately favors the defeated party.', u'If no resolution is reached in a battle, it can result in a stalemate.', u'A conflict in which one side is unwilling to reach a decision by a direct battle using conventional warfare often becomes an insurgency.', u'Until the 19th century the majority of battles were of short duration, many lasting a part of a day.', u'(The Battle of Nations (1813) and the Battle of Gettysburg (1863) were exceptional in lasting three days.)', u'This was mainly due to the difficulty of supplying armies in the field, or conducting night operations.', u'The means of prolonging a battle was typically by employment of siege warfare.', u'Improvements in transportation and the sudden evolving of trench warfare, with its siege-like nature during World War I in the 20th century, lengthened the duration of battles to days and weeks.', u'This created the requirement for unit rotation to prevent combat fatigue, with troops preferably not remaining in a combat area of operations for more than a month.', u'Trench warfare had become largely obsolete in conflicts between advanced armies by the start of the Second World War.', u'The use of the term "battle" in military history has led to its misuse when referring to almost any scale of combat, notably by strategic forces involving hundreds of thousands of troops that may be engaged in either a single battle at one time (Battle of Leipzig) or multiple operations (Battle of Kursk).', u'The space a battle occupies depends on the range of the weapons of the combatants.', u'A "battle" in this broader sense may be of long duration and take place over a large area, as in the case of the Battle of Britain or the Battle of the Atlantic.', u'Until the advent of artillery and aircraft, battles were fought with the two sides within sight, if not reach, of each other.', u'The depth of the battlefield has also increased in modern warfare with inclusion of the supporting units in the rear areas; supply, artillery, medical personnel etc.', u'often outnumber the front-line combat troops.', u"Battles are, on the whole, made up of a multitude of individual combats, skirmishes and small engagements within the context of which the combatants will usually only experience a small part of the events of the battle's entirety.", u"To the infantryman, there may be little to distinguish between combat as part of a minor raid or as a major offensive, nor is it likely that he anticipates the future course of the battle; few of the British infantry who went over the top on the first day on the Somme, July 1, 1916, would have anticipated that they would be fighting the same battle in five months' time.", u'Conversely, some of the Allied infantry who had just dealt a crushing defeat to the French at the Battle of Waterloo fully expected to have to fight again the next day (at the Battle of Wavre).', u'== Battlespace ==\n\nBattlespace is a unified strategy to integrate and combine armed forces for the military theatre of operations, including air, information, land, sea and space.', u'It includes the environment, factors and conditions that must be understood to successfully apply combat power, protect the force, or complete the mission.', u'This includes enemy and friendly armed forces; facilities; weather; terrain; and the electromagnetic spectrum within the operational areas and areas of interest.', u'== Factors ==\nBattles are decided by various factors.', u'The number and quality of combatants and equipment, the skill of the commanders of each army, and the terrain advantages are among the most prominent factors.', u'A unit may charge with high morale but less discipline and still emerge victorious.', u'This tactic was effectively used by the early French Revolutionary Armies.', u'Weapons and armour can be a decisive factor.', u'On many occasions armies have achieved victories largely owing to the employment of more advanced weapons than those of their opponents.', u'An extreme example was in the Battle of Omdurman, in which a large army of Sudanese Mahdists armed in a traditional manner were destroyed by an Anglo-Egyptian force equipped with Maxim guns.', u'On some occasions, simple weapons employed in an unorthodox fashion have proven advantageous, as with the Swiss pikemen who gained many victories through their ability to transform a traditionally defensive weapon into an offensive one.', u'Likewise, the Zulus in the early 19th century were victorious in battles against their rivals in part because they adopted a new kind of spear, the iklwa.', u'Even so, forces with inferior weapons have still emerged victorious at times, for example in the Wars of Scottish Independence and in the First Italo\u2013Ethiopian War.', u'Discipline within the troops is often of greater importance; at the Battle of Alesia, the Romans were greatly outnumbered but won because of superior training.', u'Battles can also be determined by terrain.', u'Capturing high ground, for example, has been the central strategy in innumerable battles.', u'An army that holds the high ground forces the enemy to climb, and thus wear themselves down.', u'Areas of dense vegetation, such as jungles and forest, act as force-multipliers, of benefit to inferior armies.', u'Arguably, terrain is of less importance in modern warfare, due to the advent of aircraft, though terrain is still vital for camouflage, especially for guerrilla warfare.', u'Generals and commanders also play a decisive role during combat.', u'Hannibal, Julius Caesar, Khalid ibn Walid and Napoleon Bonaparte were all skilled generals and, consequently, their armies were extremely successful.', u'An army that can trust the commands of their leaders with conviction in its success invariably has a higher morale than an army that doubts its every move.', u'The British in the naval Battle of Trafalgar, for example, owed its success to the reputation of celebrated admiral Lord Nelson.', u'== Types ==\n\nBattles can be fought on land, at sea and, in the modern age, in the air.', u'Naval battles have occurred since before the 5th century BC.', u'Air battles have been far less common, due to their late conception, the most prominent being the Battle of Britain in 1940.', u'However, since the Second World War land or sea battles have come to rely on air support.', u'Indeed, during the Battle of Midway, five aircraft carriers were sunk without either fleet coming into direct contact.', u'There are numerous types of battles:\nA battle of encounter (or encounter battle) is a meeting engagement where the opposing sides collide in the field without either having prepared their attack or defence.', u"A battle of attrition aims to inflict losses on an enemy that are less sustainable compared to one's own losses.", u'These need not be greater numerical losses \u2013 if one side is much more numerous than the other than pursuing a strategy based on attrition can work even if casualties on both sides are about equal.', u'Many battles of the Western Front in the First World War were intentionally (Verdun) or unintentionally (Somme) attrition battles.', u"A battle of breakthrough aims to pierce the enemy's defences, thereby exposing the vulnerable flanks which can be turned.", u'A battle of encirclement\u2014the Kesselschlacht of the German Blitzkrieg\u2014surrounds the enemy in a pocket.', u'A battle of envelopment involves an attack on one or both flanks; the classic example being the double-envelopment of the Battle of Cannae.', u'A battle of annihilation is one in which the defeated party is destroyed in the field, such as the French fleet at the Battle of the Nile.', u'Battles frequently do not fit one particular type perfectly, and are usually hybrids of different types listed above.', u'A decisive battle is one of particular importance; often by bringing hostilities to an end, such as the Battle of Hastings or the Battle of Hattin, or as a turning point in the fortunes of the belligerents, such as the Battle of Stalingrad.', u'A decisive battle can have political as well as military impact, changing the balance of power or boundaries between countries.', u"The concept of the decisive battle became popular with the publication in 1851 of Edward Creasy's The Fifteen Decisive Battles of the World.", u'British military historians J.F.C.', u'Fuller (The Decisive Battles of the Western World) and B.H.', u"Liddell Hart (Decisive Wars of History), among many others, have written books in the style of Creasy's work.", u'=== Land ===\nThere is an obvious difference in the way battles have been fought throughout time.', u'Early battles were probably fought between rival hunting bands as disorganized mobs.', u'However, during the Battle of Megiddo, the first reliably documented battle in the fifteenth century BC, actual discipline was instilled in both armies.', u'However, during the many wars of the Roman Empire, barbarians continued using mob tactics.', u'As the Age of Enlightenment dawned, armies began to fight in highly disciplined lines.', u'Each would follow the orders from their officers and fight as a single unit instead of individuals.', u'Each army was successively divided into regiments, battalions, companies, and platoons.', u'These armies would march, line up, and fire in divisions.', u'Native Americans, on the other hand, did not fight in lines, utilizing instead guerrilla tactics.', u'American colonists and European forces continued using disciplined lines, continuing into the American Civil War.', u'A new style, during World War I, known as trench warfare, developed nearly half a century later.', u'This also led to radio for communication between battalions.', u'Chemical warfare also emerged with the use of poisonous gas during World War I.', u'By World War II, the use of the smaller divisions, platoons and companies became much more important as precise operations became vital.', u'Instead of the locked trench warfare of World War I, during World War II, a dynamic network of battles developed where small groups encountered other platoons.', u'As a result, elite squads became much more recognized and distinguishable.', u'Maneuver warfare also developed with an astonishing pace with the advent of the tank, replacing the archaic cannons of the Enlightenment Age.', u'Artillery has since gradually replaced the use of frontal troops.', u'Modern battles now continue to resemble those of World War II, though prominent innovations have been added.', u'Indirect combat through the use of aircraft and missiles now constitutes a large portion of wars in place of battles, where battles are now mostly reserved for capturing cities.', u'=== Naval ===\n\nOne significant difference of modern naval battles as opposed to earlier forms of combat is the use of marines, which introduced amphibious warfare.', u'Today, a marine is actually an infantry regiment that sometimes fights solely on land and is no longer tied to the navy.', u'A good example of an old naval battle is the Battle of Salamis.', u'Most ancient naval battles were fought by fast ships using the battering ram to sink opposing fleets or steer close enough for boarding in hand-to-hand combat.', u'Troops were often used to storm enemy ships as used by Romans and pirates.', u'This tactic was usually used by civilizations that could not beat the enemy with ranged weaponry.', u'Another invention in the late Middle Ages was the use of Greek fire by the Byzantines, which was used to set enemy fleets on fire.', u'Empty demolition ships utilized the tactic to crash into opposing ships and set it afire with an explosion.', u'After the invention of cannons, naval warfare became useful as support units for land warfare.', u'During the 19th century, the development of mines led to a new type of naval warfare.', u'The ironclad, first used in the American Civil War, resistant to cannons, soon made the wooden ship obsolete.', u'The invention of military submarines, during World War I, brought naval warfare to both above and below the surface.', u'With the development of military aircraft during World War II, battles were fought in the sky as well as below the ocean.', u'Aircraft carriers have since become the central unit in naval warfare, acting as a mobile base for lethal aircraft.', u'=== Aerial ===\nAlthough the use of aircraft has for the most part always been used as a supplement to land or naval engagements, since their first major military use in World War I aircraft have increasingly taken on larger roles in warfare.', u'During World War I, the primary use was for reconnaissance, and small-scale bombardment.', u'Aircraft began becoming much more prominent in the Spanish Civil War and especially World War II.', u'Aircraft design began specializing, primarily into two types: bombers, which carried explosive payloads to bomb land targets or ships; and fighter-interceptors, which were used to either intercept incoming aircraft or to escort and protect bombers (engagements between fighter aircraft were known as dog fights).', u'Some of the more notable aerial battles in this period include the Battle of Britain and the Battle of Midway.', u'Another important use of aircraft came with the development of the helicopter, which first became heavily used during the Vietnam War, and still continues to be widely used today to transport and augment ground forces.', u'Today, direct engagements between aircraft are rare \u2013 the most modern fighter-interceptors carry much more extensive bombing payloads, and are used to bomb precision land targets, rather than to fight other aircraft.', u'Anti-aircraft batteries are used much more extensively to defend against incoming aircraft than interceptors.', u'Despite this, aircraft today are much more extensively used as the primary tools for both army and navy, as evidenced by the prominent use of helicopters to transport and support troops, the use of aerial bombardment as the "first strike" in many engagements, and the replacement of the battleship with the aircraft carrier as the center of most modern navies.', u'== Naming ==\n\nBattles are usually named after some feature of the battlefield geography, such as the name of a town, forest or river, commonly prefixed "Battle of...".', u'Occasionally battles are named after the date on which they took place, such as The Glorious First of June.', u'In the Middle Ages it was considered important to settle on a suitable name for a battle which could be used by the chroniclers.', u'For example, after Henry V of England defeated a French army on October 25, 1415, he met with the senior French herald and they agreed to name the battle after the nearby castle and so it was called the Battle of Agincourt.', u'In other cases, the sides adopted different names for the same battle, such as the Battle of Gallipoli which is known in Turkey as the Battle of \xc7anakkale.', u'During the American Civil War, the Union tended to name the battles after the nearest watercourse, such as the Battle of Wilsons Creek and the Battle of Stones River, whereas the Confederates favoured the nearby towns, as in the Battles of Chancellorsville and Murfreesboro.', u'Occasionally both names for the same battle entered the popular culture, such as the First and Second Battle of Bull Run, which are also referred to as the First and Second Battle of Manassas.', u'Sometimes in desert warfare, there is no nearby town name to use; map coordinates gave the name to the Battle of 73 Easting in the First Gulf War.', u'Some place names have become synonymous with the battles that took place there, such as the Passchendaele, Pearl Harbor, the Alamo, Thermopylae, or Waterloo.', u'Military operations, many of which result in battle, are given codenames, which are not necessarily meaningful or indicative of the type or the location of the battle.', u'Operation Market Garden and Operation Rolling Thunder are examples of battles known by their military codenames.', u'When a battleground is the site of more than one battle in the same conflict, the instances are distinguished by ordinal number, such as the First and Second Battles of Bull Run.', u'An extreme case are the twelve Battles of the Isonzo\u2014First to Twelfth\u2014between Italy and Austria-Hungary during the First World War.', u'Some battles are named for the convenience of military historians so that periods of combat can be neatly distinguished from one another.', u'Following the First World War, the British Battles Nomenclature Committee was formed to decide on standard names for all battles and subsidiary actions.', u'To the soldiers who did the fighting, the distinction was usually academic; a soldier fighting at Beaumont Hamel on November 13, 1916 was probably unaware he was taking part in what the committee would call the "Battle of the Ancre".', u'Many combats are too small to merit a name.', u'Terms such as "action", "skirmish", "firefight", "raid" or "offensive patrol" are used to describe small-scale battle-like encounters.', u'These combats often take place within the time and space of a battle and while they may have an objective, they are not necessarily "decisive".', u'Sometimes the soldiers are unable to immediately gauge the significance of the combat; in the aftermath of the Battle of Waterloo, some British officers were in doubt as to whether the day\'s events merited the title of "battle" or would be passed off as merely an "action".', u'== Effects ==\nBattles affect the individuals who take part, as well as the political actors.', u'Personal effects of battle range from mild psychological issues to permanent and crippling injuries.', u'Some battle-survivors have nightmares about the conditions they encountered, or abnormal reactions to certain sights or sounds.', u'Some suffer flashbacks.', u'Physical effects of battle can include scars, amputations, lesions, loss of bodily functions, blindness, paralysis \u2014 and death.', u'Battles also affect politics.', u'A decisive battle can cause the losing side to surrender, while a Pyrrhic Victory such as the Battle of Asculum can cause the winning side to reconsider its long-term goals.', u'Battles in civil wars have often decided the fate of monarchs or political factions.', u'Famous examples include the War of the Roses, as well as the Jacobite Uprisings.', u'Battles also affect the commitment of one side or the other to the continuance of a war, for example the Battle of Incheon and the Battle of Hue during the Tet Offensive.', u'== See also ==\nList of battles\nMilitary strategy\nMilitary tactics\nNaval battle\nPitched battle\nSkirmisher\nWar\n\n\n== References ==\n\nSources'], 'year': '1811-11-07', 'title': 'Battle of Tippecanoe gave Harrison a presial slogan'}

Hockey League (NHL) from 1975 to 1977.', u'He was an NHL All-Star and Bill Masterton Memorial Trophy winner.', u'Martin played seventeen seasons in the NHL for the Detroit Red Wings, Boston Bruins, the Red Wings organization.', u'He is remembered among hockey fans as being involved in one of the most one-sided trades in history.', u'In May 1967, Martin, along with Gilles Marotte and Jack Norris, was traded from Boston to Chicago for Phil Esposito, Ken Hodge, and Fred Stanfield, who would become core elements of future Boston powerhouse teams.', u'However, Martin himself was a bright spot of the trade for the Black Hawks, starring for them for ten seasons as a skilled two-way centre and being named to play in the NHL All-Star Game in four straight seasons.', u'Martin played 1101 career NHL games from 1961\u201362 to 1978\u201379.', u'He recorded 324 goals and 485 assists for 809 points.', u'His best statistical season was the 1972\u201373 season when he set career highs with 61
