{'sentences': [u'The Consolidated Model 2 was a PT-1 biplane trainer diverted to the United States Navy for a trainer competition in 1925.', u'It beat out 14 other designs, and was ordered into production as the NY-1.', u'== Development ==\nThe NY-1 was essentially a PT-1 with provisions for the wheeled landing gear to be replaced by a single large float under the fuselage and two stabilising floats under the tips of the lower wing.', u'A larger vertical tail was added to counter the effect of the floats.', u'The NY-2 had a longer span wing fitted to overcome the high wing-loading issue of the seaplane version.', u'Tested with complete success during October 1926, the Navy ordered 181 with the uprated R-790-8 Wright Whirlwind J-5 engine of 220 hp (160 kW).', u'The NY-3 aircraft were similar to the NY-2 but had 240 hp (180 kW) Wright R-760-94 engines.', u"== Operational history ==\nThe NY-1's first flight was November 1925, with deliveries starting May 1926.", {'sentences': [u'Yanks is a 1979 period drama film set during World War II in Northern England.', u'The film was directed by John Schlesinger and starred Richard Gere, Vanessa Redgrave, William Devane, Lisa Eichhorn and Tony Melody.', u"It was Schlesinger's first British film since Sunday Bloody Sunday which he directed in 1971.", u'Despite being set during the Second World War, the film is a character study which features no combat or fighting scenes.', u'The film depicts the relationships between American soldiers stationed in semi-rural Northern England and the local population during the build-up to Operation Overlord in 1944.', u'In particular, three romances between US service personnel and local women are shown, in order to explore the effects of the cultural differences between the brash GIs or "Yanks" and the more reserved British population.', u'== Plot ==\nThis film opens with the narration: "From early 1942 until the invasion of Europe over a million Americans landed in Britain.', u'They came to serve on other battle fronts or to man the vast U.S. bases in England.', u'Hardly a city, town or village remained untouched."', u'A small northern town soon finds out that a large U.S. Army base is being established for the build-up to the Normandy landings.', u'Soon thousands of rambunctious American troops, or "Yanks" as they are known to the British, descend upon the area.', u'On leave in the town, an Arizona man, Sergeant First Class Matt Dyson (Richard Gere), encounters Jean Moreton (Lisa Eichhorn) while out to the cinema.', u"She is the fianc\xe9e of Ken, a British soldier fighting overseas, and initially rebuffs Matt's advances.", u'He is quite persistent, and she, doubtful about her relationship with Ken, eventually accepts him.', u'The handsome, brash American sergeant is in stark contrast to the restrained Englishmen she has known.', u'Soon, she is keeping company with Matt, though it is largely platonic at first.', u'For her part, Helen (Vanessa Redgrave) is a bit more worldly in her affairs.', u'Captain John (William Devane) comes to her estate often, and a relationship develops.', u'They are both married, but her husband is away at sea, and his wife is thousands of miles distant.', u"Eventually, the kind-hearted Matt Dyson is accepted by the Moreton family, notwithstanding Jean's engagement.", u'They welcome his visits, when he, as an army cook, often brings hard-to-find foods normally on wartime rationing and other presents.', u"But when news of Ken's death in action arrives, Jean's ailing mother (Rachel Roberts) condemns their relationship as a kind of betrayal.", u'Jean and Matt travel together to a Welsh seaside resort, where they make love but without completion.', u'Jean is crushed, although Matt says "not like this."', u'She feels spurned, and that her willingness to risk everything has not been matched by him, concluding that he is "not ready" for her.', u'Shortly afterwards, the Americans ship out by troop train to Southern England to prepare for D-Day.', u'A characteristic last-minute gift and message from Matt prompt Jean into racing to the railway station.', u'With the town and station a hive of activity, hundreds of the townswomen, some of them pregnant from liaisons with men they may never see again, scramble to catch one last glimpse of their American boyfriends before the train leaves.', u'Matt shouts from the departing train that he will return.', u'== Cast ==\nRichard Gere as 1st Sgt Matt Dyson\nLisa Eichhorn as Jean Moreton\nVanessa Redgrave as Helen\nWilliam Devane as camp\n\n\n== Production ==\nSchlesinger was able to obtain the finance to make Yanks - which was a personal project - because of the financial success of his 1976 suspense film Marathon Man.', u'Much of the filming took place on location in Northern England between April and August 1978.', u'Scenes were shot on location in Oldham, Glossop, Stalybridge, Stockport and other surrounding areas.', u'The opening shot of the film is the war memorial in Stalybridge town centre.', u'Other scenes were filmed at the town hall in Hyde and outside a pillbox attached to a former Royal Ordnance Factory in Steeton, West Yorkshire.', u'However the cinema sequences were shot at the Davenport cinema in Stockport which was chosen due to a period Art Deco interior as well as the presence in the orchestra pit in front of the screen of a Compton 3Manual/6Ranks theatre organ on a rising platform to the left of the stage which was used in the film for scenes involving an audience sing-along to such songs as "Praise the Lord and Pass the Ammunition" and "Deep in the Heart of Texas" and exterior shots of the unnamed Welsh resort were filmed along Happy Valley Road, Llandudno, North Wales.', u'The ending, where the troops board their train to head to the front, were filmed at Keighley railway station on the line belonging to the Keighley and Worth Valley Railway.', u'An authentic Second World {'sentences': [u'Operation Highjump, officially titled The United States Navy Antarctic Developments Program, 1946\u20131947, was a United States Navy operation organized by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, Jr., USN (Ret), Officer in Charge, Task Force 68, and led by Rear Admiral Richard H. Cruzen, USN, Commanding Officer, Task Force 68.', u'Operation Highjump commenced 26 August 1946 and ended in late February 1947.', u'Task Force 68 included 4,700 men, 13 ships, and 33 aircraft.', u"Operation Highjump's primary mission was to establish the Antarctic research base Little America IV.", u"Highjump\u2019s objectives, according to the U.S. Navy report of the operation, were:\nTraining personnel and testing equipment in frigid conditions;\nConsolidating and extending the United States' sovereignty over the largest practicable area of the Antarctic continent (publicly denied as a goal even before the expedition ended);\nDetermining the feasibility of establishing, maintaining, and utilizing bases in the Antarctic and investigating possible base sites;\nDeveloping techniques for establishing, maintaining, and utilizing air bases on ice, with particular attention to later applicability of such techniques to operations in interior Greenland, where conditions are comparable to those in the Antarctic;\nAmplifying existing stores of knowledge of electromagnetic, geological, geographic, hydrographic, and meteorological propagation conditions in the area;\nSupplementary objectives of the Nanook expedition (a smaller equivalent conducted off eastern Greenland).", u'== Timeline ==\nThe Western Group of ships reached the Marquesas Islands on December 12, 1946, whereupon the Henderson and Cacapon set up weather monitoring stations.', u'By December 24, the Currituck had begun launching aircraft on reconnaissance missions.', u'The Eastern Group of ships reached Peter I Island in late December 1946.', u'On January 1, 1947, Lieutenant Commander Thompson and Chief Petty Officer Dixon utilized "Jack Browne" masks and DESCO Oxygen rebreathers to log the first dive by Americans under the Antarctic.', u'Paul Allman Siple, Ph.D. was the senior U.S. War Department representative on the expedition.', u'Dr. Siple was the same Eagle Scout who accompanied Admiral Byrd on the previous Byrd Antarctic expeditions.', u'== Human losses ==\nOn December 30, 1946, aviation radiomen Wendell K. Hendersin, Fredrick W. Williams, and Ensign Maxwell A. Lopez were killed when their Martin PBM Mariner George 1 crashed during a blizzard.', u'The surviving six crew members were rescued 13 days later, including aviation radioman James H. Robbins and co-pilot William Kearns.', u'A plaque honoring the three killed crewmen was later erected at the McMurdo Station research base, and Mount Lopez on Thurston Island was named in honor of killed airman Maxwell A. Lopez.', u'In December 2004, an attempt was made to locate the remains of the plane.', u'There are ongoing efforts to repatriate the bodies of the three men killed in the crash.', u'Some time after December 30, 1946, Vance N. Woodall died during a "ship unloading accident".', u'In a crew profile, deckman Edward Beardsley described his worst memory as "when Seaman Vance Woodall died on the Ross Ice Shelf under a piece of roller equipment designed to \'pave\' the ice to build an airstrip."', u'== Afterwards ==\nFather William Menster served as chaplain during the expedition, and in a service in 1947 he consecrated Antarctica.', u'The Central Group of ships reached the Bay of Whales on January 15, 1947, where they constructed temporary runways along the glaciers in a base dubbed Little America IV.', u'Naval ships and personnel were withdrawn back to the United States in late February 1947, and the expedition was terminated due to the early approach of winter and worsening weather conditions.', u"Admiral Byrd discussed the lessons learned from the operation in an interview with Lee van Atta of International News Service held aboard the expedition's command ship the USS Mount Olympus.", u'The interview appeared in the Wednesday, March 5, 1947 edition of the Chilean newspaper El Mercurio and read in part as follows:\n\nAdmiral Richard E. Byrd warned today that the United States should adopt measures of protection against the possibility of an invasion of the country by hostile planes coming from the polar regions.', u'The admiral explained that he was not trying to scare anyone, but the cruel reality is that in case of a new war, the United States could be attacked by planes flying over one or both poles.', u'This statement was made as part of a recapitulation of his own polar experience, in an exclusive interview with International News Service.', u'Talking about the recently completed expedition, Byrd said that the most important result of his observations and discoveries is the potential effect that they have in relation to the security of the United States.', u'The fantastic speed with which the world is shrinking \u2013 recalled the admiral \u2013 is one of the most important lessons learned during his recent Antarctic exploration.', u'I have to warn my compatriots that the time has ended when we were able to take refuge in our isolation and rely on the certainty that the distances, the oceans, and the poles were a guarantee of safety.', u'After the operation ended, a follow-up Operation Windmill returned to the area in order to provide ground-truthing to the aerial photography of Highjump from 1947-1948.', u'Finn Ronne also financed a private operation to the same territory until 1948.', u'As with other U.S. Antarctic expeditions, interested persons were allowed to send letters with enclosed envelopes to the base, where commemorative cachets were added to their enclosures, which were then returned to the senders.', u'These souvenir philatelic covers are readily available at low cost.', u'== Participating units ==\n\nTask Force 68\nRear Admiral Richard H. Campbell, USN, Commanding\nBase Little America IV\n\n\n== In media ==\nThe documentary about the expedition The Secret Land was filmed entirely by military photographers (both USN and US Army) and narrated by actors Robert Taylor, Robert Montgomery, and Van Heflin.', u'It features Chief of Naval Operations Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz in a scene where he is discussing Operation Highjump with admirals Byrd and Cruzen.', u'The film has re-enacted scenes of critical events, such as shipboard damage control and Admiral Byrd throwing items out of an airplane to lighten it to avoid crashing into a mountain.', u'It won the 1948 Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature.', u'As of 2015 Christopher Brand has a film in development of Operation Highjump entitled "Highjump".', u'In the fictional Area 51 books, the operation was cover for retrieving buried alien ships at the North Pole.', u'A Russian made documentary claims that the units of Operation Highjump were attacked by flying saucers, operated by a secret Nazi base on Antartica, constructed before and during WWII through various Nazi expeditions (including those of the Swabenland)\n\n\n== See also ==\nList of Antarctic expeditions\nMilitary activity in the Antarctic\nNew Swabia\n\n\n== References ==\n\n This article incorporates public domain material from websites or documents of the United States Coast Guard.', u'== Bibliography ==\nColin, Summerhayes; Beeching, Peter (2007).', u'"Hitler\'s Antarctic base: the myth and the reality".', u'Polar Record (full text).', u'43 (1): 1. doi:10.1017/S003224740600578X.', u'== Further reading ==\nNavy Proudly Ends Its Antarctic Mission; Air National Guard Assumes 160-Year Task.', u'Chicago Tribune; February 22, 1998.', u'Antarctic Mayday: The Crash of the George One Read the story of one of the survivors - James Haskin(Robbie) Robbins\nOperation Highjump: A Tragedy on Ice\nWhere Hell Freezes Over by David A. {'sentences': [u'Natalie Wood (born Natalia Zakharenko; July 20, 1938 \u2013 November 28 or 29, 1981) was an American film and television actress born to Russian parents.', u'She was known for her screen roles in Miracle on 34th Street, Splendor in the Grass, Rebel Without a Cause, The Searchers, and West Side Story.', u'She first worked in films as a child, then became a successful Hollywood star as a young adult, receiving three Academy Award nominations before she was 25-years-old.', u"Wood began acting in movies at the age of four and, at age eight, was given a co-starring role with Maureen O'Hara in the classic Christmas film Miracle on 34th Street.", u'As a teenager, her performance in Rebel Without a Cause (1955) earned her a nomination for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress.', u'She starred in the musical films West Side Story (1961) and Gypsy (1962), and received Academy Award for Best Actress nominations for her performances in Splendor in the Grass (1961) and Love with the Proper Stranger (1963).', u'Her career continued with films such as Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice (1969).', u'After this, she took a break from acting and had two children with different husbands, appearing in only three theatrical films during the 1970s.', u'She was married to actor Robert Wagner twice, and to producer Richard Gregson.', u'She had one daughter with Gregson, actress Natasha Gregson Wagner.', u'Wood gave birth to Courtney Wagner during her second marriage to Wagner.', u'Her younger sister Lana Wood is also an actress.', u'Wood starred in several television productions, including a remake of the film From Here to Eternity (1979) for which she won a Golden Globe Award.', u'During her career, her films represented a "coming of age" for both her and Hollywood films in general.', u'== Early years ==\nWood was born Natasha Zakharenko in San Francisco, to Russian immigrant parents Maria Stepanovna (n\xe9e Zudilova, Russian: \u041c\u0430\u0440\u0438\u044f \u0421\u0442\u0435\u043f\u0430\u043d\u043e\u0432\u043d\u0430 \u0417\u0443\u0434\u0438\u043b\u043e\u0432\u0430; 1912\u20131996) and Nikolai Stepanovich Zakharenko (Russian: \u041d\u0438\u043a\u043e\u043b\u0430\u0439 \u0421\u0442\u0435\u043f\u0430\u043d\u043e\u0432\u0438\u0447 \u0417\u0430\u0445\u0430\u0440\u0435\u043d\u043a\u043e; c. 1912\u20131980).', u'As an adult, she stated, "I\'m very Russian, you know."', u'She spoke both English and Russian with an American accent.', u'Her father was born in Vladivostok and he, his mother, and two brothers, immigrated to Montreal, Quebec, and later to San Francisco.', u'There, he worked as a day laborer and carpenter.', u'Her paternal grandfather Stepan worked in a chocolate factory in Russia and was killed in street fighting between Red and White Russian soldiers in 1918.', u"Natalie's mother originally came from Barnaul, southern Siberia, but grew up in the Chinese city of Harbin.", u'She described her family by weaving mysterious tales of being either gypsies or landowning aristocrats.', u'In her youth, her mother dreamed of becoming an actress or ballet dancer.', u'She was raised as a Russian Orthodox Christian and remained in the church.', u'Biographer Warren Harris writes that under the family\'s "needy circumstances", her mother may have transferred those ambitions to her middle daughter, Natalie.', u'Her mother would take Natalie to the movies as often as she could: "Natalie\'s only professional training was watching Hollywood child stars from her mother\'s lap," notes Harris.', u'Wood would later recall this time:\n\nMy mother used to tell me that the cameraman who pointed his lens out at the audience at the end of the Paramount newsreel was taking my picture.', u"I'd pose and smile like he was going to make me famous or something.", u'I believed everything my mother told me.', u"Shortly after Wood's birth in San Francisco, her family moved to nearby Sonoma County, and lived in Santa Rosa, California, where Wood was noticed during a film shoot in downtown Santa Rosa.", u'Her mother soon moved the family to Los Angeles and pursued a career for her daughter.', u"Wood's younger sister, Svetlana Gurdin (the family had changed their surname) \u2014 now known as Lana Wood \u2014 also became an actress and later a Bond girl.", u'She and Lana had an older half sister, Olga Viripaeff, who died in May 2015.', u'Though Natalie had been born "Natalie Zakharenko", her father later changed the family name to "Gurdin" and Natalie was often known as "Natasha", the diminutive of Natalia.', u'The studio executives at RKO Radio Pictures, David Lewis and William Goetz, later changed her name to "Natalie Wood".', u'== Child actress ==\n\nWood made her film debut a few weeks before turning five during a fifteen-second scene in the 1943 film Happy Land.', u"Despite the brief part, she attracted the notice of the director, Irving Pichel, who remained in contact with Wood's family for two years when another role came up.", u"The director telephoned Wood's mother and asked her to bring her daughter to Los Angeles for a screen test.", u'Wood\'s mother became so excited at the possibilities that she overreacted and "packed the whole family off to Los Angeles to live," writes Harris.', u'Wood\'s father opposed the idea, but his wife\'s "overpowering ambition to make Natalie a star" took priority.', u'According to Wood\'s sister, Lana Wood, Pichel "discovered her and wanted to adopt her."', u'Wood, then seven years old, got the part and played a German orphan opposite Orson Welles and Claudette Colbert in Tomorrow Is Forever (1946).', u'Welles later said that Wood was a born professional, "so good, she was terrifying."', u"After Wood acted in another film directed by Pichel, her mother signed her up with 20th Century Fox studio for her first major role, the 1947 Christmas classic Miracle on 34th Street, where she starred with Maureen O'Hara.", u'The film made her one of the top child stars in Hollywood.', u"Within a few months after the film's release, Wood was so popular that Macy's invited her to appear in the store's annual Thanksgiving Day parade.", u"Film historian John C. Tibbetts writes that for the next few years following her success in Miracle, Wood played roles as a daughter in a series of family films: Fred MacMurray's daughter in Father Was a Fullback and Dear Brat, Margaret Sullavan's daughter in No Sad Songs for Me, James Stewart's daughter in The Jackpot, Joan Blondell's neglected daughter in The Blue Veil, and the daughter of Bette Davis' character in The Star.", u'In all, Wood appeared in over 20 films as a child.', u"Because she was a minor, Wood's formal education took place on the studio lots wherever she was contracted.", u'California law required that until age 18, actors had to spend at least three hours per day in the classroom, notes Harris.', u'"She was a straight A student", and one of the few child actors to excel at arithmetic.', u'Director Joseph L. Mankiewicz, who directed her in The Ghost and Mrs. Muir (1947), said that "In all my years in the business, I never met a smarter moppet."', u'Wood remembered that period in her life, saying, "I always felt guilty when I knew the crew was sitting around waiting for me to finish my three hours.', u'As soon as the teacher let us go, I ran to the set as fast as I could".', u'As a child actress, Wood received media attention.', u'By age nine, she had been named the "most exciting juvenile motion picture star of the year" by Parents.', u"At age twelve, Wood was judged Child Star of the Year by the Children's Day National Council of New York.", u'== Teen stardom ==\nIn the 1953\u201354 television season, Wood played Ann Morrison, the teenage daughter in the ABC situation comedy, The Pride of the Family.', u"She successfully made the transition from child star to ingenue at age 16 when she co-starred with James Dean and Sal Mineo in Rebel Without a Cause (1955), Nicholas Ray's film about teenage rebellion.", u'She was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress.', u"She followed this with a small but crucial role in John Ford's The Searchers (1956).", u'Wood graduated from Van Nuys High School in 1956.', u"She signed with Warner Brothers and was kept busy during the remainder of the decade in many 'girlfriend' roles that she found unsatisfying.", u'The studio cast her in two films opposite Tab Hunter, hoping to turn the duo into a box office draw that never materialized.', u"Among the other films made at this time were 1958's Kings Go Forth and Marjorie Morningstar.", u'As Marjorie Morningstar, Wood played the role of a young Jewish girl in New York City who has to deal with the social and religious expectations of her family, as she tries to forge her own path and separate identity.', u'She also had detractors.', u'Film critic Pauline Kael referred to her as "clever little Natalie Wood ... [the] most machine-tooled of Hollywood ingenues."', u"== Later career ==\n\nWood's characters in Rebel Without a Cause, The Searchers and Marjorie Morningstar began to show her widening range of acting styles, observes Tibbetts.", u'Her former "childlike sweetness" was now being combined with a noticeable "restlessness that was characteristic of the youth of the 1950s."', u"After Wood appeared in the box office flop All the Fine Young Cannibals (1960), her career was salvaged by her casting in director Elia Kazan's Splendor in the Grass (1961) opposite Warren Beatty, which earned Wood Best Actress Nominations at the Academy Awards, Golden Globes and BAFTA Awards.", u"Wood's career was in a transition period, having until then consisted of roles as a child or as a teenager.", u'She was now hoping to be cast in adult roles.', u'Biographer Suzanne Finstad notes that a "turning point" in her life as an actress took place upon seeing the film A Streetcar Named Desire (1951): "She was transformed, in awe of director Elia Kazan and of Vivien Leigh\'s performance ... [who] became a role model for Natalie."', u'"Her roles raised the possibility that one\'s sensitivity could mark a person as a kind of victim," noted Tibbetts.', u'In 1961, after a "series of bad films, her career was already in decline", notes Rathgeb.', u'Kazan himself writes that the "sages" of the film community declared her "washed up" as an actress, although he still wanted to interview her for his next film:\n\nWhen I saw her, I detected behind the well-mannered \'young wife\' front a desperate twinkle in her eyes ...', u'I talked with her more quietly then and more personally.', u'I wanted to find out what human material was there, what her inner life was ... Then she told me she was being psychoanalyzed.', u'That did it.', u'Poor R.J., I said to myself.', u'I liked Bob Wagner, I still do.', u'Kazan cast Wood as the female lead in Splendor in the Grass, and her career rebounded.', u'He felt that despite her earlier, innocent roles, she had the talent and maturity to go beyond them.', u'In the film, Warren Beatty\'s character was deprived of sexual love with Natalie\'s character, and as a result turns to another "looser" girl; Natalie\'s character, likewise, couldn\'t handle the issue, but ended up in a mental institution.', u'Kazan writes that he cast her in the role partly because he saw in Wood\'s personality a "true-blue quality with a wanton side that is held down by social pressure," adding that "she clings to things with her eyes," a quality he found especially "appealing."', u'Finstad felt that despite Wood never having received training in Method acting techniques, "working with Kazan brought her to the greatest emotional heights of her career.', u'The experience was exhilarating but wrenching for Natalie, who faced her demons on Splendor."', u'She adds that a scene in the film, as a result of "Kazan\'s wizardry ... produced a hysteria in Natalie that may be her most powerful moment as an actress."', u'Actor Gary Lockwood, who also acted in the film, felt that "Kazan and Natalie were a terrific marriage, because you had this beautiful girl, and you had somebody that could get things out of her."', u"Kazan's favorite scene in the movie was the last one, when Wood goes back to see her lost first love, Bud (Beatty).", u'"It\'s terribly touching to me.', u'I still like it when I see it," writes Kazan.', u'In 1961, Wood played Maria in the Jerome Robbins and Robert Wise musical West Side Story, which was a major box office and critical success.', u'Tibbetts notes similarities in her role in this film and the earlier Rebel Without a Cause.', u'Here, she also plays the role of a restless adolescent reflecting the "restlessness of American youth in the 1950s", expressed by youth gangs and juvenile delinquency, along with early rock & roll.', u'Both films, he observes, were "modern allegories based on the \'Romeo and Juliet\' theme, including private restlessness and public alienation.', u'Where in Rebel she falls in love with the character played by James Dean, whose gang-like friends and violent temper alienated him from his family, in West Side Story she also enters into a romance with a gang member and his threatening world of outcasts, also alienated from their families and the law.', u"Although the singing parts were sung by Marni Nixon, West Side Story is still regarded as one of Wood's best films.", u'Wood did sing when she starred in the 1962 film Gypsy.', u'She co-starred in the slapstick comedy The Great Race (1965), with Jack Lemmon, Tony Curtis, and Peter Falk.', u"Her ability to speak Russian was an asset given to her character Maggie DuBois, justifying the character's recording the progress of the race across Siberia, and entering the race at the beginning as a contestant.", u'In 1964, Wood was nominated for her third Academy Award nomination for Love with the Proper Stranger, making Wood, 25 at the time, the youngest actress to ever net three Oscar nominations.', u'Wood held the record for exactly 50 years until 23-year-old Jennifer Lawrence received her third nomination in 2014.', u"Although many of Wood's films were commercially profitable, her acting was criticized at times.", u'In 1966, she won the Harvard Lampoon Worst Actress of the Year Award.', u'She was the first performer in the award\'s history to accept it in person and the The Harvard Crimson wrote she was "quite a good sport".', u'Director Sydney Pollack was quoted as saying about Wood, "When she was right for the part, there was no one better.', u'She was a damn good actress."', u'Other notable films starring Wood were Inside Daisy Clover (1965) and This Property Is Condemned (1966), both of which co-starred Robert Redford and brought subsequent Golden Globe nominations for Best Actress.', u'In both films, which were set during the Great Depression, Wood played small-town teens with big dreams.', u'After the release of the films, Wood suffered emotionally and sought professional therapy.', u'During this time, she turned down the Faye Dunaway role in Bonnie and Clyde (1967) because she did not want to be separated from her analyst.', u'After three years away from acting, Wood co-starred with Elliott Gould in the hit Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice (1969), a comedy about sexual liberation.', u'According to Tibbets, this was the first film in which "the saving leavening of humor was brought to bear upon the many painful dilemmas portrayed in her adult films".', u'After becoming pregnant in 1970 with her first child, Natasha Gregson, Wood went into semi-retirement and acted in only four more theatrical films during the remainder of her life.', u'She made a very brief cameo appearance as herself in The Candidate (1972), reuniting her for a third time with Robert Redford.', u'She also reunited on the screen with Robert Wagner in the television movie of the week The Affair (1973) and with Laurence Olivier and husband Wagner in an adaptation of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof (1976) broadcast as a special by NBC.', u'She made cameo appearances on Wagner\'s prime-time detective series Switch in 1978 as "Bubble Bath Girl" and Hart to Hart in 1979 as "Movie Star".', u'During the last two years of her life, Wood began to work more frequently as her daughters reached school age.', u'Film roles that Wood turned down during her career hiatus went to Ali MacGraw in Goodbye, Columbus; Mia Farrow in The Great Gatsby; and Faye Dunaway in The Towering Inferno.', u'Later, Wood chose to star in bombs like the disaster film Meteor (1979) with Sean Connery and the sex comedy The Last Married Couple in America (1980), although her performance in the latter was praised, and considered reminiscent of her performance in Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice.', u'It was also in Last Married Couple that Wood broke ground by being an actress with a clean, middle class image, yet using the "F" word in a frank, marital discussion with her husband (George Segal).', u'She found more success in television, receiving high ratings and critical acclaim in 1979 for The Cracker Factory and especially the miniseries film Here to Eternity, with Kim Basinger and William Devane.', u"Wood's performance in the latter won her a Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in 1980.", u'Later that year, she starred in The Memory of Eva Ryker, which proved to be her last completed production.', u'At the time of her death, Wood was filming the science fiction film Brainstorm (1983), co-starring Christopher Walken and directed by Douglas Trumbull.', u'She was also scheduled to star in a theatrical production of Anastasia with Wendy Hiller and in a film called Country of the Heart, playing a terminally ill writer who has an affair with a teenager, to be played by Timothy Hutton.', u'Due to her untimely death, both of the latter projects were canceled and the ending of Brainstorm had to be re-written.', u'A stand-in and sound-alikes were used to replace Wood for some of her critical scenes.', u'The film was released posthumously on September 30, 1983, and was dedicated to her in the closing credits.', u'Wood appeared in 56 films for cinema and television.', u'Following her death, Time magazine noted that although critical praise for Wood had been sparse throughout her career, "she always had work".', u"== Personal life ==\nWood's two marriages to actor Robert Wagner were highly publicized.", u'Wood said that she had had a crush on Wagner since she was a child, and on her 18th birthday she went on a studio-arranged date with the 26-year-old actor.', u"They married a year later on December 28, 1957; it was a union that met with great protest from Wood's mother.", u'In an article in February 2009, Wagner recalled their early romance:\n\nI saw Natalie around town but she never seemed interested.', u'She was making Rebel Without a Cause and hanging out with James Dean; I was with an older crowd.', u'The first time I remember really talking to her was at a fashion show in 1956.', u'She was beautiful, but still gave no hint about the mad crush she had on me.', u'I later found out she had signed with my agent simply because he was my agent.', u'A month later, I invited Natalie to a premiere on what turned out to be her 18th birthday.', u'At dinner, we both sensed things were different.', u'I sent her flowers and the dates continued.', u'I remember the instant I fell in love with her.', u'One night on board a small boat I owned, she looked at me with love, her dark brown eyes lit by a table lantern.', u'That moment changed my life.', u'Wood and Wagner separated in June 1961 and divorced in April 1962.', u'On May 30, 1969, Wood married British producer Richard Gregson.', u'The couple had dated for two and a half years prior to their marriage, while Gregson waited for his divorce to be finalized.', u'In 1970 they had a daughter, Natasha.', u'They separated in August 1971 after Wood overheard an inappropriate telephone conversation between her secretary and Gregson.', u'The split also marked a brief estrangement between Wood and her family, when mother Maria and sister Lana told her to reconcile with Gregson for the sake of her newborn child.', u'She filed for divorce, and it was finalized in April 1972.', u'In early 1972, Wood resumed her relationship with Wagner.', u'The couple remarried on July 16, 1972, five months after reconciling and three months after she divorced Gregson.', u'Their daughter, Courtney Wagner, was born in 1974.', u"Wood's sister, Lana Wood, recalls this period:\n\nHer marriage was considered to be one of the best in Hollywood, and there is no question that she was a devoted, loving\u2014even adoring\u2014mother and stepmother.", u'She and R.J. had begun with love and built from there.', u"They had overcome each other's problems and had reached an accommodation with time, and the changes time brings.", u'As with anybody else who has settled into making a long marriage work, they were far more determined than most people to make it work ...', u"They remained married until Wood's untimely death seven years later on November 29, 1981 at age 43.", u'== Death ==\nDuring the making of the film Brainstorm, Wood drowned while on a weekend boat trip to Santa Catalina Island on board the Splendour.', u'Many of the circumstances surrounding her drowning are unknown because it was never determined how she entered the water.', u"She was with her husband Robert Wagner, Brainstorm co-star Christopher Walken, and the Splendour's captain, Dennis Davern, on the evening of November 28, 1981.", u"Wood's body was recovered by authorities at 8:00 a.m. on November 29, one mile away from the boat, with a small inflatable dinghy, named the Valiant, found beached nearby.", u'According to Wagner, when he went to bed, Wood was not there.', u'The autopsy report revealed that Wood had bruises on her body and arms as well as an abrasion on her left cheek.', u'Later, in his book Pieces of My Heart, Wagner acknowledged that he had an argument with Wood before she disappeared.', u"The autopsy also found that Wood's blood alcohol level was 0.14%, and there were traces of two types of medication in her bloodstream: a motion-sickness pill and a painkiller, which increase the effects of alcohol.", u'Following his investigation, Los Angeles County coroner Thomas Noguchi ruled her death an accident by drowning and hypothermia.', u'According to Noguchi, Wood had been drinking and may have slipped while trying to re-board the dinghy.', u'Wood was buried in Westwood Village Memorial Park Cemetery in Los Angeles.', u"Scores of representatives of international media, photographers, and members of the public tried to attend Wood's funeral; however, all were required to remain outside the cemetery walls.", u'Among the celebrity attendees were Frank Sinatra, Elizabeth Taylor, Fred Astaire, Rock Hudson, David Niven, Gregory Peck, Gene Kelly, Elia Kazan and Laurence Olivier.', u'Olivier flew from London to Los Angeles to attend the service.', u'After a thirty year hiatus, the case was reopened in November, 2011 after the captain of the boat, Dennis Davern, publicly stated that he had lied to police during the initial investigation and that Wood and Wagner had an argument that evening, and alleged that Wagner was responsible for her death.', u'After nine months of further investigation, Los Angeles County Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Lakshmanan Sathyavagiswaran, amended Wood\'s death certificate and changed the cause of her death from accidental drowning to "drowning and other undetermined factors."', u'The amended document included a statement that the circumstances of how Wood ended up in the water are "not clearly established".', u"The coroner's office had been instructed by detectives not to discuss or comment on the case.", u"On January 14, 2013, the Los Angeles County coroner's office offered a 10-page addendum to Wood's autopsy report stating that some of the bruises on her body may have been sustained before she went into the water and drowned, but that could not be definitively determined.", u'Forensic pathologist Dr. Michael Hunter has speculated that Wood was particularly susceptible to bruising due to the drug synthroid that she had taken.', u"Douglas Trumbull, director of Brainstorm, quit directing after Wood's death in 1981.", u'In 2013, he explained that the uncertain circumstances of her death were the main reason for this decision.', u'He has since returned to filmmaking.', u"Wagner has denied any involvement in Wood's death.", u'== Tribute ==\nSeveral songs were written about or mention Wood, including "Natalie Wood" (1980, written by Jay Alanski, cover by Jil Caplan), "Natalie\'s Song" (David Pack), and "Eyes Like Natalie Wood" (Kathy Fleischmann).', u'In 1999, Julian Daze and the Photon Karma recorded "Natalie Wood", written by singer/songwriter Brian Bell, and released on the Stories of Old album.', u'In 2002 The Handsome Family wrote a haunting song "Natalie Wood" later released on their Twilight album.', u'In 2015, the band TV Girl released a song titled "Natalie Wood".', u'A 2004 TV film titled The Mystery of Natalie Wood was directed by Peter Bogdanovich and starred Justine Waddell and Michael Weatherly.', u'In 2015, an eau de parfum fragrance was released called "Natalie", and featuring gardenia, which was her favourite scent.', u'== Filmography {'sentences': [u'Whittaker Chambers (born Jay Vivian Chambers; April 1, 1901 \u2013 July 9, 1961) also known as Jay David Whittaker Chambers, was an American writer, editor, and Soviet spy.', u'After early years as a Communist Party member (1925) and Soviet spy (1932\u20131938), he defected from communism (underground and open party) and worked at Time magazine (1939\u20131948).', u"Under subpoena in 1948, he testified in what became Alger Hiss's perjury (espionage) trials (1949\u20131950) and he became an outspoken anti-communist (all described in his 1952 memoir Witness).", u'Afterwards, he worked briefly as a senior editor at National Review (1957\u20131959).', u'President Ronald Reagan awarded him the Medal of Freedom in 1984.', u'== Youth and education ==\nChambers was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, and spent his infancy in Brooklyn.', u'His family moved to Lynbrook, Long Island, New York, in 1904, where he grew up and attended school.', u'His parents were Jay Chambers and Laha (Whittaker).', u"Chambers described his childhood as troubled because of his parents' separation and their need to care for their mentally ill grandmother.", u'His father was a half-closeted homosexual and treated Whittaker cruelly, while his mother was neurotic.', u"Chambers' brother committed suicide shortly after withdrawing from his first year of college.", u"Chambers would cite his brother's fate as one of many reasons that he was drawn to communism at that time.", u'As he wrote, communism "offered me what nothing else in the dying world had power to offer at the same intensity, faith and a vision, something for which to live and something for which to die.\u201d\nAfter graduating from South Side High School in neighboring Rockville Centre in 1919, Chambers worked itinerantly in Washington and New Orleans, briefly attended Williams College, and then enrolled as a day student at Columbia College of Columbia University.', u'At Columbia his fellow undergraduates included Meyer Schapiro, Frank S. Hogan, Herbert Solow, Louis Zukofsky, Clifton Fadiman, Elliott V. Bell, John Gassner, Lionel Trilling (who later fictionalized him as a main character in his novel The Middle of the Journey), and Guy Endore.', u'In the intellectual environment of Columbia he gained friends and respect.', u'His professors and fellow students found him a talented writer and believed he might become a major poet or novelist.', u"In his sophomore year, Chambers joined the Boar's Head Society and wrote a play called A Play for Puppets for Columbia's literary magazine The Morningside, which he edited.", u'The work was deemed blasphemous by many students and administrators, and the controversy spread to New York City newspapers.', u'Later, the play would be used against Chambers during his testimony against Alger Hiss.', u'Disheartened over the controversy, Chambers left Columbia in 1925.', u"From Columbia, Chambers also knew Isaiah Oggins, who went into the Soviet underground a few years earlier; Chambers' wife, Esther Shemitz Chambers, knew Oggins' wife, Nerma Berman Oggins, from the Rand School of Social Science, the ILGWU, and The World Tomorrow.", u"== Communism and espionage ==\nIn 1924, Chambers read Vladimir Lenin's Soviets at Work and was deeply affected by it.", u'He now saw the dysfunctional nature of his family, he would write, as "in miniature the whole crisis of the middle class"; a malaise from which Communism promised liberation.', u'Chambers\'s biographer Sam Tanenhaus wrote that Lenin\'s authoritarianism was "precisely what attracts Chambers...', u'He had at last found his church"; that is, he became a Marxist.', u'In 1925, Chambers joined the Communist Party of the United States (CPUSA) (then known as the Workers Party of America).', u'Chambers wrote and edited for Communist publications, including The Daily Worker newspaper and The New Masses magazine.', u'Combining his literary talents with his devotion to Communism, Chambers wrote four short stories in 1931 about proletarian hardship and revolt, including Can You Make Out Their Voices?, considered by critics as one of the best pieces of fiction from the American Communist movement.', u'Hallie Flanagan co-adapted and produced it as a play entitled Can You Hear Their Voices?', u'(q.v.', u'Bibliography of Whittaker Chambers), staged across America and in many other countries.', u"Chambers also worked as a translator during this period; among his works was the English version of Felix Salten's 1923 novel Bambi, A Life in the Woods.", u'=== Harold Ware ===\nChambers was recruited to join the "Communist underground" and began his career as a spy, working for a GRU apparatus headed by Alexander Ulanovsky (aka Ulrich).', u'Later, his main controller in the underground was Josef Peters (whom CPUSA General Secretary Earl Browder later replaced with Rudy Baker).', u"Chambers claimed Peters introduced him to Harold Ware (although he later denied he had ever been introduced to Ware), and that he was head of a Communist underground cell in Washington that reportedly included:\nApart from Marion Bachrach, these people were all members of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal administration.", u'Chambers worked in Washington as an organizer among Communists in the city and as a courier between New York and Washington for stolen documents which were delivered to Boris Bykov, the GRU station chief.', u'=== Other covert sources ===\nUsing the codename "Karl" or "Carl", Chambers served during the mid-1930s as a courier between various covert sources and Soviet intelligence.', u'In addition to the Ware group mentioned above, other sources that Chambers dealt with allegedly included:\n\n\n== Break with Communism ==\nChambers carried on his espionage activities from 1932 until 1937 or 1938 even while his faith in Communism was waning.', u"He became increasingly disturbed by Joseph Stalin's Great Purge, which began in 1936.", u"He was also fearful for his own life, having noted the murder in Switzerland of Ignace Reiss, a high-ranking Soviet spy who had broken with Stalin, and the disappearance of Chambers' friend and fellow spy Juliet Poyntz in the United States.", u'Poyntz had vanished in 1937, shortly after she had visited Moscow and returned disillusioned with the Communist cause due to the Stalinist Purges.', u'Chambers ignored several orders that he travel to Moscow, worried that he might be "purged."', u'He also started concealing some of the documents he collected from his sources.', u'He planned to use these, along with several rolls of microfilm photographs of documents, as a "life preserver" to prevent the Soviets from killing him and his family.', u'In 1938, Chambers broke with Communism and took his family into hiding, storing the "life preserver" at the home of his nephew and his parents.', u'Initially he had no plans to give information on his espionage activities to the U.S. government.', u'His espionage contacts were his friends, and he had no desire to inform on them.', u"In his examination of Chambers' conversion from the political left to the right, author Daniel Oppenheimer noted that Chambers substituted his passion for communism for a passion for God.", u'Chambers saw the world in black and white terms both before his defection and after.', u'In his autobiography, he presented his devotion to communism as a reason for living, but after defecting saw his actions as being part of an "absolute evil."', u'=== Berle meeting ===\nThe August 1939 Hitler-Stalin non-aggression pact drove Chambers to take action against the Soviet Union.', u'In September 1939, at the urging of anti-Communist, Russian-born journalist Isaac Don Levine, Chambers and Levine met with Assistant Secretary of State Adolf Berle.', u'Levine had introduced Chambers to Walter Krivitsky, who was already informing American and British authorities about Soviet agents who held posts in both governments.', u'Krivitsky told Chambers it was their duty to inform.', u'Chambers agreed to reveal what he knew on the condition of immunity from prosecution.', u"During the meeting, which took place at Berle's home, Woodley Mansion in Washington, Chambers named 18 current and former government employees as spies or Communist sympathizers.", u'Many names mentioned held relatively minor posts or were already under suspicion.', u'Some names, however, were more significant and surprising: Alger Hiss, his brother Donald Hiss, and Laurence Duggan\u2014who were all respected, mid-level officials in the State Department\u2014and Lauchlin Currie, a special assistant to Franklin Roosevelt.', u'Another person named had worked on a top secret bombsight project at the Aberdeen Proving Grounds.', u"Berle found Chambers' information tentative, unclear, and uncorroborated.", u'He took the information to the White House, but the President dismissed it, to which Berle made little if any objection.', u"Berle kept his notes, however (later, evidence during Hiss' perjury trials).", u"Berle notified the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) of Chambers's information in March 1940.", u'In February 1941, Krivitsky was found dead in his hotel room.', u'While police ruled the death a suicide, it was widely speculated that Krivitsky had been killed by Soviet intelligence.', u'Worried that the Soviets might try to kill Chambers too, Berle again told the FBI about his interview with Chambers.', u'Nevertheless, the FBI took no immediate action, in line with the political orientation of the United States, which viewed the potential threat from the USSR as minor, when compared to that of Nazi Germany.', u'(The FBI did interview Chambers in May 1942 and June 1945, without further action.', u"Only in November 1945, when Elizabeth Bentley defected and corroborated much of Chambers's story, did the FBI begin to take Chambers seriously).", u'=== Time Magazine ===\nBy the time of the Berle meeting, Chambers had come out of hiding after a year and joined the staff of Time Magazine (April 1939).', u"He landed a cover story within a month on James Joyce's latest book, Finnegans Wake.", u'He started at the back of the magazine, reviewing books and film with James Agee and then Calvin Fixx.', u"When Fixx died in October 1942, Wilder Hobson succeeded him as Chambers' assistant editor in Arts & Entertainment.", u'Other writers working for Chambers in that section included: novelist Nigel Dennis, future New York Times Book Review editor Harvey Breit, and poets Howard Moss and Weldon Kees.', u"During this time, a struggle arose between those, like Theodore H. White and Richard Lauterbach, who raised criticism of what they saw as the elitism, corruption and ineptitude of Chiang Kai-shek's regime in China and advocated greater cooperation with Mao's Red Army in the struggle against Japanese imperialism, and Chambers and others like Willi Schlamm who adhered to a staunchly pro-Chiang, anti-communist perspective (and who both later joined the founding editorial board of William F. Buckley, Jr.'s National Review).", u'Time founder Henry R. Luce, who grew up in China and was a personal friend of Chiang and his wife, came down squarely on the side of Chambers to the point that White complained that his stories were being censored, and even suppressed in their entirety, and left Time shortly after the war as a result.', u'With Luce\'s blessing, Chambers received a promotion to senior editor in September 1943 and was made a member of Time\'s "Senior Group", which determined editorial policy, in December.', u'By early 1948, Chambers had become one of the best known writer-editors at Time.', u'First had come his scathing commentary "The Ghosts on the Roof" (March 5, 1945) on the Yalta Conference (in which Hiss partook).', u'Subsequent cover-story essays profiled Marian Anderson, Arnold J. Toynbee, Rebecca West and Reinhold Niebuhr.', u"The cover story on Marian Anderson (December 30, 1946) proved so popular that the magazine broke its rule of non-attribution in response to readers' letters:\n\nMost Time cover stories are written and edited by the regular staffs of the section in which they appear.", u'Certain cover stories, that present special difficulties or call for a special literary skill, are written by Senior Editor Whittaker Chambers."', u'Chambers was at the height of his career when the Hiss case broke later that year.', u'During this period, Chambers and his family became Quakers, attending Pipe Creek Friends Meetinghouse near his Maryland farm.', u'== The Hiss case ==\nOn August 3, 1948, Chambers was called to testify before the House Un-American Activities Committee (HUAC).', u'Here he gave the names of individuals he said were part of the underground "Ware group" in the late 1930s, including Alger Hiss.', u'He thus once again named Hiss as a member of the Communist Party, but did not yet make any accusations of espionage.', u'In subsequent HUAC sessions, Hiss testified and initially denied that he knew anyone by the name of Chambers, but on seeing him in person (and after it became clear that Chambers knew details about Hiss\'s life), said that he had known Chambers under the name "George Crosley".', u'Hiss denied that he had ever been a Communist, however.', u'Since Chambers still presented no evidence, the committee had initially been inclined to take the word of Hiss on the matter.', u'However, committee member Richard Nixon received secret information from the FBI which had led him to pursue the issue.', u'When it issued its report, HUAC described Hiss\'s testimony as "vague and evasive".', u'=== "Red Herring" ===\nThe country quickly became divided over the Hiss\u2013Chambers issue.', u'President Harry S Truman, not pleased with the allegation that the man who had presided over the United Nations Charter Conference was a Communist, dismissed the case as a "red herring".', u"In the atmosphere of increasing anti-communism that would later be termed McCarthyism, many conservatives viewed the Hiss case as emblematic of what they saw as Democrats' laxity towards the danger of communist infiltration and influence in the State Department.", u'Many liberals, in turn, saw the Hiss case as part of the desperation of the Republican party to regain the office of president, having been out of power for 16 years.', u'Truman also issued Executive Order 9835, which initiated a program of loyalty reviews for federal employees in 1947.', u'=== "Pumpkin Papers" ===\nHiss filed a $75,000 libel suit against Chambers on October 8, 1948.', u"Under pressure from Hiss's lawyers, Chambers finally retrieved his envelope of evidence and presented it to the HUAC after they subpoenaed them.", u"It contained four notes in Alger Hiss's handwriting, sixty-five typewritten copies of State Department documents and five strips of microfilm, some of which contained photographs of State Department documents.", u'The press came to call these the "Pumpkin Papers" referring to the fact that Chambers had briefly hidden the microfilm in a hollowed-out pumpkin.', u'These documents indicated that Hiss knew Chambers long after mid-1936, when Hiss said he had last seen "Crosley," and also that Hiss had engaged in espionage with Chambers.', u'Chambers explained his delay in producing this evidence as an effort to spare an old friend from more trouble than necessary.', u'Until October 1948, Chambers had repeatedly stated that Hiss had not engaged in espionage, even when Chambers testified under oath.', u'Chambers was forced to testify at the Hiss trials that he had committed perjury several times, which reduced his credibility in the eyes of his critics.', u'The five rolls of 35 mm film known as the "pumpkin papers" were thought until late 1974 to be locked in HUAC files.', u'Independent researcher Stephen W. Salant, an economist at the University of Michigan, sued the U.S. Justice Department in 1975 when his request for access to them under the Freedom of Information Act was denied.', u'On July 31, 1975, as a result of this lawsuit and follow-on suits filed by Peter Irons and by Alger Hiss and William Reuben, the Justice Department released copies of the "pumpkin papers" that had been used to implicate Hiss.', u'One roll of film turned out to be totally blank due to overexposure, two others are faintly legible copies of nonclassified Navy Department documents relating to such subjects as life rafts and fire extinguishers, and the remaining two are photographs of the State Department documents introduced by the prosecution at the two Hiss trials, relating to U.S./German relations in the late 1930s.', u'This story, however, as reported by the NY Times in the 1970s, contains only a partial truth.', u'The blank roll had been mentioned by Chambers in his autobiography Witness.', u'But in addition to innocuous farm reports, etc., the documents on the other pumpkin patch microfilms also included "confidential memos sent from overseas embassies to diplomatic staff in Washington, D.C."; worse, those memos had originally been transmitted in code, which, thanks to their (presumably) having both coded originals and the translations forwarded by Hiss, the Soviets now could easily understand.', u'=== Perjury ===\nHiss could not be tried for espionage at this time, because the evidence indicated the offense had occurred more than ten years prior to that time, and the statute of limitations for espionage was five years.', u'Instead, Hiss was indicted for two counts of perjury relating to testimony he had given before a federal grand jury the previous December.', u'There he had denied giving any documents to Whittaker Chambers, and testified he had not seen Chambers after mid-1936.', u'Hiss was tried twice for perjury.', u'The first trial, in June 1949, ended with the jury deadlocked eight to four for conviction.', u"In addition to Chambers's testimony, a government expert testified that other papers typed on a typewriter belonging to the Hiss family matched the secret papers produced by Chambers.", u'An impressive array of character witnesses appeared on behalf of Hiss: two U.S. Supreme Court justices, Felix Frankfurter and Stanley Reed, former Democratic presidential nominee John W. Davis and future Democratic presidential nominee Adlai Stevenson.', u'Chambers, on the other hand, was attacked by Hiss\'s attorneys as "an enemy of the Republic, a blasphemer of Christ, a disbeliever in God, with no respect for matrimony or motherhood".', u'In the second trial, Hiss\'s defense produced a psychiatrist who characterized Chambers as a "psychopathic personality" and "a pathological liar".', u'The second trial ended in January 1950 with Hiss found guilty on both counts of perjury.', u'He was sentenced to five years in prison.', u'== After the Hiss case ==\nChambers had resigned from Time in December 1948.', u'After the Hiss Case, he wrote a few articles for Fortune, Life, and Look magazines.', u"=== Witness ===\nIn 1952, Chambers's book Witness was published to widespread acclaim.", u'The book was a combination of autobiography and a warning about the dangers of Communism.', u'Arthur Schlesinger, Jr. called it "a powerful book".', u'Ronald Reagan credited the book as the inspiration behind his conversion from a New Deal Democrat to a conservative Republican.', u'Witness was a bestseller for more than a year and helped pay off Chambers\' legal debts, though bills lingered ("as Odysseus was beset by a ghost").', u'=== National Review ===\nIn 1955, William F. Buckley, Jr. started the magazine National Review, and Chambers worked there as senior editor, publishing articles there for a little over a year and a half (October 1957\u2013June 1959).', u'The most widely cited article to date is a scathing review, "Big Sister is Watching You", of Ayn Rand\'s Atlas Shrugged.', u"In 1959, after resigning from National Review, Chambers and his wife visited Europe, the highlight of which was a meeting with Arthur Koestler and Margarete Buber-Neumann at Koestler's home in Austria.", u'That fall, he recommenced studies at Western Maryland College (now McDaniel College) in Westminster, Maryland.', u'== Personal life and death ==\nIn 1930 or 1931, Chambers married the young artist Esther Shemitz (1900\u20131986).', u"Shemitz, who had studied at the Art Students League and integrated herself into New York City's intellectual circles, met Chambers at the 1926 textile strike at Passaic, New Jersey.", u"They then underwent a stormy courtship that faced resistance from their comrades, with Chambers having climbed through her window at five o'clock in the morning to propose.", u'Shemitz identified as "a pacifist rather than a revolutionary."', u'In the 1920s, she worked for The World Tomorrow, a pacifist magazine.', u'The couple had two children, Ellen and John during the 1930s.', u'(Communist leadership expected couples to go childless, but like many Chambers refused, a choice he cited as part of his gradual disillusionment with communism.)', u"In 1978, Allen Weinstein's Perjury revealed that FBI has a copy of a letter in which Chambers described homosexual liaisons during the 1930s.", u'The letter copy states that Chambers gave up these practices in 1938 when he left the underground, attributed to newfound Christianity.', u'The letter has remained controversial from many perspectives.', u'Chambers died of a heart attack on July 9, 1961, at his 300-acre (1.2 km2) farm in Westminster, Maryland.', u'He had suffered from angina since the age of 38 and had previously suffered several heart attacks.', u'Cold Friday, his second memoir, was published posthumously in 1964 with the help of Duncan Norton-Taylor.', u'The book prophetically predicted that the fall of Communism would start in the satellite states surrounding the Soviet Union in Eastern Europe.', u'A collection of his correspondence with William F. Buckley, Jr., Odyssey of a Friend, was published in 1968; a collection of his journalism\u2014including several of his Time and National Review writings, was published in 1989 as Ghosts on the Roof: Selected Journalism of Whittaker Chambers (q.v.', u'Bibliography of Whittaker Chambers.)', u'== Awards ==\n1984 - Presidential Medal of Freedom (for contribution to "the century\'s epic struggle between freedom and totalitarianism")\n1953 - National Book Award finalist for nonfiction (Witness)\n1952 - Honorary Doctorate of Law from Mount Mary College (Milwaukee)\n1937 - Order of the Red Star from Soviet Military Intelligence (GRU)\n\n\n== Legacy ==\nChambers\'s book Witness is on the reading lists of the Heritage Foundation, The Weekly Standard, The Leadership Institute, and the Russell Kirk Center for Cultural Renewal.', u"He is regularly cited by conservative writers such as Heritage's president Edwin Feulner.", u'In 1984, President Ronald Reagan posthumously awarded Chambers the Presidential Medal of Freedom, for his contribution to "the century\'s epic struggle between freedom and totalitarianism".', u'In 1988, Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel granted national landmark status to the Pipe Creek Farm.', u"In 2001, members of the George W. Bush Administration held a private ceremony to commemorate the hundredth anniversary of Chambers's birth.", u'Speakers included William F. Buckley, Jr.', u"In 2007, John Chambers stated that a library with his father's papers should open in 2008 on the Chambers farm in Maryland.", u'He indicated that the facility will be available to all scholars and that a separate library, rather than one within an established university, is needed to guarantee open access.', u'On 6 January 2010, the Medfield farmhouse at Pipe Creek Farm, in which Whittaker Chambers wrote Witness, was severely damaged by a fire that began in an electrical panel at the front entrance of the home.', u"In 2011, author Elena Maria Vidal interviewed David Chambers about his grandfather's legacy.", u'Versions of the interview were published in the National Observer and The American Conservative.', u'== See also ==\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== Further reading ==\nChambers, Whittaker (1952).', u'Witness.', u'New York: Random House.', u'LCCN 52005149.', u'Chambers, Whittaker (1964).', u'Cold Friday.', u'New York: Random House.', u'Tanenhaus, Sam (1998).', u'Whittaker Chambers: A Biography.', u'Modern Library.', u'ISBN 0-375-75145-9.', u'Weinstein, Allen (1978).', u'"Perjury: The Hiss\u2013Chambers Case".', u'New York: Ballantine Books.', u'== External links ==\nwhittakerchambers.org\n"Writings of Whittaker Chambers" from C-SPAN\'s American Writers: A Journey Through History\nJohn Beresford, "YouTube Videos About Hiss-Chambers Case," Historians of American Communism, H-Net, Feb. 26, 2014.', u'Part One of Booknotes interview with Sam Tanenhaus on Whittaker Chambers: A Biography, February 23, 1997.', u'Part Two of Booknotes interview with Tanenhaus on Whittaker Chambers: A Biography, March 2, 1997.', u'Find A Grave'], 'year': '1948-12-03', 'title': 'Pumpkin Papers came to light'}

Kennedy and alleged cover-up through the eyes of former New Orleans district attorney Jim Garrison (Kevin Costner).', u'Garrison filed charges against New Orleans businessman Clay Shaw (Tommy Lee Jones) for his alleged participation in a conspiracy to assassinate the President, for which Lee Harvey Oswald (Gary Oldman) was found responsible by a government investigation: the Warren Commission.', u'The film was adapted by Stone and Zachary Sklar from the books On the Trail of the Assassins by Jim Garrison and Crossfire: The Plot That Killed Kennedy by Jim Marrs.', u'Stone described this account as a "counter-myth" to the Warren Commission\'s "fictional myth."', u'The film became embroiled in controversy.', u"Upon JFK's theatrical release, many major American newspapers ran editorials accusing Stone of taking liberties with historical facts, including the film's implication that President Lyndon B. Johnson was part of a coup d'\xe9tat to kill Kennedy.", u'After a slow start at the box office, the film gradually picked up momentum, earning over $205 million in worldwide gross.', u'JFK was nominated for eight Academy Awards (including Best Picture) and won two for Best Cinematography and Best Film Editing.', u'It was the most successful of three films Stone made about the American Presidency, followed later by Nixon with Anthony Hopkins in the title role and W. with Josh Brolin as George W. Bush.', u'== Plot ==\nThe film opens with newsreel footage, including the farewell address in 1961 of outgoing President Dwight D. Eisenhower, warning about the build-up of the "military-industrial complex".', u"This is followed by a summary of John F. Kennedy's years as president, emphasizing the events that, in Stone's thesis, would lead to his assassination.", u'This builds to a reconstruction of the assassination on November 22, 1963.', u'New Orleans District Attorney Jim Garrison subsequently learns about potential links to the assassination in New Orleans.', u'Garrison and his team investigate several possible conspirators, including private pilot David Ferrie (Joe Pesci), but are forced to let them go after their investigation is publicly rebuked by the federal government.', u"Kennedy's suspected assassin Lee Harvey Oswald is killed by Jack Ruby, and Garrison closes the investigation.", u'The investigation is reopened in 1966 after Garrison reads the Warren Report and notices what he believes to be multiple inaccuracies.', u'Garrison and his staff interrogate several witnesses to the Kennedy assassination, and others involved with Oswald, Ruby, and Ferrie.', u"One such witness is Willie O'Keefe (Kevin Bacon), a male prostitute serving five years in prison for soliciting, who reveals he witnessed Ferrie discussing a coup d'\xe9tat.", u'As well as briefly meeting Oswald, O\'Keefe was romantically involved with a man called "Clay Bertrand".', u'Jean Hill (Ellen McElduff), a teacher who says she witnessed shots fired from the grassy knoll, tells the investigators that Secret Service threatened her into saying three shots came from the book depository, revealing changes that were made to her testimony by the Warren Commission.', u"Garrison's staff also test the single bullet theory by aiming an empty rifle from the window through which Oswald was alleged to have shot Kennedy.", u'They conclude that Oswald was too poor a marksman to make the shots, indicating someone else, or multiple marksmen, were involved.', u'In 1968, Garrison meets a high-level figure in Washington D.C. who identifies himself as "X" (Donald Sutherland).', u"He suggests a conspiracy at the highest levels of government, implicating members of the CIA, the Mafia, the military-industrial complex, Secret Service, FBI, and Kennedy's vice-president and then president Lyndon Baines Johnson as either co-conspirators or as having motives to cover up the truth of the assassination.", u'X explains that the President was killed because he wanted to pull the United States out of the Vietnam War and dismantle the CIA.', u'X encourages Garrison to keep digging and prosecute New Orleans-based international businessman Clay Shaw for his alleged involvement.', u"Upon interrogating Shaw, the businessman denies any knowledge attacking Garrison's character and criticizing the way his office is spending taxpayers' money.", u'Some key witnesses become scared and refuse to testify while others, such as Ferrie, are killed in suspicious circumstances.', u"Before his death, Ferrie tells Garrison that he believes people are after him, and reveals there was a conspiracy around Kennedy's death.", u'The trial of Clay Shaw takes
