and the Gulf of Mexico to the south, and Mississippi to the west.', u'Alabama is the 30th-most extensive and the 24th-most populous of the U.S. states.', u"At 1,300 miles (2,100 km), Alabama has one of the nation's longest navigable inland waterways.", u'From the American Civil War until World War II, Alabama, like many states in the southern U.S., suffered economic hardship, in part because of continued dependence on agriculture.', u'Despite the growth of major industries and urban centers, white rural interests dominated the state legislature from 1901 to the 1960s, as it did not regularly reapportion the legislature from 1901 to 1961; urban interests and African Americans were markedly under-represented.', u'African Americans and poor whites were essentially disenfranchised altogether by the state constitution of 1901, a status that continued into the mid-1960s before being alleviated by federal legislation.', u'Exclusion of minorities continued under at-large voting systems in most counties; some changes were made through a series of omnibus court cases in the late 1980s to establish different electoral systems.', u"Following World War II, Alabama experienced growth as the state's economy changed from one primarily based on agriculture to one with diversified interests.", u'The power of the Solid South in Congress gained the establishment or expansion of multiple United States Armed Forces installations, which helped bridge the gap between an agricultural and industrial economy during the mid-20th century.', u'The state economy in the 21st century is based on management, automotive, finance, manufacturing, aerospace, mineral extraction, healthcare, education, retail, and technology.', u'Alabama is nicknamed the Yellowhammer State, after the state bird.', u'Alabama is also known as the "Heart of Dixie" and the Cotton State.', u'The state tree is the longleaf pine, and the state flower is the camellia.', u"Alabama's capital is Montgomery.", u'The largest city by population is Birmingham, which has long been the most industrialized city, and largest city by land area is Huntsville.', u'The oldest city is Mobile, founded by French colonists in 1702 as the capital of French Louisiana.', u'== Etymology ==\n\nThe European-American naming of the Alabama River and state originates from the Alabama people, a Muskogean-speaking tribe whose members lived just below the confluence of the Coosa and Tallapoosa rivers on the upper reaches of the river.', u'In the Alabama language, the word for a person of Alabama lineage is Albaamo (or variously Albaama or Alb\xe0amo in different dialects; the plural form is Albaamaha).', u'The word Alabama is believed to have come from the Alabama language and a suggestion the name was borrowed from the Choctaw language is unlikely.', u"The word's spelling varies significantly among historical sources.", u'The first usage appears in three accounts of the Hernando de Soto expedition of 1540 with Garcilaso de la Vega using Alibamo, while the Knight of Elvas and Rodrigo Ranjel wrote Alibamu and Limamu, respectively, in efforts to transliterate the term.', u'As early as 1702, the French called the tribe the Alibamon, with French maps identifying the river as Rivi\xe8re des Alibamons.', u'Other spellings of the appellation have included Alibamu, Alabamo, Albama, Alebamon, Alibama, Alibamou, Alabamu, Allibamou.', u"Sources disagree on the word's meaning.", u'Some scholars suggest the word comes from the Choctaw alba (meaning "plants" or "weeds") and amo (meaning "to cut", "to trim", or "to gather").', u'The meaning may have been "clearers of the thicket" or "herb gatherers", referring to clearing land for cultivation or collecting medicinal plants.', u'The state has numerous place names of Native American origin.', u'However, there are no correspondingly similar words in the Alabama language.', u'An 1842 article in the Jacksonville Republican proposed it meant "Here We Rest."', u'This notion was popularized in the 1850s through the writings of Alexander Beaufort Meek.', u'Experts in the Muskogean languages have been unable to find evidence to support such a translation.', u'And, thus, this is probably erroneous.', u'== History ==\n\n\n=== Pre-European settlement ===\n\nIndigenous peoples of varying cultures lived in the area for thousands of years before European colonization.', u'Trade with the northeastern tribes by the Ohio River began during the Burial Mound Period (1000 BC\u2013AD 700) and continued until European contact.', u'The agrarian Mississippian culture covered most of the state from 1000 to 1600 AD, with one of its major centers built at what is now the Moundville Archaeological Site in Moundville, Alabama.', u'This is the second-largest complex of the classic Middle Mississippian era, after Cahokia in present-day Illinois, which was the center of the culture.', u"Analysis of artifacts from archaeological excavations at Moundville were the basis of scholars' formulating the characteristics of the Southeastern Ceremonial Complex (SECC).", u'Contrary to popular belief, the SECC appears to have no direct links to Mesoamerican culture, but developed independently.', u'The Ceremonial Complex represents a major component of the religion of the Mississippian peoples; it is one of the primary means by which their religion is understood.', u'Among the historical tribes of Native American people living in present-day Alabama at the time of European contact were the Cherokee, an Iroquoian language people; and the Muskogean-speaking Alabama (Alibamu), Chickasaw, Choctaw, Creek, and Koasati.', u'While part of the same large language family, the Muskogee tribes developed distinct cultures and languages.', u'=== European settlement ===\nWith exploration in the 16th century, the Spanish were the first Europeans to reach Alabama.', u'The expedition of Hernando de Soto passed through Mabila and other parts of the state in 1540.', u"More than 160 years later, the French founded the region's first European settlement at Old Mobile in 1702.", u'The city was moved to the current site of Mobile in 1711.', u'This area was claimed by the French from 1702 to 1763 as part of La Louisiane.', u"After the French lost to the British in the Seven Years' War, it became part of British West Florida from 1763 to 1783.", u'After the United States victory in the American Revolutionary War, the territory was divided between the United States and Spain.', u'The latter retained control of this western territory from 1783 until the surrender of the Spanish garrison at Mobile to U.S. forces on April 13, 1813.', u'Thomas Bassett, a loyalist to the British monarchy during the Revolutionary era, was one of the earliest white settlers in the state outside Mobile.', u'He settled in the Tombigbee District during the early 1770s.', u"The district's boundaries were roughly limited to the area within a few miles of the Tombigbee River and included portions of what is today southern Clarke County, northernmost Mobile County, and most of Washington County.", u'What is now the counties of Baldwin and Mobile became part of Spanish West Florida in 1783, part of the independent Republic of West Florida in 1810, and was finally added to the Mississippi Territory in 1812.', u'Most of what is now the northern two-thirds of Alabama was known as the Yazoo lands beginning during the British colonial period.', u'It was claimed by the Province of Georgia from 1767 onwards.', u'Following the Revolutionary War, it remained a part of Georgia, although heavily disputed.', u'With the exception of the area around Mobile and the Yazoo lands, what is now the lower one-third Alabama was made part of the Mississippi Territory when it was organized in 1798.', u'The Yazoo lands were added to the territory in 1804, following the Yazoo land scandal.', u'Spain kept a claim on its former Spanish West Florida territory in what would become the coastal counties until the Adams\u2013On\xeds Treaty officially ceded it to the United States in 1819.', u'=== 19th century ===\nBefore the admission of Mississippi as a state on December 10, 1817, the more sparsely settled eastern half of the territory was separated and named the Alabama Territory.', u'The Alabama Territory was created by the United States Congress on March 3, 1817.', u'St. Stephens, now abandoned, served as the territorial capital from 1817 to 1819.', u'The U.S. Congress selected Huntsville as the site for the first Constitutional Convention of Alabama after it was approved to become the 22nd state.', u'From July 5 to August 2, 1819, delegates met to prepare the new state constitution.', u"Huntsville served as Alabama's temporary capital from 1819 to 1820, when the seat of state government was moved to Cahaba in Dallas County.", u'Cahaba, now a ghost town, was the first permanent state capital from 1820 to 1825.', u'Alabama Fever was underway when the state was admitted to the Union, with settlers and land speculators pouring into the state to take advantage of fertile land suitable for cotton cultivation.', u'Part of the frontier in the 1820s and 1830s, its constitution provided for universal suffrage for white men.', u'Southeastern planters and traders from the Upper South brought slaves with them as the cotton plantations in Alabama expanded.', u"The economy of the central Black Belt (named for its dark, productive soil) was built around large cotton plantations whose owners' wealth grew largely from slave labor.", u'The area also drew many poor, disfranchised people who became subsistence farmers.', u'Alabama had an estimated population of under 10,000 people in 1810, but it increased to more than 300,000 people by 1830.', u'Most Native American tribes were completely removed from the state within a few years of the passage of the Indian Removal Act by Congress in 1830.', u"From 1826 to 1846, Tuscaloosa served as Alabama's capital.", u'On January 30, 1846, the Alabama legislature announced it had voted to move the capital city from Tuscaloosa to Montgomery.', u'The first legislative session in the new capital met in December 1847.', u'A new capitol building was erected under the direction of Stephen Decatur Button of Philadelphia.', u'The first structure burned down in 1849, but was rebuilt on the same site in 1851.', u'This second capitol building in Montgomery remains to the present day.', u'It was designed by Barachias Holt of Exeter, Maine.', u'By 1860, the population had increased to 964,201 people, of which nearly half, 435,080, were enslaved African Americans, and 2,690 were free people of color.', u'On January 11, 1861, Alabama declared its secession from the Union.', u'After remaining an independent republic for a few days, it joined the Confederate States of America.', u"The Confederacy's capital was initially at Montgomery.", u'Alabama was heavily involved in the American Civil War.', u'Although comparatively few battles were fought in the state, Alabama contributed about 120,000 soldiers to the war effort.', u"A company of cavalry soldiers from Huntsville, Alabama joined Nathan Bedford Forrest's battalion in Hopkinsville, Kentucky.", u'The company wore new uniforms with yellow trim on the sleeves, collar and coat tails.', u'This led to them being greeted with "Yellowhammer", and the name later was applied to all Alabama troops in the Confederate Army.', u"Alabama's slaves were freed by the 13th Amendment in 1865.", u'Alabama was under military rule from the end of the war in May 1865 until its official restoration to the Union in 1868.', u'From 1867 to 1874, with most white citizens barred temporarily from voting and freedmen enfranchised, many African Americans emerged as political leaders in the state.', u'Alabama was represented in Congress during this period by three African-American congressmen: Jeremiah Haralson, Benjamin S. Turner, and James T. Rapier.', u'Following the war, the state remained chiefly agricultural, with an economy tied to cotton.', u"During Reconstruction, state legislators ratified a new state constitution in 1868 that created the state's first public school system and expanded women's rights.", u'Legislators funded numerous public road and railroad projects, although these were plagued with allegations of fraud and misappropriation.', u'Organized insurgent, resistance groups tried to suppress the freedmen and Republicans.', u'Besides the short-lived original Ku Klux Klan, these included the Pale Faces, Knights of the White Camellia, Red Shirts, and the White League.', u"Reconstruction in Alabama ended in 1874, when the Democrats regained control of the legislature and governor's office through an election dominated by fraud and violence.", u'They wrote another constitution in 1875, and the legislature passed the Blaine Amendment, prohibiting public money from being used to finance religious-affiliated schools.', u'The same year, legislation was approved that called for racially segregated schools.', u'Railroad passenger cars were segregated in 1891.', u'After disfranchising most African Americans and many poor whites in the 1901 constitution, the Alabama legislature passed more Jim Crow laws at the beginning of the 20th century to impose segregation in everyday life.', u'=== 20th century ===\n\nThe new 1901 Constitution of Alabama included provisions for voter registration that effectively disenfranchised large portions of the population, including nearly all African Americans and Native Americans, and tens of thousands of poor whites, through making voter registration difficult, requiring a poll taxes and literacy test.', u'By 1903, only 2,980 African Americans were registered in Alabama, although at least 74,000 were literate.', u'This compared to more than 181,000 African Americans eligible to vote in 1900.', u'The numbers dropped even more in later decades.', u'While the planter class had persuaded poor whites to vote for this legislative effort to suppress black voting, the new restrictions resulted in their disenfranchisement as well, due mostly to the imposition of a cumulative poll tax.', u'By 1941, whites constituted a slight majority of those disenfranchised by these laws: 600,000 Whites vs. 520,000 African-Americans.', u'Nearly all African Americans had lost the ability to vote.', u'Despite numerous legal challenges that succeeded in overturning certain provisions, the state legislature would create new ones to maintain disenfranchisement.', u'The exclusion of blacks from the political system persisted until after passage of federal civil rights legislation in the 1965 to enforce their constitutional rights as citizens.', u'The 1901 constitution required racial segregation of public schools.', u'It also restated that interracial marriage was illegal, as it had been prohibited in 1867.', u'Into the 1950s, the state legislature passed additional racial segregation laws related to public facilities: jails were segregated in 1911; hospitals in 1915; toilets, hotels, and restaurants in 1928; and bus stop waiting rooms in 1945.', u'The rural-dominated Alabama legislature consistently underfunded schools and services for the disenfranchised African Americans, but it did not relieve them of paying taxes.', u'Partially as a response to chronic underfunding of education for African Americans in the South, the Rosenwald Fund began funding the construction of what came to be known as Rosenwald Schools.', u'In Alabama these schools were designed and the construction partially financed with Rosenwald funds, which paid one-third of the construction costs.', u'The fund required the local community and state to raise matching funds to pay the rest.', u'Black residents effectively taxed themselves twice, by raising additional monies to supply matching funds for such schools, which were built in many rural areas.', u'They often donated land and labor as well.', u'Beginning in 1913, the first 80 Rosenwald Schools were built in Alabama for African-American children.', u"A total of 387 schools, seven teachers' houses, and several vocational buildings were completed by 1937 in the state.", u'Several of the surviving school buildings in the state are now listed on the National Register of Historic Places.', u'Continued racial discrimination and lynchings, agricultural depression, and the failure of the cotton crops due to boll weevil infestation led tens of thousands of African Americans from rural Alabama and other states to seek opportunities in northern and midwestern cities during the early decades of the 20th century as part of the Great Migration out of the South.', u'Reflecting this emigration, the population growth rate in Alabama (see "Historical Populations" table below) dropped by nearly half from 1910 to 1920.', u'At the same time, many rural people, both White and African American, migrated to the city of Birmingham to work in new industrial jobs.', u'Birmingham experienced such rapid growth that it was called the "Magic City".', u"By the 1920s, Birmingham was the 19th-largest city in the United States and had more than 30% of the state's population.", u'Heavy industry and mining were the basis of its economy.', u'Its residents were under-represented for decades in the state legislature, which refused to redistrict after each decennial census according to population changes, as it was required by the state constitution.', u'This did not change until the late 1960s following a lawsuit and court order.', u'Beginning in the 1940s, when the courts started taking the first steps to recognize the voting rights of black voters, the Alabama legislature took several counter -steps designed to disfranchise black voters.', u'The legislature passed, and the voters ratified [as these were mostly white voters], a state constitutional amendment that gave local registrars greater latitude to disqualify voter registration applicants.', u'Black citizens in Mobile successfully challenged this amendment as a violation of the Fifteenth Amendment.', u'The legislature also changed the boundaries of Tuskegee to a 28-sided figure designed to fence out blacks from the city limits.', u'The Supreme Court unanimously held that this racial "gerrymandering" violated the Constitution.', u'In 1961, ... the Alabama legislature also intentionally diluted the effect of the black vote by instituting numbered place requirements for local elections.', u'Industrial development related to the demands of World War II brought a level of prosperity to the state not seen since before the Civil War.', u'Rural workers poured into the largest cities in the state for better jobs and a higher standard of living.', u'One example of this massive influx of workers occurred in Mobile.', u'Between 1940 and 1943, more than 89,000 people moved into the city to work for war-related industries.', u'Cotton and other cash crops faded in importance as the state developed a manufacturing and service base.', u'Despite massive population changes in the state from 1901 to 1961, the rural-dominated legislature refused to reapportion House and Senate seats based on population, as required by the state constitution to follow the results of decennial censuses.', u'They held on to old representation to maintain political and economic power in agricultural areas.', u'In addition, the state legislature gerrymandered the few Birmingham legislative seats to ensure election by persons living outside Birmingham.', u"One result was that Jefferson County, containing Birmingham's industrial and economic powerhouse, contributed more than one-third of all tax revenue to the state, but did not receive a proportional amount in services.", u'Urban interests were consistently underrepresented in the legislature.', u'A 1960 study noted that because of rural domination, "a minority of about 25 per cent of the total state population is in majority control of the Alabama legislature."', u"A class action suit initiated on behalf of plaintiffs in Lowndes County, Alabama challenged the state legislature's lack of redistricting for congressional seats.", u'In 1962 White v. Crook, Judge Frank M. Johnson ordered the state to redistrict.', u'United States Supreme Court cases of Baker v. Carr (1962) and Reynolds v. Sims (1964) ruled that the principle of "one man, one vote" needed to be the basis of both houses of state legislatures as well, and that their districts had to be based on population, rather than geographic counties, as Alabama had used for its senate.', u'In 1972, for the first time since 1901, the legislature completed the first congressional redistricting based on the decennial census.', u'This benefited the urban areas that had developed, as well as all in the population who had been underrepresented for more than 60 years.', u'Other changes were made to implement representative state house and senate districts.', u'African Americans continued to press in the 1950s and 1960s to end disenfranchisement and segregation in the state through the Civil Rights Movement, including legal challenges.', u'In 1954, the US Supreme Court ruled in Brown v. Board of Education that public schools had to be desegregated, but Alabama was slow to comply.', u'During the 1960s, under Governor George Wallace, Alabama resisted compliance with federal demands for desegregation.', u'The Civil Rights Movement had notable events in Alabama, including the Montgomery Bus Boycott (1955\u201356), Freedom Rides in 1961, and 1965 Selma to Montgomery marches.', u'These contributed to Congressional passage and enactment of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Voting Rights Act of 1965 by the U.S. Congress.', u'Legal segregation ended in the states in 1964, but Jim Crow customs often continued until specifically challenged in court.', u'Despite recommendations of a 1973 Alabama Constitutional Commission, the state legislature did not approve an amendment to establish home rule for counties.', u'There is very limited home rule, but the legislature is deeply involved in passing legislation that applies to county-level functions and policies.', u'This both deprives local residents of the ability to govern themselves and distracts the legislature from statewide issues.', u'Alabama has made some changes since the late 20th century and has used new types of voting to increase representation.', u'In the 1980s, an omnibus redistricting case, Dillard v. Crenshaw County, challenged the at-large voting for representative seats of 180 Alabama jurisdictions, including counties and school boards.', u'At-large voting had diluted the votes of any minority in a county, as the majority tended to take all seats.', u'Despite African Americans making up a significant minority in the state, they had been unable to elect any representatives in most of the at-large jurisdictions.', u'As part of settlement of this case, five Alabama cites and counties, including Chilton County, adopted a system of cumulative voting for election of representatives in multi-seat jurisdictions.', u'This has resulted in more proportional representation for voters.', u'In another form of proportional representation, 23 jurisdictions use limited voting, as in Conecuh County.', u'In 1982, limited voting was first tested in Conecuh County.', u'Together use of these systems has increased the number of African Americans and women being elected to local offices, resulting in governments that are more representative of their citizens.', u'== Geography ==\n\nAlabama is the thirtieth-largest state in the United States with 52,419 square miles (135,760 km2) of total area: 3.2% of the area is water, making Alabama 23rd in the amount of surface water, also giving it the second-largest inland waterway system in the U.S. About three-fifths of the land area is a gentle plain with a general descent towards the Mississippi River and the Gulf of Mexico.', u'The North Alabama region is mostly mountainous, with the Tennessee River cutting a large valley and creating numerous creeks, streams, rivers, mountains, and lakes.', u'Alabama is bordered by the states of Tennessee to the north, Georgia to the east, Florida to the south, and Mississippi to the west.', u'Alabama has coastline at the Gulf of Mexico, in the extreme southern edge of the state.', u'The state ranges in elevation from sea level at Mobile Bay to over 1,800 feet (550 m) in the Appalachian Mountains in the northeast.', u'The highest point is Mount Cheaha, at a height of 2,413 ft (735 m).', u"Alabama's land consists of 22 million acres (89,000 km2) of forest or 67% of total land area.", u'Suburban Baldwin County, along the Gulf Coast, is the largest county in the state in both land area and water area.', u'Areas in Alabama administered by the National Park Service include Horseshoe Bend National Military Park near Alexander City; Little River Canyon National Preserve near Fort Payne; Russell Cave National Monument in Bridgeport; Tuskegee Airmen National Historic Site in Tuskegee; and Tuskegee Institute National Historic Site near Tuskegee.', u'Additionally, Alabama has four National Forests: Conecuh, Talladega, Tuskegee, and William B. Bankhead.', u'Alabama also contains the Natchez Trace Parkway, the Selma To Montgomery National Historic Trail, and the Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail.', u'A notable natural wonder in Alabama is "Natural Bridge" rock, the longest natural bridge east of the Rockies, located just south of Haleyville.', u'A 5-mile (8 km)-wide meteorite impact crater is located in Elmore County, just north of Montgomery.', u'This is the Wetumpka crater, the site of "Alabama\'s greatest natural disaster."', u'A 1,000-foot (300 m)-wide meteorite hit the area about 80 million years ago.', u'The hills just east of downtown Wetumpka showcase the eroded remains of the impact crater that was blasted into the bedrock, with the area labeled the Wetumpka crater or astrobleme ("star-wound") because of the concentric rings of fractures and zones of shattered rock that can be found beneath the surface.', u'In 2002, Christian Koeberl with the Institute of Geochemistry University of Vienna published evidence and established the site as the 157th recognized impact crater on Earth.', u'=== Climate ===\n\nThe state is classified as humid subtropical (Cfa) under the Koppen Climate Classification.', u'The average annual temperature is 64 \xb0F (18 \xb0C).', u'Temperatures tend to be warmer in the southern part of the state with its proximity to the Gulf of Mexico, while the northern parts of the state, especially in the Appalachian Mountains in the northeast, tend to be slightly cooler.', u'Generally, Alabama has very hot summers and mild winters with copious precipitation throughout the year.', u'Alabama receives an average of 56 inches (1,400 mm) of rainfall annually and enjoys a lengthy growing season of up to 300 days in the southern part of the state.', u'Summers in Alabama are among the hottest in the U.S., with high temperatures averaging over 90 \xb0F (32 \xb0C) throughout the summer in some parts of the state.', u'Alabama is also prone to tropical storms and even hurricanes.', u'Areas of the state far away from the Gulf are not immune to the effects of the storms, which often dump tremendous amounts of rain as they move inland and weaken.', u'South Alabama reports many thunderstorms.', u'The Gulf Coast, around Mobile Bay, averages between 70 and 80 days per year with thunder reported.', u'This activity decreases somewhat further north in the state, but even the far north of the state reports thunder on about 60 days per year.', u'Occasionally, thunderstorms are severe with frequent lightning and large hail; the central and northern parts of the state are most vulnerable to this type of storm.', u'Alabama ranks ninth in the number of deaths from lightning and tenth in the number of deaths from lightning strikes per capita.', u'Alabama, along with Oklahoma, has the most reported EF5 tornadoes of any state, according to statistics from the National Climatic Data Center for the period January 1, 1950, to June 2013.', u'Several long-tracked F5/EF5 tornadoes have contributed to Alabama reporting more tornado fatalities than any other state.', u'The state was affected by the 1974 Super Outbreak and was devastated tremendously by the 2011 Super Outbreak.', u'The 2011 Super Outbreak produced a record amount of tornadoes in the state.', u'The tally reached 62.', u'The peak season for tornadoes varies from the northern to southern parts of the state.', u'Alabama is one of the few places in the world that has a secondary tornado season in November and December, along with the spring severe weather season.', u'The northern part of the state\u2014along the Tennessee Valley\u2014is one of the areas in the U.S. most vulnerable to violent tornadoes.', u'The area of Alabama and Mississippi most affected by tornadoes is sometimes referred to as Dixie Alley, as distinct from the Tornado Alley of the Southern Plains.', u'Winters are generally mild in Alabama, as they are throughout most of the southeastern U.S., with average January low temperatures around 40 \xb0F (4 \xb0C) in Mobile and around 32 \xb0F (0 \xb0C) in Birmingham.', u'Although snow is a rare event in much of Alabama, areas of the state north of Montgomery may receive a dusting of snow a few times every winter, with an occasional moderately heavy snowfall every few years.', u"Historic snowfall events include New Year's Eve 1963 snowstorm and the 1993 Storm of the Century.", u'The annual average snowfall for the Birmingham area is 2 inches (51 mm) per year.', u'In the southern Gulf coast, snowfall is less frequent, sometimes going several years without any snowfall.', u"Alabama's highest temperature of 112 \xb0F (44 \xb0C) was recorded on September 5, 1925 in the unincorporated community of Centerville.", u'The record low of \u221227 \xb0F (\u221233 \xb0C) occurred on January 30, 1966 in New Market.', u'=== Flora and fauna ===\n\nAlabama is home to a diverse array of flora and fauna, due largely to a variety of habitats that range from the Tennessee Valley, Appalachian Plateau, and Ridge-and-Valley Appalachians of the north to the Piedmont, Canebrake and Black Belt of the central region to the Gulf Coastal Plain and beaches along the Gulf of Mexico in the south.', u'The state is usually ranked among the top in nation for its range of overall biodiversity.', u'Alabama is in the subtropical coniferous forest biome and once boasted huge expanses of pine forest, which still form the largest proportion of forests in the state.', u'It currently ranks fifth in the nation for the diversity of its flora.', u'It is home to nearly 4,000 pteridophyte and spermatophyte plant species.', u'Indigenous animal species in the state include 62 mammal species, 93 reptile species, 73 amphibian species, roughly 307 native freshwater fish species, and 420 bird species that spend at least part of their year within the state.', u'Invertebrates include 83 crayfish species and 383 mollusk species.', u'113 of these mollusk species have never been collected outside the state.', u'== Demographics ==\n\nThe United States Census Bureau estimates that the population of Alabama was 4,858,979 on July 1, 2015, which represents an increase of 79,243, or 1.66%, since the 2010 Census.', u'This includes a natural increase since the last census of 121,054 people (that is 502,457 births minus 381,403 deaths) and an increase due to net migration of 104,991 people into the state.', u'Immigration from outside the U.S. resulted in a net increase of 31,180 people, and migration within the country produced a net gain of 73,811 people.', u'The state had 108,000 foreign-born (2.4% of the state population), of which an estimated 22.2% were illegal immigrants (24,000).', u'The center of population of Alabama is located in Chilton County, outside the town of Jemison.', u'=== Race and ancestry ===\nAccording to the 2010 Census, Alabama had a population of 4,779,736.', u'The racial composition of the state was 68.5% White (67.0% Non-Hispanic White and 1.5% Hispanic White), 26.2% Black or African American, 3.9% Hispanic or Latino of any race, 1.1% Asian, 0.6% American Indian and Alaska Native, 0.1% Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander, 2.0% from Some Other Race, and 1.5% from Two or More Races.', u"In 2011, 46.6% of Alabama's population younger than age 1 were minorities.", u'The largest reported ancestry groups in Alabama are: African American (26.2%), English (23.6%), Irish (7.7%), German (5.7%), and Scots-Irish (2.0%).', u'Those citing "American" ancestry in Alabama are generally of English or British ancestry; many Anglo-Americans identify as having American ancestry because their roots have been in North America for so long, in some cases since the 1600s.', u'Demographers estimate that a minimum of 20\u201323% of people in Alabama are of predominantly English ancestry and that the figure is likely higher.', u'In the 1980 census, 41% of the people in Alabama identified as being of English ancestry, making them the largest ethnic group at the time.', u'Based on historic migration and settlement patterns in the southern colonies and states, demographers estimated there are more people in Alabama of Scots-Irish origins than self-reported.', u'Many people in Alabama claim Irish ancestry because of the term Scots-Irish but, based on historic immigration and settlement, their ancestors were more likely Protestant Scots-Irish coming from northern Ireland, where they had been for a few generations as part of the English colonization.', u'The Scots-Irish were the largest non-English immigrant group from the British Isles before the American Revolution, and many settled in the South, later moving into the Deep South as it was developed.', u'In 1984, under the Davis\u2013Strong Act, the state legislature established the Alabama Indian Affairs Commission.', u'Native American groups within the state had increasingly been demanding recognition as ethnic groups and seeking an end to discrimination.', u'Given the long history of slavery and associated racial segregation, the Native American peoples, who have sometimes been of mixed race, have insisted on having their cultural identification respected.', u'In the past, their self-identification was often overlooked as the state tried to impose a binary breakdown of society into white and black.', u'The state has officially recognized nine American Indian tribes in the state, descended mostly from the Five Civilized Tribes of the American Southeast.', u'These are:\nPoarch Band of Creek Indians (who also have federal recognition),\nMOWA Band of Choctaw Indians,\nStar Clan of Muscogee Creeks,\nEchota Cherokee Tribe of Alabama,\nCherokee Tribe of Northeast Alabama,\nCher-O-Creek Intra Tribal Indians,\nMa-Chis Lower Creek Indian Tribe,\nPiqua Shawnee Tribe, and\nAni-Yun-Wiya Nation.', u'The state government has promoted recognition of Native American contributions to the state, including the designation in 2000 for Columbus Day to be jointly celebrated as American Indian Heritage Day.', u'=== Population centers ===\n\nSources: Census.gov\nSources: Census.gov\n\n\n=== Language ===\n95.1% of all Alabama residents five years old or older spoke only English at home in 2010, a minor decrease from 96.1% in 2000.', u'Alabama English is predominantly Southern, and is related to South Midland speech which was taken across the border from Tennessee.', u"In the major Southern speech region, there is the decreasing loss of the final /r/, for example the /boyd/ pronunciation of 'bird.'", u"In the northern third of the state, there is a South Midland 'arm' and 'barb' rhyming with 'form' and 'orb.'", u'Unique words in Alabama English include: redworm (earthworm), peckerwood (woodpecker), snake doctor and snake feeder (dragonfly), tow sack (burlap bag), plum peach (clingstone), French harp (harmonica), and dog irons (andirons).', u'=== Religion ===\n\nIn the 2008 American Religious Identification Survey, 86% of Alabama respondents reported their religion as Christian, including 6% Catholic, and 11% as having no religion.', u'The composition of other traditions is 0.5% Mormon, 0.5% Jewish, 0.5% Muslim, 0.5% Buddhist, and 0.5% Hindu.', u'==== Christianity ====\n\nAlabama is located in the middle of the Bible Belt, a region of numerous Protestant Christians.', u'Alabama has been identified as one of the most religious states in the United States, with about 58% of the population attending church regularly.', u'A majority of people in the state identify as Evangelical Protestant.', u'As of 2010, the three largest denominational groups in Alabama are the Southern Baptist Convention, The United Methodist Church, and non-denominational Evangelical Protestant.', u'In Alabama, the Southern Baptist Convention has the highest number of adherents with 1,380,121; this is followed by the United Methodist Church with 327,734 adherents, non-denominational Evangelical Protestant with 220,938 adherents, and the Catholic Church with 150,647 adherents.', u'Many Baptist and Methodist congregations became established in the Great Awakening of the early 19th century, when preachers proselytized across the South.', u'The Assemblies of God had almost 60,000 members, the Churches of Christ had nearly 120,000 members.', u'The Presbyterian churches, strongly associated with Scots-Irish immigrants of the 18th century and their descendants, had a combined membership around 75,000 (PCA-28,009 members in 108 congregations, PC(USA)-26,247 members in 147 congregations, the Cumberland Presbyterian Church-6,000 members in 59 congregations, the Cumberland Presbyterian Church in America-5,000 members and 50 congregations plus the EPC and Associate Reformed Presbyterians with 230 members and 9 congregations).', u'In a 2007 survey, nearly 70% of respondents could name all four of the Christian Gospels.', u'Of those who indicated a religious preference, 59% said they possessed a "full understanding" of their faith and needed no further learning.', u'In a 2007 poll, 92% of Alabamians reported having at least some confidence in churches in the state.', u"==== Other faiths ====\nAlthough in much smaller numbers, many other religious faiths are represented in the state as well, including Judaism, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism, the Bah\xe1'\xed Faith, and Unitarian Universalism.", u'Jews have been present in what is now Alabama since 1763, during the colonial era of Mobile, when Sephardic Jews immigrated from London.', u"The oldest Jewish congregation in the state is Congregation Sha'arai Shomayim in Mobile.", u'It was formally recognized by the state legislature on January 25, 1844.', u'Later immigrants in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries tended to be Ashkenazi Jews from eastern Europe.', u'Jewish denominations in the state include two Orthodox, four Conservative, ten Reform, and one Humanistic synagogue.', u'Muslims have been increasing in Alabama, with 31 mosques built by 2011, many by African-American converts.', u'Several Hindu temples and cultural centers in the state have been founded by Indian immigrants and their descendants, the best-known being the Shri Swaminarayan Mandir in Birmingham, the Hindu Temple and Cultural Center of Birmingham in Pelham, the Hindu Cultural Center of North Alabama in Capshaw, and the Hindu Mandir and Cultural Center in Tuscaloosa.', u'There are six Dharma centers and organizations for Theravada Buddhists.', u'Most monastic Buddhist temples are concentrated in southern Mobile County, near Bayou La Batre.', u'This area has attracted an influx of refugees from Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam during the 1970s and thereafter.', u'The four temples within a ten-mile radius of Bayou La Batre, include Chua Chanh Giac, Wat Buddharaksa, and Wat Lao Phoutthavihan.', u"The first community of adherents of the Baha'i Faith in Alabama was founded in 1896 by Paul K. Dealy, who moved from Chicago to Fairhope.", u"Baha'i Centers in Alabama exist in Birmingham, Alabama, Huntsville, Alabama, and Florence, Alabama.", u'=== Health ===\nA Centers for Disease Control and Prevention study in 2008 showed that obesity in Alabama was a problem, with most counties having over 29% of adults obese, except for ten which had a rate between 26% and 29%.', u'Residents of the state, along with those in five other states, were least likely in the nation to be physically active during leisure time.', u'Alabama, and the southeastern U.S. in general, has one of the highest incidences of adult onset diabetes in the country, exceeding 10% of adults.', u'== Economy ==\n\nThe state has invested in aerospace, education, health care, banking, and various heavy industries, including automobile manufacturing, mineral extraction, steel production and fabrication.', u'By 2006, crop and animal production in Alabama was valued at $1.5 billion.', u"In contrast to the primarily agricultural economy of the previous century, this was only about 1% of the state's gross domestic product.", u'The number of private farms has declined at a steady rate since the 1960s, as land has been sold to developers, timber companies, and large farming conglomerates.', u'Non-agricultural employment in 2008 was 121,800 in management occupations; 71,750 in business and financial operations; 36,790 in computer-related and mathematical occupation; 44,200 in architecture and engineering; 12,410 in life, physical, and social sciences; 32,260 in community and social services; 12,770 in legal occupations; 116,250 in education, training, and library services; 27,840 in art, design and media occupations; 121,110 in healthcare; 44,750 in fire fighting, law enforcement, and security; 154,040 in food preparation and serving; 76,650 in building and grounds cleaning and maintenance; 53,230 in personal care and services; 244,510 in sales; 338,760 in office and administration support; 20,510 in farming, fishing, and forestry; 120,155 in construction and mining, gas, and oil extraction; 106,280 in installation, maintenance, and repair; 224,110 in production; and 167,160 in transportation and material moving.', u'According to the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis, the 2008 total gross state product was $170 billion, or $29,411 per capita.', u"Alabama's 2012 GDP increased 1.2% from the previous year.", u'The single largest increase came in the area of information.', u'In 2010, per capita income for the state was $22,984.', u"The state's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 5.8% in April 2015.", u'This compared to a nationwide seasonally adjusted rate of 5.4%.', u'Alabama has no state minimum wage and uses the federal minimum wage of $7.25.', u'In February 2016, the state passed legislation that prevents Alabama municipalities from raising the minimum wage in their locality.', u"The legislation voids a Birmingham city ordinance that was to raise the city's minimum wage to $10.10.", u"=== Largest employers ===\n\nThe five employers that employed the most employees in Alabama in April 2011 were:\nThe next twenty largest employers, as of 2011, included:\n\n\n=== Agriculture ===\nAlabama's agricultural outputs include poultry and eggs, cattle, fish, plant nursery items, peanuts, cotton, grains such as corn and sorghum, vegetables, milk, soybeans, and peaches.", u'Although known as "The Cotton State", Alabama ranks between eighth and tenth in national cotton production, according to various reports, with Texas, Georgia and Mississippi comprising the top three.', u"=== Industry ===\nAlabama's industrial outputs include iron and steel products (including cast-iron and steel pipe); paper, lumber, and wood products; mining (mostly coal); plastic products; cars and trucks; and apparel.", u"In addition, Alabama produces aerospace and electronic products, mostly in the Huntsville area, the location of NASA's George C. Marshall Space Flight Center and the U.S. Army Materiel Command, headquartered at Redstone Arsenal.", u"A great deal of Alabama's economic growth since the 1990s has been due to the state's expanding automotive manufacturing industry.", u'Located in the state are Honda Manufacturing of Alabama, Hyundai Motor Manufacturing Alabama, Mercedes-Benz U.S. International, and Toyota Motor Manufacturing Alabama, as well as their various suppliers.', u'Since 1993, the automobile industry has generated more than 67,800 new jobs in the state.', u'Alabama currently ranks 4th in the nation for vehicle exports.', u'Automakers accounted for approximately a third of the industrial expansion in the state in 2012.', u"The eight models produced at the state's auto factories totaled combined sales of 74,335 vehicles for 2012.", u'The strongest model sales during this period were the Hyundai Elantra compact car, the Mercedes-Benz GL-Class sport utility vehicle and the Honda Ridgeline sport utility truck.', u'Steel producers Outokumpu, Nucor, SSAB, ThyssenKrupp, and U.S. Steel have facilities in Alabama and employ over 10,000 people.', u'In May 2007, German steelmaker ThyssenKrupp selected Calvert in Mobile County for a 4.65 billion combined stainless and carbon steel processing facility.', u"ThyssenKrupp's stainless steel division, Inoxum, including the stainless portion of the Calvert plant, was sold to Finnish stainless steel company Outokumpu in 2012.", u'The remaining portion of the ThyssenKrupp plant had final bids submitted by ArcelorMittal and Nippon Steel for $1.6 billion in March 2013.', u'Companhia Sider\xfargica Nacional submitted a combined bid for the mill at Calvert, plus a majority stake in the ThyssenKrupp mill in Brazil, for $3.8 billion.', u'In July 2013, the plant was sold to ArcelorMittal and Nippon Steel.', u'The Hunt Refining Company, a subsidiary of Hunt Consolidated, Inc., is based in Tuscaloosa and operates a refinery there.', u'The company also operates terminals in Mobile, Melvin, and Moundville.', u'JVC America, Inc. operates an optical disc replication and packaging plant in Tuscaloosa.', u'The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company operates a large plant in Gadsden that employs about 1,400 people.', u'It has been in operation since 1929.', u'Construction of an Airbus A320 family aircraft assembly plant in Mobile was formally announced by Airbus CEO Fabrice Br\xe9gier from the Mobile Convention Center on July 2, 2012.', u'The plans include a $600 million factory at the Brookley Aeroplex for the assembly of the A319, A320 and A321 aircraft.', u'Construction began in 2013, with plans for it to become operable by 2015 and produce up to 50 aircraft per year by 2017.', u"The assembly plant is the company's first factory to be built within the United States.", u'It was announced on February 1, 2013 that Airbus had hired Alabama-based Hoar Construction to oversee construction of the facility.', u'=== Tourism ===\n\nAn estimated 20 million tourists visit the state each year.', u'Over 100,000 of these are from other countries, including from Canada, the United Kingdom, Germany and Japan.', u'In 2006, 22.3 million tourists spent $8.3 billion providing an estimated 162,000 jobs in the state.', u"Some of the most popular areas include the Rocket City of Huntsville, the beaches along the Gulf, and the state's capitol in Montgomery.", u'=== Healthcare ===\nUAB Hospital is the only Level I trauma center in Alabama.', u'UAB is the largest state government employer in Alabama, with a workforce of about 18,000.', u'=== Banking ===\n\nAlabama has the headquarters of Regions Financial Corporation, BBVA Compass, Superior Bancorp and the former Colonial Bancgroup.', u'Birmingham-based Compass Banchshares was acquired by Spanish-based BBVA in September 2007, although the headquarters of BBVA Compass remains in Birmingham.', u'In November 2006, Regions Financial completed its merger with AmSouth Bancorporation, which was also headquartered in Birmingham.', u'SouthTrust Corporation, another large bank headquartered in Birmingham, was acquired by Wachovia in 2004 for $14.3 billion.', u'The city still has major operations for Wachovia and its now post-operating bank Wells Fargo, which includes a regional headquarters, an operations center campus and a $400 million data center.', u'Nearly a dozen smaller banks are also headquartered in the Birmingham, such as Superior Bancorp, ServisFirst and New South Federal Savings Bank.', u'Birmingham also serves as the headquarters for several large investment management companies, including Harbert Management Corporation.', u'=== Electronics ===\nTelecommunications provider AT&T, formerly BellSouth, has a major presence in Alabama with several large offices in Birmingham.', u'The company has over 6,000 employees and more than 1,200 contract employees.', u'Many commercial technology companies are headquartered in Huntsville, such as the network access company ADTRAN, computer graphics company Intergraph, design and manufacturer of IT infrastructure Avocent, and telecommunications provider Deltacom.', u'Cinram manufactures and distributes 20th Century Fox DVDs and Blu-ray Discs out of their Huntsville plant.', u'=== Construction ===\nRust International has grown to include Brasfield & Gorrie, BE&K, Hoar Construction and B.L.', u'Harbert International, which all routinely are included in the Engineering News-Record lists of top design, international construction, and engineering firms.', u'(Rust International was acquired in 2000 by Washington Group International, which was in turn acquired by San-Francisco based URS Corporation in 2007.)', u"== Law and government ==\n\n\n=== State government ===\n\nThe foundational document for Alabama's government is the Alabama Constitution, which was ratified in 1901.", u"At almost 800 amendments and 310,000 words, it is by some accounts the world's longest constitution and is roughly forty times the length of the United States Constitution.", u"There has been a significant movement to rewrite and modernize Alabama's constitution.", u"Critics suggest that Alabama's constitution highly centralizes power in Montgomery and leaves practically no power in local hands.", u'Most counties do not have home rule.', u'Any policy changes proposed around the state must be approved by the entire Alabama legislature and, frequently, by state referendum.', u'One criticism of the current constitution claims that its complexity and length intentionally codify segregation and racism.', u"Alabama's government is divided into three coequal branches.", u'The legislative branch is the Alabama Legislature, a bicameral assembly composed of the Alabama House of Representatives, with 105 members, and the Alabama Senate, with 35 members.', u'The Legislature is responsible for writing, debating, passing, or defeating state legislation.', u'The Republican Party currently holds a majority in both houses of the Legislature.', u'The Legislature has the power to override a gubernatorial veto by a simple majority (most state Legislatures require a two-thirds majority to override a veto).', u'Until 1964, the state elected state senators by county, with one per county.', u'It had not redistricted congressional districts since passage of its constitution in 1901; as a result, urbanized areas were grossly underrepresented.', u'It had not changed legislative districts to reflect the decennial censuses, either.', u'In Reynolds v. Sims (1964), the US Supreme Court implemented the principle of "one man, one vote", ruling that congressional districts had to be reapportioned based on censuses (as the state already had in its constitution but had not implemented.)', u'Further, it ruled that both houses of bicameral state legislatures had to be apportioned by population, as there was no constitutional basis for states to have geographically based systems.', u'At that time, Alabama and many other states had to change their legislative districting, as many across the country had systems that underrepresented urban areas and districts.', u'This had caused decades of underinvestment in such areas.', u'For instance, Birmingham and Jefferson County taxes had supplied one-third of the state budget, but Jefferson County received only 1/67th of state services in funding.', u'Through the legislative delegations, the Alabama legislature kept control of county governments.', u'The executive branch is responsible for the execution and oversight of laws.', u'It is headed by the Governor of Alabama.', u'Other members of executive branch include the cabinet, the Attorney General of Alabama, the Alabama Secretary of State, the Alabama State Treasurer, and the State Auditor of Alabama.', u'The current governor of the state is Republican Robert Bentley.', u'The lieutenant governor is Republican Kay Ivey.', u'The judicial branch is responsible for interpreting the Constitution and applying the law in state criminal and civil cases.', u"The state's highest court is the Supreme Court of Alabama.", u'Alabama uses partisan elections to choose judges, and since the 1980s judicial campaigns have become increasingly politicized.', u'The current chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court is Republican Roy Moore.', u'All sitting justices on the Alabama Supreme Court are members of the Republican Party.', u'There are two intermediate appellate courts, the Court of Civil Appeals and the Court of Criminal Appeals, and four trial courts: the circuit court (trial court of general jurisdiction), and the district, probate, and municipal courts.', u'The members of the Legislature take office immediately after the November elections.', u'Statewide officials such as the governor, lieutenant governor, attorney general, and other constitutional officers take office the following January.', u'=== Taxes ===\nAlabama levies a 2, 4, or 5 percent personal income tax, depending upon the amount earned and filing status.', u'Taxpayers are allowed to deduct their federal income tax from their Alabama state tax, and can do so even if taking the standard deduction.', u'Taxpayers who file itemized deductions are also allowed to deduct the Federal Insurance Contributions Act tax (Social Security and Medicare tax).', u"The state's general sales tax rate is 4%.", u'Sales tax rates for cities and counties are also added to purchases.', u'For example, the total sales tax rate in Mobile is 10% and there is an additional restaurant tax of 1%, which means that a diner in Mobile would pay an 11% tax on a meal.', u'As of 1999, sales and excise taxes in Alabama account for 51% of all state and local revenue, compared with an average of about 36% nationwide.', u'Alabama is one of seven states that levy a tax on food at the same rate as other goods, and one of two states (the other being neighboring Mississippi) which fully taxes groceries without any offsetting relief for low-income families.', u'(Most states exempt groceries from sales tax or apply a lower tax rate.)', u"Alabama's income tax on poor working families is among the highest in the United States.", u'Alabama is the only state that levies income tax on a family of four with income as low as $4,600, which is barely one-quarter of the federal poverty line.', u"Alabama's threshold is the lowest among the 41 states and the District of Columbia with income taxes.", u'The corporate income tax rate is currently 6.5%.', u'The overall federal, state, and local tax burden in Alabama ranks the state as the second least tax-burdened state in the country.', u'Property taxes are the lowest in the U.S.', u'The current state constitution requires a voter referendum to raise property taxes.', u"Since Alabama's tax structure largely depends on consumer spending, it is subject to high variable budget structure.", u'For example, in 2003 Alabama had an annual budget deficit as high as $670 million.', u'=== County and local governments ===\n\nAlabama has 67 counties.', u'Each county has its own elected legislative branch, usually called the county commission.', u'It also has limited executive authority in the county.', u'Because of the constraints of the Alabama Constitution, only seven counties (Jefferson, Lee, Mobile, Madison, Montgomery, Shelby, and Tuscaloosa) in the state have limited home rule.', u'Instead, most counties in the state must lobby the Local Legislation Committee of the state legislature to get simple local policies approved, ranging from waste disposal to land use zoning.', u'The cumbersome process results in local jurisdictions being unable to manage their problems, and the state legislators are buried in local county issues.', u'The state legislature has retained power over local governments by refusing to pass a constitutional amendment establishing home rule for counties, as recommended by the 1973 Alabama Constitutional Commission.', u'Legislative delegations retain certain powers over each county.', u'United States Supreme Court decisions in Baker v. Carr (1964) required that both houses have districts established on the basis of population, and redistricted after each census, in order to implement the principle of "one man, one vote".', u'Before that, each county was represented by one state senator, leading to underrepresentation in the state senate for more urbanized, populous counties.', u'"The lack of home rule for counties in Alabama has resulted in the proliferation of local legislation permitting counties to do things not authorized by the state constitution.', u"Alabama's constitution has been amended more than 700 times, and almost one-third of the amendments are local in nature, applying to only one county or city.", u'A significant part of each legislative session is spent on local legislation, taking away time and attention of legislators from issues of statewide importance."', u'On November 9, 2011, Jefferson County, which was $4 billion in debt at the time, declared bankruptcy.', u'This is the second-largest Chapter 9 (municipal) bankruptcy in the United States, after the Detroit bankruptcy.', u'Jefferson County emerged from bankruptcy in December 2013 following the approval of a bankruptcy plan by the United States bankruptcy court for the Northern District of Alabama.', u'Alabama is an alcoholic beverage control state, meaning that the state government holds a monopoly on the sale of alcohol.', u'The Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board controls the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages in the state.', u'Twenty-five of the 67 counties are "dry counties" which ban the sale of alcohol, and there are many dry municipalities even in counties which permit alcohol sales.', u'=== Politics ===\n\nDuring Reconstruction following the American Civil War, Alabama was occupied by federal troops of the Third Military District under General John Pope.', u'In 1874, the political coalition of white Democrats known as the Redeemers took control of the state government from the Republicans, in part by suppressing the African-American vote through violence, fraud and intimidation.', u'After 1890, a coalition of White Democratic politicians passed laws to segregate and disenfranchise African American residents, a process completed in provisions of the 1901 constitution.', u'Provisions which disenfranchised African Americans resulted in excluding many poor Whites.', u'By 1941 more Whites than African Americans had been disenfranchised: 600,000 to 520,000.', u'The total effects were greater on the African-American community, as almost all of its citizens were disfranchised and relegated to separate and unequal treatment under the law.', u'From 1901 through the 1960s, the state did not redraw election districts as population grew and shifted within the state during urbanization and industrialization of certain areas.', u'As counties were the basis of election districts, the result was a rural minority that dominated state politics through nearly three-quarters of the century, until a series of federal court cases required redistricting in 1972 to meet equal representation.', u'Alabama state politics gained nationwide and international attention in the 1950s and 1960s during the Civil Rights Movement, when whites bureaucratically, and at times, violently resisted protests for electoral and social reform.', u"Governor George Wallace, the state's only four-term governor, was a controversial figure who vowed to maintain segregation.", u'Only after passage of the federal Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Voting Rights Act of 1965 did African Americans regain the ability to exercise suffrage, among other civil rights.', u'In many jurisdictions, they continued to be excluded from representation by at-large electoral systems, which allowed the majority of the population to dominate elections.', u'Some changes at the county level have occurred following court challenges to establish single-member districts that enable a more diverse representation among county boards.', u'In 2007, the Alabama Legislature passed, and Republican Governor Bob Riley signed a resolution expressing "profound regret" over slavery and its lingering impact.', u'In a symbolic ceremony, the bill was signed in the Alabama State Capitol, which housed Congress of the Confederate States of America.', u'In 2010, Republicans won control of both houses of the legislature for the first time in 136 years, after a nearly complete realignment of political parties, who represent different visions in the 21st century.', u'=== Elections ===\n\n\n==== State elections ====\nWith the disfranchisement of African Americans in 1901, the state became part of the "Solid South", a system in which the Democratic Party operated as effectively the only viable political party in every Southern state.', u'For nearly 100 years, local and state elections in Alabama were decided in the Democratic Party primary, with generally only token Republican challengers running in the General Election.', u'Since the mid to late-20th century, however, there has been a realignment among the two major political parties, and white conservatives started shifting to the Republican Party.', u'In Alabama, majority-white districts are now expected to regularly elect Republican candidates to federal, state and local office.', u'Members of the nine seats on the Alabama Supreme Court and all ten seats on the state appellate courts are elected to office.', u'Until 1994, no Republicans held any of the court seats.', u'In that general election, the then-incumbent Chief Justice of Alabama, Ernest C. Hornsby, refused to leave office after losing the election by approximately 3,000 votes to Republican Perry O. Hooper, Sr.. Hornsby sued Alabama and defiantly remained in office for nearly a year before finally giving up the seat after losing in court.', u'This ultimately led to a collapse of support for Democrats at the ballot box in the next three or four election cycles.', u'The Democrats lost the last of the nineteen court seats in August 2011 with the resignation of the last Democrat on the bench.', u'In the early 21st century, Republicans hold all seven of the statewide elected executive branch offices.', u'Republicans hold six of the eight elected seats on the Alabama State Board of Education.', u'In 2010, Republicans took large majorities of both chambers of the state legislature, giving them control of that body for the first time in 136 years.', u'The last remaining statewide Democrat, who served on the Alabama Public Service Commission was defeated in 2012.', u'Only two Republican Lieutenant Governors have been elected since the end of Reconstruction, when Republicans generally represented Reconstruction government, including the newly emancipated freedmen who had gained the franchise.', u'The two GOP Lt. Governors were Steve Windom (1999-2003) and the current Lt.', u'Governor, Kay Ivey, who was elected in 2010 and re-elected in 2014.', u'==== Local elections ====\nMany local offices (County Commissioners, Boards of Education, Tax Assessors, Tax Collectors, etc.)', u'in the state are still held by Democrats.', u'Many rural counties have voters who are majority Democrats, resulting in local elections being decided in the Democratic primary.', u'Similarly many metropolitan and suburban counties are majority-Republican and elections are effectively decided in the Republican Primary, although there are exceptions.', u"Alabama's 67 County Sheriffs are elected in partisan, at-large races, and Democrats still retain the narrow majority of those posts.", u'The current split is 35 Democrats, 31 Republicans, and one Independent Fayette.', u'However, most of the Democratic sheriffs preside over rural and less populated counties.', u'The majority of Republican sheriffs have been elected in the more urban/suburban and heavily populated counties.', u'As of 2015, the state of Alabama has one female sheriff, in Morgan County, Alabama, and ten African-American sheriffs.', u"==== Federal elections ====\nThe state's two U.S. senators are Jefferson B.", u'Sessions III and Richard C. Shelby, both Republicans.', u'Shelby was originally elected to the Senate as a Democrat in 1986 and re-elected in 1992, but switched parties immediately following the November 1994 general election.', u'In the U.S. House of Representatives, the state is represented by seven members, six of whom are Republicans: (Bradley Byrne, Mike D. Rogers, Robert Aderholt, Morris J. Brooks, Martha Roby, and Gary Palmer) and one Democrat: Terri Sewell.', u'== Education ==\n\n\n=== Primary and secondary education ===\n\nPublic primary and secondary education in Alabama is under the purview of the Alabama State Board of Education as well as local oversight by 67 county school boards and 60 city boards of education.', u'Together, 1,496 individual schools provide education for 744,637 elementary and secondary students.', u'Public school funding is appropriated through the Alabama Legislature through the Education Trust Fund.', u'In FY 2006\u20132007, Alabama appropriated $3,775,163,578 for primary and secondary education.', u'That represented an increase of $444,736,387 over the previous fiscal year.', u'In 2007, over 82 percent of schools made adequate yearly progress (AYP) toward student proficiency under the National No Child Left Behind law, using measures determined by the state of Alabama.', u"While Alabama's public education system has improved in recent decades, it lags behind in achievement compared to other states.", u"According to U.S. Census data, Alabama's high school graduation rate\u201475%\u2014is the fourth lowest in the U.S. (after Kentucky, Louisiana and Mississippi).", u'The largest educational gains were among people with some college education but without degrees.', u"=== Colleges and universities ===\n\nAlabama's programs of higher education include 14 four-year public universities, two-year community colleges, and 17 private, undergraduate and graduate universities.", u'In the state are four medical schools (as of fall 2015) (University of Alabama School of Medicine, University of South Alabama and Alabama College of Osteopathic Medicine and The Edward Via College of Osteopathic Medicine - Auburn Campus), two veterinary colleges (Auburn University and Tuskegee University), a dental school (University of Alabama School of Dentistry), an optometry college (University of Alabama at Birmingham), two pharmacy schools (Auburn University and Samford University), and five law schools (University of Alabama School of Law, Birmingham School of Law, Cumberland School of Law, Miles Law School, and the Thomas Goode Jones School of Law).', u'Public, post-secondary education in Alabama is overseen by the Alabama Commission on Higher Education and the Alabama Department of Postsecondary Education.', u'Colleges and universities in Alabama offer degree programs from two-year associate degrees to a multitude of doctoral level programs.', u'The largest single campus is the University of Alabama, located in Tuscaloosa, with 33,602 enrolled for fall 2012.', u'Troy University was the largest institution in the state in 2010, with an enrollment of 29,689 students across four Alabama campuses (Troy, Dothan, Montgomery, and Phenix City), as well as sixty learning sites in seventeen other states and eleven other countries.', u'The oldest institutions are the public University of North Alabama in Florence and the Catholic Church-affiliated Spring Hill College in Mobile, both founded in 1830.', u'Accreditation of academic programs is through the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools (SACS) as well as other subject-focused national and international accreditation agencies such as the Association for Biblical Higher Education (ABHE), the Council on Occupational Education (COE), and the Accrediting Council for Independent Colleges and Schools (ACICS).', u'According to the 2011 U.S. News & World Report, Alabama had three universities ranked in the top 100 Public Schools in America (University of Alabama at 31, Auburn University at 36, and University of Alabama at Birmingham at 73).', u'According to the 2012 U.S. News & World Report, Alabama had four tier 1 universities (University of Alabama, Auburn University, University of Alabama at Birmingham and University of Alabama in Huntsville).', u'== Sports ==\n\n\n=== College ===\n\nCollege football is popular in Alabama, particularly the University of Alabama Crimson Tide and Auburn University Tigers, rivals in the Southeastern Conference.', u'In the 2013 season, Alabama averaged over 100,000 fans per game and Auburn averaged over 80,000 fans, both numbers among the top 20 in the nation in average attendance.', u'Bryant-Denny Stadium is the home of the Alabama football team, and has a seating capacity of 101,821, and is the fifth largest stadium in America.', u'Jordan-Hare Stadium is the home field of the Auburn football team and seats up to 87,451.', u'Legion Field is home for the UAB Blazers football program and the Birmingham Bowl.', u'It seats 80,601.', u'Ladd-Peebles Stadium in Mobile is the home of the University of South Alabama football team, and serves as the home of the NCAA Senior Bowl, Dollar General Bowl (formerly GoDaddy.com Bowl), and Alabama-Mississippi All Star Classic; the stadium seats 40,646.', u'In 2009, Bryant-Denny Stadium and Jordan-Hare Stadium became the homes of the Alabama High School Athletic Association state football championship games, after previously being held at Legion Field in Birmingham.', u'=== Professional ===\n\nAlabama has several professional and semi-professional sports teams, including three minor league baseball teams.', u'The Talladega Superspeedway motorsports complex hosts a series of NASCAR events.', u'It has a seating capacity of 143,000 and is the thirteenth largest stadium in the world and sixth largest stadium in America.', u'Also, the Barber Motorsports Park has hosted IndyCar Series and Rolex Sports Car Series races.', u'The ATP Birmingham was a World Championship Tennis tournament held from 1973 to 1980.', u'Alabama has hosted several professional golf tournaments, such as the 1984 and 1990 PGA Championship at Shoal Creek, the Barbasol Championship (PGA Tour), the Mobile LPGA Tournament of Champions, Airbus LPGA Classic and Yokohama Tire LPGA Classic (LPGA Tour), and The Tradition (Champions Tour).', u'== Transportation ==\n\n\n=== Aviation ===\n\nMajor airports with sustained commercial operations in Alabama include Birmingham-Shuttlesworth International Airport (BHM), Huntsville International Airport (HSV), Dothan Regional Airport (DHN), Mobile Regional Airport (MOB), Montgomery Regional Airport (MGM), and Muscle Shoals \u2013 Northwest Alabama Regional Airport (MSL).', u'=== Rail ===\nFor rail transport, Amtrak schedules the Crescent, a daily passenger train, running from New York to New Orleans with station stops at Anniston, Birmingham, and Tuscaloosa.', u'=== Roads ===\nAlabama has six major interstate roads that cross the state: Interstate 65 (I-65) travels north\u2013south roughly through the middle of the state; I-20/I-59 travel from the central west Mississippi state line to Birmingham, where I-59 continues to the north-east corner of the state and I-20 continues east towards Atlanta; I-85 originates in Montgomery and travels east-northeast to the Georgia state line, providing a main thoroughfare to Atlanta; and I-10 traverses the southernmost portion of the state, traveling from west to east through Mobile.', u'I-22 enters the state from Mississippi and connects Birmingham with Memphis, Tennessee.', u'In addition, there are currently five auxiliary interstate routes in the state: I-165 in Mobile, I-359 in Tuscaloosa, I-459 around Birmingham, I-565 in Decatur and Huntsville, and I-759 in Gadsden.', u'A sixth route, I-685, will be formed when I-85 is rerouted along a new southern bypass of Montgomery.', u'A proposed northern bypass of Birmingham will be designated as I-422.', u'Since a direct connection from I-22 to I-422 will not be possible, I-222 has been proposed, as well.', u'Several U.S.', u'Highways also pass through the state, such as U.S. Route 11 (US-11), US-29, US-31, US-43, US-45, US-72, US-78, US-80, US-82, US-84, US-90, US-98, US-231, US-278, US-280, US-331, US-411, and US-431.', u'There are four toll roads in the state: Montgomery Expressway in Montgomery; Tuscaloosa Bypass in Tuscaloosa; Emerald Mountain Expressway in Wetumpka; and Beach Express in Orange Beach.', u"=== Ports ===\nThe Port of Mobile, Alabama's only saltwater port, is a large seaport on the Gulf of Mexico with inland waterway access to the Midwest by way of the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway.", u'The Port of Mobile was ranked 12th by tons of traffic in the United States during 2009.', u'The newly expanded container terminal at the Port of Mobile was ranked as the 25th busiest for container traffic in the nation during 2011.', u"The state's other ports are on rivers with access to the Gulf of Mexico.", u'Water ports of Alabama, listed from north to south:\n\n\n== See also ==\n\nOutline of Alabama \u2013 in the Twentieth Century (2004)\nOwen Thomas M.
