Inside Alabama: A Personal History of My State (2004)\nMohl, Raymond A.', u'"Latinization in the Heart of Dixie: Hispanics in Late-twentieth-century Alabama" Alabama Review 2002 55(4): 243\u2013274.', u'ISSN 0002-4341\nPeirce, Neal R. The Deep South States of America: People, Politics, and Power in the Seven Deep South States (1974).', u'Information on politics and economics 1960\u201372.', u'Williams, Benjamin Buford.', u'A Literary History of Alabama: The Nineteenth Century 1979.', u'WPA.', u'Guide to Alabama (1939)\n\n\n== External links ==\n\nAlabama.gov \u2013 Official State Government web site\nAlabama at DMOZ\nAlabama State Guide, from the Library of Congress\nAll About Alabama, at the Alabama Department of Archives and History\nCode of Alabama 1975 \u2013 at the Alabama Legislature site\nUSGS real-time, geographic, and other scientific resources of Alabama\nAlabama QuickFacts from the U.S. Census Bureau\nAlabama State Fact Sheet from the U.S. Department of Agriculture\n Geographic data related to Alabama at OpenStreetMap'], 'year': '1819-12-14', 'title': 'Alabama becomes 22nd state'}
{'sentences': [u'The Parliament of England was the legislature of the Kingdom of England.', u'In 1066, William of Normandy introduced what, in later centuries, became referred to as a feudal system, by which he sought the advice of a council of tenants-in-chief (a person who held land) and ecclesiastics before making laws.', u'In 1215, the tenants-in-chief secured Magna Carta from King John, which established that the king may not levy or collect any taxes (except the feudal taxes to which they were hitherto accustomed), save with the consent of his royal council, which gradually developed into a parliament.', u'Over the centuries, the English Parliament progressively limited the power of the English monarchy which arguably culminated in the English Civil War and the trial and execution of Charles I in 1649.', u'After the restoration of the monarchy under Charles II, and the subsequent Glorious Revolution of 1688, the supremacy of Parliament was a settled principle and all future English and later British sovereigns were restricted to the role of constitutional monarchs with limited executive authority.', u'The Act of Union 1707 merged the English Parliament with the Parliament of Scotland to form the Parliament of Great Britain.', u'When the Parliament of Ireland was destroyed in 1801, its former members were merged into what was now called the Parliament of the United Kingdom.', u'== History ==\nUnder a monarchical system of government, monarchs usually must consult and seek a measure of acceptance for their policies if they are to enjoy the broad cooperation of their subjects.', u'Early kings of England had no standing army or police, and so depended on the support of powerful subjects.', u'The monarchy had agents in every part of the country.', u'However, under the feudal system that evolved in England following the Norman Conquest of 1066, the laws of the Crown could not have been upheld without the support of the nobility and the clergy.', u'The former had economic and military power bases of their own through major ownership of land and the feudal obligations of their tenants (some of whom held lands on condition of military service).', u'The Church was virtually a law unto itself in this period as it had its own system of religious law courts.', u'In order to seek consultation and consent from the nobility and the senior clergy on major decisions, post-Norman Conquest English monarchs called Great Councils.', u'A typical Great Council would consist of archbishops, bishops, abbots, barons and earls, the pillars of the feudal system.', u'When this system of consultation and consent broke down, it often became impossible for government to function effectively.', u'The most prominent instances of this prior to the reign of Henry III are the disagreements between Thomas Becket and Henry II and between King John and the barons.', u'Becket, who served as Archbishop of Canterbury between 1162 and 1170, was murdered following a long running dispute with Henry II over the jurisdiction of the Church.', u'John, who was king from 1199 to 1216, aroused such hostility from many leading noblemen that they forced him to agree to Magna Carta in 1215.', u"John's refusal to adhere to this charter led to civil war (see First Barons' War).", u'The Great Council evolved into the Parliament of England.', u'The term itself came into use during the early 13th century, deriving from the Latin and French words for discussion and speaking.', u'The word first appears in official documents in the 1230s.', u'As a result of the work by historians G. O. Sayles and H. G. Richardson, it is widely believed that the early parliaments had a judicial as well as a legislative function.', u'During the 13th and 14th centuries, the kings began to call Knights of the Shire to meet when the monarch saw it as necessary.', u'A notable example of this was in 1254 when sheriffs of counties were instructed to send Knights of the Shire to parliament to advise the king on finance.', u'Initially, parliaments were mostly summoned when the king needed to raise money through taxes.', u'Following the Magna Carta this became a convention.', u'This was due in no small part to the fact that King John died in 1216 and was succeeded by his young son Henry III.', u"Leading peers and clergy governed on Henry's behalf until he came of age, giving them a taste for power that they would prove unwilling to relinquish.", u'Among other things, they made sure that Magna Carta would be reaffirmed by the young king.', u'=== Parliament in the reign of Henry III ===\nOnce the minority of Henry III ended and he took full control of the government, leading peers became increasingly concerned with his style of government, specifically his unwillingness to consult them on decisions he took, and his seeming patronisation of his foreign relatives over his native subjects.', u"Henry's support of a disastrous papal invasion of Sicily was the last straw.", u'In 1258, seven leading barons forced Henry to swear to uphold the Provisions of Oxford, superseded, the following year, by the Provisions of Westminster.', u'This effectively abolished the absolutist Anglo-Norman monarchy, giving power to a council of fifteen barons, and providing for a thrice-yearly meeting of parliament to monitor their performance.', u'Parliament assembled six times between June 1258 and April 1262, most notably at Oxford in 1258.', u'The French-born nobleman Simon de Montfort, Earl of Leicester, emerged as the leader of this characteristically English rebellion.', u'In the following years, those supporting Montfort and those supporting the king grew more hostile to each other.', u'Henry obtained a papal bull in 1263 exempting him from his oath and both sides began to raise armies.', u"At the Battle of Lewes on 14 May 1264, Henry was defeated and taken prisoner by Montfort's army.", u'However, many of the peers who had initially supported Montfort began to suspect that he had gone too far with his reforming zeal.', u'His support amongst the nobility rapidly declined.', u'So in 1264, Montfort summoned the first parliament in English history without any prior royal authorisation.', u'The archbishops, bishops, abbots, earls and barons were summoned, as were two knights from each shire and two burgesses from each borough.', u'Knights had been summoned to previous councils, but the representation of the boroughs was unprecedented.', u"This was purely a move to consolidate Montfort's position as the legitimate governor of the kingdom, since he had captured Henry and his son Prince Edward (later Edward I) at the Battle of Lewes.", u'A parliament consisting of representatives of the realm was the logical way for Montfort to establish his authority.', u'In calling this parliament, in a bid to gain popular support, he summoned knights and burgesses from the emerging gentry class, thus turning to his advantage the fact that most of the nobility had abandoned his movement.', u'This parliament was summoned on 14 December 1264.', u'It first met on 20 January 1265 in Westminster Hall and was dissolved on 15 February 1265.', u'It is not certain who actually attended this parliament.', u'Nonetheless, Montfort\'s scheme was formally adopted by Edward I in the so-called "Model Parliament" of 1295.', u'The attendance at parliament of knights and burgesses historically became known as the summoning of "the Commons", a term derived from the Norman French word "commune", literally translated as the "community of the realm".', u"Following Edward's escape from captivity, Montfort was defeated and killed at the Battle of Evesham in 1265.", u"Henry's authority was restored and the Provisions of Oxford were forgotten, but this was nonetheless a turning point in the history of the Parliament of England.", u'Although he was not obliged by statute to do so, Henry summoned the Commons to parliament three times between September 1268 and April 1270.', u'However, this was not a significant turning point in the history of parliamentary democracy.', u'Subsequently, very little is known about how representatives were selected because, at this time, being sent to parliament was not a prestigious undertaking.', u"But Montfort's decision to summon knights of the shires and burgesses to his parliament did mark the irreversible emergence of the landed gentry as a force in politics.", u"From then on, monarchs could not ignore them, which explains Henry's decision to summon the Commons to several of his post-1265 parliaments.", u"Even though many peers who had supported the Provisions of Oxford remained active in English public life throughout Henry's reign, the conditions they had laid down for regular parliaments were largely forgotten, as if to symbolise the historical development of the English Parliament via convention rather than statutes and written constitutions.", u"=== The emergence of parliament as an institution ===\n\nDuring the reign of Edward I, which began in 1272, the role of Parliament in the government of the English kingdom increased due to Edward's determination to unite England, Wales and Scotland under his rule by force.", u"He was also keen to unite his subjects in order to restore his authority and not face rebellion as was his father's fate.", u'Edward therefore encouraged all sectors of society to submit petitions to parliament detailing their grievances in order for them to be resolved.', u"This seemingly gave all of Edward's subjects a potential role in government and this helped Edward assert his authority.", u'Both the Statute of Westminster 1275 and Statute of Westminster 1285, with the assistance of Robert Burnell, codified the existing law in England.', u'As the number of petitions being submitted to parliament increased, they came to be dealt with, and often ignored, more and more by ministers of the Crown so as not to block the passage of government business through parliament.', u'However the emergence of petitioning is significant because it is some of the earliest evidence of parliament being used as a forum to address the general grievances of ordinary people.', u'Submitting a petition to parliament is a tradition that continues to this day in the Parliament of the United Kingdom and in most Commonwealth realms.', u'These developments symbolise the fact that parliament and government were by no means the same thing by this point.', u'If monarchs were going to impose their will on their kingdom, they would have to control parliament rather than be subservient to it.', u"From Edward's reign onwards, the authority of the English Parliament would depend on the strength or weakness of the incumbent monarch.", u'When the king or queen was strong he or she would wield enough influence to pass their legislation through parliament without much trouble.', u'Some strong monarchs even bypassed it completely, although this was not often possible in the case of financial legislation due to the post-Magna Carta convention of parliament granting taxes.', u'When weak monarchs governed, parliament often became the centre of opposition against them.', u'Subsequently, the composition of parliaments in this period varied depending on the decisions that needed to be taken in them.', u'The nobility and senior clergy were always summoned.', u'From 1265 onwards, when the monarch needed to raise money through taxes, it was usual for knights and burgesses to be summoned too.', u'However, when the king was merely seeking advice, he often only summoned the nobility and the clergy, sometimes with and sometimes without the knights of the shires.', u'On some occasions the Commons were summoned and sent home again once the monarch was finished with them, allowing parliament to continue without them.', u'It was not until the mid-14th century that summoning representatives of the shires and the boroughs became the norm for all parliaments.', u'One of the moments that marked the emergence of parliament as a true institution in England was the deposition of Edward II.', u'Even though it is debatable whether Edward II was deposed in parliament or by parliament, this remarkable sequence of events consolidated the importance of parliament in the English unwritten constitution.', u'Parliament was also crucial in establishing the legitimacy of the king who replaced Edward II: his son Edward III.', u'In 1341 the Commons met separately from the nobility and clergy for the first time, creating what was effectively an Upper Chamber and a Lower Chamber, with the knights and burgesses sitting in the latter.', u'This Upper Chamber became known as the House of Lords from 1544 onward, and the Lower Chamber became known as the House of Commons, collectively known as the Houses of Parliament.', u'The authority of parliament grew under Edward III; it was established that no law could be made, nor any tax levied, without the consent of both Houses and the Sovereign.', u"This development occurred during the reign of Edward III because he was involved in the Hundred Years' War and needed finances.", u'During his conduct of the war, Edward tried to circumvent parliament as much as possible, which caused this edict to be passed.', u'The Commons came to act with increasing boldness during this period.', u"During the Good Parliament (1376), the Presiding Officer of the lower chamber, Sir Peter de la Mare, complained of heavy taxes, demanded an accounting of the royal expenditures, and criticised the king's management of the military.", u"The Commons even proceeded to impeach some of the king's ministers.", u'The bold Speaker was imprisoned, but was soon released after the death of Edward III.', u'During the reign of the next monarch, Richard II, the Commons once again began to impeach errant ministers of the Crown.', u'They insisted that they could not only control taxation, but also public expenditure.', u'Despite such gains in authority, however, the Commons still remained much less powerful than the House of Lords and the Crown.', u'This period also saw the introduction of a franchise which limited the number of people who could vote in elections for the House of Commons.', u'From 1430 onwards, the franchise was limited to Forty Shilling Freeholders, that is men who owned freehold property worth forty shillings or more.', u'The Parliament of England legislated the new uniform county franchise, in the statute 8 Hen.', u'6, c. 7.', u'The Chronological Table of the Statutes does not mention such a 1430 law, as it was included in the Consolidated Statutes as a recital in the Electors of Knights of the Shire Act 1432 (10 Hen.', u'6, c. 2), which amended and re-enacted the 1430 law to make clear that the resident of a county had to have a forty shilling freehold in that county to be a voter there.', u'=== King, Lords, and Commons ===\nIt was during the reign of the Tudor monarchs that the modern structure of the English Parliament began to be created.', u'The Tudor monarchy was powerful and there were often periods of several years when parliament did not sit at all.', u'However the Tudor monarchs were astute enough to realise that they needed parliament to legitimise many of their decisions, mostly out of a need to raise money through taxation legitimately without causing discontent.', u'Thus they consolidated the state of affairs whereby monarchs would call and close parliament as and when they needed it.', u'By the time Henry Tudor (Henry VII) came to the throne in 1485 the monarch was not a member of either the Upper Chamber or the Lower Chamber.', u'Consequently, the monarch would have to make his or her feelings known to Parliament through his or her supporters in both houses.', u'Proceedings were regulated by the presiding officer in either chamber.', u'From the 1540s the presiding officer in the House of Commons became formally known as the "Speaker", having previously been referred to as the "prolocutor" or "parlour" (a semi-official position, often nominated by the monarch, that had existed ever since Peter de Montfort had acted as the presiding officer of the Oxford Parliament of 1258).', u'This was not an enviable job.', u'When the House of Commons was unhappy it was the Speaker who had to deliver this news to the monarch.', u"This began the tradition whereby the Speaker of the House of Commons is dragged to the Speaker's Chair by other members once elected.", u'A member of either chamber could present a "bill" to parliament.', u'Bills supported by the monarch were often proposed by members of the Privy Council who sat in parliament.', u'In order for a bill to become law it would have to be approved by a majority of both Houses of Parliament before it passed to the monarch for royal assent or veto.', u'The royal veto was applied several times during the 16th and 17th centuries and it is still the right of the monarch of the United Kingdom and Commonwealth realms to veto legislation today, although it has not been exercised since 1707 (today such exercise would presumably precipitate a constitutional crisis).', u'When a bill was enacted into law, this process gave it the approval of each estate of the realm: the King, Lords, and Commons.', u'In reality, this was not a democratic process.', u'The Parliament of England was far from being a democratically representative institution in this period.', u'It was possible to assemble the entire peerage and senior clergy of the realm in one place to form the estate of the Upper Chamber.', u'However, the voting franchise for the House of Commons was small; some historians estimate that it was as little as three per cent of the adult male population; and there was no secret ballot.', u'This meant that elections could be controlled by local grandees, because in many boroughs a majority of voters were in some way dependent on a powerful individual, or else could be bought by money or concessions.', u'If these grandees were supporters of the incumbent monarch, this gave the Crown and its ministers considerable influence over the business of parliament.', u'Many of the men elected to parliament did not relish the prospect of having to act in the interests of others.', u'So a law was enacted, still on the statute book today, whereby it became unlawful for members of the House of Commons to resign their seat unless they were granted a position directly within the patronage of the monarchy (today this latter restriction leads to a legal fiction allowing de facto resignation despite the prohibition, but nevertheless it is a resignation which needs the permission of the Crown).', u'However, it must be emphasised that while several elections to parliament in this period were in some way corrupt by modern standards, many elections involved genuine contests between rival candidates, even though the ballot was not secret.', u'It was in this period that the Palace of Westminster was established as the seat of the English Parliament.', u"In 1548, the House of Commons was granted a regular meeting place by the Crown, St Stephen's Chapel.", u'This had been a royal chapel.', u'It was made into a debating chamber after Henry VIII became the last monarch to use the Palace of Westminster as a place of residence and following the suppression of the college there.', u'This room became the home of the House of Commons until it was destroyed by fire in 1834, although the interior was altered several times up until then.', u'The structure of this room was pivotal in the development of the Parliament of England.', u"While most modern legislatures sit in a circular chamber, the benches of the British Houses of Parliament are laid out in the form of choir stalls in a chapel, simply because this is the part of the original room that the members of the House of Commons utilised when they were granted use of St Stephen's Chapel.", u'This structure took on a new significance with the emergence of political parties in the late 17th and early 18th centuries, as the tradition began whereby the members of the governing party would sit on the benches to the right of the Speaker and the opposition members on the benches to the left.', u"It is said that the Speaker's chair was placed in front of the chapel's altar.", u'As Members came and went they observed the custom of bowing to the altar and continued to do so, even when it had been taken away, thus then bowing to the Chair, as is still the custom today.', u'The numbers of the Lords Spiritual diminished under Henry VIII, who commanded the Dissolution of the Monasteries, thereby depriving the abbots and priors of their seats in the Upper House.', u'For the first time, the Lords Temporal were more numerous than the Lords Spiritual.', u'Currently, the Lords Spiritual consist of the Archbishops of Canterbury and York, the Bishops of London, Durham and Winchester, and twenty-one other English diocesan bishops in seniority of appointment to a diocese.', u'The Laws in Wales Acts of 1535\u201342 annexed Wales as part of England and this brought Welsh representatives into the Parliament of England, first elected in 1542.', u'=== Rebellion and revolution ===\nParliament had not always submitted to the wishes of the Tudor monarchs.', u'But parliamentary criticism of the monarchy reached new levels in the 17th century.', u'When the last Tudor monarch, Elizabeth I, died in 1603, King James VI of Scotland came to power as King James I, founding the Stuart monarchy.', u'In 1628, alarmed by the arbitrary exercise of royal power, the House of Commons submitted to Charles I the Petition of Right, demanding the restoration of their liberties.', u'Though he accepted the petition, Charles later dissolved parliament and ruled without them for eleven years.', u"It was only after the financial disaster of the Scottish Bishops' Wars (1639\u20131640) that he was forced to recall Parliament so that they could authorise new taxes.", u'This resulted in the calling of the assemblies known historically as the Short Parliament of 1640 and the Long Parliament, which sat with several breaks and in various forms between 1640 and 1660.', u'The Long Parliament was characterised by the growing number of critics of the king who sat in it.', u'The most prominent of these critics in the House of Commons was John Pym.', u'Tensions between the king and his parliament reached boiling point in January 1642 when Charles entered the House of Commons and tried, unsuccessfully, to arrest Pym and four other members for their alleged treason.', u'The five members had been tipped off about this, and by the time Charles came into the chamber with a group of soldiers they had disappeared.', u'Charles was further humiliated when he asked the Speaker, William Lenthall, to give their whereabouts, which Lenthall famously refused to do.', u'From then on relations between the king and his parliament deteriorated further.', u'When trouble started to brew in Ireland, both Charles and his parliament raised armies to quell the uprisings by native Catholics there.', u'It was not long before it was clear that these forces would end up fighting each other, leading to the English Civil War which began with the Battle of Edgehill in October 1642: those supporting the cause of parliament were called Parliamentarians (or Roundheads).', u'Battles between Crown and Parliament would continue throughout the 17th and 18th centuries, but parliament was no longer subservient to the English monarchy.', u'This change was symbolised in the execution of Charles I in January 1649.', u'It is somewhat ironic that this event was not instigated by the elected representatives of the realm.', u"In Pride's Purge of December 1648, the New Model Army (which by then had emerged as the leading force in the parliamentary alliance) purged Parliament of members that did not support them.", u'The remaining "Rump Parliament", as it was later referred to by critics, enacted legislation to put the king on trial for treason.', u'This trial, the outcome of which was a foregone conclusion, led to the execution of the king and the start of an 11 year republic.', u'The House of Lords was abolished and the purged House of Commons governed England until April 1653, when army chief Oliver Cromwell dissolved it following disagreements over religious policy and how to carry out elections to parliament.', u"Cromwell later convened a parliament of religious radicals in 1653, commonly known as Barebone's Parliament, followed by the unicameral First Protectorate Parliament that sat from September 1654 to January 1655 and the Second Protectorate Parliament that sat in two sessions between 1656 and 1658, the first session was unicameral and the second session was bicameral.", u'Although it is easy to dismiss the English Republic of 1649-60 as nothing more than a Cromwellian military dictatorship, the events that took place in this decade were hugely important in determining the future of parliament.', u'First, it was during the sitting of the first Rump Parliament that members of the House of Commons became known as "MPs" (Members of Parliament).', u'Second, Cromwell gave a huge degree of freedom to his parliaments, although royalists were barred from sitting in all but a handful of cases.', u'His vision of parliament appears to have been largely based on the example of the Elizabethan parliaments.', u'However, he underestimated the extent to which Elizabeth I and her ministers had directly and indirectly influenced the decision-making process of her parliaments.', u'He was thus always surprised when they became troublesome.', u'He ended up dissolving each parliament that he convened.', u'Yet it is worth noting that the structure of the second session of the Second Protectorate Parliament of 1658 was almost identical to the parliamentary structure consolidated in the Glorious Revolution Settlement of 1689.', u'In 1653 Cromwell had been made head of state with the title Lord Protector of the Realm.', u'The Second Protectorate Parliament offered him the crown.', u'Cromwell rejected this offer, but the governmental structure embodied in the final version of the Humble Petition and Advice was a basis for all future parliaments.', u'It proposed an elected House of Commons as the Lower Chamber, a House of Lords containing peers of the realm as the Upper Chamber, and a constitutional monarchy, subservient to parliament and the laws of the nation, as the executive arm of the state at the top of the tree, assisted in carrying out their duties by a Privy Council.', u'Oliver Cromwell had thus inadvertently presided over the creation of a basis for the future parliamentary government of England.', u'In 1657 he had the Parliament of Scotland unified with the English Parliament.', u'In terms of the evolution of parliament as an institution, by far the most important development during the republic was the sitting of the Rump Parliament between 1649 and 1653.', u'This proved that parliament could survive without a monarchy and a House of Lords if it wanted to.', u'Future English monarchs would never forget this.', u'Charles I was the last English monarch ever to enter the House of Commons.', u'Even to this day, a Member of the Parliament of the United Kingdom is sent to Buckingham Palace as a ceremonial hostage during the State Opening of Parliament, in order to ensure the safe return of the sovereign from a potentially hostile parliament.', u'During the ceremony the monarch sits on the throne in the House of Lords and signals for the Lord Great Chamberlain to summon the House of Commons to the Lords Chamber.', u'The Lord Great Chamberlain then raises his wand of office to signal to the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod, who has been waiting in the central lobby.', u'Black Rod turns and, escorted by the doorkeeper of the House of Lords and an inspector of police, approaches the doors to the chamber of the Commons.', u"The doors are slammed in his face \u2013 symbolising the right of the Commons to debate without the presence of the Queen's representative.", u'He then strikes three times with his staff (the Black Rod), and he is admitted.', u'=== Parliament from the Restoration to the Act of Settlement ===\nThe revolutionary events that occurred between 1620 and 1689 all took place in the name of parliament.', u'The new status of parliament as the central governmental organ of the English state was consolidated during the events surrounding the Restoration of the monarchy in 1660.', u'Following the death of Oliver Cromwell in September 1658, his son Richard Cromwell succeeded him as Lord Protector, summoning the Third Protectorate Parliament in the process.', u'When this parliament was dissolved following pressure from the army in April 1659, the Rump Parliament was recalled at the insistence of the surviving army grandees.', u'This in turn was dissolved in a coup led by army general John Lambert, leading to the formation of the Committee of Safety, dominated by Lambert and his supporters.', u"When the breakaway forces of George Monck invaded England from Scotland where they had been stationed\u2014without Lambert's supporters putting up a fight\u2014Monck temporarily recalled the Rump Parliament and reversed Pride's Purge by recalling the entirety of the Long Parliament.", u'They then voted to dissolve themselves and call new elections, which were arguably the most democratic for 20 years although the franchise was still very small.', u'This led to the calling of the Convention Parliament which was dominated by royalists.', u'This parliament voted to reinstate the monarchy and the House of Lords.', u'Charles II returned to England as king in May 1660.', u'The Anglo-Scottish parliamentary union that Cromwell had established was dissolved in 1661 when the Scottish Parliament resumed its separate meeting place in Edinburgh.', u'The Restoration began the tradition whereby all governments looked to parliament for legitimacy.', u'In 1681 Charles II dissolved parliament and ruled without them for the last four years of his reign.', u'This followed bitter disagreements between the king and parliament that had occurred between 1679 and 1681.', u'Charles took a big gamble by doing this.', u'He risked the possibility of a military showdown akin to that of 1642.', u'However he rightly predicted that the nation did not want another civil war.', u'Parliament disbanded without a fight.', u'Events that followed ensured that this would be nothing but a temporary blip.', u'Charles II died in 1685 and he was succeeded by his brother James II.', u'During his lifetime Charles had always pledged loyalty to the Protestant Church of England, despite his private Catholic sympathies.', u'James was openly Catholic.', u'He attempted to lift restrictions on Catholics taking up public offices.', u'This was bitterly opposed by Protestants in his kingdom.', u'They invited William of Orange, a Protestant who had married Mary, daughter of James II and Anne Hyde to invade England and claim the throne.', u'William assembled an army estimated at 15,000 soldiers (11,000 foot and 4000 horse) and landed at Brixham in southwest England in November, 1688.', u"When many Protestant officers, including James's close adviser, John Churchill, 1st Duke of Marlborough, defected from the English army to William's invasion force, James fled the country.", u'Parliament then offered the Crown to his Protestant daughter Mary, instead of his son (James Francis Edward Stuart).', u"Mary refused the offer, and instead William and Mary ruled jointly, with both having the right to rule alone on the other's death.", u'As part of the compromise in allowing William to be King\u2014called the Glorious Revolution\u2014Parliament was able to have the 1689 Bill of Rights enacted.', u'Later the 1701 Act of Settlement was approved.', u'These were statutes that lawfully upheld the prominence of parliament for the first time in English history.', u'These events marked the beginning of the English constitutional monarchy and its role as one of the three elements of parliament.', u'=== Union: the Parliament of Great Britain ===\n\nFollowing the Treaty of Union in 1707, Acts of Parliament passed in the Parliament of England and the Parliament of Scotland created a new Kingdom of Great Britain and dissolved both parliaments, replacing them with a new Parliament of Great Britain based in the former home of the English parliament.', u'The Parliament of Great Britain later became the Parliament of the United Kingdom in 1801 when the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland was formed through the Act of Union 1800.', u'== Places where Parliament has been held other than London ==\nYork, various\nLincoln, various\nOxford, 1258 (Mad Parliament), 1681\nKenilworth, 1266\nActon Burnell Castle, 1283\nShrewsbury, 1283 (trial of Dafydd ap Gruffydd)\nLincoln, 1301\nCarlisle, 1307\nNorthampton 1328\nNew Sarum, 1330\nWinchester, 1332\nLeicester, 1414 (Fire and Faggot Parliament), 1426 (Parliament of Bats)\nReading Abbey, 1453\nCoventry, 1459 (Parliament of Devils)\n\n\n== Representation on the English Parliament outside the British Isles ==\nTwo European cities, both annexed from and later ceded to the Kingdom of France were represented in the Parliament as borough constituencies while they were English possessions:\nCalais, between 1372 and 1558.', u'Tournai between 1513 and 1519.', u'(Now in Belgium.)', u'== See also 1485\u20131601\nList of Acts of the Parliament of England, 1603\u20131641\nWitenagemot\nMagnum Concilium\n\n\n== References ==\n\n\n== Sources ==\nBlackstone, Sir William.', u'(1765).', u'Commentaries {'sentences': [u"The Battle of Fort Niagara was a siege late in the French and Indian War, the North American theatre of the Seven Years' War.", u"The British siege of Fort Niagara in July 1759 was part of a campaign to remove French control of the Great Lakes and Ohio Valley regions, making possible a western invasion of the French province of Canada in conjunction with General James Wolfe's invasion to the east.", u'== Background ==\nBritish General Jeffrey Amherst made plans for the 1759 military campaigns of the French and Indian War that included an expedition to capture Fort Niagara, a major French military and supply point between the French province of Canada and their forts in the Ohio Valley.', u"Amherst chose Brigadier General John Prideaux to lead the expedition, which also included Sir William Johnson, the British Indian agent who led the expedition's Iroquois forces.", u'Fort Niagara had been largely constructed under the direction of Captain Pierre Pouchot of the French Army.', u"In early 1759, General Louis-Joseph de Montcalm and New France's Governor, the Marquis de Vaudreuil, sent him with about 2,500 men to fortify Niagara beyond the 500 men that had wintered there.", u'Pouchot, under orders from Vaudreuil, sent many of those men south to Fort Machault in mid-June as part of a plan to reinforce the French forts of the Ohio Country and attack the British at Fort Pitt.', u'The forces left to defend Niagara consisted of about 200 men from the regiments of Royal Roussillon, Languedoc, La Sarre, and B\xe9arn, 20 artillerymen, and about 300 provincial troops and militia.', u"Prideaux's British Army troops consisted of the 44th and 46th Regiments, and two companies from the 60th, numbering about 2,200 men.", u'He also commanded 2500 provincial militia from New York and 700 from Rhode Island.', u'Delayed by high water on the Mohawk River and the late arrival of some of the provincial companies, the expedition did not begin leaving Schenectady until mid-May.', u'On 27 June the army arrived at Fort Oswego, where they were joined by Johnson and about 600 Iroquois.', u'Leaving men behind to garrison Oswego, Prideaux departed on 1 July for Niagara with about 3,500 men.', u'While the French had ships patrolling Lake Ontario for British movements, inattention on the part of one the crews allowed the British flotilla to avoid discovery.', u'They arrived at Fort Niagara on 6 July, landed near a marsh out of sight of the fort, and immediately began siege operations.', u'== Siege ==\nThe French had about one hundred Iroquois allies at the Fort who deserted when the British arrived.', u'Captain Pouchot directed a vigorous defense.', u'Prideaux was killed when a shell fragment from one of his own guns hit him, and command of the British forces fell to Sir William Johnson.', u'Johnson was a provincial officer and not in the regular army, and thus there was some question of his right to take command.', u"But Sir William held a royal colonel's commission in his role as commander of the Iroquois auxiliaries, and so he insisted on remaining in command after a lower-ranking regular army officer, Lieutenant Colonel Frederick Haldimand, arrived on the scene.", u'The French capitulated on 26 July after a French relief force was defeated at the Battle of La Belle-Famille two miles south of the fort.', u'== Aftermath ==\nThe capitulation of Fort Niagara occurred on the same day that French troops abandoned Fort Carillon to an overwhelming British army under General Amherst.', u'Fort St. Fr\xe9d\xe9ric was also destroyed as French troops abandoned Lake Champlain to protect the Canadian heartland.', u"Most French forces were at Quebec, where Montcalm was leading the defences against Wolfe's siege.", u'Quebec fell in September 1759, and all of New France was surrendered in September 1760.', u'The remaining French forts in the Ohio and Illinois Country were eventually turned over to British forces.', u'== References ==\n\n\n== Bibliography ==\nDunnigan, Brian Leigh (1996).', u'Siege - 1759, The Campaign against Niagara.', u'ISBN 0-941967-15-8.', u'Severance, Frank Hayward (1917).', u'An Old Frontier of France.', u'Dodd, Mead and Company.', u'OCLC 5973820.'], 'year': '1813-12-18', 'title': 'British take Fort Niagara in the War of 1812'}
{'sentences': [u"The Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, designated the Hawai\u02bbi State Museum of Natural and Cultural History, is a museum of history and science located in the historic Kalihi district of Honolulu on the Hawaiian island of O'ahu.", u"Founded in 1889, it is the largest museum in Hawai'i and has the world's largest collection of Polynesian cultural artifacts and natural history specimens.", u"Besides the comprehensive exhibits of Hawaiiana, the museum's total holding of natural history specimens exceeds 24 million, of which the entomological collection alone represents more than 13.5 million specimens (making it the third-largest insect collection in the United States).", u'The museum is accessible on public transit: TheBus Routes A, 1, 2, 7, 10.', u'The museum complex is home to the Richard T. Mamiya Science Adventure Center.', u'== Establishment ==\n\nCharles Reed Bishop (1822\u20131915), a businessman and philanthropist, co-founder of the First Hawaiian Bank and Kamehameha Schools, built the museum in memory of his late wife, Princess Bernice Pauahi Bishop (1831\u20131884).', u'Born into the royal family, she was the last legal heir of the Kamehameha Dynasty, which had ruled the Kingdom of Hawai\u02bbi between 1810 and 1872.', u'Bishop had originally intended the museum to house family heirlooms passed down to him through the royal lineage of his wife.', u'Bishop hired William Tufts Brigham as the first curator of the Museum; Brigham later served as director from 1898 until his retirement in 1918.', u"The museum was built on the original boys' campus of Kamehameha Schools, an institution created at the bequest of the Princess, to benefit native Hawaiian children; she gave details in her last will and testament.", u'In 1898, Bishop had Hawaiian Hall and Polynesian Hall built on the campus, in the popular Richardsonian Romanesque architectural style.', u'The Pacific Commercial Advertiser newspaper dubbed these two structures as "the noblest buildings of Honolulu".', u'Today both halls are listed on the National Register of Historic Places.', u'Hawaiian Hall is home to a complete sperm-whale skeleton, accompanied by a papier-m\xe2ch\xe9 body suspended above the central gallery.', u'Along the walls are prized koa wood display cases; today this wood in total is worth more than the original Bishop Museum buildings.', u'== Later development ==\nIn 1940, Kamehameha Schools moved to its new campus in Kap\u0101lama, allowing the museum to expand at the original campus site.', u'Bishop Hall, first built for use by the school, was adapted for museum use.', u'Most other school structures were razed, and new museum facilities were constructed.', u'By the late 1980s, the Bishop Museum had become the largest natural and cultural history institution in Polynesia.', u'In 1988, construction of the Castle Memorial Building was begun.', u'Dedicated on January 13, 1990, Castle Memorial Building houses all the major traveling exhibits that come to the Bishop Museum from institutions around the world.', u'The Richard T. Mamiya Science Adventure Center opened in November 2005.', u'The building is designed as a learning center for children, and includes many interactive exhibits focused on marine science, volcanology, and related sciences.', u"== Library and archives ==\nThe museum library has one of the most extensive collections of books, periodicals, newspapers and special collections concerned with Hawai'i and the Pacific.", u'The archives hold the results of extensive studies done by museum staff in the Pacific Basin, as well as manuscripts, photographs, artwork, oral histories, commercial sound recordings and maps.', u"Many of Hawai\u02bbi's royalty, including Bernice Pauahi Bishop and Queen Lili\u02bbuokalani, deposited their personal papers at Bishop Museum.", u'Manuscripts in the collection also include scientific papers, genealogical records, and memorabilia.', u"The book collection consists of approximately 50,000 volumes with an emphasis on the cultural and natural history of Hawai'i and the Pacific, with subject strengths in anthropology, music, botany, entomology, and zoology.", u"The library provides extra access to the collection of published diaries, narratives, memoirs, and other writings relating to 18th and 19th century Hawai'i.", u'== Institutions ==\nOn the campus of Bishop Museum is the Jhamandas Watumull Planetarium, an educational and research facility devoted to the astronomical sciences and the oldest planetarium in Polynesia.', u'Also on the campus is Pauahi Hall, home to the J. Linsley Gressit Center for Research in Entomology, which houses some 14 million prepared specimens of insects and related arthropods, including over 16,500 primary types.', u'It is the third-largest entomology collection in the United States and the eighth-largest in the world.', u'An active research facility, Pauahi Hall is not open to the public.', u'Nearby is P\u0101k\u012b Hall, home to the Hawai\u02bbi Sports Hall of Fame, a museum library and archives, which are open to the public.', u'From 1988 until 2009, the Bishop Museum also administered the Hawai\u02bbi Maritime Center in downtown Honolulu.', u'Built on a former private pier of Honolulu Harbor for the royal family, the center was the premier maritime museum in the Pacific Rim with artifacts in relation to the Pacific whaling industry and the Hawai\u02bbi steamship industry.', u"On the Big Island of Hawai'i, the Bishop Museum administers the Amy B.H.", u'Greenwell Ethnobotanical Garden, specializing in indigenous Hawaiian plant life.', u'Since 1920, the Secretariat of the Pacific Science Association (PSA), founded that year as an independent regional, non-governmental, scholarly organization, has been based at Bishop Museum.', u'It seeks to advance science and technology in support of sustainable development in the Asia-Pacific.', u'== Kaimiloa Expedition ==\nIn 1924, American millionaire, Medford Ross Kellum, outfitted a four masted barkantine for a scientific expedition which, even the naming of the ship Kaimiloa, was left entirely to the scientific circles of Honolulu.', u'The goal of the expedition was a five-year expedition to many of the then inaccessible spots of the Pacific.', u'Under the auspices of the Bishop Museum, a group of Hawaiian scientists joined the ship: Gerrit P. Wilder, botanist; Mrs. Wilder, historian; Kenneth Emory, ethnologist; Dr. Armstrong Sperry, writer and illustrator; and Dr. Stanley Ball.', u'The vessel was a complete floating laboratory, possibly the most complete of any craft that has undertaken a similar trip.', u'Bottles, crates, and boxes were stowed below, along with gallons of preservatives for insects and plant specimens for the Bishop Museum.', u'The goals of the expedition were exhaustive:\ncomplete collections of islands subjects ranging from insects, plants, minerals, and archaeological and ethnological specimens,\nstudy of the fish and sea life,\nchart as accurately as possible the ocean currents,\nfor the United States government, conform and correct to the findings of the expedition the charts of the island groups,\nattempt to trace the origin of the Polynesians, their language and their migrations,\nphotograph the natives and measure accurately portions of their bodies,\nrecord phonographically records of the speech, the songs, their chants,\nsound the ocean floor and study the formation of the islands in an effort to prove the theory that these islands were once a part of the mainland and that they formed a \u201clost continent\u201d.', u'== Falls of Clyde ==\n\nFrom 1968 until September 2008, the Bishop Museum owned the Falls of Clyde, the oldest sail-driven oil tanker, which was moored at the Hawai\u2018i Maritime Center.', u'In early 2007, the ship was closed to public tours for safety reasons and in order to facilitate repairs to the deteriorating tank, which frequently caused the ship to list dramatically.', u'Marine experts conducted a thorough inspection of the ship.', u'Between 1998 and 2008 the Museum incurred more than $2 million in preservation costs.', u'The museum threatened to sink the ship by the end of 2008 unless private funds were raised for a perpetual care endowment.', u'On September 28, 2008, ownership was transferred to the non-profit group, Friends of Falls of Clyde, which intends to restore the ship.', u'In October of that same year, the Bishop Museum was criticized for having raised $600,000 to preserve the ship, and spent only about half that on the ship, and that for sandblasting that was determined to damage the integrity of the vessel.', u'The media also pointed out other questionable spending decisions.', u'== Gallery ==\n\n\n== See also Gulick, an early evolution proponent who advanced concepts now known as genetic drift, anagenesis, cladogenesis, and speciation, sold his shell collection to the Bishop Museum.', u'== Notes ==\n\n\n== External links ==\nOfficial website\nOfficial website of the Amy B.H.', u'Ethnobotanical Garden\nJ. {'sentences': [u"Radio Australia is the international broadcasting and online service operated by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), Australia's public broadcaster.", u'Most programming is in English, with some in Tok Pisin and French.', u'== History ==\nShortwave services from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation were inaugurated in December 1939 by Prime Minister Robert Menzies.', u'One of the functions of Australian shortwave broadcasting was to counter Axis powers propaganda, particularly that of the Japanese.', u"However, the ABC's transmitters were much weaker than the Japanese or German services.", u'The transmitter of Amalgamated Wireless (Australasia) (AWA) near Sydney had 10 kilowatts (kW) of power, and stations VLR and VLW had 2 kW each.', u'In 1941, following consultation between the British and Australian governments, a transmitter site in Shepparton, Victoria was selected, in part because of a flat landscape and soil conductivity.', u'The site was completed in 1944 with one 50 kW and two 100 kW transmitters.', u'The station was then formally named Radio Australia.', u"A new transmitting facility was installed by the PMG's Department at Cox Peninsula near Darwin in the late 1960s, rebroadcasting programs emanating from Radio Australia studios in Melbourne.", u'Equipment included three Collins Radio 250 kW HF transmitters and five log-periodic antennas directed at East Asia and South-east Asia.', u'The antennas were largely demolished by Cyclone Tracy on 25 December 1974 and Radio Australia broadcasts from this locality were not reinstated (by then Telecom Australia) until about 1988.', u'During the first Gulf war in 1990/91 the station provided valuable information and support to expatriate Australians caught in Iraq, and others working in (eg) Saudi Arabia.', u'In the event however, due to financial and political pressures, as it was an expensive facility to staff being some distance from Darwin proper, transmissions from Cox Peninsula were terminated in the late 1990s.', u'For a few years the facilities were leased to commercial operators, but eventually it was closed down.', u'The equipment and buildings removed, and the land restored.', u'Radio Australia had a considerable range of broadcasts to the Asian region in the 1970s and 1980s, however in the late 1990s political influence on its broadcasting range and programming limited its Asian spread.', u'In recent years Radio Australia programs have also become available via the internet.', u'These services are streamed from machines hosted by Akamai Technologies in Steinsel, Luxembourg ensuring good network connectivity for listeners in Europe.', u"== Target areas ==\nRadio Australia's signal is primarily aimed at the Asia-Pacific region.", u'It broadcasts in multiple languages, namely English, Mandarin Chinese, Vietnamese, Indonesian, Khmer, French, Burmese, and Tok Pisin (a creole language commonly spoken in Papua New Guinea).', u'A daily Pacific news bulletin is podcast in French.', u'Though Radio Australia does not directly target North America or Europe via shortwave, some of its transmissions can be heard in these areas.', u'Radio Australia can also be heard on CBC Radio across Canada during their overnight broadcast.', u'The station resumed Fiji transmission through negotiations with the Ministry of Information and the Fiji Broadcasting Corporation (FBC) in July 2012.', u'Radio Australia can be heard on 106.6FM in main cities of Fiji.', u'== Current market situation ==\nThere have been many changes and alterations in the international media market in recent years.', u'One notable change is the move to new media and online content, such as digital radio, digital television, podcasting, and vodcasting.', u'Of the key markets that Radio Australia operates in, each market segment is at different stages of growth and requires marketing information specific to those markets for sustainable strategic plans to be developed that focus on product, packaging, placement, and promotion.', u'There are two key industry wide trends that affect the nature of Radio Australia\u2019s operations:\nTechnology changes: changes within the radio/media broadcasting industry means that Radio Australia now faces greater competition, as the number of delivery platforms has increased;\nAsian and Pacific affluence: deregulated media environments across Southeast Asia, together with greater wealth and education, continue to drive the demand for diversified content, such as English lessons, and more defined information about Australian life or stronger understanding of Australian perspectives in issues.', u"== Sources of programming ==\nRadio Australia's English language
