{'sentences': [u'The 1984 New York City Subway shooting was a shooting in the New York City Subway, in which Bernhard Goetz shot four alleged muggers on a New York City Subway train in Manhattan on December 22, 1984.', u'He fired five shots, seriously wounding all four men.', u'Goetz surrendered to police nine days after the shooting and was eventually charged with attempted murder, assault, reckless endangerment, and several firearms offenses.', u'A jury found him not guilty of all charges except for one count of carrying an unlicensed firearm, for which he served eight months of a one-year sentence.', u'In 1996, one of the shot men, who had been left paraplegic and brain damaged as a result of his injuries, obtained a civil judgment of $43 million against Goetz.', u'The incident sparked a nationwide debate on race and crime in major cities, the legal limits of self-defense, and the extent to which the citizenry could rely on the police to secure their safety.', u'Although Goetz, dubbed the "Subway Vigilante" by New York City\'s press, came to symbolize New Yorkers\' frustrations with the high crime rates of the 1980s, he was both praised and vilified in the media and public opinion.', u'The incident has also been cited as a contributing factor to the groundswell movement against urban crime and disorder, and the successful National Rifle Association campaigns to loosen restrictions on the concealed carrying of firearms.', u'== Context and background ==\n\nDuring the 1980s, crime rates in New York City were peaking after rising since 1966.', u'Between 1966 and 1981, violent crime rates in the city had more than tripled from 325 to 1100 violent crimes per 100,000 people annually.', u'By mid-decade, the city had a reported crime rate over 70% higher than the rest of the United States.', u'In 1984, there were 2 homicides, 18 violent crimes, and 65 property thefts reported per 10,000 people.', u"The subway became a symbol of the city's inability to control crime.", u'In an opinion poll of New York City residents taken the month after the shootings, more than half of those surveyed said crime was the worst thing about living in the city; about a quarter said they or a family member had been a victim of crime in the last year; and two-thirds said they would be willing to pay for private security for their building or block.', u'Goetz alleged that while transporting electronic equipment in 1981, he was attacked in the Canal Street subway station by three youths in an attempted robbery.', u'They smashed him into a plate-glass door and threw him to the ground, permanently injuring his chest and knee.', u'Goetz assisted an off-duty officer in arresting one of them; the other two attackers escaped.', u"Goetz was angered when the arrested attacker spent less than half the time in the police station spent by Goetz himself, and he was angered further when this attacker was charged only with criminal mischief, for ripping Goetz's jacket.", u'Goetz subsequently applied for a permit to carry a handgun, on the basis of routinely carrying valuable equipment and large sums of cash, but his application was denied for insufficient need.', u'He bought a 5-shot .38-caliber Smith & Wesson Model 38 Airweight revolver during a trip to Florida.', u'== Incident ==\n\nIn the early afternoon of Saturday, December 22, 1984, four African American men from the Bronx\u2014Barry Allen, Troy Canty, Darrell Cabey (all 19) and James Ramseur (18)\u2014boarded a downtown 2 train (Broadway \u2013 Seventh Avenue Line express) carrying screwdrivers, apparently on a mission to steal money from video arcade machines in Manhattan.', u'When the train arrived at the 14th Street station in Manhattan, 15 to 20 other passengers remained with them in R22 subway car 7657, the seventh car of the ten-car train.', u'At the 14th Street station, Goetz entered the car through the rearmost door, crossed the aisle and took a seat on the long bench across from the door.', u'Canty was across the aisle from him, lying on the long bench just to the right of the door.', u"Allen was seated to Canty's left, on the short seat on the other side of the door.", u"Ramseur and Cabey were seated across from the door and to Goetz's right, on the short seat by the conductor's cab.", u'According to Goetz\'s statement to the police, approximately ten seconds later Canty asked him, "How are you?"', u'Goetz responded, "Fine."', u'According to Goetz, the four men gave signals to each other, and shortly thereafter Canty and Barry Allen rose from their seats and moved over to the left of Goetz, blocking Goetz off from the other passengers in the car.', u'By Goetz\'s account, Canty then said, "Give me five dollars."', u'Canty and Ramseur testified at the criminal trial that they were panhandling, and had only requested the money, not demanded it.', u'Cabey did not testify and Allen took the Fifth Amendment.', u'=== Sequence of shots ===\nSources differ in reporting the sequence of shots fired, and whether Cabey was shot once or twice.', u'Following are four versions from significant or reliable sources describing the sequence of shots:\n\n\n==== Cabey shot on the fourth and fifth shots ====\nPrior to the criminal trial, the media reported that Cabey had been shot on the fourth shot and then again on the fifth shot, with Goetz saying, "You don\'t look too bad, here\'s another," or, "You seem all right, here\'s another."', u'This sequence of shots was discredited at the criminal trial when it was revealed that Cabey was shot once in the left side; however, some media still reported this sequence long after the criminal trial.', u'==== Cabey shot on the fifth shot ====\n"Speed is everything," Goetz said in a videotaped statement made after he surrendered nine days later.', u'He told police that while still seated, he planned a "pattern of fire" from left to right.', u'He then stood, stepped clear of Canty, drew his revolver, turned back to Canty, and fired four shots, one at each man, then fired a fifth shot.', u'At the civil trial years later he said, "I was trying to get as many of them as I could."', u"Other sources repeated Goetz's statements to New York City police as to the sequence of shots: Canty was shot first, then Allen, then Ramseur, then Cabey.", u'In the related proceeding People v. Goetz, the New York Court of Appeals summarized the incident:\n\nIt appears from the evidence before the Grand Jury that Canty approached Goetz, possibly with Allen beside him, and stated "Give me five dollars."', u'Neither Canty nor any of the other youths displayed a weapon.', u'Goetz responded by standing up, pulling out his handgun, and firing four shots in rapid succession.', u"The first shot hit Canty in the chest; the second struck Allen in the back; the third went through Ramseur's arm and into his left side; the fourth was fired at Cabey, who apparently was then standing in the corner of the car, but missed, deflecting instead off of a wall of the conductor's cab.", u'After Goetz briefly surveyed the train scene around him, he fired another shot at Cabey, who then was sitting on the end bench of the car.', u"The bullet entered the rear of Cabey's side and severed his spinal cord.", u'According to his statements to police, Goetz checked the first two men to make sure that they had been "taken care of," then, seeing that the fourth man was now sitting down and seemed unhurt, said, "You seem to be all right, here\'s another," and fired at him again.', u'That the fourth man, Cabey, was shot only once was a fact not made known to Goetz or his attorneys until shortly before the trial.', u'One bullet missed, fragmenting on the steel cab wall behind Cabey.', u'(The missed shot would also be the basis of a charge of reckless endangerment of other passengers.)', u'==== Cabey shot on the fourth shot ====\nAt the Bronx civil trial Goetz testified the first shot was Canty, Allen second, the third shot missed, Cabey fourth, and Ramseur fifth.', u"The following similar shooting sequence is from Bernie Goetz's website:\n\nI decided to shoot as many as I could as quickly as I could.", u'I did a fast draw, and shot with one hand (my right), pulling the trigger prior to the gun being aligned on the targets.', u'All actual shots plus my draw time occurred easily within 1.6 seconds or less.', u'This is not as difficult to do as some might think, and occasionally I give a description of the technique along with a re-enactment.', u'The first shot hit Canty in the center of the chest.', u'After the first shot my vision changed and I lost my sense of hearing.', u'The second shot hit lightning fast Barry Allen in the upper rear shoulder as he was ducking (later the bullet was removed from his arm).', u'The third shot hit the subway wall just in front of Cabey; the fourth shot hit Cabey in the left side (severing his spinal cord and rendering him paraplegic).', u"The fifth shot hit Ramseur's arm on the way into his left side.", u'I immediately looked at the first two to make sure they were "taken care of," and then attempted to shoot Cabey again in the stomach, but the gun was empty.', u"I thought Cabey was shot twice after reading a media account no shots missed; I had lost count of the shots and while under adrenaline I didn't even hear the shots or feel the kick of the gun.", u"'You don't look too bad, here's another', is a phrase I came up with later when trying to explain the shooting while I was under the impression that Cabey was shot twice.", u'Cabey, who was briefly standing prior to the shooting, was sitting on the subway bench during all attempted shots.', u'The others were standing.', u'Shortly after the shooting my vision and hearing returned to normal.', u'Goetz does a shooting demonstration (five shots in 1.0 seconds) on the Biography Channel show Aftermath with William Shatner.', u"==== Time magazine's theory (April 8, 1985) ====\nGoetz said one of the boys made gestures that may have implied he had a weapon.", u'He rose and partly unzipped his jacket where the revolver was concealed, and plotted his "pattern of fire" for shooting them.', u'He asked Canty what he had said, and he repeated his statement.', u'At this Goetz unzipping his jacket the rest of the way, drew the gun, and shot Canty, hitting him in the center of the body.', u'He then turned to shoot Allen, who had tried to flee, hitting him in the back, and then shot Ramseur, wounding him in the chest and arm.', u'He then shot again, at Cabey, but may have missed.', u'According to Goetz he then approached Cabey and shot him on the ground; however another witness disputed that Goetz shot Cabey a second time.', u'=== Cabey and the "here\'s another" issue ===\nCabey ended up slumped in the short seat in the corner of the car next to the conductor\'s cab.', u"Whether Cabey was struck by the fourth shot or by the fifth was critical to Goetz's claim of self-defense; this issue was fiercely contested at trial.", u"Medical testimony said that such an injury would render the lower half of Cabey's body instantly useless.", u'According to the prosecution, the fourth shot missed; then Goetz shot a seated Cabey at point-blank range with the fifth.', u'The defense theory of how Cabey ended up in the seat was that he was standing when hit by the fourth shot, then collapsed into the seat due to the lurching and swaying of the train; with the fifth shot being the shot that missed.', u"A summary of Goetz's statements to the police had become public two months after the incident, drawing intense media coverage.", u'Probably most damaging to Goetz\'s public support and to his claim of acting in self-defense was his statement that he had said, "You don\'t look so bad, here\'s another," before firing at Cabey a second time.', u"Media concentration on the summary's more damning portions created a public mindset that a wounded Cabey was shot a second time, with the second shot taken in a premeditated and deliberate way\u2014an impression that stood uncorrected until the criminal trial two years later.", u'Eleven years later, at least one city newspaper (The New York Times) was still reporting as fact that Cabey was shot twice.', u'At trial, one witness testified that Goetz approached to within "two to three feet" of a seated Cabey, then demonstrated how Goetz stood directly in front of Cabey and fired downward, a description that matched Goetz\'s published statements.', u'Eight other independent witnesses testified that all shots came in "rapid succession"; one of these said the firing lasted "about a second".', u'None of the eight heard a pause before the final shot, and none saw Goetz standing in front of Cabey.', u'Whether Goetz actually said aloud the words "You don\'t look so bad, here\'s another" or only thought them is still a matter of dispute.', u'He has subsequently denied on several occasions making the statement.', u'One source said, "In all probability, the defendant uttered these words only to himself and probably not even mouthing the words, but just saying them in his own mind as he squeezed the trigger that fifth time."', u'=== Flight and surrender ===\nThe terrified passengers ran to the other end and out of the car, leaving behind the two women who had been closest to the shooting, fallen or knocked down by the exodus, and immobilized by fear.', u'Goetz talked to them to make sure they were not injured, then was approached by the conductor of the train.', u'Goetz stated, "They tried to rob me."', u'The conductor asked whether Goetz was a police officer, receiving the reply, "No."', u'Some time after a brief conversation in which he refused to hand over his revolver, Goetz jumped to the tracks and ran south through the tunnel to the Chambers Street station, where he exited the system.', u'He went home to gather some belongings, then rented a car and drove north to Bennington, Vermont, where he burned his blue jacket and dismantled the revolver, scattering the pieces in the woods north of town.', u'He drove around New England for several days, registering at motels under various names and paying in cash.', u"On 26 December, an anonymous hotline caller told New York City police that Goetz matched the gunman's description, owned a gun, and had been mugged previously.", u'On December 29, Goetz called his neighbor, Myra Friedman, who told him that police had come by his apartment looking for him, and had left notes asking to be contacted as soon as possible.', u"He gave his side of the story to Friedman, and described his psychological state at the time:\nMyra, in a situation like this, your mind, you're in a combat situation.", u'Your mind is functioning.', u"You're not thinking in a normal way.", u"Your memory isn't even working normally.", u'You are so hyped up.', u'Your vision actually changes.', u'Your field of view changes.', u'Your capabilities change.', u'What you are capable of changes.', u'You are under adrenaline, a drug called adrenaline.', u'And you respond very quickly, and you think very quickly.', u"That's all.", u'[...] You think!', u'You think, you analyze, and you act.', u'And in any situation, you just have to think more quickly than your opposition.', u"That's all.", u'You know.', u'Speed is very important.', u'Goetz returned to New York City on 30 December, turned in the car, picked up some clothing and business papers at his apartment, rented another car and drove back to New England.', u'Shortly after noon the next day, he walked into the Concord, New Hampshire, police headquarters and told the officer on duty, "I am the person they are seeking in New York."', u'=== Statements to police ===\nOnce the officer realized that Goetz was a genuine suspect, Goetz was given a Miranda warning and he waived his right to have an attorney present.', u'After an interview that lasted over an hour, a Concord detective asked Goetz to consent to making an audiotaped statement.', u'Goetz agreed, and a two-hour statement was recorded.', u'That evening, New York City detectives and an assistant district attorney arrived in Concord, and Goetz submitted to a two-hour videotaped interview.', u'Both interviews were eventually played back for the grand juries, the criminal trial, and a civil trial years later.', u'When the audiotape was first played in open court, Goetz was described by The New York Times as "confused and emotional, alternately horrified by and defensive about his actions, and obsessed with justifying them."', u'In his statements, Goetz described his past mugging, in which he was injured and the only assailant arrested went unpunished.', u'He called New York City "lawless" and expressed contempt for its justice system, calling it a "joke," a "sham," and "a disgrace".', u'Goetz said that when the four men he shot surrounded him on the train, he feared being "beaten to a pulp" as well as being robbed.', u'He denied any premeditation for the shooting, something that had been speculated on by the press.', u'Asked what his intentions were when he drew his revolver, Goetz replied, "My intention was to murder them, to hurt them, to make them suffer as much as possible."', u'Later in the tape, Goetz said, "If I had more bullets, I would have shot \'em all again and again.', u'My problem was I ran out of bullets."', u'He added, "I was gonna, I was gonna gouge one of the guys\' [Canty\'s] eyes out with my keys afterwards", but said he stopped when he saw the fear in his eyes.', u"At the criminal trial, Goetz's defense attorneys, Barry Slotnick and Mark M. Baker, argued that this and other extreme statements by Goetz were the product of emotion and an overactive imagination.", u'Goetz was brought back to Manhattan on January 3, 1985 and arraigned on four charges of attempted murder, with bail set at $50,000.', u'He was held in protective custody at the Rikers Island prison hospital.', u'Refusing offers of bail assistance from the public and from his family, he posted bail with his own funds and was released on bond January 8.', u'=== Early reports ===\nBecause of the loudness of the shots inside the confined space of the subway car, there were initial witness reports that suggested the gun involved was a .357 Magnum revolver.', u'Goetz alluded to these reports in a December 2004 interview on the Opie and Anthony radio show, saying that the first shot he fired that afternoon had been unusually loud in part because it was the first shot fired by the small-frame .38 caliber revolver after the factory tests, which "cleaned the barrel."', u'After the incident, rumors spread that Goetz had been threatened with sharpened screwdrivers.', u'This rumor was published as fact by some newspapers including The New York Times; however, neither Goetz nor the men made any such claim.', u'During his subsequent statement to the police, Goetz expressed a belief that none of the young men had been armed.', u"Paramedics and police did find a total of three screwdrivers on two of the men; when Canty testified at Goetz's criminal trial, he said they were to be used to break into video arcade change boxes and not as weapons.", u"== Perpetrator ==\n\nBernhard Goetz was born on November 7, 1947, in Kew Gardens, Queens, New York City, the son of Gertrude and Bernhard Willard Goetz, Sr. His parents were German-born immigrants who had met in the United States; Goetz's father was Lutheran; his mother, who was Jewish, converted to her husband's faith.", u'While growing up, Goetz lived with his parents and three older siblings upstate, where his father ran a dairy farm and a bookbinding business.', u'He and his sister attended boarding school in Switzerland for high school.', u"Goetz returned to the United States in 1965 for college, and earned a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering and nuclear engineering from New York University.", u"By this time the family had relocated to Orlando, Florida; Goetz joined them and worked at his father's residential development business.", u'He was briefly married, and after his divorce moved to New York City, where he started an electronics business out of his Greenwich Village apartment.', u'== Public reaction ==\n"The Subway Vigilante," as Goetz was labeled by New York City media, was front-page news for months, partly owing to the repressed passions the incident unleashed in New York and other cities.', u"Public opinion tended to fall into one of three camps: Those in the first camp tended to believe Goetz's version of the incident, that he was aggressively accosted and surrounded by the four men and feared he was about to be beaten and robbed.", u'Those in the second camp tended to believe the version told by the four men, that they were merely panhandling to get some money to play video games.', u'A third camp believed that Goetz had indeed been threatened, but viewed the shooting as an unjustified overreaction.', u'=== Supporters ===\nSupporters viewed Goetz as a hero for standing up to his attackers and defending himself in an environment where the police were increasingly viewed as ineffective in combating crime.', u'The Guardian Angels, a volunteer patrol group of mostly black and Hispanic teenagers, collected thousands of dollars from subway riders toward a legal defense fund for Goetz.', u'The Congress of Racial Equality (CORE), a civil rights organization, supported Goetz.', u'Its director, Roy Innis, a member of the National Rifle Association\'s governing board, offered to raise defense money, saying Goetz was "the avenger for all of us," and calling for a volunteer force of armed civilians to patrol the streets.', u'The prior criminal convictions of three of the four men (and the published accounts of such) prevented them from gaining much sympathy from many people.', u'A special hotline set up by police to seek information was swamped by calls supporting the shooter and calling him a hero.', u'Harvard Professor of Government James Q. Wilson explained the broad sentiment by saying, "It may simply indicate that there are no more liberals on the crime and law-and-order issue in New York City, because they\'ve all been mugged.', u'"(subscription required)\n\n\n=== Other viewpoints ===\nSome believed the version of the incident as told by the four men\u2014that they were merely panhandling with neither intimidation nor threats of violence.', u'This view was later discredited when Cabey admitted in a newspaper interview that his friends had indeed intended to rob Goetz, who looked like "easy bait".', u'Some saw the incident as racial (with Goetz being white and the four young men black), and the jury verdict as a blow to race relations.', u'Benjamin Hooks, director of the NAACP, said "The jury verdict was inexcusable.', u'[...] It was proven\u2014according to his own statements\u2014that Goetz did the shooting and went far beyond the realm of self-defense.', u'There was no provocation for what he did."', u'Representative Floyd Flake agreed, saying, "I think that if a black had shot four whites, the cry for the death penalty would have been almost automatic."', u"C. Vernon Mason, a candidate for district attorney and co-counsel for Cabey who was later disbarred, said Goetz's actions were racist, as did the Rev.", u'Al Sharpton.', u'Organized demonstrators accused Goetz of genocide.', u'Goetz\'s racial language about criminal activity on 14th Street, allegedly made at a community meeting 18 months before the shooting\u2014"The only way we\'re going to clean up this street is to get rid of the spics and niggers"\u2014was offered as evidence of racial motivation for the shooting.', u'Black political and religious leaders twice called for Federal civil rights investigations.', u'An investigation by the office of U.S. Attorney Rudolph Giuliani determined that the impetus for the shooting had been fear, not race.', u'In an interview with Stone Phillips of Dateline NBC, Goetz later admitted that his fear was enhanced due to the fact that the alleged muggers were black.', u'== Grand juries ==\nManhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau asked a grand jury to indict Goetz on four counts of attempted murder, four of assault, four of reckless endangerment, and one of criminal possession of a weapon.', u'Because they would have to be granted immunity from prosecution, neither Goetz nor the four men he shot were called to testify.', u'The 23 jurors heard witnesses, considered the police report of the shooting, and studied transcripts and tapes of the sometimes conflicting statements Goetz made to police in New Hampshire.', u'The jury refused to indict Goetz on the more serious charges, voting indictments only for unlawful gun possession \u2013 one count of criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree, for carrying in public the loaded unlicensed gun used in the subway shooting, and two counts of possession in the fourth degree, for keeping two other unlicensed handguns in his home.', u'The case was assigned to Judge Stephen Crane.', u'The shootings initially drew wide support from a public fearful and frustrated with rising crime rates and the state of the criminal justice system.', u'A month after the grand jury\'s decision, a report summarizing statements Goetz made to police became public, indicating he had fired one shot at each of the four men, then checked their condition, and seeing no blood on the fourth, said "You don\'t look so bad, here\'s another" and fired again.', u'The media now wrote of a change in the public mood and demanded that Goetz be tried on the attempted murder and assault charges while suggesting approaches that would allow Morgenthau to convene a new grand jury.', u'Public figures including New York Governor Mario Cuomo raised questions based on the police summary.', u'Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania called for a special prosecutor.', u"Stating that he had a new witness, Morgenthau obtained Judge Crane's authorization to convene a second grand jury, which heard testimony by Canty and Ramseur and indicted Goetz on charges of attempted murder, assault, reckless endangerment and weapons possession.", u"Judge Crane later granted a motion by Goetz to dismiss the new indictments, based on alleged errors in the prosecutor's instructions to the jury regarding Goetz's defense of justification for the use of deadly force.", u'A second factor in the dismissal was the judge\'s opinion that testimony by Canty and Ramseur "strongly appeared" to have been perjury, based on later public statements by Canty and Ramseur that they had intended to rob Goetz, and on a newspaper interview where Cabey stated that the other members of the group planned to frighten and rob Goetz because he "looked like easy bait".', u'The judge allowed the weapons possession and reckless endangerment charges to stand.', u"The New York Court of Appeals, in People v. Goetz, reversed Judge Crane's dismissal, affirming the prosecutor's charge to the grand jury that a defendant's subjective belief that he is in imminent danger does not by itself justify the use of deadly force.", u'The court agreed with the prosecutor that an objective belief, one that would be shared by a hypothetical reasonable person, is also required.', u"The appeals court further held that Judge Crane's opinion that the testimony of Canty and Ramseur was perjurious was speculative and inappropriate.", u'All charges were reinstated, and the case was sent to trial.', u'== Trials ==\n\n\n=== Criminal trial ===\nThe case was defended by Barry Slotnick and Mark M. Baker.', u"Slotnick argued that Goetz's actions fell within the New York self-defense statute.", u'Under Section 35.15, "A person may not use deadly physical force upon another person ... unless ...', u'He reasonably believes that such other person is committing or attempting to commit [one of certain enumerated predicate offenses, including robbery]."', u'Goetz was tried before a mainly white Manhattan jury, six of whom had been victims of street crime.', u'He was acquitted of the attempted murder and first-degree assault charges and convicted of criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree \u2013 carrying a loaded, unlicensed weapon in a public place.', u"He was sentenced to six months in jail, one year's psychiatric treatment, five years' probation, 200 hours community service, and a $5,000 fine.", u'An appellate court affirmed the conviction and changed the sentence to one year in jail without probation.', u'The order of the appellate court was affirmed because the trial court had not erred in instructing the jury that, if it found the People had proved each of the elements of the crime beyond a reasonable doubt, it "must" find the defendant guilty.', u'This was not a directed verdict.', u'Goetz served eight months.', u"=== Civil trial ===\nA month after the shootings, Cabey's lawyers William Kunstler and Ron Kuby filed a civil suit against Goetz.", u'The case was tried in 1996, eleven years later, in the Bronx, with race as the dominant theme.', u'During jury selection, Kuby asked the mostly non-white prospective jurors whether they had ever been discriminated against.', u'Goetz admitted to previous use of racial language and to smoking marijuana laced with PCP in the 1980s.', u"Kuby portrayed Goetz as a racist aggressor; Goetz's defense was that when surrounded he reacted in fear of being again robbed and beaten.", u'Newspaper columnist Jimmy Breslin testified that in a 1985 interview, Cabey denied his involvement in an attempted robbery, but said that Canty, Allen, and Ramseur intended to rob Goetz.', u'The jury found that Goetz had acted recklessly and had deliberately inflicted emotional distress on Cabey.', u'Jurors stated that Goetz shooting Cabey twice was a key factor in their decision.', u'The jury awarded Cabey $43 million \u2013 $18 million for pain and suffering and $25 million in punitive damages.', u'Goetz subsequently filed for bankruptcy, saying that legal expenses had left him almost penniless.', u'A judge of the United States Bankruptcy Court ruled that the $43 million jury award could not be dismissed by the bankruptcy.', u'Asked in 2004 whether he was making payments on the judgment, Goetz responded "I don\'t think I\'ve paid a penny on that", and referred any questions on the subject to his attorney.', u'== Aftermath ==\n\n\n=== Legacy ===\nThe New York State legal standard for the self-defense justification use of deadly force shifted after rulings in the case.', u"New York State jurors are now told to consider a defendant's background and to consider whether a hypothetical reasonable person would feel imperiled if that reasonable person were the defendant.", u'After reaching an all-time peak in 1990, crime in New York City dropped dramatically through the rest of the 1990s.', u'As of 2006, New York City had statistically become one of the safest large cities in the U.S., with its crime rate being ranked 194th of the 210 American cities with populations over 100,000.', u'New York City crime rates as of 2014 were comparable to those of the early 1960s.', u'Goetz and others have interpreted the significance of his actions in the subway incident as a contributing factor precipitating the groundswell movement against crime in subsequent years.', u'While that claim is impossible to verify, Goetz achieved celebrity status as a popular cultural symbol of a public disgusted with urban crime and disorder.', u"=== Goetz's activities since the incident ===\nGoetz occasionally gives media interviews about the 1984 subway incident that brought him into the public eye.", u'In 2004, Goetz was interviewed by Nancy Grace on Larry King Live, where he stated his actions were good for New York City and forced the city to address crime.', u"In 2010 he was interviewed and did a shooting demonstration on the inaugural episode of The Biography Channel's documentary show Aftermath with William Shatner.", u'== See also ==\n\nJoe Horn shooting controversy\nTony Martin (farmer)\n\n\n== References ==\n\nSources\n\n\n== External links ==\nBernhard Goetz at {'sentences': [u'The Prussian uprisings were two major and three smaller uprisings by the Prussians, one of the Baltic tribes, against the Teutonic Knights that took place in the 13th century during the Prussian Crusade.', u'The crusading military order, supported by the Popes and Christian Europe, sought to conquer and convert the pagan Prussians.', u'In the first ten years of the crusade five of the seven major Prussian clans fell under the control of the less numerous Teutonic Knights.', u'However, the Prussians rose against their conquerors on five occasions.', u'The first uprising was supported by Duke Swietopelk II, Duke of Pomerania.', u'The Prussians were successful at first, reducing the Knights to only five of their strongest castles.', u'Conversely, the duke suffered a series of military defeats and was eventually forced to make peace with the Teutonic Knights.', u"With Duke Swietopelk's support for the Prussians broken, a prelate of Pope Innocent IV then negotiated a peace treaty between the Prussians and the Knights.", u'However, this treaty was never honored or enforced, especially after the Battle of Kr\xfccken at the end of 1249.', u'The second uprising, known in historiography as "The Great Prussian Uprising", was prompted by the 1260 Battle of Durbe, the largest defeat suffered by the Teutonic Knights in the 13th century.', u'This uprising was the longest, largest, and most threatening to the Teutonic Order, who again were reduced to five of their strongest castles.', u'Reinforcements for the Knights were slow to arrive, despite repeated encouragements from Pope Urban IV, and the position of the Order looked set to worsen.', u'Luckily for the Order, the Prussians lacked unity and a common strategy and reinforcements finally reached Prussia in around 1265.', u'One by one, Prussian clans surrendered and the uprising was ended in 1274.', u'The later three lesser uprisings depended on foreign help and were suppressed within one or two years.', u'The last uprising in 1295 effectively ended the Prussian Crusade and Prussia became a Christian German-speaking territory, which assimilated native Prussians and a number of settlers from different German states.', u'== Background ==\nAlthough the Prussians repelled early incursions by the Order of Dobrzy\u0144, they were outnumbered by attacks from Poland, Russians in the southeast and the Teutonic Knights from the west.', u'The Teutonic Order was called to the Culmerland (Che\u0142mno Land) in 1226 by Konrad I of Masovia, who started a number of attacks and crusades against the Prussians and later asked the Knights to protect him from retaliatory raids by the Prussians.', u'Preoccupied with crusades in the Holy Land, the Teutonic Knights arrived only in 1230.', u'Their first task was to build a base on the left bank of Vistula at Vogelsang, opposite of Toru\u0144 (Thorn), which was completed a year later.', u'Led by Hermann Balk, the Knights did not repeat the mistakes of the previous Order and did not push eastwards into the forest of the interior.', u'They would further build fortified log (later brick and stone) castles along major rivers and the Vistula Lagoon to serve as basis for future expansion.', u'In 1231\u20131242, forty such castles were built.', u'The Prussians faced major difficulties in capturing these castles as they were accustomed only to battling in open fields.', u'Most conflicts occurred either in summer or winter.', u'Heavily-armoured knights could not travel and fight on land soaked by water from melting snow or autumn rains.', u'Summer campaigns were most dangerous as the Knights would immediately build new castles in the conquered territory.', u"The Teutonic Knight's strategy proved successful: in ten years, five of the seven major Prussian clans fell under control of the less-numerous Teutonic Knights.", u'However, the Prussians further resisted the conquerors, leading to five uprisings over the following fifty years.', u'== The First Prussian Uprising (1242\u20131249) ==\n\nThe First Prussian Uprising was influenced by three major events.', u'Firstly, the Teutonic Knights lost the Battle of the Ice on Lake Peipus to Alexander Nevsky in April 1242.', u'Secondly, southern Poland was devastated by a Mongol invasion in 1241; Poland lost the Battle of Legnica and the Teutonic Knights lost one of its most trusted allies that often supplied troops.', u"Thirdly, Duke Swantopolk II of Pomerania was fighting against the Knights, who supported his brothers' dynastic claims against him.", u'It has been implied that the new castles of the Knights were competing with his lands over the trade routes along the Vistula River.', u'While some historians embrace the Swantopolk\u2013Prussian alliance without hesitation, others are more careful.', u'They point out that the historical information came from documents written by the Teutonic Knights and must have been ideologically charged to persuade the Pope to declare a crusade not only against the pagan Prussians but also against the Christian duke.', u'Prussians besieged Teutonic castles and managed to capture all except for Elbing (Elbl\u0105g) and Balga in the eastern regions of Natangia, Barta and Warmia; Thorn (Toru\u0144), Culm (Che\u0142mno), and Rehden (Radzy\u0144 Che\u0142mi\u0144ski) in the western parts.', u"In December 1242, the Knights were able to capture Sartowice, Swantopolk's castle on the banks of the Vistula.", u'The ensuing five-week siege of Sartowice failed to recapture the fortress and Swantopolk lost 900 men.', u'In the spring of 1243, Swantopolk also lost the castle at Nakel (Nak\u0142o nad Noteci\u0105), which dominated trade on the Note\u0107 River.', u'In the face of these losses, the duke was forced to make short-lived truce.', u'In the summer of 1243, Prussians with Sudovian help raided the Culmerland (Che\u0142mno Land) and, on their way back, defeated the pursuing Teutonic Knights on June 15 on the banks of the Osa River.', u'Some 400 Teutonic soldiers perished, including their marshal.', u'Swantopolk, encouraged by the defeat, gathered an army of 2,000 men and unsuccessfully besieged Culm (Che\u0142mno).', u'The Teutonic Knights managed to gather a coalition against Swantopolk: Dukes of Masovia were given territories in Prussia, Dukes of Greater Poland received Nakel, and Dukes of Pomerellia, brothers of Swantopolk, hoped to regain their inheritance.', u'Swantopolk built a castle at Zantyr, where Nogat separated from the Vistula, and launched a blockade of Elbing and Balga.', u'While the castle withstood Teutonic attacks, the blockade was smashed by cogs.', u"In late 1245 Swantopolks's army suffered a great defeat at S(ch)wetz \u015awiecie, and another one in early 1246, where 1,500 Pomeranians were killed.", u'Swantopolk II asked for truce and Pope Innocent IV appointed his chaplain, Jacob of Li\xe8ge, the future Pope Urban IV, to handle the peace negotiations.', u'However, the war was renewed in 1247 when large Teutonic reinforcements arrived in Prussia.', u'On Christmas Eve of 1247 the Knights besieged and overwhelmed a major Pomesanian fortress, which they later renamed Christburg (Dzierzgo\u0144), and newly arrived Henry III, Margrave of Meissen subdued the Pogesanians.', u'Swantopolk retaliated and destroyed Christburg, but the Knights rebuilt it in a new location.', u"Both Prussian and Swantopolk's armies failed to capture the new castle.", u'Otto III of Brandenburg raided Warmia and Natangia forcing the locals to surrender.', u'The peace talks that begun in 1247 achieved little, but a new truce was arranged in September 1248 and peace was made on November 24, 1248.', u'Swantopolk had to return lands seized from his brothers, allow Teutonic Knights to pass through his domains, stop charging tolls on ships using the Vistula, and stop any aid to the Prussians.', u'Prussians were compelled to sign the Treaty of Christburg on February 7, 1249.', u'The treaty provided personal freedom and rights to newly converted Christians.', u'It formally ended the uprising, but already in November 1249 the Natangians defeated the Knights at the Battle of Kr\xfccken.', u'The skirmishes lasted until 1253 and some sources cite this year as the end of the uprising.', u'At that point the treaty ceased its political power but remained an interesting historical document.', u'== The Great Prussian Uprising (1260\u20131274) ==\n\n\n=== Preparation and tactics ===\nThe major revolt began on September 20, 1260.', u'It was triggered by the Lithuanian and Samogitian military victory against the joint forces of the Livonian Order and Teutonic Knights in the Battle of Durbe.', u'As the uprising was spreading through Prussian lands, each clan chose a leader: the Sambians were led by Glande, the Natangians by Herkus Monte, the Bartians by Diwanus, the Warmians by Glappe, the Pogesanians by Auktume.', u'One clan that did not join the uprising was the Pomesanians.', u'The uprising was also supported by Skalmantas, leader of the Sudovians.', u'However, there was no one leader to coordinate efforts of these different forces.', u'Herkus Monte, who was educated in Germany, became the best known and most successful of the leaders, but he commanded only his Natangians.', u'The Prussians besieged the many castles that the Knights had built and could not send large armies to fight in the west.', u'Prussians were not familiar with Western European siege tactics and machinery and relied on siege forts, built around the castle, to cut the supplies to the garrisons.', u'The Teutonic Knights could not raise large armies to deliver supplies to the starving garrisons and smaller castles began to fall.', u'Those castles were usually destroyed and the Prussians manned just a few castles, notably one in Heilsberg (Lidzbark Warmi\u0144ski), because they lacked technology to defend the captured castles and organization to provide food and supplies to stationed garrisons.', u'On August 29, 1261 Jacob of Li\xe8ge, who negotiated the Treaty of Christburg after the first uprising, was elected as Pope Urban IV.', u'He, having an inside scope on events in Prussia, was especially favourable to the Teutonic Knights and issued 22 papal bulls in three years of his papacy calling for reinforcements to the Knights.', u'However, the reinforcements were slow to come as dukes of Poland and Germany were preoccupied with their own disputes and the Livonian Order was fighting the Semigallian uprising.', u'=== Early Prussian success ===\n\nThe first reinforcement to the Teutonic forces arrived in early 1261, but was wiped out on January 21, 1261 by Herkus Monte in the Battle of Pokarwis.', u'In January 1262 reinforcements arrived from the Rhineland, led by Wilhelm VII, Duke of J\xfclich, who was obliged by Pope Alexander IV to fulfil his crusader duties in Prussia.', u'This army broke the Siege of K\xf6nigsberg but as soon as the army returned home, the Sambians resumed the siege and were reinforced by Herkus Monte and his Natangians.', u'Herkus was later injured and the Natangians retreated, leaving the Sambians unable to stop supplies reaching the castle and the siege eventually failed.', u'Prussians were more successful capturing castles deeper into the Prussian territory (with an exception of Wehlau, now Znamensk), and the Knights were left only with strongholds in Balga, Elbing, Culm, Thorn, and K\xf6nigsberg.', u'Most castles fell in 1262\u20131263, and Bartenstein fell in 1264.', u'The Prussians destroyed captured forts instead of using them for their own defence, so the end of successful sieges meant that large Prussian forces did not have to stay near their home and were then free to operate in other parts of Prussia, raiding the Culmerland and Kuyavia.', u'A recovered Herkus Monte raided Culmerland with a large force and took many prisoners in 1263.', u'On his way back to Natangia, Herkus and his men were confronted by a contingent of their enemies.', u'In the Battle of L\xf6bau that ensued, Prussians killed forty knights, including the Master and the Marshal.', u'The Prussians also received help from Lithuanians and Sudovians.', u'In summer of 1262 Treniota and Shvarn attacked Masovia, killing Duke Siemowit I, and raided Culmerland, provoking Pogesanians to join the uprising.', u'However, assassination of Mindaugas and subsequent dynastic fights prevented Lithuanians from further campaigns.', u'Skalmantas, leader of Sudovians, raided Culm (Che\u0142mno) in 1263 and in 1265.', u'=== Turning point ===\n\nThe year of 1265 was the turning point in the uprising: more substantial reinforcements for the Teutonic Knights finally started arriving in Prussia and Sambia gave up the fight.', u'Teutonic castles in K\xf6nigsberg and Wehlau on the Pregel River cut off the region from the rest of Prussia.', u'Supplies to K\xf6nigsberg were brought by sea, and the castle served as the basis for raids in surrounding Samland (Sambia).', u'The Livonian Order sent troops to K\xf6nigsberg and the joint forces defeated the Sambians in a decisive battle forcing them to surrender.', u'In 1265 reinforcements arrived from Germany: armies of Duke Albrecht of Braunschweig and Margrave Albert of Meissen arrived in Prussia, but were unable to achieve much.', u'In 1266 Otto III and John I, co-rulers of Brandenburg, built a castle in the Natangian lands between Balga and K\xf6nigsberg and named it Brandenburg (since 1945 Ushakovo).', u'Due to bad weather they did not organize campaigns into Prussian lands.', u'When the Dukes returned home, Brandenburg was captured by Glappe and his Warmians.', u'The very next year Otto returned to rebuild the castle.', u"However, both John and Otto died before the end of 1267, and Otto's son was killed in a tournament.", u'Subsequent Dukes of Brandenburg were not as supportive of the Knights.', u'In 1266 Duke Swantopolk, the supporter of the Prussians during the First Uprising, died and his sons Mestwin and Warcis\u0142aw briefly joined the Prussians in the uprising.', u'In 1267 King Ottokar II of Bohemia, who already participated in the Prussian Crusade in 1254 and who was promised by Pope Urban IV all Prussian lands he could conquer, finally arrived in Prussia.', u'His only achievement was forcing Duke Mestwin to reconcile with the Teutonic Knights.', u'His large army was unable to campaign due to an early thaw: heavily armed knights could hardly fight during the wet and swampy spring season.', u'The warfare with the Prussians relied on guerilla raids in the border regions.', u'Small groups of men, a dozen to a hundred, made quick raids on farms, villages, border posts, etc.', u'This was a positional warfare where neither side could defeat the other, but the Teutonic Knights relied on future reinforcements from Germany and Europe, while Prussians were draining their local resources.', u'After the massacre of surrendered Teutonic soldiers in the Battle of Kr\xfccken in 1249, the Knights refused to negotiate with the Prussians.', u'The Prussians were also unable to coordinate their efforts and develop a common strategy: while each clan had its own leader, there was no one to lead all the clans.', u'The Natangians had to watch for attacks from Balga, Brandenburg, Wehlau, and K\xf6nigsberg while the Warmians were threatened by garrisons at Christburg and Elbing.', u'This way only Diwane and his Bartians were able to continue the war in the west.', u'They made several minor expeditions to Culmerland each year.', u'=== The end of the uprising ===\n\nThe major Prussian offensive was organized in 1271 together with Linka, leader of the Pogesanians.', u'The Bartian infantry and Pogesanians besieged a border castle, but were fended off by the Knights from Christburg.', u'The Prussians who managed to escape joined their cavalry while the Knights set up a camp on the opposite bank of the Dargune River (Dzierzgo\u0144 River), blocking the route home.', u'When Christians retired for the night, one half of the Prussian army crossed the river in a distance, in order to attack the Knights from the rear, while the other half charged straight across the river.', u'The Knights were encircled.', u'The Battle of Paganstin saw twelve knights and 500 men killed.', u'The Prussians immediately assaulted Christburg and almost captured it.', u'The Prussians were still looting the surrounding area when cavalry from Elbing arrived.', u'Many of the Prussian infantry perished while cavalry escaped.', u'Despite these losses, Diwane was soon back and blocked roads leading to Christburg hoping to starve the castle.', u'Diwane was killed during a siege of a small post at Sch\xf6nsee (W\u0105brze\u017ano) in 1273.', u'In the winter of 1271\u20131272 reinforcements arrived from Meissen, led by Count Dietrich II.', u'The army invaded Natangia and besieged an unnamed Natangian castle.', u'While the assault claimed 150 lives of the crusaders, most of Natangian resistance was broken and the region was decimated.', u'Herkus Monte, with a small group of his followers, was forced to withdraw to the forests of southern Prussia.', u'Within a year he was finally captured and hanged.', u'The last Prussian leader, Glappe of Warmians, was also hanged when his siege campaign on Brandenburg (now Ushakovo) was attacked from the rear.', u'The last tribe standing were the Pogesanians, who made a surprise raid into Elbing and ambushed its garrison.', u'In 1274 the Knights made a great expedition to avenge this raid, capturing the rebel headquarters at Heilsberg (Lidzbark Warmi\u0144ski) and ending the uprising.', u'The Knights proceeded to rebuild and strengthen castles destroyed by the Prussians.', u'A number of Prussians escaped either to Sudovia or to Lithuania, or were resettled by the Knights.', u'Many free peasants were made into serfs.', u'Local nobles had to convert and give hostages, and only a few of them were granted privileges to retain their noble status.', u'From 1274 to 1283 the Teutonic Knights conquered Skalvians, Nadruvians, and Sudovians/Yotvingians.', u'== Further uprisings and aftermath ==\n\nAfter the Great Uprising, the Prussians rose a number of times against the Knights, but these uprisings were much smaller in scale and posed no real danger to the Teutonic Knights, who could concentrate on further conquests.', u'The number of uprisings is variously considered to be two or three..', u'They were suppressed within a year or two and showed exhaustion and division of the Prussian tribes.', u'The third uprising in 1276 was provoked by Skalmantas, leader of the Sudovians, who successfully raided Teutonic lands.', u'The next year he, with help from the Lithuanians, led 4,000 men into the Culmerland (Che\u0142mno Land).', u'The uprising failed to spread after Theodoric, vogt of Sambia, convinced the Sambians not to join the insurrection; Natangians and Warmians had also accepted baptism and promised their loyalty to the Knights.', u'The Pogesanians alone continued the fight and were crushed.', u'Survivors with their Bartian chief escaped to Hrodna in the Grand Duchy of Lithuania where they joined some of the Bartians, Skalvians, and all of the Nadruvians, who fled there after the Great Uprising.', u'The last two Prussian attempts to rid itself of the Teutonic rule were made relying on the foreign powers who were enemies of the Knights.', u'The first one in 1286, also known as the fourth uprising, depended upon help from the Duke of R\xfcgen, the grandson of Swantopolk.', u'The plot was soon revealed and the Bartians and Pogesanians suffered the consequences.', u'In 1295 the last uprising was limited to Natangia and Sambia and depended upon help from Vytenis, Grand Duke of Lithuania.', u'The rebels captured Bartenstein (Bartoszyce) by surprise and plundered as far as K\xf6nigsberg, but were never a serious threat.', u'By that time Prussian nobility was already baptized and pro-Teutonic to the extent that peasants killed them first before attacking the Knights.', u'This last attempt effectively ended the Prussian Crusade and the Knights concentrated on conquering Samogitia and Lithuania.', u'Lithuanian historians note that fierce resistance by the Prussians won time for the young Lithuanian state to mature and strengthen so it could withstand the hundred-year crusade, culminating in the 1410 Battle of Grunwald, with minimal territorial losses.', u'The Prussian lands were repopulated by colonists from Germany, who after the 16th century eventually outnumbered the natives.', u'It is estimated that around 1400 Prussians numbered 100,000 and comprised about half of the total population in Prussia.', u'The Prussians were subject to Germanization and assimilation and eventually became extinct sometime after the 16th century.', u'It is believed that the Prussian language became extinct sometime at the beginning of the 18th century.', u'== See also ==\nNorthern Crusade\nTeutonic Knights\nLivonian Order\nPrussia (region)\n\n\n== References =='], 'year': '1741-12-27', 'title': 'Prussian forces took Olmutz Czechoslovakia'}
{'sentences': [u'Thomas Becket (/\u02c8b\u025bk\u026at/; also known as Saint Thomas of Canterbury, Thomas of London, and later Thomas \xe0 Becket; 21 December c. 1119 (or 1120) \u2013 29 December 1170) was Archbishop of Canterbury from 1162 until his murder in 1170.', u'He is venerated as a saint and martyr by both the Catholic Church and the Anglican Communion.', u'He engaged in conflict with Henry II, King of England over the rights and privileges of the Church and was murdered by followers of the king in Canterbury Cathedral.', u'Soon after his death, he was canonised by Pope Alexander III.', u'== Sources ==\nThe main sources for the life of Becket are a number of biographies that were written by contemporaries.', u'A few of these documents are by unknown writers, although traditional historiography has given them names.', u'The known biographers are John of Salisbury, Edward Grim, Benedict of Peterborough, William of Canterbury, William fitz Stephen, Guernes of Pont-Sainte-Maxence, Robert of Cricklade, Alan of Tewkesbury, Benet of St Albans, and Herbert of Bosham.', u'The other biographers, who remain anonymous, are generally given the pseudonyms of Anonymous I, Anonymous II (or Anonymous of Lambeth), and Anonymous III (or Lansdowne Anonymous).', u'Besides these accounts, there are also two other accounts that are likely contemporary that appear in the Quadrilogus II and the Th\xf3mas saga Erkibyskups.', u"Besides these biographies, there is also the mention of the events of Becket's life in the chroniclers of the time.", u"These include Robert of Torigni's work, Roger of Howden's Gesta Regis Henrici Secundi and Chronica, Ralph Diceto's works, William of Newburgh's Historia Rerum, and Gervase of Canterbury's works.", u'== Early life ==\n\nBecket was born about 1119, or in 1120 according to later tradition.', u'He was born in Cheapside, London, on 21 December, which was the feast day of St Thomas the Apostle.', u"He was the son of Gilbert Beket and Gilbert's wife Matilda.", u"Gilbert's father was from Thierville in the lordship of Brionne in Normandy, and was either a small landowner or a petty knight.", u'Matilda was also of Norman ancestry, and her family may have originated near Caen.', u'Gilbert was perhaps related to Theobald of Bec, whose family also was from Thierville.', u'Gilbert began his life as a merchant, perhaps as a textile merchant, but by the 1120s he was living in London and was a property owner, living on the rental income from his properties.', u'He also served as the sheriff of the city at some point.', u"They were buried in Old St Paul's Cathedral.", u"One of Becket's father's wealthy friends, Richer de L'Aigle, often invited Thomas to his estates in Sussex where Becket was exposed to hunting and hawking.", u'According to Grim, Becket learned much from Richer, who was later a signatory of the Constitutions of Clarendon against Thomas.', u"Beginning when he was 10, Becket was sent as a student to Merton Priory in England and later attended a grammar school in London, perhaps the one at St Paul's Cathedral.", u'He did not study any subjects beyond the trivium and quadrivium at these schools.', u'Later, he spent about a year in Paris around age 20.', u'He did not, however, study canon or civil law at this time and his Latin skill always remained somewhat rudimentary.', u'Some time after Becket began his schooling, Gilbert Beket suffered financial reverses, and the younger Becket was forced to earn a living as a clerk.', u'Gilbert first secured a place for his son in the business of a relative \u2013 Osbert Huitdeniers \u2013 and then later Becket acquired a position in the household of Theobald of Bec, by now the Archbishop of Canterbury.', u'Theobald entrusted him with several important missions to Rome and also sent him to Bologna and Auxerre to study canon law.', u"Theobald in 1154 named Becket Archdeacon of Canterbury, and other ecclesiastical offices included a number of benefices, prebends at Lincoln Cathedral and St Paul's Cathedral, and the office of Provost of Beverley.", u'His efficiency in those posts led to Theobald recommending him to King Henry II for the vacant post of Lord Chancellor, to which Becket was appointed in January 1155.', u"As Chancellor, Becket enforced the king's traditional sources of revenue that were exacted from all landowners, including churches and bishoprics.", u"King Henry even sent his son Henry to live in Becket's household, it being the custom then for noble children to be fostered out to other noble houses.", u'The younger Henry was reported to have said Becket showed him more fatherly love in a day than his father did for his entire life.', u'== Primacy ==\nBecket was nominated as Archbishop of Canterbury in 1162, several months after the death of Theobald.', u'His election was confirmed on 23 May 1162 by a royal council of bishops and noblemen.', u'Henry may have hoped that Becket would continue to put the royal government first, rather than the church.', u'However, the famous transformation of Becket into an ascetic occurred at this time.', u'Becket enthroned as Archbishop of Canterbury from a Nottingham Alabaster in the Victoria & Albert Museum\n\nBecket was ordained a priest on 2 June 1162 at Canterbury, and on 3 June 1162 was consecrated as archbishop by Henry of Blois, the Bishop of Winchester and the other suffragan bishops of Canterbury.', u'A rift grew between Henry and Becket as the new archbishop resigned his chancellorship and sought to recover and extend the rights of the archbishopric.', u'This led to a series of conflicts with the King, including that over the jurisdiction of secular courts over English clergymen, which accelerated antipathy between Becket and the king.', u'Attempts by Henry to influence the other bishops against Becket began in Westminster in October 1163, where the King sought approval of the traditional rights of the royal government in regard to the church.', u"This led to Clarendon, where Becket was officially asked to agree to the King's rights or face political repercussions.", u'== Constitutions of Clarendon ==\n\nKing Henry II presided over the assemblies of most of the higher English clergy at Clarendon Palace on 30 January 1164.', u'In sixteen constitutions, he sought less clerical independence and a weaker connection with Rome.', u'He employed all his skills to induce their consent and was apparently successful with all but Becket.', u'Finally, even Becket expressed his willingness to agree to the substance of the Constitutions of Clarendon, but he still refused to formally sign the documents.', u"Henry summoned Becket to appear before a great council at Northampton Castle on 8 October 1164, to answer allegations of contempt of royal authority and malfeasance in the Chancellor's office.", u'Convicted on the charges, Becket stormed out of the trial and fled to the Continent.', u"Henry pursued the fugitive archbishop with a series of edicts, targeting Becket as well as all of Becket's friends and supporters; but King Louis VII of France offered Becket protection.", u"He spent nearly two years in the Cistercian abbey of Pontigny, until Henry's threats against the order obliged him to return to Sens.", u'Becket fought back by threatening excommunication and interdict against the king and bishops and the kingdom, but Pope Alexander III, though sympathising with him in theory, favoured a more diplomatic approach.', u'Papal legates were sent in 1167 with authority to act as arbitrators.', u'In 1170, Alexander sent delegates to impose a solution to the dispute.', u'At that point, Henry offered a compromise that would allow Thomas to return to England from exile.', u"== Assassination ==\nIn June 1170, Roger de Pont L'\xc9v\xeaque, the archbishop of York, along with Gilbert Foliot, the Bishop of London, and Josceline de Bohon, the Bishop of Salisbury, crowned the heir apparent, Henry the Young King, at York.", u"This was a breach of Canterbury's privilege of coronation, and in November 1170 Becket excommunicated all three.", u'While the three clergymen fled to the king in Normandy, Becket continued to excommunicate his opponents in the church, the news of which also reached Henry.', u"Upon hearing reports of Becket's actions, Henry is said to have uttered words that were interpreted by his men as wishing Becket killed.", u"The king's exact words are in doubt and several versions have been reported.", u'The most commonly quoted, as handed down by oral tradition, is "Who will rid me of this troublesome priest?', u'", but according to historian Simon Schama this is incorrect: he accepts the account of the contemporary biographer Edward Grim, writing in Latin, who gives us "What miserable drones and traitors have I nourished and brought up in my household, who let their lord be treated with such shameful contempt by a low-born cleric?"', u'Many variations have found their way into popular culture.', u'Whatever Henry said, it was interpreted as a royal command, and four knights, Reginald FitzUrse, Hugh de Morville, William de Tracy and Richard le Breton, set out to confront the Archbishop of Canterbury.', u'On 29 December 1170 they arrived at Canterbury.', u'According to accounts left by the monk Gervase of Canterbury and eyewitness Edward Grim, they placed their weapons under a tree outside the cathedral and hid their mail armour under cloaks before entering to challenge Becket.', u'The knights informed Becket he was to go to Winchester to give an account of his actions, but Becket refused.', u"It was not until Becket refused their demands to submit to the king's will that they retrieved their weapons and rushed back inside for the killing.", u'Becket, meanwhile, proceeded to the main hall for vespers.', u'The four knights, wielding drawn swords, caught up with him in a spot near a door to the monastic cloister, the stairs into the crypt, and the stairs leading up into the quire of the cathedral, where the monks were chanting vespers.', u'Several contemporary accounts of what happened next exist; of particular note is that of Edward Grim, who was himself wounded in the attack.', u'This is part of the account from Edward Grim:\n\nThe wicked knight leapt suddenly upon him, cutting off the top of the crown which the unction of sacred chrism had dedicated to God.', u'Next he received a second blow on the head, but still he stood firm and immovable.', u'At the third blow he fell on his knees and elbows, offering himself a living sacrifice, and saying in a low voice, "For the name of Jesus and the protection of the Church, I am ready to embrace death."', u'But the third knight inflicted a terrible wound as he lay prostrate.', u'By this stroke, the crown of his head was separated from the head in such a way that the blood white with the brain, and the brain no less red from the blood, dyed the floor of the cathedral.', u"The same clerk who had entered with the knights placed his foot on the neck of the holy priest and precious martyr, and, horrible to relate, scattered the brains and blood about the pavements, crying to the others, 'Let us away, knights; this fellow will arise no more.", u'Another account can be found in Expugnatio Hibernica ("Conquest of Ireland", 1189) written by Gerald of Wales.', u"== After Becket's death ==\n\nFollowing Becket's death, the monks prepared his body for burial.", u"According to some accounts, it was discovered that Becket had worn a hairshirt under his archbishop's garments\u2014a sign of penance.", u"Soon after, the faithful throughout Europe began venerating Becket as a martyr, and on 21 February 1173\u2014little more than two years after his death\u2014he was canonised by Pope Alexander III in St Peter's Church in Segni.", u"In 1173, Becket's sister Mary was appointed as abbess of Barking Abbey as reparation for the murder of her brother.", u"On 12 July 1174, in the midst of the Revolt of 1173\u201374, Henry humbled himself with public penance at Becket's tomb as well as at the church of St. Dunstan's, which became one of the most popular pilgrimage sites in England.", u"Becket's assassins fled north to Knaresborough Castle, which was held by Hugh de Morville, where they remained for about a year.", u'De Morville held property in Cumbria and this may also have provided a convenient bolt-hole, as the men prepared for a longer stay in the separate kingdom of Scotland.', u'They were not arrested and neither did Henry confiscate their lands, but he failed to help them when they sought his advice in August 1171.', u'Pope Alexander excommunicated all four.', u'Seeking forgiveness, the assassins travelled to Rome and were ordered by the Pope to serve as knights in the Holy Lands for a period of fourteen years.', u'This last also inspired Knights of Saint Thomas, incorporated in 1191 at Acre, and which was to be modelled on the Teutonic Knights.', u'It is the only military order native to England (with chapters in not only Acre, but London, Kilkenny, and Nicosia), like the Gilbertine Order being the only monastic order native to England as well.', u'Nevertheless, Henry VIII dissolved both of these English institutions upon passing the Reformation, rather than merging foreign orders with them and nationalising them as elements of the Protestant Church of England.', u"The monks were afraid that Becket's body might be stolen.", u"To prevent this Becket's remains were placed beneath the floor of the eastern crypt of the cathedral.", u'A stone cover was placed over the burial place with two holes where pilgrims could insert their heads and kiss the tomb; this arrangement is illustrated in the "Miracle Windows" of the Trinity Chapel.', u'A guard chamber (now called the Wax Chamber) had a clear view of the grave.', u"In 1220, Becket's bones were moved to a new gold-plated and bejewelled shrine behind the high altar in the Trinity Chapel.", u'The shrine was supported by three pairs of pillars, placed on a raised platform with three steps.', u'This is also illustrated in one of the miracle windows.', u'Canterbury, because of its religious history, had always seen a large number of pilgrims.', u'However, after the death of Thomas Becket, the number of pilgrims visiting the city rose rapidly.', u"== Cult in the Middle Ages ==\n\nOn 7 July 1220, in the 50th jubilee year of his death, Becket's remains were moved from this first tomb to a shrine, in the recently completed Trinity Chapel.", u'This act of translation was "one of the great symbolic events in the life of the medieval English Church" and was attended by King Henry III, the papal legate, the Archbishop of Canterbury Stephen Langton and large numbers of dignitaries and magnates secular and ecclesiastical.', u'Thus a "major new feast day was instituted, commemorating the translation, that was celebrated each July almost everywhere in England and also in many French churches."', u'This feast was suppressed in 1536 at the Reformation.', u'The shrine stood until it was destroyed in 1538, during the Dissolution of the Monasteries, on orders from King Henry VIII.', u"The king also destroyed Becket's bones and ordered that all mention of his name be obliterated.", u"As the scion of the leading mercantile dynasty of later centuries, Mercers, Becket was very much regarded as a Londoner by the citizens and was adopted as London's co-patron saint with St Paul: both their images appeared on the seals of the city and of the Lord Mayor.", u'The Bridge House Estates seal used only the image of Becket, while the reverse featured a depiction of his martyrdom.', u'Local legends regarding Becket arose after his canonisation.', u"Though they are typical hagiographical stories, they also display Becket's particular gruffness.", u'"Becket\'s Well", in Otford, Kent, is said to have been created after Becket had become displeased with the taste of the local water.', u'Two springs of clear water are said to have bubbled up after he struck the ground with his crozier.', u'The absence of nightingales in Otford is also ascribed to Becket, who is said to have been so disturbed in his devotions by the song of a nightingale that he commanded that none should sing in the town ever again.', u'In the town of Strood, also in Kent, Becket is said to have caused the inhabitants of the town and their descendants to be born with tails.', u"The men of Strood had sided with the king in his struggles against the archbishop, and to demonstrate their support, had cut off the tail of Becket's horse as he passed through the town.", u"The saint's fame quickly spread throughout the Norman world.", u'The first holy image of Becket is thought to be a mosaic icon still visible in Monreale Cathedral, in Sicily, created shortly after his death.', u"Becket's cousins obtained refuge at the Sicilian court during his exile, and King William II of Sicily wed a daughter of Henry II.", u'The principal church of the Sicilian city of Marsala is dedicated to St Thomas Becket.', u"Over forty-five medieval chasse reliquaries decorated in champlev\xe9 enamel showing similar scenes from Becket's life survive, including the Becket Casket, originally constructed to hold relics of the saint at Peterborough Abbey, and now housed in the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.", u'In Scotland, King William the Lion ordered the building of Arbroath Abbey in 1178.', u'On completion in 1197 the new foundation was dedicated to Becket, whom the king had known personally while at the English court as a young man.', u"== Legacy ==\n\nGeoffrey Chaucer's The Canterbury Tales is set in a company of pilgrims on their way from Southwark to the shrine of St Thomas Becket in Canterbury Cathedral.", u"The story of Becket's life became a popular theme for the medieval Nottingham Alabaster carvers.", u'One set of Becket panels is displayed in the Victoria and Albert Museum.', u"In 1884, England's poet laureate Alfred, Lord Tennyson wrote Becket, a play about Thomas Becket and Henry II.", u"Henry Irving produced the play after Tennyson's death, and was celebrated in the title role.", u"Modern works based on the story of Thomas Becket include T. S. Eliot's play Murder in the Cathedral, Jean Anouilh's play Becket (where Becket is no longer a Norman but a Saxon), which was made into a movie with the same title, and Paul Webb's play Four Nights in Knaresborough.", u'Webb has adapted his play for the screen and sold the rights to Harvey and Bob Weinstein.', u"The struggle between Church's and King's power is a theme of Ken Follett's novel The Pillars of the Earth, of which one of the last scenes features the murder of Thomas Becket.", u"Medieval mystery author Jeri Westerson recreated Chaucer's pilgrims and their time in Canterbury, along with murder and the theft of Becket's bones in her fourth novel in the Crispin Guest series Troubled Bones.", u'The Becket Fund for Religious Liberty, a nonprofit, nonpartisan, interfaith, legal and educational institute dedicated to protecting the free expression of all religious traditions, took its inspiration and namesake from Thomas Becket.', u'In a 2006 poll by BBC History magazine for "worst Briton" of the previous millennium, Becket came second behind Jack the Ripper.', u'The poll was dismissed as "daft" in The Guardian, and the result disputed by Anglicans and Catholics.', u'Historians had nominated one person per century, and for the 12th century John Hudson chose Becket for being "greedy", "hypocritical", "founder of gesture politics" and "master of the soundbite".', u'The magazine editor suggested most other nominees were too obscure for voters, as well as saying, "In an era when thumbscrews, racks and burning alive could be passed off as robust law and order\u2014being guilty of \'gesture politics\' might seem something of a minor charge."', u"There are many churches named after Thomas Becket in Great Britain, including St Thomas of Canterbury
